After the movie, 4 people from the audience (from different sections) clapped. It was funny because nobody followed after them. I feel sorry for them ;oP

title: I don't like the way the novel was made into a film.
review:
4 out of 10. Because it was not what was written in the novel. Almost. Its artistic quality is mediocre.

I made a "review" of this film in my LiveJournal blog (just key in "JenShinrai" in any search engine). I've listed seven things that were not right about the movie. It's not about Jesus' relationship, divinity or mortality. My faith is strong and nothing can take it away. It's unshaken. The 'review' was about how the book was made into a film.

The Da Vinci Code was categorized as R-18 in the Philippines. We're the most strict in rating this film. I'd say it is justified.

When I left the theatre house, I have disliked the director or whoever may be responsible of what happened. There were skipped parts or scenes from the novel. And they were important. I wonder what Brown will say about this. His novel's quite "ruined".

title: Why Complain -It's not out yet!
review:
Incredible, amazes me how people can judge a movie that hasn't started playing yet. The movie is based on a book, which is either fiction - according to Ron Howard's disclaimer or true according to Dan Brown's version.

The best thing to do is sit back and wait for the movie to come out and whoever wishes to see it, can do so, other's who nag, complain and put their two cents in, can sit back and keep quiet until they have seen the movie.

So much for optimism.

Get well soon.

title: Great Movie
review:
Excellent! Just like the book.

The parts not in the movie and in the book, if any exist, are irrelevant.

Sometimes, the movie, in the beginning is a little too violent, but it is understandable, since the author/director wanted to make a statement about something (go see the movie! :)

Tom Hanks has done a great part. Furthermore, the "Silas" actor is astonishing.

The plot is amazing as are the actors. This director should do the Harry Potter movies, since in those, one can notice that all the good parts have been taken out!

Recommended!

title: A masterpiece in itself!
review:
Wow! Don't believe the nay-sayers on this one. I have read the book twice and find this movie not only to be faithful and respectful of the book but a tight, taut thriller in its own right. The acting is top notch and you get a real feel that it has been lovingly crafted.

I have often criticised movies for leaving out critical parts of the book, but this is as good as the source material, primarily because the plot is preserved and presented in a way that conveys every nuance in a very effective way.

The one critcism I had of the book was that the ending was sudden and a slight let down. In this movie they surround the final scene with fantastic camera work and stunning music such that it becomes a fitting end to a great movie. As a catholic in the 21st century, I'm stunned that the church can't just accept Da Vinci Code (book and film) as a piece of fiction where some humans - even catholics - can be baddies!! I'm also Australian but that does not make me the killer from Wolf Creek!

title: Good movie version of the book
review: Given that films can rarely do full justice to the book they are based on, my wife and I found this film to be a very good movie representation of the book. The screenplay was largely faithful to the book, as far as a movie allows, particularly with regard to the relevant parts. We enjoyed it and would be happy to see it again. Tom Hanks did not entirely correspond to my idea of Robert Langdon but his performance was very convincing. Audrey Tautou was both beautiful (as usual) and also portrayed a creditable Sophie - a far cry from her character of Amelie. I wasn't entirely convinced by their looks of concern when facing probable imminent death but I've seen worse. Silas was as menacing as in the book, in both his looks and his ghastly rituals. Ian McKellen was a superb Teabing, entirely capturing the character of the book. Altogether a good 150 minutes of entertainment.

title: The Adaptation.
review:
First of all, kudos to the cast and crew of the Da Vinci Code adaptation. The movie is more abridged than I would have it but it is certainly more faithful than Tony Gilroy reconstructing the Jason Bourne story or Steven DeZousa ripping apart Roderick Thorpe's story of Joe Leland for the betterment of the movie we now know as "Die Hard." The opening scene and the last scene are exactly what the mind's eye would see if one would read the book. The last scene even performs beautiful photogrammetry or "omnipresent" phantom camera-work to confirm the innuendos of Dan Brown's finale to the story. What is different? Among many, are the cryptex - I can tell you now if you've read that book that Sauniere in the movie obviously was more merciful than in the film, there was that shocking discovery regarding the cryptex in the airplane that was spared in the movie, the Hieros Jerjerous or whatever it was called was only flashed and not annotated by Langdon and instead of on the airplane, this flashback happens in the end. Let me also commend Howard for creating a beautiful atmosphere of the ages of old when Teabing or Langdon recount their interpretations of history. From the Council of Nicaea, to the execution of the Templars, and even later scene with "scepter-like" super imposition when Langdon explains about "A. Pope" and Sir Isaac Newton while crossing the street. And as one viewer has already noted, Akiva Goldsman was calculating enough to make Langdon and Teabing even debate a bit just so the unorthodox Gnostic ideas aren't necessarily fortified, and as Dan Brown stated in a forum - the audiences are free to believe which of the interpretations in these matters are correct. Langdon even emphasizes the words "MAY have... MAY have..." at one point in opposition to Teabing's strict affirmation regarding the Grail legend. Langdon also cracks the final puzzle instead of it being accidentally unravelled as in the book, the one regarding the missing orb. The five letter word. Missing are a great many things from the book, such as Sister Sandrine per Ron Howard or Akiva Goldsman's hand failing to say the line, "I do not see that one message in Opus Dei." before Silas silences the nun. Omitted also is the sequence when the otherwise maniacal Aringarosa, in the book tells Silas that forgiveness is God's greatest gift, in the end when they discover about the treachery. The reveal of The Teacher is less shocking in the film than it is in the book although I love the tease of cinematic sequence when Remy speaks to the initially anonymous villain. But among those which are made concise by Ron Howard, I appreciate the "instant library card" in the bus a very appreciated short-cut as to eliminate a rather taxing task that Langdon and Sophie had to do in the book.... I do NOT appreciate the fact that Sophie was not the one who deciphered the mystery language in the airplane, the engravings on metal, that Langdon thought was reminiscent of Semitic writing. It was a language, or system of writing that only Sophie knew about from her grandfather... And also, I didn't mind much about the absence of an extended recount of the Fibonnaci sequence, the androgyny theory of the Mona Lisa as these things I'm afraid are gonna require the observer to read Brown's novel. The discovery in the Rosslyn church is also altered much, but as I mentioned earlier it doesn't change the very very very last scene, but the revelations are similar nonetheless. Sophie, and no one else instantly spots the "blade and the chalice fused into one" in the church building which is not the case in the book. Zimmer's score is above par and it accentuates the visuals and nuances that Howard and his crew have put to the screen. And for Christians whether candid or the more religious, I may have sensed an attempt of Akiva Goldsman to put in Dan Brown's conscious thoughts and even his comments on the fact that Da Vinci Code and it's maker isn't one that has the luxury of absolute correctness. Langdon expounds more on his spiritual side, and regarding his childhood mishap at the well, and this tops off his unbiased convictions and makes ground for those who might be otherwise offended by the movie's Gnostic concepts. That scene was a payoff for what was foreshadowed, a question asked by Sophie in response to a question about belief that Langdon brought up earlier in the bank vehicle. By the way, Vernet doesn't get any denouement in the end, in the book he is only referenced but Goldsman probably chose to make him one we merely pass-by. Jean Reno is as intense as he can be as the zealous Fache, and it will also be a loss to NOT see his final exchange with Aringarosa in the book..... he has no resolve with Collet either and the funny alibi Collet makes about the error of the DCPJ on TV in the novel is nowhere in the film. Nonetheless Howard and company create a piece that reflects the bestseller and can hardly be called a sacrilege in light of it's source and author. But because of some writing decisions of Akiva Goldsman that I have disagreed with, I will give this an 8 instead of a 10 out of 10. And P.S..... P.S. Mickey Mouse doesn't get an explanation or an annotation of his presence in an appliance that Langdon owns, obviously to jive with how Goldsman put lesser bias in Langdon's stand of the Grail legend, the book gave Langdon more conviction on the theories and consequently the book chronicled hidden references to the legend in Walt Disney.

Grade B+

title: Da Vinci Code a Deliberate Work of Fiction
review:
Firstly, I would like to say that I am looking very forward to the release of this film. I have read the book and anticipate it making a wonderful movie. That, however, is not why I write.

To the readers of this comment, I would like to say that I am a devout Christian. Bear this in mind when I say that I have no problem whatsoever with this book and/or movie. I view it, as absolutely everyone should, as a work of pure fiction. It is a novel, created from the thoughts of a man whom many people now hate. Many people, including the previous commentator (whom I offer my respectful apologies for this comment), have learned to despise the filmmakers and the author because they feel their faith is threatened. I feel that people can have faith and still be able to realize that the book is not factual. That said, anybody whose faith has been tested by this book should, indeed, not have read it, for they have missed the point of the story entirely: to entertain.

title: Distortion of history
review: Even though this movie is only a fiction it is still trying to tell us about the history events in the way that they did not happen. It's like making a history movie about the World War 2 where Jews were trying to take over the world and that they were putting Germans in to the concentration camps or making a history movie where black people were coming over from Africa to America and were enslaving white people. In both of those instances we know it is not true, but two thousand years from now people could believe that. So just because the storyline is interesting and acting was superb, I would not waste my time watching a distorted history movie, instead I would love to watch any movie which accurately portrays history events.

title: Badly presented blasphemy
review: I must say that I have read the book, before I saw the picture which I don't recommend because I was absolutely disappointed. Historically the whole story is the biggest lie ever presented and I just can't understand why some people chose to offend the name of Christ, The Son of God, and with It the foundations of all Christianity. I mean why? What wrong did Christ do to them? I really disaprove the idea of one religion assaulting the other and I find that this is the surest way of creating disorder. This is the only benefit of this movie...disorder and blasphemy. On the other hand the movie as a movie was surely not what I would expect. The whole plot seems to drag itself, the actors are not leading the film but are lead by it and from a point on the only thing you wish is for the movie to end! Before I saw this monstrosity I believed Tom Hanks to be the greatest actor of our times, especially after Forest Gump, but in this film his appearance tumbles to a mere presence. It will certainly take him a long time to restore his fame. Why Tom? Why producers? Why?

title: Reviews were the letdown, movie was excellent!
review: I was at the Louvre this summer when they were filming this movie and it made me interested in it. Not enough to read the book or see the movie but still interested. Then I saw the trailers for it on TV and became excited for the day it came out. I love movies with clues and suspense. My mom and I went on opening night to see it and after seeing the movie, it makes me want to read the book! I'm not Catholic but I'm still a very religious person. I think that everyone who's even just a little religious should come see this movie, and when they do, they need to remember that it's fiction. That's what all the controversy is about. As long as people do that, they will really enjoy this movie, just as I have.

title: Forget the critics, watch the movie and judge for yourself!
review:
Coming into the film, I knew there would be many moments where the term "suspension of disbelief" would come into hand. Although I must admit I never got through reading the entire book (mostly because of my intense life style that leaves me with minimal free time), I knew the basic plot line, including the big secret that the Da Vinci code protects. What I didn't know was the sheer magnitude of writer Dan Brown's conspiracy theory, which crosses time and land and provokes an intriguing discussion about the authenticity of the foundations on which our religions stand. Sure, many of the "facts" that are claimed throughout the film are not necessarily true, but the slight possibility that it is plausible is what makes it even more entertaining and interesting to view.

For those of you who don't know what the film is about (are there any?), Da Vinci Code tells the story of the mysterious murder of a curator in the famous Louvre museum in current day France. World acclaimed Harvard Symbolistic, Robert Langdon (two time Academy Award winner Tom Hanks), is called in by the local police to help investigate the case, using his academic skills to connect the clues left in the murder scene in order to find out why the curator was killed. From there on, starts an intense chase throughout Europe which goal is to untangle the startling truth behind the murder and unleash a secret kept for centuries. Joining Langdon is French cryptologist, Sophie Neveu (French actress Audrey Tautou from 'Amelie' fame), which helps Langdon escape evil forces who are after him, whilst struggling to uncover the religious secret that lies beneath what may well be "the biggest cover-up in human history".

I won't say anything further about the plot since I don't want to spoil the fun for any of you, but I can say this  the movie is very loyal to the novel, both in premise as in spirit, which is a rarity these days. For those of you who read the book, I can promise you will not be disappointed. However, for those who didn't, beware: some of the revelations are quite talky and less intense than your usual Hollywood fare, so I can see how many viewers may loose their patience from time to time. Alas, there are still some very suspenseful scenes throughout the flick, and if you can forgive a cinematography that is less than perfect (despite the beautiful scenery the plot has to offer, the camera work was anything but inspirational); you will thoroughly enjoy Da Vinci Code. Concentrate on the ideas the movie brings to life, on the fine acting by supporting actors Paul Bettany ('A Beautiful Mind', 'Dogville') and Sir Ian McKellen ('Lord of the Rings' trilogy, 'X-Men' trilogy), on the predictable-yet-enjoyable twists and turns the story has to offer  and believe you me, you will be having a good time.

Honestly, I didn't expect for anything else than the aforementioned details, so believe me when I say I'm having a hard time understanding what the critics were so upset about. For me, this is a classic example of the everlasting dissonance between viewers and critics worldwide.

I give Da Vinci Code a very satisfying 9 out of 10!

title: Dan Brown Has Got To Be Thrilled
review: I don't read a lot of books, I'm a movie fan, but I read the book in two nights...couldn't put it down. Was like a kid waiting for Santa Claus when I heard that Ron Howard was gonna turn it into a movie. Well today was Christmas ! I just saw the film with my wife ( who has not yet read the book ) and we both thought it was wonderful. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou work well together and their acting is flawless. But Ron Howard is the real star of the show. The film holds remarkably true to Brown's masterpiece and communicates the story extremely well. The scenes in the Louvre and around Paris are amazing. I absolutely loved it...I think you will too !

title: Not very good
review: Kind of boring. With bad acting all around. Tom Hanks can act, but the material is not translated well from the literary world to the celluloid world. And his haircut looks just dumb.

title: Each breath you take is a sin. No shadow will be safe again, for you will be hunted by angels.
review:
The Da Vinci Code is directed by Ron Howard and adapted to screenplay by Akiva Goldsman from the novel of the same name written by Dan Brown. It stars Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou, Ian McKellen, Paul Bettany, Jean Reno, Alfred Molina and Jürgen Prochnow. Music is scored by Hans Zimmer and cinematography by Salvatore Totino.

When a man is murdered inside the Louvre, his body is found to be surrounded by cryptic messages. The police call in American symbology expert Robert Langdon (Hanks) to decode the clues. When he is joined by Parisian cryptologist Sophie Neveu (Tautou), it quickly becomes apparent that nothing is as it first seems and a mystery begins to unravel that could shake Christianity to its very core.

Extended Cut (Blu-ray) Version Viewed.

I haven't read the book! And I love treasure hunt/clue chasing movies! So I came to Ron Howard's hugely successful film (over $600 million in worldwide profit) bereft of literary pressure and with only a modicum of genre expectation. Perhaps this is why I'm apparently only in a small percentage of film lovers who really enjoyed the film? In spite of those gargantuan financial figures.

Ultimately it's very safe film making, with a director and cast guaranteeing professionalism, but it weaves a magical mystery tour full of cryptic clues, secret organisations and cover ups. Yes, there is a good deal of corn thrown in as well, which inevitably stops the adaptation from being hyper intelligent. There's also an understanding on my part as to why many feel it's just too talky, but was the film ever going to be unfurled as an action movie blockbuster for the popcorn munching crowd, like National Treasure et al?

It is a clever conspiracy thriller full of twists and turns with a outlandish revelation at the finale. It's also very appropriately performed by the cast (serio brooding and fret), and when McKellen joins the fray after an hour of film it has a little class as well, while Zimmer's score is a majestic blending of choir, strings and synths. I maintain that the film didn't deserve the critical whacking it got, but again I say I had a blank canvas going in for my first viewing.

I wasn't sold to it because of controversy or had a saliva tinged mouth having worshipped at the altar of Dan Brown, I expected exactly what I got. A flawed but ever so intriguing adult mystery thriller, and not even Hanks' hair stopped me having a great time with the movie. 7/10

title: Not as good as it should have been
review:
I'm sure everyone remembers the controversy that this film caused during it's release. By the hype this film was receiving, everyone was sure that they were going to experience something big. Truth is though, this film is nothing more than a flat, mundane piece of cinema. The problem is the lack of any real mystery in the film. You don't really get involved with the film or the characters and by the time the climax of the film comes along, I didn't really care.

Unlike the film National Treasure, which had similar flaws. This film takes itself too seriously and could have at least tried to be fun. I'd recommend reading the Dan Brown book, which is a good adventure novel. But the less said about this film, the better. It is watchable at best.

title: Hollywood Hokum at its Worst
review:
The film gets dafter and dafter as it grinds on. The revelation that the French female protagonist is really a descendant of The Virgin Mary beggars belief. Tom Hanks tries unsuccessfully to look as if he has been pole-axed by the discovery but all he manages is a wistful, half-fruity look as if wrestling between falling at her feet or going straight for the beaver.

Now this is the point, if any, to wheel on a few extras - preferably children of tender age and shepherds (the Church's stock witnesses of miracles and revelations). Instead, a small tweedy bunch of elderly French men and women crinkle their brows and shoot puzzled looks as they behold the scene from about fifty yards away. The viewer might be forgiven for thinking these old crocks are Alzheimer patients lost on an outing to the country but - believe it or not - they are none other than the guardians of the secret. Their chances against the likes of the strapping young albino monk-cum-serial assassin in the film are slender to say the least. The "surrogate Mary" might do well to take a leaf out of the Pope's book - a bullet-proof limo and a small army of Swiss mercenaries to keep violent death at bay. The bad news is that the cast are likely to live long enough to spawn a sequel.

title: The Best Advertisement For Atheism.
review:
I'm feeling generous - Christian, if you like - so I've given it 5 stars.

Though quite where I'm awarding them is unclear even to me. This has to be one of the ditchiest-dull movies of all time. It's like a Tolkein epic but without the special effects, the battles and the monsters.

Tom Hanks, his face stricken and artificially-aged by a permanent frown, escorts some sort of femme-fatale through all of the gloomiest set-pieces ever dreamt-up by Hollywood. A curious albino bloke with a penchant for self-flagellation - who might well have escaped from a Tolkein set - pops-up from time to time to commit sundry acts of murder. Various other characters come and go. Jurgen Prochnow trades his U-boat for a truck, Ian McKellern lends a bit more middle-earth de-ja-vu, and Jean Reno attempts to obscure the other actors with his nose.

This is the ultimate religious conspiracy theorists movie. A deep, dark secret is being held by a furtive organisation. It's the biblical equivalent of 'Hanger 13'. What is this secret? Does anyone stay awake long enough to find out? Someone with more resilience than myself told me that - apparently - this femme-fatale is a direct descendant of Christ. Like; the crucified one had a bit on the side with Mary Magdalen. Is that it? Is that the great big bete-noir of history? Gosh; stop the press.

After 2000 years of generations, lets say - about 100; how much of Christ's genetic constitution is she likely to speak for now? Somebody knows a lot more about 'mystery' than they do about genetics.

This is slow, dark, and oh-so-talky. Despite the fact that the lead characters seem to run everywhere. It's a religious storm-in a tea-cup, much ado about nothing, clerical codswallop. Neither does it help that I'm no particular fan of Tom Hanks.

Conspiracy theorists and religious freaks will no-doubt nod sagely at its gloomy foreboding passage. Whereas those of us who live in the rational world can see it for the pretentious tripe that it is.

For some, it's as if The Enlightenment never happened.

title: Decent Movie, But Not Worthy Of The Controversy It Spawned
review:
Give credit to Dan Brown (author of the novel on which this movie is based) on a number of counts. First, he did good research into the non-canonical gospels (especially, since they were referenced in the film, to those of Philip and Mary Magdalene). Second, he showed his skill as a novelist by weaving a creative tale around the question of why they're non-canonical, combining the presence of secret societies (Opus Dei and the Knights Templar) along with a hardly unique interpretation of Da Vinci's painting "The Last Supper" to produce a novel which obviously caught the public's attention. Then, he showed his skills as a businessman by selling the novel to Hollywood, which ended up putting out this mildly suspenseful, largely well acted and mostly entertaining action/suspense/conspiracy theory movie.

Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon (a professor of Religious Symbology - of which there is no such beast!) and Audrey Tautou as Sophie are both quite good and worth watching. The story revolves around the search for the Holy Grail (but Monty Python this ain't!). In this case, the Holy Grail is Mary Magdalene's tomb, and the conspiracy revolves around the efforts of the Roman Catholic Church to suppress the truth about Jesus being merely human rather than divine - a figure who, according to the movie, was married to Mary Magdalene and had children with her. Thus, there is also the question of who Jesus' descendants in today's world are. It stirred too much controversy in my view. It certainly has an anti-Catholic tone to it, I admit. The Catholic Church is dismissed as oppressive and misogynistic, involved in murder to keep its secret (and therefore its power). Still, the extreme reaction of the Catholic Church (and some fundamentalist Protestant sects) probably gave more credibility to the movie than it deserved. As a Protestant pastor, I found nothing here that would shake my faith, and the movie never quite goes to the extreme of saying that the story was true. As Langdon says, "what's really important is what you believe." In other words, whatever your faith is - it's a matter of faith! (And remember - this movie is based on a novel, not a history text book. It's a piece of entertainment!)

Personally I thought the movie a bit too long. The ending, revolving around Langdon actually finding Magdalene's tomb, wasn't really necessary (except, I suppose, to be faithful to the novel) and the revelation of Sophie's identity was anti-climactic. I figured it would turn out that way. (Another nod to Brown's obvious acquaintance with the state of contemporary religion is his choice of the name "Sophie" for the female protagonist - an obvious nod to the "sophia" movement in modern feminist Christianity.) It's also yet another example of the "religion is the cause of all the evil in the world" mentality that is so yawningly cliché in today's society. Overall it's pretty good, although not really deserving of the controversy it spawned, which probably lent it more credence than it should have had. (The secular world would say "if the church is so against it, it must be true.") I'd give it a 6/10

title: most underrated movie of all time perhaps
review: How dare people say this movie is bad. You are wrong! I am sorry there is no other way to put it. I do not know what was wrong with this movie. Everything was done extraordinarily well. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou were perfectly cast as Robert Langdon and Sophie Neveu. Jean Reno was good at being what he always is. A cop. Ian McKellen was probably the best as Sir Leigh Teabing and Paul Bettany did a decent job as Silas as well as Alfred Molina who played Bishop Aringarosa. The score was superb and dare i say should have got an Oscar nomination perhaps even should have won! Ron Howard's directing and the camera work are exceptional. I was surprised to find this got second most disappointing adaption from a book to a movie. (first being golden compass) This is unfair. Everything in the book was in the movie except for a few minor details. Nothing huge. I thing everyone did very well and i do not understand what was wrong with the script. It worked fine. It was not outstanding but it was definitely not something to criticize. Do not let anyone else stop you from seeing this movie. :)

title: Limp literary adaptation
review:
Book-to-screen adaptations have proved themselves as tricky creatures. Peter Jackson set a new standard with his Lord of the Rings trilogy, but his success remains one of very few. The Da Vinci Code therefore presents itself as a prime example of literature limping lethargically onto the big screen.

Most frustrating is that the concept is a genuinely intriguing one. Blending a re-interpretation of biblical legend with mad monks, murder and a virtual beehive of conspiracies, Da Vinci sets itself up as a mature, contemplative project with Big Ideas. Howard's moody photography establishes a suitably ominous tone, including some inventive CGI that merges landscape from medieval times with that of the present, but Goldman's clunky script seems responsible for most of the damage.

Following its source material with an uninspired paint-by-numbers precision, Brown's book is treated with a religious reverence that would no doubt do Ian McKellen's character proud. As a viewing experience, however, it proves dull and vacant, failing to stir the emotional response that one would expect from such controversial subject matter. Adding insult to injury, the most interesting aspect of the premise  that of deciphering clues within works of art  is horribly skewed, never allowing the audience to participate in and decipher the mysteries alongside the characters.

In the end, Da Vinci is over-long and over-confident, talking itself to death. In a film about faith and its emotional bearing on the world, it is a sad irony that The Da Vinci Code leaves its audience cold and unmoved.

title: This is why you shouldn't ever read the book.
review: I loved this movie. And there is one reason why I am more often than not satisfied with a movie that was turned from a book into a movie. The answer is.....I don't read books. I'm a movie lover, not a book lover. So when I watch a movie that was a book first, and hear everyone saying "It wasn't as good as the book." (as they always do) I am the only one not disappointed. Morons who read a book, and expect the movie to be as good, are going to ALWAYS be disappointed. It is rare that a movie is ever as good as the book. I will say though, that if this movie didn't have the exact ending that it did, than I probably wouldn't have liked it as much. I would have still liked it, but just not as much. That ending scene is one of my biggest goosebumps experiences i have ever had during a movie. Sorry if that sounds gay. :-) I think Ron Howard did a great job with turning such a HUGELY popular book, into a movie. The expectations were so big, so i understand how some were let down. Anytime you have such huge expectations for a movie, it's never as good as you want it to be. Just some advice to those who have read the book, but haven't seen the movie yet.....Treat it like a movie, not a book.

title: Interesting!
review: Based on the best-selling novel, "The DaVinci Code" is a highly questionable thriller that made some headlines, yet, to me it's a very watchable movie. Tom Hanks did a spectacular job playing his role as Dr. Langdon. He may have his opinions, yet he has his views on life were right on the dot. Sir Ian McKellan is superb as Sir Leah Teabing. I liked his character in the movie. But I was disappointed he turned out to be a shady character. The clues, the graphic scenes, and the action in the movie made it very interesting to watch. The main thing of that movie is the puzzle. That piece of the puzzle was the real deal to that movie. I don't have any objection to the movie or the book. I just want to see things for myself. Avoid all the controversy, and the media hype, "The DaVinci Code" puts the "I" in intrigue. 4.5 out of 5 stars!

title: Even as a movie, its bad
review:
I watched this movie out of curiosity and through Netflix, just so I would spend as little money on it as possible. Although I completely detest the subject matter, it did so-so at the box office and with the talent involved (Howard/Hanks) I decided to watch it anyway, viewing it strictly as a movie to see how Howard/Hanks handled the material.

Simply put, this movie does not work. It plays more like a school play, with deadpan acting and so much information being flayed at you that there's no time do develop the characters. The only emotion in the film comes in the very last scenes, when Hanks actually put some meaning in his words.

Also blaring were huge plot holes that distract the viewer from what's going on. As these have been so belabored in other reviews, I shan't enumerate them here - suffice to say that it would appear to me that this was not a labor of love, as are so many of Howard's movies, but more of a cash vehicle off the source material. It does not have the polish and fineness that Howard puts on his other work, and Hanks' phoned-in performance is a pure waste of talent.

If Howard had been given the time and incentive to do more with the material, we actually could have had something special here. As it is, look for it in the Wal-Mart discount bin very soon.

title: good show
review: The DaVinci Code is another wonderful Howard movie with a superb cast and excellent screenplay. The chemistry between the actors makes the film a true epic of emotional platitudes. Everything about the film is technically of classic magnitude. The film is about the idea that there is a bloodline of Christ through Mary Magdalene as Jesus wife who has been protected by a secret order of the Templar's and attacked by the patriarchal traditional church through the Opus Dei sect of self mutilators. If you can get past the not so obvious heresy in the whole idea, it is an interesting movie filled with proof of concept and very likely a good amount of embellishment. Still, there is nothing wrong with calling this film a must see. I understand the Christian fundamentalists gave Dan Brown death threats just like the Muslims and Rushdie.

title: Certainly not as bad as everyone makes you believe it is but also too long and it tries to tell way too much to consider this a great movie.
review:
Perhaps the most anticipated and talked about movie of 2006, by both positive and bashing negative parties (mostly from religious persons). Controversy had always surrounded this movie and the book it was based on. It's such a shame that some people just can't separate fact from fiction and just take the movie for what it is; good intelligent entertainment. Judging by its style and directing this movie was clearly not made to shock or offend but to purely entertain.

And for the unbiased open minded person this is surely an entertaining movie to watch. It was not as slow or boring is I had heard and expected. The movie is definitely fast paced and features lots of thrilling moments.

The movie its story had definitely enough potential to make this one of the best movies of 2006 but yet it isn't. The story tries to tell too much and often goes to deep into certain aspects which certainly doesn't help to make this movie the most pleasant or easiest one to watch. The story also takes lot for granted and goes to deep with its theories which isn't always good for the realism of the movie. It overall also makes the movie too long which makes it hard to keep interest for its entire duration.

The movie has a good style and quick pace, with some good editing and moody camera-work and a great perfectly suiting Hans Zimmer soundtrack. The directing is also good when for most part but yet you can tell that thriller/mystery just isn't Ron Howard's genre. The movie doesn't always flow well enough. My advice to him would be to just stick to drama's and comedies, were his true talent lies. Guess Howard really wasn't the right guy for this job.

Lots of fine actors are also wasted in the movie. The movie lies its emphasis on the story and therefor too often forgets about its character that become at times a secondary element in the movie. The movie does really lack a solid main character. It's not that Tom Hanks is of course an horrible actor and it's not like he's miscast in the movie, like most people say he is, his character just isn't always likable or understandable enough. Ian McKellen's role is too limited, as he is introduced too late into the movie. So is Jürgen Prochnow in a very small role and Alfred Molina, who's character had way more potential than was eventually used.

Yet the movie remains a perfectly watchable one that is also more entertaining than you'll perhaps would expect. The movie features more than enough interesting and mysterious elements to keep you interest in the story until the end. The story features lots of imaginative and fascinating elements, the book by Dan Brown on which this movie is based is not a world wide success for no reason. Too bad that in the end the movie does not live up to the book it's success or brilliance and it doesn't quite meet expectations.

It's some good intelligent entertainment but it's just not one of those movies people will still talk about in 10 years from now, I would reckon.

7/10

http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

title: Nah
review:
I watched movie in the plane and i must admit that I'm really disappointed. I mean book is great and the movie has good actors, but still its boring..

I mean, have you watched Forest Gump?

Hey Tom Hanks can do much better then stupid Langdon role..

I think that movie has ruined the book.. Totally.

But thats what happens if you have such a great book - its usually much better then a movie.. Specially because this one has really bad lighting and when you turn it on you already get bored..

So Book is so much better Movie sucks

title: Great
review:
This movie starts fell very crazy and will have you interested the whole movie.

Tom Hanks is very good in this movie and though there is not that much action in this movie I was entertained the whole movie.

Paul Bettany is amazing in this movie and is so good it hurts.

Many people said this movie but questions the catholic church but that is not the case. This movie makes you think but does not tell you what to believe and what is right about the catholic world. This movie makes you think and is great.

Go see this movie you will not be disappointed

title: Well Done all the way through..........
review:
First of all, I would like to say I am one of a very few people who have not read the book.

I went to see the film recently on a weekend afternoon with my wife who absolutely loved the book and was dying with anticipation to see this film. Not to mention the fact she has an art degree.

I was aware of the negative criticism about the film before I saw it but I wasn't going to let that bias my opinion.

I thought the film was well done and that the film makers gave out enough information without giving us a history lesson. There were a few moments during the film when it seemed the film dragged just a bit, but picked up again as the police narrowed in on Sophie and Langdon.

I was very pleased with this film and would recommend it to anyone willing to be open minded.

In closing I would just like to say.....If you are intent on looking for the bad in something, that's all you're gonna find. I think a lot of people had already prejudged this film and nothing was going to change their mind.

title: I Thought It was Good
review: OK I'm 15 Years Old. I Never Read The Book Before The Movie. I Loved The Movie. i Don't Care What Any Religious Person Says "Oh i Hate That movie So Much" Well You Need To Keep It To Yourself Because If your So Stuck On Your Faith Chances Are You Haven't Seen The Movie So WHo Are YOu To GIve An Opinion On It? But The Movie Was Awesome Love The Acton Loved The Clues One Right After Another. I Think They Could Picked A Better Female LEad ROle Because She Kinda Bring The Movie Down A Little But TOm Hanks Was Amazing. I Loved The Character Silias.The Only Bad Thing I Thought About THe Movie Was 1.The female Lead Role(*Bad Dialouge*) And 2.I Think They Stretched The Ending Out To Long.But Hey It Was Good.Movie Was Excellent 10/10

title: Movie beautifully captures book in tone and story
review:
Great movie, lots of action, gorgeous sets in some very interesting locales. Thought provoking, tender. Yeah, it's a bit talky but that's called "dialogue". (It used to be in movies before "Terminator").

Concepts were presented in a way which made them very understandable. I disagree with folks who claim Mr. Hanks was wooden(apologies to Toy Story). I thought he developed his character to a high degree and played him truthfully throughout. The character Langdon is a Harvard professor folks...and Hanks is a great actor in an important role.

To the critics who say there is no chemistry between Sophie and Langdon in the film?...um this isn't a love story. If anything, he is her protector and she is the metaphorical "wisdom". Think of him almost like a modern Galahad, the knight who seeks then protects the grail. Galahad was chaste/pure thus deserving to find the grail in Arthurian legend. Having a love affair between them would have weakened the story, even though ironically the story is "about" a love affair. I thought there was plenty of chemistry between the two leads albeit nonsexual.

The direction was another feather in Ron Howards cap. He took a very cerebral and controversial novel and made it very watchable while remaining true to the novel. One of the best adaptations I can think of. I have often felt Dan Brown has mastered the elusive art of edutainment, where he presents information wrapped around an interesting story line so, as you enjoy the twists and turns of a mystery yarn, you don't notice that you're learning something. Howard understands this and does a great job as well. Opening to 225 Million dollars worldwide??? 77 Million dollars US??? Not too shabby!!

Great Photography!!! Great locations even if there were some stand-ins. I thought the flashback historical scenes were illuminating and beautifully realized, not cheesy as some critics have posited.

My thinking is the people who are trashing the film are doing so out of allegiance to a particular religious dogma. And that's fine, they have their opinion. (I guess the idea of a "divinity" having sex and a child while in human form would upset the rank and file especially since the taboo against sex ironically seems to have been a staple of the religion.(Thankfully every generation has caved or their'd be no one left to view the film.) To be fair, Mr. Howard presents opposing thematic views, having Langdon frequently debate Teabing albeit without much fervor, but the film is not meant to be a spirited fair debate, it is an adaptation of a novel after all, thus the final question of the film needs be... does it do justice to the book? I believe it does with exceptional grace, sensitivity, emotion and understanding. The problems I had with the movie were the problems I had with the book. The ending drags on a little long but the final scene is such a beautiful moment it is well worth that indulgence. Teabing's motivations are still the real mystery to me but Brown likes to seed his bad-guys as the ones you'd least expect, for the surprise factor I assume. To the critics who judge the movie not on it's merits but on it's subject, remember it is the villain who makes most of the "heretical" claims/points.

I don't think the film will alter anyone's faith or start a new religion as perhaps the book may, but I don't think asking questions and seeking answers, even if they are as elusive as the grail itself, should ever be shamed out of the seeker of truth, the reader of fiction or the summer popcorn-eating blockbuster movie patron. Thumbs up, way up!!!!

title: It's disappointing for the book fan! BUT still cool...
review: Hmmm... i've read the book, and to tell the truth, if u compare both movie & novel. U'll realize the book gave u more satisfaction. There's a huge piece of "not-so-important but juicy" detail missing, like the origin of MONA LISA, the DIVINE PROPORTION...the list goes on. The presentation is not quite...sophisticating, remember that car chasing scene? The cute little smart car on the road, but with the pace and the speed, Oh man... makes me drowsy! And the background of Silas wasn't clearly presented. But with such powerful story as the backbone, the film is great. Who cares if Jesus is or not a god, FAITH is what we need. He loves us and we love him, no matter what!

title: Don't believe the critics
review:
After completing the book, 'The Da Vinci Code', I couldn't wait to witness the movie. The book has a great storyline and the movie came with Ron Howard, Tom Hanks and Sir Ian MccKellan. What more Could you ask for? However, after the critics had all seen it, it made me wonder. I couldn't find a review to support the film. Most reviews made the film seem awful, and shouldn't be watched.

However, after watching the film, i can safely say the critics got it wrong. Granted it's no phenomenon the book was, but Ron Howard delivers a thoughtful film that stays faithful to the book. Sure some people will laugh at the climax when Tom Hanks says 'I have to get to a library fast!', but the film is overall very successful. One major factor in the films success is the performance by Paul Bettany as Silas. He delivers an awesome performance.

So don't believe what the critics say, the Da Vinci Code is a winner.

title: The critics are full of it.
review: I read a few of the reviews on web sites such as meta-critic and rottentomatoes before I went to see the film. Although this movie was universally scorned I still went and was really quite disgusted by the inaccurate picture that they painted. Ron Howard, with all of his skill and experience in this industry just does not make bad movies anymore (if he ever did). I feel that the critic's reactions were directed toward 1) the hype and 2) the controversial religious subject matter. They simply were not able to remain impartial and judge this movie based on its true merits. Its actually quite good, having an excellent story (one of the best adaptations of a book in recent memory) and great performances from the cast. Early comments such as the reaction at Cannes where people were laughing at serious scenes have me baffled. I saw this movie in a packed theater and certainly no one laughed, except when it was intended. I don't have any idea what scene this could have even been? I certainly doubt that the film was re-edited one week before release.

title: The Davinci Cod
review: Yep I spelt it right, this is a stinker. It's a shame because, although I haven't read the book, I like Tom Hanks, Sir Ian Mckellen and being a red blooded male I love Audrey Tautou. The main problem with this film is it is so flat. Tom plays well it seems he's playing himself its how I imagine he would be when not acting. Ian is way over camp, more so than usual and Audrey is just bad accented eye candy. I don't think it's anyone's fault, it probably works as a book, but with no set pieces or major dramatic elements it just ends up being pompous, drawn out and ultimately boring. The story if you don't know it is basically about a series of codes hidden in various things that tell the whereabouts of the holy grail which is said to be not a big gold cup but a direct descendant of Christ thus making him mortal and not the son of god and so throwing out any form of religion that anyone knows. Pretty big stuff if true, enter people who want that truth exposed and those that don't, murder, mystery and anagrams come thick and fast or should I say thin and slow? Along the way we meet mad monks, corrupt cops and dodgy bank managers (hold on I'm making it sound interesting here!) when all is said and done 40 million people brought the book, and just like the first few ropey Harry potters, it has a guaranteed audience. I think the saddest thing is that audiences don't seem bothered anymore about the quality, this film was the second biggest opening weekend after Star Wars: Revenge of the sh*t, so its weird that a film that has had below average reviews can still pack out cinemas and break records. Whether it was the draw of the story, the stars or the controversy surrounding its blasphemous suggestions (get over it guys it's a work of fiction) something is pulling in the people and I for one can't work out what it is. This film is a perfect example of a great idea executed badly by people who should know better. Unless you're a massive fan I'd give it a miss.

title: Forget the controversy, this is a cinematic clunker
review:
The 'Da Vinci Code' is not a very good film. Ignoring the debate about the relative merits of Dan Brown's plot on an historical basis and taking it simply as a plot, it's a potboiler, but a pretty good one. But adding Ron Howard and Tom Hanks to the mix is like putting lead boots on Justin Gatlin - it just drains it of all it's energy and removes any power it had to excite.

This reviewer has always found Hanks particularly off-putting as a leading man - 'Philadelphia' being his nadir - and this film does nothing to redeem him in my eyes. His appalling mullet at least made me chuckle, though his continual odd lip contortions seemed to display an inner doubt as to what, exactly, his character felt or believed. Thanks for that must, I'm sure, go to Ron Howard.

Poor Audrey Tautou. A wonderful actress here handed some of the worst dialogue since 'Star Wars'. For her straight face alone she deserves an Oscar nomination. Compare and contrast her here and in the marvellous (no, not that one) 'He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not', which is a minor masterpiece and allows her to show some real talent, unlike this pudding of a film.

Paul Bettany does his best with possibly one of the least promising characters ever to hit our screens: an albino Hit Monk. He is a good actor and does his best. Sir Ian McKellern does another jolly turn as Sir Leigh Teabing. He has a glint in his eyes throughout that shows he decided to play it as 'Carry On Holy Grail' and he clearly had a wonderful time chewing on the scenery. He was marvellous and the only one of this ensemble to unshackle themselves from the po-faced reverence Howard seemed to expect for this clunker of a screenplay. Even the normally excellent Alfred Molina succumbed.

*** Mini-spoiler ** So: implausible, unbelievable and unintentionally hilarious - I mean, did you see the state of some of the acrylic jumpers on the bunch of Priory of Sion at the end? I'm sure Sophie felt very protected when they appeared - and that is without recourse to a debate about the validity of Brown's plot as an historical argument. A clunker from start to finish that, joyously, reaches that tipping point that takes it from merely bad to so bad it is almost an instant cult classic. The Razzies must be in the bag already.

A shame for Tautou, Bettany, Molina and McKellern who deserve better. Par for the course for Hanks and Howard. 2/10 - for the unintentionally funny bits and for the luminous beauty of Ms Tautou.

title: "I felt stupider after the movie than I did when I came in"
review:
The above summary was overheard in the theater as I was exiting THE DA VINCI CODE. I feel sympathy for those who have not read the book as there is a lot to digest from the dialogue. I felt totally engaged with this film from beginning to end...and I read the book. I needed a greater sense of urgency from Tom Hank's performance.

I have appreciated Tom Hank's acting skills in many of his previous roles. This great cast, especially McKellen, Reno, Tautou and Bettany (in that order) ended up upstaging Hank's in most of the scenes. Still this did not ruin the film for me...just a slight distraction. Do yourself a favor and read the book prior to seeing this fine film. You'll be glad you did! 8 out of 10.

title: Movie is very good
review: After reading many mixed reviews about this movie I just want to say that I thought it was very good. Tom Hanks did well as Robert Langdon and the movie moved along well. The chemistry between Hanks and Sophie was fine, I did not feel that they did not flow together as some people have commented. Silas and Teibing characters were great.The movie did have a lot of dialogue as many have reviewed as a boring part of the movie, but it needed it to explain a lot of details.Ron Howard did a fine job, it couldn't have been done any better. Some parts from the book were not in the movie and some changed slightly, but all in all ...a very good movie. Go see it and enjoy...

title: Take it for what it is...and you'll want to see it again
review:
First off, I must start by saying that before I saw this movie, I made the mistake of going to rottentomatoes and reading some reviews...I really didn't understand why this movie could be as bad as the critics said...

Let me tell you, the critics were way off!! The DaVinci code is hands down one of the best films of the year and despite its 150 mins runtime, there is not a dull moment in the entire movie and keeps you guessing until the very end.

I have not read the book, so had nothing to compare it to, but as a stand alone movie it does very well entertaining the audience and would definitely make a top 10 list of mine for the genre no questions asked.

As far as performances go, Tom Hanks is excellent and fits the role well as Robert Langdon. I can not think of anyone else that could capture this role as he has. Audrey Tautou, Ian McKellen, Jean Reno, and Paul Bettany all are excellent in their respective roles.

Of note about the movie are the breathtaking locals and Hans Zimmer's background score which truly captures the essence of The DaVinci Code.

Walking out of the movie I was truly disappointed by the critics that bashed this movie as there was not much to bash about it. However, in the theme of the movie itself, I guess I must entitle them the freedom to say what they want.....a must see!!! 10/10

title: A fun flick--I don't get the critical drubbing
review:
Yes, I read the book. And I enjoyed the film as much if not more. The movie dispenses with lots of unnecessary rambling and gets right to the action. Some have questioned why Langdon has become more of a skeptic of Teabing's theories, but it truly helps to balance out Dan Brown's story where everyone agrees on the same radical beliefs. It's not as much of a turn-off-your-brain action movie as National Treasure, but it's more satisfying. The art direction is superb and I had no problems with the acting. My only real problems came from the pedestrian dialogue. I know they were trying to stay true to a dumbly written book, but they could have spiced it up a bit and avoided a lot of the cheesiness.

If more critics were concerned with objectively looking at movies rather than selling a pithy blurb, this movie would be getting better ratings.

title: ignore the critics again
review: Faith or no faith, it is a very good book and movie. tom hanks was good as just a regular guy caught up in something he never expected. The story follows the book perfectly, which is both good and bad. The whole movie the protagonists appear confused, as they were in the book. i would like to have seen a bit more over-acting to embellish the points. At any rate, see the movie if you read the book. And if you haven't read the book, congratulations- you are a moron. Jeez, I need 10 lines of text just to post a commentary!! What if I am a concise person, and I said what needs to be said in 5 lines? I have to keep typing, and so I shall. Any poo- go see the dang movie already. If you are actually still reading, you will see the movie.

title: A good run after a good read
review: I think this film version of Dan Brown's NOVEL was better than I had been hearing about but not as good as I expected after all the hoopla around it. It's still a wild ride and provocative story with some interesting film-making techniques, and some not so great editing. In some ways it is better than the book, such as at specific parts portrayed at the ending, but so much explanatory stuff is left out, I really think one has to read the book first to "get" much of what happens in the film. While not any masterpiece, the novel was a good read, so that's not a waste of time. However, if one wants the real meat of the controversy, I think reading Holy Blood, Holy Grail and The Templar Revelation, or The Holy Place, are some of the best places to start. By the end of the film I was enchanted with Audrey Tatou, who for the most part was wasted in what is supposed to be a pivotal role. I love Tom Hanks, but thought he looked uncomfortable much of the time in his role. Ian McKellen is flat-out brilliant as Teabing. I found the film for the most part, like the novel, sort of "Holy Blood, Holy Grail Lite," but still an inspiration for continued spiritual seeking and searching and strengthening of belief in God, not one iota of blasphemy toward God of any sort. Then again, it still makes me question the power and validity of institutional church propaganda no matter what. The film is worth seeing, but certainly not worth boycotting.

title: Never seen such a strong unjustified media campaign against a movie
review: Never seen such a strong unjustified media campaign against a movie. We went to see this film yesterday despite the fact that every single review said the movie was dull, lacked spark, was poorly made, etc, etc. To our surprise, Tom Hank's hair wasn't distracting, and we were pleaseantly entertained and amused by the whole thing. The British actors steal the show, no doubt, and we have seen Tom hanks do better. But the movie delivered the goods solidly. The only weak link in the movie is the otherwise amazing Audrey Tautou. We have seen the french actress devour the screen in Amelie, Dirty Pretty Things and a few others. She is an accomplished actress, no doubt. In this movie, she was acting in some scenes, in others, i think the director told her she wasn't going to be in the scene and she was flat,amateurish and dull. So I fully recommend it, forget the reviews, don't know why they are so against this film. And it is fantastic!!!

title: if you haven't seen the movie or read the book wait to read this!!!
review: i have read the book. the book is amazing. i understand that when making a book into a movie things are changed and lost. i do not like when things are added. they added things in the movie that didn't need to be there. they removed things and changed things that DID need to be there. like why say that Sauniere was not Sofie's real grandfather but then have her real grandmother appear. thats wrong totally wrong. he was her real grandfather and yes she meets her grandmother at the end but she also meets her brother. her brother and herself were no actually in the car when the accident happened. another thing i didn't like was the ritual she witnessed her grandfather preforming. she wasn't that young she was in college when she came home and saw it. that was wrong to make it a child. they didn't explain that the ritual was the last one for a member to preform before becoming the master. i think casting tom hanks was wrong. he plays the same person in every movie tom hanks. he has no emotions no change from character to character. i think everyone else was very well casted.

title: what are you guys on?
review:
look, am i the only gal who thinks this movie was really good. it had 3 of my favourite actors in it: tom hanks (swoon!), Ian mckellin and Paul bettany.

ever since i saw the trailer, i have died to see this movie, and it hasn't let me down. when it came out last Friday in the UK, i saw it that day and every day after that, i am so addicted to it! Honestly, you people that think this movie sucked, need to see it again because you pick things up that you didn't before every time you see it.

you guys who rated it awful can burn in hell cause this has become one of my favourite films, ha ha

title: Da Vinci Code was great!!!!!
review:
The critics have been soooo harsh with this film, along with all the religious people who take this film too seriously. The film was awesome. I read the book a little over two years ago and the film is very true to the book. It's fast, it's action packed, and it's an extremely fun adventure. The whole cast was super. I can't even think of one bad thing to say about this movie.

After walking out of the theater, my boyfriend and I were dying for Hollywood to make Angels & Demons now.!! Just put aside what the critics say (they are wrong most of the time anyway) and see the movie for your self!!

title: If you are a fan of the book, then you should like this movie too
review: I don't know why critics have been fussing about this movie. It's The Da Vinci Code come to life, with the exception of a few very minor details left out. Sure I had picked my ideal cast for this movie and when the cast was actually announced, I had my misgivings. But none of that mattered when I actually saw the movie because the acting was so good it made me forget about whom I wanted to see in the movie instead. I also loved how Mr. Howard handled the various historical explanations. Instead of just resorting to dialogue, Mr. Howard showed us what happened by transporting us back to Rome and Constantinople and the witch trials and the Templar knights, etc. So kudos Mr. Howard and company for making such an excellent screen adaptation!

title: Overwhelmingly Stupid
review:
I'm not sure why I even went to see this movie; I hated Dan Brown's book and find Tom Hanks about as appealing as dental surgery. More to the point, I'm not religious and couldn't care less if Jesus got hitched or not. I just figured that my expectations were already so low that I might enjoy the film. After all, despite its general idiocy, I still managed to finish that damn book.

The Da Vinci Code is not a poorly made film. I think the actors (with one exception) are fine and the adaptation is faithful to the novel. The problem is more that the concept of solving riddles is not cinematic, thus making the large, gaping holes in the plot so much more apparent. The film's slow pacing and unimaginative use of locations just makes things worse. I managed to take the film seriously until Robert and Sophie left France. After that the stupidity of it all became too much to bear.

Some critics have singled Tom Hanks out as the bad apple in the cast. Personally, I found him far less annoying than usual. His performance is relatively restrained and his general cluelessness seems appropriate for the dumbest hero in movie history. Audrey Tautou is endearing as Sophie. Audrey is too good an actress for trash like this. I just hope she was paid a lot of money because this will probably kill her international career, at least for the next few years. The supporting cast is composed of several great character actors. Ian McKellen, Hollywood's current favourite "hire-a-thespian", is enthusiastic as Leigh, while Alfred Molina continues to carve a niche for himself as a bad guy specialist. Jean Reno, not surprisingly, shines as Fache. However, he also made "Empire Of The Wolves" watchable, so the man is obviously capable of anything. I was also pleased to see Juergen Prochnow score a role in another big budget film.

The exception to the generally impressive performances belongs to Paul Bettany. It doesn't help that his character is a walking sight gag but there was no need to camp it up even further with crazy eyes and demented stares. The scenes of him running around London are unintentionally hilarious, with the Michael Jackson make-up and bad contact lenses, he looks more like a crazed fan on their way to a Star Wars convention than an Opus Dei monk.

The Da Vinci Code is not a total waste of time. For example, I congratulate the joker in the make-up department who gave Tom Hanks Pat Benatar's hairstyle. However, Tom's amusing mullet is not enough to sustain 120 minutes of this crap. Fans of the book may enjoy the film but I think that even they will be put off by the plodding action and cheap flashbacks. It saddens me to think that religious groups have taken this tripe seriously enough to bother protesting it. They really should have more important things to do.

title: Better than expected after having read the book
review:
I have reservations on how they are going to squeeze all that information into a movie without making Tom Hanks sound like a walking encyclopedia (many of the information presented in the book are through memory flashbacks of Robert Langdon). The beginning of the movie is very shaky and confusing to those that have not read the book. The introduction of Opus Dei, The Priory of Sion, The Louve, Robert's char and especially Sophie's char are all under done. Sophie's char was really underdeveloped and as a result i think they left out the romantic portion between her and Robert (if not it would look like it is forced). Her history and flashbacks are too vague which is sad because i felt that it was one of the more important aspect of the book.

But the movie really picks up when they got to Teabing's mansion. From there onwards, it was a good blend of adventure, mystery and a bit of a "history" lesson. The music also really contribute to the excitement. The movie really does the book justice from that point onwards.

Tom Hanks does a credible Robert Langdon and Audrey is quite good, but the show is stolen by Ian McKellen. The key of the book (and this movie) is to make people think the "history" is real, and Sir Ian McKellen delivers.

I am a bit disappointed by the ending (not the part when Robert found the grail, that was good!!!) but the part where they traveled to that place (forgot the name) following the last clue. It was changed from the book and they made it worst. Also a bit disappointed about the romance being left out.

All and all, a relatively well done adaption of a very difficult act to follow, considering that they really have nothing to show for on =the movie format except a great conspiracy story (unlike LOTR with the scenery, CGI monsters, action etc)

title: Witness the biggest cover-up in human history! - In a sentence that's what you'll be seeing!
review: I'm sorry but I totally disagree with the other comment and feel that is very misleading! Personally I thought it was a really good film and played out very well yes it was a tad American but so what? Some of the best films are American what's the problem with it being American? The people I went with all enjoyed it as well so if you're not sure whether to see this film or not GO FOR IT!!! What have you really got to lose? I have just expressed a difference in opinion, who knows you might enjoy it too!!! I'm deliberately NOT going to say much about it because I strongly believe you should all just go and see for yourself!! What I will say is that it starts off with a murder in this museum by this weird guy (who worships Jesus and hurts himself in the name of him!) Tom Hanks (a lecturer in Theology or something religion related) becomes involved presumably because the people unravelling the mystery thought he would come in useful.. the story unfolds from there really with the different people trying to work out the code etc, quite funny in places, also quite graphic scenes (especially with the man who hurts himself, so bare that in mind for under 12's) but a thoroughly motivating storyline that keeps you on the edge of your seats so to speak! (Which you need because it is quite long, I think it was almost 3 hours) Still it is definitely worth watching!!!!

title: I loved it!
review: I absolutely loved this movie! I thought it was exciting, funny in parts, thrilling and so interesting. I loved Paul Bettany as Silas, even though he is fundamentally the bad guy I loved this character and I was not at all disappointed. Some people didn't like the idea of Tom Hanks playing Robert Langdon but I thought he was fantastic. I can't believe how many bad reviews this movie got. They referenced the book just enough, while still keeping in their time limit, the characters where perfectly portrayed. I couldn't find anything wrong with this movie, the directing, acting and sets were wonderful. The cast and crew deserve nothing less than consistent congratulations.

title: Brown's Best-Seller On The Big Screen: A Sensationalist Work Of Speculative Fiction
review:
The Da Vinci Code (2006): Starring Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou, Ian McKellen, Paul Bettany, Jean Pierre Marielle, Jean Reno, Alfred Molina, Jurgen Prochnow, Jean-Yves Bertelot, Etienne Chicot, Marie Francoise Audolet....Director Ron Howard, Based On The Best Selling Novel By Dan Brown.

"Too many deaths and wars have been caused in the name of the One True God" - Sir Leigh Teibing (Ian Mckellen)

"I believe in people, and that sometimes they can be good" - Sophie (Audrey Tatou).......

The premiere weekend is over and dozens of Americans have seen the controversial film, based on the Dan Brown best-seller. With all the hype surrounding it, and the recent protests, book-burning and angry Opus Dei members, Christians and Catholics, this film will enjoy a great summer at the box office. Bottom line: this is a sensational work of speculative fiction, offers a theory, and doesn't take itself seriously. Neither should you. Keep an open mind but if you're a person of faith, don't let a simple little adventure story rock the foundations of what you believe. The film is an odd choice for director Ron Howard and for actor Tom Hanks, but the end result is it is a satisfying adaptation with lots of suspense, mystery and adventure. Shot on location at the Louvre and other sites of Paris, as well as Temple Church and Rosslyn chapel in England, the movie follows the perilous journey of Professor Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) and the daughter of the murdered Frenchman, Jacques Sauniere (Jean Pierre Marielle) Sophie Nouveau (Audrey Tatou). Sauniere groomed the orphaned Sophie to unravel codes and puzzles she didn't quite understand as a child. Now as an adult woman, she embarks on a quest to decipher clues in Leonardo Da Vinci paintings and architectural landmarks to get to the bottom of an age-old secret that some are willing to kill for. A small group from within Opus Dei (wrongfully portrayed) that includes Bishop Aringarosa (Alfred Molina) and the young monk he has taken under his wing, an Albino named Silas (Paul Bettany). Silas was disowned by his family who thought him to be repulsive and was taken from a life of crime in the street by the Bishop who recruits him to do his dirty work, namely kill any member of the secret Priory of Sion whose mission is to protect what they believe are the descendants of Jesus Christ and Mary Magdalene, who contrary to the Church-imposed image of her as a whore, was in fact, the "Holy Bride". Paul Bettany steals the show as a brutal agent for this Catholic sect and gets into the character's damaged psyche quite well. Tom Hanks is doing a good performance but not his best work and doubtless he could have done better and is in the end, miscast. Audrey Tatou is terrific as a girl caught up in a larger-than-life mission and who steps up to the challenge, ultimately discovering her own hidden identity in the process. She plays the part as a strong female, even stronger than Tom Hanks' Langdon, but if she disappoints in something, it's in the absence of emotion and transformation. She is the last descendant of Jesus and she doesn't believe it nor take it too seriously nor react with any depth of emotion. Her acting is slightly on the bland side, but so is Hanks'. Veteran British actor Ian McKellen (who also worked on X-Men Last Stand at the same time) as the knowledgeable Sir Leigh Teibing does better. He's very humorous, intelligent and nuanced. He has the single greatest line in the whole movie, "So many deaths have been caused in the name of the One True God". And isn't that the truth! Religion and war, Bible and weapons, when will it end ? There are some plot holes here and there due to the fact the film doesn't convey every aspect of the novel and does feel rushed when parts of it could have been slower, especially such pivotal moments as when Langdon and Sophie first learn about the Jesus/Mary theory from Tiebing in his estate. The paintings could have also featured more prominently in the film as the Louvre scene in the beginning is too brief. In the end, this is just a Gnostic fantasy thriller and you can choose to believe in it or not as it is all conjecture. True for most part to the novel, it is an exciting, edge-of-your-seat ride through Europe, past and present, and makes one want to learn about such mysteries as the Templar Knights, the Priory of Sion and visit the exotic locations. The music by Hans Zimmer is dramatic and oddly beautiful. This is a well-made movie and I highly recommend everyone, irregardless of their beliefs, to treat yourself to an adventure such as this one. Dan Brown's book has achieved a level of immortality now that it has been made into a stunning Hollywood film. It is the number one film in America right now. DVD's will sell like crazy in a few months and is sure to be recognized for at least one or two Oscars come next February or March. There is a lot to admire in the direction, art direction, cinematography, music, screenplay and other aspects, even if the acting is not Oscar worthy. The film has struck chords and nerves with Americans and will not soon be forgotten. It takes its place with other religious controversial films like "Ken Russel's The Devils " "Jesus Christ Superstar" Last Temptation of Christ" and the recent Mel Gibson film The Passion Of The Christ.

title: Excellent Movie
review: Ron Howard has done an excellent job of bringing this great book to the screen. Maybe even improved it, as Dan Brown's literary skills leave something to be desired (Yes, I have read the book). But it's a terrific story on one level and an extremely thought-provoking subject at another level. The casting is perfect, all the actors give very fine performances (esp McKellen, Bettany). The photography is excellent, with good special effects to describe historical events. Seeing the actual locations really brings it home. In short, if you liked the book (or if you think you might like it but haven't time to read it), you'll love this movie. And yes, you need to see it on a big screen with good sound.

title: A Classic In Every Dimension
review: Whether its entertainment only, or a thriller with historical depth and substance, Ron Howard explodes the limits with this 21st Century masterpiece. There is no gratuitous anything, only a tight story line of fictional outcomes to factual scholarship by academic and religious experts. Based on solid historical and theological research up to the minute, this is a story beginning long before Christianity's origin. Yet it draws us into the mainstream of today's Church. Did not read the book, but "The DaVinci Code" opens us to new insights for human spirituality. Like "Gone With the Wind", in 10,20, or 50 years, this will still be a classic, both for content, acting and story.

title: Unusual for a adaptation to stay so true to it's source - the novel!
review:
My only explanation, regarding the negative criticism of this movie, would be found if a thorough examination of the religious biases was undertaken.

My wife and I almost stayed home, when we saw the low ratings bestowed on this magnificent movie. Luckilly, we understood there might be religious bias affecting the ratings, so decided, in this free-thinking society, that we would have to examine, and then form our own opinions.

This movie is the best example of staying true to the novel, that I recollect in the 10 to 15 experiences that I have had. The acting, direction, photography, and location choices were solid.

Please do not be swayed by those that may try to discourage you from seeing this movie.

title: The Book is Always Better Than The Film, And That Is Not Saying Much.
review:
My whole world has been flipped upside down....Mission Impossible 3 was better than the Da Vinci Code.

The movie seems to suffer from the same shortcomings as the book itself. The basic story is an interesting one; not the religious controversy, but rather the elaborate treasure hunt the characters take to unravel the titular secret, and the twists and turns they encounter along the way. One of the problems with the book is Dan Brown's mediocre prose, and the movie seems to be plagued by more of the same. Much of the dialogue is unmemorable or ridiculous, and some of the details that made the book intriguing and the characters likable have been altered or removed.

The film alternates between short bursts of unsatisfying action and ponderous scenes of exposition, second-guessing the audience's ability to grasp the more "challenging" concepts by stating them repeatedly. The film itself is over-long, yet still manages to leave out some of the book's more interesting scenes.

The movie's only saving grace, IMHO, is the cast. Tom Hanks is a suitable Langdon, as far as I am concerned. The character is not a difficult one to translate to the screen, being fairly flat. The always radiant Audrey Tatou brings a wounded grace to her French cryptologist; Paul Bettany (one of my personal favorites) makes the albino Silas a sympathetic character, even lacking the scant scenes of narration from his point of view the novel offers. It is Ian McKellan who deserves the most credit for his role, giving the film a much needed dose of humor with his sparkling portrayal of Sir Leigh Teabing, the physically crippled but quick witted historian who helps Langdon and Neveu in their modern-day Grail Quest.

All in all, I would say that fans of the book should see the film, if only to take in the disappointment for themselves.

title: Much, much better than the reviews
review: Don't know what happened at Cannes. But their sensibilities are not your sensibilities. And chances are, you are going to really like this movie. Why? It's entertaining. Good camera work. Good script. Fun to watch. And it actually deals with a serious subject even though it is a work of fiction. It helps to have read the book. I understood the plot better than my wife, who is not one of the 40 million or so who have read it. But she still enjoyed the film. Now, what about the critics? This lacked tension, or energy, or creative something or other? Nah. Bad acting? Nah. Bad script? Actually, a rather ingenious adaptation of a complex novel. I have seen a lot worse. So, my advice. Forget the early reviews from Cannes. There are a lot of domestic reviewers (e.g Roger Ebert) who are more in touch with American tastes, who liked the film. Go see it for yourself!

title: There's the conspiracy?
review:
If you haven't read the book, you can watch it with "fresh eyes", so to say. The fact is that this script would never have been filmed, without being based on a bestseller.
