Quite the contrary, to me this film's main strength is that it sets up an interesting mystery and pursues it vigorously with a lot of interesting twists. Any film that manages that will always get high praise from me.

title: Worst Film of 2006
review:
Ron Howard should just stop making films.The whole time through The DaVinci Code he treats the audience as if they're too stupid too figure things out for themselves.He makes the obvious even more obvious.(The bad guys have shifty eyes etc..) Not even Tom hanks,the everyman of modern cinema,can save this lackluster attempt at an adaptation from Dan Brown's book.There is no attempt to compensate for the books failings and follows it almost to the letter.

And the scenes with Silas and his whip just look completely out of place.They go on so much you just have to laugh.

AVOID AT ALL COSTS

title: Tom Hanks and the Holy Grail
review:
Right off, I admit to not having read the book "The Da Vinci Code" but I was familiar with the story before seeing the film. Due to the lackluster reviews this movie received, I decided to rent it rather than rush out and see it. I find sometimes that films not well received in the theater do better as rentals. I'm not sure why. It may be the shelling out of so much money to see a film nowadays. Nevertheless, I suspect I had a better experience than some people.

I won't bother to repeat the story, but I am one person who did not find this film dull, lackluster, or felt like nothing was happening. I found it suspenseful and interesting, with good performances, Ian McKellan being a standout. The scenery was stunning, as was the musical score - the whole look and sound was that of a very big money production, which of course it was. I liked both Tom Hanks and Audrey Tatou - Hanks never imposes himself on the material, so he didn't try to make more of the Robert Langdon character than is there - which isn't much. Just about anyone could have played the part. Hanks was the icing on an expensive cake. Audrey Tatou was very good in her role. But these parts take a back seat to the intricate and controversial story.

"The Da Vinci Code" is provocative, exciting, and well done. My only complaint is that it had several of what I call false endings - i.e., you think the film is over and it isn't. I loved the true ending - once it got there.

title: that movie
review: i hate it. that was a terrible movie. I when on Dan brown or what ever is name is site and he talks pare foolishness bout he's a Christian. he is not no Christian because i don't think he sees that in Christian there is Christ. tom hanks gosh no. never again will i wacth is shows. i don't care if i cant spell but this movie is a demonic movie, trying to say that Jesus was foni. no he ain't people like them always try to find things to say about Christ bout there trying to crack some stupid code go crack the code of why you even exist. bout these facts are true are u stupid? . ever since the passion of the Christ came out some one has to come and put a movie that gives u pare lies about Christ gosh.

title: A waste of time and money
review: Tom Hanks should get an Oscar for pretending he was in a movie. I can't believe this dull turkey is still selling out. It can't possibly be getting good word of mouth. Maybe it's okay for someone who hasn't read the book and doesn't know what is going to happen. Maybe finding out what's going to happen is reward enough. But for someone who has read the book, there are no other attractions to the film. There is no serious excitement, suspense, emotion, love interest, action, cinematography, acting, social message, or anything else that makes a movie worth lining up for. It might have been more interesting if they had concentrated on the historical events leading up to the present and made it a saga of the activities of the Roman Catholic church from the time of Constantine, through the Holy Roman Empire, then the Crusades, then the plague, then the renaissance, then the industrial age, and finally the last century. If they had done that, with lots of context and verisimilitude, then it might have been intriguing and exciting. As it turns out, the flash backs were low-budget scenes like the kind you see in cheesy History Channel documentaries. Maybe I'm disappointed because I had just seen Sir Ian in X-Men, and I expected that anything he would do with Tom Hanks would have to be even better. Well, I guess even Opie is entitled to sleep walk through a certain percentage of projects. Let's just hope he takes Viagra and not Ambien for the next one.

title: This movie sucks
review: I just say the movie yesterday, I liked the book and read it two times (some time ago and just a month ago). It's not my favorite book and I don't think I'll read it again, however I expected justice to be made for the story. However I can tell you that besides changing a good part of the book in order to "adapt" it there are several loopholes in the story portrayed on screen that make it seem ludicrous and at times just plain stupid. I'm not going to tell you much but just the fact that J.S is not Sophie's grandfather really spoils the story. A great number of details is exactly what makes the book interesting and that is exactly what is missing in this film! It seems Ron Howard and co. tought we just wouldn't care for the details and decided to let them out of the story

title: Dire
review:
This is a very revealing film. It doesn't have anything new, original or particularly interesting about the Catholic church, Christianity or the nature of belief, but it speaks volumes about the source novel. I didn't like 'The DaVinci Code' as a piece of prose: I think Dan Brown is a lazy, derivative, plodder of a writer. I did think, however, that it might make a decent film  a medium where cliché, preposterous serendipitous co-incidence and an emphasis on spectacle rather than substance is often an advantage.

It isn't. This doggedly loyal adaptation simply highlights the writer's creative deficiencies. The dialogue is leaden, loaded with unnecessarily heavy-handed hints at profundity and significance  ironing the much touted plot twists and revelations flat. The nature of Audrey Tautou's character (of which more later) is so lumpenly telegraphed that even those who had not read the book (lucky them) would guess at it after the first half hour. There is no real attempt at characterisation, as dialogue is so heavy in exposition that personality and psychology don't get a look-in. Hanks and Tautou stagger through the film looking as though they've been stunned  reading the novel had the same effect on my mind, though in my case I was near-insensible at the thought that this drivel is currently the best-selling novel in the English language. Ian McKellern fares a little better, enjoying the few comic lines the wearily dry script is graced with, but even he is lumbered with a tired archetype. The normally excellent Bettany and Molina are just plain awful.

These faults are, essentially, those of the source text. Director Ron Howard must share some blame, however, for allowing the pace of what is essentially a chase-movie to sag so often, and using the wide variety of artworks and historic buildings featured so poorly. This could  for all it's lack of narrative drive  have been a beautiful film. It isn't. At best, visually, it's unremarkable. It's a controversial book, undeservedly so, as it has nothing new to say and what it does have to say is put poorly, so it is possible that Howard and screenwriter Akiva Goldsmith  both capable of excellent work - have chosen to stuck so closely to Brown's book in order to deflect criticism as to it's content. If this is the case, then they are cowards. If it is not, then there is little excuse for this being such a poor film.

title: This is dire...
review:
This film is complete rubbish... dull, boring, disjointed, trite, hammy.

I can't believe that such decent actors could put in such wooden performances (esp Hanks, Tautou, Bettany).... Ian McKellen was the only life in the whole thing....

The pacey style of the book was completely lost.... in the book there are lots of relatively short chapters and like an episode of a soap opera each chapter ends with a climax, surprise or suspense enticing you to turn the page and read on.... in the film that was all lost or the attempt made just didn't come off or was just plain comical.

And because they were tight for time and had to get in all the explanation of the conspiracy and religious background (with bizarre 'ghosts' superimposed on the contemporary scenes and out of focus flashbacks) that necessarily meant they left out loads about the back-stories about the characters, especially about the monk - anyone who hasn't read the book will just not understand the monk at all.

So you lost everything engaging about the characters and all you were left with was dull and lifeless polemic and dry boring "problem solving" scenes interspersed with arbitrary chases. And it was full of implausible holes and loose threads that were resolved and explored in the book but left out in the film.

All in all I'd give it 1 out of 10..... even National Treasure was a better chase thriller than this.

title: Why the bad reviews?
review: I didn't find the movie to be Oscar worthy but very adept nonetheless. Howard does a good job of staying out of the way of the story, adding only a few very deft and subtle unique directorial touches. I was pleasantly surprised at how much French was in the film. I'm glad that Howard doesn't assume the audience won't be able to read the subtitles, because hearing the French police speak French adds a lot. Paul Bettany was simply brilliant. He has got to be one of the top actors currently working. Despite all the talk about their lack of chemistry, I thought Hanks and Tatou played very well together. For the most part, the movie stayed very close to the book. Just further proof that most movie critics have become too detached to appreciate a film that simply tells a story, without all the cute tricks.

title: Quite entertaining
review: I went along to see this film with a completely open mind - I had never read the book so only knew what the general theme of the story was. It is, therefore, impossible for me to judge it in the way that those of you who know the book well may judge it. I understand that the film has been branded a turkey by the critics. I must disagree with them. OK, it's not great art and will never become a classic of the cinema, but it holds up as a reasonable thriller and is quite acceptable for an evening's entertainment. The cast puts in an acceptable effort to keep the plot rolling along at a good pace. I must add that the film has not made me want to rush out and buy the book and I really can't see what all the fuss is about (that's probably because I'm a non - believer). As for the film's effect on me - I didn't leave the cinema thinking about anything really, apart from the fact that I fancied Jean Yves Berteloot (Ian Mckellan's butler/valet in the film)!

title: The Code
review:
I understand that mediocrity runs over more than 75% of our planet but when I see it being praised and elevated to this high rank, then I find myself in the situation of being a spectator, crossing my hands and regarding it all with a bitter smile. No chances of straighting things up...

A sub-mediocre writer successfully managed to trigger success with an even sub-mediocre book, now sustained by an awful screen adaptation. I came to realize that actors I admired (i.e. Mr. Hanks) have no morale left (e.g. when accepting to compromise themselves for the sake of success), what to say about the young Audrey who plays pathetically and triggers no emotional feelings - except, perhaps the disgust. Hat's off to sir Ian McKellen adding value to some scenes. Even though he would also deserve less approval.

I see mediocrity enjoying itself at her best. Hat's off Dan Brown! You did it! America - you're the best!

title: Disappointed in Texas
review:
I love going to movies, and can tolerate about anything and still find some level of enjoyment. I must say this is the first movie I've ever walked out on in the middle of the film. When I left, I felt not just disappointed but wronged. Perhaps the conspiracy here is not within the film but in the hype that would lead someone to pay good money for such a disappointment.

I'm not for sure even how much of the film I watched, at least an hour. If this was the first half, it moved painfully slow, the characters were difficult to connect with and the whole first hour was devoted to the setup of the crux of the film - you know, the part where catholics were duped and Jesus was a fraud.

I'm sorry, but the conspiracy this film hinges on is hard for me to find entertaining. If I were a Catholic, and I'm not, I would be highly offended by this characterization. When the film reaches the conspiracy crux, it comes across more as sermonizing, with a bit silly attempt to interpret history to develop its conspiracy theory. I know. It's just fiction, but put in a different context, say the Jews were duped about the Holocaust, it would be considered anti-Semitic, but if you make the same fictional assumption about the Catholics and Jesus, its now just fiction with no overtones? Even if it was not intended, it does smack of an attempt to discredit, or at a minimum, cast doubt upon Catholics and their beliefs.

Again, I'm not Catholic, but of all the things to develop a conspiracy on for entertainment purposes, surely something more interesting could be found. Overall, I'm just disappointed. Having great respect for the producer and Mr. Hanks, I expected much more from this film and don't understand the need to build such as powerful entertainment medium that promotes such a theory at the expense of a religious faith. I wished they would have been more forthcoming about the true entertainment value of this film, rather than letting the advertising hype mislead people into viewing this film.

Go if you like. Personally, I don't feel this film deserves your financial endorsement.

title: sub-average movie with some good parts.
review: tom hanks is usually one of Hollywood's finest actors but he stinks in this boring movie. there is no tension/chemistry between langdon and sophie neveu (the two lead characters). the first half of the movie is disjointed (but easily understood by those who read the book) and stilted (not easily tolerated by those who felt a rush of excitement by the book). ian mckellen (sir leigh teabing) is the movie's saving grace and his acting and line delivery transmute scenes in which he appears to the only enjoyable portion of the movie. his scene's seem to have a faster pace and more radiance from all the actors. for these reasons the movie is enjoyable during the 55% to 85% portion of its time-line. as i said the beginning is boring and the end just drags on uneventfully and dogmatically. the movie is very true to the book and perhaps this will answer the question regarding the many other book to movie conversions: why wasn't the movie exactly like the book? because it is a different medium and it calls for a different style of communication. i prefer a movie with a good screenplay to a movie based on a good book, anytime.

title: Terrible adaptation
review:
For the record, I absolutely love the book. Now for the bad news, this movie is one of the worst book adaptations I've ever seen. They managed to take an enormously exciting book and turn it into a boring, confusing, ignorant movie.

I'll just give a few examples. For one, the book's theme is the importance of the sacred feminine and how women should be viewed as equals if not superior to men and yet Sophie (the main feminine character) is pretty well portrayed as a moron. She is supposed to be a genius cryptographer and yet she really adds nothing to their quest. In the movie, Langdon figures out to look behind 'Madonna on the Rocks' not Sophie, Langdon discovers the address on the back on the key not Sophie, Langdon figures out the mirror script not Sophie. In the book Sophie figures all of these things out and for some reason Ron Howard takes that away.

Another thing that irritated me was the deletion of one of the riddles. They completely got rid of the first cryptex which, in the book, helps to show Sophie's importance in the quest.

They also make Bishop Aringarosa (a character that I really like in the book) look like a bad guy. In the book, he is just trying to save Opus Dei when the Catholic Church decides to cut all ties to them. He even confesses everything to Fache and practically turns himself in. However, in the movie, they have him invent this lie about Langdon confessing to him about the murders. They also have him as a part of the League of Shadows (which isn't even in the book). At the end of the book, you understand his motivations and admire his character. At the end of the movie, you don't like him at all.

Oh, and did I mention they change the whole ending? Instead of Sophie remembering her childhood, finding her grandmother, reuniting with her brother, and then her grandmother explaining to Langdon that the grail isn't there anymore; they invent this whole new ending where they go into a catacomb and find the Sangraal documents (which contradicts the book because the grail includes both the documents and the sarcophagus; the sarcophagus alone is just a coffin, it needs the documents to make its claim as Mary Magdalene, wife of Christ). Also, they make Sauniere not actually Sophie's grandfather in the movie, which is a pointless stupid change.

Also, here are some of the minor changes that still annoyed me very much: Silas doesn't have red eyes; they don't take a taxi through the garden of earthly delights; the plane takes off for Zurich instead of going to London all along; Sophie does her pathetic little slapping of Silas (which looks ridiculous); Teabing's dramatic exposure to Langdon and Sophie is ruined when they show him earlier as the Teacher; Fache is a member of Opus Dei in the movie, not in the book; Sophie and Langdon don't have their final kiss and plan to meet in a month; Sophie is just a Saint Clair, not a union of the last two divine bloodlines.

And even with all these complaints, I haven't even touched on the acting, which was sub-par; Langdon and Sophie have no chemistry together; etc.

All in all, this movie left me incredibly disappointed. Ron Howard had the easiest job in the world. The book is already written like a movie, all he had to do was shorten some conversations and put it on screen, but he failed to do that. I love the book, but I won't ever buy the movie.

title: From Bad to Worse....
review:
Historians like myself cringe whenever Hollywood attempts to portray famous events and people from the past because we know Tinsel Town is going to foul it up. Usually it's the result of pandering to the intellectually challenged masses who care more for a cheesy love story or high octane special effects than substance and accuracy. Such is once again the case with The Da Vinci Code. Only this time the way was paved by a mine-numbingly painful book that had already succeeded where Hollywood often fails. Why? Most people are stupid. Most people think Leonardo's last name is Da Vinci (it's not). Most people believe anything they read in a trashy spy or mystery novel and don't bother to look up the facts for themselves. And with the very preface to the novel, Dan Brown informs his 40 million-plus readers that the art, architecture, documents and secret societies described in his book are FACT. Not fiction, mind you, but FACT. Oh sure, it's a fictional novel, we all know that. But so too are the "facts" Dan Brown hinges his entire story upon. FACT: The Priory of Scion didn't exist until 1956, and it was a fabricated society concocted by French hoaxster Pierre Plantard, who later confessed under oath that he lied about the Priory's long and storied past. That means Leonardo Da Vinci was NOT a member of the Priory of Scion, nor was Sir Issac Newton, nor was Alexander Pope. FACT: The Dossiere Secrets are a forgery, and were proved so by the 1970's. That means that Plantard and Co. simply invented the entire myth of the Merovingian Kings carrying the bloodline of Christ and Mary Magdalene, a bloodline they erroneously claimed still exists today. FACT: The Dead Sea Scrolls say ABSOLUTELY NOTHING about Jesus, contain no lost Gospels of Jesus, and in no way mention anything about Mary Magdalene.

All Dan Brown had to do was pick up a damn copy of them in translation from Barnes and Noble and he would have known that. Instead he got his idiot "art historian" wife to do the "research" for him. The same holds true with the Gnostic Gospels. Dan Brown claims they portray Jesus in human terms only and that's why they were rejected by the Church. That's CRAP. Again, Dan, pick up a copy of the Gnostic Gospels by Elaine Pagels and read for yourself how they portray Jesus as even MORE Divine than in the 4 canonical gospels. The Gnostics believed Jesus was never even made flesh, that he was all spirit and that his followers should reject material things in favor of spiritual pursuits. All of this is ignored in the book and the film. Leigh Teabing's rant on Constantine was downright laughable. The Council of Nicea did NOT determine the books of the New Testament that are now canon; that didn't happen until 50 years later, by Athanasius of Alexandria. The issue at Nicea was NOT whether Jesus was mortal or divine, but whether the Arian view of Jesus being "of a similar substance" to God the father OR "of the same substance" was acceptable. The latter view was accepted, and that produced the Nicene Creed, which most brainwashed and ill-informed Catholics recite every Sunday like sheep thinking it's in one of the Gospels or epistles of Paul. It's not. It was written by Eusebius of Caesarea 300 years after the fact in an attempt to produce some unity of belief in a Christian network of followers who disagreed on anything and everything having to do with Jesus. Hence Catholicism was born: three centuries after Christ. But one thing they DID agree on (again obvious from the literature that has survived from the first 3 centuries AD), Jesus was at least somewhat divine, he never married and he never produced offspring. That nonsense was only the later mythologizing of an already problem-plagued, contradiction-riddled storyline presented in the Gospels. Oh, and try to find a secret chamber below Rosslyn Chapel, the supposed resting place of Mary Magdalene's sarcophagus. You won't. Many have already tried--with no success.

As a film-goer, I wanted to at least have a PLAUSIBLE conspiracy dangled before me. I know the Catholic Church is corrupt, I know the 4 Gospels are flawed and don't tell the whole story of a man who somehow got followers to believe he was divine. I know would-be Messiahs were a dime a dozen in the 1st century world of Roman Judea. I know that tens of thousands just as faithfully built temples and worshiped the likes of Hercules, the son of a mortal woman and a god, who performed great feats, suffered a horrible death and was resurrected by Zeus and taken up to Mt. Olympus as a god. Ho-hum. Nothing original there, Christianity. But for $9 bucks, I want Tom Hanks to actually act and not phone in a catatonic, 2-dimensional performance. I wanted the plot holes to be smaller than the Grand Canyon. I wanted a pretty Frenchwoman who could actually ACT. Thank god for Paul Bettany and Sir Ian McKellen. Leave it to the Brits to inject at least some infusion of spirit and emotion. But what was Ron Howard thinking? The film was overly-long, painfully shot (though the flashback sequences were mildly redeeming), and just plain excruciating at times. That dialogue between Langdon and Neveu often made me want to wretch, and there was about enough chemistry between them to make sulfur dioxide, and only that.

In short, I didn't hate The Da Vinci Code because I'm a devout Christian/Catholic (I'm not), or a devotee of the book (I'm absolutely not), but because I have half a brain and some taste for what constitutes good cinema. And this ars-dribble was an insult to both.

title: Disappointed
review: I saw this film tonight hoping that it would recapture the feeling of seeing a film that everyone in the world wanted to see. It might have been the somewhat lame audience, but the movie did nothing for me. Ron Howard was an excellent choice to direct Dan Brown's novel; he's a sharp and provoking director with a beautifully universal aesthetic. This film has less in common with the fluid editing or powerful photography of Apollo 13, A Beautiful Mind, or even Cinderella Man and more in common with some of his sloppier work with EdTV or The Grinch. Partly because this film is an adaptation from a book, The DaVinci Code suffers from a choppy, incoherent feel. Howard and long time collaborator Akiva Goldsman try to follow Brown's novel religiously, nervously moving from one character and narrative to the next. What ensues is a stylistic mess, clumsily using hand held cameras and somewhat obscure angles for a mass appeal film. Hanz Zimmer does provide a supportive score, but it is too prevalent in the film. I don't know if that belongs to Howard or Zimmer, but much of the action would have more impact if we were less dependent on someone telling us when to be excited. Which brings me finally to the flashbacks. This is especially where the adaptation component comes in. Since novels have so much more room and time to elaborate upon a character's history and personal development, movie adaptations must make up for this with more succinct and efficient suggestions. Howard chose to actually show many of the characters' "historical monologues" (these could either pertain to the characters' actual recollection of personal memories or their summations of the conspiratorial history regarding their pursuit) through an awkward integration of flashbacks. The one and only that sticks out successfully is the Council of Nicaea-portrayed as a mess of courtly men throwing words at one another as if they were weapons. Pulling back, the cast is good but, as other critics have noted, they look rather silly speaking some of Brown's gibberish with serious tones. Hanks and Paul Bettany surprised me. Hanks is a fantastic actor, but I thought him wrong for the role until I saw the film. Bettany was very effective, leaving no hint of his lighter side he's shown in previous films. McKellan is wonderful as always. Like the actual locales the characters travel to, the rest of the cast function as props, looking very pretty on screen but remain underused.

title: The biggest cover-up in the history of mankind made the most boring movie so far in 2006
review:
I haven't read the book, but I hoped that, since pretty much everyone I know recommends it, that this movie may turn out to be good...Gos, I was SO wrong.

It all starts as we see Jacques SauniÃ¨re running from Silas, in an attempt to save his life, failing miserably. Past this we see Tom Hanks' awful acting as a professor, where he barely changes his voice rhythm and his facial expression through the 2 and a half hours of the movie. Silas is also a problem here, being one of the worst portrayals of the insane, religious killer. The cast was very mislead and there is not a single, good acting in it. I know Hanks an McKellen are very good actors, but they picked the wrong one here.

The movie is generally boring, with a lot of talking and very few action. I recommend you passed it, you won't be missing anything, seriously...

title: This movie was brilliant. A big achievement for Ron Howard!
review:
Ron Howard scores again with a big hit based on the hit novel written by Dan Brown. Set in Europe, a professor (Tom Hanks) is framed for a murder he did not commit. With symbols marked on the corpse, Hanks character finds clues to revile a plot to keep a secret about Jesus Chirst that he might not have been the son of G-d, but a regular wise man of his age. With the help of the granddaughter of the murdered man, Hanks character continues his riddle and discovers something larger than life itself. The search for the "holy grail". But with the police in Europe looking for an American framed for murder, the time is not on his side and must think quick in order to prove his innocence, and solve DaVinci's master riddle of time.

While it twists two religions in it (Christianity and Judiasm) it keeps everyone on the edge of their seats guessing what will happen next. While the movie is long, it is worth it to sit for a bout 2 1/2 hours. And please note, THIS MOVIE IS NOT SAYING THAT Christ WASN'T WHO HE IS BELIEVED TO BE. IT IS JUST TRYING TO SAY "WHAT IF", NOTHING MORE. I highly recommend it to everyone.

title: Excellent Movie... The Critics Have Gotten It Wrong...
review: I saw The Da Vinci Code on May 19th, and have been eagerly awaiting its release for well over a year and a half. I believe the book was amazing and as a person who is not devoted to any religion I felt it was thought provoking. I felt that the movie took a great book and made it into the best movie humanly possible. This book is an incredibly hard novel to turn into a movie as the information provided through pages of dialogue (between characters) is vitally important to the whole story. This information is terribly hard to get across onto the screen without having terribly long scenes of actors spouting pages of dialogue. The movie provides this information perfectly and with interesting flashback sequences. I think that if you loved the book you will love the movie. Also, I don't know how others feel who have read the book, but I felt that the ending of the movie was more satisfying than the end of the book was. They haven't changed too much from the book and I felt the time fly. This movie was awesome!

title: If you read the book first....INCREDIBLE
review:
I went into this movie expecting it not to live up to the book. Which it didn't- but could ANY movie live up to the book? The movie depicts the story and does an outstanding job of balancing the amount of Religious history, symbols and a plot-twisting nail biter.

If you look at the movie and watch carefully for symbols with an open mind, the movie will fascinate and amaze. There are even surprises for the millions of Da Vinci code readers.

However, keep in mind that you will find the movie boring and confusing. The book was so intense that the movie would have to be even longer than its 2.5 hours. They remove the details, which is what creates the confusion.

In summary: don't go in expecting an edge of your seat thriller. Read the book and go to see a movie depiction of what you have read. Then you will find it absolutely amazing. Quite possibly the best movie I have ever seen. Don't always listen to the critics.

title: See Da Vinci Code and Sleeeeep
review: I couldn't believe that a movie directed by Ron Howard and starring Tom Hanks, Paul Bettany, and Jean Reno could be as uninteresting as this sedative was. I am highly skeptical about the whole premise of the story before I went, but I thought that Ron and Tom would provide a good thinking man's mystery/thriller; so I went to see it. The quality was as poor as most of the major network thriller movie fair (like the recent stinker about bird flu); I was astonished and felt like I was scammed. The characters were dull and uninteresting (how low can Jean Reno sink? He was excellent in The Professional), the story line unconvincing, and the movie was trying so hard to push the idea that Christianity was a fairy tale that it lost track of its purpose; to entertain! I will not recommend this film to anyone and I hope Ron Howard, Tom Hanks, and Jean Reno join Paul Bettany in self flagellation as penance for foisting this dog on the movie going public.

title: Opie Breaks the Code
review:
So, The Da Vinci Code by Dan Brown is a real page turner. It is easy to become engrossed in the novel and lose track of time. Moreover, you become drawn into the mystery and suspense and find yourself running to the research area of the library or google to verify his facts or try to solve the puzzle first only to return to the book more amazed than before. Yes, it is a work a fiction, but has elements of truth and fun puzzles.

The Da Vinci Code directed by Ron Howard, based on the novel by Dan Brown, seemed inconsistent in intent. He attempted to capture the various elements of the novel, but couldn't decide if he wanted there to be an element puzzle solving, so he just let the characters find the puzzle, ponder it for a few seconds and tell us the answers. That's fine, I can understand, he only had three hours. The action scenes were alright; as was the use of ghosting to show elements of the past, at first anyway it got a little old after a while.

Several portions dragged. Several more seemed out of place. Tom Hanks though not believable at first begins to grow on you as Robert Langdon-- sort of like an infected sore, until the final scene where the script of the movie takes a left turn and heads into the land of "let's pacify the people that might riot" by having Langdon do a soliloquy that is somehow at once deeply agnostic, Christian, and entirely out of character. Mlle. Tautou made for an adorable Sophie and I blame the writers and Opie for any problems I had with the Sophie character.

The other characters were passable despite poor direction with the MVP award going to Ian for, though diverging from the text, utterly running away with the movie. There were several scenes, saved by him.

The ending, up until the left turn and then once again when it got on track was alright as were some scenes in the middle. The closing scene managed to conjure a slight sense of adventure and awe that a search for the san grail ought, but otherwise I was glad to see the credits.

Overall, it gets a "Meh" and a shrug. Not the greatest book-to-movie but it's not VanHellsing or anything. I wouldn't go see it again in a theater, but I might rent it or watch it on cable. If you were a fan of the book or are curious it might be worth the price of admission just to see what they did with it, if you are a die-hard fan of the book... you might want to bring some Zoloft.

title: Disappointing
review:
This was not a very good movie.

Having read the book, I must say that I did look forward to seeing this film. What a major disappointment.

But there are some good aspects of the movie: The first 10 minutes of the film look promising, Ian McKellen as Leigh Teabing and Paul Bettany as Silas were great to watch, and the film stayed true to the book throughout.

Still, Tom Hanks looked tired. Time after time, movie after movie he has delivered acting performances in Oscar-range, but this time, he looked tired and bored with it all.

For example: How stupid it looked when he said, "I can remember the things I see," while trying to figure out the encrypted message Sauniere had left them; or when Langdon first sees the body of Sauniere, he says something like, "The Virtuvian Man; one of the most famous works by Leonardi Da Vinci." Uhm, Okay, Mr. Know-It-All...? And the following scene where he and Neveu is in the bathroom, the dialogue is so daft and forced, and there you'll get a taste of what the rest of the movie is going to be like.

The films seemed rushed, yet everything moved slow; after 1/4 of the movie, I lost all feeling of suspense and excitement, and started to look for goofs (which I found quite a few of) and began turning around in my seat.

When I read the book, and learned of the conspiracy theories, I was really wondering, "Wow! Maybe this is true?" But when re-experiencing them in the theatre, the whole thing was ridiculously stupid-sounding.

It was as if the movie missed the little "spark" that makes the audience want to pay attention. I was quite bored throughout.

If you have read the book, you're probably going to see it anyway, just don't expect too much of it.

title: Eh
review:
I would like to say that The DaVinci Code left much to be desired. As one who has read the book, I must say that the detail in the book simply could not be captured on film, regardless of director or producer. The book was so well written and so explanatory, that it could not all be expressed in a three hour film. At any rate, the movie had enough of a plot for the average movie goer to understand what was going on for the most part. Some scenes were confusing. The scene where the Bishop obtained the bonds was rather confusing in the movie, where as in the book, it is crystal clear.

I feel that the biggest disappointment for me was Tom Hanks. His acting was completely flat and emotionless. I have seen many of Hanks's films, and this was not his best character. I feel that Ron Howard should have gone for more of an unknown actor. I spent most of my time comparing Hanks as Langdon to Hanks as other characters. If you want to see the film, I recommend not reading the book prior.

title: Entertaining if you can stomach outlandish theory
review:
First off, I hated the book. I thought Dan Brown had produced an interesting, if ridiculous, storyline that had me asking myself lots of questions- but I despised his writing style and the pathetic excuse for duologue he made his characters spew. Therefore, I found the film itself entertaining and suspenseful (since I read the book a year ago and didn't remember all the details), but was grieved indeed to find that the terrible duologue had been kept. Why couldn't they adapt the script a little bit more? Regardless, the acting was overall rather good: I am always impressed with Audrey Tatou's natural talent, she never seems to have to overdo anything. I worship her. Tom Hanks was alright, but didn't have much to do other than to be the bearer of code-breaking genius. Ian McKellen was wonderful and added some much needed comedy. Paul Bettany, of course, was a stand out and stole every single scene he was in- even when he didn't speak. I swear, that man needs to get an Oscar for breathing. The fast-paced-yet-leaden-with-heavy-exposition storyline doesn't leave much room for character development, so I felt the Silas story was underused and ended with a lot less redemption than I remember in the novel.

I still don't get how Jesus having a bloodline proves he's not divine, but whatever.

title: Da Vinci code not so good
review: i just came back from seeing the Da Vinci code, i had read the novel and had high hopes for the film version but to my dismay i encountered a terrible portrayal of what could have been an award winning film. Throughout the entire film you felt as though you were being rushed out of the theater. Maybe its because of the fact that i enjoyed the novel so greatly that i am picking on the movie but i went with a novice to the story and they said that if i were not there explaining what was going on in the parts that Ron Howard left out that they probably would have walked out of the theater and asked for a refund. I was especially disappointed in the ending of the film, In the book Sofie, her grandmother, and her YOUNGER brother(the movie says he is older) are all reunited. In the movie, however, out of nowhere the entire priory of Sion shows up at Roslyn chapel in the matter of about thirty minutes, i found this to be no where near as fulfilling as the ending in the book. also when Silas is killed by the police he randomly says " i am a ghost" which if you haven't read the book you were left pondering what the hell he was talking about. Finally the Sofie in the book had auburn hair which is the same color as what Mary Madeline supposedly had which sort of foreshadowed the ending of the story but in the movie they gave her brown hair which wasn't bad but the auburn hair would have suited the ending even more. The one thing i did enjoy was during the movie i noticed that Sofie had a strange mole or birthmark on her clavicle in the shape of the sign that tea bing and Langdon describe as being the chalice when interpreting Da Vinci's last supper, just a cool thing that you should try to seek out if you decide to see the movie which i do not recommend.

title: Anacrostic: The Movie
review:
Have you ever sat and watched someone else do a crossword puzzle? Not particularly interesting, is it. Sure, maybe there's that one tricky word that causes a bit of consternation, but beyond that, it's quite dull.

Such is the film version of The Da Vinci Code.

This film is such a non-event, a total waste of the talents of Ron Howard, Tom Hanks, Alfred Molina, and Ian McKellan. You're effectively watching others meander through a puzzle, without any sense of drama or human interest or anything to keep you involved. The worst part is you're not even shown the clues! You just trudge along, being told what's happening. It's like listening to color commentary at a Scrabble tournament.

Character development is non-existent. Hanks' character is dull and lifeless, as is his partner (the sultry Audrey Tautou). Jeopardy is non-existent, frankly who cares if the Catholic Church is turned on its side (that's happened so much in recent years it's old news). The antagonists are not particularly threatening and only mildly creepy (and their eventual dispatch is, again, a non-event). The only interesting character is McKellan's Teabing, who provides the only levity and humanity in the film.

There are a few interesting visuals involving flashbacks to events in the distance past. There is also one real shocking sequence that made me swear out loud (it is that good). Beyond that, this film doesn't have many redeeming features.

5 out of 10, and I'm being generous.

Barky

title: An Honorably Darn'd Worthwhile Dragon
review: Pop culture religious heresy is a pleasure only mildly guilty as long as it's done with reverence. Spielberg nailed this formula long ago with the "Raiders" movies & Ron Howard takes a pretty good whack at it with "The Da Vinci Code," or, "Dan Brown's Big Book of Renaissance Puzzles." Harvard religious symbology professor Langdon (Hanks) is brought in to consult on the murder in the Louvre of his associate Sauniere (Marielle), which features numerous cryptic symbols & clues left by the dying man in his last minutes. Police cryptologist Sophie Neveu (Tautou), after learning that detective Captain Fache (Reno) is convinced that Langdon is the killer but knowing that the professor is not, helps Langdon escape. They can only clear their names by solving riddles deliberately left by the dead Sauniere & leading to the exposure of a secret society dedicated to preserving the hidden truth of the "Holy Grail," a revelation that would embarrass & perhaps destroy the Catholic Church hierarchy. The Quest for the Grail crosses the paths of Opus Dei official Bishop Aringarosa (Molina), his vicious, self-mortifying albino henchman Silas (Bettany), oily Swiss banker Vernet (Prochnow), wealthy, eccentric Grail expert Sir Leigh Teabing (McKellen) & an unseen, sinister mastermind whom Silas & Aringarosa know only as "The Teacher." Brown's convoluted tale is built around puzzles & selective interpretations of historical fact & legend, a challenge for a filmmaker since the viewer, unlike the reader, can't turn back the pages or put the story down until the movie comes out on video. Howard & Company get off to a strong start. Akiva Goldsman's script begins deftly, following the book closely without losing or intimidating the viewer. Howard's direction sets the tone darkly & tensely, not ponderously or somberly. Hanks is understated & terse as Langdon, much as Howard directed him in "Apollo 13," where he also played a stressed-out professional whose life depends on his skill. Tautou is strongly, heartbreakingly evocative of Audrey Hepburn, almost as if she were in "Charade" and her roles with Cary Grant were reversed. Bettany, Reno & Molina portray their heavies with even more sympathy than Brown let them have, one way in which the movie improved on the book. Howard & Goldsman do an excellent job of covering up the book's greatest flaw, which is the ludicrous ease of solving a key mystery, by keeping the action moving steadily & reducing the mystery's prominence. The film is still aloft when it gets to Teabing, whom McKellen makes his very own with a perfect mixture of self-important eccentricity, condescending intelligence and scholarly eagerness. As the clues unravel, so does the film. It goes on at least a half hour too long, passing one Oh-My-God climax after another, desperately throwing in more Western Civ puzzles like fuel on a fire. CGI special effects in the second half confuse more than illustrate, though they probably cost more than all those ever created by Ray Harryhausen. Perhaps Howard, like most other big-ticket directors, is no longer capable of telling a story without whiz-bang effects, or maybe he couldn't find another way to deal with Brown's concentration of so many difficult, confusing clues near the end of the story. For most of the movie, the action keeps the viewer's attention away from glaring holes in Brown's religious-historical background, particularly the flawed interpretation of Da Vinci's "The Last Supper" which should be apparent if you can answer "yes" when Indiana Jones asks if you ever went to Sunday School. Unfortunately, all that baggage comes crashing down as the film approaches its end. Langdon's attempt to explain it away in a short speech to Sophie falls flat, tending, if anything, to negate the whole point of the bloody adventure they share. Despite several brief attempts, Hanks & Tautou never get to fully develop their characters either individually or together, another drawback of following Brown's story closely. Those looking forward to a chemistry like Cary Grant/Audrey Hepburn or Gregory Peck/Sophia Loren will be quite disappointed. Despite the global furor, the Opus Dei order is not demonized, since the story clearly indicates that Aringarosa & Silas are operating beyond official sanction. Catholic characters in fact come across with a sympathy--sometimes even nobility--when the story has time for them, which is seldom. If the "The Da Vinci Code" is open to a religious criticism, it's a depiction of Christianity as a religion only fully appreciated by brainiac puzzle-masters. To that end, this reviewer has left you an anagram in the title of this review, made up of the names of two real-life people associated with this movie plus the name of one vital plot device. Like "The Da Vinci Code," it's best enjoyed without thinking much about any historical rationales behind it.

title: Not as gripping as the book is
review:
It is already 1.5 years since I read the book, and yet I interested me so much that I still remember the details. I had high hopes on this adaptation and hence I rushed to see this film. I am afraid this film is not as gripping as the book. In fact it does not get the viewers interested at all. It was so uninteresting that there were loud yawns in the cinema! I think the main problem of this film is that there were too many explanations and hypothesis telling. It almost becomes a documentary with all the history lessons. There were so much talking and left no time for action. Nor was there time for real character development.

Disappointing film, I would say. Or maybe it was just because I had my hopes too high.

title: Please do not judge the show based on your religion
review:
Don't you realize that Da Vinci Code is just a fictional book and movie? It's just a story. So, why all this controversy for a movie? In fact, this movie stars some of the most talented actors/actresses. Tom Hanks for instance, he won 2 Academy awards for best actor and Ian McKellen has starred as Magneto (X-Men) and Gandalf in LOTR.

This movie after all, is based on the best-seller Da Vinci Code. With all the famous stars, and Ron Howard who directed this movie (he directed the Award-winning A Beautiful Mind) and interesting plot... this movie promises a wonderful piece of work.

Do not judge the movie just because it features stories about the background of Jesus Christ. All movie producers and book writers are free to produce whatever they wished. It is unfair to conclude that the movie is terrible or awful before even watching it.

So, comment about this movie ONLY after you watched the movie.

title: "DaVinci" fake and fraud
review: This is not for the faint-hearted. On May 19, 2006, was the release of what was not a very movie. "The DaVinci Code" novel written by Dan Brown directed by Ron Howard and awful performances by Tom Hanks and Sir Ian McKellan were not out of this world--they were rotten and stunk up the screen. This movie should have not been made for it rebukes and defies every single right for a Christian. As Americans and more importantly as God's children, we are to be heard. For most of you, who do not know this, God sent his disciples here on this earth to protect His love, His son--Jesus Christ. "The DaVinci Code" despises everything that has to do with the Cross, the Birth, and the Resurrection of our Lord. For every monetary value you give to this movie, you are encouraging it. Do not give any money to this movie. Do not send this movie to Hollywood.

title: Decent adventure - but not outstanding
review:
Based on the popular book by Dan Brown, this film tells the story a race against time to solve a centuries old riddle crossing through religion, literature, folklore and culture. Tom Hanks plays Robert Langdon, a professor/teacher/symbolist/literature expert/puzzle specialist who gets mixed up with a plot that put him both in danger, and in the driving seat to reveal one of religions biggest cover ups. It all starts in France, when a Louvre curator is killed. He is found in mysterious circumstances with mysterious codes on and about him. Langdon, along with Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou) attempt to unravel the clues to the murder, and the clues to the cover up - this takes them through various locations all to do with Leonardo Da Vinci, as he was one of the perpetrators of the cover up. The cover up suggests that Jesus Christ and Mary Magdalene had a child and there is in fact an active blood-line of decedents still alive. Throw in the mix various corrupt law enforcement agencies, various religious sects such as Opus Dei and the Priory of Sion, various independent parties too - and you have a adrenaline fuelled mystery that spans the time of man and religion too.

Directed by Ron Howard this film takes it's source material from the Dan Brown book of the same name. I have read the book but I wanted to review the film without the book in mind - so rather complain about differences or changes - I'm mainly going to be focussing on the delivery of the film rather than the contents of the book.

Howard's choice of locations make the film visually pleasing, some lovely architecture has been really looked at from interesting perspectives. On first inspection his choice of casting too seems to have been a good choice; there are times where the lines are a little wooden, leaving me unable to connect or empathise for the characters - but for the most part performances are decent. Hanks and Tautou do well to carry the forward, while other appearances from Ian McKellen, Jean Reno, Paul Bettany and Albert Molina (amongst others) all come off believable. Effects have been done tastefully for the most part, with emphasis on clues to help the audience along - sometimes practically spelling out the issue for audience members unable to understand. There's a decent pace for the most part but there are times where action drags a little - presumably to allow the audience to catch up.

All in all this is a decent detective slash chase slash journey of a film. It's like an Indiana Jones style film with less action and more book smart. I'd give this a 7 out of 10. It wasn't awful but it's not totally my cup of tea. The hardcore book fans probably won't like some things about it, but as a standalone film it's got enough to keep viewers entertained.

title: A bit to much for me
review: When I see this type of movies where a big puzzle is being solved with ancient text and so on. I always I always put myself in the shoes of the person/persons doing it in the first place in how they create the hints and create the secret doors that only open in very specific ways. I imagine him having contractors over to do these secret door and try to explain why he needs them. People would think he is a bit weird and if he had done it all himself even more weird and bit trapped in his own world. its like when you see documentary's about ancient secrets they try to unravel by finding clues in old texts. People don't do this, why would they when there exist more easy and more rational ways to do things.

title: A mediocre thriller adaptation
review:
Dan Brown's novel The Da Vinci Code is brought to life under the direction of Ron Howard. Tom Hanks stars as the renowned symbologist Robert Langdon who is called to the Louvre to solve a murder mystery. Paul Bettany plays the devout albino assassin, Silas. The murdered curator leaves behind a set of clues that Langdon must solve in order to discover an ancient secret left behind by the artist Leonardo Da Vinci.

Langdon is assisted by the curator's adopted granddaughter Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou). Pursued by Captain Bezu Fache (Jean Reno) who is convinced of Langdon's guilt, Neveu and Langdon follow the clues that have been left behind. Silas also uncovers mysteries as he chases Langdon and violently chastises himself. The symbologist and cryptologist together elude capture and travel throughout Paris as the clues lead them towards a greater mystery.

Eventually, they encounter a scholar, Sir Leigh Teabing (Ian McKellen) who reveals the secrets that Da Vinci hid. These revelations may not be historically accurate but the conspiracy is intriguing enough to have achieved the popularity of the novel and film. As I remember, the mystery and intrigue were served better by Brown's writing but the controversy is entertaining enough.

Check out more of this review and others at swilliky.com

title: terrible
review:
Robert Langdon didn't seem like the smart Harvard professor that he is. He wasn't offering up information in the same way he did in the book. Sophie Neveu also did not seem as smart as she should have been. With the book you really got the feeling that they were intelligent people who could follow the clues and solve the mystery. With the film I thought if these two can figure out the clues anyone can. It wouldn't take a Harvard professor or a cryptologist. You expect a higher intellect level from these people. Also, it was not the same give and take as in the book. It seemed Robert was solving all the clues himself. In the novel Robert would give a little, Sophie would give a little. It was a team effort with a good dynamic.

One of my main problems with the film is the way Robert thinks things through in his mind. It was reminiscent of the way Russell Crowe's character saw things in A Beautiful Mind. I'm not sure if this was done in an effort to save time, or to make Langdon seem smarter.

I saw this film with a friend who has never read the book. When the credits began she immediately said she thought it was one of the best movies she had ever seen. With that impression of it she still had a few negative things to say. She felt that there was was a lot of information that was hard to keep up with at times. She also agreed about the way Langdon's thought process was shown. She plans to read the book and see the film again to get a new perspective.

I did enjoy Ian McKellen's performance. I think Sir Leigh Teabing had the best lines in the whole film. Paul Bettany also impressed me as Silas.

I'm giving this a 4 out of 10. It was not the worst movie I have ever seen but I don't think I will ever watch it again. I was very disappointed and bored. The entire length of the movie I kept thinking "I don't like that its so different from the book". I couldn't turn my brain off long enough to enjoy the film and not think about all the changes.

title: The Da VInci Code: The Adaptation Strikes Back
review: The Da Vinci Code, a mystery book written by Dan Brown, tells the story of Robert Langdon, a seismologist and professor of religious iconology in his journey with Sophie Neveu to discover who assassinated the Louvre's curator Saunière. As well as in the book, the movie follows the steps of the couple while they find out an unknown side of one of the brightest minds of our history: Leonardo Da Vinci. Furthermore, it is revealed a secret not mentioned in the Bible together with the amount of corruption and conspiracy that surrounded it. As most of you might know, when released The Da Vinci Code suffered a lot of critics by the Vatican and was and still is prohibited in some countries around the world. That being said, I do not intend to extend myself discussing whether or not the affirmations made in the book are real. Although I've got to give credit to Ron Howard who tried his best to be loyal with the best-seller, it was a disappointment to see the quantity of gaps that were left throughout the play. Important issues and answers were forgotten during the film, that shown being of crucial importance for the understanding of the movie. However, unlike most of books converted to films, this one perfectly managed to mix action and dialogs (which I am not saying were good, but I will get there) that were able to catch my attention, something that not even "The Avengers" could do. Finally, my complaints about the characters: with no exception, all actors and actress were exactly the way I pictured while reading the book. Besides, all had a great historic of successful movies. Yet, the development of characters was poor and the alterations made in the plot did not contribute to their roles. In conclusion, I personally hated this movie due to the massive quantity of differences from the original. However, my mother who has not read the book loved it. My final advice is that if you want to watch the movie, please do not read the book, you may share my opinions if you start with the papers.

title: Movie of the century
review:
This movie is just a must-have.

I did not read the book.

I knew nothing of the Da Vinci's mystery before watching this movie.

But I really loved this movie.

If you like conspiracies, Vatican's hidden secrets from Middle-Age, religious cast who control the world and mystery, you'll love this movie.

If not, you'll love it too.

This movie describes so much thing that the human brain is not -I think- capable of holding all of it.

That's why this movie was done.

To zip all it and describe it within a story.

title: Tom Hanks Is Nothing Less Than Brilliant
review: Giving what is arguably the most outstanding performance of his very distinguished career, Tom Hanks proves once again what a gifted actor of stunning proportions he truly is. He succeeds in bring depth and passion to the one dimensional Langdon character in the book and sets the screen afire with a searing performance that will be studied in acting classes and amaze audience for generations to come. There is no doubt that what he achieves in this film is Oscar worthy and among one of the most memorable acting accomplishments in cinema history. The rest of the cast is certainly adequate in support of Hanks but Tattou is sadly miscast egregiously in what should have been a pivotal role. Emily Watson would have been a superior choice in every way as she could easily communicate the saintliness of the character as well as the burning humanity. It was an opportunity dramatically missed by Ron Howard and one can only wonder what he was thinking when he did not demand Watson for what could have been his masterpiece.

title: A Great Suspense Thriller
review:
There are few movies or books that are as controversial as this one, and this one doesn't even have nudity or much swearing in it. Dan Brown did a wonderful job weaving a fictional story with historical facts to tell the story of The Da Vinci Code. Some of the historical facts are true, some of them have been interpreted in such a way in order to tell the story. The Da Vinci Code is of course a novel and now a movie.

I love this movie because it has suspense, murder, mystery and history. I love the historical twists that have been added in order to tell this story. I love how Dan Brown tries to tell the story by showing that Jesus could have been married and had children, or at least one child, and that that child survived to adulthood and had children and so on. It also tells of the story that that child's bloodline, Jesus's bloodline, survived to the present day.

The first scene I like is the scene where Silas (Paul Bettany) hunts down Jacques Sauniere (Jean-Pierre Marielle) and kills him. The reason I like this scene is because after Silas shoots Sauniere, Sauniere leaves a message that only Robert Landon (Tom Hanks) could decipher. Landon does so with the help of Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou).

My next favorite scene is when Bishop Manuel Aringarosa (Alfred Molina) is trying to get the Shadow Council to give money to pay for the information that would lead to the Holy Grail. It is surprising that Aringarosa and his fellow council members are aware of what the grail actually is, Mary Magdalene. Aringarosa vows that once he gets the location of the grail he will destroy all documents as well as the sarcophagus of Mary Magdalene.

My most favorite scene is when the heir of Jesus is revealed to the audience as Sophie herself. I like this scene because it shows her lineage and those of the group that has protected her line for over a thousand years, including the man she thought of as her grandfather, Jacques Sauniere.

I know this movie and the corresponding book has drawn the criticism of many critics because it calls into question the divinity of Jesus. I ask, though, why couldn't Jesus have had a wife and a child and still be divine?

I give this movie 10 out of 10 stars.

title: Dissopointing
review: I red the book and i enjoyed every second of it, it is a masterpiece. This movie however is horrible compared to the book, of course you can't expect it to be as good or better than the book, thats simply impossible. The movie failed to engage me, it suffers from poor acting, important missing details and a lack of excitement. please don't judge the plot and story from this movie only, read the book instead. if you red the book, you don't have to watch the movie, but if you do, Im sure you will feel the same disappointment as I. Also, if you are a fan of the work of Dan Brown, Im sure you will agree on the fact that this movie is a disgrace to Dan's work.

title: Women are a huge threat to the Church
review:
Do you love a good mystery/thriller? How about one that is supposedly based on fact? (Ha Ha) How about one that takes place in Paris and the UK? If you do, then this film has every thing you could be looking for in a movie.

Ron Howard and Tom Hanks had an impossible job. Making a credible film on the tail of a hugely successful book. They managed to make a film that was interesting and exciting, and it had a great score, and superb sound and visual effects.

Yes, I read the book, and I even knew about the Templars and Opus Dei before I read the book. I also read the book that The DaVinci Code was based upon. I knew the premises and that did not spoil the book for me, just as reading the book did not spoil the movie.

Tom Hanks did a great job, Ron Howard did a great job, Audrey Tautou was delicious, and, of course, Sir Ian McKellen was fantastic.

title: Authentication and therefore perpetuation of mumbo jumbo
review:
Interested in the hype surrounding this for a long time I finally got to see the film tonight, it happening to be buried somewhere amongst UK Channel 5's usual shedload of brain numbing adverts. For films like this that require some thinking I find these many interruptions more than a distraction and almost a hindrance to acceptance of either film or advert.

Complicated and convoluted tale of various goodies and baddies chasing after that ultimate holy grail, The Holy Grail. During the chases you can lose track of who is good, bad or both apart from the earnest and always dependable Tom Hanks. And by the end I had denouement fatigue, so many pre or misconceptions were reversed or blown away that it almost became a comedy for me. I think they found the HG by the end, although another last minute "discovery" by Hanks overshadowed even that. I thought the ending of Pygmalion was the most contrived I'd ever seen until this - all that was revealed to me was nearly 3 hours had gone and that my TV was still on the same side.

There's usually at least two things I take away from films with religious messages: 1/ just how destructive fanatics of all kinds (whether believers unbelievers or neithers) can be; 2/ just how works of fiction such as this can end up authenticating the subject by serious treatment and therefore invigorating the superstition they are fictionalising. Also I suppose it's incredibly sad that so many intelligent people of all persuasions got so swallowed up with this nonsense they partially jettisoned common sense - whereas all religious or anti-religious fanatics jettison all common sense. My Catholic father in law would never watch this on principle! Well, he didn't miss anything conceptually vital here except maybe a good laugh.

It's fascinating and extra-thought-provoking hokum! A well made slick time-passer cleverly mixing fact fiction and fantasy and God willing something I'll watch again - but apart from fanatics does anyone really know or care where the key to the code to the key to properly appreciating it is to be found?

title: Flat
review:
I have been reading some of the reviews written here, and I have to say I strongly disagree with the two main lines of opinion I've detected: You will love this movie if you are an educated person with an interest for culture, or you will hate it because of the religious controversy. No, it's rather a combination of those two lines: You will hate it precisely because you are an educated person with an interest for culture. Because the movie is flat and shallow, mediocre. The story is decent, although they are including way too much information for a movie, which is a typical error when adapting a book. If you haven't read the book (and I have not) you might find yourself drowning in a historical essay rather than enjoying a movie. But well, this doesn't really matter because there is little to enjoy: The direction is so bad that the movie is simply annoying. The actors seem to be there by coincidence, puppets of a crazy script. Things happen to them all the time, but it's like they are not touched, they are just watching. So when they are forced to show some kind of life or feelings, it's almost ridiculous. Take the love story between the two main characters: Where did that come from? Zero chemistry. Not credible at all. So bottomline: Much ado about nothing. Puff!

PS- The issues some people might have with religions or opinions about them have nothing to do with cinema and shouldn't be taken into consideration when reviewing a movie. Please!

title: The Da Vinci Code's not awful, but not great.
review: Dan Brown's novel has become a global hit and now Ron Howard has directed the film adaptation. The film certainly diminishes the power of the book mostly due to over length and lack of pacing. The pace is slow, given the two and a half hour length, but the subject matter is still powerful enough to give me some enjoyment out of it. Some of the fun and thrill is present from the Dan Brown novel, but not all of it, making a serviceable, if not well-executed thriller. If you can sit through the two and a half hours of controversial material, you should get decent entertainment out of this limited film. See Also: Howard's prequel Angels & Demons.

title: Decent attempt to represent the book.
review:
For me, the film falls into the mystery genre. It uses the typical who-dun-it type of progression. The whole movie revolves around 'solving' the mystery. In the case of this movie, the solving part takes front stage. In order to find out the solution, real life items, structures, and ideas are used to give clues to Robert (Tom Hanks) and Sophie (Audrey Tautou). The mystery itself revolves around religious beliefs about the life, moreover the lifestyle, of Jesus Christ. The flow of this film goes along the same path as films from the James Bond series. In the Bond films, James tends to travel from one location to another looking for the next clue or chasing a particular person. One clue takes the characters here, the clue they find there takes them somewhere new. Even though the clues in the movie are almost their own character, there are many more in-depth puzzles given in the book.

The location shots play a large part in making the film feel like it involves clues from the past. There are also elements of modern technology used to rush the information to the viewer. At one point, a pseudo power point is given to explain the significance of a picture. The movie has a very dark feeling. This plays a large role in making the viewer feel that there is something not right somewhere. It gives the feeling that there is a dark evil force behind all of the trouble. The brightest scene in the movie is the end, after all has been 'discovered'.

There are a few scenes shot from above that help give the viewer an idea of the surroundings for that scene. It also helps to show that the location is realistic; whether it was shot in a set or not. Some of the indoor church scenes have a lot of sculptures that add to the feeling of realism for those particular scenes.

All in all, this is a very good attempt at recreating a very information packed book. The nice thing about the movie is that it does not actually state whether or not everything was true or not. It gives the information and progresses through the plot quite nicely, but still leaves room for the audience to form their own opinion.

title: Better than I expected
review: I never went to see this when it came out in the cinema and watched it on TV while abroad. I was surprised at what a good film The Da Vinci Code is. Has Tom Hanks ever given a bad performance? And Aurey Tatou was also excellent in a film that showed her intellect as well as her beauty. In my opinion Ian Mckellen overacts ( as do many stage actors when on screen ) but that can be forgiven as the film moves at such a fast pace with lots to keep me glued to the screen. The premise behind the story is all nonsense as has been shown many times, but as others have said this is fiction, so taking it for what it is, I loved it and even bought Angels and Demons on DVD to see if that is also as good.

title: This movie is not a documentary people; its an entertaining conspiracy theory.
review:
A lot of people who criticize this movie forget that it isn't a documentary or even historical fiction, it is pure fiction. The movie uses historical references and manipulates them to come up with an entertaining story. Its the same technique used in Forrest Gump with a different theme.

The entire movie is a conspiracy theory, so if you like that sort of stuff its a plus. If you enjoy a fast paced plot, its a plus. If you like a complicated plot with many twists, its a plus. If you are overzealous Christian, its a double minus. The "infallible" Christians won't enjoy this movie because of pre-instilled biases; that might as well be a fact. I've seen comments on this movie degrading it for its deviance from the facts, but thats insignificant and inconsequential; this is not an educational film.

Honestly, if you are expecting to be educated by Hollywood films, you are terribly misinformed and are forgetting the purpose of the ENTERTAINMENT industry.

title: A Decent Flick!
review:
When a movie is made from a novel, there is always an uncertainty involved as to how it will be received by the audience and the critics. Some of the movies like The Godfather have been successful in creating master pieces by drawing inspiration from master pieces. But there is always a problem with movies derived from popular novels. There is something missing in the novels that movies can provide. It is pictures! There are no pictures in novels as a result of which you tend to form your own images of the places and the characters when you read through a novel. Now, should a movie be made based on the novel, you tend to have some amount of prejudice in the sense that you are searching for the precise same images you had created for yourself when you read the novel. Many a times, movies flop simply because the director's vision of the story and the happenings does not seem to match or resonate with the opinions of most readers. I believe that the Da Vinci Code can be placed in this category.

The Da Vinci Code was a novel written by Dan Brown. Dan Brown, of course, cannot be considered an incredible author but he had done a decent job with it. Of course, the plot can be questioned in many ways but the way the novel as such had become very popular most people had heard about it and many had read it. And the starting note had made the novel even more popular. The statement made by the author that all the descriptions of the customs, rituals and artwork are real caused many people to be convinced by the conclusions drawn by the characters are true and the popularity of novel spread far and wide.

Dan Brown definitely did not build the characters in extreme detail. For example, when Al Pacino had read The Godfather, he knew what he was suppose to do when he'd play Michael Corleone. But my personal opinion about the character of Robert Langdon is that different people will visualize him differently when reading the novel and hence many might not like the role of Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon. Add to this the incredible reputation of Tom Hanks for having portrayed extremely complex characters before and you get a collection of negative comments on Tom Hanks' role. I think Tom Hanks has done a decent job with the role. It might not be a Forrest Gump or a Castaway kind of a role but nonetheless it was a decent act.

There are two ways of looking at this movie. One is with prejudice formed based on your version of novel. And other is that of a viewer who has not read the novel at all. Those of you who have read the novel and disliked, you really should not be bothered about the movie at all. Those you who read the novel might not like it unless you are able to reset your mind and see the movie from an independent perspective. And those of you who have not read the novel, there is a good chance that you might enjoy it.

The Da Vinci code does not deserve any exceptional place in the history of movies as a critically acclaimed movie. But it still remains a well done movie. The screenplay is fast paced and the characters are quite good. Tom Hanks is a good Robert Langdon, so are all other actors good in their own places. Sometimes the movie can get monotonic with the chase sequences but overall, it is a decent movie. Ron Howard's work as a director may not be his best but is overall decent.

This movie is worth watching for both people who have read the novel and who have not read the novel. For those of you have read the novel, my sincere advice would be to try and look at the movie unbiased and unprejudiced. Kudos!

title: Too long -- too distorted --- and (the biggest sin of all) too DULL
review:
Is it FICTION or FACT? (Spoiler soon.) The scholar Leigh Teabing reveals the secret in this too long film - that some Catholic group (Opus Dei) will kill and torture to suppress....

Teabing claims that bloodthirsty churchmember fans of Dan Brown's cardboard "jesus" long ago decided to kill thousands (maybe millions), brutally oppress women and be as ruthless as any mafia in keeping the big secret. The supposed secret (based on incredibly bad scholarship) was that "jesus" married Mary Magdalene (per some spurious ancient texts long passed over as - fake).

And the French girl Sophie is "jesus's" descendant - so she is the living "holy grail" that the church mafia types wish to murder. And since Teabing turns out to be the villain, the film/book can "officially" VERBALLY step away from his claim. ...+++++

There are many websites, scholarly books to debunk this most silly set of half baked truth claims.

The movie has the big name actors and rides on the publicity from a highly controversial book. Ron Howard (who has directed quality films elsewhere) joins Dan Brown & co to do the "Mapplethorpe" to the Christian faith and say "It's just art! It's merely fiction!" as they pocket their bankroll.

In the movie's second scene, Tom Hank's character justaposes various potent visual images on the screen as he talks about the POWER of the IMAGE.. It's a clue to the not so secret slant of the movie.

Technically, Hank's character is not saying that Spanish priests (dressed in white hooded robes) ARE like the KKK, but the VISUAL image clearly implies this.

Most visual images for Christianity (incluing some of the artwork and statues as well as most all the film's Jesus followers) are shown as evil, tormented, cruel, and or strangely laden with secret meanings just discovered...so that one wants to breathe a sigh of false "relief" at the film's claim of religious "fraud".

This is masterful manipulation. Plainly portrayed, but verbally denied by the participants.

***** But to those who want to TEST truth claims - even in a fiction story - Research the pagan era. It's not the glorious era hinted at by this movie...Our ancestors turned from the "cold cruel night of paganism" to leave such things as...

Women as temple prostitutes (Hinted at in this movie - developed more in the book)--Infants (especially girls or the disabled) exposed to die--Slaves who were no longer fit thrown on the streets to die (and then taken in and nursed by early Christians)...and various examples of human sacrifice as well as a general contempt for human life. That truly was the beastly era.

This movie could be called "Seducing Sophie". For the Feminine in full blast Paganism is "the abused".

title: Good but not Great
review: I think the problem the makers had was trying to get the very convoluted story across with reams of dialogue. The nature of the story demands this but it takes a while and doesn't have the 'page-turner' effect of the book as these revelations, which happen often, are not visually appealing but portray images when you read them. I think they did as well as could be expected getting a complicated story to the screen intact. Silas the monk is menacing, Jean Reno as Bezu Fache could have been made more of but as is the nature of the story, it doesn't lend itself well to character development, the main focus of the film is on the revelations, which are just spoken words. Ian McKellen is excellent as Sir Leigh Teabing, the eccentric English symbologist who turns a bit nasty and Audrey Tatou as Sophie Neveu is exactly how you would have imagined her to look whilst reading the book. Tom Hanks's voice was uncannily similar to that of the voice the reader used when Robert Langdon was speaking. Also, I didn't feel(as some others have said before me) that the dialouge was wooden, nor did I feel that you had to read the book to like this movie.
