I think special effects/flashbacks were by far the best part of the movie...they weren't confusing or scrambled but fairly clear...

I know what you gonna say....you cannot compare book to a movie..and its true..where are very very few movies that are as good as a book my guess.

The biggest problem is with the adaptation and cutting material...they left out a lot of flashbacks...so that the terror/anticipation you feel when you read, you don't feel it here(the whole scene with opening the safe box...was a joke/could have been done a lot better).

Also, i didn't like the french speaking policemen or Latin(Italian?) cardinal/silas...least they could do is give us some kinda translation in the subtitles (the whole 2nd plot about betrayal or the cardinal and such would have made it a lot more layered, like in the book)...

like that scene when they found them at mckellen's place..obviously the armored car had a GSP..i guess they talked about it in the policy office...but its a guess...if they had some sort of subtitles it'd been clear.

perhaps making this a 3 hr movie would have been implausible since most ppl who did not read the book won't sit through a 3 hr movie and producers who put that kinda money for it,...wont risk it a nice.

director's cut would be nice...adding 30-40 min of footage..more flashbacks to her childhood would have added necessary ambiance.

also...in the end when they show the reason she stopped talking to him...i always thought it was different than in the movie...more of some sort of sacrifice or the killing or maiming perhaps

title: waste of time
review:
If you've read the book.. this movie is a total and complete waste of your time! I had high hopes for this movie. I hoped, but didn't expect it would be as good as the book. And though I didn't agree with the casting of Tom Hanks (I thought Clive Owen was a better choice), I couldn't argue that Hanks is a great actor (his last few pictures notwithstanding). Seemed a pairing of Ron Howard & Hanks would deliver an excellent film.

This certainly was not the case. The movie drags even when it's in high gear. So much of the book is just glossed over that there is no soul to the movie. Hanks' Langdon is walking through the movie as if what's happening is an everyday occurrence... where's the fear, awe and incredulity?? Such a great book and story completely wasted in this movie.

As I've said; if you've read the book, this movie is a waste. If you've never read the book.. you should and forget this mess. If you have no intentions of reading the book, then who knows you might actually think the movie isn't that bad.

title: A wonderful thrill ride, even if you haven't read the book!
review:
This is definitely one of Ron Howard's great films. I approached it ignoring all the controversy that surrounded it (GET OVER IT!!), and left the theatre satisfied.

Tom Hanks' performance was wonderful (he's one of my favourite actors), the twists and turns got me going and it really was a wonderful thrill ride, and that's saying something (coming from a comedy/slapstick fan). I should also mention Ian McKellen's performance. He was wonderful also.

Bravo to Ron Howard for creating a great film for thrill seekers alike and a film that did stay true to the book (my brother loved it too).

title: Appreciate this movie for what it is.
review:
I made the mistake of watching the movie after reading the book, and I was disappointed, but I watched it again a while later and enjoyed it much more. The movie itself is great; it's just sometimes difficult to separate books from their movies, so if you haven't read the book or seen the movie, I would recommend watching the movie first. The book is by far more detailed than the film, naturally, so anything you don't understand can be explained in the book.

It's a good movie. The casting and acting is all fabulous, and even though I was a little unsure about Tom Hanks as Langdon at first, I did eventually get used to the idea. Appreciate this movie for what it is.

title: A Nice Piece of Fiction
review:
As an extremely devout Catholic I had to think long and hard before deciding to watch this film for fear of being offended.

I needn't have had my fears - none of them were realised. I viewed the film for what it is - a piece of fiction and another angle on the story of Jesus Christ.

Nothing could rock my solid faith and this film didn't even raise a speck of dust. At the end of the day it's just a ludicrous story and in no way should be taken seriously.

I enjoyed it very much indeed and was amazed that I'd sat through 2 and a quarter hours by the time the credits rolled. It is rare that a film grips me enough to prevent me from continually clock watching but this film did just that. It was entertaining from beginning to end and I though everyone played their part very well indeed, especially Sir Ian McKellan.

Several of my church friends refuse to watch this film but I can't think why. Probably their faith isn't profound enough and they fear this film may make them re-think their beliefs. I was much the same when I first heard about the film and the associated controversy with my church but after time I realised my faith was strong enough and was in no danger whatsoever of being swayed by the screenplay of a fictional book.

I can honestly say, as a devout Catholic, that I enjoyed this film very much and, ironically, it has helped to deepen my faith even further. If anyone starts to question their faith after watching this film then I would advise them to watch The Passion of the Christ and get the true story of Jesus Christ.

Thanks.

title: Probably the worst film ever made
review: Plot with more holes than a colander, wooden acting, preposterous central idea - don't waste your time watching this! Ron Howard can be a fine director - why did he waste his time on this mediocre Dan Brown pot-boiler? Tom Hanks looks perplexed throughout - presumably because he can't believe he agreed to "act" in this film. I know the book was a huge success - but the film deserves only derision. No suspense, no character development, no interest, predictable plot "twists"... there have got to be better ways to waste 2 hours of your life than watching this twaddle! Don't be tempted by the "millions have people have watched this - they can't all be wrong" argument!

title: avoid at all costs!!!!!!
review: First off I would like to state that there is one thing in this movie I like. The end. But even the titles lacked something of originality. Having read the book My expectations were high and to see what the call a hit movie turn into a flop like this made my heart sink. Like the fourth Harry Potter book film makers have successfully managed to take something I love and destroy it. My advice to anyone who is reading this is to avoid at all risks if you can, but if you feel you must see it to decide for yourself, I advise you wait for a month after they release it onto DVD where you will find it in the bargain bin at your local blockbusters, thats how bad it is!!!!!!TRUST ME!!!!!!!!!

title: Dreck
review: This is everything that gives Hollywood films a bad name. All those books listing the great movie turkeys of all time will now have to be rewritten. The turkeys have a new champion. Pure, undiluted bilge. What is even more shocking is that it will probably be a huge hit, required viewing for all those who don't usually go to the movies, the brain dead and the entire population of the American Mid-West. I am actually quite an admirer of Tom Hanks, presumably they must have offered him many millions, plus a percentage of the gross, for him to be involved with this tripe. But Tom, Tom, Tom, however much it was, it wasn't enough. What price self-respect and dignity?

title: A half ass job........
review: This movie is just like the book - overrated. Many people seems to think that the book is the best of all time (which it is not!!) and tend to forget classics like Howard Fasts Spartacus (a work of art a true masterpiece) and Tolkiens Lord Of The Rings (the entire series is a masterpiece). And then some stupid asshole decides to make a movie out of it and of course all it becomes is crap. This is not a good movie!! Tom Hanks does a lame performance while Audrey Tautou on the other hand does a more even performance. Ian McKellen does a good job and fits in pretty good in his role which also goes for Jean Reno. The plot follows the book and works a little better than the actors. It truly surprises me that the leads in this movie can suck when they have got a pretty good manuscript and an interesting plot. The poor performances in this movie sinks it to the bottom of the drink. The best actor in this poor half ass production is Paul Bettany, who does a very good job. If you really must know what all the fuss is about - read the book it's better than the movie.

title: Crap!
review:
Big budjet, big stars, no script, no director. I was very disappointed to see that the scrip guy use again the old recipe from Hollywood.The plot is poor, full of mistakes ; how come the precious documents from another time are written in contemporary English? The scenes at the Louvre are ridiculous. The cops going and coming back is child play. We stop believing in the film a few minutes after it begins. The dialog are much too long, and empty. This director was not the one for this film. Tom Hanks and Tatie Audrey do their best, but we don't believe them because it is too far fetch.

Nostradamus

title: Ron Howard, my wrath is upon thee
review: I cannot hide the fact that I WAS expecting this film for quite some time, and I WAS expecting something really good. I had very high hope for this movie, Ron Howard being the director, Hanks, Reno, Prochnov and McKellen being the main characters and a few years of time given to make this thing. I also cannot hide my disappointment when I saw it. What is more, I intend to show my disappointment in this humble review. First of all, the script is chopped into little pieces, I believe in order to somewhat imitate the original novel. However it does certainly not serve the production well. The action is quick, that's true, but all the rest totally sucks. The dialogs are meaningless because the action goes on "without thinking" I'd say. The viewer does not consider the things the actors say as significant to drive the action or create a mysterious atmosphere, a chilling one or whatever (I read the book a long time ago, by the way). Secondly, I was really confused by the actors' performance. I said to myself "Tom Hanks and the gang can't possibly mess this up, there's no way something like that would happen". Again, I was left speechless after the movie, and it wasn't because of my utmost admiration. The actors are surprisingly weak and uncool, not one of them showed anything above an awful sope opera (then again, sope opera characters can at least imitate extreme emotions). I was especially sad by the acting of Reno and McKellen as they are my favorites in this production, and they have always made me admire their work, no matter what. Next, the music..... WHERE IS IT, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD? Music is one of the most important issues of a movie, it cannot be omitted like some petty minor role. Needless to say, the scriptwriter himself tried to be very witty, but it didn't work out. What he was trying to do was twisting the facts presented in the book (I still can't even fathom why) and make some kind of deranged version of The Da Vinci Code strictly for those who haven't read the book and don't know the brighter side. Overall, this is some kind of piece of art and it pains me to give it a whole big 3.

title: the result of stuffing money down the toilet
review: Ron Howard must be at the top of my list of BAD directors. I went to see the movie two days after i had just written the book, which if i might add, pretty dull. Not the story or the information, but the style, as said in family guy " the chapters are short and arty so you think you're real smart every time you finish one. Of course, having read the book a few days before, i was just hoping to visualize the story, and got pretty annoyed when they tampered with the book. Foundation number one for any film is good acting. What happened here? Jean Reno, Audrey Tatou, Tom Hanks and Ian Mc Kellen. All save the last two seem to have seen their talent washed away with this project. Jean Reno, the detective from Crimson Rivers, The assassin of Leon, must have given his worst role in this movie. Audrey Tatou was despicable and Tom Hanks, Though playing the part well was just extremely annoying. And Mr.Howard, when the hero of a story is a history teacher, you better get the most likable one on the planet. Ian Mc Kellen was good during the scene in château Villette. As for the directing, it seemed as if every scene was given to a different director without any of them knowing what feel the other scenes have been given. I will forgive Amelie Poulain, the prison guard in the Green Mile, Leon the professional and Gandalf as none of them could have delivered such a bad part without the help of Mr. Howard. So next time you are about to see a very well marketed film, remember the heap of trash i have just commented on, and rent an old classic along the line of Kubrick or Leone.

title: A movie that motivates ...A RED GIN (Screen)
review:
The "Da Vinci Code" has a lot of things the others haven't, thus giving an unique flavor:

  • a complex story: it isn't usual to have your "grey matter" working in a movie. My last time was "JFK" (another big conspiracy...?). Human nature likes to ponder, solve questions, so thanks for the authors to offer such pleasure...


  • the American blockbuster effect to a french set: I am french & lives in Paris, have visited the Louvres museum... So it was great to see my neighborhood directed in a new & speedy way.. The same feeling applies to the cast: Tautou & Reno are very famous here, and hearing them speak fluently English was fun... And Hanks, as excellent wines, ages very well...


  • the subject, now.... ah!.... well, i don't think a movie (or a book) can erase questions, traditions, beliefs from about 2000 years. Personally, i can watch this movie and read a book from Pope Pie XVI, offered by a friend...


Finally, a essential question: is the movie better than the book ? Well, I am maybe the last human on earth, but I haven't read it. The movie was my first experience of this Da Vinci mania... The only opinion I can give is the basic truth of film-making: pictures have strength than words haven't & vice-versa: The beginning of the story is thus masterly, and the Valette stage is revealing...

NB: "a red gin" is a puzzle: solution is "reading".....

title: This film is sloooooooooooooooooooowwwwwwwwwww.......
review:
Before reviewing such a 'controversial' film, it may be worth making it clear where I am coming from.

First of all, I thought the book was entertaining, if badly written hokum. Second, as someone who was raised Catholic, I did not find any of the ideas in the book offensive, as I consider myself to be intelligent enough to realise that the central conceit of the film- that Jesus fathered a child- is a fiction, just as I now believe that much of the bible is apocryphal.

The problem I have with this film is that it is so slow. Every scene has the life stamped out of it by journeyman directing , painful (long) moments of exposition, and what I can only assume was penny-pinching by the producers. An example- the film contains the shortest and least exciting car chase ever, lasting approx 20 seconds and involving a car driving between two bin (garbage to Americans) wagons. I seem to recall the chase in the book was quite involved, allowing the Prof to have a Dan Brown trademarked 'really big think' whilst Sophie handled the driving.

Some bits are just plain hilarious- exhibit 1- Paul Bettany's mad monk turn was straight out of panto exhibit 2- The low flying plane- Sophie looks out of a plane window at the police cars, the way it is edited gives the impression that the plane is about 30 feet in the air. I'm no air traffic controller, but I would assume that planes do not fly that low until seconds before landing. exhibit 3- when they are investigating the body of the old bloke at the Louvre- why do they always shine a really bright light at the body's crotch? To be fair they do this on CSI as well, so it must be standard practice for Coroners to do this.

To be fair, I thought there were two good scenes- the scene with the Cryptex (where the prof visualizes the planets after visiting Newton's tomb- another 'really big think') and the scene at the end where he visits the Louvre- more thinking. This had nothing to do with the writing, directing, editing (etc), rather the music swelled up real good, and Tom Hanks did some of his best 'thinking acting'. He is one of the few Hollywood actors to be able to convey the impression of someone who is actually thinking (and remain credible) rather than just daydreaming.

Also it just occurred to me that Ian McKellen steals every scene that he's in, and the scenes showing stuff happening in historical times look awesome- like they are out of a much better movie. So I give it an extra star (from 2* to 3*).

In all, a big let down. I don't think I will ever watch this again, even if it shown on TV on a Sunday and there is nothing else on.

title: Rushed Job...not what it "could have/should have" been
review:
This was poor movie. Please allow me to take some time to explain why I feel this way. Let me start by looking at it from the POV of someone who never read the book, Someone whose expectations shouldn't be too high.

It seemed like this movie was rushed to get it into the theaters. I don't think too much effort was put into it at all. The acting is anything but good, which is a sign of poor directing (sorry Ron). Except for a few characters (Ian McKellen and Paul Bettany) the acting was mediocre at best. The editing was very bad. The cuts to-and-from the action, as well as key events, were spastic and unclean. They did not flow worth a D@mn. And it wasn't like the movie was intensionally made jumpy as an editing technique. It was just poor editing. I've seen High School student projects with better editing. On the plus side. the DP did a GREAT job. Very nice cinematography and lighting, but that isn't enough to make up for just a plain bad movie. I am sorry Ron, but this film does not reflect your talents as a skilled movie director.

Now from the POV of someone who has read the book, I don't care that it doesn't follow the story line perfectly. I understand that some things just don't transfer to film very well, while other things can be easily cut from the story for time and to make it flow better. Yes there are plenty of changes to the original story, all of which I was able to live with. In fact I am very pleased with how it followed the book, which is usually the biggest complaint when a popular novel is transfered to film. However, anyone who has read the book, would agree that one of the things that made the book such a big hit were all of the codes and secrets, all of the mystery surrounding artwork and architecture, all the history(real or fake). This movie however, treated these elements of the story as an after thought. Every time a puzzle came up, a mystery had to be solved, or a revelation had been made, the movie breezed right through them, never giving the audience time to ponder the clues or to even to 'know' the clues. It went through them SO FAST that even someone like me, who had read the book, had trouble following what was going on and what had just happened (once again much is due to very VERY poor editing). Every part of the movie where things should have been slowed down and given more detail, it was drastically sped up and cut short. Every part of the move that was just transitional and could be taken at a nice easy pace ended up being drawn way out and was turned into the focus of the whole movie. The hidden elements in the artwork and architecture were never explained or given any screen time, except for a short sequence on DaVinci's "Last Supper". Not a single "double entendre" was ever revealed. Not a single element of what made the book such a hit, was added to the movie.

So in conclusion, if you liked the book, don't go see this movie. If you didn't like the book, don't go see this movie. If you have not yet read the book, don't go see this movie. If you never have, nor ever will read the book, because you have absolutely no interest in it or it's subject matter, don't go see this movie. It was made simply for the sake of making it. Zero thought and effort were put into making it a good movie. The screenplay was OK, the directing sucked, the acting sucked, the editing REALLY REALLY sucked, the cinematography was good. It was built on hype and a desire for money alone.

title: Appalling
review:
Having always been wary of Summer Blockbuster books whose title clearly follows the magic formula of : Definite Article + Classical Reference (a name, or letter from the Greek alphabet) + Code/Conspiracy/Affair, I wouldn't have gone to see it, but a couple of friends asked me along. Well, it was nice seeing them and having a beer beforehand.

The film itself? Two and a half hours which could be usefully reduced to two, removing all the pointless flashbacks for a start. Even so, the film still lacks pace - 80% of the point in a thriller, as it creates suspense even when the scenario is painfully thin, as is the case here. It is much too easy to see what's coming next.

The acting? Apart from Ian McKellen, who does his considerable best to make something out of a two-dimensional character, it's frankly wooden. Some of these people have won awards for performances in other films, but you'd never guess. No doubt the lacklustre direction nobbled them.

All in all, an extremely disappointing film which fully merited its panning by professional critics when shown at Cannes. Don't waste time and money on it: it'll leave a sour taste in your mouth and might even put you off going to see better films with the same actors *actually being allowed to act*.

Incidentally, nobody it going to make me believe that a professor in an obscure branch of theology writes bestselling books and can afford to stay at the Ritz, any more than you can see the stars through the pollution in any major city anywhere in the world. I apologise to the other people in the cinema for bursting out laughing at this point: it really is far too over the top.

title: Did Ron Howard do the book justice?
review:
I had just finished reading the book a week before seeing the movie, and every detail was fresh in my mind as I saw it with my daughter. As one who hadn't read the book, she had little idea what Silas's true calling was. The book portrays him as a devoted re-born man with a tormented past, willing to kill or be killed serving his beloved bishop. The movie offered a muddled collage of Silas's past that left him looking more like an emotionally needy ex-con with a zeal for self abuse.

Teabing's character was toned down considerably compared to the book, which really disappointed me. Peter O'Toole would have been fantastic for the part, and perhaps would have brought the broader ranges of the character to the screen. Though Remy (his man-servant) was instrumental in the book, his character could basically have been written out of the movie without affecting anything. His presence was trivial, and his murder pointless to the movie plot.

Considering the story was designed to pay tribute to the "Sacred Feminine", Sophie's book character as a brilliant cryptographer was reduced to more like a side-kick chick who received occasional compliments.

Ultimately, I think that certain cast choices were off, and that Ron Howard should have made the movie thirty minutes longer if that's what it would have taken to tell the story thoroughly.

title: Stephen Fry was right
review:
Haven't read the book (descibed as 'arsewater of the vilest kind' by Stephen Fry).

Went to see the film and although | have no problem with the central premise ,not being the religious type.... (Deep breath) The acting is poor , the pacing is awful , the script is trite , the albino monk is laughable , and the film boring as hell. Dan Brown must be laughing his ass off at the religious loonies drumming up business for this stinker. Ron Howard is currently running for the hills leaving a jet-stream of whirling dollar bills in his wake - I just hope he's got enough money to buy back his directorial reputation.

title: Missed Opportunity
review:
After being underwhelmed by the book I had my doubts whether I should see the movie or not, but I always like to give people the benefit of the doubt and seeing the line-up of the actors I hoped that Ron Howard would make the most of it.

But, to be honest and in my opinion, after all the hype that preceded both the book and the movie I found The DaVinci Code to be a huge disappointment.

Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon performed incredibly flat and one-dimensional; and he looks like Steven Seagal and I can only hope Tom didn't try to emulate Steven's acting abilities. Audrey Tautou looks lovely, but she played her role as Sophie Neveu without any emotion whatsoever and her grandfather (or at least who she thought was her grandfather) was murdered. Jean Reno was horribly painful miscast as Bezu Fache.

The only two that made the movie a little bearable were Paul Bettany as Silas, since he was allowed to show a range of emotions, although still I had the impression they were downplayed by the director and/or editor, and Ian McKellen who stole the movie as Leigh Teabing in every scene he was in showcasing his class and talent.

Considering they shot a great part of the movie in Louvre, they could have done so much more with it; for all I know, they could have filmed this entirely on a sound-stage. The other locations were pretty bland as well and much more dramatic effect could have been achieved with more daring camera work. The movie could also have used a little more humor; I think I smiled about two times, while I believe there was more room for a few quips.

And the movie was way too long with 2.5 hours. I realize that making it shorter it would mean that there would be less room for flashbacks telling the back-story of some of the events, but leaving out all this detail could have been beneficial for the story arc. Also, every lead Robert and Sophie follow up is explained to death, so it shows that this is an American movie made primarily for an American audience (no offense, though). I saw this movie in its second week, and halfway during the movie people left, the friend I went to see it with fell asleep for about half an hour and after waking up he felt as if he didn't miss anything.

Perhaps another director and a different cast would have made a difference, then again, the book was pretty bland as well, so perhaps not turning this book into a movie would have been the best choice. For all the people who loved the book let me point you to Foucault's Pendulum by Umberto Eco, written 15 years before Dan Brown's movie script, but so much better on all levels.

Overall, let me advise anyone who is in doubt to go see it to wait till the movie is releases on DVD and spend the ticket money on another film; I'm sure you can think of a few, because I can.

title: Entertaining Enough But Glad I Got a Concession On The Ticket
review:
Having not read the book I think my review of the film may well be savaged by devoted fans of the best-selling novel although considering I was not particularly impressed by it, perhaps it will coincide with the views of those who were thrilled by the book and feel let down (as is often the case) with movie adaptations.

Audrey Tatou gives a solid performance as the beautiful and doe-eyed Sophie (the only thing I have seen her in is Amelie and she shook the character off quite well) Hanks is OK although not particularly charismatic as Robert Langford.

Though the story is essentially quite silly, difficult to follow and even dull in parts (I think this is why you should read it first) the film is on the whole entertaining enough - the final twist in the tale nicely rounding off what was an interesting spin on, dare I say it, the traditional "story".

Dan Brown cannot be given full marks for originality, however; anyone who has seen "Dogma" will notice a similar twist in the plot line. Like JK Rowling and her Harry Potter books, Brown simply got scribbling at a time when people wanted something a little controversial and juicy to read. Ron Howard cashed in on that just in time, while Code was fresh in people's memories and before Brown's other books got popular.

I'm inclined to agree with other reviewers of this movie about whether or not Catholics should be offended by its content. Don't be. It's just a story created for entertainment value; if anything it gives the Church free publicity!

title: Missed opportunities
review:
I read the book and enjoyed it very much, but the movie didn't quite measure up. I think this may be partly because the screenplay followed the book too closely. (I can't believe I just wrote that.)

For example, I think an opportunity was missed at the beginning of the film when Robert Langdon's character is established. I would have liked to have seen him waiting for Sauniere as the credits rolled, and then when Sauniere doesn't show, having him run into a bunch of other academics who have read his book. They scoff at him, but he explains his theories so logically and brilliantly (writing symbols down on a cocktail napkin) that they're blown away. They are full of respect. Then he dashes off to do his lecture, having been fully established as Symbolic-Man for the rest of the movie. That would have been better than the lecture alone, even though it was interestingly inter-cut with the opening scene at the Louvre.

But if we had seen him waiting for Sauniere, we would know that he was speaking the truth a little bit later when Fache asks him if he's met Sauniere, and Langdon says no.

Langdon should be the audience's stand-in throughout the movie, and I don't think we identify with him enough. The storytelling seems distant and removed from his character. The book was great because readers could solve the puzzles along with the characters, but in the movie you don't get the same feeling of urgency and triumph.

If Langdon's character had been all about "puzzles are cool! symbols are my life!" I think we would have been drawn in more deeply. Unfortunately, Langdon doesn't care deeply about anything, so neither do we.

The scenes with Ian McKellan and Tom Hanks are brilliant, and full of the kind of excitement that bring the movie to life. Finally, SOMEBODY cares about these darn symbols. It seemed to me that the story really caught fire once it got to that part, when it should have been like that from the beginning. They're so "Gee Whiz! look at these cool secrets hidden in the painting!" It was great. That same excitement should have been present in the opening scenes.

Also, I think Sophie should have had a chance to solve a puzzle. Audrey Tatou's character is emotional and handles her gun competently enough but doesn't get a chance to display any intellectual prowess. Another missed opportunity.

Anyway, the rest of the movie was fun. It just took so long to get the ball rolling. Jean Reno was terrific (and his sidekick was great, too), Albert Molina was in great form, and Paul Bettany was a scary Silas.

I don't give a hoot about the so-called theological underpinnings. It's fiction, nothing more. No sense straining at gnats and swallowing camels, folks.

title: A Con Hid Vice, Det
review:
It was utterly predictable an outcome - a much anticipated screen adaptation of Dan Brown's indeed horribly written, but quite entertaining (and even somewhat thought-provoking - quite a feat for the area of contemporary mainstream entertainment) in terms of its plot, and certainly humanistic in terms of its message, "The Da Vinci Code" turning out to be a disappointment. What has become a surprise is the extent of it. Actually, it was an announcement of Ron Howard to become a director on this project that instantly turned a cheerful anticipation into a concerned apprehension. Mr. Howard is commonly known as a conscientious workman, but nothing more than that. While in this case some real creativity was needed. Well, judging by the result, even the director's not quite imaginative craftsmanship seems to have been seriously exaggerated.

The way in which the movie is made clearly suggests that its creators assumed that their potential audiences were acquainted with the book. I might be mistaken, but it's immaterial - a good portion of those who wound up as the viewers of this one, if not the overwhelming majority of them, WERE familiar with it. So I wonder if it ever occurred to the creators that they were actually supposed to come up with some idea in order to overcome this unfortunate circumstance? And if you come to think about it there was only one approach that gave a chance to stay faithful to the book and, at the same time, provide people with something which wouldn't reduce their experience to a dubiously entertaining undertaking of getting themselves acquainted with a weather forecast for yesterday.

To illustrate this point allow me a brief deviation. For any sentient viewer the ending of M. Night Shyamalan's minor "ghost" masterpiece is more than predictable - after all the answer is being delivered in plain words somewhere in the middle of the movie. Nonetheless, the finale with its "revelation" works out superbly and is indeed quite overwhelming. It's just that it's rather strikes you with its dramatic than surprising effect. That was exactly the way to go on this occasion.

The similar shift of emphasis - enigmas giving way to drama - might have saved this adaptation. Through creating a dense atmosphere, arranging meticulously all elements in every scene, introducing, if necessary, sensible alterations to the original developments, and engaging some real acting it was possible to try to shift accents from mysteries to the dramatic meaning behind their resolutions, characters' feelings about them and gradually transpiring behind each of those events the general message. Thus it was possible to repeat the effect as it occurred in the process of reading of the novel - despite the fact that, strictly speaking, none of those revelations would be something actually new to the audience. Consider, for instance, Mr. Shyamalan's ingenious use of a chain of subplots for deviating our attention in a very organic way from contemplating the obvious truth and creating the perfect emotional landscape which in turn is then used to sweep us away in the end. So it can be said that such an accomplishment was well within the capacities of a mortal. But, obviously, far beyond the abilities of two creative "corpses" who teamed up here to write and direct.

And , unfortunately, what we are offered instead as a result of their joint efforts is just an idiotic recountal of the novel's well-known events in pictures - obviously meant for those who failed to develop their reading skills. And properly speaking those pictures suck. The performers exchange their lines in a hasty manner which would be more appropriate for a first reading rehearsal. As to Mr. Howard's directing skills in general manifested here they simply seem laughable up to a certain point in the movie. After that point it ain't even funny anymore. Though the director has certainly managed to provide one single contribution to all the original mysteries - when for some profoundly enigmatic reasons decided to make Jurgen Prochnow with his "a working class hero is something to be" looks pose as a refined French aristocrat.

It also should be mentioned that Mr. Brown had probably made a mistake when he rejected the initial proposition to turn his book into a TV production. Had the material been properly rendered it might simply have exceeded all the reasonable time limitations applicable to a theatrical release. As it is the movie does the same thing - but in terms of its quality. And now what can be said? - A CON HID VICE, DET.

title: Ugh
review:
I now understand why the Catholic Church does not like this movie. I don't blame them. It portrays a bishop in a very negative light. The plot is improbable from the beginning. I just do not understand how anyone could take this seriously for more than 30 seconds out of the 2 1/2 hrs this movie runs. The plot is a joke. It should have been a comedy. The fellow who portrays Forest Gump or a cast-away who talks to volleyball's makes a very improbable professor of anything.

The only reason I rated this a 5 out of 10 was the villain saves this picture with a wonderful performance. He was the only convincing person in this movie. He is the one creating the drama. And he is the only one creating drama.

As for the writing, using the church to launch a drama is one of the dumbest notions ever conceived. Surely the idea pool is not this dry. Lunacy runs rampant throughout this whole story.

title: Mr. Howard Throws a Gutter Ball!
review: I'll give it a 3 out of 10, just because they used so much film! It's way too long, too dark, too boring and when the big punchline comes where Hanks says to the cute brunette; without spoiling or causing you to not read this, telling the girl the succinct, 'breaking news' of the movie...it's entirely laughable. Wow! How can a director (Howard) be given such a powerful opportunity to dig up something from the past, that's new and original to a society so well informed that, prior to the release, has such captivating interest from the public, only to have it blown on such a boring, fragmented, uninteresting movie as this! (For Mr. Ron Howard:) Now, if the plot had been let's say...that some archeologists had found the hidden, buried head that Jacob buries beneath an oak tree (Gen: 35) which his wife, Rachel had stolen (Gen. 31:19) from her father so that he (Laban) couldn't go to his graven image and find out where they (Jacob; wives Leah and Rachel; all their children and all the others) had gone...which graven image, according to the Book of Jasher (Parry & Sons, 1887, Salt Lake City, UT)which is referenced (Jasher) twice in the Old Testament which says "...graven images were created by slaying a first born male, decapitating the head and placing a gold or copper plate under the tongue...that will devinate the answer to any question asked...THEN, Mr. Howard, you would have had a story!!! And a plot line! Mr. Howard: Please see "Graven Image" by author RF Hawthorne. Then, Mr. Howard you will have a gripping, Hollywood, Bible based movie that NO ONE yet has a clue about which is just waiting for some bright and brilliant Hollywooder to grab and run with!

title: Thought I'd dozed off a couple of times
review:
Just seen this film and thought it demonstrated just how average this very successful book really was. The story that was transferred to the screen was dreary and the script and characters were very wooden. You know there's something very wrong when not even a couple of great actors like Hanks and McKellen can bring their characters to life.

There were a couple of times in the movie when I thought I'd dozed off as a fairly obscure piece of information in one scene suddenly becomes established fact in the next.

It felt to me like the intention of the director was to get to the end of the film as fast as possible touching base with the book as briefly as possible; fortunately that was exactly what I wanted too after the first 10 minutes or so.

title: As good as the book...so pretty bad
review: Well, they did a good job following the book and churned out a rather boring movie. Tom Hanks seemed half-asleep and actors like Jean Reneau and Alfred Molina weren't given much to work with. Ian McKlellan more or less saves the movie with a performance that actually required effort. Basically, proof that a poorly-written book doesn't translate well even when-thankfully-the movie is shortened a bit. Probably better if you haven't read the book because the painfully obvious twists won't be confirmed beforehand. Not that it takes much to figure them out, an IQ of more than 70 or so should be sufficient. Might as well spend money on something worthwhile and check out National Treasure (it got ripped off, anyway); for once Nicholas Cage outdoes Mr. Hanks.

title: An acceptable summer popcorn movie that improves on the book
review:
SPOILER ALERT!

While not a perfect film by any means, and surrounded by far too much hysteria, the film can be an enjoyable experience if one puts aside all the hype surrounding it (which may have contributed to the negativity of some of the reviews of the film).

Although others disagree, I thought the film improved many aspects of the novel. Because I enjoy mysteries, and have some expertise in symbols, myths, and archetypes, my Catholic-raised spouse recommended the book. I enjoyed it, but thought it was sloppily written, derivative, and not particularly compelling (as in the page-turning sense mentioned so frequently by others). As someone who is knowledgeable in history, I found the "historical" aspects of the books laughable, but I didn't take them seriously. As a long-time feminist, I was more perturbed by the claim that it was "feminist," because it certainly did not strike me as remotely feminist, or even very empowering to women, in its depiction of the "sacred feminine," an archetype often seen as ensuring male enlightenment, a point both Langdon and Teabing bring up in the novel (Men find heaven through sex! Mary Magadelene moves from prostitute to wife and mother! Very enlightened).

Because I am also a film scholar who has started a research project on the film, I went to the film with some trepidation, hearing that it was faithful to the novel. As I tell my students, such faithfulness rarely makes a good film. I was pleasantly surprised. Yes, the movie is close to the book, but there are some key changes that made the film better for me than the book (those who love the book certainly would disagree, but I thought the changes made the story better at my first viewing. I still think that after viewing the film three times and reading the book four times).

I won't detail all of the changes from novel to film, but one is the choice to have Langdon be more skeptical of the more far-fetched "historical" claims spouted by Teabing (the wonderful, scenery-chewing Ian McKellen). As a college professor, I found Tom Hank's low-key, somewhat befuddled performance appropriate to how an academic might behave in such circumstances (unlike the "Indiana Jones in tweed" description of Langdon in the novel). I also felt it was better to make explicit the implied connection of Bezu Fache to Opus Dei.

I also thought Sophie Neveu fared better in the film. I know a lot of people believe the book Sophie was stronger, but I did not (nor did my husband or many others I've talked to). I was not impressed with her character in the novel, nor did I find the character particularly believable. I thought she was far too weak, naive, sheltered, and dependent for a French police cryptologist. Beyond throwing the soap out the window (implied in the film), threatening a painting (filmed but not used), and holding a gun on a taxi driver, she doesn't do much else except to solve three puzzles by herself (the Fibonnaci sequence, the Madonna on the Rocks anagram and the mirror writing; all the rest are solved by the male characters, even the first cryptex, where the men help her get the right answer). She certainly never thinks for herself about the preposterous stuff Langdon and Teabing are feeding her. Perhaps many think she is strong because she comes on strong, like Marion in "Raiders of the Lost Ark," but as the story progresses, she loses power and presence, becoming in many ways a prop dragged about by the male leads.

In contrast, I thought the film Sophie (the luminous Audrey Tautou) was stronger, and more believable, both in her behavior toward Langdon and in the reasons for her conflict with her grandfather. In the film it is revealed that he has forbidden her look up anything on her family (a departure from the book; indeed, in the published screenplay, the grandfather slaps the young Sophie to get her compliance). She is sent away to boarding school, then, on a visit home stumbles upon the hieros-gamos ritual as a much younger girl, so her shock is more credible, at least to me (I found it very unlikely that a grown woman in graduate school would be shocked, shocked! to find her grandfather having sex in the basement. Turned off maybe, but not so much she'd never speak to him again). The film Sophie does almost all the things the book one does (okay, she only solves two puzzles, not three, and the whole taxi scene is not shown). She is far more physical toward Silas, both at Château Villette (where she slams his head on the floor twice, and takes his gun--not in the book), and then in Teabing's plane (where she slaps him twice when interrogating him, also not in the book). It is true she does wind up being dragged around at the end, but that is a problem in the novel as well.

As for the rest of the film, the desaturated flashbacks also added to the film, as did the choir-like score, enhancing both the mystery and the suspense. The cinematography, while not the best, blends real location footage with sound-stage work and CGI effects to make it appear first as if the characters are really in various spots (e.g. Westminster Abbey, parts of the Louvre and San Sulpice--the mattes are especially effective there) and as if people from the past are surrounding the main characters at points in the film.

Because I love all types of movies, and have seen thousands, I've rated it as 6/10, but I really see it as more 6.5./10. No where near outstanding, but certainly not horrible either, given its genre (I've seen far worse).

title: Forrest Gump meets the Holy Grail
review:
I read the book and truly enjoyed it. Furthermore I understood it and that includes all the characters, plot twists and so on and so forth. I found it to be better than Brown's "Angels and Demons" which. in my opinion, should be read first in order to get a grip on all the Vatican deeds and misdeeds. At any rate, I urge anyone intending to see "DaVinci" to FIRST READ THE BOOK because if not, then the film will become ultra ultra confusing, hard to follow and BORING. Come to think of it, even though I read it, it still was confusing, hard to follow and boring.

Tom Hanks is definitely miscast. He had a rather astonished look about him throughout the 2:29 minutes. It was if he was trying to tell us,"You know...that DaVinci fellow is like a box of chocolates. You never can tell what you're gonna get." The hero of it all, Dr.Robert Langdon,is a world famous symbologist and Mr. Hanks came across as a "simpologist." Although he's one of Hollywood's great actors, he simply does not convince as the type of egghead Langdon is supposed to be. Audrey Tatou, one of the French "fuzz" looks innocent, cute and pixyish enough to be able to walk on water but would have made a better race car driver than a detective but you'll have to see the movie to figure out my symbolic metaphors. On the other hand, Ian McKellen who plays Sir Leigh Teabing, an expert on the mysterious society called the Priory of Scion, steals the show. He does a superb job even though it does NOT totally reflect what he's all about in the novel. Close but no cigar. Jean Reno,playing Captain Bezu Fache, a man with a secret and who acts the part of someone in charge of the French version of the Keystone Cops, does an adequate job but I still prefer Mack Sennett's Keystone Cops. Paul Bettany, acting as the murderous Opus Dei monk, Silas,is indeed convincingly frightening even though Opus Dei Headquarters in New York has stated that, in truth, they are as sweet and caring as Mary Poppins. So go figure.

In the book,the ultra famous "Mona Lisa" plays an important role for several reasons but is glossed over in the film as a human looking like a male on one side of the face and a female on the other. Yes,that statement does touch on the book's subject but doesn't go anywhere deeply enough into what the painting's all about and what secrets it holds. To me, that was a major disappointment in the film. And of course the main ingredient of the book is the legendary fresco of "The Last Supper" which is treated quite well in the film. It should be because it is the central theme of the entire novel.

I read about the anger of the Vatican over the film. Beats me why. The movie stinks compared to the book so it's angry at the wrong venue. I venture to say that the movie makes a mockery out of Brown's novel. So help me,some of the scenes are downright laughable therefore I don't see where the Catholic Church will sustain any type of a hit thanks to Columbia Pictures,Imagine Entertainment and Brian Grazer/John Calley.

How ironic is history? Plenty and I'll explain. Not too long ago, Mel Gibson came out with "Passion of the Christ" which stirred up resentment against the Jewish people and of course the State of Israel. Now we have "The DaVinci Code" which gives Roman Catholicism a black eye and does nothing at all to enhance Roman Catholicism's offshoot, Protestantism. Can we not say that the combination of Judaism and Christianity represents western civilization, something being challenged and targeted by radical Islam? The answer of course is YES therefore it behooves us all living in the Judeo-Christian world to UNITE against a common enemy. It makes sense to do so but along came Mel Gibson and Dan Brown who, despite their artistry, drive wedges between us. Make us uncomfortable with one another. Makes us question our own beliefs and values. Puts us on the defensive. Introduces uncertainty among us. You know what all this adds up to? WEAKNESS. Just the opposite of the solidarity we need.

title: totally dispensable movie
review:
I read the book, and I liked it very much. So I watched the movie, and I just don't get how they could mess it up like this. There were several scenes which only made sense when you read the book, otherwise they just look totally stupid and seem to connect the plot line which would have had a whole if these scenes weren't there (and they boost the feeling of a stupid action-flick).

But worst, probably to strengthen the sympathy for our "hero" Langdon, they gave him abilities which -in the book- Sophie had. In the movie, Sophie is reduced to a stupid little girl just asking questions so that someone explains to the viewers what they need to know.

To sum it up, for those which didn't read the book, the movie will be unintelligible and look like a stupid action flick with a treasure hunt, but they won't understand what the treasure is and means. Many scenes and decisions made can't be comprehended and the message of the book (may it be right or wrong) is not to be understood.

For those who read the book however, the movie will be dispensable, because it doesn't reach the depth of the book and is altered in some really annoying ways (i won't mention cause that would spoil the movie). They did anything to make Langdon look perfect, which in the book he was not. This elevates him (mostly at the expense of Sophia) to a Hollywood-Hero.

The story has lost all depth and they made (out of the really extraordinary book) a totally normal, stupid but entertaining treasure-hunt Hollywood action flick without any depth.

title: for the bright twelve-year-old
review:
There are some intellectual movies (and books) that are just right for the precocious 12-yr.-old. This is one of them. Lots of stylized intellectual arguments between characters, but also occasional action and humor woven into a strictly formulaic plot. I won't give anything away, but if you are like me and didn't read the book, there is a "surprise" twist at the end. I began to guess it, though, and I became convinced after the conflict in the plot ran down but the movie kept going. To keep going after that point, there has to be a really potent plot twist and I guessed it. Telegraph received.

This is a fun, entertaining movie (see four points of Redeeming value below). A lot of stuff is silly. Several facts are just wrong. For example, the Catholic Church no longer holds that Mary Magdelene was a prostitute. It once held that position --held it for almost 1500 years-- but since 1969, Church doctrine has been that she was not a prostitute. So some of things in this movie are, to one degree or another, not to be taken as true. On the other hand, the contention that Emperor Constantine was not a real Christian--that is true.

Some of my favorite scenes in this movie are the burnished tableaux of historical and speculative events such as the death of Constantine and the Council of Nicea (those are historical). The Council is shown with the Bishops of the fourth century Church in a great hall that is lined with Roman soldiers; some bishops in togas and neatly coifed while others are in rude tunics, long hair and beards. They are all shouting and arguing. Yes, that is what it probably looked like.

The characters are either flat or caricatures. The plot is unbelievable in whole if not in a few parts. Liberties are taken with real life organizations. This could have made for fun satire, but ultimately it's a pseudo-intellectual suspense yarn that delivered little intellectual stimulation and little suspense for me. So why see this movie at all (say, when it comes out on DVD)?

1. Ian McKellan steals scenes like nobody's business 2. scenes inside the Louvre (unless you can go to the Louvre in person) 3. some of the historical tableaux 4. over-the-top performance as villain by Paul Bettany tied with understated performance as villain by Alfred Molina

title: The only thing that sucks are the pathetic little minds that are governed by pretentious critics.
review: The only thing that sucks about Davinci Code are the pathetic lemmings who read the erroneously published accounts from the Cannes Festival. The movie was excellent! If you read the book, you will be pleased at the laborious tasks the production had to perform to remain faithful to the bestseller (Its core audience).Hey, maybe they should have changed the book to suit the mentally challenged who couldn't follow a high paced, realistic thrill ride across continents. And true we didn't have any mutants or seventeen big explosions to keep the masses happy. Fact is the film followed the movie because that's what it was suppose to do! I've read from these knowledgeable(?) critics said it was boring "one place and then another" series of locales. Or the ever popular, "Everyone knew the ending", criticism. Did anyone else see the six month (and still counting) media barrage detailing every controversy caused by the Catholic Church, Muslims, Albinos etc. You would have to be living underground to not know the ending! But hey let's blame Ron Howard or Tom Hanks hair. Oh and there's another one "Hanks is so boring". His character is a College professor, a TEACHER! not Indiana Jones, who was a relic raider and not much of a teacher. The characters played their parts well. I admire the work very much and highly recommend the film.

title: Howard Fails to Thrill
review: This film was very disappointing - which I find so sad because it COULD have been so good - given a little more directorial thought by Mr Howard. It lacked excitement - there were no thrills, no tension, no......NOTHING. When the credits rolled at the end all I could think was 'thank goodness that's over'. In a way I wish I'd never bothered but like the rest of the population I was curious to see how such a terrific story would translate onto the screen. Tom Hanks is always very watchable but he was definitely miscast as Langdon and as for Ms Tatou...her heavily accented voice was a constant irritation and her lines delivered in a monotone fashion. Paul Bettany and Sir Ian McKellen performed their roles well but it wasn't enough to save this movie. I'm sure had someone like Spielberg taken on the task of directing this movie it would have been a different story altogether. What a waste of 2 1/2 hours.

title: It was cool, but I din't get it.
review: I didn't particularly like or hate this movie, just I didn't get it. You have to read the book to get the story line. I'm only 12, maybe I just wasn't mature enough. It did challenge Christian beliefs, Jesus got married had kids, blah blah blah. I didn't care. It was cool that the paintings played such a huge part in the movie though. The movie is violent though. There is this albino monk, that serves god in a scary way, by killing people and torturing himself, those are gory parts. It was a great movie though. (Hey couples, everyone is so attached to the screen of this movie, so maybe you can get a little closer, when no ones watching he he)

title: dire warning
review: If you have read the book and are highly anticipating this movie, do not waste your time. It is a complete and utter disaster. I was highly upset at this fiasco. The reason why I did not like the movie is because the whole plot of the movie is rushed and there is no thrill or suspense at all, whereas you open the book and read the first 2 pages and you're hooked already..this movie had me closing my eyes after the first scene. I applaud Hollywood for trying, and even though it may be the number one movie in America, only those who have read the book would really understand where i am coming from. The actors chosen for the movie are not who you would have expected to be in the movie.

title: Da Vinci Failure...
review:
For the love of God Ron... 122M  for this... Probably the worsts Blockbuster of the year, and maybe the decade.

2.30 minutes of suffering. Bad construction of the plot, there are times in the movie that u are filled with info and others that u are thinking what u will eat tomorrow for lunch...

The caracthers are median... Tom go away... Audrey not bad and Sir Ian probably only the good cause for a 5 ticket...

I really don't like the changes that the production made to the book, specially in the end of the movie. And for God sake, the end with a praying Tom above Louvre's piramid... Simply hillarius.

I'd like to see wath a good director would do with something like this.

title: there are better thing to do with your time and money
review:
I never read the book and after seeing this movie I probably never will. Although it was never really boring, there was no drama, there were no thrills, there is no mystery. The music is quite good at times. Very disappointing.

The film starts quit good. Seeing Silas at his home, is the only climax in the film. Then it just goes on and on and on. A predictable twist and the end. And then, a second ending. Boring.

Hanks never shines. Tautou doesn't convince me. McKellen plays his role like he is a cartoon figure. Bettany isn't scary enough. Reno is unbalanced. Molina is the better actor in this movie.

What was Ron Howard thinking? What did he want to achieve? I couldn't find out.

Even the sound is a bit tame.

Hans Zimmer never fails to write good music. But there's to much of it.

The more I think of it, the more I dislike it.

Really, there are better thing to do with your time and money.

title: Movie's depiction of Langdon
review: I liked the movie more than I thought I would. It was fairly entertaining and moved pretty well. The casting was kind of awkward though. I really didn't like Tom Hanks as Langdon. For some reason, he just didn't seem to resemble my vision of what Robert Langdon would be. I liked the guy from the Professional as Fache and I liked the guy who played Teabing. But, Sophie, although very pretty, seemed to struggle a little too much with her English to put on a convincing performance. Maybe that was intentional to be authentic? But, I don't think so. But, to the point, the biggest thing that disappointed me was the movie's depiction of Robert Langdon. I didn't like the fact that he was depicted as a defender of the Christian faith. Now, I'm sure Christians would not see it this way at all... But, he kept referring to all of the theories that Teabing and he would bring up about the Sangreal as "myths". I'm not arguing that they are or aren't myths, I'm just saying that this is not how he was depicted in the book. I also realize that changes need to be made from the book to the movie for it to work on screen. But, in my mind, this change was made to pander to the Christian world and paint a more "open" picture. The book clearly has Langdon as a "believer" in the Sangreal "myth". But, the movie pits him in direct contention with Teabing and his thoughts.

title: A Malign Mutation Spawned From A Surplus Of Talent
review:
I loved Dan Brown's book. That being said, this movie should be a let down to anyone who enjoyed reading it.

This was the last possible outcome I expected from a corroboration of distinguished stars-- a tractor/train wreck. Who would have thought that a movie involving Ron Howard as director, Tom Hanks as star, Audrey Tautou (from 'Amelie' & Dirty Pretty Things) as co-star, and Akiva Goldsman as screenwriter, could have created such a 'distortion' of the original Dan Brown text? This very act could be compared with the Catholic Church's shameful distortion of the New Testament! All jabs to the holy rollers aside, this movie failed and was painful to watch.

The question that begs an answer is this: did Ron Howard actually direct any of this horrible acting? Tom Hanks was too nonchalant portraying the role of scholar on the run from a secret society and INTERPOL, not to mention all of France. I was convinced at one point he was a heroin addict who just checked out of a methadone clinic. He was that bad! And poor Audrey. . . I loved this woman in many of her previous roles. None of her talents were brought to the big screen for her American debut. Her charm, beauty, and wit- curiously absent from the film. This in itself is a crime against humanity. And I expected a hell of a lot more from Akiva Goldsman, who brought us the masterpiece, 'A Beautiful Mind'.

What went wrong, Ron? Did the Pope slip you a 'bad movie-making mickey' into your drink? Did Opus Dei members get together one dark evening by the light of the moon and chant Latin curses? Or perhaps. . .

It was just a fluke.

My one positive comment is this: this movie will incite conversation for years to come.

title: Wasted opportunities
review:
The book was cool and even made me put it down to go online to find a photo of the Last Supper to check for myself if it could actually be Mary sitting next to Jezus. As a bonus I liked the controversy surrounding the book. Not being the least bit religious I was fascinated to see people around the world fighting a book of fiction to defend their own books of fiction (ie bible). Travelling in France and visiting Cannes just before the premiere of the film, I decided to go see it. And I was not at all impressed and left the cinema with a feeling of being cheated out of what might have been a great film.

What's wrong with the DVC? Too much to mention, but here are my (spoiler) highlights:

1. The book is quite intelligent, fast paced, gets you to look at 'common knowledge' cultural 'facts' with a thrill. The film is never thrilling, not even during action scenes.

2. The premises in the book about equally intelligent etc male and female counterparts, also found in the relationship between Neveu and Langdon is missing. The character development in the book is missing in the film, with the exception of a couple of way too obvious personal trauma's that are used to bring religion back into the context of the film (Langdon's experience in the well as a child).

3. Some things that didn't come across as silly in the book (must have been more elaborately constructed) were plain stupid and inexplicable in the movie: It's ridiculous the way the Professor is suddenly turning against them. You fin yourself asking why he went through the whole theatrics before showing them his malicious intent. So in other words, essential plot structure is missing. This also happens when the beginning hints at Sophie's falling out with her grandfather and later Langdon suddenly says: what happened? I'm being shot at, so I deserve an explanation. In the book that makes sense. At this point in the movie it doesn't. There is no factual evidence presented yet that suggests her falling out with her grandpa has any bearing on the situation.

4. , I didn't like the ending of the book all that much either, but I didn't feel the urge to throw up as I did with the film.

5. The actors: To me Hanks simply is too much of a religious family man kind of actor to pull off the (religiously) critical scientist with an autonomous mind. Tatou is great to watch (her mouth!), but this film didn't give her the opportunity to shine as a performer. And although Jean Reno is one of my favorites ever since Le Grand Bleu, his character was just plain weird here. Unlogical again due to the script.

To summarize: Howard must have thought this film, based on a bestseller, was a guaranteed winner. I'm however left with the distinct feeling that he sacrificed the sharp edges of the book as to not alienate too many viewers. By not adding anything interesting to the script to make it an original and captivating new controversial art product, and also by choosing an actor with the aura of a good Christian family man, Howard took out the exciting atmosphere of the book. Add to that the many abrupt revelations, the absence of thrills on any level, flat characters in general and towards the end a religious revelation to please the religious viewers (nooo, this is really not an anti Christian film people) and you've got a movie that offers extremely little besides disappointment.

PS It seems Howard plus his scriptwriter now plan to turn the Bernini Mystery into a film, apparently hoping to cash in on another Brown-novel. However, that book wasn't half as controversial ór interesting as the Da Vinci Code was, so that doesn't bode well for their next project.

title: 45 minutes too long
review: Despite all the hype surrounding this movie, it just turned out to be a cookie cutter conspiracy thriller. I wasn't offended by the film's portrayal of the life of Jesus, or albinos. People should relax about that, since even the author of the book stated this was a work of fiction. My main complaint of this movie was that it was just plodding, they should have cut at least 45 minutes of it. Many of the actions scenes were poorly conceived. Tom Hanks also made a weak lead. And I went to see it with three other people, and I kid you not, two of them fell asleep during this film. It wasn't a truly awful film, it was a very well made(filmed), but it was incredibly tedious.

title: Don't go, don't think of going, very weak indeed
review:
Never have I seen a movie with so much anticipated word-of-mouth with such potential and broad appeal for the general movie-going public, and which benefited from so many resources as far as stars, budget, and publicity that fell so unequivocally flat on its face.

I don't know what movie most of the people in this comments sections saw, but it wasn't the one I nearly fell asleep during. Yes I read the book, which was "just OK," but I said, this one will make a better movie. What a dud. Never again an Akiva Goldsman /Ron Howard picture -- NEVER AGAIN.

In one sentence: the only thing good about this movie are the French.

SPOILERS: And where were the performances? A platinum blonde Bettany feigning an Italian whisper was laughable, even Tom the great just writes the performance in. No one took it seriously with the exception of the secondary characters.

SPOILERS: And will someone please tell Ron Howard to stop using Disney effects and learn once and for all that the audience is much more intelligent than he gives them credit for. I don't want to see glow in the dark letters and numbers, and stars twinkling in the sky. I want to see numbers, on paper, or where they sit. (See "Proof", "Indiana Jones" for examples) Real hard numbers. Let me use my brain, please!

Where is Spielberg from "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade" when you need him? You didn't see him putting glow in the dark numbers in movies for Adults. And the suspense of Spielberg's own Church scene in the aforementioned Crusade, put all the direction in this movie to shame. There was no thriller here, no suspense.

A grand disappointment to all movie buffs who were waiting to be wowed.

Really sad.

title: Average
review:
I did not know what to expect from the movie as I never read the book. I must say the movie disappointed me. It looked to be made very quickly. Sometimes actors, especially Tom Hanks, looked like they just said a line in the script... Did they realize they were not at the lunch break anymore and they should at least look like they thought about what they were saying? The puzzles looked childish. Langdon (Hanks) solved them all within seconds... Wow! What a perfect way to protect Holy Grail! And then there was this ancient secret note written backwards... And in perfect English! All ancient people in France, Italy, Vatican and wherever probably spoke perfect English. I think children at primary school would laugh.

My girlfriend asked me after the film - Did the characters actually change their dresses throughout the movie? - I guess they did not. Then she just commented - Very stupid movie.

I say the same. Very stupid, long and boring movie. Why they spend money to make such films?

title: The book is better.
review:
Having read the book i was expecting so much more from the film. The DaVinci Code is set in beautiful locations and Ron Howard holds mostly to the books plot.

At first it is hard to get used to Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon just because having read the book there is such a preconceived notion of the character. Audrey Tatou is a believable Sophie Neveu but in comparison to how she is in the book she's a watered down version. Paul Bettany is perfectly creepy and intense in his portrayal of Silas. Sir Ian McKellen is exactly how I pictured Sir Leigh Teabing, he brings the comedic element to the film which otherwise would make it too heavy going. Jean Reno and Alfred Molina are good in their roles of Captain Fache and Bishop Aringarosa. Apart from Paul Bettany and Sir Ian McKellen the acting seemed rather flat.

I found there to be an over reliance on computer graphics. For example when Langdon is solving the first clue the fact that the letters flashed or when he visualises the tomb of Sir Issac Newton. Wonderful graphics yet slightly unnecessary. The flashback sequences designed to help you understand the history better tended to annoy me more than anything else.

The film starts out with a fast pace but in the middle it just starts to loose momentum. Overall the film is average. I was expecting it to be much better. If you've read the book you may be disappointed with some of the changes that were made. In this case the book was better.

title: Code Error Accepted
review:
Over two years ago, I'm at a bar, meeting a few friends. Around the table, conversation is awash with tales of an exciting new book that everyone wants to get their hands on. Upon closer inspection, it is revealed to be Mr. Dan Brown's The Da Vinci Code, and a rather scuffed looking copy at that seeing as several members of the clique have been going to great pains in circulating it amongst themselves.

After sitting through a lengthy recount of what TDVC is all about, I still didn't really get it, much as I have yet to get the hoopla around that magician-cum-heartthrob, Harry Potter. Then again, I'm not a big fan of religion-inspired high adventure, and think that Indiana Jones and the Holy Grail remains the franchise's weakest outing by far.

But this is a bias, and to those enamored with the book at hand, my sincerest apologies. Although never having read TDVC may put this reviewer at a certain disadvantage, it also allows me to behold its cinematic rendition with more of a clean slate. Building on those pillars, I still don't see the great attraction, as Ron Howard's long-winded motion picture, although far from a catastrophe of biblical proportions, comes across equally removed from big-screen supremacy.

Taking its cue from mysticism and backstage whisperings about the legacy of Christ on this earth, The Da Vinci Code puts itself in a precarious position by establishing most of its premise on assumptions any budding cynic will easily discount. On top of that, the story lacks a fantastical punch to compensate for the above-mentioned shortcoming, unlike previously discussed Indiana Jones and its various counterparts. TDVC's most formidable challenge lies in selling mind-blowing theory in a straight-faced style more suited to a documentary, and unfortunately, it's one hurdle the pseudo-opus fails to surmount.

In fact, at two hours and quite a bit of change, Da Vinci sags noticeably in the frills department, putting viewers to sleep faster than on the edge of their seats. And while the almost complete lack of tacky visual red herrings is commendable, it nonetheless contributes to the general state of languor afflicting this project.

Perhaps, then, its main audience should in fact be those legions of converted fans who've read the book and took to it. They certainly have much to enjoy here, even if they emerge disappointed. At least the comparison between the two formats in itself can be pleasurable for those in the know.

As a standalone film, we have little to recommend here. The story's decent enough, but again, minus suitably mind-blowing slights of hand comes in as a distinct ho-hum letdown. In terms of acting, as well, nary a highlight crops up. Tom Hanks appears as Robert Langdon, a US researcher and novelist specializing in ancient cultures and symbolism. Langdon's international repute marks him as a man wanted by French officials in a Louvre murder investigation. The main cop, done by Jean Reno, presents an ambiguous character with an agenda we're not supposed to glimpse early on, but due to a lackluster performance on the part of Reno, nor do we really care to anyway. Much the same can be said of Hanks, who's usually a solid actor. Here he's flying on instrumentation only, almost entirely devoid of gusto.

Additional also-rans in TDVC include young female lead Audrey Tatuou, who we loved in Amelie and Happenstance, as Langdon's righthand lady and professional object of desire, Sophie. Save for being pretty in a Lolita kind of way, Tautou adds little to the course of this movie. There's also the conspiratorial contingent, led by stalwart Ian McKellen. This guy's getting somewhat long in the tooth, to the point where one can no longer discern between him as eccentric man of the occult Sir Leigh Teabing and as world-dominating mutant Magneto. Identical tantrums in either case.

Probably the only ones really doing their jobs faithfully are Paul Bettany as errand-assassin Silas (beforehand we saw him alongside Russell Crowe in Master and Commander), and former Dr. Octopus of Spiderman 2 infamy, Alfred Molina. He does a church operative coordinating schemes aimed at silencing the greatest secretive conspiracy ever, and together with Bettany gives the movie its only impactful ingredient. At times Silas's violence repulses enough to induce the odd cringe, thankfully.

Without giving away the plot to those few uninitiated still out there, the struggle to trace Jesus Christ's living heritage in the modern world brings into conflict several factions, including science, the law, the clergy and an underground secret society. This arguably sounds like a recipe for explosive antics, but in truth has no such effect. For all the anger and furor over TDVC's alleged blasphemy, it poses in reality little threat to anybody's feelings or belief systems, not simply due to freedom of speech issues, but because it's so flat and uninspired.

The best thing we can say of Da Vinci, as a work of cinema, is that it keeps rolling at a steady clip and steers clear of cheap trickery. It has you sitting there, ever on the verge of dozing off, but not wholly in pain.

Otherwise, there's hardly any facet of it worth getting worked up over. It's not touching, moving or stirring, possesses no groundbreaking film-making techniques, and provides barely detectable quantities of good acting.

Is torment the exact opposite of pleasure? Maybe not. Look at The Da Vinci Code, proof positive there's at the very least 150 minutes of middle ground between the two.

Rating: * * ½

title: Weak, no emotional value, no....connection
review:
No I didn't read the book so this is not an age old comparison of, "Oh, the book was so much better." No, this movie simply lacked anything I'd envisioned it would have. An awesome Director, one of the top male actors and a seemingly interesting story line however this film was like plain white bread, without filling the stomach.

I believe the biggest problem with this film was the script. Simply sub-par in comparison to all it had going for it with the director, actor and interests that was going for it. I believe the first weekend (as it was) would be exceptional. However now that almost a week has passed, and more than just critics bad reviews are out, I believe the word of mouth of just how bland this film is will drops it's box office to it's knees like a hooker at a millionaires convention. (sorry, first thing that came to mind) Either way, I wanted this to be a good film yet as much as I hoped, as much leeway I gave it, it was a waste of my time. Ron Howard... no special touch as in his past films. Tom Hanks.. pound for pound one of the top actors out there yet he seemed to contribute not a thing any other actor could have. And again the script... they should have brought someone in far better because he really helped sink this film.

The only real point of interest at all.... Paul Bettany. His character was very interesting and he did a very, very good job with it. However not nearly enough to save this 'could of been' film.

title: Good movie?
review: I found the movie worst than I thought! I have some consideration for the director and I had enjoyed previous works of his; however, this time Howard terribly disappoints me . The movie is not only too short but it also lacks the emotion of the code-breaking process (if there is any in the book also)showing it as easy as multiplying 1 times 1. I've read the book (lucky of me that I borrowed it from someone) and I hoped Howard was going to make an improvement out of it or even make it somehow more bearable, but nothing! I am starting to believe that the movies are getting worse and worse at the same time they become more and more commercial. I put 1 star just because I don't want to be rude.

title: Fan of the book? Saddly, the movie will disappoint you
review:
I had read the book once before when it was first released (I had also read Angels & Demons which I enjoyed only slightly more than TDC), and a week before it's release decided to read it again to brush up on the story.
