Boy was that a mistake. Going into the movie with a fresh knowledge of the story only amplified my frustration. Ron Howards interpretation of the book was all wrong. I felt he left out key bits of information. For instance, he could have focused more on the Pagen symbolism, the Prior and umm how about Da Vinci? Also, the infamous Micky Mouse watch makes a brief appearance but no mention is made.

The movie (w/o even reading the book)fell flat. The script was bland at best. I think that the star power over shadowed my expectations. Overall Da Vinci left me unsatisfied.

title: Very entertaining, well portrayed, well directed, closely follows the book.
review: I don't understand all the hoopla and negativity around this film. I find that any movie that makes me think about historical possibilities; or, for that matter, makes me think at all, is well worth seeing. Tom Hanks gives a fine performance and his hair is a non-issue! I have no problem believing him as Robert Langdon, a College professor who fits into the plot. Audrey Tautou is beautiful and, despite her heavy accent, a delight to watch as Sophie. If you chose to believe that the story is 100 % fiction, it is a great story, totally engaging. If you have an open mind, and are willing to entertain the possibilities, you will have a most rewarding experience. Ron Howard shows as once more that he is a master movie maker. Considering the complexity of the plot and the huge amount of information that the writer had to pack into the 2 hours and 20 minutes, writer Akiva Goldman did an incredible job. I feel that reading the book before seeing the movie is an asset to understanding; but not necessarily a pre-requisite. If you get a bit lost, you'll understand better if you read the book afterwords, or, better yet, see the movie again! If you have a closed mind, are a Christian fanatic and must have everything stagnant, do yourself a favor and don't see it. You don't have to you know. Just live and let live!

title: Nice one Ron
review:
Having enjoyed reading Dan Brown's books and followed up by visiting some of the key locations of the Da Vinci code I looked forward to seeing how the story would be interpreted as a film. It was disappointing to read of efforts to suppress or censor the film and the professional critics had a field day at its opening, panning it as a turkey. I have just returned from the cinema where I saw a very well made film, faithful to the book, and mainly resisting the temptation to over dramatise the action. I realise there are a lot of factual inaccuracies in this piece of fiction, just as there are in the Holy Bible, and some sections of the original book do seem improbable but this should not prevent those who enjoy conspiracy theories having a chance to consider alternatives to the established doctrines while being entertained.

What are the chances of Angels and Demons reaching the screen and how much cooperation will be forthcoming from the Vatican?

title: I want to know what Dan Brown Feels
review: Wonder if he has seen the movie and what he feels about this audio visual rendition. For me it was very very disappointing, as the movie was a far cry from the artfully and articulately crafted book. I doubt that anyone who has not read the book will follow anything in the movie... and for those like me who have read the book, i'd say preserve the good memories of the book and don't watch the movie. The movie is nothing but a montage of poorly put together snippets of the book and falls way below the standards one has come to expect of Tom Hanks & his movies. The only character who comes close to the delivery in the book however is "Silas" the Opus Dei Albino.

title: The book was absolutely brilliant, but the film let it down spectacularly.
review:
The book was absolutely brilliant, but the film let it down spectacularly. Tom Hanks was awful. Half the plot was changed to try and make it more exciting, but it just made me feel even worse about the film, came out thinking what a waste of 2 hours of my life. Sir Ian McCellen wasn't that bad compared to the rest of the cast. Since when in the book does Miss Neuveu become the new Grand Master and in the film sauniere is not her real grandfather. Bishop Aringarosa was not friendly with the Vatican in the book, but in the film he is working with them to destroy the Holy Grail and the inspector is not a member of Opus Dei, like in the film who takes orders from Aringarosa. I being quite picky now, but Silas does not shoot about 5 police officers and then Aringarosa. The worst is that they don't explain that there is a teacher behind all of it, which doesn't create any tension and any that has been produced, well lets say Teabing gives himself away on camera well before any climax.

Anyone who hasn't read the book will find the film OK, but for me and many other people we found it an utter disgrace.

title: What a disappointment
review:
I had great hopes for Da Vinci Code on the big screen. I liked the book - I thought it was quite good in the story telling, albeit poorly written sentence by sentence. Although, I have to say I think it was way over-hyped as a book - I don't really understand the craze for it the past 2 years.

But the movie adaptation - what a bore! I almost fell asleep in a few parts. The acting, especially that of Hanks and Tautou - both seem like cardboard cutouts, reading a very lame script. Tautou, especially - uttering the same few french words under her breath at just about every pouting scene she plays. Hanks too. "Oh my God - a rose" - when he first sees the cryptex box. Looks like a cheesy Chinese box, with what looks much more like a white petunia than a rose - hardly an 'Oh my God' moment. This sort of thing repeats and repeats and repeats. I've never seen Hanks so dull and lifeless in a film.

I think the problem with making a movie of such a book is that there is so much information (whether fact or fiction) doled out in the book that you can digest at your leisure - perhaps even rereading a section or two to make sure you got it all. But in a movie, that sort of thing comes off as stiff and force-fed - the actors are made to feed out this information in scenes that come off as totally unnatural. It just seems dull and forced.

The whole thing culminates in a cheesy end scene that is just over the top in trying to convey deep 'oh my God' thought and emotion, and to me just seems silly and trying too hard to be dramatic.

I wanted to like this movie, but I have no intention of buying the DVD and really don't care to see it again. Too bad.

title: I liked the book more
review:
They had the chance to make this movie more better, and they didn't.

This movie is interesting but there is no intrigue, the actors, and they are great actors, played poorly in this movie...with a lack of reaction...and...it was kinda boring...like I said...the book was more great.

Some effects were nice, the myth was good...actually I get a message that my comment does not contain enough lines :)) because the minimum length for comments is 10 lines of text...but I don't have anything else to say about this movie, sorry...there's nothing else...

Hmm...so....how is everybody?...any chance to change this rule about the 10 minimum length for comments?...

title: Croissant hamburger with some porridge
review: Writing a action/adventure book based on a conspiracy theory, in principle, is a bad idea. But when you make a movie based on that very book you get a recipe for disaster. I don't know if you heard about this but there is a conspiracy theory concerning the Beatles; it basically suggests that starting with Seargent Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band - LP, the original Beatles were replaced, and this theory is supported by "facts". Now imagine you would make a adventure novel and movie out of this. Imagine having a scene where outside the studio where the historic Let It Be is being recorded, the "real" Paul McCartney would try to take out the new Paul McCartney with a sniper rifle. You get the picture here? Now Da Vinci's Code is really an unimaginative book and film. It "steals" a very well known conspiracy theory, turns it into a freaking circus, done in bad taste. Clichés and kitsch hit you every 5 minutes. The French look disgustingly boring.... "French-like", the American is a brilliant intellectual (completely opposed to the obnoxious hoards of American tourists visiting Europe, ;)) and the English was so "typical" English that he managed to get on my nerves in the first 2 minutes. I hate clichés, and this movie is full of it. And then you have the "action". It's supposed to be a roller-coaster ride but it looked like a cheap predictable TV-show episode. I won't go in the conspiracy theory and I won't rant about the reason why the book and the movie were so successful because I really don't want to offend people. But I will say this: for a movie that is supposed to be bold and a a sort of taboo-breaker, the almost complete silence regarding MASONS and FREEMASONRY is pathetic. I mean, what were the movie-makers afraid of? They can mention that Jesus had a sex-life but let's not talk about Masons cuz I guess it's taboo. Booooooo!.Those Masons are soooo tabooooo !!! Booooo!!!!!!! Jesus!. I mean Jesus, Mary and Tautou !!!! Boooooo!!!!!! P.S.1 point is for the actors, who really kept me awake. Cuz the movie was a sleeper. Zzzzzzz!!!!!!

title: it's fiction!!!!!!!!!!
review: i don't understand why people take this movie seriously. it's fiction novel for God's sake!!! F-I-C-T-I-O-N! it's sad that people don't see the real movie beneath it. while everybody wrote that book was great, all journalists and writers, i can't see why the movie is considered to be awful. and let's face it, those reviews were written by theologists and the Church and they are trying to effect others. they don't understand that this is a movie not something that can destroy Catholic church. if they are such great believers, they shouldn't find this movie as a threat. there are a lot of other movies that are a lot worse than The da Vinci Code and Church don't find them offensive. why? because they are not no.1 at box office, and they didn't draw so much attention as The da Vinci Code did. people should understand that this is a movie, and as i recall it never said "based on true story" so what's the fuss all about???

title: Solemn and gloomy.
review: "The Da Vinci Code" was OK. It wasn't a great movie and I don't think the book could be made into a great movie. The book was too much about ideas, word games, anagrams and puzzles that are better read than seen. The movie suffered from too much dialog used to explain the plot. Movies are visual and time taken for long swathes of dialog tends to be boring. In this movie Ron Howard chose to fill the exposition periods with many jump shots and extreme close-ups that I found irritating. In fact the movie is filled with jerky cuts and extreme close-ups. Given the lure of the locales used in the movie I expected to see some nice shots of the Louvre and old cathedrals but what I got was some quick overall establishing shots then it was back to the extreme close-ups and jerky camera. Why make a big deal about where the movie was filmed and then hardly use the setting. Most of the shots in the Louvre could have been done in my family room. Put some old painting on the wall with the actor's head in front of it and presto a museum shot. I disliked the look of the movie. It was very dark and gloomy and the active camera work tended to be irritating. The latest trend in movies is to have a very mobile, jerky camera maybe used to add interest to an otherwise boring scene but for me it detracts from the scene and cheapens the movie. If you need a mobile camera to keep the audience entertained maybe you should rethink the scene. Many, many, many wonderful movie scenes were filmed using a static camera where the actors created the interest not the motion. Tom Hanks was miscast. I like his work but he is best as an everyman caught up in extraordinary circumstances not as a supposed expert who looks mostly befuddled. Audrey Tautou was OK. She is attractive and did a competent job but there was no spark in her performance. Ian McKellen was the best thing in this movie and scenes containing him were highlights. The rest of the cast was competent and forgettable. Given the hype of the book this movie could never live up to the expectations. Unless my watery coke got turned to wine or I was levitated out of my seat the movie would have been a let down. I read the book, ( a good airplane book, not at all great literature), and I wonder if the movie would have been better watched cold. I based my rating on the movie alone since most movies made from books are a disappointment. I would have probably been more entertained if the story line was discovered as the movie unfolded instead of being known and anticipated. It's worth a watch but it is flawed.

title: Very Disappointed!!
review: I think Dan Brown is a brilliant writer. I loved the story, and the fact that it is making people think and debate is a major bonus! However, I felt the movie did not capture the intensity or the heart of the book. Making a successful movie out of a book this huge is not an easy task. I feel everyone involved did the best with what they had. But they did not have enough to work with. I believe it might have worked if people could sit through a 6 hour film, but even then I have my doubts that this story could be properly told in movie form. I do need to say, I loved watching all the buildings, the paintings, all the sets. Those things were the highlight of this film for me.

title: Code blue
review:
'The Da Vinci Code' was a big bestseller, not, generally, a sign of great literary merit. The author Dan Brown's method, as well as one can detect from the Ron Howard movie version, is to bombard you with arcane-sounding information about Christianity, the divinity of Jesus, signs and symbols, the Priory, the Knights Templar, Opus Dei, and of course Leonardo Da Vinci, who's woven in as an officer of the Priory and unifies the story, to a degree, because it begins with a murder in the Louvre (wasn't Da Vinci an artist? and doesn't he have a painting or two in the Louvre?) -- and to add absurd and quite unbelievable twists, in the interest of -- what, exactly? Well, keeping the story going, I guess. Some who read the book say it looks very foolish on screen. Yes, it does. One doesn't need to read the book to see that. One wonders if this movie will bury the book or revive it. Certainly with the libel trial in London and the pore-opening publicity about "anti-Christian" content, the book has so far done well for the movie's box office.

What's 'The Da Vinci Code' a story about, exactly? It could be regarded as simply a murder mystery, but it's both much more ambitious and much less successful than the usual detective story. Brown's revisionist account of the Council of Nicaea and claim, at least for the purposes of the novel, that Christ's divinity was a matter of general dispute at the time of the Emperor Constantine, and that Jesus started a blood line with Mary Magdalene, that this was covered up, that the Holy Grail is really a feminine symbol -- the blasphemy gets lost in absurdity and the tangled web adds up to very little, but it keeps Ron Howard and hapless viewers busy and befuddled for two and a half hours. All of this is too preposterous and silly to deserve to be considered a threat to anyone's faith, but the fact that Christians have objected to Brown's book and to its being made into a movie has been amply capitalized upon by the Hollywood promoters (See Frank Rich on the op ed page of Sunday's NYTimes -- May 21, 2006).

What happens? A guy gets murdered, pursued by a faceless monk, and flays himself on the floor of the museum. A Harvard professor and expert on symbols named Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) who's conveniently in Paris to give a big lecture (conveniently in English) is summoned by a certain French detective (soon replaced by the main detective, Bezu Fache, i.e., the trusty Jean Reno -- looking bloated, and wasted here) to help out with the symbolism of the cuts the murdered gentleman has made in his body -- and the story is on its jagged way. Clever Prof. Langdon may be, but he needs help, and it comes in the form of a French police cryptographer, Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou).

Langdon and Neveu proceed to lecture each other through the rest of the movie, augmented by an old friend of Langdon's, Sir Leigh Teabing (Ian McClellan, who shouldn't be here; but who should?), a sort of expert on the Holy Grail who's supposedly in search of that mythical object. What sinks the movie for any intelligent viewer is that it treats us as idiots. It explains the obvious and claims the most ludicrous absurdities to be true.

Brown's story demonizes the "prelature" known as Opus Dei, to a degree toned down, it's said, in the movie -- but Opus Dei in the movie still includes homicidal self-flagellating monks, most notably the albino madman Silas (Paul Bettany), whose use of the cilice, a way of digging nails in one's leg, is gruesomely illustrated in a scene that would appeal to any masochist and shows off Bettany's hunky nakedness. Silas comes in every so often to start up our pulses, which tend to die down with all the tedious explanations that make up the bulk of the movie.

Langdon is a professor of "symbology," which Walter Chaw accurately describes as "a malapropism invented by idiots so as not to confuse their flock with real words like 'semiotics' or 'epistemology.'" He's a debased -- horribly debased -- version of Joseph Campbell -- as if Campbell's unifying humanism were reducible to riddles and word games. The movie does a bit better with its monsters -- Silas, and a couple of initially kindly-seeming figures. But the screen-time belongs to the boring explainers, and Hanks and Tautou make the least sexy couple imaginable.

Reno's casting as a daring detective in a mystery involving murderous monks makes a kind of mindless casting sense, since he played the same thing -- in the person of the intrepid Commissioner Niemans in Matthieu Kassovitz's rousing horror-actioner 'Crimson Rivers.' The sequel, ably directed for visuals by Olivier Dahan but less well for character, also stars Reno as Niemans and is full of FACELESS, HOMICIDAL MONKS. Either of the 'Crimson Rivers' films provides five times the satisfaction of the talky, absurd 'Da Vinci Code.'

title: You can't put a book in a film camera Ron...
review:
I think with this film they were trying to translate from page to screen as accurately as possible. However this approach not only bores those who've already read it, but those who knew nothing about it. Small changes are made just because it cuts a few corners and because the book was actually a sequel so Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) isn't greatly developed.

In theory the cast is really great but the character work is so paper thin(pun intended) they all look rather rather bored, Hanks especially who is bland and uninvolved. Jean Reno comes out OK as bullish detective Bezu Fache and Sir Ian Mckellan does well with what he has.

On a technical level and I don't know if it's just me but the focus pulling seemed really bad and the one action scene was totally botched through bad editing. Suspense was lacking, the pace the slow, despite the book being frantic until the last third and comically Tom Hanks seemed to have magic vision that allowed him to solve everything.

Silas the albino monk (Paul Bettany) was daft and useless, as he was in the book. If he'd have given the flagellation a rest until after work he'd have stood a much better chance. But that's just me I guess.

I was also disappointed in the mystery element to the film, there are so many puzzles, they're solved too quickly and it detaches the audience, plus the exposition is so arduous that it becomes dull and you wish Ron Howard would've had the balls to deviate from the book and rework it so that characters were developed better and suspense can be built. I think they should have been brave and created new scenes separate from the book and taken risks, but then it is Ron Howard, so middle of the road he should get his license revoked for bad driving.

To sum up, this film is not worth seeing if you've read the book, because you'll gain nothing, but you might want to give it a try if you know little about it. 4/10

title: This one really sucks...
review:
I have never given a movie such a low rating in my life but I had to. I am very disappointed in this project for a number of reasons....

First, being a Ron Howard fan, I have to say that this is his first flop.

Second, I read the book and was expecting the same excitement from the movie and it let me down every time.

Just when you think things are going to get rolling the script seems to throw in this overpowering relentless dialog that just slows down everything and flattens any emotional power that might have been created by a preceding event.

The movie fails to create tension over and over again. The acting is fine. The special effects and editing are even great -but the script sucks. I don't blame Ron, I blame Mr. Goldsman. I don't think Goldsman gave Ron much to work with viewing this catastrophe!

title: save the euro culture...
review: I am really disappointed. Under the Louvre's crystal pyramid lies the body of Jesu's bride?? I thing this movie can be better (may be) then National Treasure, and lot worse then The name of the Rose (Annaud), but this is not the question. I've seen Troy, then Alexander, then at last The Da Vinci Code... somebody can tell me when Americans will stop to produce cultural and historical movies?? Shots on the road, rivers of blood, flying and crashing cars... that's the way. European culture, for uncle Sam, is too much. What we will want to destroy again? Charles the Great? Emperor Augustus? Galileo Galilei? I sincerely trust on the UNESCO's rapid action about. SAVE THE WORLD'S CULTURE!

title: Just OK
review:
This is not a great movie and it's not going to win Tom Hanks another Oscar nomination, but I quite enjoyed it. There! I've said it! I enjoyed it. I do appreciate that it's really rather naff to admit to liking this movie, but truly, it's not as bad as the critics made out. I've passed worse time in a cinema on a Friday night after a long tedious week at work. Had I seen it at a time when my brain was functional, possibly I would be less kind.

I won't go through the plot again, so if you are one of the ten people on the face of the planet who don't know what it's about, read another review. The story premise is interesting, and ties together some history, lots of myths and many half truths in a way that suggests it could be plausible...maybe. It seems to get people riled up for some reason I can't quite fathom, but then I'm not a practising anything, let alone Christian.

I read the book, which I thought was just appallingly written (yet somehow I couldn't put it down...) and I thought the movie stuck to it pretty closely. Probably too closely, as some acknowledgement that the screen and the page are different mediums might have helped the rather leaden dialogue. But the action trots along briskly, the editing is good, and the French actors all did their stuff in a suitably Gallic manner. I rather enjoyed Jean Reno's impersonation of a bloodhound, and Marie Francoise Audollent stood out in a small part. There were some pretty pictures of the Louvre's glass pyramid, and it made me nostalgic to see Lincoln Cathedral (a few miles from where I used to live in England) standing in for Westminster Abbey. Apparently the Abbey wouldn't let them film inside, but Lincoln Cathedral will do anything for money and the Chapter House, as shown here, is certainly worth a visit.

As for any controversy - it seemed to me they bent over backwards to be non-controversial, with Hanks character Langdon, and McKellen's character Teabing giving lengthy expositions of balancing opposing views to the point of tedium. In fact, the movie would have been improved by more controversy, not less. Sir Ian was wonderful, worth the admission price alone. Without him, the movie would be very dull and I get the feeling he's had rather a lot of fun with it. But far and away the best reason to see The Da Vinci Code - as opposed to reading it - is because you will be spared Dan Brown's terminally banal prose.

Not too bad a movie. But I doubt I'd ever watch it again.

title: It was very well done.....so whats the problem????
review: This movie was simply fantastic and true to the novel. I think those who dislike the movie have no attention span for detailed and intelligent dialog or are perhaps just put off by the controversial content. Some have criticized the apparent lack of chemistry between the two main characters but this is not supposed to be a story about a flourishing romance between the two of them anyway. I felt they had enough of the chemistry needed for two people acting in a dire life and death situation that demands they move quickly and search to find the answers required to solve the mystery. It was filmed beautifully with the flashback sequences of ancient civilizations that brilliantly give the background needed to understand the stories impact. WELL DONE!!

title: Opie Gone Iconoclastic
review:
Parentally irresponsible scions of Christ, a scholarly academic who keeps saying "supposably", and that obnoxious jerk-off from "A Knight's Tale" as a fascist Catholic albino psycho-killer who bared his fanny WAY too much. We've arrived at the cinematic stop known as "The Da Vinci Code" ladies and gents.

Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) gets involved in a criminal conspiracy that has gargantuan implications  during a 24-hour period he has more revelations than Tom Cruise has social embarrassments during the past year. All the ecumenically iconoclastic assertions (theories, really) that are made during this movie have a stultifying effect on the mind  you start to not care about anythingand it seems like that is the movie's goal.

It was funny because as soon as the opening credits started to roll in a pseudo-mysterious way with the clichéd orchestral accompaniment that's supposed to inspire "profundity" I knew that this was going to be a bad movieand it was (oh boy, it was).

BB

title: An ambitious film
review:
There are three films that come to mind while watching The Da Vinci Code: "Citizen Kane", "Raiders of the Lost Ark", and "Monty Python and the Holy Grail".

This film mixes fact and fiction in much the same way that "Citizen Kane" portrayed the life of William Randolph Hearst: it's not close to being accurate, but there is enough truth to be compelling.

The film is really an adventure/mystery in the style of "Raiders": An expert in history becomes part of history itself. This film is a nice travelogue. You find yourself wanting to visit Paris, London and the Holy Land.

What makes this film unique is that it ties together two of the most fascinating and extraordinary figures in history: Christ and Da Vinci.

When people use the term "Renaissance Man", they are referring to someone who is extremely accomplished in many fields, and the archetype is, of course, Leonardo Da Vinci. Not only did he create two of the greatest paintings ever ("The Mona Lisa" and "The Last Supper"), but he was a great inventor and excelled in many other fields.

You leave this film with a yearning to learn: about Da Vinci, history, religion, symbology, cryptography and cinematography.

The plot and character development is convoluted, but you find yourself constantly saying: "I hope it doesn't end here!"

Admittedly, this film doesn't flow like "Raiders", but would you call "The Bible" anything less than great because you think some of the passages are slow?

title: Ron Howard and Tom Hanks
review:
The movie grossed 77mil. last weekend. Apparently people don't mind being bored, so long as there's a healthy dose of conspiracy theory and slander involved.

Yeah, and have you seen Ron Howard lately (director of the movie and former child star)? Opie now looks like the guy who fell into a toxic waste barrel at the end of Robocop. And how about Tom Hanks? He's looking really good with the long hair and permanent scowl. Selling your soul to the devil for a few million bucks takes its toll.

This reminds me of Dorian Gray's portrait in The Picture of Dorian Gray by Oscar Wilde. The picture got uglier as Gray aged and involved himself in a profligate life. Unfortunately for Howard and Hanks, they have no alter ego portrait to hide the scars of intercourse with the devil... or do they? Hollywood make up can do wonders, and the plastic surgeons these boys can afford now...

"Tell me lies, tell me lies, tell me sweet little lies," but please don't confuse me with the facts.

title: Pretty Poor - bordering on boredom
review:
Sad to say, this film drags on quite a bit. Lots of codes, waffle, symbology, and more waffle explaining the puzzle - all blended and served on a spoon so you can just watch the screen without putting any of the pieces of the codes (and waffle) together yourself.

Romance is as dry as a bone and there is not a lot of any other kind of action either.. what else can I say? Ian McKellen performs quite well but Tom Hanks plays a drab character. I'm not going to start criticizing the actors - the script was lame so let's just leave the blame there and move on.

I suspect that Sony Pictures is focused on cashing in on anything they can market - fine, but I'd suggest they start looking at quality control quick smart. They are developing a reputation for smash and grab flicks that leave the audience short changed. The Da Vinci Code - is cracked.

title: The film disappointed to me
review: When I read the book of The Da Vinci Code had left a very good flavor of mouth, it was a book that enchanted and woke up my interest to me in the reading. When I knew that they were going to do the film I had tremendous desire to see the film. I was the day of the opening and the truth is that it disappointed to me enough, nor point of comparison with the interesting thing that was the book to me. It is truth that is very difficult to transfer all a novel in 2 hours of film but it disappointed much to me because the interest does not wake up for anything and have changed some things that Dan Brown in the book does not explain. In the novel Sophie it knows his brother who was been taking care of his grandmother, for example; Robert Langdon far from it discovers the messages so easily, and thus many things. The truth is that the film was to me very disappointing in comparison with the book, that is much more interesting.

title: Movie somewhat boring and unprofessional
review:
I found the movie boring; like one of those movies from the nineties that immediately go to TV. There was some bad acting from both the main actors and even others like Bazu Fache.

Sophie goes straight for the painting to reveal the key as if she knows that the key is already there. You don't just go for it. Take at least the time to study the painting and then come to it. Didn't you see their faces as the key dropped to the ground? They looked so dumb as to 'what is this?' There was no reaction what-so-ever. They looked at the key disinterested.

Most of the time, Langdon looked LOST. There where moment where you see his face completely, but you don't really get the feeling that he's thinking about the riddle, rather on the next L.A. Lakers vs. Chicago Bulls match.

At that late scene where Fache arrests Theabing, he doesn't pay any attention to Langdon and Sophie. He doesn't even looks at them or says a word to them. I mean, there surely must have been a reason to explain to Langdon and Sophie why he's arresting Theabing or that he knows to what's going on. There was no occurrence of this what-so-ever.

Finally - bad acting from the main actors of the movie. Paul Bettany as Silas showed the most promise of them all.

I rate this movie 6/10.

title: The books is always better than the film
review: Hey guys! This movie should be seen and is good for what it is, but the book was way better. Good point I can say were, the cinematography was great, the locations were cool, excellently shot. Silas frightening entrance in the Château Villette had me jumping off my seat. Paul Bettany did a great job with his European accent. However some questions must be raised with the screen play. Where was Sophie's brother? Where was Sophie's love for her grandfather? Why was Langdon arguing with Teabing when discussing Mary Magdalene in Château Villette? What was the point in having Sauniere not Sophie's grandfather? These things just would have made the overall script tighter and the 2 1/2 hours more enjoyable.

title: Surprisingly Boring
review:
After hearing so much about the fast paced novel by Dan Brown, that everyone seemed to like, I entered the theater ready for a exciting thriller. The fact that Ron Howard was the director only kept my expectations high.

I was rather disappointed as I struggled to stay awake halfway through the film. I could not determine what happened to the fast paced thriller I had heard so much about. Also, all the plot "twist" seemed so standard and predictable. It was a formula film that lack the excitement and fast pace that I heard the novel contained.

I had only read the first seven chapters before seeing the movie, but will finish the book. I am curious as to what went wrong.

The performances were fine, Ron Howard's directing and selection of shots seemed up to his abilities. I think it went wrong in the editing. Some shots seemed a bit too long, holding after the cut was necessary, to maintain a faster paced film. Thus the film never built any tension or anticipation. I am shock it did as well at the box office as it did the opening weekend. I can only think word of mouth had not spread fast enough. I was equally shock at how some critics have given good reviews (including E&R two thumbs up). Although not a bad film, not one of the better ones. Far from it.

title: Quite good, somewhat disappointing
review:
Being quite intrigued by colliding reviews I got about the Da Vinci code, I went to see it last night. It was a full house at the cinema but I got the better of it taking a seat on the floor on the walkway between the main seat rows.

I followed the movie's action thoroughly and I must say I was rather disappointed. It's true that this movie isn't supposed to be a work of art and its main goal isn't character development. But that's the thing: it reaches for that direction. Why do we get flashbacks of Silas? Why do we get those images of him flagellating himself? It doesn't help the story at all, wastes some good time that might've been put to better use in the story. Those flashbacks don't reveal anything useful. Sure, we get to know how Silas got to be with the archbishop, but that's not interesting at all, nor important. When it comes to the main characters, the situation is slightly better, since our finding from flashbacks do contribute to the story ... but ... What makes the movie really dull is the director's never to try and explain everything the characters do. Why on Earth does he spend a minute to show us how they got out of the plane and into the car? No matter how half-witted the audience might be, they could figure that out by themselves, there's plenty of time with the plane turning and all. Why on Earth are we shown Teabing killing his butler? Again, anyone could've figure it out, but showing this makes the pathetic attempt at suspense (with the butler bragging around) useless and another waste of time. The movie is plot driven, not character driven and that's understandable so if you like character development and all, you're better off without spending your money here. Speaking of the plot, it's pretty solid (given the book anyway). Still since the movie misses on a lot of book material, it gave me the feeling that Langdon himself is not so bright (a protector of Christianty's roots raises a girl and tries to train her mind and he doesn't see the light at the end of the tunnel). The movie gives a half excuse as it conveys the feeling he doesn't have the time to look at his partner's past. That's a half excuse because they do spend some time talking but he never asks the right questions. The cast's weakest point is Tom Hanks. He acts completely without involvement and is hardly believable as Rober Langdon. Hell, Nick Cage was much better at this in 'National Treasure', no matter how ridiculous he looked there. Unfortunately this casts a shadow on his closet peer, Audrey Tatou who does a slightly better job. Alfred Molina is OK, he doesn't have too much space to do his thing but spends his time acting. Paul Bettany looks OK, he has no room to really act but does his moves with some style. Jean Reno is OK too, not great though but provides the movie with some much needed humour from time to time. Ian McKellen however couldn't do a bad job if he tried. He actually saves the movie's cast and his character seems the most plausible and 'in-character'. Overall not bad, I liked the scene where Teabing and Langdon argue over the 'last supper'. It's not too much of a foot up Church a*se but it takes a lot of spirit and attention to identify some interesting and valid points of view and questions to be asked.

title: A brave but failed attempt.
review:
The book takes nearly 600 pages. The film lasts about 130 minutes plus who-knows-how-long in credits. So that there was plenty of time for the book to advance its theories and show how the codes were broken. But there just wasn't enough time for that in the film. So we were left with long periods of talk and inaction, then a few minutes of fairly over-the-top action to make up for it. Hence I felt that the film dragged. What did come over very strongly is the frightening belief that if a "believer" has different views from another "be-liever" but one with a different faith, then the second person is wrong  God hates him, and he deserves to be: framed for murder; killed, tortured  who cares? And if you truly believe in a certain God, then it's great to murder provided you also flagellate yourself and wear torture implements. But if you treat this film purely as fiction (which is quite likely what Dan Brown intended in the first place), then it lacks pace and surprise. By the way if Leigh Teabing really was the master criminal (or teacher) he had several opportunities to do what he did earlier on. The so-called climax and surprise identity of the teacher, was just wrong. In book as well as film. This film is advertised as 150 minutes. The credits started rolling at 130 minutes. I didn't time them, since I really have no interest in who supplied the donuts or did the washing up. But surely they didn't last 20 minutes!

(I kept hoping that someone would put a notice on the fridge saying: In fridge, in plastic box, next to the baked beans. That would have saved a lot of trouble.)

title: No kings on the back Row.
review: Regardless of your faith, this movie is difficult to sit through. I enjoyed the novel. I got a bang out of it. The movie? It's for phonies. It was a bore to sit through. No depth. See it if you wish. I hold my opinion. I mean no offense to those who get off at this film, I just ask you to form your opinion independent of a religious attitude, a non-religious attitude, or any attitude pertaining to a belief in the power of human triumph over adversity (this film supports none of the above). If you receive a religious experience from this movie or from the novel it derived from, I laugh at you (sympathetically). Take it for what it is- an unnecessary blockbuster that perpetuates the crippling of American cinema. It butchered the novel- an interesting FICTITIOUS novel- and it lowers the standard of Hollywood releases. Don't waste your money on this one. Just re-rent Pee-wee's Big Adventure and, at least, laugh.

title: failed to meet expectations
review:
Most of us were excitedly waiting the release of this movie. I, personally, expected another "Passion of the Christ" type hit, or something even greater. After all, the book is one of my favorite books ever, and Dan Brown made millions off of it.

I must say, 30 minutes into the movie, and I COULD NOT WAIT FOR IT TO END. I was disappointed. Like the comment before mine said...there was no connection between the characters, nothing to keep me interested in the movie. I was just disappointed. Some of the ending is changed a bit, which I think might have been a mistake.

The movie is NOTHING compared to the book...

title: Good enough I guess
review: I have to agree with others on the casting aspects. Hanks not a good choice for Langdon. Tautou took some getting used to but in the end I liked her, it was if she grew throughout the film. Reno was excellent as Fache, Jurgen Prochnow as Andre Vernet? Oh dear. Molina makes a good Aringrosa. Silas was about right. But to cap it all, Sir Ian as Leight Teabing, perfect. Made for it and acts Monsieur Hanks off the screen. I knew it was going to be difficult to see a film of a book I knew inside out. What makes it worse is that even if I say so myself, I am somewhat of a well read person on the mysteries which the book itself is based on, so I suspect I was hoping for a lot from the film. The adaptation from the book was clumsily done, bits from the book which should never have been lost were and some stupid bits were added. For instance a scene on the top deck of a bus where instead of using a database at a library, Langdon uses WAP on some poor kids phone was laughable, especially as he was chatted up by Sophie. Then the absolute travesty that was the change of story lines. Neveux has messiah-like powers. Also Langdon has developed a gift for making words and figures dance in front of him like apparitions. All rather badly done. The final insult was what appeared to have been a hasty change of story. When Langdon and Neveux get to Rosslyn, the young lad who should be her brother suddenly has no part in the story. The the mysterious Priory members tun up, looking like they had been dragged off the street. The screenplay writer should be ashamed, and it would appear that they had no love for the story or else they would have done a much better job. I'm surprised if Dan Brown likes what has been done to it. Should a film of Angels and Demons ever be made, please keep Tom Hanks and Ron Howard should be kept well away. Onle last thing, the dialogue, oh please, "Godspeed" from Robert Langdon at the end. I cringed. Who on earth was responsible for that. The 7 out of 10 I gave this film were for my passion on this subject and for the performances of Sir Ian and Reno. The plot changes and terrible dialogue are almost unforgivable.

title: A Disgrace to the Book!
review: I watched this movie last night, and felt like leaving after the first twenty minutes. If you enjoyed the movie then I advise you not to read on because I will be trashing this movie starting now.... First of all, the acting was horrible. Tom Hanks and Jean Reno gave some of their worst performances i years. Audrey Tatou was weak, cast well yet she couldn't perform. Paul Bettany and Ian McKellan were fine and saved the film for me. Next, the idea of having one cryptex was confusing enough for viewers who haven't read the book. The "apple" clue isn't supported with enough background info. and seems meaningless. Also, the fact that in the end, them finding all the documents was cheesy and not truthful. Like a "private" sign would stop anyone. The list goes on about how they inaccurately portrayed the book and quite frankly, I was disappointed at Ron Howards attempt at this series.

title: Worse based on a book movie.
review: Having first read The Da Vinci Code I was very excited to see it brought to the big screen. The book made you never want to put it down. The movie on the other hand made me want to get up and go and do anything but watch that movie. The book was cut up so bad, things were added things were deleted, the ending was nothing like the book. I wonder if the actors, director, and anyone else working on this movie ever read the book. I would read the book over and over again, the movie on the other hand was a waste of $7.50. All the critics were 100% on the money about this movie it was just plain crap. The acting was so flat, no emotion. If I was the author of this book I would sue Ron Howard for taking my book and destroying all the hard work that went into it. If you haven't seen the movie save your self go see something like Over The Hedge or RV, even 99cent porn is better then this. Read the book forget the movie.

title: Good but not great
review: If you have read the book prior to seeing the movie, then the suspense is almost non-existent. That being said where is the charisma? Except for Ian McKellan (Teabing) Jean Reno (Fache) non of the characters stood out as awesome. Tom Hanks was lackluster as Langdon. In the book Langdon is much more suave and clever even if he is a professor at Harvard. This movie did not live up to the hype. While a quality film overall and one that I did enjoy, it was not so good that I had much good to say afterward. Except for Teabing and Silas there was no character that stirred up any real emotions, whether good or bad. I expected a lot more from such actors and director.

title: don't bite off more than you can chew
review:
***potential spoilers*** Ron was presented with a 9 course meal when he wasn't hungry and 7 months later we got the DA Vince code.

Before the camera: Given the chance to emulate Lucas in creating his own Indy, RonH fell face flat at the outset by trying to "langdonize" hanks. Hanks is no Robert, so lets leave all the Indy parallels to rest @ the outset. Hanks was no scene stealer either and was found wanting and misplaced in most of the scenes.

Case in point: Indiana Jones and the last crusade has a scene in the end where Indy has to choose the "true grail" to save his fathers life. RobL is in a eerily similar predicament when Sophie has a gun to her head and hanks has to think on his head to get out of the situation. Compare the scenes, its an open and shut case.

The other main protagonist, Sophie nouveau. We have a lady who in 12 hours(time duration of the plot), learns of her grandfathers death, hasn't talked to him in ages, faces the prospect of getting killed, finds herself having to place her trust, life and grandfathers legacy on a man she barely knows and if the requirements weren't enough, she faced the prospect of being the sole surviver of the man up there. This is a role many "actors" spend a life time searching and Audrey just wasn't equipped to handle it.

The Silas I had in mind when reading the book was an innocent yet tough character. He had unquestionable faith(in Christ, aringarosa and the teacher), he wasn't supposed to react. But Ron's Silas is projected as a man with an agenda. He came across as a doped guy from a crazy cult and the way he "enjoyed" the killing Jacques and the old lady took him further from my Silas

I wont even bother covering Collete, fache and aringarosa. the guys I saw in the movie weren't in the book I read.

the silver lining, and this silver had high luminosity mind you, was without doubt IanMc. He had the right amount of senility, humor, awe, excitement, vulnerability, tact and the lack of it for an aging grail historian with no other aim in life but to uncover the location.

Behind the camera: RonH had a tough act to follow. On the one hand he could have made a docu drama like the ninth gate, on the other he could have made a racy action thriller, a national treasure or a mummy. Turns out he made a very bad decision. The book came with a lot of baggage, not counting the 2000 year old history of the grail, each of the protagonists and antagonists had their own story to tell and the editing needed to be top notch to drive home the point. I will reserve judgment on who takes the most blame for the failure, the screen play or the editing dept, after watching the deleted scenes in the DVD.

There was a lot of french commentary and the subtitles just seemed increase the agitation of the viewers who were already in the middle of a patience test. The team decided to deviate from the book quite a bit and the changes didn't add to the viewing experience IMO. The sensational grail revelation at the château, could have heightened the tension quite a bit but I guess Ron took the safe way out and the viewer was left with a 5 minute grail history 101 lesson.

In the theater My group had both Christians and "pagans" The Christians had the advantage of at least hearing about the gnostic gospels and decided the film was a tame affair low on thrills. The pagans were lost with the proceeding on the screen and had bucket loads of questions

The film fails on all fronts and all were are left with is a 150 minute "im sorry i suck at this" message from Ron

title: Not what I expected
review: I was really, truly, honestly looking forward to seeing this movie, however I was blinded-sided when I realized that the scriptwriter didn't even read the book and decided to write a movie based on what he/she thought the book was about . . . the movie was hardly anything like the book and ending was royally messed up and incorrect. I was absolutely dissatisfied! HORRIBLE. The premise of the book was to state that there were TWO living survivors and the movie destroys this premise. The jokes, which were funny in the book, seemed long and drawn out in the movie. The movie gives away the identity of the 'teacher' before the book does and ruins the movie entirely, seeing as you don't know WHY this person went to the extremes because there is NO detail or Character depth. What a horrible, horrible movie! For a better time, read the book!

title: It was very transparent the the director was doing his best to stay true to the book
review: Like many people I wanted to see the film after reading the book. I actually remember saying to my partner, who had also just read it. "What a great film this will make" We even spent time guessing the cast! (We need to get out more). Overall I was disappointed. I could see what the director was trying to do. It was very transparent the he was doing his best to stay true to the book, and with over 20 million copies sold or what ever it was, you can understand why. I think the film lacked the pace the book itself had. There were some real James Bond moments and these were left wanting. Where was the high- tech barn? or the homing device in the armoured truck? The narrative within the book described it in such encapsulating detail, the reader was gripped. Not so with the film. A few great camera shots. But it needed Spielberg behind it to give the spit and polish it deserved.

title: A Dull Experience, hugely Disappointing
review:
I didn't read the novel on which this film is based on, but I was eagerly anticipating it's release. To Say I was disappointed is to say the least. Ultimately, you can dissect the film all you want.The fact of the matter is that it is a huge failure, Simply because it's a bore.

Director Ron Howard somehow manages to keep the film crawling at such a such a slow pace, that For the exception of a few scenes, There just isn't any excitement here at all. From the opening scenes I knew it. I can always tell from the first few minutes, and I was right on the mark with this one. It just plods along like a train going no where. Believe you me, where's there's smoke there's fire. The world wide critics aren't to far from the mark. I mean did they screen this thing ? Anyone who knows film in the least, would have told the filmmakers ( hey guys your film dosen't work ). Maybe some re editing would have done it some good . I doubt it. And to think, the subject matter is a filmmakers dream... What the hell happen ?????

Dan Brown must have watched this thing, and hoped another Director would have made this film. That's not to say, Howard isn't an accomplished filmmaker, because he certainly is, but he blew it big with this one. The most anticipated film in Years.

title: here it is
review: The acting on parts of some was good enjoyed many of talents that were in this movie such as Alfred Miliano and Ian Mckellon, and the directing and such were fine...however it was the idiot who rewrote the script that ruined the movie...everything seemed rushed and the rewriting of the almost entire ending was plain awful like a spit in the face for those who read the book...is it hard to get a long book in a almost three hour film yes and no...maybe if they would have but the important things in and left the other things out...and with that time or no time the ending did not need to be changed that much....4...just 4

title: Overall a good enough job...
review:
First of all, I totally hate it when people criticise this film on the basis of its storyline....That is THE BOOK!!! So, I am not gonna give my opinion on the BOOK here....just the film. Of course though, I would like to compare with the book at times, but that's different. Let's see: First of all, the main good thing: Excellent acting by Sir Ian McKellan and Paul Bettany. Well done, gents.

Then the main bad thing: The acting by Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautoo. I love Tom Hanks, but whether it was due to bad direction, bad screenplay or poorly written script, his portrayal of Robert Langdon was far from perfect. His lines were poor AND poorly executed. The film had so much scope for facial expressions of surprise, etc and even some funny moments. But it had none of that. Leigh Teabing's "The more penises you have the higher you rank. Boys will be boys." was about THE only comedy element in the film, whereas in the book (and hereby start my comparisons), there were more comedy moments. And I had imagined Langdon and Sophie's characters to have more to do in that sense and more (which would have made the film more entertaining) than just look like puppets / robots. Their characters were very lacklustre. They lacked emotions. They lacked depth.

Fair enough, Ron Howard only had about 2 and a half hours to portray the characters AND tell us a complicated story. But even then, I had imagined better in my head when I had seen the film Which brings us onto the debatable bits (the dark side)...

Was it just me or did the film seem to assume you had read the book? I know millions of people have indeed done so, but that is no reason to assume. Some parts of the film are not well explained at all. I mean, what on Earth is one meant to understand from Silas's flashback of his life?? That would make no sense at all for someone who had not read the book.

Talking about flashbacks, I had gone to see the film knowing that there were flashbacks even to the days of Mary Magdalene and had initially thought it a bad idea, but it kind of worked well enough.

Now the main debate: How true to the book, and, really, does it matter? A lot of the minor changes helped rather than hindered the story telling overall. Most of them made me start to cringe and then wave them off as acceptable. So that's good so far...

SPOILERS AHEAD.

The order in which things are revealed to Sophie in the film is all over the place. And that kinda annoyed me. But it always worked out in the end, so that was okay as well.

The fact that Langdon is made to sound anti-grail-theory (I know, not exactly, but kind of) left me with mixed feelings. On the one hand, it made no sense. Why does he take Sophie to Teabing if he does not believe in the grail?? But then at least that showed both sides of the story for a more balanced view on things in the film that it is in the book. And quite frankly, at the rate some people out there are ready to accept every word written in the book, that seems like not such a bad thing. ((And to those same people: what's with the refusal to believe blindly in the church if you then go out and believe Brown blindly??!! But I wasn't gonna comment on the book, so stop there.I did totally enjoy the book myself)) Then they chopped out a whole bit - in the film, there is no cryptex within cryptex. We go straight to the 2nd one. I agree it was probably needed to shorten the film, but also does not help explain how Teabing realised that he was gonna need help solving the riddles, so attacked Silas and kept Langdon and Sophie with him longer...

And then the last bit: I totally do not understand why it had to be changed. But in a way the alternate ending was not so bad. And not so different really. So I do not mind.

OVERALL, pros and cons (no puns intended). One can't complain about the far-fetched storyline, nor the double endings, as that is how the book goes. Not the best film of the year, but it was okay. Watchable, though not as enjoyable as the book. Could be better, but not bad....

title: Dodgy Da Vinci???
review:
In a packed cinema (it is opening weekend)I waited in anticipation of THE summer blockbuster. Having witnessed several adaptions before after reading the book (Potters all, American Psycho, blah blah) I wondered what the afternoon would hold in store. Especially as I found the book extremely entertaining and a definite page-turner.

The store (unfortunately)was replete with a large helping of average. The practically catatonic audience were only stirred to the occasional titter raised by Sir Ian McKellan, who clearly decided that he was going to get in a bit of early practise for panto season. The normally elegant and alluring Audrey Tatou looked decidedly uncomfortable most of the way through, and Tom Hanks bore a puzzled look all the way through the film, even when he wasn't deciphering a puzzle. He just does not fit at all. Perhaps he was working out whether he's going to pick up an Oscar nomination or maybe he'd left the stove on? Only Jean Reno, Alfred Molina & the superb Paul Bettany as Silas (Yes, I know Opus Dei don't have monks) looked as if they were giving it their full attention.

The film is decidedly flabby somewhere and in definite need of a visit to the gym. Which aspect (be it director, screenplay, editor, leading man etc.) I shall leave up to you. If the execs decide they want another Brown conversion, perhaps the slightly better 'Angels & Demons), then they need to look seriously at some personnel changes, if they want it to do justice to the page turners that Brown produces.

I'm sure it will make the money; it's just a shame that in so many aspects it falls flat.

title: Ugh.... it ... was... so.... BORING.
review: Standing in line for any of the Star Wars prequels, a car driving by might yell; "Get a life!", as I jokingly yelled out of the car at the sting of protesters in front of where we tried to see The DaVinci Code. See, in line for Star Wars, we were gathered in common appreciation, not common disdain or ignorance. There have been many movies I find offensive, but no group ever is boycotting them, or causing some controversy... everything offends someone, and I was offended by The DaVinci Code myself, for being BORING. We got to the box office, and it was sold out, every screen that it was on in our suburban mega-super-whatever plex, plus the IMAX attached and lost in some small corner of this small city of a theater. Just as we were leaving the parking lot to find a different theater, the protesters were leaving... I said to one; "Don't leave now, it's sold out..." "That's why we're leaving." The other theater had no protesters, and no crowd... The friend I went with is from a devout Catholic family and his mother loved the book. He saw nothing to be spiritually offended by probably because it was a movie the waste is that people allowed themselves to get upset by such a bad movie. I haven't read the book, for all I know the filmmakers may have thought the story was a pile of crud. Take all the Jesus you want, and religion out of the movie, and it's still a pile of crud Why? Two hours of ruminative reaction shots, about some secrets that everyone nods because every character knew it already and it was all kicked off by a murder where you'd think there might have been a security camera. Probably wouldn't have thought of that, if it hadn't been so long.

title: Terrible, as I suspected it would be
review:
From the moment I heard Hanks would be Tom Langdon, my heart sank and I knew the picture would sink too. Too old, too lacking in charisma, too wooden an actor to portray the viral, young and handsome Langdon (but not that young). Russell Crowe would have been perfect: professorial, handsome in a rugged way, and very charismatic. Tatou, ditto. No spark. These two alone would sink this movie. And Bettany was no albino. His skin was too dark and he didn't look sinister enough.

POSSIBLE SPOILER AFFECTS Didn's play true to the book. For one thing, Sophie WAS Sauniere's granddaughter and her brother survived. Her grandmother was the women seen making love to her grandfather in a ritual ceremony which Langdon explained to her. That hokum ending with the entire family and group was off the wall.

Plus there were more clues from the scroll than those given in the film.

don't waste time with this movie. Go read the book. Great read on a long airplane ride. Impossible to put down. This picture, however, was interminable.

title: Dumbed down from the book
review:
Overall, The Da Vinci Code was a good theater experience. However, when compared to the book, it was seemingly dumbed down for general viewing and pointless changes were made to the plot. In general, the plot line remained similar but emphasis was taken away from the character's challenges and placed more on character interactions, some of which it was difficult to follow or to place exactly why they were happening.

If you haven't read the book, save the $10.00 from the movie ticket and buy the paperback for $7.99, you'll enjoy the book far more than the movie and hopefully appreciate the character's challenges and obstacles far more than watching the movie.

Generally speaking, it was a decent movie but definitely not worth the cost of a theater ticket when compared to the book itself. Wait for the DVD and read the book in the meantime.

title: A rather dull adaptation shows the flaws of an overrated book
review:
Sorry to tell you but I found it all rather disappointing... First of all, the translation onto the big screen showed the flaws of the book which, however "grabby" it was, let's face it, it wasn't the big masterpiece most people believe it to be... It's an incredibly static movie: there' s so much exposition that it hurts!!! On a book you might get away with long scene of dialogue that go on for chapters and chapters (after all that was the strength of Brown's book: all those conspiracy theories) , but on a film, it all looks and feels rather dull! The few "action" scenes are so badly handled that it's almost incredible they got away with making them and have them financed by producers (The producer is the same guy who produces "24" a TV show that keeps you on the edge of your seat from week after week, with a twentieth of the budget DVC had)... I mean, let's take the car chase for example... It was all done in close-ups and cut so fast to try to deceive the audience that it was bigger and better that it actually was.

Tom Hanks looks almost embarrassed to be in the film bringing NO depth to his character at all... I could hardly care less about him... and (sadly) our lovely "Amelie" is ...erm... well lovely, but she should definitely stick to French films, where she is way better! The Character of Silas is very well portrait and Ian McKellen does a pretty good job too with a part that is so full of dialogue for the sake of exposition that it's unbelievable!

The direction itself by Ron Howard is pretty standard I have to say. He brings absolutely nothing new to the picture... The film is an exact transposition from the written page to the celluloid... but since we are talking about a book that's hardly "Shakespear", the end result feel all rather conventional. Ron Howard shoots everything in a pretty standard way. I have been to half of those places where the film takes place, and all of them(Louvre aside) looked much better in reality, something quite rare in an age of movies looking astonishingly perfect.

Some of the strength of the book was its construction: the way it left you hanging form one chapter to the other... Unfortunately the film follows he same tricks, and it failed! What works on the written page doesn't necessarily works on film. I'll give you an example: in the book Tom Hank's character arrives at the Louvre and is amazed by the sight of "something..." End of a chapter... Next chapter is about something else... and it'll pick up in the Louvre in a couple of chapters... That works in a book obviously. You just want to turn the next page and see what's going on. you don't want to go to bed, you just want to carry on reading...

The film does the same thing, it leaves the audience hanging for a moment... the same way TV series do... like a cliffhanger, but unfortunately it spoils the mood of that moment and ruins it all... It's against everything that movies (especially blockbusters.. which this clearly is!) are supposed to be. Movies are about creating the right mood, making people scared, making them laugh... creating tension... and so on. They are a different medium from books, and they should work in different way. Theer's no need to break the low of certain scenes, just because the book does so. In a cinema, you're sitting down anyway, and you're inside a dark room.. You just want to enjoy the moment, you don't want to be teased by a scene and than pick it up later when you're attention has already gone somewhere else and your nerves relaxed

In other words, it was all too literal, and to sterile if you ask me. And also... VERY LOOOOOOONG!!! The last half hour really lacks fuel... And that scene towards the ending... "I'm your grandmother" Oh My God!!! It was so dodgy. Just like a bad soap opera where relatives show up from nowhere... Another example of how something might seem right on the written page.. but when it's materialised on film it looks very cheesy and rather unbelievable!

Maybe it was because I had read the book, but it all felt very slow to me. But I suppose people who are new to the book might enjoy it more... Let's face it, it's just a "one-single good idea" (the whole Madgadalene thing) stretched for 2 and a half hour of "clucky" dialogue, 2-dimentional characters, rather standard recreations, and cheap twists!

title: The DV Code is Awesome!!!
review: If you like Dan Brown's novels and mystery/crime action movies, the Da Vinci Code is definitely something to enjoy. Besides Tom Hanks (Saving Private Ryan, Cast Away, Forrest Gump, etc.) and Ian McKellen (Lords of the Ring Trilogy, X-Men series, etc.) are both great and talented actors. This movie has great scenes of the city of Paris, the Louvre Museum, and other great cathedrals in England. Despite the controversy on the book by harsh critics, this movie will definitely be liked by people whom either already read or did not read the novel. This movie got it all--great actors/actresses, awesome plot, and great action scenes. It is definitely worth a trip to your nearest theater to enjoy this 2 and half hours of mystery and suspense flick.

title: Excellent movie! I suggest you go and see it if you haven't already!
review: This movie was just as good as the book was. Although I am a younger female, I really loved this movie. In the end, there's the part of him kneeling before the resting spot of Mary Magdelene. I still couldn't believe that they would move her tomb to directly underneath the two pyramids. All of the actors and actresses did an amazing job on this movie and I couldn't believe how well they depicted the book. Ian McKellan's role as Teabing, Paul Bettany's role as Silas, Audrey Tautou's role as Sophie Neveu, and Tom Hank's role as Robert Langdon all just struck out at me. I never thought I would see Tom Hank and Ian McKellan in a movie together. It was an all-time amazing movie!

title: The DaVinci Code is wonderful, intriguing, and suggestive
review: I was born and raised as a Roman Catholic, but after reading The DaVinci Code prior to viewing the film, I feel there is a connection between scientific proof and Christianity. The DaVinci Code does NOT insist on Catholics changing their belief in Jesus, but rather attempts to bring people to be more open-minded enough to weigh the option that there may be a great possibility that Jesus was human. Why not? Jesus was a man, he was human, and therefor it can be presumed that Jesus felt the emotions and urges that all other human males feel. I believe Jesus was a great man who had the power to see things that average people could not see, or rather, comprehend. But the movie was wonderful at bringing to light other possibilities as just that: possibilities. It does not claim that the theories are reality, but instead attempts to open the minds of the closed-minded and embrace the possibility that there are just those: possibilities. Overall, go see the movie....with an open mind!

title: An honest movie that does justice to the novel
review:
I read the novel a month ago and since then had been eagerly waiting for the May 19. A novel-based movie can never be as good as the novel itself. At least I have seen none. Novel has space where locations, thoughts, ideas can be described virtually without any limitation on the number of pages but my friends, this is not the case with the movie. A movie has only limited time and to present the novel in that time is no easy task. With that I would say that Ron has done indeed a great job. I would agree that the choice of the cast might not be the best but he did a great job of making an honest movie that does complete justice to the novel. I would rephrase that Don't try to compare it with the novel but I think Ron presented the big picture and key aspects very well. Locations were amazing. This is not Tom Hanks' best performance neither it is for Audrey but they are not bad. I think the movie has bad rating because of (i) biased audience, (ii) people comparing it with the novel, (iii) people who have not read the novel and could not understand what was happening owing to the fast pace. The overall impact of the movie is superb with the best possible way to film the climax.

I would highly recommend this movie. Go, watch and find out for yourself.

title: A movie slandered for unjust reasons
review:
When I went to see the Da Vinci Code this evening I was bombarded with people protesting from our local Catholic Church. I thought to myself "This movie is based on a man's beliefs and if anything it will make people question religion, putting up the ultimate test of faith, and strengthening them as a whole" So I went in clouded with the thoughts of their sheer ignorance and my friends I have great news to report.

The Da Vinci Code was an amazing movie with not only wonderful acting, but a plot line that should be remembered and revered as one of the greats. "Evil people" (I use quotes for the sheer fact that they are not evil in sticking up for their beliefs), were concealed by the shadows of secrets and deceit, a war which has lasted centuries to either silence or hide a secret is at a point of considerable attention, and the ending is just a shock for even the brightest of people.

Some may say that my review is not accurate and what would a fourteen year old boy know, but those people are only using my age as an excuse. To those of you who find my review helpful in any way, I am glad. To those of you who find it unhelpful, I am terribly sorry, you must quest on to find the truth.

title: Da Vinci is a hit
review:
For starters the film was an excellent adaptation of the book. When the date for the movie release was drawing closer I went and obtained the Da Vinci Code from my local library. The storyline was very original and exciting. The mystery of it all kept me guessing and increased my anticipation for the movie.

After watching the film I was pleased to note that although not every part of the story was told(a happening which almost never occur es) nothing was really lacking. Casting was excellent. Although in parts some of the accents were a little tough to follow, and I felt too many subtitles were used, the movie was very enjoyable and kept my attention. I was leaning forward in my seat anticipating the scenes I knew were coming, and enjoying the excellence of the directing and shooting when they happened. most of the scenes took place exactly as I had imagined them in my head.

As far as the content is concerned, I being a Christan, was not offended in any way. In fact the information in the book and movie actually has motivated me to do some studying of my own on the subject. The story is FICTIONAL and not reality. So I guess if a movie can upset you and challenge your faith, it probably wasn't all that strong in the first place.

I give this movie two thumbs up. The storyline from the movie holds up on it's own. You don't have to read the book in order to get it all, but once you see the movie you will almost definitely want to read it anyway.

title: This film allows for excellent conversation-and everyone is talking
review: As the Hollywood hit machine is in a definite lull, there is nothing finer than a film that stimulates great discussions. The Da Vinci code certainly achieves that and more. Combine this fact with the divine Tatou (what other actress can make the ending seem even remotely plausible?)and no one should miss this experience. Now I am one who really resents the "I read the book first" crowd who will always dismiss a film like this. Nothing is more irritating than this silliness. "Da Vinci Code", which I haven't read yet, and may not get to is no work of great literature. It may even be a well written work of mass culture, but in any case, movies and books are two totally separate art forms. This film works because it keeps you thinking and guessing right to the end, and that is quite an achievement in an era where utter stupidity is worshipped and praised. Secondly, opening the can of worms which is the history of the Catholic church is a delicious morsel for all of us who have been starved for such fair since "The Mission." Frankly, I am rather stunned that the outrage isn't a roar because no movie in years has portrayed these men of the cloth with such a black and historically pointed brush. If you have even a remote interest in such things (history that is), and you can sink yourself into the delicious melange of Paris and London that this movie produces, and you haven't spoiled your imagination with actually reading the thing, you will have a fine time. The best part is outside the theater, because this is a movie that is just as much fun to talk about as to watch. And conversations are to be cherished. Take a stroll and bring it up. You won't be sorry.

title: Great adaption, well worth the ticket price!
review:
The Da Vinci Code stands as a prime example of critics being out of touch with their audience. Despite negative critic reviews, The Da Vinci Code has launched with a well deserved strong box office result worldwide.

While some debatable casting errors and a long running time can be an annoyance, the film remains very well adapted from the book. Hanks, McKellen and Bettany deliver quality performances that enrich the film with both comedy and suspense.

Ignore the protests and the hype, see it yourself and make your own call.

title: yuck
review: yuck. and yawn. I almost fell asleep numerous times during this boring thriller! Very Hollywood, so it will appease those types. The characters are flat, and boring...but it's not the actor's faults because the book doesn't give them much to work with in the beginning. I thought the casting worked pretty well with a few exceptions, however it just wasn't enough to save this thing. I'm not going to say it was completely awful as some of the scenery was nice and the acting good. I found myself laughing at moments that were supposed to be serious, like when Langdon was figuring out things so quickly. I'm sorry but in real life, this just wouldn't happen. I don't care how smart you are, it would be almost impossible to do the things in this book. Again, not the actor's faults. More because the book wasn't very good. My advice is to save your money.

title: The Eye Sees What It Wants- Excellent movie.
review:
Many people did not appreciate this film, and I think a line from the movie very well applies here. "The eye sees what it wants." Many people chose not to like this movie because they felt the book was better, take a look at the book again, you will find the movie offered everything.

Critics have been smashing this, negative viewers should perhaps take another look. Unlike many books turned movies, the Da Vinci Code skips basically nothing. It was just as entertaining and mysterious as the book itself and it left me wanting more. The acting is excellent, everything is put together very well. The Da Vinci Code is absolutely worth seeing.

title: Looking forward to the remake!
review:
Although this movie got its quality moments, it totally lacks the punch that the book gave us. It's far from as fast-paced as the book and it ends up in a rather slow moving chatterbox thriller. Some of the plot has been watered down and what's left is played out by uninspired actors. Tom Hanks has been one of my absolute favorite actors, but in The Da Vinci Code he hugely disappoints. He's in some kind of auto gear in this movie. He doesn't give all and there's few and far between the the typical "Hanks moments" in this movie. But I won't blame him for the embarrassing role, as little in this movie's chemistry seems to be right. However, kudos to Ian McKellen for his role as the eccentric Leigh Teabing. McKellen plays his role so well, he doesn't seem to be even remotely affected by the, at times, poor scripting. Appropos the script. I won't give away any details, but there's some plain awkward moments in this film. Like a scene (that's - thank God - not in the book) on a London bus featuring a random guy on the bus and his mobile phone helping Robert and Sophie finding the "knight a pope interred". And let me put it this way; the movie's ending is ruined.

This movie is hardly Oscar-material and I highly doubt I would recommend it to anyone. Instead, I'm hoping for a remake in 20-30 years time because the book really deserves a better movie than this!

title: Not bad - but not outstanding
review:
After hearing some bad reviews, I was sceptical about this movie. However, I was surprised - but only because my expectations were low.

First of all, I really was not particularly impressed with the book. All comments about the plot aside, I simply found that Dan Brown wrote like an accountant - it opened well, but degenerated quickly into very bland prose. The direction took a similar turn. It opened rather well, but I found that towards the end, I felt entirely bored with it. I expected something with a greater climax - it didn't seem to go anywhere. Visually it is very stunning - but whilst the direction is competent, it is quite bland. The historical sequences don't add much to the plot, and all it does it break up the endless talking.
