Secondly, some of the casting was very good. Ian McKellen was very good as Leigh Teabing, and got a few laughs, although, I must admit that the casting of Paul Bettany was completely inspired. He really was very good as Silas, and his final scene was really compelling. Alfred Molina's role was smaller, but he did a good job with it. However, I felt that Jean Reno was not a strong enough villain. I was expecting a much more powerful villain - although he did impress me in one of his later scenes. Tom Hanks I found also was a bit lacklustre - his character didn't seem to do anything other than run around a lot and crack all the codes inordinately quickly. Audrey Tautou was very gorgeous, but despite the fact that she was meant to be the cryptographer, she didn't seem to have much of a role in the actual detective work; she just stood there and looked astonished.

Whilst the Da Vinci Code just about works on paper, the major difference between the book and the film is that you can't pad the film out with pages of description. Everything had to be explained through talking, which meant that the whole film boiled down to two hours of wooden dialogue. The Latin and French conversations seemed to be thrown in simply to make the viewer watch the screen.

Whilst this film is definitely worth seeing, don't go in with high expectations, and you might just be surprised.

title: An opportunity missed
review:
"The Da Vinci Code" has been a publishing phenomenon. Even before the film version appeared, the novel had been translated into 44 languages and sold an utterly amazing 40 million copies. Rarely then has a film been so anticipated by millions and then so panned by virtually all the critics. In truth, I had hoped that this would have been one of those very rare occasions when the movie would prove better than the book because the novel contains some interesting plot elements but is appallingly badly written. Sadly I have to record that the critics are right and my hope has been dashed.

Tom Hanks, as the American professor of symbiology Robert Langdon, sports a strange haircut and speaks as if he has a cold, while gamine Audrey Tautou, as French cryptologist Sophie Nevue, struggles somewhat with her first English-speaking role and accomplished actor Jean Reno - here playing the policeman in charge of the murder investigation - is underused. Only Ian McKellen, in a rather camp and breathless performance as the Holy Grail expert Leigh Teabing, really impresses.

I had thought that the movie might soften the portrayal in the book of the Catholic Church and more especially the Opus Dei organisation and that it would ease back on the self-punishment inflicted by the albino monk Silas, but there is no sparing of Catholic sensibilities here. Indeed the film is remarkably faithful to both the substance and the style of the book - and this is mainly what dooms it to such tedium. The movie, like the novel, has little characterisation, is excessively wordy, and concludes in a limp and most unsatisfactory manner.

Director Ron Howard and producer Brian Grazer can do much better than this ("A Beautiful Mind" and "Apollo 13"), so I blame Dan Brown. He wrote the book, he was executive producer on the film, and he even supplied a bit of the music and some extra codes. The film look quite good - with location shooting in places like The Louvre - and sounds good too - with music from Hans Zimmer - but it is too long (two and half hours), too dense, and poorly written and paced. In spite of these serious flaws, I suspect that the movie will still do well enough to recoup its considerable investment and will push the novel back to the top of the best-seller lists because so many people have a restless urge to see patterns and meanings and conspiracies even when there are none.

title: Keep an open mind, and you'll be fine...
review:
I thought this movie was great. While I haven't read the book, I felt the way the movie played out was good, gripping. The dark feel of the movie fit very well. The actors portrayed the characters well and the atmosphere of the historical locations was a real treat. It is a very well made movie. Entertaining and a perfect movie to see in a darkened theater on a big screen.

I would bet that most of the criticism of this movie is coming from people involved in the religion portrayed in the film. It's just a big, fat hot button. Although, I'm sure some religious people can see it for what it is. Just. A. Movie.

I'm not surprised that the Cannes crowd didn't like it, just with the dry spell big Hollywood seems to be having in the substance department.

title: Nothing spectacular but was OK
review:
I did think Tom Hanks' hair was a bit odd at first, but it grew on me. I thought that Fache was played superbly and Bettany did the role of Silas justice- I don't believe anyone could have done it better.

i didn't check my watch half way through wondering how long it had left, I was engrossed. I had read the book and therefore waited in expectation for things to happen. Predictably and pleasingly they did- it follows the book remarkably well.

Is it cheesy? possibly, but isn't the book a little predictable and cheesy too. I suppose it has to entertain all those that read the book and enjoyed, read the book but didn't have a clue what it was all about and finally all those people who don't read books but like a good movie.

Overall, it wasn't spectacular, it was comfy.

title: Forgiveness
review:
I was sad to see that a key running theme in the book was removed from the film. In the film, Sophie's flashback to her grandfather's sex ritual is shown so near the end that it is almost pointless.

In the film, Sophie's flashback to her walking in on her grandfather's sexual ritual is revealed nearer the start of the book. This sets a running theme in motion. The more Sophie learns, the less repulsive she finds her grandfather and she builds up respect for (according to this film) Real (more sexual) Christianity and Paganism. In the book she starts off despising her grandfather slightly, but as she uncovers his clues and learns more about the attitudes behind the ritual, she realises that it was really only her own Constantine-Christianity prejudice that made her feel that way and slowly grew to forgive him.

Maybe this theme did exist in another way somewhere in the film and I just missed it. Anybody? ~Iain

title: Amazing movie!!!
review:
The Da Vinci Code movie was amazing. The story line was just brilliant and kept you intrigued for the length of the movie. I loved the movie because of the interesting story line. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou fitted their roles brilliantly.

Silas, the man who is trying to find the secret and save it from coming out, plays the character quite well. When it looks like the end of the movie, it goes on. The camera angles and shots were perfect for the movie. The movie is truly amazing.

I recommend seeing the movie because it is truly an fantastic movie that keeps you intrigued the whole time.

title: Alas and alack.......
review:
Well let's see....Ron Howard is a great and accomplished director, the success of past films has proved that. Tom Hanks and Ian Mckellen are both fine, successful actors, awards and accolades have proved that. Dan Brown wrote a provocative and bestselling novel, millions of copies in sales have proved that. So at the convergence of those three matrices, you would expect that a fantastic film would come forth out the these fine talents and persons. Unfortunately, this is not the case with the Da Vinci Code, and I can say these educatedly as I just returned from the theater. First of all, I am a pastor at a church. I have my beliefs, and I stick to them, others have theirs, and they stick to them. I respect that. I did not go to watch this movie to try to make Dan Brown or Ron Howard out as Satanist who are out to disprove the Bible, I just wanted to see an interesting movie. So, let's accentuate the positive: The cinematography is beautiful. Paris in the evening never looked so good, nor have the outskirts of London. The story line is very thought provoking, and your mind is alert throughout the entire film, you are always wondering what will happen next, and you are constantly trying to anticipate the next part of the "code". That's all for the good. Seriously. Now for the rest.... All of the persons in this film are fine actors, however the writing does not do ANY of them justice, they are constantly over-explaining details that the viewer could easily infer, thus making it more interesting. The dialog is chock full of these over-explanatory terms, so that you almost wish that someone would shut-up and let a moment pass. This is not a spoiler, but the entire crux of the film is laid out in a single moment that happens far too quick, the viewer is left with no imagination. Tom Hanks' dialog is almost wooden and emotionless, it is almost as if Mr. Spock has become Robert Langdon, everything is "logical", and he logically proceeds through every step of the movie. I LOVE Sir Ian Mckellen, he is a FINE actor, however, he too falls into the jabber of over-explanatory dialog, and muddles his natural acting ability. Suffice to say, however, he is the shining moment of acting in this film. The screenplay of this film is VERY poor. Too many impossible, implausible, and inconceivable things take place too fast, and the characters figure things out too quick for it to work. Had this been "The Never-Ending Story" it would be acceptable, but shot as it is, in the present-day, it simply does not work well. And my final comment, the make-up and hair in this movie are completely unnatural. Again, no spoiler, but after a vigorous chase scene, Audrey Tautou and Tom Hanks' hair and makeup are absolutely infallible, Ms. Tautou looks as though she just applied lipstick whilst running for her life. All in all, this movie is, as the other comments have said, a major disappointment. I believe that there is so much story and information in the novel, that the director, writers, etc. tried to cram it all into a 2.5 hour movie, and unfortunately failed. I think had this been a longer movie, with more time to let things evolve, I would have been more satisfied (I hope). Again, this is my opinion, and offered here for your review, I hope you find it beneficial.

will

title: a wonderful movie. I was not disappointed.
review:
This is a wonderful movie. Tom Hanks was not the perfect choice for the star but it was a mistake i can live with. I was reduced to tears when Salis was shot. I enjoyed the diversity in this movie. one moment it would be calm and peaceful and the next moment all action.

It is one of those movies you can't properly describe but it makes you jump in your seat. many people hated this movie. I am afraid to say it is an emotion i cant understand as I loved it. If you loved the book don't listen to what anyone says go see it and make up your own mind.

P.S. this movie is best seen in theaters and also don't be turned off by the choice of Tom Hanks. while he was not ideal for the part it was not a major flaw in the presentation of the movie. and anyway it is nice to see a celebrity who looks aged and natural.

title: so-so
review:
after reading mixed reviews (mostly negative) about the film, i finally decided to watch the movie with lower-than-usual expectations for a movie based on a great book. after approximately 2hours and 30 minutes, i got a little bored probably because it was kind of dragging.

all i can say is if you haven't read the book or was able to read it but didn't really understood the book, you will appreciate the movie. my parents, brothers, and friends who didn't read the book enjoyed the movie and thought of it as an OK thriller-mystery (ish) movie. however, if you love the book, you will most likely not appreciate the movie - which is a normal reaction of book fans once they've seen the movie version of a novel.

title: So, what's all the flap about?
review: Look. Dan Brown wrote a mystery thriller. He researched it using some revisionist themes and built it on an earlier novel and it became a best seller. Good fiction always spins yarns on bits of facts and figures and then weaves them into patterns to excite our fancies and footsies. The more fantastic, very often, the greater appeal. In the case of his novel, it worked. But, is this novel based on hard evidence? C'mon. It's a novel. If one takes it seriously as an exposition of esoteric beliefs, arcane knowledge and sinister conspiracies, that is one's problem. Ron Howard made this film because he likes meaty, twisty plots and got a great crew together to do it. Tom Hanks is great, as always, so is the very lovely Audrey Tautou, Paul Bettany is creepy, Jean Reno is intense, Alfred Molina is sneaky and Ian McKellen is slimy. The film is lively, fast-paced, follows the story line of the book and if anyone's offended, that's their fault for making this tale more out than the novel it is. The end product is an entertaining movie and thanks again, Ron Howard, for giving me my money's worth.

title: never judge a book by its movie
review: I just got home from seeing the DaVinci Code. It was good but.......yes a caveat. I'm not sure why Ron Howard added material to the end but it would have been a much better and stronger movie if he had just let people use their imaginations. Up until the last 20-25 minutes the movie was going along swimmingly and, I thought, pretty well done. It had taken most of the important scenes from the book and translated them fairly well to screen. But then he re-wrote the ending. What was that for? Sophie ended up more of a pretty face than the intelligent cryptographer she was in the book but still the character was good. I thought Tom Hanks did a pretty fair job but it was Paul Bettany that made me jump in one scene. He did a really scary villain in Firewall and his Silas in this movie was just as scary. All in all this was not the best movie I've seen this year but it was OK.

title: not really sure what to make of it
review:
i am one of those who read the book before the movie was released and was thoroughly excited when i heard it was being made into a movie with 2 actors i was very familiar with and liked, Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou.

When i heard Robert Langdon was to be played by Tom Hanks i was shocked, like most people, because hes not the dashing lecturer that was described in the book, however Hanks still gave a good performance.

i must say I'm not sure whether it was the hype, the fact that I've read the book and new what was going to happen, or whether it was just, not a very well made movie that left me feeling quite empty when walking out of the cinema. The movie just didn't seam to have the excitement or the thrill of the book.

the movie was still bearable until the last 30 minutes, the last part of the story just seamed to drag and drag, as if they were using time to justify the pricing of movies, to make the viewers feel like the money was well spent as the got 2hrs 20min movie. The movie also lost the love story between Sophie and Robert.

i advice one to watch the movie first, as one is more likely to enjoy it then, the one would also be able to fully appreciate how good the book is.

to end on a good note, i was thoroughly surprised and impressed by Paul Bettanys performance as Silas, at one point i genuinely jumped even though i kind of new it was coming, he is actually quite scaring looking in this movie as well, his performance was probably the best out of all the high profile cast members, what makes it even better is hes British.

title: A Movie For The Ears Rather Than The Eyes
review:
After months of anticipation, I finally got the chance to watch the Da Vinci Code tonight and I was left wanting a bit more...

I read only half the book and because the release of the motion picture was not too far off, this hindered me from finishing it. The first thing that struck me about the movie was how the casting of Tom Hanks and Jean Reno tarnished the content. As an actor myself I thought that Hanks should not have been cast in this role, however his performance grows on you throughout the movie. I think Hanks is an exceptional actor, but after watching it I think that a fresh face would have been more appropriate. Maybe if they decide to create a movie of Angels & Demons they might not use Hanks again. From what I could gather from the book, the character that Reno played was not what I expected. He seems to always play the French guy in Hollywood movies and I suppose it seemed only natural to cast him as a French guy in France for once. But, I could not steer my mind clear of the fact that I was watching Jean Reno and not a French equivalent of an FBI agent.

The movie itself was always going to be a hit because of the success of the book and as a whole it did not disappoint. It is rare in movies that the dialogue is more successful than the action. But, Da Vinci Code is an excellent example of using the spoken word to its full potential.

The best part of the movie for me was the feudal debate between Robert Langdon and Sir Ian McKellan's character (who never fails to disappoint me with a performance) where he exposes the painting of The Last Supper as being a controversial alternative version of Jesus'last supper with his disciples. 'The eyes see only what you want them to see', is a clever phrase that is repeated quite often throughout.

The worst parts of the movie for me were when we were shown Robert Langdon's fear of claustrophobia. Having already read Angels & Demons and half of Da Vinci code before watching the movie I already knew a lot of information about Langdon's character, but the way his fear was depicted reminded me of a 1980's American Soap Opera. And his fear wasn't exposed until it was dropped into conversation about three quarters of the way through the movie.

Overall, I really did enjoy this movie and I have no doubt that I will be buying the DVD when it comes out and I will be eagerly awaiting the movie of Angels & Demons. It's a must-see movie, which appealed to me more than the similar boom of the Lord of the Rings movies over the past four years. It's two and a half hours of education and entertainment and it won't have you looking at your watch.

title: The adventure I liked not the talking
review:
The Da Vinci Code was a fun movie. It was as entertaining as a James Bond movie. Nonetheless, as The Da Vinci Code progressed my understanding of the plot grew confused. By the two-thirds point I wasn't quite certain if Opus Dei was bad or was it the Priory of Sion. And, exactly where was the movie headed too? Would I recognize the end when I saw it? Apparently not, because I thought the movie had reached its end at least four times. And that finally ending  well, yah sooooooooooo.

I didn't get it.

But as long as I'm not going to be tested for comprehension and understanding, then I don't really care  except for the talking parts. Perhaps because the talking parts 'caused me to zone out into ADD land that I missed those crucial plot points. The James Bond parts though I liked. Silas (Paul Bettany) the albino psychopath monk was definitely a James Bond character. Funny there was no romantic interest between the characters of Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) and Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou).

Tom Hanks was OK. Imagine if they'd cast Leonardo DiCaprio? Leonardo in the Da Vinci Code. Bad joke maybe but DiCaprio would have carried the adventure part of the movie better than Tom Hanks did. And, in the end it was the physical adventure that kept the movie going and kept it fun.

title: Did I see the same movie?
review: Went to the only sold out showing opening night. Myself and the rest of the party I was with really enjoyed the movie. Two of us had read the novel and we both felt that the movie captured the feeling that you were in the story rather than watching a movie. This was the feeling I had when I read the novel, I couldn't put the book down. I was very impressed with how close the movie was able to follow the book. I thought the acting was very good and the actors believable in their roles. If I wanted to, I can poke holes in part of the plot, but that isn't why I go to movies or read books. I go to movies and read books to be entertained, and both the book and movie are very entertaining. It is funny that some many groups dismiss the premise of the movie/book since there is no proof Jesus was married. But it is equally true that there is no proof he wasn't. There is a large gap in the gospels that cover a lot of his life. Who knows what happened? Is Da Vinci Code fact? Obviously not. Is the premise possible? Sure. Do critics know anything about movies? Absolutely not.

title: I thought it was just fine
review: It will not live in the annals of movie making, but I think they did a very good job. I thought the flashbacks were effective and I thought the acting was just fine. Some of the dialogue was a bit improbable, but it was in the book as well. The scenery was great and I certainly didn't notice that two and a half hours had passed. Good movie---and definitely worth seeing in the theater. There was nothing wrong with Tom Hanks' hair (mentioned in several professional reviews)--he looks just like the slightly distracted academic he's supposed to be. Audrey Tatou has been more animated in other movies but she was believable---Their chemistry was just fine. ..not overtly sexual but certainly a warm and caring one as one would expect to find in two people who had just been through the longest night in their lives.

title: Better than the critics say it is
review: I have seen a lot of write ups on this movie from critics who were not very kind to this movie. And, having seen the movie, I DO NOT understand why critics have been so harsh. I am guessing that a lot of the negative critiques have more to do with the authors' religious beliefs, rather than the quality/merit of this movie? I read the book. It was fabulous! A definite page turner. After hearing the critics pan this movie, I wasn't expecting much when I went to see the movie. The movie turned out to be sooo much better than I expected!! Although the movie could not include all the details of the book, it covered the most important ones. And, in a way that everyone could understand and keep up. This movie is a bit long, and though there were a few slow spots, overall, I truly enjoyed this movie. I would definitely recommend it. I was definitely NOT disappointed.

title: I saw Da Vinci code today.
review:
I think the critical reviews of this movie were very harsh. Watching in Vienna I did not hear any laughter or negative comments. Most comments I did hear were of a positive nature. Whilst the script could have been better in parts, however the film did hold the viewers attention, including my 17-year-old son who had not read the novel. Overall it remained and pretty faithful to its source material.

The casting was pretty good, especially Paul Bettany and Ian McKellan who bought real depth to their characters.

All the controversy surrounding the book and movie is stupid. It is a work of fiction, not an attack on Christian values or anything like that. So what if it offers an alternative view of history. A person's faith should be strong enough to take any criticism.

Go and see the movie with an open mind. Ignore the harsh reviews

title: It might be better not to read the book before watching the movie
review:
This movie stays very faithful to the book. Watching this movie was like reading the book without actually having to do any reading, and this isn't a good thing if you've already read the book. The biggest (and probably only) factors of the book that had an impact on me were the controversial challenges against fundamental religious beliefs, as aside from this, this thriller differs very little in its suspense and storytelling than most half-decent thrillers.

It has been years since I've read the book and so the impact this story had on me has had years to fade away, and sadly I realised while watching this movie that it had faded completely. Since this movie is such an accurate portrayal of the novel, it expresses the exact same controversial issues that I have gotten over in the last few years, and so this movie generated very little excitement for me and provoked no thought whatsoever.

However, if you haven't read the book before then you should give it a go because if you strip away all the hype and controversy, it isn't a bad movie.

title: Review
review:
I was intrigued to see the film even though I thought the book was a real disappointment and a waste of trees and time (you can see my book review here: http://angusabranson.livejournal.com/326531.html Saturday 9th July 2005). I've said for a while that I thought it would be a better film than it was a book (which is something I will rarely say as books give you so much more that is not captured on celluloid) so was interested to see the film despite all my opinions on Mr Browns lacklustre novel.

I've also been surprised that the film has been fairly universally panned in the press. I've not seen a positive review of it as yet and many places have called it this years dullest film. I, strangely enough, now find myself defending Mr Browns novel. For starters I guess they haven't read the book. The book is hardly an action thriller. It's a 590+ page book that covers the event of ONE day. The book is slow, the book doesn't give the reader anything real to think about - just leading them from one encounter or discovery of a bit information to another. THE DA VINCI CODE WAS NEVER GOING TO BE A FAST PACED FILM!

I also find myself flowing against public opinion once again.

Public Opinion on the book: Loved It Angus Opinion on the book: " the book is actually about as controversial and ground breaking as a book as Busted is to Punk rock."

Public Opinion on the film: (So far) Found it boring Angus Opinion on the film: Far better than the book and actually pretty enjoyable

Yes that's right folks. I, Angus, Hater of All Things Brown "LIKED" the film adaptation.

And it is an adaptation. They have changed a number of things from the book (as with almost all adaptations) some of which are for the better others of which are not. Maybe because at it's core The Da Vinci Code seems to have been written for the big screen as well as airport lounges. Maybe it's because I prefer wasting a couple of hours at the cinema than several nights reading a bland piece of fiction. In any case I enjoyed the film.

Yes, it is slow paced. But, as I mentioned before, anyone who has read the book should be expecting this. The ideas and settings suit the big screen and have been very well handled by Ron Howard (yes, he of Happy Days fame). Tom Hanks does a fine job as Robert Langdon - won't be getting any Oscar nominations for it, but he portrays him well and once again comes across as a good actor - Audrey Tautou (whom I've loved since Amelie) is still sexy and lends Sophie Neveu an added element of charm and sex appeal, Ian McKellen is brilliant as Sir Leigh Teabing and Paul Bettany is an excellent Silas (the albino monk).

It was odd seeing Alfred Molina playing Bishop Aringarosa as whenever he came on screen I just kept thinking about Doctor Octopus! Jean Reno (who was excellent in Leon/The Professional - depending on which continent you live on) put in a disappointing performance as Captain Fache. I can't really put my finger on it but he just didn't come across as well as he did in the books. This is probably partially because of some changes they made in his storyline.

I had to smile at a couple of scenes (mainly street scenes in Paris) as the director must have done some homework because some of the location he uses (that aren't mentioned in the book) are actually fairly important in Templar history. One in particular near Notre Dame :p

Overall I was surprised by the film. Despite my views on the novel - and the fact that I feel they changed a few of the good bits in the transition - I found myself enjoying the film and would certainly recommend it to people as long as they like slower paced more thinking films.

I can't believe I've actually said good things about this! If you've ever thought about reading the book - don't. Go and watch the film instead. If you want a proper book dealing with the Templars and conspiracy theories go and read the excellent Focaults Pendulum by Umberto Eco instead. That is something that deserves the title of 'Masterpiece'.

School Report: B (Ron Howard somehow made a bland book into an interesting film)

title: The DaVinci decoded
review:
Probably one of the most anticipated book to film adaptations of recent times, this film does live up to expectations.

The plot, in case you aren't familiar with the book, revolves around a Harvard symbology professor by the name of Robert Langdon and a young French cryptologist named Sophie Neveu who go on a kind of a treasure hunt to find the greatest secret in history that could rattle the foundations of modern society. If you have read the novel, I have to say that the film follows it quite faithfully and never really deviates far from the words of Dan Brown.

Tom Hanks may seem like an odd casting choice but he does an excellent job with his role. Convincing and intelligent, he even looks the part well. Audrey Tatou looks simply adorable with that awesome hairstyle of hers. The chemistry between them works well and doesn't go into any unnecessary or cheesy romance. There are also some good supporting roles by Ian McKellen (playing a historian who helps the leads on their quest) and Paul Bettany, the main antagonist. Alfred Molina also shows in the role of a villainous bishop but I felt that they could have given him a little more of a back story and explained his intent.

Ron Howard does a decent job being the director. Along with cinematographer Salvatore Totino they have created some nice dark visuals and used and portrayed the locations (the Louvre in Paris among many other spectacular place) well but never having those overtake the story. There were also some wonderful flashbacks into various points in history while the back story was being explained. At 149 minutes, this film may seem long but that time goes by fast, but fortunately not too fast. My only complaint to Howard is that the film's biggest action scene is like is the case with many films these days, hampered by overly fast editing and unclear camera-work. Hans Zimmer has created a nice score that adds to the atmosphere of the film but never really rises above that.

However what made me very mad was the ending. They could have done something incredible with it (for the sake of your enjoyment of this film, I'm not going to reveal it here) but instead, went a very politically correct route.

Although it doesn't rise to any grand or new heights, this is still a very enjoyable film.

8/10

title: Not a masterpiece but not a disaster either, Da Vinci Code will leave you entertained...and thinking
review:
Every single time that religion is depicted on film, there will be a problem and plenty of controversy behind it. It happened with Dogma years ago, Passion of the Christ not too long ago, and now with The Da Vinci Code. Now, apparently, I totally missed the memo that I was supposed to thrash this film to no end because it's confusing, boring, repetitive, and a written catastrophe of epic proportions. The Da Vinci Code is far from that; it is nowhere near as a bad as critics say it is. While the writing is different from the book (what book-to-film adaptation isn't?) and the directing is a bit flawed, this is still an entertaining murder mystery that requires an open mind and a will to receive a plethora of background information that will be revealed throughout the lengthy movie. It is rather obvious that critics and most of the public were ready to fail this motion picture from the moment the title is revealed.

While it still isn't as shocking or as much of a page-turner than the original work, its Howard's fear of a backlash that results in this being different from Dan Brown's instant best-seller. Like Ron Howard's critically acclaimed Best Picture winner A Beautiful Mind, The Da Vinci Code frays away from shocking even more in order to avoid a recoil that will result in fewer people watching it. The weakest part of the movie is the writing and the pacing, which is what keeps it away from being an excellent film yet gives it potential in becoming an eventual box office success-turned cult hit (The Matrix). Anyone expecting an accurate description of the book will leave disappointed, even though some of the differences are actually pretty minor, and some actually result in the movie being a bit better. Lack of romance in the movie is a breath of fresh air as it goes against the average drama that needs to throw in some random love story in between the carnage. But, the first part of the film is built up way too slow, too much dialogue and pointless trivia can be found all over the place within the first half hour.

Pacing is ruined because of this. Clocked in at over 145 minutes, The Da Vinci Code has the potential of giving you that nice, long nap that you've needed. Fortunately for us, the pacing totally picks up in the second stage, when the two main characters run into a crucial character, Sir Leigh Teabing. After they meet, the movie picks up and does not let go except for a few moments of slowdown. Ironically, the best action sequence involves a short yet satisfying drive towards incoming traffic while avoiding the enemyin the beginning of the movie. But, don't expect to just sit there and watch, thinking is required, learning is required, and so is the fact that this is all fiction and in no way is trying to question your faith. Actually, The Da Vinci Code does not question or bash any religion, it is an obvious fictitious tale. But when a thing such as God and Jesus is questioned, no matter what the circumstances are, we will have chickens with their heads cut off gawking obscenities at the body of work.

It is about Faith against Fact, Fiction against Non-Fiction, Science against Christianity. This is the sort of stuff questioned constantly in the hit show "Lost," but it is presented in a more underlying manner, which is how it avoids the smoking gun of the public. Da Vinci on the other hand, is not afraid of such a touchy subject, even though Ron Howard obviously is. There is an entire portion of the book left off the movie, just so that it doesn't add to the negative hype. Another reason why The Da Vinci Code the movie failed a little is because Howard also underestimated the intelligence of the audience, as his clue-leaving skills from A Beautiful Mind sadly results in the majority of the public figuring out the plot twists before they happen.

If there is a reason to watch this movie, it is certainly for the acting. Tom Hanks though, he really couldn't make his character that interesting, as hard as he tried. Robert Langdon is not that memorable a person, he is just another person jumbled in a religious mess. His assistant throughout the film is Sophie, played by unknown actress Audrey Tautou, whose previous works are mostly foreign movies. The best performances come from the supporting cast, especially the unrecognizable Paul Bettany as the amazingly creepy and psycho monk whose views on God and whatnot is just scary. Sir Ian McKellen also shines as the friendly and intelligent Leigh Teabing. Other notable performances come from Alfred Molina, and Jean Reno. The acting here is above and beyond the average summer flick, and runs this movie when the writing is running out of gas and Howard is taking a break from leaving obvious clues.

Bottom Line: Risky, but not risky enough. Decent, but not decent enough. While it is not a horrible disaster, it does stand just a few steps above mediocre because of a few flaws here and there. A different director could have been better, and a better writing staff could have quickened the pace of the movie and also cut back on all the worthless dialogue that happens from time to time. We do have some Oscar-worthy performances here though, and we do have some beautiful, beautiful scenery to marvel at. While the Indiana Jones movies are much better in terms of hunting for religious artifacts, this movie isn't as bad as what the bitter critics have been showcasing as. The Da Vinci Code: Enter with an open mind, leave entertained and ready for discussion.

title: Book adaptation worth seeing
review:
When I walked into the cinema last night, I was excited, apprehensive, nervous all rolled into one! That's because I love the book so much that I never expected the film to live up to my expectations. By the time I came out, I felt like Ron Howard, Tom Hanks et al. had done justice to the novel, with regards to the time limit they had. Although not everything from the book was in the film, all the major plot was there, so I don't know why people have been slating it as 'unloyal' to the novel! Only minor points were missing, which neither added nor took away from the actual story telling.

The actors themselves fleshed out the characters in a way that I wasn't expected, after reading several bad reviews. Paul Bettany and Ian McKellen stole the show in any scene they were in, bringing real emotional depth to Silas and Leigh Teabing. I felt Audrey Tautou was an inspired choice as Sophie Neveu, and Tom Hanks filled the shoes of Robert Langdon perfectly (with a much floppier hairstyle than expected).

When reading the reviews, I found it highly annoying that critics were saying there wasn't enough action in it... Well it's not supposed to be an action film! Throwing unwanted explosions and gun fights here and there would have taken away from the thoroughly gripping seriousness of the story (Although, to all you devote Christian's, IT IS A WORK OF FICTION!)

Overall, I enjoyed The Da Vinci Code A LOT! Fans of the book shouldn't be disappointed! And if you haven't read the book, watch it anyway! Just don't take things too seriously...

title: Invitation to think beyond the square
review:
Hello, I have just returned home from enjoying Da Vinci Code and I am totally disappointed as I know too few people with whom I can enjoy a healthy discussion on the possibilities behind the script.

This also reinforces my belief that until we question and explore the foundations of all organisations we cannot come to belonging via choice and integrity and without that we cannot mature into personal peace let alone global Peace. While ever we need defend without listening or discussion we will not free ourselves of any teaching that is passed generation to generation via the hand of dogma.

I thank Ron Howard and the entire cast for co-creating a visual version of a story which, with respect, invites question and exploration into the political history of the Church of Rome and the man who stands at its Heart and foundation. I do not feel there is a wrong or right conclusion however I am fascinated when I think of the number of people who cannot imagine that it is entirely possible that what Christians believe may not be accurate and that what is behind their belief can be made stronger by exploration of the mystery.

I hold great movies as the ones that keep returning after viewing. A scene, a word, the music, something plays in my sub-conscious and invites me to ponder, consider, think or feel and in the case of DaVinci Code I wonder what I would do if I found myself in the position of Sarah. Would I set in motion the deliberate destruction of a faith and a religion that sustains many while its political side is responsible for the death of many or would I take up the challenge to find a creative, gentle Path of renewing and retelling the most enduring, mysterious story in our history and psychi. Their is more than one way to view everything?

Congratulations on a great movie which asks us to think beyond the square. walk gently Christine

title: I liked and did not like parts of this movie
review: I have seen much better movies and seen much worse movies. It was well acted I thought and it did make you think. I liked the part Tom Hanks played and while some make fun of his hair I thought it became him. As a Christian it did not sway me on how I feel and believe about Christianity. It did make the Catholic religion look bad though so I can see there being upset by the movie contents. Since I knew it was fiction I did not let it effect my feelings that the religion was corrupt. I enjoyed the film and liked it's ending. I thought to myself before going to see it that it was a fiction and factual movie. It was entertaining and the 2 1/2 hours did not seem to drag on for me. I feel others in the theater enjoyed the movie for what it was. I hope that it does not create static to a younger person's attitude about what the movie says verses the Bible. I will believe the Bible any day over any movie. It did make some people probably wonder about the relationship of Jesus and Mary because of the painting being dissected by the actor. Again it was fiction. I am not sure totally how I feel for sure about the movie but after seeing it a few hours ago I feel it was well made, good acting, but it should not have challenged the Catholic religion as it did. At times it was rather deep and hard to figure out some of the things in the movie so if you see it pay close attention, like no bathroom breaks or you might get a bit lost on the story line. The good seeing this movie may do is to make some Christians firmer in their beliefs. The bad is that it could make others doubt what they already believe and know from the Bible. After thinking and hearing more comments on this movie I might add another post here. Being an open minded person and curious I had to go see it myself. I did not read the book and now will probably not read it ever since I know what it is about. Mary, OH. OK...... back again with a note..I thought about this movie more the next day and I really did enjoy watching it and I thought it was well worth the time and money spent. It is thought provoking, and made your imagination work as well as made you think. I liked the actors and think they were right for the parts they played. I really like the ending and found it touching. I think everyone should see it that is at least around 18 or older and judge for themselves. It was a movie I would watch again. I want to change my rating and give it a 9*****. Well done!

title: A wasted story with lethargic characters
review:
i saw this film last night and was completely disappointed with it. its such a shame as the story is really good, its just everything else that isn't. my opinion is that the characters are just boring in this film, there isn't any fun. plus there is way too much talk going on. it also seems to be one of those films where everything seems to happen in one night. there isn't quite the sense of mystery as film like "raiders of the lost ark" had. stupid car chases which are completely impossible don't help this film as does a tired sounding soundtrack.

there just isn't any characters really that stick in my head. its all very talk talk and no action or fun whatsoever. overall i'd say this is a film thats worth seeing, just don't expect any classic.

title: Fabulous!
review: I saw this movie the day it was released and absolutely loved it. I too read the book, and disagree with the generally negative reviews it received. Critics claimed it was 'boring' and long-winded, however that's because these critics most probably (subconsciously) expected some sort of romantic development between the main characters. I have to say it was incredibly refreshing to watch a movie that focuses so entirely on plot development without polluting and diluting the story with unnecessary romantic rubbish. I do believe however that in order to fully appreciate the intellectual dimension of the story one must have read the book, and that the story is better as a book than as film. One of the benefits of watching it on a screen however was the visuals - when I was reading the book I had to actually google some of the images to make sense of the words! A must see...But I recommend reading the book first.

title: I think this film is taken a little to seriously
review: I have just returned from seeing The Da Vinci Code and would like to say I really enjoyed it. I cannot understand some critics rating this as a bad film, it does have some minor drawbacks in its story telling but overall is good to see in the cinema. I have not read the book yet but am looking forward to it, so my review of the film is based on what I saw on screen only. This is a film where the viewer has a chance to see real fiction at work, which is why I think it has been given some bad reviews, remember it is fiction, so if you can go in with an open mind you may enjoy it. I found it was similar to the film National Treasure, apart from the fact that Jesus was involved in The Da Vinci Code, the film runs much like a treasure hunt, as stated by Robert Langdon (played greatly by Tom Hanks). Perhaps the reason for bad reviews is that the film does go into great detail that it could be called heresy, fiction, fiction, fiction. Overall I found it interesting, and thought Ron Howard has made another good film, and remember it is a film, not real, made in such a way that it has angered some people, like Mel Gibson did with Passion, which apparently was real, you be the judge.

title: Very very good adaptation of a book that INCITES TO THINK BY YOURSELF about the History written by the winners
review:
The DaVinci Code movie contains the most important points of a book that is extremely engaging but, also rich in ideas and raw historical data. And to respond right away to the critics of the History here told, I just remind them what the famous historian Will Durant stated, more or less that History is 10% facts and 90% prejudice (prejudice of the particular historian). Do an experiment on your own try to attend a potentially historical event, such as an important public protest (it is important that the event you attend is not micromanaged, so there is opportunity of spontaneous behavior from the people attending), and then afterward read newspapers or watch TV or listen to radio about that event you attended, making sure you get different sources, and then you will get an idea first hand of the distortion of history, not just of the history of 100 or 1000 years ago, but from the history of yesterday and of last week.

The movie hints to the reasons there are many flavors or variations of History, of an idea, or of an ideal ( such as a religion has orthodox, ultra orthodox, different kind of protestants branches, liberals, etc ) One of the main reasons is that most people tend modify everything to their own convenience, both consciously and unconsciously; and then there are the manipulators who manage to get to control over an idea or religion or activist group, for their own benefit deceiving anyone willing to be deceived and anyone unable to see the deception, into what they want them to believe. Some people understand that deceptions/distortions happened in the past in the Soviet Union and other countries, and maybe even understand that it happened in this country, but few less see it to contine happening in the present in other countries and in this country. What most people do not understand or do not want to understand is that deception and manipulation for power, money, and all other self-serving reasons happens and can happen any place, any time, for as long as any person has any power without supervision. People, in general, do not check thinks up by themselves. And people do not want to realize that every single act we do we do it for ourselves, and that we can not avoid this even if we want to.

This movie by Ron Howard does almost the best that can be expected considering the large number of important ideas implicit in the DaVinci Code book story. If Mr. Howard had tried to include more information, the movie would had been a heavy "forced down your throat" dissertation on history, the distortion of history by the winners, symbology, mythology, and some of what is known about the corruption and manipulation of ideals (ideals as those first expressed by religious and political icons such as Buddha, Jesus, Mohamed, and others, that later on have been used by the next wise guy as tools to become powerful and rich, as most of the winners of the internal dog fights AKA "chosen leaders" of modern religions and political parties in power are. The movie can not include, as the book does, how in the past politics & religion were mixed even more than today, as when popes had armies, and as when people were tortured and savagely killed by the Inquisition and other "self-righteous" and "I am doing it for your own good" movements. The movie just barely has time to touch some of this points, while remaining engaging entertaining. However, there is a chance some in the audience may actually start thinking something new, and this is what the church really fears. Because, that is why the church says the "first virtue" is faith. The church can not tolerate any real questioning otherwise its self-stated monopoly on Truth falls apart. So if you question you are committing "heresy" and automatically out; unless, of course, you have a very big group with you (read market), in which case the church may adapt to you (for example the changes in the official position about Galileo's ideas or about the inquisition, or the recent changes to try to include evolution under the name of "intelligent design"). Or at least it may create a branch to include you (and your market), if possible. An example of their effort to control their people's thinking is that of very orthodox Jewish people, who are told not read some newspapers, nor to watch the news on TV. They are told that their religious leaders will give them "the news which are important and pertinent to them" "to avoid the contamination of their minds" (read the opening to questioning of their minds). Another form of thought control, which is less severe, but more common are the school, religious and others. That is why teaching people to think for themselves is very important.

For those who may begin to question History as told by the winners there are many many books out there, including those about the "Dead Sea Scrolls" which contain some of the several gospels which did not make the cut of the editors of the Bible.

However, most people find those history books boring, and here is for me the main merit of the DaVinci Code movie and book; that because of being very entertaining it has caused some people, which otherwise would had never read or think about the innumerable distortions in History, to think for the first time about "unquestionable subjects." In this particular case about "the History" The Church does not want people to think about, and much less to question at all.

title: A good movie!:)
review: I think that it is a very good movie.Not as good as the book, probably, but it's normal!:)The actors are very "sympa" (in french:) ), and look almost exactly in the way that they are described in the Dan Brown's bestseller. But I realized that a lot of interesting things are not exposed in the film.A lot of explanations are missing, and for a person that hasn't read the book, it's "a bit" difficult to understand what is happening, in fact.I believe that it is one the most strong reasons of "not liking" the movie. But despite all, it is a good work, and we should estimate its beauty!:)Here in Plovdiv, a lot of persons who saw the movie yesterday, think that it is a brilliant pearl of the contemporary cinema!:)

title: Generally good movie without the excitement of the book
review:
The movie is a faithful rendering of the book in almost every detail.

What made the book a real page-turner was the cutting back and forth between two parallel but finally intersecting story lines. In movies this technique is called crosscutting and Dan Brown made it work on paper by alternating short chapters, ending each with a cliffhanger. That doesn't carry over into the movie with at all the same effect.

A difficulty Brown overcame in the book was explaining so much historical research without turning the book into a treatise. The movie has harder time doing this and at some points it sags under the weight. A few things aren't explained at all in an effort to speed the action.

The final scene in which Hanks returns to the Louvre is puzzling. It's meant to sum things up by using the two pyramids in the Carrousel du Louvre, the underground shopping center adjacent to the museum, but it doesn't work. Apparently you are supposed to think this is the center of things at the Louvre and not simply an element of decor in a mall. Anyone who has been there won't be fooled.

One thing the movie does better than the book is the visual analysis of Da Vinci's painting, The Last Supper. On the screen you can show the visual components very effectively.

As for the acting, I thought Tom Hanks was wooden and Ian McKellen a delight.

title: Disappointing...
review:
OK, the book wasn't a literary masterpiece, but it was good fun, and kept the action and suspense rolling along nicely. Ron Howard's determination to stick to the story is admirable, but what is sadly missing is any real sense of excitement.

Hanks looks bored, and Tatou's "I don't understand" face gets old very quickly. McKellen is having a great time, and Bettany does a reasonably job. Alfred Molina - one of the UK's finest actors is criminally wasted in a supporting role with no bite to it. As is Jean Reno.

And will someone tell Ron that his reliance on flashbacks is getting out of hand.

I had high hopes, and they have not come close to being met.

title: The Catholic Church's worst nightmare, Cracking the "Code" reminds me of a long, boring history lesson that dreads on and on...
review:
**1/2 Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou, Ian McKellen, Jean Reno and Alfred Molina. Directed by Ron Howard

After all the buzz and people scurrying about to get their hands on Dan Brown's copy of "The DaVinci Code" and skim through each page exasperating at it's wonder. I for one have not read the book so I won't continuously talk about it in comparison but what I do have to say is, if the movie is anything like the book I won't be reading it very soon. As was everyone, I was excited about Ron Howard's adaptation and teaming with his producer-pal Brian Grazer, how could they fail?

Robert Landon (Hanks) an ingenious professor in the art of symbols is called away to investigate a murder in the (gorgeous) Louvre. With Sophie Neveu (Tautou) helping him along the way, they may find a secret leading them to the paintings of Leonardo DaVinci. Which may in turn shake down the forever truth on Jesus Christ and Christianity. As a cop (Reno) tries to take him down for the murder inside the Louvre, Langdon seeks aid from his aging pal (McKellen). Together they try to spring the trap and discover the truth or just crack the code.

I was indeed disappointed by "DaVinci Code" I was mislead and may have misread the trailer. Most of the scenes, not including the ones with DaVinci's artwork, dragged on and on with no end. The movie was a little boring and not worth the buzz let alone the 2 hours and 30 minutes of Church gossip. If you want a lecture on history, open up a text book and look the stuff up rather then sit in a chair for hours on end watching Hanks in his new haircut.

title: Don't see the movie if you haven't read the book
review: Do not watch the movie if you have not read the book! If you do, you'd be jipping yourself of the better of the two. Out of five stars, I give "The DaVinci Code" movie a three and a half. The movie, in general, is enjoyable to watch. The first 30 minutes can seems almost a blur, as many events go by really quickly. People who have not read the book will probably be like "What what what? What's happening?" I find the movie enjoyable bcuz it's nice to see things that you've made up in your imagination come to life visually. I would have liked to see a bit more chemistry between Langdon and Sofie. In the book there's this unspoken attraction between them that is not portrayed in the movie. I kinda missed that sexual tension, not that it takes anything in particular away from the movie. The ending of the movie, however, is actually better than the ending of the book, which kinda leaves you like "ahhh!!!!!" Also, there are some things that are shown in the movie, but not explained, like the very graphic sex rite. People who have not read the book may think it was a quick pornographic scene to make sure you're awake. The definitely needed to be more of that characteristic Dan Brown elaboration and explanation. In conclusion, the movie is worth seeing only if you've read the book. If you have already read the book, go see the movie. It's not something you'll have a carnal urge to see again, but it's just nice to see some of the scenes in the book come to life on a screen.

title: Despite an awful beginning, it's a pretty good movie
review: Well, another blockbuster rises in a lot of movie rooms spread the world:The Da Vinci Code...As a fan of movies with great investments...of course i ran into a cinema to see that one.. First of all, i'd like to say that i read the book, so my expectations was about a great job, because that story was easy to transport for a movie set...(it's fluid and dynamic...) Talking about the picture, we can see some disappointing things: In the beginning, the story told, was too fast(some people that were watching with me, realized that too),and Tom Hanks, was a little bit confusing in his "work"...he was a little embarrassed with all that speech, about symbolist and that audience behind him, was disgusting..i have to tell...seems like people taken out of streets that never saw that pictures and opinionated about that..for God sake,they were too superficial... After that,when Langdon(Tom) received an advise asking him to go to Louvre Museum, i felt some insecurity action between Langdon and Fache(Jean Reno)...seems like chemistry was awful in the set... In Louvre action, all things happened too fast, something that was cleared in the book, that never happened in that way...It was like Langdon and Sophie were genius...and somewhere, somehow,they had a mystical power to discover everything that happened there...another time...a superficial sequence... In the bank, things get a little bit better,Langdon and Sophie seemed more connected and with some tenderness between them...Finally the movie become to take off, and begins to satisfy the audience... After that,when Langdon and Sophie searched for Teabing, things get a lot better and the picture, becomes more substantial with all flashbacks about Langdon and Sophie lives'...It seems that director Ron Howard could make himself comfortable after that point... Well, i won't talk about the rest of the movie because i don't want to freak out other people that wants to see, so let's talk about the cast: Tom Hanks-I Think he had a disappointing performance here,he is much better in other movies,and with no time to improvise he seems a little bit robotic...just in last five minutes you see how great actor he is... Audrey Tatou: A lovely surprise...i thought that she won't have ability to act with Tom...but she's much better than he is in this movie...Deep performance...a lot like Sophie in the book... Ian Mckellen:Maybe, the best actor here...got all maniacs of Teabing and transported well to the screen...Excellent..I will see X-MEN:The Last Stand,in some way because of him... Jean Reno:An slightly disappointing performance...i fought he would be better...Maybe next time... Paul Bettany:He is perfect...Great...An Oscar nomination isn't a grievance for this man...All movies that i saw him, he's acting great...Excellent work...He deserves stardom... All other performances were good too,and besides that,they weren't so important... Finally,i wish for people that didn't see this movie, to have fun...Don't go with great expectations...this is not a favorite for an Academy Award nomination...

title: Decent attempt, not as bad as what people are saying
review:
When I first read the Da Vinci code I was overwhelmed and captured by the level of detail that Dan Brown went into about the myth of the Holy Grail and the conspiracies surrounding it, which I think was the key characteristic that allowed this to become one of the best selling books of modern times. Given the audience that Brown has reached with this book, Howard had an almighty task of being able to portray such story in a way that would satisfy all parties.

Personally I think Howard did a good job of being able to summaries a novel that goes into great detail surrounding the main plot and still produce a film that keeps on you the edge of your seat about an idea that has caught the imagination of people of all religions. Howard was able to use an outstanding cast and multiple locations to build the grail story and stick to closely to the story that Dan Brown originally published. The cinematography and music in the movie kept you as gripped to the ever developing story as a first time reader of the book.

Special mention should go to Paul Bettany, who played the dark character of Silas to perfection and added to the intense plot of the story. In addition Hanks, McKellen, Tautou & Reno all put in a masterful performance and contributed significantly to Howards attempt of recapturing the essence of the novel that gripped millions of readers world wide.

Overall I think this was a very well made film, with great directing (as always), a clever & yet simple screenplay of the original novel, clever cinematography and music that allowed the viewer to follow the plot and enormity of the events unfolding in the film. The film is not as good as the book purely as it can't go into as much detail that made the book so good, but it was a very good attempt and rendered very closely to how I would vision the novel as a film. Kept me an enthralled as the book did when I first read it. 8 of 10.

title: This movie is a diamond
review:
Don't let the critics fool you - this is the best movie in a verrry long time...

However, it does not come for free: you'll have to do some effort for it. Leave your popcorn at the entry, don't expect explosions and impressive fights and give it your full attention from the very first minute.

Was the book better ? Well, under normals circumstances a book should always be better than a movie for the simple reason there is much more time to build a strong story and characters.

In this case, however, the movie stays very close to the book and having read the book before you see the move might actually help you in better understanding and appreciating the movie.

If then you are open to the story, give it your full attention and are willing to plunge in a different world for two hours (and aren't movies all about that after all ?), you're in for a wonderful and intelligent surprise.

Enjoy ! Mav.

title: Very entertaining
review:
First of all, I had not read the book when I went to see this movie in the theaters. Therefore I have an unclouded judgment about the movie, not having to worry about the book vs. movie comparison. And that's exactly what I advise everybody else who's going to see this movie to do: Go and see this movie without any prejudice nor expectations. You'll find that this film is what you expect from a movie: Entertaining! At least, that's what I expect. I do not want to see art, I do not want to learn some moral lesson, I simply want to be entertained, which this movie has succeeded in. It has suspense, mystery, action, a good plot, great filming locations and good acting. The pace of this film is perfect and will keep you intrigued with the story for more than two hours. I think this was a great movie and I will certainly read the book too, because the story intrigued me.

In summary, I found this a very entertaining movie to see. And if you want to relax and entertain yourself for more than two hours, I don't think The Da Vinci Code will disappoint you.

title: fans of the book, stay away.
review:
The Da Vinci Code is one of my absolute favorite books. Great turn-paging action and impressive yet shocking facts. I could not have been more excited to hear that two of my absolute favorite actors, Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou, were starring in the adaptation.

The word that can best describe what I felt as I left the theater this afternoon is disappointment. The movie just didn't work. It couldn't live up to its name. The actors themselves were great, but the movie didn't flow. It never really picked up the pace and it honestly seemed rush. Before I even knew what was happening, it was over.

People who have not read the book, like my two friends that had not, will most likely enjoy this film. But for fellow readers and fans, see this at a discount matinée if you must.

title: Well Worth It
review:
The Da Vinci Code is an outstanding film. Ron Howard does an excellent job of direction. The timing is nicely paced, the acting is outstanding, the scenes are beautifully shot and the film feels right.

Ian McKellen steals the movie. McKellen is superb and his performance is definitely worth an Oscar bid. I enjoyed every single moment that McKellen was on the screen. This is McKellen's best work since he played Gandolf and he took full advantage of every second that he was on film.

While the church, and the ignorant religious zealots, are condemning this movie; there is nothing in this film that exhibits an anti-church or an anti-Christian movement. The film does show the ignorance of some members of the church in their quest to gain more power over people. The movie shows the evils that religious intolerance can cause when one priest says that Christ sacrificed himself for the betterment of mankind and so shall his descendants. The priests talks about this to assure himself that it is right, and good, to kill innocents in the name of the church. While this is going on, that same priests talks about how the Vatican would punish him, and his cohorts, if they found out what they were doing. Therefore, the movie shows that it is not the entire church, but a small part, doing the evil things. As intelligent people, we see that this is true in all religions. This is exhibited in the news on a regular basis. There is nothing in this movie that would make a person question their faith--but there is enough that may make someone take an interest in Christian history. Is that a bad thing? I do not think so.

title: Good but not great
review:
I saw this tonight with someone who had read the book (very quickly), and they enjoyed it more than I did I think. Not to say that I didn't enjoy it. The music was good, the composition was very good. Ron Howard has carved out a niche or trademark in the "the solution appears to the protagonist using CGI and stuff" for himself. A lot of the actors were on autopilot though, namely Hanks and Reno. Bettany and McKellen put in good, solid performances.

Some things were just a bit convenient to me, not to mention one or two plot holes but I really can't be bothered going into them here. I also don't understand the controversy here - did the Church whine regarding the first and third Indiana Jones movies?

Anyway, there were one or two moments where it seemed like the end but it continued for just a little longer, and character development was somewhat thin but not completely amiss.

All in all, not a waste of a night out, a definite critic-proof movie, although more of an OK thriller than a revelatory, iconic piece of work.

title: DaVinci Was Fabulous
review:
The critics really blew it on this one! I thought this was a fabulous portrayal of the book...verbatim! Hanks was absolutely appropriate for the role...he was "the professor"; exactly the way I envisioned Robert Langden to be...an older "nerdy" bookworm professor.

It was NOT a love story....but neither was the book! I think the critics are just jealous because Ron Howard did it just the way it should be done....a suspense story, nothing more. Not too gristly...but just enough to tell the story as close as possible to the way Dan Brown wrote it.

An absolute MUST SEE!!!! I can't wait to go again next week while on vacation.

title: Da Vinci Code
review: The movie, while good, did not capture the gripping, fast paced action I experienced in reading the book. After reading the first few pages of the book I just had to finish reading it. The movie moved along smartly, but not at the Indiana Jones pace that I was expecting. Tom Hanks didn't fully convince me that he was Robert Langdon although he didn't appear as Forest Gump either. While, in my opinion, the book was outstanding the film was merely good. I would recommend the film to people who have read the book, but not to those who haven't. The film does not do justice to the book. The Da Vinci Code is a work of fiction and should be read or viewed as such. It is entertainment pure and simple. The book and its forty million readers are tributes to Dan Brown's story telling expertise. The movie left out the anticipatory angst to which the always pressured main characters were subjected in the book.

title: Good but not great...
review: Like many people, after reading the book, I couldn't wait to see this film on the big screen. I think in general, for people who hadn't read the book, people will find this film quite good. For those who have read the book, they will realise that they have changed/left out a lot of the film. The authenticity of the film, I thought was quite good. I really liked the way they had the central French characters spoke to each other in French....Small little observation I know, but I like these little things. As for the acting, I think we can all agree that we have seen both Hanks and Tataou in better roles. In the beginning of the film Hanks seemed stiff, he loosened up a little but both lacked the chemistry needed for the role!...Tataou, as well wasn't at her best, but given the fact that this is her first major film role being spoken in English, she can be forgiven!....Personally I thought the age gap between Hanks and Tataou was too great for people to totally except a possible relationship. The best acting in the film came from the non-central characters, being Ian McKellen, Alfred Molina and Jean Reno, Paul Bettany also gave a really good performance playing Silas. In general, this film is good, nothing at all what is built up to be, but still worth the watch. Those of you who have read the book, get ready for some "odd" changes, you will find yourself coming out saying "in the book it wasn't like that etc...", if you haven't read the book, sit back enjoy the story that has caused so much (might I add unnecessary)controversy!

title: Sharing a curiosity
review:
Well, the story is great; the book - as well as most books that explore the same subject - was great; so the movie had all conditions to be great and off course it is. The actors do their job very well, but even with giants like Hanks, Reno, McKellen and Tautou on the screen, what still shines is the story and not the acting - there's nothing wrong with the acting, though; its just the story that is too absorbing!

Anyway, my reason to come here was mostly to share a curiosity: Have anyone noticed that among the Bus passengers at the London Bus scene are Lynn Pricknett and Clive Prince, the authors of the book "The Templar Revelation" - one of the books that inspired Dan Brown to write "The Da Vinci Code"? It was really funny to spot them there!!! ;-)

P.S.: I have not selected the "spoiler" option, because I am not telling anything about the movie story, just sharing a two second's frame that can easily pass unnoticed for people who are not familiar with these author's faces - so, my advice is that you look for their pictures on the internet before watching the movie. That way you can easily recognize them at the London Bus scene.

title: Great Concept Sleepy Story - Mainstream Conspiracy Theory
review:
It was not as exciting as the book where it is page by page thrills. The movie should have been done in an adaptation of Alfred Hitchcock movies. As in all Ron Howard's film, the movie is sleepy at best. I always go to sleep in all his film and the movie tends to be like one of those stagnant films that Ron Howard himself played as Opie in Andy Griffith's Show in a sleepy town. If it had not been for that wide eyed Don Knotts, the television series would have fallen flat. Will, this movie does not have any really great memorable characters like those of Minority Report, the story is slow. I think Ron Howard would learn more by trying to create excitement minute by minute like those of Crichton's books, which are really page turners. For the film it should be like frame by frame thrills. The movie hopes to cash in on one of those "if you think it is true" but it is really really not then I think Ron Howard made a big mistake. Those movies have a uniqueness in themselves, such as the Texas Chainsaw Massacre, or Blair Witch project. Of course, he would have improve greatly if he at least make it into some horror like suspense out of this Da Vinci thing. Now for the conspiracy theories, be warned: Mainstream Conspiracy theories have very little truth to them. For a good reason: they are designed for people discredit the real conspiracy theories, which can NEVER be a mainstream and a lot of truth exists, but will always be an underground one anyway. Mainstream conspiracy theory movies include, Mel Gibson's Conspiracy Theories, the Moon Hoax (many of these), and In Plane Site.

I am sure this movie will spark debates, so I will clear something here to save your time.

Most of these mainstream are designed to discredit them. The more interesting underground conspiracy theory movies that is a lot better are those movies which you know are from Noam Chomsky, Michael Moore, Alex Jones, and a lot of others. So don't take these movie other than the art of the movie. Is there any truth in all this? Well just watch the Real Da Vinci code, which is popularly downloaded for free using your own P2P. If you want a more in-depth really eye opening books just download some underground books such as the bible fraud, the God Code, which are most of the times very interesting. Or the conspiracy surrounding the cover-up of the Dead Sea Scrolls, before a couple of really bright scholars finally found it from some "insiders" who leaked out thousands of those pictures for public viewing. In fact it is a LOT MORE interesting to read those Dead Sea Scrolls because many of these were almost destroyed during the preparation and writing of the bible. And a lot of it was actually omitted. Now this is a place where we can start. Or perhaps look at some underground videos on the origins of the bible where scholars actually showed an exact copy of the story of the bible coming from the pages of Egyptian lores and that was an almost exact copy from the Babylonian ones. Many will miss the point that the bible has something to hide. It doesn't, it just simply left out in history where hundreds of these books were hidden in the Dead Sea for thousands of years to protect historical knowledge from destruction. I therefore salute those who hide them.

In summary of the movie, don't take a salt of truth of the movie. If you want to just investigate and get yourself the movie The Real Dead Sea Scrolls or a British documentary the Real Da Vinci Code. Authors want you to believe its real, to get sales no doubt just like The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. Just sit back and enjoy Ron Howard film. If you haven't fallen asleep in Ron Howard's The Alamo, then you have a good chance to sit this one through.

title: Worth seeing, but not much entertaining, a fall between two stools
review: First of all I hate the critics, who are acting like this. Sometimes they are not capable of judging the movie itself. They hate the book, so the decided to hate the films. They should use good reason not bashing the book. Because the movie doesn't stand on his own. It fails to reach the level of the book. Now it is the time to ask the question: what went wrong? Everything seemed right. Good cast, good director and writer. And just all turned out wrong. I like Ron Howard, I think he is a very good director, but his latest work is very poor. He isn't very brave. He tried to make an entertaining movie and a smart, serious thriller at the same time. But it's a failure in both ways. The script is awful. It's ridiculous. To tell you the truth they're just reading out the book in some part. The action scenes are really short, although the entire movie lasts more than two hour, and it is boring in some places. As of the cast: Tom Hanks was a surprise to me. I think he's one of the best actor in Hollywood, but definitely it's his worst acting ever. Audreay Tatou was an awful choice from the beginning, Paul Bettany hasn't got a chance to act behind the make-up, Jean Reno didn't add anything special, neither did Alfred Molina, only one person did his job brilliantly: Sir Ian McKellen. He is the perfect man to play Teabing and he saved this movie. When he first appears, that's when the movie starts. The first part is very boring. There isn't any excitement, although the book was very exciting from the beginning to the end. Something missing. The dynamism and the power. It's not a bad movie at all, but it disappoints. But I have to admit that it can be a real fun and joy for those who didn't read the book, but I really doubt that the fan of the book will be satisfied after watching the movie. About the controversy: it's pathetic what the Church and the anti-DVC believers are doing. The Passion wasn't a good example for them? This controversy will be make this film into a big hit, although I'm sure that the WOM won't be good. The ending is great. And there are some good scenes, but the flashback scenes and the whole concept is just not working. The music is great, but they used it very poorly, that's why the scenes are not effective. Only the action and the dramatic scenes are poor, what else left? Find out yourselves! :)

title: Disappointing
review:
General consensus was that Da Vinci Code failed because it didn't live up to the book, though I've never read the book, so I'll just judge the movie on it's own merits; this was a poorly put together movie with bad pacing. The plot just felt way too rushed to be enjoyable. And Tom Hanks (who is awesome) looked completely uninterested during the entire film and that hair OMG~! I'd say it would have been better as a much longer movie, except I have a hard time saying that about a movie I found boring to begin with. If I entered an alternate reality where it had a better script and was done by a different director, I'd probably give it a chance. There was potential there.

Also, when I say it could have been longer, I mean it could have been stretched out some while giving the plot some room to breathe, not have another 45 minutes of plot twists thrown in.

The other thing I thought was dumb was when Hanks and Sophie was about to be shot by the butler, and doves fly out of no where. Seriously, did John Woo direct that portion? Though saying that, I'm very much looking forward to Angels and Demons
