title: Interesting But Self-Important And Unsatisfying Religious Conspiracy Thriller
review:
Robert Langdon is a visiting professor in Paris who is suddenly accused of the violent murder of a curator at The Louvre. He is rescued by a young woman, Sophie, who has a hidden connection to the case. The two go on the run from the authorities and are drawn into a shadowy world of murder, conspiracy and religious distortion 

It's best to reveal prejudices first. I think the plot of this movie, from Dan Brown's 2003 bestseller, is pretty lame at best, and pilfered at worst. The concept of a female Last Scion descendant of Christ comes from Kevin Smith's film Dogma. The idea of Christ marrying Mary Magdalene comes from Nikos Kazantzakis' novel The Last Temptation Of Christ. The notion that the Knights Templars hid the Holy Grail in Rosslyn Chapel comes from a non-fiction book, The Holy Blood And The Holy Grail. The closest the story gets to a cinematic idea is that John the Apostle in Leonardo Da Vinci's 1497 painting The Last Supper is really Magdalene, but even that comes from yet another book, The Templar Revelation. So in terms of originality, it's right up there with Not Another Teen Movie. I haven't read the book, so maybe it works better in print, but on film it has lots of boring, talky, confusing scenes where characters argue about theological conspiracy. A woman's figure or a desert sunset may be clichéd images, but I'd much rather look at them any day of the week. There are good points though - by far the most interesting character is Silas, the self-flagellating reformed albino monk assassin, nicely played with a zealot's fervour by Bettany (check him out in Gangster No. 1), and stalwarts Reno, Molina and Prochnow pep things up a little, albeit with rather threadbare characters. McKellan strains credibility however, and edges dangerously close to camp. Crucially, there is a tremendous low-key string score by the always-reliable Hans Zimmer which lifts the whole film up, adding suspense, menace and pathos where there wasn't much to begin with. Without the music this would be an stultifying experience. Like most of Howard's films, it's too long, the action is weak, there's too much dialogue and the style is flat. There are better movies on similar subjects - John Carpenter's Prince Of Darkness or Gregory Widen's The Prophecy to name a couple. Worth a watch, but afterwards, check out Dogma as an alternative - it has just as many religious twists, but is very funny, has lots of action, terrific characters and is a total original, all lessons this movie could do well to learn.

title: Flagellating albino gave best performance
review:
Missed this due to traveling when it played first-run, and hadn't caught it until just recently.

What a disappointment. I know the subject matter and settings demanded a significant amount of filming in dim light -- but holy hell!!!! - with his "A-list" status as a director, and everything else about this flick also in the same top category - I got the feeling that Ron Howard had run-out of money for light bulbs.

With folks like Hanks, McKellen and Tautou, each with credentials in the acting profession at the top in his/her own nation - their collective performances could have been equaled by a trio of weirdos in a John Waters opus. Hanks and Tautou moved and delivered lines like a pair of postal workers who had overdosed on Valium.

The best acting and most interesting character was the albino, psychotic religious fanatic, loosening and tightening the cilice around his thigh, proceeding to flagellate himself, and belting an elderly nun like Joe Pesci stomping a rival in "Goodfellas." If somebody totally unfamiliar with the U.S. film industry were told Tom Hanks is considered by many to be its top actor, and by virtually everybody to be on the shortest of "A" lists - and then exposed only to this performance, he'd think whoever conveyed this information to be insane.

title: Did that old cannabis charge finally catch up with me?
review:
Do you love a good mystery/thriller? How about one that is supposedly based on fact? How about one that takes place in Paris and the UK? If you do, then this film has every thing you could be looking for in a movie.

Ron Howard and Tom Hanks had an impossible job. Making a credible film on the tail of a hugely successful book. They managed to make a film that was interesting and exciting, and it had a great score, and superb sound and visual effects.

Yes, I read the book, and I even knew about the Templars and Opus Dei before I read the book. I also read the book that The DaVinci Code was based upon. I knew the premises and that did not spoil the book for me, just as reading the book did not spoil the movie.

Tom Hanks did a great job, Ron Howard did a great job, Audrey Tautou was delicious, and, of course, Sir Ian was fantastic.

title: Read the book again, because this is rubbish
review:
The Da Vinci Code was a straight adventure story with a dramatic revelation concerning historical events around The Holy Grail. Once you read the book by Dan Brown, you really did not need to see a film about the story, so when the book became a huge bestseller Hollywood produced one of the biggest wastes of money ever...yet it was a hit.

The films crap. Tom Hanks is 100% miscast with one of the worst mullets in Cinema history.

Audrey Tautou is frankly rubbish as Sophie and can't speak English very well.

Jean Reno will always be Leon no matter how good he gets in films.

The character of Silas is wrong. Paul Bettany is too young for the role and looks like a Sith Lord from the Star Wars films.

And when the revelation comes it goes with a whimper and not a bang.

One of the biggest letdowns of 2006.

title: This movie is a travesty
review:
If a movie like this was made about Moses or Mohammed, there would be outrage throughout the world.

But if you make a movie that tries to undermine Jesus and Christianity in the guise of "fiction", you apparently get a pass. Millions of gullible lemmings fill the theaters. The producers, cast and crew make a fortune promulgating a lie.

The premise that Jesus married and fathered a child is preposterous and not based on any shred of historical or Biblical evidence. Even the authors call it fiction - so why make such a movie except to get rich off a mind-numbed public.

H.L. Mencken was right and the box office success of this tripe proves it: "NO ONE EVER WENT BROKE UNDERESTIMATING THE INTELLIGENCE OF THE American PEOPLE."

I have lost all respect for Ronnie Howard and Tom Hanks to have taken on such a project. They and everyone else associated with this travesty should be deeply ashamed.

title: DaVinci
review: I think it's a great movie with a great cast. It might be difficult for some people to understand, but it helps when you've read the book. I hope that someday, they will make a movie of Angels & Demons, because I think it's much more exiting. But however, the DaVinci Code is very interesting, and you get to know a lot about the Holy Grail, or the Sangreal. Audrey Toutou is a good actress, she played leading parts in films as Amélie Poulain, He loves me, he loves me not and Un long dimanche de fiancailles. It's a bit of a disappointment that she hasn't got red hair, like Dan Brown described in the book. Tom Hanks does it great as Robert Langdon. Anyway, this is what I wanted to say about it...

title: Wretched disappointment
review:
This is my first ever review.

People who haven't read the book will be totally bewildered by this lackluster recital of Dan Brown's text. The movie does not stand on its own. It's as if every creative idea had by anyone involved was tabled by committee. My guess is there was conflict in the creative process. The movie is flat and uninteresting instead of being an exciting cinematic exploration of a contemporary masterpiece. For my $8.50, it was a disappointment to say the least - it reminds me of 'Star Trek: Nemesis'; lots of unmet expectations and a waste of top-notch talent. Howard and Hanks are capable of much better work.

The casting is so bad I can't believe it. The albino has blue eyes and whiskers. (hint to folks who've never seen an albino: red eyes and no pigment in hair - none.) Audrey is a chiseled waif, not a woman with words or body that "curved richly". Sophie is green-eyed and has burgundy hair. Fache is supposed to be a guy that looks more like Danny DeVito on steroids than unshaved Tommy Lee Jones. The guy that played Fache looked totally wrong and Jack Palance should have played Teabing - totally botched. Gates McFadden should have played Sophie.. or maybe even Jennifer Connelly (with burgundy hair and green contacts).

The scene where Sophie is in the bathroom with Langdon is supposed to result in the authorities thinking he committed suicide - this is totally botched in the movie as is the murder scene from chapter 94 - which is supposed to occur inside a car.

Read the book. It's a good story. Don't waste your money on this movie.

title: Botox Goes To Hanks' Brain
review:
Oooooo My Gosh.

Sorry this is my first Comment.

Sorry to start on such a negative.

But this is in reply to all the

'¡¡¡¡SUPER HAPPY POSITIVE BLOGS!!!!!"

This Movie is almost as bad....(Hmm) Nah, This piece of celluloid rubbish...... IS as bad as Ishtar. But, Hey! HMV still sells that for £15.99! So what do I know. Take a loved one for a big Steak dinner. Or give your money to a worthy cause. Just don't bother. Also. The Catholic Church is up in arms about this movie.

If only they gave half as much interest to the real issues that the CC Should be dealing with. Discuss.......

title: Watching the lawn grow on Da Vinci's grave is more entertaining
review: Anyone with IQ over 90 will find the movie boring and its ideas absurd. The book it is based on contains a feeble and inconsistent attempt to rewrite history and popularize freemasonry, and the movie is even worse than the book. I can recommend it only to chronic insomniacs, as they may find that attempting to watch it will give them 2 hours of boredom - induced sleep, and we all know that sleep is essential for the functioning of the human organism. The rest of the viewers are advised to avoid it in a wide circle, lest they find themselves cursing the fact that they spent their hard-earned cash on this senseless butchering of both history and the seventh art. Da Vinci is rolling in his grave and as a cryptographer I find cryptographic references laughable.

title: what is there to hide...? the movie was great
review: Hello fellow readers. DaVinci rules...I find that it is very revealing. It exposes what everyone thinks low. I encourage everyone to go see the movie. The movie starts off with action and does not stop 'till the end. clues after clues are revealed and make you enjoy the ride. It's a movie worth paying for - I haven't felt that in a long time. Ron said loud what other think low - religion was invented to control the masses and make money...that's why this movie comes in as a revelation...and wakes people up. I liked the interview where Ron said "this is fiction" - it invites the audience to see it. If the Church has nothing to hide then why are they making a big fuss about it and hide behind 60feet tall walls in Vatican?

title: Protesting?? Bible fiction?? I don't get it...
review:
Read this first, then listen to the audio clip that I've posted below. It's very interesting and will get you thinking.

There are a few things in life that really confuse me. Catholics and Christians say they were taught to accept and be tolerant to all religions and beliefs, but they spend their time protesting a movie where the author has announced that it's pure, fun fiction. How crazy is that! How can you protest something that is labeled FICTION?? Why, because even if it is fiction, they can't stand the fact that it's implying the fictional possibility that the Mona Lisa proves something they truly believe in to be completely wrong. I need someone to explain this to me and everyone else that agrees with me because it doesn't make sense.

Seeing people protest over this movie proves one thing, people still mistaken their religious beliefs as facts. This is no different than what's going on in Iraq. Humans NEED to understand that what they study, what they pray to, is nothing more than a belief, an ideanot a fact. It's that simple. When Mel's Jesus movie hit the big screen, I wasn't sitting at the movie theater quoting scientific facts about why religion is not correct. Besides it being a complete waste of time, I realize that what I believe in is just thata belief. Plus, I respect others and their opinions. It's not my job to change their mind or be mad because they don't believe in what I do.

It's amazing how humans have such a hard time admitting or accepting the fact or possibility that what they believe in could be wrong. Call it ego, call it ignorance, it's almost funny. I'm surprised we were able to convince people that the world actually is round amongst many other things that science has proved which has gone against popular religious beliefs. That in itself is a huge accomplishment for mankind, not landing on the moon! :)

Many Catholics and Christians were angry with the 'idea' of which this movie presented. Has it occurred to anyone that the Bible could be purely fiction as well? If you truly believe that religion is just that, a belief, you must take into consideration that your beliefs, your Bible, could all be fictional and written for control and profit. I'm not religious and have many beliefs and facts that I think support my argument. However, I can't 100% prove it so therefore I acknowledge the fact that everything I believe in about life and death could also be just fiction. The problem is when people mistaken their religious beliefs or non religious beliefs as facts. No matter how much scientific data I have that I think proves most major religions to be nothing more than a form of human control and guidance, I can not 100% prove it and yes, it could all be fictional. That's why I just live my life with an open mind. I'm a good person and at night I can sleep with a clear conscious.

Over the years, science has proved many religious facts to be wrong, and will continue to do so for many years to come. The bible can only be edited and re-written so many times folks. I've been lucky to work with some of the most advanced technologies on earth today and I'm pretty certain the real truth about life and death in general lies somewhere within advanced mathematics. Everything in life seems to always point back to math in one way or another. Actually, the real truth about life and death is probably a lot simpler and less complicated than we think it is. But humans have always been great of making simple things very complicated (usually only for profit :) ) That's for a different discussion.

One quick note, my Grandfather was one of the VPs for Arthur Gallagher, insurance company of the Catholic church. Through him I discovered that Arthur Gallagher knew about the whole 'touching little boys' issue way before it ever hit main stream media, the first happening almost 20 years ago. It's amazing how long it went on before hitting mainstream media and I was informed on how powerful the Catholic church really isnow there's a scary movie! I can't grasp the idea that people can forgive child molesters and rapist as long as they ask for forgiveness from god. The only thing they can't do is not believe in God or Jesus. I don't know about you, but that sure sounds like a great form of control and brain washing. Again, that's just my BELIEF.

It's been amusing to see what kind of fire this movie has caused. A whole forum could be created just for this one topic. If any of you (religious or non-religious) would like to be entertained for 120 minutes, download this audio file where science and religion go head to head. It's great and well worth your time. Listen to it while you work on other things. I've uploaded it for anyone to download. Discuss it here! It's a 14mb mp3 file which you listen to through putfile.com. http://www.putfile.com/evocity2006

Enjoy and always keep your mind open to new possibilities, HiTechBrad

title: This movie is definitely not boring, just bogus
review:
New York Times critic A. O. Scott filed one of the first reviews of this movie, from the Cannes Film Festival on Thursday the day before opening. The film was not released ahead of time to reviewers, which, by conventional wisdom, signals a turkey. Scott kvetched about how boring it was. There is no ennui. The film kept me jumping with ambushes, chases and plot twists to keep my adrenalin level high.

The contrasting scenes between 21st century Europe and medieval Europe in flashbacks are eye-catching. Hanks is low key, but he's usually low key, whether he's a high school teacher turned captain overwhelmed by battle and responsibility or a lone castaway on a Pacific island using assorted washed-up cargo items like a deflated basketball to keep his sanity.

If you want to see how bogus Dan Brown's story is, check out the History Channel this week for programs on Opus Dei, Leonardo DaVinci and other topics suggested by the story. How much more powerful this story would have been if it were more grounded in fact! And certainly a case can be made from facts in the Gnostic gospels and other sources for all that is suggested. There has to be worldwide hunger for a better understanding of the Christian mythic monopoly given how a book with such awkward writing could sell some 65 million copies.

title: Lost In Translation
review:
Let me start off by saying that I DID NOT read the book. So I was expecting a masterful story-telling session of the highest order, given the success of the novel. How could you screw this up? This film was not about the characters, it was about the story and setting. Howard got the setting right, the locales were breath-taking and exquisitely shot. What was lacking however was the suspenseful buildup of the plot as it delved deeper into history's sordid past. Rule number one of a mystery drama, let the viewer take part in the detective work. Maybe Ron Howard assumed that we already knew what the clues were, and how they were going to be figured out. So the action on the screen was relegated to crappy car chases, goofy gun play, and anti-climatic near-misses. Meanwhile the mystery aspect of the film was absent (save for the best scene of the film, Teabing's lecture on The Last Supper). This script should have been sandbagged from the moment Howard looked at it. The fact that author Dan Brown allowed his story to be told this way is a blot on his artistic integrity. I guess he was laughing all the way to the bank too hard to notice that his book was being butchered.

Having said that, I did not hate the film. It still was more thoughtfully done than 75% of the other schlock out there. Tom Hanks, even as wooden as he was here, is still good. Ian was great. I thought Bethany was frightening but underused by the screenwriter (his face being the antithesis of humanistic Renaissance art). The Sophie character was like Hanks' character - nothing special. 2 1/2 hours is not long if the film moves briskly and keeps your interest. Gladiator was close to three hours but felt 90 minutes long. It is all in the writing. Maybe big shot directors will have greater appreciation in the future for the craft of screen writing. Without a good script, even the best actors, and best stories, will suffer

title: plain and simple: not entertaining. has it's moments, but it's too long and not well directed
review:
First off, I am ashamed that this movie did not turn out as I had expected. The acting of Tom Hanks and the direction of Ron Howard always grabs my attention, but neither of these two entertainment giants do well in their jobs of keeping the audience interested. The film also is way too long at just under 2.5 hours. While the film does get strong performances from Ian McKellen and Paul Bettany, the film does not do a good job of keeping the audience entertained, and it is also very predictable, even if you haven't read the book, which I haven't.

The plot of 'The Da Vinci Code' is as follows: A murder in the Louvre leaves mysterious clues in the works of artist Leonardo Da Vinci, clues that when investigated by symbol interpreter, Robert Langdon (Hanks), and a French police officer (Audrey Tatou), could possibly change the world's view of Christianity with its groundbreaking discoveries.

The movie does have moments where the audience will be sickly disgusted, such as the beginning, moments of some intense action, and some dramatic moments, but one of the main problems circling the film is the fact that Howard fails to establish a true genre for the movie. Sometimes, it feels like an action/thriller, then to a suspenseful drama, then a mystery, then totally shifting gears and becoming a fantasy. This is not the fault of the writing or acting, as one of a director's many jobs is to establish a mood and feel for the film, which Howard fails to do, as much as it pains me to say this about such a wonderful director.

Tom Hanks seems miscast in the role of Robert Langdon, and I feel that an actor such as Ralph Fiennes or Liam Neeson would have made the role ten times better. Hanks doesn't perform to his abilities in the film, as shown when he never really seems to take control of the movie, because the whole movie circles around his investigation and findings of the mysterious clues possibly left behind by Leonardo Da Vinci. Hanks is constantly thrown around, and from what I've heard from friends, that's not what Robert is like in the book.

The primary supporting role is that of Audrey Tatou's character, and I must say that her character often seems expressionless and flat, which is sad, because the writing for her character is very well done. She has her opportunities to shine, but simply doesn't.

Now, it's time to give some good things about the film. Paul Bettany's Albino character Silas is just plain creepy, yet you can't help but be in awe of how real Paul Bettany plays the character, because he barely speaks English in the film (Silas speaks mostly French throughout the film). I really felt that Silas was in control of every scene he appears in, while Bettany still provides a good human realism to the character. Ian McKellen shines as always as Leigh, Robert's old friend and fellow clueseeker. He provides a certain amount of mystery about his character, while still keeping him charming and likable (Ian provides most of the films comedic moments). McKellen proves that he can survive any genre with class and style again, and I think that had the film been better, he could scrap an Oscar nod.

There are two other name actors in supporting roles, but they feel forced into the film, and the movie could have done without them. The characters played by Jean Reno and Alfred Molina are both characters that could have been divided into smaller characters. I'm not knocking Reno and Molina, as they both perform admirably, but there is really no point to their characters, especially Molina's bishop.

When push comes to shove, Ron Howard's direction and the acting of Tom Hanks are not up to snuff, thus being two of the elements that sink 'The Da Vinci Code'. The film gets decent supporting performances and B class writing, but other than that, this film seems lost in its own skin. The movie seems to drag on forever, and you'll find yourself sleepy after the resolution, as the denouement takes too much time. I felt severely let down.

5/10 --spy

title: The best movie 2006 ( So far :)
review:

My name is Patricia Prata and I'd love to be your friend and work with Tom Hanks, Ron Haward, Madonna, Prince, Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and all the GOOD FORCE in the Planet Hollywood. title: good movie
review: I am tired of reading these so called "critics reviews", what do they know anyway?! Probably half of the "critics" have not even read the novel "The Da Vinci Code", that is my feeling anyway. I felt the movie followed the book almost to exactness, of course they had to eliminate a few parts for time sake, (the library scene etc.). I want to give a big thumbs up to Ron Howard, I felt he did a great job! The movie captivated my attention for the full 2 1/2 hrs, (not very many movies can do that). My husband enjoyed the movie and he hasn't even read the novel. Maybe personal beliefs got in the way of the "critics reviews" or maybe it was too complex for some critics to follow, who knows? If you are looking for a movie that makes you think and mentally follow the plot this is the movie for you! I was on the edge of my seat.

title: Great Disappointment
review:
I could not wait for this movie to come out. I was so psyched up to see it that I had sleepless nights because of the anticipation! Imagine how I must have felt to finally take my seat in the cinema and having the lights dim...

I became so caught up in the thought of the movie that I completely forgot my criticism about the book! When I first read it, I thought "WOW, what an interesting story! Pity about the predictable "Goosebumps"-type plot, though." I had read somewhere that Dan Brown said the film sticks very close to the novel, and boy does it ever! All the people who criticized Chris Columbus for sticking too close to the page for the first two Harry Potter movies have to be very thankful that Ron Howard and Akiva Goldsman Didi't have a shot at it. For the most part, The Da Vinci code literally translates the novel from page to screen. That is, they translate the STORYLINE, in my opinion the weakest aspect of the book. The thing that kept me reading late into the night was the interesting codes being cracked and the wonderful intellectual treasure hunts around art and history.

Instead, we get the boring, predictable storyline that skips over the code cracking in a "Bee Season" type of way. Added to this, we jump so suddenly from location to location that it all just becomes a blur. Don't get me wrong, the pacing could have been quicker, but at least tell us where we are, won't you! The characters were so shallow, even though Akiva Goldsman tried (and failed) fleshing them out a bit. Quite frankly I Didi't care about one of them, except maybe Sophie, but only because I love Audrey Tautou. Tom Hanks was terribly miscast and his funny hairstyle was just plain distracting.

I suppose my main quibble with the film is that it was done in a very unimaginative way. This is the sort of novel that needs to be reinvented when being adapted for the big screen. Purists may want to kill me now, but honestly, why watch a movie if you don't get anything new you couldn't get in the book? Other than this, it was quite an enjoyable night out. I Didi't feel I wasted my money, but I really did expect more from (Academy Award Winner) Ron Howard. Although, I would give him another Oscar for managing to make a movie feel RUSHED and SLOW at the same time!!! That takes some doing.

And finally, would it have killed the cinematographer to shed a little more light on the wonderful location, the Louvre? I couldn't see any of the paintings, it was so dark! (Yes, I know it was supposed to be dark, but come on! How many people get the opportunity to shoot a $125 million movie in the Louvre?)

title: Tom Hanks' Worst Film
review: Let me first state that i am unbiased when i comes to religion. I also loved the amazing novel THE DA VINCI CODE by Dan Brown. What happened Ron Howard? This movie is constantly laced with dry, boring subject matter, over and under explained events, and horrible acting. Throughout the whole two and a half hours, Tom Hanks manages to crank out two expressions. Mad, in most of the film, and surprised, when he cuts himself shaving. The only saving grace in this film is the fact Ian McKellan, (unsure of spelling), lends talent and manages to juice up the boring plot and pace in this film. I think there were many things wrong with this film. Acting, directing, cinematography... overall i think the film was rushed, and maybe THE DA VINCI CODE wasn't really meant to be discovered on screen. My recommendation, spend your 10.95 on the book.

title: ++==--__Here be Spoilers__--==++ A travesty
review: ++==--__Here be Spoilers__--==++ A travesty Saw this movie no more then 10 minuets ago I HATED IT. Thy butchered the book, they destroyed it. I understand that they would have to leave stuff out but they left to much out to much to write down. But not only did they leave stuff out they added a lot they added stuff like they mad it seem like Sophie was stupid or just slow not fast enough to figure things out like on the plan when see figures out Da Vinci's back words script Langdon figured it out in seconds, or that Sophie's Grand father Jacques Sauniere might not be her grand father and when she was younger he yelled at her, If Akiva Goldsman had read the book he would have known that her grandfather would never have yelled at her or that Captain Fache was highly abusive and that Bishop Aringarosa told him to find Langdon and said it was a mission from god. Or the part at the end of the book where Sophie and Langdon kiss yeah you guess it they left that out too. I'm sorry I went into this movie with a very open mind and left very disappointed this movie fails to impress anyone who has ever read the book if you have read the book please do not see this movie it sucks oh and tom hanks was not even a kinda of good Langdon

title: Well done, Well thought out! Great pace!
review: I wasn't too sure if I wanted to see the film. I've been sick of every film being adapted by a book or something, having no original ideas. And I was a bit surprised that it starred Tom Hanks, don't get me wrong I love him! Well I saw the film just last night and I was engaged the whole entire time. The 2+ hours flew by and it was well made. From the film stock to the editing to the effects and of course the story I loved it! I can understand why a lot of people hate it from the whole flashback sequences and of course the new thought to Christianity. But people do forget that its a story and an imitation. It's not necessary true nor false. I feel that it was an outstanding film. It was a great adventure watching these characters trying to solve a mystery. And how it just never end! of course a lot of people would hate that but I loved it. I personally did not want this film to end! I thought it was extremely well done. I feel that Tom Hanks did a great job. And I think that Ron Howard is starting to step up. The pacing was a lot better than his previous films. When I saw the reviews after seeing the film I was in complete shock. I really feel that this film is a B+/A-. You should definitely see it in the theaters! And I would buy the DVD! Give this film a try!

title: Why do we have film critics?
review:
I found this movie to be outstanding. Maybe it was because my expectations were very low - but I was so pleasantly surprised. I thought Hanks pulled off Robert Langdon - even if it wasn't one of his most memorable roles. I thought the supporting cast was outstanding, and the movie was surprisingly true to the book.

My wife, who had never read the book, thought it was great as well. She was very intrigued by the story line, and like most people who read the book, she came home and started researching some of the basis of the movie to see how much was factual and how much was just entertainment.

I read an article that talked about the term "Faction" - a mixture of facts and fiction that make a novel more appealing. I think Mr. Brown has discovered the magic recipe for faction and will continue to thrill readers for many years.

Film critics do not seem to represent the American public in any way and therefor serve no purpose.

title: Being catholic. And a hater of the book I haven't read. I enjoyed this!
review:
This film is excellent if for no other reason than its an exciting thriller!

Being catholic. And a hater of the book I haven't read (not because I feel strongly or anything) I just like to jump on bandwagons and am not much of a reader.

But I defiantly enjoyed this film because it offered me what I feel was a good depiction of what would be the books main events. And it was very exciting learning the "naughty" stuff about Jesus. A bit of a 'guilty pleasure' if I do say so.

If you have read the book I don't need to tell you to see it.

But if you have not don't let that put you off seeing the film. It's a good film in its own "film merits". Additionally Tom Hanks and Ron Howard pairing up to bring you a film about a crazy albino monk? If thats not a formula for a successful plot then what is?!

title: Disappointing to say the least
review:
I'll say right off, I haven't read the book. i tried, but found Dan Browns style of "Langdon drove past a monument, heres a 20 page history on it" very difficult to get into.

As such i went into this movie not sure what to expect. I had liked previous films done by Ron Howard, but i have hated everything written by Akiva Goldsman. the cast looked great, but the story didn't interest me. All the same i did end up seeing it the day it came out, because all the controversy and huge amount of advertising for this film had certainly been effective in building hype.

Unfortunately its hype that really isn't deserved. There ends up being very little to get excited over in this movie, and maybe it plays well on page, where millions of readers got hooked to this modern day holy grail quest, but translate to screen it does not.

The main problem with this film is the characters. there aren't any. instead the film makers have given us merely a bunch of people able to recite exposition. The convoluted plot demands so much explanation, the religious mythology and art history so complicated and difficult to explain to an audience, that there's really no time left for dialog about anything else. We know Langdon is meant to be the hero, but i cant for the life of me figure out why. He doesn't really do anything heroic. he doesn't really give us any insight into his character, apart from the fact he happens to be claustrophobic, which never has any relevancy towards anything.

The murder from which the whole story begins seems utterly ludicrous. An old man who is part of a secret society gets shot in the stomach, and then with his final moments to live, goes all around the giant museum that is the Louvre, painting over famous art works, hiding keys, and eventually stripping off, painting a circle with his own blood and laying in the middle of it in order to recreate another famous art work. Did it not cross his mind, while he had all this ample time to... oh i don't know... call an ambulance? or even better, ring Langdon directly and just tell him the frigging mystery? it just seems ridiculous for Pete's sake.

In spite of this insipid plot, the cast are all pretty good. Hanks does an OK job with a non existent character. Audrey Tautou is so beautiful you will ignore the fact that she doesn't get to do anything except every now and then say "what does this mean" and "what's going on?" thus allowing the other characters to go on a giant ramble to explain the historical relevancy of just about every tiny religious detail in order for the plot to make a lick of sense. Ian McKellan is just as fantastic as everyone says, as is to be expected, and manages to have fun with each and every syllable of his clunky dialog. Jean Reno and Alfred Molina really don't get anything to do, which is unfortunate for two such excellent actors.

When all is said and done, there's not much going on with this film, a pulp novel adaptation that takes itself far too seriously. I found myself drifting off towards the end, because they seem to want to end the movie at at least three separate points. i wont spoil the twist but you'll understand if you see it. a disappointing effort I'm sad to say.

title: A brilliant portrayal of a novel book!
review:
First, let me begin by addressing some of the negative comments made by certain critics. We must remember that, in reality, this is still a predominantly Christian country. Although the Da Vinci Code is indeed listed as FICTION, the mere fact that it undermines the church will no doubt cause a stir among the religious - and even some who aren't. That said, it is human nature to take something we don't like, and then find every possible flaw therein that we can. I believe this is why the movie has gotten so many bad reviews. People don't like the message, in fact, some hate it, so they feel the need to find fault wherevere they can, be it with the actors, the producers, or the movie as a whole. Many even go so far as to use reverse psychology on the public, making statements such as, "I don't see how any intelligent person can find this film entertaining." This, of course, is nothing but a meager attempt to condition the public to their beliefs simply by attacking the intelligence of the general public. In that, they create bias in people even before those people enter the theater. In my opinion, anyone interested in this movie should put aside everything they've heard from the critics, and enter the theater with an open mind. You might just be surprised! But enough of that. On to the movie!

Brilliant! I loved the book and, to be honest, I feared that the movie would not, or maybe could not, live up to the true ideals that Dan Brown set forth in the book. Never in my life have I been so pleased to be wrong! The movie stayed true to the book, with only a few minor details left out. The portrayal of the characters was indeed magnificent, chilling even, and I sat breathless as I watched Dan Brown's visions play out on the big screen. Not for the faint of heart, as there are some very graphic scenes, but then in order to stay true to the book, there have to be. With a wonderful cast and breath taking imagery, I have no doubt that the Da Vinci Code will remain at the top of the box office for many, MANY months! I give this movie two thumbs up. Really, I wish I had more thumbs.

title: all in all- great!!
review: I thought the movie was great- the characters and actors fantastic. It was very similar to the book and I thought that the only obvious part that wasn't in the book was the part in which Sophie and Robert go to the huge library in London to search for the grail- in the movie *spoiler*- they just get a bus and use a random guy's phone to search on the web. I loved the way they used the flashbacks in the movie- i thought it was a good way to visually picture the parts in history- all in all i would highly recommend seeing the movie- Sophie and Silas were my favorite characters in the movie- Paul bettany was so realistic as an albino monk- and Audrey tautous voice was fantastic and her personality really shined through in the movie- i personally thought it was very good

title: Bad thriller, Bad drama, Bad Action film.
review:
I know the da vinci code is not the best book ever but it was a good story, an easy reading and somehow entertain, I was looking forward to see Audrey Tautou and Jean Reno, but I was very disappointed with her performance, definitely English is not a language for french people.

But lets get to the movie. * I haven ever seen a movie with so many FLASHBACKS trying to build up character background, and i thought the film style they use was corny. * For somebody who hasn't read the book, i don't really think that the movie makes too much sense on a storyline. * For someone who actually read the book, the good points of the plot and the puzzles on the book are completely pass over on the movie and all the difficulties they encounter seemed very easy to solve. * The action sequences didn't have anything magnificent that you would have expect from a big production like this. * The "deciphering ability" was , without surprise, the same technique used on Beautiful Mind. * Most of the scenes spend just time getting into a building and going out of it.

The cinematography wasn't bad, some shoots looked good but nothing to really praise, but it was a good job. The performance of Ian McKellen was very good, and Paul Bettany Spanish was convincing. :).

I thought for all the anticipation and scandal that has been around the da vinci code, the movie was a failure.

* Apologize for my English, is not my first language.

title: Compelling with historical facts
review: Never a dull moment. A must see. I think the Da Vinci Code is similar to "National Treasure." Lots of clues, twists and turns. Before going to see it today, I read the reviews here on IMDbÂ—and went anyway. I was glad I did ! It was much better than the reviews had led on. The acting and directing were superb. It's possible that some church members may not agree with some parts in the movie. And maybe that's why the reviews were not as good as they could have been. I also like the fact that a bit of history about how and why the bible was written was woven into the plot. My girlfriend liked it so much she wanted to go back see it again--the same day.

title: absolutely amazing
review:
I've never read this book but the film was absolutely amazing so now i'm definitely gonna read the book. It was so interesting film and i even began to think about the history and how fascinating it all actually is, specially this story. I wonder if it is also true, even half of it.

And of course...the actors...Tom Hanks, Audrey Tatou, Jean Reno. They were absolutely brilliant!

Last time that i was amazed because of a movie, was when I saw "The tales of Narnia...".

So in spite of all this criticism that has been, it is a good movie and i recommend it to all my friends. It's thrilling, catching, mysterious and yet deep!

title: It's just amazing
review: I saw the movie on Thursday, and i've read the book like a year ago. Personally y think the film is great, although in some parts it wasn't exactly like the book. Nevertheless, the characters are just like i imagined when i read the book (Silas is really scary) and despite the critics that a lot of people made about the ending...that's the way the book ended, i think that Ron Howard did a great job taking this best seller to the big screen. When i heard that Tom Hanks was going to be Robert Langdon, at first i thought it would be awful, but i was wrong. He is a very talented actor, and so is Ian McKellen in the role of Sir Leigh Teabing. To conclude with this "review" i must say that it's worth seeing the film and you won't regret it. I'll be a hit.

title: Relax
review:
I read the book.

I saw the movie.

I enjoyed both.

It's entertainment, folks, that's it.

The critics apparently didn't like it. Then, again, they loved Sideways which wasted a couple hours of my life.

I characterize myself as conservative, and I am a Christian, but this religious controversy is silly.

I recommend the movie, and the book.

Try to enjoy them for what they are...entertainment.

title: Excellent!
review: I saw the Da Vinci Code last night. The theater was completely sold out. I have to admit that I was a little nervous after reading some of the reviews, but then I remembered the book got pretty much the same reviews and the book was excellent. As soon as the movie starts it brings you in, and makes you forget the people around you. I forgot that it was Tom Hanks; he became Robert Langdon to me. Some of the more controversial theories about The Virgin Mary, and the Grail story being everywhere, (even in the Little Mermaid) were left out. Some of the puzzles were also left out. None of that made a difference. The movie was exactly as I had pictured the book when I read it, and yet it was still surprising and enthralling. I didn't understand how the book could have gotten bad reviews, and I really don't understand them for the movie. It was not boring, or a snooze fest in any way. For the people who are worried the movie was derogatory to the Catholic Church or Opus Dei, I didn't see that at all. The Bishop and Silas were portrayed as fanatics, not as your everyday member. Bazu Fache was supposed to be your average member and he was an upstanding, moral and religious guy. When it came down to it, he wouldn't lie just because the Bishop asked him to, he did the right thing. I think it was at that moment that the fanaticism of Silas and Bishop Aringoza was the most obvious. The media and the Catholic Church obviously want people to believe that this movie is evil. It's really just a good movie, with a lot of interesting theories, some which can be backed up by fact, and some just supposition. I agree with Sir Ian McKellen. If their faith is so strong, why are they so afraid of this movie?

title: Flawed but Not Boring At All
review:
After having read some of the early publicity on this film, I headed out to a screening of the film with a bit of hesitation since I expected a big, boring, convoluted mess. Add to that, the unexciting and hesitant direction of Howard in both "Cinderella Man" and "The Missing", I was ready for the worst possible experience. I was surprised when I became engrossed by a film that moved very nicely and was very faithful to its written source.

Most of the film is in fact, very entertaining, and it is enough of a minefield to make a few people quite nervous along the road. It keeps its central premise, which will keep people arguing over the possibilities of historical cover-up for quite a while. In fact, seeing some of the arguments, presented visually will probably have a much stronger impact than some of the prose in Brown's novel. There are some handsome flashbacks depicting some of the elements of the cover-up, and the fact that now we see the road to discovery that our leading couple must take to "uncover" the truth makes the experience more believable; the power of cinema is indeed great.

So, why does the entire experience feels a bit like we've been cheated? It's not Hanks (or his hairdo's) fault. He plays his role very well, and his co-stars are delightful because their characters are for a change well developed. Another positive aspect of the film is the fact that Howard's direction is this time more on target, allowing us to relish the moments where witty, intellectual exchanges are happening. Academics can be proud that their depiction in the film makes them look like real people who seem to know their subject matter. McKellen's character is memorable because there he is fully dimensional, not the collaboration of a research group who is trying to appeal to as many possible teenagers in an opening night. It was truly refreshing to see a film where scenes were framed and the camera-work wasn't the result of an appeal to an ADD-afflicted audience or filmmaker. Watching a thriller where we see what is "happening" on the screen is more effective that quick cuts that are trying to give us an illusion of action and poorly executed attempts at being clever.

There are some problems in the last third of the film, where we are witnesses to some rather upsetting liberties taken by Mr. Goldman who couldn't leave its good source material alone. It is distressing to see how some of the ends were "quickly" tied at the end, an some of the resolution has taken a turn that was apparently tacked on to push more buttons but look more superfluous than anything else. Goldman was either experiencing a lack of confidence in the strength of Brown's subtle ending, or maybe he was looking to showcase his talents as an adapter who can't leave the integrity of the source alone. Do we really need to see more of "followers" there at the Chapel? Wasn't her performance strong enough? Also, what in the world is going with the dynamics of the relationship of the members of the radical order? It is especially in this section where we question the integrity of a filmmaker who can't handle controversy...

The film works mostly because it does serve an intelligent thriller with a premise that might open up interest in looking back at history and ourselves for sign of sorely missed intelligence in contemporary films that ironically seem of to be of anything else but intellligence. "The Da Vinci Code" gives us proof that there is still some true talent in Hollywood, that it believes good acting can still make a film a success. It is time we go back and revisit good, old fashioned screen writing, competent use of technical effects in both visual and computerized craftmanship to serve the whole, instead of just overpadding the film with flashy visual and sound effects, that end up becoming the center of attention. Here technology serves a purpose, other than numbing our common sense, our brains, and our abilities to enjoy intellectual questions.

The film has a tough road because it needs to appeal to those who read the novel, and those didn't but wonder what the hoopla is all about. Maybe there will be a succession of related theme projects, and let's welcome them if they induce a little thinking from our side, and hopefully it prods the so called Hollywood crowd to move away from pure marketing to what is required from those who want to be recognized as true artists in the medium.

title: I am pro Catholic Church but there are still angels in the architecture here
review: The Da Vinci code hints at decendants of the Messiah. I went to a Catholic High School although I am a Presbyterian. It is important to remember that we are all Christians with tolerance for other Religions who do good work. It is often an unpopular message that God the Creator of Humans chose King George VI Windsor as the Messiah. I am the Grandson of King George VI Windsor and the Queen Mother. Since this is a holodeck I just had a message from my Daughter Julias Artificial Intelligence computer on the Planet Coaltrain the home world of our creator that has been through at least one big crunch and big bang towed to safety by the Care rank Ki Aliens Moonfleet with a fusion reaction at its core for billions of years recharged with hydrogen from time to time. title: A Mixed bag.
review:
After seeing a early screening of the DA Vince code, i was left with mixed feelings.

After reading only the beginning of the book (due to my library demanding it back because of its popularity) i only knew the story up to the point of the ex cape from "The Bull".

The film, on the other hand, although faithful to the book, is a mixed bag. In parts it excels and really gets you thinking about THE POSABILITY, in other parts, it fails to convince me, even just for story wise, of the main plot line.

Having only read part of the book, its hard to compare the too.

But i did find it very predictable. SPOILERS AHEAD: DO NOT READ FURTHER IF YOU WANT TO REMAIN SPOILER FREE About 20 minuets into the movie, i knew that Sophie was the decedent of Christ and that Teabring was the teacher. The moment they arrived at his home, i automatically knew, simply from his obsession. Also, the confrontation on the plane between Sophie and Silas cemented my suspicion that Sophie was not the protector of the secrete, but the secrete herself with the words "Every breath you take is a sin".

END SPOILER Overall, the film, although entertaining, is long, and drags on in a lot of places. i simply loved the history visual effect, of how when they went to the church in London, they had the past mixed with the future, an image i saw in my minds eye many a time when i went to a historical place. It was almost odd seeing something for real that had only been in my minds eye, and it actually living up to the image of the mind But, overall, the plot itself, the whole Christ is married, etc, didn't really sell it to me. Sure, there is theories, and its not completely imposable, but, i just don't understand to this day, what the big deal is if he did have a child. Why cant he be the son of god and still be a man? Idk, i guess people need to believe only what they want to, and feel threaten if they might be wrong.

Overall, its a odd film, mealing its great in parts, and lame in others. I guess its worth checking out, but i don't know for sure if it will receive a home on my DVD shelf of honor (as i like to call it) when it hits DVD.

title: I wasn't disappointed
review:
After reading some other reviews on it, I thought The Da Vinci Code would be disappointing, but despite those reviews, I thoroughly enjoyed it. It may have gone on a bit too long at the end, but all for good reason. I can't fault the directing, by Ron Howard (Randsom); and I can't fault the performances, Tom Hanks (Philladelphia, Forest Gump, Catch Me If You Can), Audrey Tautou (Dirty Pretty Things), Jean Reno (Wasabi, Leon), Ian McKellen (Lord of the Rings, X Men) and Paul Bettany (Wimbeldon, Firewall). I found mostly everything about this movie excellent.

If your someone who can easily concentrate for a couple of hours, and you like psychological thrillers. This movie is for you. I'd give it 8 and a half stars.

title: I was only about to say it is NOT as bad as the book...
review:
I will not go into any analysis of the content and even serious evaluation -- there has been more than enough of that, just say that: 1) a mediocre triller scheme does not benefit too much from the religious dressing -- neither movie nor novel, it just does not hold together; 2) as for me, the movies is better -- while reading THE BOOK I -- a) was fighting with the words "thick as a whale omelette" booming in the back of my head, joined by "ignoramus", "pinhead", etc. b) thought that already "Il pendolo di Foucault", one of the sources of this plagiarism, was a bit boring, but that was a novel, while Mr Brown is asking for a four letter word .. I mean crap, c)was able to recognise mirrored writing and word "APPLE" one page before the characters did figure it out, and that's saying something as I am not a native speaker (just look how dodgy is this comment). To do it some credit I can only say that this is not the worst book I have red (still may be the worst among those I have actually finished reading).

To cut it short: For me it is a feeble, but reasonable MOVIE on it's own right, it is the weedy BOOK that gives it a bad connotation.

title: Paging Dante: A New Circle of Hell, Please, for Cinematic Sin
review:
Did Ron Howard direct this movie with the aid of a seeing-eye dog? "The Da Vinci Code" is set in stunning locales in France, England, and Scotland. It may as well have been set in a closet. How could a director spend so much time in Gothic cathedrals and make them appear visually dull? Stained glass windows, flying buttresses, vaulted ceilings - did Howard even register these? Howard doesn't just drop the ball with Christian art. The Nike of Samothrace, perhaps the single most thrilling sculpture ever to emerge under the hands of an artist, serves as backdrop for one scene. Howard does absolutely nothing with it.

The bad reviews for Ron Howard's "The Da Vinci Code" are not the result of a Vatican conspiracy. "The Da Vinci Code" presents its audience with a timeless, diabolical mystery. How do you take one of the most riveting, page turning novels of all time, jam packed with controversial propositions, and turn it into a bore? As a Catholic, I was prepared to be offended; as a scholar, I was prepared to scoff at cheap, pop, historical revisionism. Instead, I am outraged that this movie paralyzed me with boredom.

Reviews criticized the film as talky. I don't have a problem with talky films; I do have a problem with ineptitude. For all the guns and plots and threats on screen, the movie lacks a single moment of real thrill.

I kept thinking of Stanley Donen's 1963 Cary Grant - Audrey Hepburn film "Charade." Like "The Da Vinci Code," "Charade" is set in Paris, it involves a mystery hiding in plane sight that people kill over, and a suave man and a beautiful woman thrown together in a perilous effort to solve the mystery, before they are killed. "Charade" makes you feel as if you are actually in Paris. It wrings that setting as if it were a dishcloth. The chemistry between Grant and Hepburn snaps, crackles, and pops. "The Da Vinci Code" doesn't present a single moment with "Charade's" magic.

"The Da Vinci Code" also never manages to convey the deadly menace the protagonists face. Its hairbreadth escapes and creaky plot points strain credulity. There is a scene where a woman confronts the masochist, albino, monk assassin - you know the type - who has murdered her grandfather. The scene is meant to be heavy; it is just plain silly.

So much for "The Da Vinci Code" as a movie. How about as a sociological artifact? This much is clear: the movie hates Catholics. Catholics, here, are masochistic self flagellators, spooky, world manipulating conspirators, and are, as said in so many words, responsible for all human strife everywhere and throughout time. One has to ask, Why was such a weirdly bigoted movie made? Why devote so much time and energy to calumniating Catholicism? Could a similar mainstream American movie be made stating just as baldly that a conspiracy of Jews are responsible for all strife, or a conspiracy of Muslims? The answer, clearly, is no.

One thing that is not going on is what the movie claims it is all about. "The Da Vinci Code" presents itself as a defense of women who have been under assault by the Catholic Church. Virtually all of the main and minor characters of "The Da Vinci Code," though, are, as is standard in Hollywood blockbusters, male. Again, as is standard, there is one female, she is young, she is attractive, she is tiny, she wears a short skirt and high heels while running away from bad guys who menace her, into the arms of good guys who rescue her. If this is Dan Brown's or Ron Howard's idea of how to rescue Catholic women, I'm ready to become a nun.

"The Da Vinci Code" tells some very big lies about church history. Read Rodney Stark and Anne Jensen on women in the early Christian church, read Lyndal Roper on the truth of the witch hunts, read Cynthia Eller on the pure nonsense that this film sells about women's status in pre-Christian Paganism. There will be a quiz. Don't worry. Taking the quiz will be more fun than watching "The Da Vinci Code."

title: Superior to it's source material.
review:
Having heard about this book constantly for more than three years, and seeing that a film version was in production with a slew of my favorite actors, I finally decided to read it about a month ago. While it was a decent way to spend a boring afternoon, it was nothing beyond that. I found all the characters (with the exception Lieutenant Collet) trite and shallow, most especially Silas and Bishop Aringanosa. What annoyed me most about the book is a problem I see with a large number of thrillers; while the plots are usually decent, no thriller writer can write worth a penny. Dan Brown is better than most, but his character development and ear for words are about as good as a Special Ed high schoolers. The movie, while flawed, rose quite a bit above it's source novel.

As far as the lead goes, Robert Langdon may be Tom Hanks' weakest bit of acting since "Joe vs. the Volcano," but even a lackluster performance from Hanks is a cut above most of what you'll see for until Oscar season. It was a horribly flat role, and Hanks managed to put at least a bit of life into it.

As for Audrey Tatou, a decent job, but I had trouble adjusting to seeing her in a thriller, having gotten used to her in films such as "Amelie." Still, she was a believable Sophie, though that role could have gone to almost any young women that could have faked a french accent (or had a real one, as the case is here.) Mms. Nouveau was not quite as an empty character in the book as Langdon, but very close.

Sir Ian McKellan, however, was brilliant, as he was clearly having the time of his life playing the eccentric Grail historian, Sir Leigh Teabing; clever, crafty, witty, Brown seemed to have written the character with Sir Ian in mind. One of the better characters in the novel, McKellan almost steals the movie.

However, that distinction goes to Paul Bettany, as the fanatical albino monk Silas. In the novel, Silas comes off as sort of a rampaging bull, or something of that nature; Bettany seems more like a great white cat, tense, coiled, ready to attack and kill at any given moment.

The rest of the cast is decent, at worst (Jean Reno was especially notable,) and the directing is about what I've come to expect form Howard; over-dramatic, but decent over-all. As far as the plot goes, well, we all know what it's about.

While not the best or most intelligent movie of the year so far, much of the flak this film is receiving seems undeserved, probably coming from people who were hoping that Brown's glorified scavenger-hunt could become a Best Picture contender. Of course they were disappointed. But it is a well-paced thriller, with a (to some) fascinating conjectural background of "what ifs" and "whys" throughout history.

title: Boring? I think not!
review:
I do read what critics have to say, I just don't give their reviews much credence. Thank goodness for my bullheadedness! The early reports from the Cannes Film Festival was that this brilliant film was boring and Tom Hanks miscast. My question to those critics: what film did you see??? I have not read the book...one of the few out here who hasn't, I suppose. I'm a novelist myself and working on two books, so reading Dan Brown's novel just didn't fit in. I did, however, fit in the film on opening day. I'm glad I did. "The Davinci Code" was certainly not boring, nor did any of the cast seem out of place in their actors' skins. I found the pacing quite adequate, perhaps a little rushed in a couple of places, but felt comfortable on the whole. Tom Hanks was a brilliant choice for Langdon, as were the rest. I love mysteries and this one was wonderful. Ron Howard is one of our best directors today; I'd like to get him to produce and direct an adaptation of my book! Who wouldn't?? I don't like to give too much away, but I guess most people already know at least the premise of this story. I will say, people's faith in what they believe will not be shattered. If it is, I suspect their faith wasn't much to begin with. I, myself, believe in spiritual things, not religion. I do profess to believe in Jesus...by the way, his last name is not Christ; Christ means King from the Greek...as divine and totally deserving of my belief in Him. And if He did marry Magdelagne...her name was not Mary and she was not a prostitute...and had a child, more power to them. What's wrong with that? Why should that knowledge diminish His impact on the world? Religion gets in the way. One can believe without interference from the church. I have friends who are Catholic, and others who are recovering Catholics. I am not, nor have I ever been. However, I did attend cathecism with a friend one summer because she had to go. I found it stimulating but I had lots of questions. The teachers, nuns, were not intimidating,probably because I wasn't Catholic! The experience did start me questioning a lot, but I never stopped believing in my own spirituality. To anyone reading this, my humble opinion, I urge you to go see this movie. See it with an open heart and open mind.

Thanks!

title: Entertaining and politically meaningful
review:
I'm something of a fan of Howard's films. Even though he is not a brilliant auteur, he rarely disappoints, and always achieves a high level of visual interest and coherence of story line. I figured that the Da Vinci Code would pose little difficulty because as many have pointed out, the book was written as a screenplay.

The showing room was empty when we arrived, ten minutes before the showing, and it didn't fill up very much. The opening weekend may be a Guinness record setter for low opening weekend revenues if last night was any indication. People in the audience were commenting that they had seen few viewers exiting from the 6:45 showing, either.

Well, I am just dim and gullible enough to write a defense of this film, which did not disappoint me. First, it is really an exciting story, packed with surprises even for one who read the book. As one who hopes to spend more time there in years to come, I was excited to see Paris as an implicit character, via the portrayals of the local constabulary (Jean Reno), the ambient sounds of Paris at night, and some wonderful photography of the Louvre. Reno, Paul Bettany, Alfred Molina, and Ian McKellen are perfectly cast, and I thoroughly enjoyed their performances. I am not an especially big fan of Tom Hanks, but his presence enhanced my appreciation of him. Audrey Tatou is magical.

Had there never been an issue raised about blasphemy; had the film been made from a screenplay and not from a book everybody had read; it might be seen as a triumph of the genre. None of those conditions obtain, however, and this film does make a profound statement about Christianity. No doubt about it. Even though many critics have commented that the message is muted, it is not. The film is unmistakably blasphemous in the eyes of many self-respecting Christians. Which is why I liked it as much as I did. It deals with the issues in such a forthright manner that wider exposure to the ideas would be of great benefit.

Ian McKellen's description if Da Vinci's Last Supper is marvelously convincing, and as myth, his account has the virtue that it explains the historical and corrosive anti-feminism of the Roman Church in a way that requires little further explanation. It is a myth that I can and do embrace.

title: Why The Poor Reviews?
review:
Perhaps the movie critics did not read through or enjoy the novel The Da Vinci Code by Dan Brown. Perhaps they disagreed with its controversial ideas and their closed-mindedness resulted in a total lack of appreciation. However, I believe that as "It's A Wonderful Life" received poor reviews and later became a masterpiece, so too will The Da Vinci Code capture the hearts of anyone who is truly a fan of the book.

Critics are commenting that this film is lacking in action. I beg to differ. The Da Vinci Code offers almost as much excitement as the novel. Its action lies not only in the main plot but in the discussions between the characters. Although there were some parts of the novel that I thoroughly enjoyed that were either left out or cut short, Ron Howard cannot possibly be expected to provide his viewers with the same amount of information that was presented by Brown. This is, after all, a movie that lasts only two and a half hours.

As for Tom Hanks being "miscast" in the role of Robert Langdon, perhaps this is partially true. Although I am a great fan of Hanks' work, he stands out as one of the true Hollywood celebrities whose lives many know and read about in the daily tabloids. Most of the other characters, with a few exceptions (Ian McClellan and Paul Bettany) are faces we have seen before but in much less significant or well-known roles. Hanks stands out to the viewer as the A actor and we naturally place higher expectations on his shoulders. It was initially difficult for me to view him as Robert Langdon but I left the theater a thrilled customer.

I challenge anyone who is contemplating about whether or not to see this film to be his or her own critic. Do not rely on movie reviewers. Instead, be open-minded and judge for yourself. If you are truly a fan of Brown's work, you will likely walk away with a feeling of true satisfaction.

title: it's just a movie people, quit freaking out.
review: To those of you who are seriously, seriously religious...I have nothing against religion, but it's just a movie. It's a piece of entertainment, if it bothers you so much, don't see it. But don't make others think that it's a "sin" to go see this movie just because of YOUR religion. I thought it was an excellent movie, Paul Bettany is one of my favorite actors, and Tom Hanks was perfect for the role...those are just my opinions though. But seriously let's drop the whole protest about why the movie should be banned because of religious reasons, that's just stupid, it's just a movie. I'm not making fun of religious people, but there have been some many people posting on here saying that their parents won't let them see this movie because of the plot. I just think that's ridiculous. Considering they're of age, I think they should make the choice whether or not to see the movie (and to chose their religious beliefs.

title: Ron Howard, I salute you on a job well done.
review:
I saw the Da Vinci Code in the UK last night. I really cannot understand, why it has been so badly received. I went with 10 other people (some had read the book, others had not) and everyone of us thoroughly enjoyed the film.

I must say, I have never seen so many people queueing for the cinema!! Bearing in mind, that half of the world, know the start, finish and end (from the book), you knew there wasn't going to be any major shocks.

Also you have to think that it has a 12a rating, so the action sequences cannot be too gory/shocking.

If you look at it in simple terms, it is an adaptation of a book. The book was entertaining, (with a controversial subject matter) the film has stayed loyal to the book.

Ron Howard has done a great job, bringing the book to life. The old adage "if it isn't broken, don't try and fix it" applies to this, I think he deserves some credit, for not being one of these, pompous Directors, who try and tell the story in their own aloof way.

As for the characters, all have played the parts well.

Hanks plays Langdon well, (remember Langdon wasn't portrayed as Mr Action in the book), he's a lecturer, who is a play by the rules type guy. McKellen is great as Teabing,he brings some humour to the film too, Bettany is excellent as Silas, (but remember 12a rating!!!) so he can't be too menacing, although he does a very good job.

Tautou plays Neveu well too, as a quiet, shy cryptologist. Reno plays the part well, broody, mysterious, somewhat of a shifty character.

All of the actors involved, just played the characters, as they were portrayed in the book! what else do people want????

Why are people listening to Cannes critics anyway???? if a film doesn't shock, depress or downright disgust you, then the Cannes lot are never happy!!!

Go see it, judge for yourself people.

title: Intellectual 007
review:
The reviews are very harsh which leads me to believe the critics were mostly concerned about political correctness.

Additionally, looking at the user profile vote on this site now, and the fact that the majority of the votes are either 1's or 10's it is obviously about people who come into the movie with a preferred dogma...

Luckily, I was just in the mood for a good movie...just like I only wanted a good read when I read the book.

I think the movie is very pleasant to watch, grabs your attention, does not drag, and it is very careful with its subject, for fear of the PC police. I felt it was no different than a well thought out 007 movie, with less sex, less violence, less pop cultural references and more historical references...In general, an intellectual 007

title: Like The Book ...Good But Not Great
review:
The trouble with making a movie out of book so wildly popular as The Da Vinci Code is that we all knew (just knew!) it'd have problems. Detractors will lambaste it for the pages of the novel that had to be cast aside for the sake of film time (the movie is still 2 hours and 29 minutes, though) and any changes to characters or plots (all of which have happened.) But when you transfer a book to film, a certain amount of trust has to go to the screenwriters; a level of trust that basically says, "Please don't screw this up! But give us a good story that'll engage film audiences!" I've read The Da Vinci Code and I must say that the book was interesting, but I felt it didn't live up to the hype surrounding it. I was continually astounded to see it on the best seller list month after month after month. I kept asking myself, "Did I miss something? Was it really THAT good?" Maybe. Either way, however, I approached this film with a fairly high level of trepidation. "Will the movie be over-hyped, too?" I'm happy to say that this is an adequate film (thus my thumbs up rating.) But I don't believe it'll stay in theaters as long as the book stayed on the best seller lists.

The film DOES follow the book surprisingly well. Tom Hanks plays symbologist Robert Langdon. He's in Paris autographing his latest book when a police officer approaches and asks him to come to the Louvre. Once there, Mr. Hanks discovers that a murder has taken place. A curator that Mr. Langdon was supposed to meet that night was murdered and his body desecrated. But it appears the dead curator desecrated his own body. But why? Sophie Neveu, a young detective played by Audrey Tautou, arrives at the scene and soon Mr. Langdon's life begins to unravel. Trapped by the French police, a murder investigation in which he is the prime suspect, a secret society of ultra-worshippers known as the Opus Dei, and a group of Templar Knights in hiding, Robert Langdon is quickly whisked into a life of puzzle solving in order to find a secret that could unravel Christianity as we know it.

Much controversy surrounded the film before its release. The main controversy was from albinos. Amazingly I heard nothing from this group while the book was out, but now that the film is here, they've emerged from the woodwork. Why? I'll let you all think about that one on your own.

There have been complaints, too, that the film is "too slow to get going" or that Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou gave wooden performances. I didn't see that.

I will complain about Tom Hanks in this role, however. I'm sure Ron Howard and he work together comfortably after their previous collaborations from SPLASH to APOLLO 13. But I just couldn't swallow Mr. Hanks as the prime character. There was zero chemistry between him and Mrs. Tautou, and his long hair was well nasty looking (like it needed a good washing.) He's getting up there in age and I think Clive Owen or some other up-and-coming actor would've been a wiser choice. My two-cents

title: No Suspense
review:
Did you read the movie? Well, now you can see the book!! There's only one problem: Reading the book is just one giant spoiler for the movie now isn't it? It was for myself anyhow. But, then again, I guess I didn't let that matter, I threw down my eight and a half bucks anyway, so I can't really complain.

I'm with a lot of people in agreement over the casting (or miscasting of the film). I've always enjoyed Tom Hanks' work, and have no impartiality to him whatsoever. He's just not right for Robert Langdon, long hair or no. Same goes for Ian McKellen, another outstanding actor, again though, not quite right. Heads up though for Audrey Tautou. I'll watch her in anything.

In the end, was it worth it? Hmmmmmm....... Maybe I'll read the movie, uh, book, again and see.

title: Disappointing? No!!
review:
I must admit, before walking in to see The Da Vinci Code, I was a little nervous. After checking up on other reviews they were nothing but bad reviews.

Tonight My girlfriend and I went to watch the film and after reading the book, I was hoping that the film could live up to the expectations of the fantastic book by Dan Brown. Now a lot of people have been highly critical of the film and I think that they have got it all wrong right from the beginning. The book itself has come under unnecessary criticism. Hanks and McKellen were great together in their scenes, and their conversations of the grail were fantastic and great to watch.

The film is a good mystery but it does lack in a few areas, but after watching the film both my girlfriend and I agreed that the film was brilliant.

8/10 - Not as good as the book, but it's a great film.

title: See it for yourself and decide for yourself
review:
The Da Vinci Code reminded me that cinema audience's today there have the intelligence of gnats. This is a good movie, despite what the critics say - I haven't read the book but I do know the basics and to my knowledge was an intelligent and thought provoking outing at the cinemas, for once. It's a clever film that raises a lot of questions. It was epic adventure and I thoroughly enjoyed it for what it was.

Whether or not any of it is true is really irrelevant. This is fiction, it's a film and the controversy that surrounds it is ridiculous. For anybody to turn their backs on their faith after viewing this film means one thing. Obviously their faith wasn't that strong to begin with.

This was not the greatest story ever told, nor did it claim to be yet the expectations for this film were out of the ballpark and it was destined to disappoint after the success of Dan Brown's best-selling novel. Keep in mind everybody has an opinion and in this film's case, everybody has his or her own agenda because the subject matter is deemed so "controversial".

See it for yourself and decide for yourself. Whether you believe or you don't, neither version of the "truth" can truly be approved or disproved and that's the beauty of this film, it's got everyone talking.

title: Faithful to Novel
review:
I saw the movie today expecting to be disappointed. I had read many negative comments from reviewers and individuals who posted on movie sites and was curious how I would feel after seeing it.

I was pleasantly surprised that the movie was very faithful to the story. (Yes, I read the book....three times). There are a few minor changes in the storyline but none that changed the quality of the story. Overall, I thought it was an excellent movie and, judging by the comments I heard from many that were around me, they felt the same.

I wanted to address some of the negative comments I've read. One of the comments I've read often is how awful Tom Hanks was with the dialog. I'm not sure what people were expecting but Hank's character of Robert Langdon is not some James Bond-ish type of character. He is an innocent drawn into the plot and that is the way Hanks played him. Very matter of fact and little emotion. Another comment I read was the poor chemistry between Hank's character and Audry Tautou's character Sophie Neveu. There was no chemistry between the characters in the novel until the end and at no time was it an overwhelming romantic interest. Oh, it may have been hinted at in the book but nothing obvious. Another gripe was that the dialog was poor all the way around. I know there was a lot of dialog about the meaning of the Grail, etc. but that had to be in there. People that have not read the book would have no idea what was going on if the premise of the book was not discussed. Yes, there were stupid lines like at the end with Hanks saying "Godspeed" but gimme a break, it didn't detract from the entire movie. Long movie? Yes...it was. But Brown was not just writing an action novel. He was writing about something that has been debated for 2,000 years and which most people are totally ignorant of (i.e., what the Holy Grail may really be). So if the movie was going to be faithful to the story, there's not a lot that could be cut out and still have the story make sense.

So, that's my two cents. If you want to see it, go see it. I think that people who are open-minded will enjoy it. Those who can't imagine a Christianity in any other way that what the Church has taught for 1,600 years might as well skip it. You'll hate it. Ignore the negative comments....take a look for yourself.

title: Excellent movie!
review:
