title: Unfair Adaptation
review:
I changed the rating from 10 to 7 after reading the book.

Very bad adaptation, how could Dan Brown agree on an unfair adaptation like this ?!!!

Maybe that happened so the filmmakers won't get in trouble with the Vatican or Christians, though it did.

Maybe the novel were so long and can't be filmed like that but that's not an excuse to cut short important scenes and dialogues.

The ingenious Ron Howard and the talented Tom Hanks are the reasons why I liked the movie after all.

Hans Zimmer, you're my man :)

I hope this not happens to Angels & Demons after reading the novel.

title: Good Movie
review: This movie is a fiction, but I felt down the story which I am made to think whether it is a historical fact. The mystery of Christ which is hidden in The Da Vinci Code. The hero and his company receives the code that Mayor of Louvre left and starts trip of the demystification. They solves a code one by one, and I was excited in the moment when those points and points are in one line.I wanted to go the Louvre after watching it. There may be the mystery that Da Vinci left in the present. If you like urban legend, you will be favorite. But it is difficult to understand the story if you don't know well about the history of Christ. But it is worth watching if you are interested it. If you have not seen it, you should so by all means. This is my recommendation

title: But first, a test of honor.
review:
I'm actually impressed by how effective this schmaltzy blockbuster is. The original novel by Dan Brown had an immediate impact and popularity, partly because of its controversial premise that made people flock to find out the truth for themselves. Brown semi-convincingly weaves enough historical truth and reference into it that the more gullible reader takes at face value. I remember myself being momentarily amazed after looking closely at The Last Supper for the first time and seeing the feminine figure hand in hand with Jesus Christ himself. That was a page turner - doctor waiting room material, for light reading on public transport, and so on. The film takes on the same qualities. It starts essentially as a detective mystery, which is a genre which has worked for centuries because we as an audience like being told that final, baffling yet brilliant solution and then rifling back through the pages and picking up on the clues that have been subtly inserted. The film, like the novel, is effective because it builds on our assumed knowledge and weedles its way past our doubts. We know the Mona Lisa, we know the Last Supper, we know the legend of the Holy Grail, but did we know these little secrets beyond them? How many knew of the Opus Dei before The Da-Vinci Code?

What the detective mystery also relies on is dumping loads of information and then re-assembling the bits into a solution that the audience would recognise but not have the expertise to solve themselves. The film takes the laziest route here, relying on the authoritative prowess and aura of veterans like Hanks and McKellen to continually be fountains of knowledge, to know the answer to every question from the clueless vessel of Tautou, who doubles as the viewer. Everyone knows Hanks and McKellen, so we don't doubt what they say, and when they are confronted with a seemingly baffling puzzle to solve, their historical and intellectual know-how isn't questioned. This is of course film-making at the lowest level; there are scenes where the two are basically narrating straight from the novel, talking directly at Tautou and therefore the viewer, making sure they are up to speed. Everything serves to move the film along. There is remarkably zero fat for something almost three hours long. Part of this is nonsensical padding; Sauniere's final cryptic message scrawled in blood is an anagram which leads to the Mona Lisa, which contains another anagram to another artwork, which leads to a key with another puzzle...and so on. If you take a step back all this mystery seems tedious and convoluted, and a few of the steps are unnecessary. But because the film is so brisk, never giving any breathing room but rushing from puzzle to puzzle, it doesn't ever feel like dragging. Our curiosity is swiftly and efficiently replaced by another, and there is never any time to really think or reflect.

The film format is visual, so Howard has gone above and beyond the book, gifted with a generous budget, to further add to the faux historical authenticity of the premise. The lavish flashbacks are clearly colour coded, with a slight wash to contrast so we know exactly what timeline we are experiencing. The characters narrate over them with the air of authority as if they were providing the voice-over for a historical documentary. Langdon's opening presentation is directed not only at his chirpy lecture audience, but also at the viewer, overturning all their preconceptions with a flashy barrage of symbols and their secondary meanings. Every mystery is given immediate priority; the novel presented a puzzle and solved it almost immediately, to the reader's satisfaction. When they do the little bait and switch on the plane, seconds later we see the washed out flashback explaining exactly what happened. This is low culture entertainment, but it certainly is effective.

title: An adaptation faithful to the original book.
review:
Based on the homonyms best seller by Dan Brown, this film begins in the Louvre, where a crime and several clues hidden in Da Vinci's works takes the symbologist Robert Langdon in an unexpected treasure hunt. Directed by Ron Howard, the film has a screenplay by Akiva Goldsman, and a cast headed by Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou.

The cinema has always had difficulty in please the public when it decides to make the adaptation of a best-known literary work. For me, an avid reader, a film can rarely be better than the original book. There are always chapters that are cutted or adapted in a less well accomplished way. But that doesn't mean that the film is bad (well, sometimes it is). In this case, the adaptation isn't bad, following the book very faithfully. And that is essential.

The actors are excellent and were quite good in their roles. Despite some minor flaws, they all shone and gave credibility to their characters. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou managed to give soul, ingenuity and charm to Langdon and Neveu, managing to soften the audience in some scenes without, however, never assert themselves as a romantic couple because, in fact, they weren't. Ian McKellen, as expected, was impeccable in the role of the academic Sir Leigh, and gave a great liveliness to the film with his British manners and careful diction. Paul Bettany surprised in the role of the monk Silas, a religious fanatic. He was truly unrecognizable. Finally a word of recognition for Jean Reno, who returned to make a detective (he already had a similar role in "Les Rivières Pourpres"), again with great clearance. The special, visual and sound effects were excellent but unobtrusive; the photography, a bit dark and nebulous sometimes, contributed to thicken the mysterious environment in which the film unfolds. The soundtrack, done by Hans Zimmer, was perfect.

In conclusion: the film is very good and is faithful to the original book but, to properly appreciate it, we have to resist to make many comparisons. The book is so good that, usually, too much increases our expectations for the film.

title: Very dull film
review: 2005's The Da Vinci code movie is a very dull and just flat out boring movie that's not worth the time to watch it. The storyline is lacking and the idea is an interesting idea but the execution of the plot falls flat. The actors really do try their best to save the movie, but they cannot save it from the dull script and the lackluster execution. Tom Hanks is just OK in the film I felt like he could've been better though. And the other main actress along with Ian McKellen do all right in the film, not great. At first I was really excited to see this movie because I thought that it was going to be an exciting controversial film about the foundation of religion and it being toppled, but it just turned out to be a boring dumb movie about this discovery rocking the foundations of Christianity. It's true that there were one or two scenes that kind of peaked my interest, but it was only one or two scenes out of over 100. So the da Vinci code unfortunately will only receive a 3 on a scale of ten.

title: Classic Langdon Movie
review:
'The Da Vinci Code ' just like the book by Dan Brown is truly a perplexing film which will keep the audience struck with bewilderment and keeps them guessing right till the end.

Starting the classic Tom Hanks as Professor Robert Langdon and Sir Ian Mckellen as Teabing, will surely keep the bats in the cave !

Tom Hanks' acting is just dazzling. He played his part of Robert Langdon so beautifully ! His humor, I must say is the best !

Do I need to say anything about the legend Sir Ian Mckellen's wonderful acting ? I think not !

Hats off to the director Ron Howard for directing such an amazing movie who is arguably one of the best directors of the century.

The twist at the end is quite unexpected. I highly suggest you to read the book first and then watch the movie. You will surely love the film if you have read the book.

title: Loved the book hated the movie
review: I won't bother addressing the nonsense about religion. For me, the book, itself was very entertaining. Unfortunately, the movie failed on every level. In the hands of Ron Howard, an exciting story became a dull Hardy Boys mystery, and even the cinematography was poorly thought out by Salvatore Totino. One might have been able to overlook those problems had it not been for the dreadful casting by casting directors Janet Hirshenson and Jane Jenkins. Audrey Tautou, in the role of Sophie, almost single-handedly ruined the movie with her unintelligible English and Tom Hanks was terribly miscast, in my opinion, in the role of Robert Langdon. The lesser characters were reasonably well cast, Ian McKellen especially. Sadly, they weren't the ones responsible for carrying the movie.

title: Cryptic crypts
review:
Dan Brown is a good enough storyteller to sell millions of books.

The Da Vinci Code was a blockbuster of a book and it was only a matter of time that it was turned into a movie.

A controversial plot that visits lots of foreign locations, mystery, thrills, graphic violence and a search for religious artifacts where you are chased by nasty villains.

You can call this a modern Indiana Jones.

Paul Bettany is chilling as a faithful henchman of Opus Dei, aiding Alfred Molina who incidentally was in the beginning of Raiders of the Lost Ark.

However, Ron Howard's direction is bland despite the the good use of locations.

The screenplay by the hack Akiva Goldsman is uninspired as always, although he or Dan Brown might had got some inspiration from Kevin Smith's Dogma.

Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou lack spark and you end up staring at Hanks hair for all the wrong reasons.

The film is watchable enough but there is too much silliness and some of it is just implausible with cryptic clues that the greatest minds have been unable to solve until Robert Langdon came on the scene.

title: Much Ado About Nothing
review:
Dan Brown wrote a book called THE DA VINCI CODE which had a premise that Jesus Christ and Mary Magdalene had a child and the Centuries of Christian teaching is one big conspiracy to hide this fact . The book itself featured much controversy from the religious leaders and became subject to court cases alleging plagiarism . The novel itself went on to become a big hit with the public but not with the critics who considered it popcorn trash for the masses but literary wotrhless . The same could be said of THE GODFATHER and JAWS two classic examples of trash becoming immortal films . Certainly THE DA VINCI CODE has all the makings of a fast paced high concept blockbuster. Stick in some well regarded names like Hanks , Reno , Molina and McKellen , an Oscar winning director and an Oscar winning screenwriter and you should have a massive hit on your hands . This film can't fail can it ?

As someone who has never read any Dan Brown I'm afraid the film version does to a large extent . The problem with the film is that assumes that no one is aware of the hype involving the book . I've never read the book but I know what the plot involves - an albino monk working for an internal sect of the Vatican bumping off people who know too much . It's a bonkers idea and in the context of a trashy blockbuster it's a good one . The thing is the story structure that assumes that the audience know nothing has to by necessity create an air of mystery to the proceedings . This means that the first half is taken up by some painfully obvious exposition . Everyone on the planet must know where all this is heading and even if they didn't it'd still be badly done and unnecessary exposition

Things do pick up in the second half but that's not saying much and for a film featuring an albino monk bumping off people too clever for their own good THE DA VINCI CODE doesn't feel like it reaches its maximum potential as the storyline descends in to a runaround with the good guys getting crossed and double crossed by the bad guys which makes for an unengaging because the audience are one step ahead of good guy Robert Langdon and good girl Sophie Neveu . One thing is assured whilst watching this film and that is neither Dan Brown or screenwriter Akiva Goldman are going to be bumped off by an albino monk or anyone else for being too clever for their own good

title: Impossible to take seriously
review:
Which of the following statements are true?

 Rosslyn Chapel in Midlothian, Scotland, was built by the Knights Templar

 The name "Rosslyn" is a corruption of the phrase "Rose Line"

 "Rose Line" is another term for a meridian or line of longitude

 Rosslyn Chapel lies on the same meridian as Paris

 The organisation known as Opus Dei is an order of monks

 The organisation known as the Priory of Sion is the modern successor to the Knights Templar.

 Leonardo da Vinci and Sir Isaac Newton were both members of this organisation

 Alexander Pope presided over Newton's funeral

 Leonardo's famous painting of the Last Supper shows Mary Magdalene sitting on Christ's right

 Christ and Mary Magdalene were married and had a daughter, Sarah, from whom the French Royal Family are descended.

The answer is that all these statements are demonstrably false, apart from the last which, while unsupported by any evidence, cannot be definitively disproved. Rosslyn Chapel was built in 1456, more than a century after the suppression of the Templars. "Ross" (headland) and "lyn" (waterfall) are both common elements in Celtic place-names. Nobody except Dan Brown ever refers to a meridian as a "rose line". Rosslyn Chapel lies more than five degrees to the west of the Paris meridian. Opus Dei is not a monastic order but a Catholic organisation of lay people and secular priests. The Priory of Sion has no connection to the Templars and was not founded until 1956, so Leonardo and Newton could not possibly have been members. Pope, as a Catholic layman, could not have officiated at an Anglican funeral service. The figure sitting to Christ's right in "The Last Supper" is St John the Evangelist, traditionally shown in Christian art as a fair-haired beardless youth.

"The Da Vinci Code", however, is a film which assumes that all the above statements, especially the last one, are true. In form, it is a Hitchcock-style thriller, based around a man and woman accused of a crime they did not commit. An elderly Frenchman named Jacques Saunière is found murdered in the Louvre. We learn that the real culprit is an "Opus Dei monk" named Silas, but (for reasons too complex to set out here) suspicion falls upon a visiting Harvard University academic named Robert Langdon and the dead man's granddaughter Sophie Neveu. Langdon and Sophie go on the run across France, England and Scotland, following various clues in search of the information which will establish their innocence. They are well equipped to decipher complex clues as he is a "symbologist" (one who makes a study of symbols and symbolism) and she is by profession a police cryptographer.

The McGuffin which they are seeking is the Holy Grail. In the Arthurian legends and films such as "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade" this is depicted as a cup or chalice, but Dan Brown inclines to the theory that the Old French for "Holy Grail", "San Greal", is really a corruption of "Sang Real", or "Royal Blood". The Holy Grail is therefore the royal bloodline deriving from Christ's supposed marriage to Mary Magdalene. According to the film, the Catholic Church has throughout history sought to destroy all evidence of this marriage, believing that such a revelation would destroy Christianity, while the Knights Templar and their successors the Priory of Sion have sought to preserve this forbidden knowledge. It turns out that Sauniere was killed because he was a member of the Priory and that Langdon and Sophie are in danger not only from the police but also from fanatical elements within the Church.

There are some good things about the film- there is, for example, an entertaining performance from Ian McKellen as the historian Sir Leigh Teabing- but overall, I found it dull. Ron Howard has made some decent films in a number of genres, but thrillers like this are not really his forte, and I found the action too slow-moving and the plot over-complex. This is not one of Tom Hanks's better films, and, as in "Dirty Pretty Things", Audrey Tautou shows that she is not as accomplished an actress in English as she is in her native language.

I had, however, two other, more important, reasons for disliking the film. The first is that a conspiracy thriller has to have some connection with reality if the alleged conspiracy is to remain plausible, and "The Da Vinci Code" is so riddled with factual errors that I found it impossible to take seriously anything it has to say. (I listed a few, but by no means all, of these errors at the beginning of this review). The second is that Dan Brown seems not to realise that his main thesis could, if true, actually have led to a more reactionary form of Christianity, not to the more liberal one which he claims would have been the result. If the Kings of France (and other European countries) had indeed been direct descendents of Christ and Mary Magdalene they would most assuredly not have kept this fact a secret. They and their servants in the Church would loudly have proclaimed their holy bloodline- and their consequent superiority to ordinary mortals- to the world.

I am not a Catholic, and unlike many of those Catholics and other Christians who denounced the film as "blasphemous" I am personally sympathetic towards those interpretations of Christianity which place more stress on Christ's humanity than on His supposed divinity. I doubt, however, if many of us- regardless of our religious views- would want to live in a society ruled by quasi-divine monarchs claiming direct descent from God himself. 5/10

title: The Da Vinci Code (2006)
review:
"He forgot everything we've learned. Everything we teach. It's why we study history. So we'll stop killing each other."

This is the story of how the most important secret in the history of the world was - almost - revealed. The movie has a very controversial subject, told by a great cast.

The subject is quite unbelievable. So unbelievable, in fact, that if it were ever revealed to the world it would destroy the foundations of Christianity itself. And so, it was kept secret. A select few kept it hidden from the curious eyes of the world, while a select - other - few tried to eliminate the threat by eliminating the secret itself. By any means necessary. Until one day, when the two factions, like two fighters almost out of breath, are finally too weak to control the secret any longer. Will it get out? Will it destroy the world?

The script tends to minimize everything except the subject, and that is why it is so predictable. It is acted out by a fantastic cast, and I can think of no one better to tell the story. Tom Hanks and Ian McKellen do a great job of explaining events and symbols long forgotten. Audrey Tautou has the innocence needed for the part. Paul Bettany the intensity. And Alfred Molina is perfect as the powerful elite working in the shadows.

The music is great, a little over the top maybe, but very much fitting the magnitude of the story. The special effects are few but very well done.

The Da Vinci Code. A very intriguing story, for those who care enough to listen. 9/10.

title: Excellent! Must See! *SPOILERS ALERT*
review:
*SPOILERS* OK, I'm watching this movie right now and I'm a half an hour in...

This is strange as I've never written a review of anything before I'm finished with it.

Well.. I do not recall any movie which I had to wikipedia(like googling) so many mathematics and names. Like (in order of occurrence): - Musée du Louvre (Didn't know much about it except for being called Louvre and that it is in Paris) - Vitruvian Man (Well, of course I knew this one, but I was still intrigued to know little bit more bout this nd it's origin) - Fibonaci Sequence (I forgot this one, I knew it once since I'm a programmer) - Eidetic Memory (Didn't know what that was, and now I know it means photographic memory, which I'm familiar with, and that the

word "eidetic" comes from the Greek word "eidos") - Spatial frequency (didn't know about it) - Mona Lisa (Interesting to know the facts) - Virgin of the Rocks (I have seen it, but didn't know it is called that way, now I'll never forget it) - French King conquered Jerusalem (I suppose I should know this from assassin's creed but I don't remember, so looking it up on

wiki as well) - Friday the 13th (good to know) - The Holy Grail (I know it by name but not its history) - Holy Blood, Holy Grail (which inspired this movie) - Rudimentary Phallus (now what's that? Do note: I'm not from the states and English isn't my native language) - Opus Dei (So many things to learn) - Zealots (What is this? Starcraft?)

The second scene where he talks about symbols gave me goose bumps, and I actually wanted to see the whole lecture (hence the

rest of this movie).

I think it is mind blowing how much this movie has to offer. Aside from it being a great mystery thriller (I mean, this hollywoodian movie is one of it's genres best), it is focused on a subject so basic to some people, JC, and brings so much light on to this subject... it's.. ahhh... amazing. And the ending... Good god!

I still don't get why it's focused on DeVinchi.

Great movie! Must see! Over-well-done performance from tome hanks.

---

Yeah, so, after reading a bit of the goofs... of course, almost every movie has goofs (this one has a lot though), but the overall experience from the movie was positive A+! Great work!

title: It was pretty good.
review:
Im 13 and I've recently watched this movie and I thought it was very, very good.

Though for kids 12 or younger, I don't think they will enjoy it or care because the plot line was difficult to follow.

Through the movie, I had to ask frequent questions because I was sort of confused.

Overall, I think this was a VERY good movie and i think anybody who likes mystery, drama, crazy movies would enjoy this movie very much.

The sexual themes were not bad and younger kids would not have a problem with them.

The gore. though was somewhat graphic and thats where those younger kids would have a problem and would probably not want to continue watching the movie.

I think this was a wonderfully made movie and the cast was also very good.

This will definitely be a must watch for many, including myself.

Again, overall, most younger kids will not like this movie.

Watch out Christians, if you are Christian, DO NOT watch this movie because you will be very angry with the people who made this movie because they, i don't know, they go against everything Christians believe.

They say MAry MAgladine was Jesus's wife and Im sure, as a Christian myself, you will not be happy about what they say about Jesus and the Bible.

title: Must watch!
review:
When I first heard of this movie, I heard it as being 'one of the most controversial' movies to be released. Sadly to say, when I did finally get around to watching this understated movie, there was a lack of people in the theater.

Still, I went to watch this with a friend of mine (a catholic) who was determined to find out if it was truly as bad as people made it out to be! Far from it! We both thoroughly enjoyed the movie - with me going on to purchase the book. The movie did its best to stay true to the novel from what I can tell, and I fail to see why so many religious people went up in arms over a FICTIONAL movie! Had the movie been trying to be one of those 'Based on true event' movies, I may have understood... but I don't.

Surely, if you believe in something then you'd stay firm to your beliefs and not let anything deter you? Anyway, for the proper review: You follow Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) as he is called upon - after his name was discovered at the murder scene of his friend Jacques Saunière (Jean-Pierre Marielle). Now, Robert is a Professor at Harvard University who specialises in religious iconology and symbology and Jacques had intended for Robert to be able to work out the clues (which were various puzzles amongst 'religious' portraits) leading up to his slow and painful death, only for him to be considered the murderer by the police.

One of the members of the police is revealed to be Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou), Jacque's granddaughter, who wants to know the truth behind the murder.

As the movie progresses they come into contact with Sir Leigh Teabing (Ian McKellen) and it is from then on the movie begins to twist, leaving the audience on the edge of their seats.

It's a brilliant movie and the script was wonderfully done - if not for Robert Langdon's inhuman speed at the end of the movie where he suddenly appears at one place than the next as he follows the Rose Line to his final destination.

I give this a definite 10, and remember - one should watch the movie for what it is and not get worked up when they fail to see the word 'FICTIONAL'.

title: The greatest mystery of all
review:
Robert Langdon a famed lecturer becomes one of the key players in uncovering one of the greatest story never told. It involves Jesus and his child, one that has survived through the ages and whose life maybe in danger as enemies scour the globe for Langdon as he tries to put the pieces together.

Honestly, when I first heard of the book and film, I was bewildered, it was a very controversial, but I never got the chance to watch the film, or read the book...But recently I watched both Davinci's Code and Angels & Demons...And what do I think of Davinci's Code...Does not live up to the hype...It's too fast, too long at times....There are moments of complete intrigue, like when the 'truth' is revealed by Sir Teabing, quite captivating, but the film does not capture the sheer size, if you will of the story. And the ending after a while can be deduced, however it's still a little surprising.

title: Splendid,Marvellous,Mesmerising,Amazing,Fantastic,Awesome
review:
Its been almost five years since the release of this movie and i heard a lot about this flick from friends so i decided to have a look at this flick

and...

goodness gracious me .... it was amazing ... adrenalin pumping and frankly speaking,i never wanted this movie to end...

over two hours of complete amazement and a superb movie in nutshell..

i will give 2 for Tom Hanks 5 for the story and 3 for the wonderful direction ......

surely worth a watch

title: It's a HORROR flick because it is a HORRIBLE movie!
review:
I finally watched it tonight, and in my 5 decades of movie watching I gotta tell you this movie is insultingly horrible. Why? Because it is one stupid piece of nonsense after another piece of stupid nonsense, ad infinitum. And oh, is it boring! It doesn't give the viewer a chance to recover from one stupid thing before another is thrown at them just for good measure.

I did NOT read the book, and am glad I did not. Because if it is anything like the movie (as some reviewers have stated), then it must me one lousy book.

If I were held down and threatened with being forced to watch Sarah Palin for an hour, I would grudgingly admit that there was some good camera work, and some clever movie-shot techniques. But that's about as far as I could take it! Bad Bad Bad! Stupid-Bad!

title: Failed to live up to the book hype
review:
The Da Vinci Code

The Da Vinci Code, before viewing I had heard all the hype about the book, but I have never read it. After watching the film I now must read the book if for no other reason than to find out what the hype was all about. Now, I am not saying it was a horrible film I think it was a victim of over editing. By not including enough key details intact, I was confused or bored for most of the film; I am however assuming the book has these needed details of course.

I am a huge Tom Hanks fan; he can make even a bad movie mediocre, which is what I believe his character Robert Langdon did for this film. He played his role with his usual passion and enthusiasm, and managed to keep me somewhat involved. Another character that kept this film alive was that of Silas (Paul Bettany) a crazed albino monk belonging to a branch of Catholicism known as Opus Dei. He played the part great, and was truly an interesting character that I wanted to learn more about.

I believe the scene lengths were too short. I believe this was done to hasten the pace of the film, but what it did for me was make scenes that were too short to fully absorb what had just happened. As for the film lighting and picture quality, they did a great job; the dark scenes were comfortably to view and no overly bright spots. The soundtrack on the other hand was horrible, with the exception of some appropriate angelic music with the scenes involving Silas. The other scenes were polluted with this annoying low base; I thought it was my TV so I switched to another set, same result.

I used the patented family rating system of "how many out of ten," I would give the film a five and that is being generous. It was not the worst film I have ever seen, but if could get the hour and forty nine minutes back id use it to read the book.

title: Buy the book for more fun!!!!
review:
Thrillers by nature drop someone in at the deep end, immediately taking them out of their comfort zone. The Da Vinci code, based on the bestselling book by Dan Brown, follows suit by taking symbologist Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks), into a fast paced pursuit to find the true meaning behind a suspicious murder. The dead body has significance because it has a symbol on it, which opens up a religious conspiracy long forgotten but no less dangerous.

The film takes true thriller form with a truly complicated plot which will leave you thinking about the film long after it has finished. Instead of the conventional agencies used in thrillers, he is chased around Europe by a religious cult, Opus Dei; therefore creating a fresh take on thriller films. At this point a comparison would be necessary however there are no films like this, so this opens a up a new sub genre of thriller which captivated the audience. Overall the film is a good watch and we don't discourage you from seeing it but if you want the full ride of the Da Vinci Code buy the book.

title: Rubbish don't waste your time
review:
The story is plain rubbish. It is silly simplistic illogical and I'm not objecting from a religious point of view. To anyone of any intelligence the story is daft.

Aside from that - the making of this movie itself was not great. Tom Hanks is too old - squinty and puffy looking he looks tired. It would be better he retired than take such silly roles. Tatou looks like she'd rather be elsewhere. The sheer idiocy that she could be anyone of any significance is laughable.

People who go round looking at Da Vinci code sights are mad since it's all based on absolute rubbish anyway.

Angels and Demons is even more ghastly so don't bother with either.

The most anticlimactic movie ever.

title: I liked the book, but I hated the film version of The DaVinci Code.
review:
I enjoyed the book of The DaVinci Code and, to my surprise, everything that was interesting in the book was seriously missing in this film, there was no suspense, any real sense of adventure, and no real surprises at the end.

Tom Hanks is completely miscast as Langdon, and I pictured a more interesting character than his interpretation. Hanks does nothing really interesting in this film other than reacting to others and their emotions.

Audrey Tautou is also not much better as Sophie, and I also pictured another actress in this role.

The only "actor" in this film who completely redeems himself is the great Sir Ian McKellan as Teabing, even though, I pictured someone like Sir Anthony Hopkins in the role instead.

This is not like a Ron Howard film, and it shows, Howard, who is a very talented director, with such hits as Apollo 13 and A Beautiful Mind, is completely wasted, as he puts in the storyline of the book, with none of the advent's tone of the book.

Like the Harry Potter movies, the book is a whole lot better than the finished product.

Not as controversial as many people think, but nowhere near as interesting either not at all.

title: Cruddy, pseudo-intellectual garbage
review:
Can I just say that this film was the most vile mind-raping phenomenon to ever exist. People on this site are out of their minds to give it a good review for it even failed to deliver as entertainment. This film adapted a pseudo-intellectual potboiler airport novel into a Hollywood cringe-fest.

It wasted good actors like Tom Hanks, Jean Reno and Ian McKellen. It couldn't move like a thriller should, it was poorly directed by the infamous hack Ron Howard.

I don't even see why there was a controversy. I would have thought that even brainless Christians would have disregarded this since it had no factual basis for any criticism. I mean seriously, Dan Brown has no intellectual standing. He used to write and perform pop songs and he read Sidney Sheldon and decided to write thrillers instead. His novel was poorly researched and the prose style was clumsy.

title: Why do critics unanimously pan this movie?
review:
Critics have consistently called this a bad movie - the rating on Rotten Tomatoes is 25%, the director Ron Howard was nominated a Razzie for worst director, and the movie has been called one of the worst of 2006!

I wouldn't call it bad - but it isn't exactly great. I'd say that, it is at least above average. I would not watch this movie again, but I didn't mind watching it the first time, and I didn't hate what I saw.

One of the problems with the movie is that it's too long - about 2.5 hours - and that, during that time, there are long periods where nothing happens. In that sense, the movie can be boring to the point that you turn to daydreaming, or stop paying attention. The movie seems to piddle along.

Another problem that I have with the movie is that, in some annoying scenes, the characters only speak in French, and you have no clue what is happening.

Also, and I don't know if this is a problem with the movie or with the book, since I haven't read the book, but it seems that the plot to this movie and to Angels and Demons is an almost aimless drifting. Robert Langdon will discover an almost arbitrary thing, and then, through some very random string of arguments on esoteric history and signs, will come to a conclusion that is too absurd to believe, and yet is almost always correct.

Nevertheless, I don't consider this a bad movie. I didn't pay close attention to every detail - I was multi-tasking on the computer - and so I wasn't bored. Honestly, I don't see how you can watch this movie without multi-tasking. It is interesting to see how the plot unfolds, and to learn about history and conspiracy. Things do happen, and while the plot can be a little unreal it still has the consistent flow, with a number of breaks, that you would expect in a mystery. It is not exactly a thriller in the sense that you are at the edge of your seat, although it does have those moments. I would not say that it is exactly a cerebral movie, but it is still interesting to think about.

Overlooking the plot, I think that everything else about the movie was well-done. The musical composition, the camera work, the scenery.

title: Interesting, but full of holes
review:
It sure makes you think how amazing it is that all these hidden things in the paintings exists in reality (whether they were meant to be put there or not). But if you've read the book you'll see how much of the story that is missing in the film! Literally, the holes are bigger than the Grand Canyon! I can still understand what's going on and what the professor is trying to say, but it just raises more questions! Where do you find the answers? In the book!

The problem with this film is like the Harry Potter movies, where they try to make a book of over 1,000 pages into a movie that's about 2-2½ hours long. They have to cut away so much of the original shootings that the storyline gets a bit or sometimes even too hard to follow!

But overall, whether you've read the book or not, it's a good movie, but it could have been a whole lot better.

title: Movie can be enjoyed only as visual extension of the book... Read it 1st !!
review:
(I've cut paste it from my own age old post on a book community site called shelfari http://www.shelfari.com/groups/12372/discussions/32068/book-or- film- )

Just yesterday I saw the movie completely & focused to compare it with the book.

Movie, pace of the movie struck me. When compared to book, Cuts away lot of fun. But I don't think they could've done it any slower, that would have killed the movie. So basically you've to be a book reader 1st, to enjoy the movie, you've to take movie just as 'visual extension' of the book. Scenes like Swiss bank vault, Rob Langdon coming to Louvre murder scene from hotel room across the Paris, Leigh Teabings' flight from Paris & particularly London arrival are so much enjoyable in book but have made no mark in movie.

When it comes to character & actors, Sophie Nevou is perfect, I think character should match our imagination we make while reading, & it fits. For Robert Langdon there's no other replacement for Tom Hanks, his expression, intelligent look on face it feels like Prof. Langdon rising out of book. But I personally feel he looks bit older.....In book he's 42 right? Looks 53here :) (We've seen him in You've Got Mail, that same tom hanks would've suited perfectly) Teabing perfect, Bezu Fache I had imagined more massive n sharp. Sounier, Silas right ones.

one point, in book he wins a date promise from Sophie after a week right? (Or Am I confusing it with A&D end, no I'm not) Why have they cut the concept from movie? They just part caressing!! That's it? Possible Reasons - Tom Hanks looks too old to date young Sophie? lol! I think they want to show there is more important, different path for Sophie as last descendant of Jesus than just leading normal life now on.(???) I didn't really understand d reason for this change from book.Whatever..

My pick from movie & according to me only scene which is more enjoyable than in book, is last one when he realizes the secret. While shaving, gets a cut, blood forms red line on white basin,, he follows the secret till he's standing on Roslin n which leads to The Louvre Pyramid. It's just brilliant.

title: Film serves what purpose?
review:
((The problem with this film (as with the book) is that whether or not it was intended as fiction, for pure entertainment values, it attacks the faith of millions of believers, simply by being made. Period.

If you cannot see how that is reason enough for Christians to defend their faith, then who's being biased here?

Why can't Christians defend what they believe in? What's wrong with that? Why is defending one's beliefs wrong? Is this work of 'fiction' more important than the faith of millions, who believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God and the Son of Man and have done so for two thousand years?

Does this film really think it can change the Truth?))

The above comment was deleted as someone seemed to find my opinion abusive. I was encouraged to resubmit after editing. So I have done so below.

This film sucks.

Thank you for your time ;)

title: A critique of the book vs. the film lacked delivery and effectiveness
review:
This is a critique not a synopsis. I'm a huge fan of the books and of course I will be critical of the delivery on film, but this movie made the book seem bad. Which is not the case, the book is superb and delivered badly on film.

I've read both Dan Brown's books Angels and Demons and The Da Vinci Code a number of years ago. Upon reading both books, I remember thinking Angels&Demons was much better suited for the big screen before Da Vinci Code. The theatricals were all built into the story... but anyways, I digress...

The book The Da Vinci Code is very very good. It is intelligent enough to form questions, action packed to keep moving, filled with crime, mystery, international intrigue taking place around the famous landmarks and locations around Europe. The story involves a colorful array of characters and is in fact set as an International thriller. The book inquires and stimulates the mind and spirit as the reader follows Robert Langdon's quest for truth. This is really the universal tender that makes the book so good.

The film, directed by Ron Howard. Starring Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon follows the book chapter by chapter, step by step in its execution. To those who read the book, the movie is not bad. Unfortunately, even liking the book, the film becomes tedious and confusing. I found it annoying that they felt they had to over intellectualize the significance of every symbol and pattern in the film. The film is too politically correct when the book was not and challenged what is known as the truth and not a story created by the powers that be.

The film had plenty of funding, plenty of time and some of the most talented to make a really good book into an really good movie but what we got was overly delivered and had little significance. That's my one criticism, it's the one biggest complaint that viewers had who never read the book. They had no idea what was going on and was even more confused at the end. I guess to say in a nice way, the book was so good, it made the film didn't seem as good. But that is not the case with the Angels&Demons.

title: Great Novel. VERY Bad Film.
review: I have to admit here that i adored the novel. Despite being full of some offensive facts about Christianity (which have been refuted by church afterward), it remains from the most entertaining books i have ever read. For the film, i got disappointed. The fact here is that a good successful novel is not necessary to be a good successful film. The secret word here is the SCRIPT. In this film i felt that the script writer just did his best to transform the novel words, page by page, to successive cinematic scenes. As a result, a very boring dull film has been created. This was not a novel adaptation, this was rather a novel 'translation' if you know what i mean. Thus the film had very long speeches, unclear characters development (unlike the novel), waxy faces actors. Cinema sense is not felt during the coarse of the film. Tom Hanks was not in mood completely. I didn't feel he is Robert Langdon at all. I give this film THREE only for its fine technical quality (despite everything it has a good cinematography). A better script was badly needed to save this film.

title: It was a total lie bashing Christianity.
review:
This movie completely offended me. it was interesting, but none of this is true. I believe that God did create the universe, and us. I was talking to these atheist kids at my school, and they said "There is no proof". And I said that you really think that every cell that is doing a specific job in your' body, and how the earth is tilt just so perfectly, so it remains on the axis, and you really think that the stars in the universe, and the fish in the sea, you really think that happened by this big explosion!!! No! you didn't come, from a monkey.

I thought that it was an interesting movie and all, but i think that holly wood needs to open its' eyes a little bit more. If Christian movies like "Fireproof" are not allowed to be released into worldwide theaters, why should movies that go against Christianity have the right???!!

title: Leonardo We Hardly Knew Ye
review:
As a ritualistic murder is committed, in Paris' Louvre museum, Harvard "Professor of Religious Symbology" Tom Hanks (as Robert Langdon) delivers a lecture on "The Interpretation of Symbols". Naturally, as a famed symbologist, Mr. Hanks is called upon, to help investigate the murder. Assisting Hanks is pretty police cryptologist Audrey Tautou (as Sophie Neveu). Ms. Tautou immediately hooks up with Hanks; and, the two quickly turn from investigators to investigated. Meanwhile, fanatical self-flogging murderer Paul Bettany (as Silas) eludes capture

Writer Dan Brown's storyline is a grand one; and, director Ron Howard's film adaptation of "The DaVinci Code" is definitely well-produced. Still, it's neither as successful nor startling as the book. If you've managed to stay unfamiliar with the main plot revelations, they should be apparent by the time Ian McKellen (as Leigh Teabing) pontificates. Mr. McKellen and Mr. Bettany effectively play their showy supporting roles. Hans Zimmer contributes a marvelous soundtrack. Until something better comes along, this version of the story is intriguing, at least.

****** The DaVinci Code (2006) Ron Howard ~ Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou, Paul Bettany

title: .saw it twice, need to see it again..
review:
I've read 28-of-89 pages of comments posted here. I totally agree the book AND THE MOVIE are FICTIONAL. The film (directed by Ron Howard, scripted by Akiva Goldman) is very educationally entertaining, if you don't know too much about what the factual story is. Few users seem to know this; they did no research about the "facts" presented by author Dan Brown. One user wrote, "Dan Brown believes the documentation is fact; Ron Howard does not".

Dumb me, I had no idea "The Da Vinci Code" was causing such an uproar when the book was published (work-schedule). Therefore, IF I knew the book were being made into a film - and people all over the world were protesting it - I don't remember. I learned of it from a conversation I had with a fellow-worker.

I am a Christian and totally believe in the scriptures of The New Testament, and the holiness of Jesus. That is called "faith".

There is nothing to convince me otherwise. "Jesus of Nazareth" is my favorite movie of all time; it too, was not chronologically faithful to The New Testament. The difference between "Code" and "Nazareth" is, "Code" was filmed to be seen in a single viewing - "Nazareth" was a multi-series for British TV. Therefore, there was no concern about wasting time for character-development, nor re-arranging and discarding parts of the book's plot.

I feel Ron Howard should have made the movie much longer - in order to explain all the mysteries of the story presented through dialog - with an intermission to let the audience discuss what they had seen in the first half, so the second half would demand more attention and deep thought.

All of the actors/actresses were excellent in their roles, with the exception of diction; with the exception of "Silas" (Paul Bettany); "Sir Leigh Teabing" (Ian McKellan); and "Sister Sandrine" (Marie-Francoise Audollent), who were stellar in their roles. Although the actors who played the French police may be big stars, their elocution left something to be desired. That includes Tom Hanks ("Robert Langdon") and Audrey Tautou ("Sophie Neveu"). Movies depend upon dialog to tell the story, Ron Howard was just a bit careless not to be certain every word would be audible and understood.

"The Da Vinci Code" is a griping, fast-moving film, with the exception of character-development. People appeared instantaneously without any explanation of their importance to the story, yet we see archbishops playing pool. I found it ironic that "the last survivor (on Earth) of Jesus' bloodline" would be a police-woman, also one attempting to break the code.....also the grand-daughter of the curator of le Louvre.......he just happened to know the entire secret and the whereabouts of "The Holy Grail". How convenient. I also found it a stretch for "Sauniere" (Jean-Pierre Marielle) to painfully disfigure himself as he was dying, and to leave messages around his body to solve his murder and protect the resting-place of "The Grail". However, that made for great sleuthing for the rest of the cast, down to an archbishop of The Catholic Church.

A little research would have shown OPUS DEI ("God's Work") was not a secret faction of the church exclusively for bigwigs - it includes many ordinary people, all around the world, who are STILL radical with their self-flagellation, some of them even willing to be crucified to show their love of Jesus. They hear "take-up your cross and follow me" seriously. Paul Bettany's character exemplified that desire passionately, and his role made the entire movie meaningful.

None of the comments presented on IMDb.com mentioned that popes were not always religious people. "The Vatican" (the nation of "The Holy See") is a tiny, independent nation ruled autocratically by The Pope. He is not sent down from Heaven to be Jesus' vicar on Earth (Simon Peter), as some believe The Dali Lama is a divine being. The Pope is elected by other very ambitious, political archbishops. History certainly documents how they used the kings and queens of Europe to do their dirty work, to control the world....The Holy Roman Empire: the de Medicis, the Borgias? The Knights Exmplar were (and still may be) factual. In our present day, there is much debate whether Pope Pius XII connived with Hitler and Mussolini to save The Vatican, although he saved many Jews.

I truly enjoyed "The Da Vinci Code," and am anxious to view the DVD......a director's cut, I hope. Whether any of Da Vinci's paintings had hidden clues doesn't matter much to me. One user wrote, "Mona Lisa smiles because she knows The Holy Grail is missing and Jesus is still a bachelor." Another, "Fear men who can justify doing evil in God's name." Sounds like "Aringarosa" and "Silas" ? - does to me ! The action-scenes and the cathedrals in all those gorgeous places made-up for the few holes in the plot. I didn't find anything to laugh-at; this is a serious drama about a serious theory. As a Christian, I don't believe much of it. As for His marriage to Mary Magdalene, "google: 'The Bloodline of The Holy Grail'".

He was not divine ? Please......

I did far too much research on subjects of which I am familiar. I found "The Gospel of Mary" and read it. Now, I hope my next viewing of "Code" will be one for pure enjoyment and enrichment, WITHOUT commercials. I recommend this film for all, Christian or of any other religion. The theory that all religions have one god - Jesus and The Holy Spirit - is widely accepted. A couple of hours to lose oneself in a fascinating tale for the opportunity to further understand a topic about which one may not know too much, surely is not wasted time. I disagree with all of those who think this movie will not become a classic - it is, already. Bravo to all who had any part in its production.

title: The Da Vinci Code
review:
"Seek The Truth"

Dan Brown's controversial best-selling novel about a powerful secret that's been kept under wraps for thousands of years comes to the screen in this suspense thriller from director Ron Howard. The stately silence of Paris' Louvre museum is broken when one of the gallery's leading curators is found dead on the grounds, with strange symbols carved into his body and left around the spot where he died. Hoping to learn the significance of the symbols, police bring in Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou), a gifted cryptographer who is also the victim's granddaughter. Needing help, Sophie calls on Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks), a leading symbologist from the United States. As Sophie and Robert dig deeper into the case, they discover the victim's involvement in the Priory of Sion, a secret society whose members have been privy to forbidden knowledge dating back to the birth of Christianity. In their search, Sophie and Robert happen upon evidence that could lead to the final resting place of the Holy Grail, while members of the priory and an underground Catholic society known as Opus Dei give chase, determined to prevent them from sharing their greatest secrets with the world. Also starring Ian McKellen, Jean Reno, and Alfred Molina, The Da Vinci Code was shot on location in France and the United Kingdom; the Louvre allowed the producers to film at the famous museum, but scenes taking place at Westminster Abbey had to filmed elsewhere when church officials declined permission.

I remember reading the book a long time ago and as soon as news broke out that a film was in the works, I was so pumped. The book was a good read so I was eager to see how they'll interpret the novel to the big screen. I went nuts over this movie when Ron Howard was on board to direct and he's leading an all-star cast so my anticipation meter reached sky high.

While I can say that I was entertained, it was a bit disappointing in some points. They edited out a lot of crucial and important key scenes that was present in the novel, I know they had to consider time constraints but they should have just wiped out some minor less-important parts in the movie. I guess that's what you get when your anticipation reaches sky high.

Ron Howard does the job of entertaining us for almost two hours and the pace never slows down. The acting was great although I'm still having a hard time with Tom Hanks' killer mullet. Audrey Tautou, one of my favorite actresses, handles her English diction very well and she matches up with Hanks' on screen charisma. Ian McKellen is an effective villain and so is white albino monk Silas portrayed by Paul Bettany.

title: I liked the book better !
review:
It IS possible to make a filmproduction of a great book without loosing the strength, details, storyline, suspense, characterdepts and even the readers imagination. Just check 'Lord of the Rings'.

In this case I read the book first, indeed a pageturner which I finished in merely two days. The day after I watched the film, with high expectations.

The disappointment began after app. 15 minutes. Trying to put the story in 200 minutes, the makers fail in every possible way. Not only did they rape the storyline and characters, they also completely ignored the beauty of Da Vinci's work.

I wish I hadn't see this one, now I will have to read the book again just to forget this bad bad interpretation.

Therefor: Film 4,5 Book 10

title: Should Not Have Been Solved...
review: I was not too pleased with the movie adaptation of The Da Vinci Code. I read the book by Dan Brown and really enjoyed it. I know when a movie was made from a book much of the content could be lost. That was definitely the case with The Da Vinci Code. It seemed like the main actors were just standing around, waiting for something to do. I would only get small glimpses of what the book was like. Ron Howard should have taken more time to pull some of the more meatier parts out of the book. Religious stories are hard to cover and I thought that this movie proved my point. It could have been so much better. I would choose the book version by Dan Brown instead of the movie The Da Vinci Code.

title: Doesn't measure up to the book
review:
At the risk of sounding clichéd, I'll say the book is better than the movie, even though I haven't read the book. But it can't be worse than the movie.

The movie begins with people breaking in an out of the Louvre like it's no thing. I'm going to try it next time I visit Paris. At one point, I think one of the characters forgets something there (after already having broken in), so breaks in again to get it.

After the whole Louvre bit, other things happen, none worthy of mention.

Interesting trivia: this is the first movie in which Tom Hanks was hired under a strictly-no-acting contract, and he delivers.

Warning: This film might upset you if you're a devout Christian, due to its scientific inaccuracies.

title: It's okay...better than the book. But that's not saying much
review:
I am going to be completely honest with you. I am a Catholic...I've read the book, and didn't like it. Not because it was against my religion and all that controversy c**p. I didn't like it because it wasn't written well. With all sincerity, the original Harry Potter novel was written better than it. However, I must say that the movie is MUCH better than the Harry Potter movies. It's acted decently (I've seen Hanks do much better than this, but he still acted quite well), scripted fairly decently, paced better than the book was, and it even wraps up a few story hinges that Dan Brown couldn't work his way out of.

I can't really say that I enjoyed it, because it's just as predictable as the book was, just as corny, and the chase scenes are just as ridiculous as the next cheesy Hollywood thriller flick. But that doesn't make it evil. It is, after all, A WORK OF FICTION (despite the comments to the contrary in the front of the book, stating information in the novel as apparently "true"), and it needs to be treated as such.

Good, but not great. But then again, Michael Bay's "Transformers" was good, but not great, and I'd still see that twice over before seeing The Da Vinci Code again. Because at least Transformers had picture perfect CGI animation.

title: "Each breath you take is a sin. No shadow will be safe again, for you will be hunted by angels."
review:
I haven't read the book. But i have heard great things about it. I have seen the movie. But i have heard bad things about it. This is a movie where you have to make your own decision.

As some might already know this is a very religious film and caused controversy by religious people. So if you are a very religious person you may be disgusted by this.

The acting was 50-50 in this movie. Some were good and some were OK. Tom Hanks felt like he was in the wrong movie. He was good but he was so out of place. Audrey Tautou was good also. But there are many better people who could have played her role. I am not a fan of Ian McKellen but he did do great in this. Paul Bettany was great he is one of the actors who owns his character.

I recommend this if you have read the book. But if you have you have probably seen it anyways. I also recommend if you want a good mystery movie.

7/10

title: I am even sorry I paid to see this film
review: This movie was terrible from every point of view. The plot..how the f**k can you say you can prove something like that? Is the author of the book the anti-Christ by chance? I went in that theater room without actually informing myself regarding to what the movie is actually about. I thought it was something like Bruce Willis' movie with Da Vinci stuff to be honest. It was so bad, that I did not even download this movie once it was available as a DVDRiP (I do download the movies that I see in theatres and that I like). I don't understand why Tom Hanks accepted to lower his persona by playing in such a controversial film. Definitely one of the worst movies I have ever seen!

title: Not a bad movie but it is better to read the book first
review: OK, I am one of those people who were blown away by the book. It kept me 3 nights without sleeping because i could not stop reading.But i better talk about the movie. Having read the book and knowing already the plot and what is going to happen I still went to the cinema with high expectations because of the great cast(Hanks,Reno,McKellen).I found my self enjoying the movie although i was bored at some points.The movie was quite close to the book but it was not the best adaptation of a book.The acting was not bad, Paul Bettany was very good as Silas, Tom hanks was OK so did the rest of the cast.But still the film had lack of inspiration from the director,it may have been that i read the book already,but it did not kept me hooked like the book. Overall this is slightly above average film in everything.I advise the readers to read Dan Brown's piece first and then if they are interesting to watch the movie.

title: The Da Vinci Code
review:
The film will be boring for those people who have not read the novel and who are not a Catholic, a Christian or have some background knowledge of the history of the period of Christ and the bible. It talks about the code or the religious terms are also not easy to understand. The movie is slow, unexciting and uneventful. Audience loses track of who is who, who is bad and who is good in the movie. You have to be really concentrated or you will get lost very soon.

When it talks about Jesus affair with Magdalene and had a baby, it seem ridiculous to me. It also says that Vatican conspiring to kill people in the name of God. I think the movie insults the Christian belief and their religion. I cannot accept the idea of making fun of Christ and I am offended by the movie because it insults my faith.

Tom Hanks is not a good choice to act the brilliant and smart professor Robert Langdon. His curly hair makes the audience laugh. May be his acting of "Forest Gum" has deeply embedded in my mind. He doesn't have the charisma to convince me that he is an intelligent in this movie,the professor.

All in all, this film sucks and certainly it is not my cup of tea.

title: Knocking on heavens door
review: I came to this movie with very low expectations. I have not read the book upon which it is based, and had read and heard only bad things about this movie. To add to this I have never been a great fan of Ron Howard's movies or of the films of Tom Hanks. But I have to say this movie without being anything exceptional, was nowhere near as bad as I expected. The fact that the movie bashes organised religion was always going to appeal to me, but I do not have a clue how much of the background of this story is based on fact of if it is all fiction. The film it's self is probably to long at two and a half hours and it seemed to really drag towards the end. However it was reasonably well directed without being anything special. There where a few trite moments which felt forced just to move the plot along, but all the acting was fine I think the script really did play the characters out as national caricatures All in all not as bad as expected but I would not watch it again.

title: Hokum - Entertaining - But not thought through.
review: Isn't the whole plot rendered obsolete by the fact that both Opus Dei and the Priory of Sion want the same thing. The secret to remain secret? I found the film entertaining enough, but all rather ludicrous because surely Opus Dei - who know the secret - would not actually believe in Christianity as they apparently know the truth. I also doubt that DNA from so far back would be of any real use.It would probably only be able to show general markers. I also fail to understand Sophie's memory of her "Grandfather" having sex with a woman while surrounded by strangers in robes and masks. What was that about? So with those reservations aside - it was entertaining enough.

title: Huge Hype, No Payoff
review:
The Da Vinci Code (2006)

Review: With Tom Hanks and director Ron Howard, the hype is huge. Once again, hype is still my worst enemy. Will it ever deliver?

The Da Vinci Code is a dreary, ugly, boring and lousy movie all in one. Yeah, i'm all too familiar with the Hanks' hairdo, but this movie is worse. The story is not compelling in the least. I'm not at all a religious guy at all, but this is just flat out boring. In a another way: It did not get my attention.

With the talent pool at an all time high, even they could not save this. Another downfall is the fact that filming this across the sea, Ron Howard did not take advantage of the many scenic locations over there. The scenery because of that was awful.

The Last Word: Don't Bother. This is too long with no payoff. Booo, hiss.

title: Hod Dare They Defile The Savouir's Name
review:
As a Christian mother of six, I disapprove of this unholy inappropriate shitfest of a film, and all of its Faustenian glory. Its portrayal of our Saviour Jesus Christ is one that even the lowliest of Womyn (and men) have a hard time appreciating. This script itself seemed as an inspiration by the dark lord himself (Satan). This movie is an abomination and fails to pay its due respect to Jesus's birthday which is on 06/06/06(bc). It is also to be noted that there were no African American creature-servants to guide Jesus to release the daemon within, his Glutious maxi mus. his mud monkey, would have then made a valuable contribution to relieve Christ of His pain. I also noted a foul stench of homosexuality that had spawn from the evil directors themselves, may there souls be ever tortured in hell(new Jersy) for eternity +1.

Your faithful humble servant of your lord Optimus Prime, Reviewer

title: I believe Dan Browns books are great for movie adaptation, if and when done with the right professionals.
review:
I have read the book many times and the movie does not do it justice. I don't believe that Tom Hanks was the man for this part. Every word Tom spoke was not legible, the actions and acting was that of a beginner in class. I've seen many of Tom Hanks movies and enjoyed them, however this was not a roll for Tom. Also, I think Ron Howard should stick to comedy movies like happy days of old.

What could have been a wonderful movie, in my opinion turned into a disaster. Why don't they try this again with the proper preparation the book deserves. I hope they don't try this with Dan's other books.

THE REST OF THE CAST WAS GREAT.

title: Not so good, disappointingly so
review: A lot about this movie could have been done better. What I missed from it were: good chemistry between cast members, and a truly gripping storyline. In fact a lot could have been learned from how The Bourne Identity was done. The Discovery Of Heaven meets The Bourne Identity, but worse than either. Not one character playing as interesting as Onno, or Bourne, or Marie. The hunt and chase scenes never reach the level found with Bourne. There is enough there in terms of good actors and story content, so ultimate the producers and director are the main culprits. A pity, good and interesting stories converted to good movies are far in between as it is.

title: One time use
review:
The film has the same flaws as the book. Everything lies in the plot unveiling, and when you know the end it is tasteless.

The cast is good, I mean there are far too many good, excellent actors to get it wrong: Tom Hanks, Andrey Tautou, Jean Reno, Ian McKellen. If you can't get a decent film out of THAT cast, you're done. Even I could (just kidding).

You don't want to know the story I hope? A conspiracy about the Holy Grail being in fact Jesus Christ's bloodline.

The book was nice to read once. I still have it, but try to read it twice, and it gets so boring. Same thing for the film. Once it will be fun "how did they adapt the book?" and then you can sleep it through.

Just a cheap rent for a single use.

title: Nothing special, but worth a watch
review: The movie version of THE DA VINCI CODE is an OK action thriller, but nothing special. Tom Hanks is miscast as hero Robert Langdon, but Ian McKellan, Paul Bettany and Jean Reno all acquit themselves quite nicely as various supporting characters. Audrey Tattoo as Langdon's unexpected companion makes for nice eye candy. The plot involves tracking down the Holy Grail, among other things, and is not a bad adaptation of the book, which itself is a hokey mishmash of conspiracy theories and alternate takes on the lives of Jesus and Mary Magdeline, with lots of international derring-do thrown in for good measure. Director Ron Howard perhaps bit off more than he could chew here, but he does keep things moving at a decent pace, right up to the unnerving climax. I just wish someone other than Hanks had played Langdon. When they get around to filming ANGELS AND DEMONS, an earlier and far superior Langdon adventure involving murder at the Vatican, I'd love to see someone like Christian Bale (astutely suggested by my youngest kid) take on the role. Or Harrison Ford, if he could somehow shed 30 years.

title: 3 things regarding this film
review:
1) The cast. Often using a great cast can be a huge mistake, and among that some of them miscast! Tom Hanks is still in Forrest, Audrey Tautou is too "petite", Ian McKellen is too tall to think of him as a weak cripple, and Jean Reno is far too energetic to play a religious cop. Don't get me wrong, they all have proved being GREAT actors... it's just the movie didn't suit them. Irène Jacob would have done a great Sophie Neveu (perhaps a bit 'old') and Robson Green a magnificent Robert Langdon (excepting the FACT that he's English, maybe), probably Peter O'Toole would have done a more gloomy Leigh Teabing...

2) The film itself. I'm one of those who read the book first, so guess I'm pretty disappointed. The film begins so slow, focusing on non-important issues (Silas' whipping over Fibonacci's Sequence?? Silas' past over the Spring Rite of Sophie's grandpa??), where it should go slow goes fast, and where it should go fast goes tremendously slow. No rhetoric, plain voices all over the movie, and for music Libera would have been better. It's not that the score is bad, no, but they chose a star cast, why not a star boy-choir band? One point in favor: the flashbacks and reminiscences in time while the characters speak or think, pretty good move!

3) Beliefs. I'm raised a Christian Catholic, I know my religion in deep, this is a NOVEL; please, unless you're a living Silas, don't watch it over a historical, facts or religious basis: you'll be disappointed and enraged. Enjoy it for what it is, 'fiction'. I have an open mind, so I quote Mr. Langdon: IT CAN BE POSSIBLE. Let the mystery sensation, the what-if feeling assault you, having in mind it's a drama-suspense story. You'd be longing to be in the Louvre or in Paris, chasing the Rose Line...

So, 5 stars out of 10 in my personal opinion. My recommendation: if you read the book, don't watch it; if you HAVEN'T read the book, watch it, THEN read the book... Your mind will be more vivid in recreating scenarios and faces...

title: Of Rosslyn Chapel
review:
What made me smile was this comment about Rosslyn Chapel on this entry '...The chapel is noted for its many internal carvings, including what appears to be a depiction of American maize -- but the chapel was completed before 1492.' More propaganda from Christopher Columbus! I suspect another Catholic plot here. Read Gavin Menzies book '1421: The Year China Discovered the World' recounts that maize originated in Central America, that Magellan loaded it in the Philippines and that the Chinese transported Maize around the world. Maize is incapable of self-propagation, it needs mans help. It's now well known that the Chinese navigated around the world well before Columbus. The book says the Portuguese had a colony in Central America and that there caravels were making journeys across the Atlantic BEFORE Columbus. So why can't the Rosslyn Chapel have maize carvings

Continuity: When Langdon and Sophie approach Westminster Abbey, there is no scaffolding around the right tower in the first shot. Then, when they cross the street to enter the church, suddenly scaffolding surrounds the tower. No, look again, as Langdon and Sophie approach Westminster Abbey he is talking and the scene has 'ghostly' images of the past with people from the middle ages(?) walking past, the scaffolding is made of wood, its part of Langdon's recounting, NOT a continuity error.

Alexander Pope wrote the epitaph for Sir Isaac Newton: "Nature and nature's laws lay hid in night; God said 'Let Newton be' and all was light."

title: For Non-Readers of the Novel, I Enjoyed It!
review:
The Da Vinci Code (2006, Dir. Ron Howard)

Symbologist Robert Langdon is thrown into a mysterious and bizarre murder. Alongside Langon is the victims granddaughter and cryptologist Sophie Neveu , who with Robert discovers clues within Da Vinci's paintings. To further find the truth, Robert and Sophie travel from Paris to London, whilst crossing paths with allies and villains such as Sir Leigh Teabing and Silas. Wherever their path takes them, there discovery which is about to be revealed could shake the foundations of mankind.

I was rather optimistic about this film, and wasn't too sure what i was going to think when i decided to watch this film. I had no intention to read the novel, and still don't now, but what i saw on film, was a wonderfully crafter adventure mystery, which was a lot of fun to watch. It does have a slow start with various time when i was beginning to switch off, but when the characters really start moving, you start to gain interest again. Although i must warn you on one thing. If you find it hard to understand the story of a film, you are going to have a rough time with this one. There are certain parts of the film, in which you do feel lost and confused, but once the film finished, you could fully realise and understand the main story which was going on. There are some interesting on characters, especially Silas and some beautiful music played throughout. It's hard to mention whether readers of the novel will enjoy this, but as someone who hasn't read it, i definitely enjoyed it.

"The Holy Grail." - Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou) "A magic up. The source of God's power on earth." - Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou) "It's nonsense." - Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou)

title: Poor Ron Howard effort.
review:
It is beyond me how this below average bore-fest earned a 6.5 on IMDb. Technically, I usually enjoy Ron Howard films but this feature just doesn't cut it. Religious controversy aside, what you have is an empty , uninvolving "thriller" that utterly fails at providing a single thrill.

This film is propaganda. You can tell that its sole purpose is to try and prove the basis of Christianity wrong. Why I ask? The purpose of a film is to entertain and shouldn't be an attempt to sway viewers from their religious beliefs. I assure everyone reading this that no movie ever made could have that kind of impact on me. It's ridiculous that the makers of this film were concentrating more on proving a romantic relationship between Jesus and Mary Magdeline existed rather than focusing on the core elements that it clearly lacked such as the wooden dialogue and unimpressive cinematography.

From the terribly bland history lessons Tom Hanks mumbles to the shaky dialogue of the leading actress, this is one turkey you will want to leave in the oven. Shame on you Ron!

title: I was forced to watch this as a date movie: Loved IT!
review:
Forget reality and what your religious convictions are!

This was a great movie romp, dashing over accepted religious history. The movie reminded me of National Treasure. The book and movie trample over accepted religious facts. Note that no Christians rioted and killed people world wide. This differs with eastern religions.

The movie twists accepted religious doctrine in the favor of conspiracy theory, which makes the content fun.

At the same time, a man watches the movie and thinks, "Hey, I'd nail that French chick." The book/movie don't lecture us over morals, ethics or values; we are left to decide what is right an wrong in the movie. Turn the volume up and listen closely to the whisperings, or you'll miss some good content.

title: Unentertaining Movie
review:
THE DA VINCI CODE was an extremely boring movie. I left this movie right after seeing some insane man whipping himself. Which means I only stayed for about fifteen through twenty minutes, which is a shock because I would have stayed even if the movie was not good. This movie was just too boring to even pay attention to. I did not wish to stay at the movies any longer to watch a movie that had been criticized so much for plagiarism.

If you have read the book and loved it, do not watch this movie for it will not entertain you, and it will cause yawning in large doses. But that is just my opinion.

title: Better than the reviewers led to believe.
review:
I am not at all a fan of Tom Hanks or Opie. I always skip their movies, I never liked either. I skipped this in the theater because of these two and the dreadful reviews.

However, I rented the DVD and I was more than surprised at this movie. Having read the book, there is no way the film could ever manage to achieve the delicious and unbreakable grasp on the reader from start to finish.

If you have neither read the book nor seen the movie, by all means read the book first. Sure the book and movie are complete works of fiction. But the book is infinitely more exciting and satisfying. Like almost all of Dan Browns books, this isn't classical literature. But it is by no means dumb. The book dangles such enormous, tantalizing hooks that you should set aside an entire rainy day to read it, because it is much too engrossing to read in more than one sitting. It is rare that a book completely obliterates any sense of disbelief, and this does it. Make no doubt, its literate fluff, but it is still fluff. Instead of cotton candy, it is a delicious Godiva truffle. Not a classic book, but a great book, and one hell of a breathless page turner that makes just enough sense to completely suck you in for the day and even make you ask what if?

The movie is similar. While some of the book was changed for cinema conventions, the movie rolls along at a frantic pace, and is still engrossing. There are more spine tingling gee whiz what if moments than I would have ever expected. Opie did a good job mixing these mystery moments with car chases to keep up the action and tension and suspense. Not much is truly overdone, and not much is undercooked. He unfolds the story at a deliberate pace that doesn't ever get boring or slow. There is less character development, but hey, this is a big blockbuster Hollywood movie. The character development is more than one would normally see from a summer tent-pole, and the characters are fleshed out enough to root for them. Opie cuts the chase scenes before they get too long and stop serving the story, they are never outrageous and showy but actually suspenseful. And he cuts the mysticism and revelations before they are given the clobber treatment where things are spelled out to you. The movie, even though it is a popcorn movie, is a smart one, and expects more from the average viewer than the vast majority of Hollywood garbage. It is by no means perfect, it doesn't really deserve my 8 for quality, but it does deserve the 8 for entertainment value. I would like to think of myself as a film snob, but I greatly appreciate any movie that causes me to buy in to the story and characters, and get lost in the film and its twists and turns and suspense and gee-whiz moments.
