The DaVinci Code managed to do that for me. It was entertaining without being (for the most part) condescending. And I don't understand the b.s. about Tom Hanks hair nor his casting. Im not a fan of his, but he performed aptly and believably. Still, he cannot hold a candle to French legend Jean Reno, nor can he keep up with Audrey Tatou. Thank God the filmmakers did not add in any sense of sexual tension or romance between Hanks and Tatou. There is just not time in a 24 hour span of saving the world for a budding romance or even a quickie.

Not the best movie ever made, but it manages the rare feat of being compulsively watchable multiple times on DVD, something I couldn't say for many Best Picture winners. In my book its along the line of a Fifth Element or a Underworld. Its actually worth buying on DVD and watching over and over.

title: Good supporting cast, good cinematography, but that's all
review:
Tom Hanks was not believable as a professor (I pictured Russell Crowe as an excellent choice, and he has played a professor successfully). Audrey Tautou left me flat; she was so wimpy/passive that I think they did not want her competing with Tom Hanks. I felt that a stronger woman should have been portrayed. She is suppose to be an extremely smart woman that works for the police department. As far as the story goes, I believe that the story would have been much better if they had stayed more closely with the book. For a book with lots of suspense and action, this movie misses a lot of that.

It is really too bad the movie fails because the original story and the supporting cast are excellent. The supporting cast is the only reason I give this movie 4 stars. Hopefully they will never use Tom Hanks to portray Dr. Robert Langdon again.

title: A pleasant surprise!
review:
I picked this movie up on a whim, on a Saturday evening, with time to myself.

Reviews on release were lukewarm, so I wasn't expecting a lot.

What I got was a top drawer thriller, with intelligence, a fair bit of boldness in it's style, and lots of watchable actors doing decent jobs.

Never having read the book might help your enjoyment, as the plot twists all over the place. Robert and Sophie never know who to trust, and neither should you. It's great Saturday night fare, and one of the best thrillers I've seen in a long while.

As a standalone movie, and ignoring the book completely, I found this thoroughly enjoyable. And if nothing else, Audrey Tatou is absolutely divine. A solid eight.

title: Great movie to watch!
review: In my opinion Da Vinci Code has taken everyones attention, not to mention the scandal that has been cause at different religions. To really understand the movie or to have an idea of what is actually the mystery inside the movie, I will suggest reading the book first. Even though this movie looks and feels so real, reading it just makes you wonder why and how all the facts that we have known about Jesus are just appearing in this century. I personally read and watched the movie in concern of information in order to have the ability to discuss in my temple. Dan Brown has done a great book making him more famous. Overall this movie is a well done fiction movie.

title: Ron Howard didn't crack the Da Vinci Code.
review:
I have read the book before seeing the movie with family members who haven't. Thanks Heavens we watched it on DVD because after every 10 minutes we had to stop for me to explain what was going on.

It seems that director Ron Howard and his script-writers have left out just about everything that would have added some depth or meaning to an otherwise not bad, but far-from-great novel.

The cast is an enigma to me. Audrey Tatou in all of her roles is always herself, and I think few are extraordinarily fond of her (she is somewhat creepy) and Tom Hanks, otherwise good as he may be, here with a humiliating toupee or bob, whichever)is not fit for the role of an adventurous beau professor, either.

Paul Bettany excels as Silas (okay, he is always great), he is outstanding in an otherwise extremely poor movie. Ian McKellen is miscast. Alfred Molina tries his best but the role he has has been twisted been emptied by the movie makers. Even Jean Reno has such a poor role that I completely forgot he had anything to do with the flick and just got reminded as I went through the cast.

This all adds up to a movie where - as our private screen testing revealed- nobody gets anything who hasn't read the book, and the ones who have feel they have to apologize.

The others didn't get that Silas is a victim of fanaticism and is betrayed. They saw a freak and serial killer in him.

Nobody understood what the catholic Church was doing with Bishop Aringarosa.

Nobody seriously believed that Audrey Tatou's character understands even part of what she is talking about (as it could not be understood by anyone who has not read the novel).

The novel has something of the Umberto Eco's Name of the Rose- some thinking, some theories, some religious sacrileges, to give you a spooky and enjoyable medieval feeling. The movie completely fails to transfer this. Instead, the characters do an awful lot of talking- which is really annoying, as the characters portrayed by the badly picked actors are, other than in the book- and from their lengthy and cheesy dialogs is the complicated story to unfold. Well, it doesn't.

If there is anything good to be credited to the novel of Dan Brown, it is the atmosphere and tension related to mysticism, fanaticism and religion in general, as well as the secretiveness of the sects involved that hook you and make you read the novel in one night. Nothing of that atmosphere was cast in the movie adaptation. Less talking (or even a dark, male narrator's voice) and a little more tension could have done most of the job.

If there ever was a movie deserving a 1 out of 10, this surely does.

title: Depicts the Catholic Church at its Best!
review:
Ron Howard does it again! And another stellar performance by Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon, an interpreter of ancient symbols and cryptography. This is the first time that a film prompted me to buy the book. Dan Brown leaves you wondering where the line is between fiction and truth. The story goes beyond the normal thriller in that the plot isn't predictable. It had me doing my own research into the Priory of Scion Leonardo Da Vinci, Galileo, Isaac Newton, etc. The entire subject must be approached with an open mind. And now (June 18, 2007), "The Da Vinci Code" is being investigated by Italian state attorneys on the grounds that it is "obscene" from a religious perspective... get real! The state prosecutor did reveal that the complainants are Catholic clergy. So now the reality of this complex, intriguing and often factual subject continues.

I have one word for this film and its storyline... awesome!

title: Outstanding Production
review: I will not comment on the content of DaVinci Code. What is truly compelling about this film is Ron Howard's production. He goes from darkness to light, his commentary on the content, I do believe. Also I found Tom Hanks to be outstanding. He makes the viewer take his interpretation of his character seriously. I enjoyed watching him fulfill his role. Other actors also were very believable ~ except the Opus Dei bishop. Watch this film for its production values, don't try to make sense of the film's content. It's fiction so have a good time viewing because it's not understandable. I also had a good time trying to figure out where the film was made. With so many wonderful buildings and edifices to select, Howard made excellent choices. In the end, it's not the story but the characters and production values that are compelling.

title: glad I didn't see it in the theater
review:
Once again, another movie that is no where near as good as the book. I read the book a couple of years ago, and I thought it was good and suspenseful. But, partly because I already knew the ending, this movie did not live up to the hype. But it wasn't just that I knew what would happen, but there are just too many slow moving scenes and puzzles seemed boring in the movie. It made a lot more sense and was much more suspenseful in the book.

Silas character did not come off that great in the movie. He was much better and scarier in the book. And Hanks and Tautou had little chemistry. It was almost painful to see them together on screen.

FINAL VERDICT: If you are interested in the story, read the book and do not see the movie.

title: Enjoyable historical fantasy
review: I entered The DaVinci Code never having read the book. To be honest I started reading Angels & Demons and just couldn't enjoy Dan Brown's prose. So I came to this movie with no preconceived notions of what the film adaptation of the book should be like. As such, I had no real problem with Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon. He does a fine, though rather unimpressive job in the role. Hanks is good in everything he does, but while he could have shone here as he has in other films, there just doesn't seem to be that extra spark. Audrey Tautou is actually my pick for a better actor in the film. She delivers a conviction to her role. I also really got a kick out of Sir Ian McKellen. I was actually surprised at the sheer amount of familiar faces in the film. Its rare to see this many talented actors in one place. Its just too bad that they were not put to better use. In the end, DaVinci Code is an enjoyable historical fantasy (we can't call it fact as it is supposition and unproven) and as such is a decent time waster.

title: One of my 5 least favorite movies.
review: You might like this movie. This just wasn't for me. It was practically like a modern day film-noir. I just didn't like this movie. If you liked it, you probably won't agree with me. This movie was terrible! It was just so bad. First of all, let me start with the goods. Um, oh thats right. There was nothing good about this movie! Now, the bads. This movie was just so bad! It had absolutely no story. It just went on and on and on and on and on for about 2 1/2 hours. It had such talented actors like Tom Hanks and Ian Mcellan (I don't know how his name is spelled). It was just a waste of talent. This movie knew exactly how to ruin such a great book. The book had a great mystery and story. I just wanted somebody to make a movie about it. But I wasn't expecting this. There is absolutely no mystery. There is no drama and it is not thrilling like the genre says. Also, before I finish, if you have seen it, that part with the car going between the bus and the wall or something, that doesn't happen in real life! But this movie does deliver one good thing. The movie was fast. Somehow, but I don't know. This was a horrible movie. I think that it is the second worst movie ever next to "Sea of Fear". This was horrible. 1/10.

title: An awful movie
review: This film is neither disrespectful nor brilliant. It,s one of the most ridiculous film I've ever seen in my whole life. A piece of gossip turned into a so called feature film. Besides, it's pretty much boring and sometimes made me laugh. What a waste of time! Its cast is a ruin. Great actors like Tom Hanks, Paul Bettany(about his character had better not say a single word...), Alfred Molina or Jean Reno wander terribly throughout its exaggerated runtime. Fortunately, I saw this dreadful movie on DVD so I hadn't to pay a price which this film is worth nothing at all. Moreover, its historical background is as stupid as the script of a teenage movie (in case of this kind of movies have something similar to a minimal idea to develop...) In fact, when a movie like this is based upon a successful but superficial best seller there's only a purpose: to make a fortune. Nothing more is the goal that make a great amount of money with such a short lived blockbuster. Though other reason would be make a fuss in order to increase the world wide box office. More than two and a half hours of non stop nonsenses played by a couple of actors without spark moving on all sides like puppets in search of... What? What a mess! I've marked this movie with one star because of there's not negative stars...

title: A Little Satisfying.
review:
The Da Vinci Code movie was, in a way, satisfying but if you were a fan of the book, I doubt this would have anything new to give you. I guess the movie is not as awesome as the book as is the case with the other books-turned-to-movies. The movie certainly can't be credited as a "work of art" but it certainly is a huge blockbuster even if it was rated R-18. Who can resist a controversy? The cast is amazing! Audrey Tatou (being one of my favorite actress) is perfect as Sophie Neveau (also one of my favorite fictional characters off all time). Paul Bettany (another of my favorites) played Silas (another fave F.C.) flawlessly (not to mention I got to see him stark naked ::PervertMeTalking:). Sir Ian McKellen (yup, another of my veteran favorites) is greatly convincing as Sir Leigh Teabing (another fave F.C.) and, as always, Tom Hanks plays his character Robert Langdon almost to perfection. Kudos also to Jean Reno for an amazing job playing Fache.

I guess my only complaints are that, if you weren't able to read the book, the plot would confuse you (but I guess that's not much of a problem guessing as almost everybody on this planet HAVE read the book). Plus, it's such a shame that the movie didn't show the reunion between Sophie and her brother. That scene in the book did, in fact, almost made bawl like a baby.

However, I think that the final scene in the movie (when Langdon fell down on both knees on the Louvre after going through the supposed Rose Line) is deeply moving.

title: A pretty good thriller
review: I just thumbed through Angels And Demons-a mass media paperback,written by Dan Brown.Only cursory-nothing specific.I find this writing hateful to my intellect and my own person.This book,Angels and Demons-is so stupid and hateful-to the quality of American society-that it is a book for retards-and not true men.Angels and Demons is a complete disgrace to human history,specifically-to the fine grand and powerful art of writing-going back to the great writers like Plato and Marcus Aurelius,and also to the fine writers of today,such as William Faulkner-amongst many others.It is writing for a ninth grader-disguised as adult popular fiction.It adds absolutely nothing to my great Western Culture.It disguises its fraud with esoteric references to the ancient history of the Catholic Church. The movie Da Vinci Code is more complicated.It spreads a hatred for the Opus Dei-literally-Work of God-movement-that-in actual fact-must be much more benign-and loving-than could be portrayed in a Mass-media paperback/movie.This being a dramatic movie-the evil albino Opus Dei follower-Silas- must of course, be psychotic.I say to you, my reader-this is artistic license.I say to you-Dear reader-that the pathetic Slander against Opus Dei is unfounded.For Christ's sake-Opus Dei is a bunch of Catholics-who wish to serve God.Catholics are Not Psychotic!I mean-C'mon!That being said, this is a thrilling and pretty plausible thriller-about: The End of Catholicism.That is to say-The Bitter End of The Catholic Church.Thom Robbins of course wrote the book,Another Roadside Attraction,about the end of Catholicism- a mere 37 years ago.In the end,Tom Hanks looks distracted.Audrey Tatou looks rather fetching.This is a thriller-let's move on to the next thing already.

title: Boring as a blank canvas
review:
Leonardo Da Vinci + Tom Hanks + Ian McKellan + Ron Howard should = a good film, but the Da Vinci code is as interesting as a blank canvas.

The plot: take every conspiracy theory you've ever heard of - leave out the space aliens - glue them all together with bubble gum, and you've got The Da Vinci code. It's a confounded mess that goes on and on like a twisted maze and in the end adds up to absolutely nothing.

Tom Hanks looks absolutely bored throughout the entire film. Ian MacKellan is good, as he usually is.

I guess the film had to be made by someone since the book was such a best seller. Dan Brown is laughing all the way to the bank.

title: Not offensive, but way too long
review:
We all know the ridiculous 'controversy' brought about by extreme religious nuts about this movie. It IS fiction. Too bad it isn't GOOD fiction.

After a very promising and interesting start, the movie devolves into a vehicle where the director seems to be trying to figure out just how many 'twists' he can throw into one movie. Trust me, there's about 800 too many. Also, this film seemed like it was going to end about four different times, and when it didn't, it wasn't interesting at all. It was just a DVD that we were watching that seemed to never end.

Huge production values and good acting really couldn't save this contrived mess. 4 out of 10.

title: Pretty good for a movie from the book.
review:
I love this movie very very much.

But this movie or book is a very controversial subject matter. Okay guys it's called FICTION!!! GET OVER IT!! Now that I got that off my chest back to the Movie.

The book was definitely better and I was very disappointed when I found out that the director missed SO much from the book to the movie.

But the part that REALLY made me mad was the ending, how he screwed it all up like that. I literally was planning on smashing and breaking the rented disc, but decided against it.

Like COME ON! Jacques Sauniere IS her grandfather!! It's not that hard Mr. Director to put that part in the movie! Sure it makes a better ending but COME ON! You already screwed up half the movie. At least get something RIGHT! I have also researched that the history of the movie is extremely far-fetched and do-sen't fit at all, and for someone who hasn't read the book I would believe to be confused while watching the movie. Im my opinion you should'nt watch this movie until you read the book. You will have a lot better understanding of the movie.

Well sorry for taking it out on all you guys but I needed to take that out on something.

title: Actually better than the book
review: It doesn't happen often, but in this case, the movie is better than the book. What the author didn't execute well in print the screenwriter and director *greatly* improve upon in this film adaptation. Gone is the cliché-ridden dialogue and, in its place, a fast-paced, well-executed thriller. It's not a great film, but certainly much better than most reviews would lead one to believe: the cast is solid and make the characters much more believable than the book, the flash backs and overlays representing historical events make events much more compelling than the book did, and the intrigues and red herrings just keep coming. As usual, Ron Howard delivers a visually-stunning film. A movie that will more than hold your attention until the final credits roll.

title: The Da Vinci Code... better than book was!
review: I'll do my best in here! First, It took long time before i decided to watch the movie, why, well because i think that Book was really bad, good idea, but written badly) anyhow. FIrst i tough, Ron Howard, great director, actors... great so it cant' be totally bad and i finally take risk and watch it! I'm happy that i did watch it. It was one of the better movies i have watch in this year (and that list is long). All the idiotic and boringness of the book was gone and there was great movie left! Actors fit to the characters pretty good, storyline was interesting and kept me watching all the way to the end. No pause anytime! Ay, as i told, I that think book was boring and... well that's enough of that... so this is the first ever movie what was actually better than book where story comes!

title: Some HUGE howling mistakes
review:
OK, I watched this on DVD last night and tried to have as open a mind as I possibly could.

It's very obvious that Tom Hanks was never the 1st choice for the lead role in this film. Not even 2nd, 3rd, 4th 5th or 6th choice I would have said. And reading the trivia for the film I was gratified to discover my feelings were correct.

I totally didn't recognise Audrey Tatou but she was excellent in her role and out performed Hanks in every scene they were both in. Jean Reno was excellent as the Opus Dei police inspector but he was a bit clichéd in certain sections of the film.

Sir Ian McKellern was brilliant and his unexpected heel-turn totally threw a spanner into the smooth running plot of the film.

The locations and sets of the film all look wonderfully, some of the characters are a tad annoying, Silas the albino monk especially so.

I noticed a couple of huge mistakes. The British Police vehicles, namely the grey BMW's with orange stripes. No Uk police forces use BMW's and all police car markings are yellow, not orange.

Also in the sequence where Silas has shot the armed police, they would have no need to issue him a verbal challenge to open fire. Under the armed rules of engagement he could have shot and killed Silas with no problems at all.

When he was shouting at Silas to drop his weapon, the gun Silas was holding was clearly empty - with the working parts fully forward meaning there were no rounds in the pistol and he was no longer a risk.

The officer who opened fire therefore committed an act of murder.

Once Ian McKellern told us the Holy Grail was a living person I worked out it was Audrey Tatou right away. That outcome was totally predictable.

The films ending is very weak, where they show where the tomb actually is. Right back where the story 1st started for Tom Hanks, in The Louvre.

This film was way over hyped and no-where near as good as the hysteria over the book and the stories behind it led us to believe.

Watch with an open mind and enjoy the visuals.

title: Great movie
review:
I'm picky about historical or even quasi historical movies but I am happy to report that this is a marvelously entertaining movie. A word of caution for anyone who has read extensively on the subject of the Holy Grail, Rennes Le' Château, the Priory of Sion, the St. Clair (or Sinclair) family, and early church history: There are a number of very obvious inaccuracies that could be annoying to a perfectionist! I won't say what they are but in my view they do not detract from the film in any significant way.

The movie incorporates some of the locations and figures associated with Priory myth and even the generally understood significance of the Rose Line is incorporated effectively (this line doesn't just pass through Paris!). Tom Hanks turns in his usual accomplished performance. Audrey Tautou easily holds her own against heavy weight Hanks and further she is in a word gorgeous. Paul Bettany almost steals the movie and offers yet another astonishing performance. This man's acting range is incredible. Jean Reno, Ian McKellen, Alfred Molina also provide strong performances in very important supporting rolls. I almost hesitate to call McKellen's roll supporting since he is integral to the plot but he doesn't make an appearance until the movie is almost half over.

Ron Howard has done it again. This movie is a near perfect blend of complex plot, great characters we come to care about, a nice blend of action and drama, and for once no silly romantic subplot although the attraction between the female and male leads is palpable by the end of the movie and one wonders why they didn't fall into each others arms. The music and cinematography are also wonderful. I recommend it highly.

title: managed to stay awake
review:
Review: Other than the fact that I found the book so mind-numbingly boring and horribly written (grammar for starters) I had to put it down, the movie wasn't too awful. Dan Brown should have stuck with the theories and concepts and nixed the stupid "thriller" stuff or just gone with the thriller stuff alone. Actually, he would have failed miserably at the theories. Actually, the "thriller" part wasn't that good either. The movie was tolerable up until they started running from Château Villete.

Other: The ideas aren't new. From actual ancient documents, it is clear things are not nearly so cut-and-dried as the Catholic/Christian religion would like. But Dan Brown munged a lot of facts and theories. It is very possible Mary Magdelene could have been Jesus Christ's wife. A definite was there was no consensus on whether Jesus was divine or human, or some strange combo of the two. The idea of that the Council declared Jesus being divine actually lasted for the first 300 years or so of Christianity. The Nicene Council was called because one faction wanted to assert its view as canon law (truth or lie has no relevance at these things) and declare the rest heretics.

title: There's nothing else matters.
review: I think (and it was said in film, by the way) the only thing that matters is what you really believe in. I'm sure. Whatever that you stand for, that you protect sincerely. REAL faith is your true. It is REAL strong belief that can make the blind see, and the crippled walk. It is miracle, wonder. And maybe the idea is to show that human is able to work wonder? Don't you believe in it? If your faith isn't REAL, if it can be somehow broken, destructed it's useless. You haven't believed yet, there's nothing to stand for. And real pious needn't evidence. Loads of facts against his belief can do nothing with his mind. It's a tragedy, if a believer is forced to doubt. I don't protect, excuse or justify Silas, and Opus, and Vatican, for their "methods" of believing and religionizing. That's a vast topic to discuss. There is one important aspect: Mind you, I accept and understand only peaceful humanistic religions and beliefs. No aggression, no violence. Was Jesus kind human, paragon of sanctity OR divine or God? Maybe, he was just fairly convincing? I mean for those people who got his help by Gospel. If your faith helps you to get out of life troubles, to live fairly, honestly, generously,BLESS YOU! Dan Brown's research is quite interesting. Why not? One of the points of view, one more perspective is entitled to life. That big research worths attention.

title: Very well planned movie
review: I have just spent the entire evening watching this movie and couldn't help realize how sick Tom Hanks sounds in it. Did he have a cold or the flu? If that was the case why couldn't he wait until he was better to make the movie. The entire movie was quite intense and well acted out. The brutal violent scenes were a bit overwhelming to watch, especially Silas and his nude body covered in scars and wounds of all kinds. I felt scared to death by his looks , but alas he was part of the movie so i best not complain for i waited for ages to buy it and now i own the movie and will love its mystery and religion base. I would recommend this movie to any one who does not believe in god or who is not a practicing Christian. I myself have not went into the house of god until Christmas. I always believed in something much higher and until now i wondered if there even was a real God or Jesus. This movie can really make you think about the everyday symbols we see and pass by every day on the streets and billboards. so next time you see something that looks like a bad omen,think again and see how it can affect you and the people surrounding you.

title: It would have made a better book.
review:
Seriously Reading the book it seems that such a thrilling tale should make a great movie, especially one starring Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou. But things don't always work out. With loads of details and frequent plot twists the story becomes cumbersome to translate into a feature film. This saturation instead produces a talking-heads routine where the picture depends on constant dialogue to relay the necessary information, and really without enough pay-off. Ian McKellen, however, delivers a superb performance, and even manages to pull of an otherwise boring 15-minute monologue sequence in captivating style as usual.

http://manwithavan.blogspot.com/

title: One of the best adaptations of a book I've ever seen.
review:
The only reason I did not give this a ten out of ten was because I reserve that for "Citizen Kane." This wan excellent film. As to the controversy surrounding the film, wake up people. It is fiction, nothing more. Dan Brown never claimed that it was anything more and the people who attack the film tend to do so for religious reasons.

I am not a Tom Hanks fan, never have been, but having read the book and seeing his performance I could no more see anyone else in the part than I could part the Red Sea. Ron Howard assembled a fine cast with stars like Sir Ian McKellan, Jean Reno and Paul Bettany, not to mention Alfred Molina, all of whom gave finely crafted performances. I was not prepared to find a film that was as good as this one was after hearing a number of people run it down. I can only say they were wrong, wrong, wrong!

title: I enjoyed the film
review:
A good few beers and a night with not much to do. I like Paris and used to live in London so seeing my old haunts was good for me..... The idea of the book and the response from Rome shows how near the mark some of the comments could be.

As far as a "royal" linage is concerned I would be amazed if it could be kept a secret for this long. Although I guess the "maisons" would have a few words to say on that front.

One thing the book and the film made me do, was to review the "fresco" of the last supper, the person sitting to JC's right sure looks like a lady to me

However I do not take such films too seriously, like some.

title: Basic Review
review: Although I absolutely adore this film the book and everything to do with it I think that Sir Ian McKellen was too nice as Teabing. He was always a sort of Jekyll and Hyde character in my imagination. Maybe thats just my imagination going wild but you know. While Paul Bettany (Silas) excelled at his part. I jumped many times and his image haunted me well after the film had finished. The chemistry between Sophie (Tautou) and Robert (Hanks) was only apparent in certain scenes, but in the book it is clear they are attracted to one another. Tautou made the character of Sophie believable and also made you want to protect her - perhaps explaining the brother/sister relationship I thought they portrayed. In total, I absolutely ADORED the film.

title: A lot better than I thought. ENDING IS ANALYZED HERE.
review:
I had a very low expectation of this movie given the blandness of many of Howard's films and was pleasantly surprised. I guess being forced into making an action oriented film because of the nature of the book made Howard actually give some drive to this. Despite a weak opening sequence in which Hanks sends the entire French police force into the streets while he deciphers the meaning of the dead body in the museum, the movie moves quite quickly and has a different ending than the book.

The ending at first seems intriguing but then you think about it and its laugh out loud re-god-damn-diculous. Hanks and the chick from Amelie run around escaping death, being pursued by the cops because she's 'the last living link to Jesus', then A HUNDRED FRIGGING PEOPLE SHOW UP AT THIS SUPER SECRET PLACE THAT WAS ENCODED IN TEN DIFFERENT IMPOSSIBLE TO BREAK CODES. Which renders the entire movie pointless. If all these people knew where the final location was, then why the hell didn't they just tell her? They all knew who she was yet forced her to go through hell to find it? Retarded. Stupid. Annoying. But a good movie.

title: It's as good as any director could do it
review:
A lot of criticism has been leveled at this movie, almost as much criticism as the book itself. But I'm of the firm belief that this is the kind of story that doesn't adapt easily to the big screen and Ron Howard has done the best he was able to do with the material he was given.

My only complaint is the casting choices. I agree with Sir Ian McKellan and Paul Bettany - they were the right choices (perhaps the only choices) but I think Tom Hanks and Audrey Tatou were the wrong choices to play Langdon and Neveu. Hanks is just not the Langdon type (if you've read the book, you'll know what I mean) and Tatou just looks to me like some kind of wilting lily, not the tough assertive woman portrayed in the book. I would have much preferred something along the lines of Harrison Ford and Sophie Marceau.

Jean Reno did a decent enough job as Bezu Fache. When it comes to playing French policemen, Reno basically monopolizes those roles!

The movie does do a fairly good job of following the book plot. There's a few minor changes in the movie but nothing worth mentioning. The "extended version" of the movie, now out on DVD, adds an approximate extra half hour to the running time and the extra scenes concentrate mainly on Bishop Aringarosa's dealings with the secret Vatican council.

By the way, look out for a cameo appearance in the movie from Dan Brown himself! He appears at the beginning when Hanks is doing his symbology conference. When Hanks is signing books, Brown is in the crowd talking to someone. Just look out for the Harris Tweed jacket and the blond moppy hair!

All in all, quite a good movie and surprisingly quite faithful to the book.

title: Excellent movie
review:
I had read the book sometime back and plan to read it again. This movie was very fast paced and Tom Hanks did an outstanding job and was a great match for the part. The plot was like a repeat of a church history class and made you think back to what you were taught. By helping you to think about what was happening, it helped me to think about my thoughts as a Christian. There now is plenty of research to do on some of the ideas brought up.

I don't mean this as a spoiler but this is how i feel. Unfortunately this movie got a lot of bad press from the church because they seemed to be threatened by it. I enjoyed being challenged by new ideas and thoughts and the plot was excellent at doing this. Supposedly controversial films serve a purpose for they help us examine our present ideas and then ask questions.

Most of all this movie was based on a book of fiction which was right away apparent to me. The many twists and turns in the action and the characters developing into who they were, kept me focused at all times on this movie. There was plenty of human interest too for the grand daughter was very down to earth and really cared for the other characters.

I enjoyed the moving action and the shifting scenes toward the end. This film was hard to figure out which kept me fascinated. Ron Howard films are always great to watch. I would recommend seeing this movie and I am considering buying a copy. The movie ending was a surprise which was great to see. Unpredictable movies keep us wanting to watch more and more of them.

title: Tom Hanks
review: I agree with you, the book was most definitely better...Tom Hanks was not what i except from Robert Langdon. It still bothers me about that. I pictured him with blue eyes, and light brown hair. And they forgot the ending, didn't they?, it might have been in Angels & Demons though, but doesn't Neavu find her mom in the house next to the church at the very end???... i read the two books back to back so I always get confused. I hope they come out with an Angels & Demons movie....but yet again, Tom Hanks would bother me, and the book would most likely be better. It was a lot more twisted in the book. But you should def. watch the movie AFTER reading the book....it's just so much more interesting

title: a lot of hype about nothing....
review:
so this evening I finally saw THE Da Vinci code with a girlfriend who was so clever to let the whole hype pass by ( both book and film) just as I did. but this evening we decided to watch it and so we can make our own judgment about the whole hype.

like I said , i wasn't into the hype at all. yes of course I read a bit here and there ( because it was impossible to ignore it completely by the media) and I know it was a bit about, secret Christian society, a lot of codes,Da Vinci and heir of Jesus.but I didn't knew anything about specific story lines and plot twists...

though, ... it was really very painfully predictable to me... McClellan and butler turns to be bad guys...NOOOOO, chick turns to be the heir of Christ...NOOOOOOOOOI hadn't see those coming ( for the morons among us this is Ironic)like many other things in this movie :predictable escapes(of course)the one a bit more realistic than the other; the heroic death of the monk;the betrayal...really the whole movie.though I was a bit amused by some conversations about the secret society and the history of the Grail. accidentally I read a lot about the Grail when I was a child and all the fancy stories of the templar knights and its secrets. I read them many ,many years before I watched this film so I was already totally up to date :-)

but my final conclusion is that it was totally predictable and a bit lame,I think the actors agreed with me, because everyone sucked big time ( Mcclallen was OK, but the rest should be ashamed of themselves) and at a certain moment I even didn't care about how it should end... the chick dies, fine! the chick doesn't die also fine!she marries tom hanks and make the next heir with him, be my pleasure;where are Magdalena's remains, who gives a f*ck... I really didn't care during the end of the film.honestly this not the worst film i've ever seen, but its definitely totally not worth the hype, the story isn't really that brilliant, maybe the book is better I don't know, but i believe it will have a lot more of suspense... the good: Ian Mc clellan,Silas, the Hans zimmer soundtrack; the bad: the acting of all the rest; the ugly : the story

don't spoil your money and time on this hype, you can also live a nice peaceful and happy life without seeing this overrated hype thing I rest my case

title: An Unusual Review
review:
If I ever have the pleasure of meeting Tom Hanks I probably owe him an apology. Often times a movie will be released and receives so much hype from critics and movie goers that if I don't see it within the first 48 hours of its release I won't see it for quite some time. I'm not sure there is any logical explanation for this. Perhaps I get tired of people quoting and/or talking about the movie. Perhaps I fear that the hype surrounding the movie will only spell disappointment for me as I sit in the theater. For this reason I didn't see Rain Man for at least 10 years after it was released in the theaters. For this reason I will probably never see any of the Austin Powers movies.

This has happened to me twice with Tom Hanks and I now own 9 of his movies. I didn't see Forrest Gump for the first time until a year or two ago. The second was The Da Vinci Code which I just finished watching for the first time. Now, this movie is still pretty recent and is actually still considered a new release on DVD. This is one movie I should have seen in the theater for the set pieces alone! I guess this is as good a time as any to mention that I have never read the book and probably never will (sorry Dan Brown). I don't read fiction, which is not to say I don't read. I know that much of the criticism this movie has received is based on how closely it follows the novel.

This is an argument that will never end and it's one I don't quite understand. We're talking about two completely different mediums that satisfy and stimulate two completely different parts of our brains. People that whine and complain about how much better a book was than the movie that followed are totally unrealistic. Books have an unlimited amount of time (pages) to discuss the smallest of details. The same people that bemoan movies for not being true to the book from which they were adapted would no more enjoy sitting in a movie theater for 4 hours watching the sincere version of the story that they were hoping to see.

All that being said, I think The Da Vinci Code is a superb movie. If you've read the book and seen the movie yet feel the movie was "lacking" ask yourself this. If you'd never read the book, how would you feel about the movie? How can you not enjoy this movie. I suppose that is the challenge a director like Ron Howard and an actor like Tom Hanks face when making a movie from a book that was so widely read as The Da Vinci Code.

There really isn't enough room here to discuss plot points and most of you reading this probably already know the gist anyway. Just know that this is a fantastic thriller. I'm not terribly religious so I had no personal objections to the content. The twists and turns keep you guessing until the very end as quality movies of this kind should.

As I said the set pieces are gorgeous. The directing is top notch (the ever reliable Ron Howard rarely disappoints) and the acting is everything you'd hope for and expect from one of our greatest actors, Tom Hanks. I firmly agree with those who compare Hanks to Jimmy Stewart as today's version of the "every day hero". Audrey Tautao stands toe to toe with Hanks in the role of Agent Sophie Neveu.

This movie is one that I am sure to view several times over the course of the next month trying to soak up all the clues and details that I missed during the first viewing. I'd also read several reviews that stated the movie was too confusing to follow. Not so at all. I had no problems following the movie or understanding what was going on. That being said, there is a lot to take in.

I think what confuses me the most about those who are fans of cinema yet did not like this movie is that The Da Vinci Code is a movie fan's movie. It's a thrill ride from start to finish that relies very little on special effects and when they are used they are used very tastefully to help further the advancement of the plot.

If you're expecting to be satisfied in the same way you were when you read The Da Vinci Code my advice is to wait for Dan Brown's next novel. If you are in the mood to enjoy a thrilling movie that excites on every level a movie should than The Da Vinci Code is sure to please.

title: Excellent
review:
I have read the book and then I just was compelled to see the movie. The adaptation from book to film is very good. And I mean Veeeeeery good. I was amazed at the way the plot was developed in the screen. Even though I'm no film maker, I think it was quite a difficult book to turn into a movie. Probably the presence of Dan Brown helped and the directorial talent of Ron Howard was no small thing either. Hanks and Tautou deliver the strength of their characters and Reno's role is simply delightful to watch. All in all, a very tight production, deserving (I think), some nominations for the BIG Academy Awards.

On another side, I've read a lot of reviews posted here by people that seem to have lost the real meaning of what they are criticizing. This is just a work of fiction (both the movie and the book, of course), and as such, a SUPERB work of fiction. Who cares if Phillip's gospel was written in Arameic, Copt, or English, for that matter?. It is just a literary license, useful to tell a story. Who cares if the Nicea Council was held to determine Jesus' divinity, to unify concepts between ancient christians or whatever?. Again, it's just a literary "trick" to tell a story. And Brown uses these (as well as others) brilliantly. The way that he combines symbology, bigotry and criminal investigation is simply great.

I think that if someone is too dogmatic and narrow minded, you should not get close to something that, even being fiction, could threaten your closely held beliefs. After all, the role of education is to take an empty mind and turn it into an open mind.

title: Certainly not the worst
review:
I loved the book and I thought that Ron Howard did an excellent job of covering such a wealth of detail in a movie. I cannot see why so many people are slamming this movie. Perhaps people cannot view the book and movie as a work of fiction and are threatened by the views that are different than those that we have lived with for a long time. The only real threat is the inability to question and to think independently. I am not saying that I buy the ideas in this movie, but I am not threatened by them either.

I have talked to many people who have thoroughly enjoyed this movie. They may not have gone to the theater to watch the movie, but were spellbound by the movie when rented on DVD.

title: More Blank than Frank
review:
The Da Vinci Code is a decent film that could have been a great one, but it has some problems. In what follows, I'm going to focus on the problems, as a bit of constructive criticism.

Unlike many viewers, I don't believe that the problems are related to the film's subject matter or "thesis". I also don't believe that the problems lie with the book-to-film "translation". I don't take this film as anything other than fiction, and I like my fiction to have strong fantastical elements. For me, there is no taboo subject matter, and there are no taboo ways of fictionalizing the actual world to create interesting artworks. As for book-to-film translations, in my view it is a mistake amounting to a category error to try to compare books and films--they're two very different mediums. It's not only fine for films to be very different from their corresponding books and vice versa, it's unavoidable.

Rather, the problems with The Da Vinci Code all stem from one fact that requires much caution when storytelling--it's plot-heavy. The story here (and keep in mind in what follows that I'm talking about this as fiction, relative to the film's world) is a very complex one that necessitates explaining and then tying together a wide variety of historical and other "academic" material. The main character, Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks), has to solve something of a puzzle, and another character, Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou) accompanies him. At one point they're assisted by yet another character, Sir Leigh Teabing (Ian McKellen). They each know things that the others need to know in order for the puzzle to be solved, and the entire film involves them explaining and to some extent figuring out these things as they go along--which functions to also explain the "thesis" to the audience. Of course this requires a lot of dialogue, and because of the subject matter, it tends to involve "telling" rather than "showing".

Now, the kind of film explained above isn't inherently problematic. It can be done with finesse in a very exciting way--a prime example is National Treasure (2004). Director Jon Turtletaub made that film work as a suspenseful action-adventure flick as well as any James Bond or Mission: Impossible film, while still retaining an intriguingly complex mythology along with the intellectual pleasures of puzzle solving. For The Da Vinci Code, helmer Ron Howard doesn't completely abandon action and adventure, but he too often forgets about it, and it's rare that it becomes very suspenseful. It's a shame, because when Howard remembers to keep those elements present, The Da Vinci Code shows how great it could have been. At a couple points, Howard takes another angle--making the film play like more of a fictional documentary. That approach worked, too, but it's also left by the wayside much of the time, and the end result is inconsistent. There are too many stretches where it's just Langdon or Neveu or Teabing explaining and helping each other figure out the story, and everything else--all of the mise en scène--functions just as decoration.

There are other aspects of the film hurt by this approach, especially characterization. For example, there are villains in this story, and the villains seem to be involved in complex (somewhat) conspiratorial relationships with one another. But only one villain is developed as a character, with a few others functioning more like movable props. And those others are meant to be the primary source of suspense. We just don't know them well enough--what they're capable of and why they're doing what they are--for the suspense scenes to work; they're more faceless than suspenseful.

Another problem is that the storytelling mechanics are too transparent. I'm usually awful at guessing plot twists. Here, I guessed them all almost immediately (without reading the book first, although I knew the gist of the "thesis", as probably everyone at this point does). At the same time, too much is left a bit vague--again especially when it comes to the villains. For example, I never did quite understand what Captain Bezu Fache's (Jean Reno) position and role in the events was, especially with respect to his relationship with Bishop Manuel Aringarosa (Alfred Molina). I suspect that was better explained in the book, but films shouldn't have prerequisites.

(And another problem suggesting that maybe prerequisites were suggested was given in the DVD extras--there are references to the "thesis" worked into the film symbolically--for example, references to supposed members of the Priory of Sion. The only way to catch the significance is to be versed in the mythology already. While some references for "insiders" can be fun, how much more interesting would it have been for the film as an artwork to create more robust internal, self-contained puzzles and references on this level instead? There is a bit of that--for example, the "forest for the trees" reconceptualization theme, and that's one of the film's highlights, but most of the subtextual puzzle-like references are to outside information from the relevant mythology.)

So that's focusing on the problems. But The Da Vinci Code isn't exactly a horrible film. I enjoyed watching it enough to watch it again in the future. Although the tone of the film is a bit inconsistent, most other aspects of Howard's direction are good, the performances are fine, and the technical aspects are very good. It's definitely worth a watch if you're interested in the relevant genres, and if you're intrigued by the relation of the "thesis" to the actual world--as many folks are, both pro and con--then you just may love it . . . or love to hate it.

title: nice movie
review: I had read the book long before I saw the movie. Usually what happens with me is that I don't like the movies if I have read the book before. I expected to be this way with this movie too. I was even hesitant to see the movie, as I had read many not so good reviews. But when I saw it I liked it. The actors are great. the interpretation is superb and the director has done a very good job. Congratulation to the all the members of the staff. But when it comes to suggesting to others to see the movie or the to read the book, I am always rooting for the book. I would suggest to buy the book, to read it, to read the reviews and to really understand the point of the whole story. I once heard Dan Brown say that he was worried that people liked the book not because of the good writing but because of what it writes about. I am sorry I cannot rephrase exactly what he said, but it was something like this. And I think the reviews about the movie are generated mostly for the same reason. I cannot see it anymore, but in the beginning I was also worried about the content. Now I get it. The more I read the book the more I get what Dan wants me to see. But not everybody likes the books, or even is able to fit the time to read this book into their schedules. If this is your case, then I would recommend you go and see the movie. All the actors are at their best. I am sorry that because of what it tries to tell about, it wont receive the real appreciation for the art work, but what can I say. At the end, it is a good spent time that will raise questions for you, and, why not, even make you start your own little internet quest.

title: Truly a fabulous story, book, and movie!
review: It was simply the most interesting book I have ever read. Since then, I have read at least ten more related books (to better understand the history of Christianity, religion, and where the bible actually came from). The issue of whether Jesus was actually married or not is not the biggest revelation to me. I am more interested in the role of Constantine and how they decided on the 27 books of the new testament. The fact that other gospels do exist and reveal that there was a diversity of thought in early Christianity is interesting and worthy of research. Hopefully, there will be a sequel and significance of the finds at Nag Hammadi will be addressed. Even still, the movie was an almost perfect translation to the big screen. The cast was excellent and they played their roles perfectly. The only changes I might have made would be to use Harrison Ford as Langdon and not showing the face of the hooded monk at the beginning. Overall, it was truly an excellent movie!

title: I loved the book, but I was disappointed by the movie ...
review:
I think the movie was too long - the material could have been contained in a picture with length of under two hours in my opinion. The movie was following the book too closely, which didn't work out very well. The retrospective sequences were short and fast and didn't create the effect they created in the book. Also, the scenes were mostly not well lit, which exhausted the viewers.

I would have expected more action sequences - at least that was the feeling the book left me with. The time-span of the story is very short yet the movie was as long as movies, that cover lifetimes.

Another disappointment for me were the changes in pace between the three story levels in the movie. The three levels were the current events, the retrospective material, and the historical explanations in the form of dry conversations. Those were irregularly dispersed throughout the film and introduced drastic changes in pace.

I liked the fact that the French characters spoke in French. I thought Hanks was a perfect cast for the part and I was most impressed by Paul Bettany.

title: Very good adaptation of the book
review:
After all the criticism this movie received in the press I was pleasantly surprised with the effort. The casting, cinematography, locations, editing, music and acting were all very strong. If anything could be considered less than excellent perhaps it was the screenplay. The story's complex plot and controversial nature didn't easily lend itself to adaptation for the silver screen. There were times I found myself thinking that if a viewer hadn't read the book they might get lost in the movies plot. However, other times I found the movie exceeded the book in representing the story through the use of its excellent visuals.

The lukewarm response to the movie was predictable I suppose. The public simply expected too much after the books stupendous success. I also wonder if there wasn't a bit of snobbishness directed at Ron Howard by some film critics who refuse to see him as a top notch talent, undeserving of such an enviable opportunity.

I found the movie totally enjoyable and very accurate to the book.

title: Poor treatment of a potentially fascinating subject
review:
I'm writing this without having read any other comment, just after finally watching the movie, which I had excitedly anticipated.

I found it to be just a regular thriller, and not a very good one at that.

The script, in my opinion, was the main reason the movie was so "busy", with so many unconvincing events happening.

The photography and shots were pretty great, but that is just about it.

The albino 'killer-angel" was played way over the top. Tom Hanks remained an unknown throughout the film, with the same expression on his face for the whole duration. Audrey Tautou and Tm hanks had zero connection, and zedro chemistry, which seemed absurd, given what they went through and why. that alone trivialized the whole film.

There was time allocated for secondary scenes in the movie, disproportionately to their importance-ex. the self-flagellation of the albino monk.

The concept of "Deus ex machina" is way over-used, and the whole thing gave me the impression that it was a summary of a very long book, not knowing what to keep and what to abandon in the script.

It was a conseptually mediocre movie,which disappointed me, to say the least.

title: Good story....bad art work
review:
The story line was good. But the "arty" type of filming...the darkness, the almost sepia color....ruined it for me. I have 25 year old tapes of movies that look better that this film.I don't know why it was necessary to use cheap "art movie" tricks to enhance the film. It was very distracting. And difficult to watch. The thought running through my mind was I could have got all the story from a radio version for all the good the film did. Sometimes dark to the point of "dead air".

I thought Hank was good. He played the role just as I imagined the character was in the book. He was good! I thought Audrey Tautou's character was rather wooden...but again maybe the darkness hid her work. Even Jean Reno wasn't his usual good self. He seemed unsure of his role.

I hated all the tricks...the blurry scenes...Why, Why did he do it. Ron it could have been a great movie. I would have liked to see Mel Gibson do this one.

All in all, I would expect this film to do lots of time on Sundance channel. And get passed over by a lot of viewers in the years to come. Too bad...Tom Hanks did a good job.

title: A lukewarm visual rendition of a gripping book
review:
For me, having read the book recently was a big spoiler. All I could do is yawn through all the predictable twists of the movie. The only parts that kept me somewhat interested were in fact the parts where the story didn't exactly follow the book.

But then I realized that I had seen before movies based on books that I have read, and that doesn't necessarily steal the charm of a movie, however faithful to the storyline in the book. This particular movie, though, had nothing extra to offer apart from what is already in the the book: no great acting, no chemistry between the main characters, no stunning action or settings, no moving visuals, gripping pace or wise lines. Nothing, zero. Moreover, I felt that half the magic of the book was gone, with all the detailed explanations and historical curiosities left out. The movie is barely a skeleton of a gripping and rich book.

On the other hand, having read all the reviews beforehand, I felt that the movie wasn't that bad as it was portrayed, after all. It was just lukewarm, that's all. Certainly, a movie which should have been directed differently.

title: "True to the book"
review:
I'm giving this film 5/10... not because it is a terrible film; it is actually quite a good film, but it doesn't not stay "true to the book". The ending is altered and crucial scenes have been missed out from the book. It is disappointing to have such a perfect novel twisted to what the producers feel is more interesting for the reader. If you haven't read the book then I'm sure you'll thourally enjoy this film, if you have read the book, I think you will leave feeling cheated of the true story line.

Tom Hanks plays an excellent role as Robert Langdon and the other actors are exceptional too, but to call it 'The Da Vinci Code', I would have expected them to at least stuck to the storyline...

title: Dull experience
review:
I read the book beforehand, and it's by no means a great book, but I think certain things work better for literature than they do on film, and this is one of those cases. Without spoiling anything the whole back storyline about the Knights and the Grail and the bloodline and whatever else is pretty absurd in both the book and film, but in the film the plot line in the present is greater exposed. For instance in the book the constant chase sequences were pretty exciting, but in the film it becomes more clear that the cat and mouse game lacks imagination and more or less is an elaborate version of peek-a-boo. And the changes they make in the movie version, while I understand some had to be done for time constraints, for the most part do not seem to help it, and only make it a lesser experience. One last thing about the movie book comparison: the weak character development in the book is also greater exposed in the movie. That last one is this movie's greatest failure.

Now judging the movie by itself it just comes off as dull: dull dialog, dull characters, and for the most part dull action sequences if one even wants to call them that. Tom Hank's performance as Dr. Robert Langdon, the main character of the story, is one of the most underwhelming and dry I've ever seen him do, and Audrey Tautou as Agent Sophie Neveu falls flat right from her weak introduction, with her motivations hardly ever being clear. What one is left with are some nice plot twists, and Ian McCellen's worthy performance of historian Leigh Teabling.

I have to admit stories like this just aren't my thing. I just don't get enticed by these silly treasure hunt stories, as would be clear from me disliking the movie National Treasure as well. But I think I like this movie even less because Nation Treasure knew it was being silly, while this film tries to take itself a little more seriously and the results are less entertaining. I can understand how one could come to saying this is a passable experience. However I would recommend this to no one. Like I said at the beginning of this review it works better as a book. As a film the story flaws are exposed more clearly, and it's unfortunate a great director like Ron Howard couldn't have done more with it.

title: What was the fuss all about??
review: I finally got to watch this movie last night on my TV, thanks to my local convenience store's offer of a free DVD rental. I was rather looking forward to finally savor this master-piece, as it was previously presented. Well, I must admit that we both were looking forward to the end of this overrated movie! I'm not saying that it was one of the worst flicks we had ever seen but it was certainly not what we expected. The never ending chase of our two heroes contained a fair share of poor and downright silly scenes! Are we glad we didn't spend a dime to watch it? It wasn't even suspenseful! That guy Silas who looked and acted like a chap who should have been locked up for his own safety was beginning to get on my nerves after the first drops of blood. '' Monsieur is just a truck-driver yet wears an expensive Swiss watch? '' And our heroine backing up at full speed through the busy Paris traffic?? Mon Dieu, those movie producers take us for imbeciles? I have learned to read between the lines of the movie critics' eulogies!

title: What a disappointment
review: I read the book and couldn't put it down. Then I heard the movie was coming out, so I read the book again. I was utterly let down. Anyone who read the book probably agrees at how boring the movie was. What should have been a great thrill ride on the screen almost put me to sleep. The screenplay was ridiculous at how far from the book's dialog it drifted. The music was boring background noise that did nothing for the mood of the film. Tom Hanks was all wrong and I don't think he read the book. The monk was reasonably creepy but I think they missed who he was as character by a long shot - albino's usually have pink eyes and I thought Silas did in the book (I may be wrong here). The opening scene sucked and it goes down hill from there. I could go on and on about how awful it was, but I suppose if you've never read the book it might be an alright movie. I just hope somebody else directs Angels and Demons because that was a great book also. I'm just relieved that I didn't pay to see this movie or the DVD. What a waste of one of the best stories of all time.

title: An intriguing adventure filled with secrets, mysteries and murder
review:
I picked up the book by Dan Brown about 2 months before the film came out and entered into the world of secrets, mysteries and murder. I thoroughly enjoyed the book and was rather worried about how it would translate to screen. But it was done rather well.

Plot: Robert Langdon a Harvard professor of iconography and religious art is called in when a famous curator, Jacques is found dead in a historical museum. Jacques left behind a series of codes and clues for Langdon and his granddaughter Sophie Neveu, a French cryptologist, to unravel and discover the truth about many things to do with the past and the present. As Robert and Sophie begin breaking the codes, many secrets are revealed that delve into the works of Leonardo da Vinci and the clues that he might have left behind in his paintings. They go on an adventure to discover the true meanings behind the famous works of Leonardo da Vinci. The film reveals a lot about historical times and the Holy Grail. Many twists result.

What's right with it? The cast is great, although Tom Hanks didn't do such a great job at playing Robert Langdon. The story is clever and imaginative and the sets and scenery add to the film's fine details. Most things in the book were included in the film but plenty was shortened. All in all the film is quite entertaining and it makes you wonder.

What's Wrong With It? The film does start off quite slow in the first 10 minutes or so and you may find that you are bored but don't fret, the film quickly picks up pace later on. I was upset by one particular thing that was left out at the end of the film. It would've only taken the filmmakers less than a minute to include it in the movie but unfortunately it disappeared completely. If you are clever, though, you may figure it out for yourself.

Verdict The Da Vinci Code won't please all, especially religious Christians but it was well done and deserves credit. But all in all, the story is better in the form of a book than in the form of a film.

title: Hanks miscast in drawn out mystery
review:
Having never read the book, I cannot comment one way or the other on whether or not "The Da Vinci Code" is a faithful adaptation of Dan Browne's tremendously successful story. So I am left to comment on the story as film screenplay. Well, it must have been one hell of a good book, but it is a mess of a movie.

The central theme is very interesting. Was Jesus Christ the son of God, or an ordinary man who did many good deeds, who married Mary Magdalene, and produced heirs? As a theory or history lesson, this is really quite remarkable to contemplate. As a film however, it leaves way too much of the story being told to us, and not enough of it unfolds for us to discover. This is a dreadful mistake to make in a murder mystery. As such, I kept hearing interesting theories, but I did not see anything take place on the screen.

And that includes the acting. With the wonderful cast that appears, you would think that there would be several good performances. But that is not the case. In my opinion, Tom Hanks is badly miscast here. I felt that he was a little too old for the part. He was not the least bit interesting to watch, often appeared wooden, and trying not to "act". The always reliable Jean Reno was for the most part wasted.

In the end, this was a story that probably should not have been adapted to the movies. Perhaps it could not be adapted successfully. Too much background detail, and too confusing to keep track of who were the good guys and who were the bad guys. Don't waste your money on this one.

4 out of 10

title: Entertainment at all costs...
review:
Should I say it or not? Well, I will: "The Da Vinci Code" is a film made for two kinds of people; the ones who have read the book and the ones who haven't. Being a part of the first group, I could be a little subjective, but I'll do my best and just review the movie as what it is: non- stop quality entertainment (I think I said that about "House of Wax", without the quality part).

Why do I say this? Because as a reader of the book, I find myself in a position many may have encounteredThe movie and the book are not the same thing: the book is an entertainment literature piece, with very accurate descriptions of important places of the world and a not very complex vocabulary or technique, but a very detailed view of the facts; the picture is a gift to the interested viewer and a clearly modified version of Dan Brown's novel, however done with the eye for entertainment, which becomes the only thing in common between both elements.

You see, Ron Howard is a truly gifted director and Akiva Goldsman is a truly gifted writer, but "Da Vinci" as a film was, above all things, a marketing project to them, and to Dreamworks of course. If Dan Brown had adapted the screenplay it would have probably been the longest this year; he couldn't have taken anything of, so that's what Goldsman did.

And that's also why the movie moves so fast. The viewer senses this too, but he doesn't mind because, just like in the novel, when "The Da Vinci Code" begins, you can't stop until you get to the end of it. This said, Howard is also very loyal to the viewer, giving him what he wants to get; showing him what he wants to see, the way he wants to see it. So basically, if the spectator hasn't read the book, he'll be amazed; with the accomplished frames and shots of places from all around Europe, as the book exposes.

Because of the same reasons I've been explaining, the cast is not given a chance to shine And it is an all-star cast! Tom Hanks in the main role of Robert Langdon is extremely measured and calm, but you can see clearly that it is not his fault and that he enjoyed playing the part. Audrey Tatou portrays a calm character in some way, so her performance just fits.

Jean Reno is also inside the ride, speaking his very best French and stealing every scene he is in. Alfred Molina participates a little bit as the Spanish Opus Dei member Manuel Aringarosa, who built his first church with the albino Silas, played fearlessly by the unique Paul Bettany. And do I have to mention Sir Ian McKellen's gracious presence as 'Sir' Leigh Teabing? Yes, a Sir playing a 'Sir', having a lot of fun.

That's what everybody had in "The Da Vinci Code's" set: fun. That's what the movie is and that's the feeling you get when looking at the audience trying to find out if they're buying the story or not; specially if you've read the novel. By the way, Hans Zimmer 's score is remarkable, perfect: the man is a genius.

title: The Da Vinci Code...uncertainties or certainties!!!
review:
The Da Vinci Code:

The Da Vinci Code is a mystery/detective novel by American author Dan Brown, published in 2003 by Doubleday.

Movie is based on the Novel.

The novel is based on the controversial premise that there is a conspiracy within the Roman Catholic Church to cover up the true story of Jesus. The novel has helped generate popular interest in speculation concerning the Holy Grail legend and the role of Mary Magdalene in the history of Christianity. According to this premise, the Vatican knows it is living a lie, but continues to do so to keep itself in power.

Acting by Cast of roles have done amazing job. Tom Hanks as Professor Robert Langdon Audrey Tautou as Sophie Neveu Ian McKellen as Sir Leigh Teabing Paul Bettany as Silas

Gist of the movie...is all about... Seek The Truth. Seek the codes. Can you crack the code?

Most fascinating is the actual locations and the animations, which is awesome.

End of the movie still leads many Questions unanswered and mysterious!!

Watch it!!

title: Christian churches and Western Judao-Christian Media rally against Da Vinci Code Movie
review:
Hard to believe? If you review the media's writings regarding Da Vinci Code - we see that community church leaders were saying, "this movie is terrible and not worth watching". In fact, the Scotish Christian council leader said, "I'm not even going to watch it because it is so terrible." So terrible? It stars the most famous actor in Hollywood - Hanks. Do you think Hanks would lend himself to a piece of crap??? Think again.

In short, media ran many similar articles which rang the same "don't see" message - a sad attempt to convince "the flock" not to bother seeing a very controversial think-piece (Da Vinci Code) which sprang from the most popular book in a very long time.

Simply, the media is guilty - as always - for not offering a counter view to the "don't see" opinion of church leaders. It's their job to present a scholar (or equiv) to suggest why we should see it.

unbiased is best

title: Da Vinci's worst paint
review:
It is a really bad bad movie. The only thinkable reason for making this movie is that the producers know all the money they can inherit with this trash. I've already read the book, it is awful just like the movie, I don't know why so much angry of the church about this movie.

It is boring from the beginning to the end, Tom Hanks worst than ever ( yes, even more than "my red shoe), mi beloved "Amelie" beautiful but wasting all her talent just for a fat check. Don't waste your time watching this "suppose to be" movie, if you want to see a film that really question the catholic church, take time to watch martin scorcece's "The last temptation of the Christ".

title: Da Da Vinchy Code
review: Dan Brown faced many weeks in court for plagiarism over this book, and somehow escaped, although it seemed to me that Holy Blood, Holy Grail, written by two TV producers in the early 1980s, certainly WAS the story behind it. Brown dodged the suit by having added all the daft puzzles that punctuate the so-called action. I visited a village on the Camargue coast called Les Trois Saintes Maries, where the tradition goes that the three Marys of the Holy Story landed and lived on, thus many people in the South of France would find nothing surprising about the basic proposal behind the balderdash that Brown trowels on top of it, replete with cod-codes in doggerel English verse --- a language that started to be used some thirteen hundred years after the Holy Story was invented. But it's fair enough that Brown published this rubbish: it's the millions of readers who lapped it up who need their heads read. They poured in to this movie in their millions, too, and the participants must be laughing all the way to the bank. The whole thing is preposterous, never believable for more than one minute, lousily written, appallingly acted and utterly gauche from start to finish. The mad monk, Silas, belongs in a horror film, his Opus Dei mentor in a farce, and the English Milord in a mental hospital. Even the requisite romance between the leading lady and the protagonist never occurs. When Hanks pulls it all out and announces: "You are the closest living descendant of Jesus Christ" our house rocked with wild laughter --- so thanks for that, at least, Mr Hanks.

title: Moderately interesting work of fiction regarding religious beliefs.
review:
This movie received lots of 'hype' before its introduction, and that often signals 'mediocre.' Although it has an all-star cast and a competent director, the controversy surrounding it turns out to be more interesting than the movie itself.

Tom Hanks is Dr. Robert Langdon, a Harvard professor specializing in symbols. In Paris a murder is committed in the Louvre, and his name is scribbled in blood by the victim. So that puts him directly on the suspect list, even though we know someone else is responsible.

Audrey Tautou (of Amelie) shows up quickly as Agent Sophie Neveu. Their chief pursuer is Frenchman Jean Reno as Captain Bezu Fache. The trouble is many of these characters belong to a fictitious secret society to protect the faith. At issue is whether an old code left by da Vinci leads to the location of the Holy Grail. The movie is done in a style where the protagonists are being chased by the cops and each time they barely escape via a ruse right before getting caught. Plus, there are many slow-moving parts where characters talk and explain what is going on. Often it reminded me of 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' in the way arcane clues are pieced together to lead them to the next set of clues in a different city or country.

Other key characters are Paul Bettany as the ghostly Silas and Alfred Molina as Bishop Manuel Aringarosa. My wife and I watched it on DVD, free from the library. She had read the book and said it was a faithful adaptation. Both of us thought it interesting, neither of us thought it was a particularly good thriller.

SPOILERS. Although the ending leaves everything open, as to what is real, it hints that the 'grail' is really a female descendant of Jesus who married Mary Magdalene, and further that Agent Sophie Neveu is the last living descendant.

title: Enjoyable, yet silly, the Da Vinci Code is another great film of 2006!
review: The Da Vinci Code may have received far less than full universal acclaim, but it certainly didn't bomb at the box office (with overall takings of over $700 million worldwide) and was the financial success that all the producers were hoping for. It was a better book-to-film adaptation than Stormbreaker (and certainly a more profitable one), but it is easy to see why it flopped critically - some parts were really silly, and parts in which you were meant to gasp with shock, you burst out laughing. But while there's no denying it's just silly, it is also quite gripping in parts - the constant darkness in the Louvre and the blood all over the professor's body keep an appropriately haunting atmosphere throughout the start. And it stays true to its Christian roots, and doesn't leave out anything vital in the story. It would be better to read the book before watching the film to get a better understanding of what exactly is happening, but you can still vaguely keep along with the plot as it continues and there is a clear beginning, middle and end. It won't have you on the edge of your seat, it won't have you gasping in shock, but it will entertain - and I think that is why it did so well. Some of the photography was neat, and though the budget wasn't exactly tiny, it didn't exactly show off with massive epic sets and kept a rather small-scale atmosphere, like it was in the book. The ending is satisfying, and at the end, you realise the film stayed loyal to the book all along, and it managed to show off that fact with neat photography and a rather epic feel. But one person saved this film from total disaster - Ian McKellen. He managed to keep the film enjoyable and ham it up to restore faith - especially in the scenes at his mansion in which he revealed to Robert Langdon and Sophie Neveu the truth about the "Da Vinci Code". There is only one bit in this film that will make you jump out of your seat (let's just say, it is a flashback (and it may not even frighten you)), and there isn't any high-octane action or explosions, but this is meant to be something that challenges the roots of Christian history. Though the film doesn't exactly do that, it does engage in the aspect of being a thriller and a big-budget book adaptation. Dan Brown can stay optimistic in the fact that his book has received a worthy adaptation and that both the book and the film have bought much more success than anybody could have anticipated. The Da Vinci Code is fun and quite fast-paced, but if you want something gripping and suspenseful, you'd be better off looking somewhere else. But then again, which kind of person doesn't enjoy a laugh? 9/10

title: Really Bad
review:
The DaVinci Code, the bestseller that sold as much as possible. This movie works...as a comedy. (Almost) everything is wrong on this, with the exception of Ian McKellen and some of the supporting cast. Come on, the book was a fun, exciting, light read, with a good sense of pace and a lot of interesting puzzles to solve. Not perfection or anything, but nice.
