This movie will be hard going for anyone unfamiliar with the book and will probably incense those who are familiar with it. If you do feel a burning need to see this, then rent (preferably borrow) the DVD - at least you'll have the comfort of falling asleep in your own home.

title: An expected disappointment
review:
A few weeks before seeing the film I started reading the book. I had read about one third of it when I misplaced it between hotels but had no urge to replace it. The movie gave me the same feeling. I had no problem sitting through it (although it was rather long), but had some emergency forced me to leave it would not have bothered me. The plotting seemed mechanical, as if a computer told the screenwriter to "insert a plot element here, insert a plot element there," etc.

I felt that Tom Hanks was miscast in the lead role. The audience would have been better served if Langdon had been portrayed by an actor who can drive events, rather than be driven by them. And Audrey Tautou was the wrong actress to play Sophie. There was no chemistry between her and Hanks, and it would have been a better movie had the chemistry been there. Hanks is 20 years older than Tautou, but that happens all the time in movies. I think Tautou's problem is that she has had very little experience in English-language films.

Two supporting actors stand out. Sir Ian McKellen's scenery chewing was entertaining, but it could have been used in any movie, or as a one-man stage performance. The only actor who might be considered for an Academy Award nomination is Paul Bettany for his sympathetic portrayal of a deranged killer.

Overall, the film left little impression on me. As I left the theater I felt that I should check the box stating that I had seen the movie, and then file and forget.

title: Da Vinci Code is grand
review: When reading the book, I thought that if this were to be made into a feature film it would either be one of the greats or a monumental flop. When I first saw Da Vinci after hearing all the panning from the critics I was hopeful it would be good. But with major differences from the book it seemed to me that it was quite ordinary. But then after seeing it again it seems that the movie is very good and not a boring, melodramatic movie. With wonderful performances from Ian McKellen and Paul Bettany (in what should be award-winning roles) and a good performance from Hanks the movie is a great adaptation of the book. Over two months it's made a staggering 730 million dollars and doesn't look like stopping. With a great production from Ron Howard and Brian Grazer let's hope Angels and Demons will be just as good.

title: different from the book
review: I would have to agree with Marta-63. I guess that I had high expectations because when I found out that they would turn the fabulous book in a movie, I really thought it would depict what I had imagined. There's no need to praise the actors because they were all sublime and thats 10/10 but the storyline and the screenplay was not the same. If you did not read the book, you would have a different interpretation on the movie and some of the scenes were not given emphasis on. One example I was expecting that on the last scene as well that Audrey would find out that the people in the church were his family but I don't think that it was shown on the level that I thought it would be. I don't know if its the direction but I just felt that it was a "commercial" movie and it was not an "art" like the painting included in the film.

title: Boy, am I glad I didn't read the book before I saw the movie
review:
I must say that I enjoyed the movie. Templar and grail lore has always fascinated me, but the popularity and genre of the book had become an obstacle to my reading tastes. I had no preconceived notions or expectations. I was not disappointed. Most of the people that have both seen the movie and read the book are somewhat disappointed, siting that shorter scenes in the book were lengthened and other scenes were slightly altered for dramatic, visual effect.

The performances in the movie were excellent. I always love Audrey Tatou. Paul Bettany as Silas, the murderous, albino monk (how many times will I get to use that phrase in live?) was the stand out character. Every time he appeared on screen, I felt pity for him as a man believing passionately in a work that will end in despair. And Ian McKellen, what more can I say? His portrayal of Leigh left me loving and loathing him all at once.

The only problem I had with the film was in the choice of Tom Hanks as Langdon. Although he does a fine job, I couldn't help but feel that anyone could have played this role. It wasn't that his performance was lack luster; after all, he is Tom Hanks. He was not the person that I left the theater thinking about, and I have not gushed about his character at all. An unknown could have played the part and done just as well.

Despite the controversy and lawsuits that have surrounded both book and movie, I could recommend that everyone see "The DaVinci Code" for the sheer joy of seeing a mesmerizing Paul Bettany and an extremely entertaining Ian McKellen.

title: Watchable
review:
I felt that the movie was watchable, but apart from the hype surrounding the film I could actually pick anything that made it stand out from other films.

I felt that the acting was solid, but nothing spectacular and the film provide some interesting miniature history lessons. I was impressed by how rigidly the film stuck to the book unlike some other films. It provides an interesting topic to discuss once you have seen it

If you were going in and not watching the film too seriously, it would probably be fine, but you may try to think too hard about it. I am pleased that I saw it, but probably wont be buying it when it is released on DVD

title: Loved the book, loved the film
review:
I was really impressed with the way the film had the same spirit that I so loved about the book. Even though, some bits of the film were slightly fabricated, it didn't affect my enjoyment. (Except for the part when Langdon and Neveu are on the bus, what was that all about?) I think Tom Hanks did a great job as Robert Langon, however I did think that Audrey Tatou seemed slightly uncomfortable in her role, and could have been more charismatic. Overall I think Paul Bettany did some of the best acting in the film, with his portrayal of the troubled albino monk, Silas.

I sat glued to the film all the way through and enjoyed every minute. However, those who haven't read the book may be slightly confused in some parts of the film which are not really self explanatory.

This film is really good, and shouldn't be missed by Dan Brown fans.

title: the Da vinci code
review: the Da vinci code by Dan brown was an interesting and fast paced book, but I'm afraid the movie does not live up to it.the movie is let down by consistent poor acting a lack of explaining that for viewers who haven't read the book will be confused by. Ron Howard has made two big mistake in making this film, he has rushed the last half hour of the film and giving it a pure American ending. these things let the movie down but it's a good story and worth a watch. i decided to read the book before i saw the movie and it definitely changed the way i saw the movie so it's probably better to have not read the book when watching the movie ' but if given the choice read the book and forget the movie . if you go to see it don't expect a masterpiece

title: Ho Hum!!
review:
While I have really enjoyed previous movies in which Tom Hanks starred or was featured, he was totally miscast in this movie. Having just recently read the book (I waited for the paperback edition) I was also somewhat disappointed at the screen adaptation.

Go buy the book and then read it. You'll get a lot more out the the pictures generated in your mind that from the movie. Both Sony and Howard should be paying residuals to the Catholic Church for the box office they generated with their bad mouthing. Maybe the Church should talk a page from the politicians campaign manual that says if you don't want your opponent to have visibility you don't run around talking about them.

title: so disappointing...
review:
With this film Ron Howard has achieved the impossible. He has taken the ultimate cinematic novel, a pulpy treasure hunt that ends every chapter on a cliffhanger; a book that with its shoddy writing and one-dimensional characters reads like a movie, exciting, fast-paced and gripping and turned it into one of the most boring films i have seen.

Its padded out with endless exposition but no development, fine actors like Hanks and Reno just stand around looking puzzled without giving us any insight into their characters. Silas, the best character in the film, is the most interesting character but he is pretty much sidelined throughout. Even Ian McKellan seems hammy as historian Leigh Teabing, less David Starkey and more Christopher Biggins.

Another problem is that while the book can bombard us with facts and make a relatively convincing conspiracy theory, on a widescreen coupled with dumbed down dialogue, the historical, theological and scientific fallacies in the argument become painfully apparent, and without this strong narrative link between actions and locations, the film feels episodic and repetitive.

It would probably be a better idea just to read the book, which is an exciting pulp fiction page turner, than watch this tedious nonsense which plays out as across between a coach tour of Europe and a KS3 history lesson. In the search for the holy grail, Indiana Jones is miles ahead.

2.5/5

title: A major stinker
review: I thought this was the most anti-climactic book and movie of all time. Down the path and over the hill to grandma's house for........more speculation and some big-time implausibility as to the isolation of Sophie from her family. What a rip! And what does it mean if Da Vinci painted a woman into the Last Supper? Nothing!! Was he there? I think not. So, so what? Maybe he did, and if so, how novel, but let's not confuse his fancy with history. Dan Brown spun a yarn, but that's all it is, and not a very good one at that in my estimate. Wish he could have shown a little more creativity for an exciting conclusion. Alas, he did not, and I thought the movie and book ended with a seriously dull thud. I mean, since you're clearly writing fiction, why not inject a really good whopper and give us our monies' worth?

title: Disappointing...
review: I never read the book, and after watching the film I don't want to. That isn't to say that the film is all bad, because it's not- there are some brilliant performances from Ian McKellen and Paul Bettany. Unfortunately the film is let down by the fact that Tom Hanks is unforgivably miscast (remember I haven't read the book) but it is clear that the role isn't right for him. Some of my friends have said that Sophie (Audrey Tatou) is nothing like she is portrayed in the book, but I think she played, what is essentially a very silly part, well. Hanks though is no Harrison Ford/Indiana Jones, whom I believe Robert Langdon to be based on and that combined with some dull direction makes the film suffer. On the plus side, every moment that Ian McKellen is on screen is a joy. Now to the religious aspect of the film. Why anybody got upset is a mystery to me. The final 'twist' in the film was obvious from the moment the film began and the whole 'Da Vinci Code' is ridiculous. This film wants to be 'Indiana Jones & the Last Crusade' but isn't. I have heard that 'Angels and Demons' (the superior predecessor to 'Da Vinci') is to be made. Let's just hope that Howard/Hanks do a better job with that film than they have done with this. 5/10.

title: the da vinci code
review:
i like the book very much, and i've seen the movie. A lot of cutting. It seems that many scenes are cut so that they won't raise controversial. Sometimes the translators do not translate some dialogues (in Indonesia language ). I think it is bozo the actors and the actress talk about the crucial thing that is on the contrary with church's belief. If people do not read the book first, they will be confused. One of my friends said that the book is more interesting and better than the movie.

i myself was quite satisfied bozo i didn't need to imagine how the shape of the cryptex was, etc.

title: One should have settled with reading the book
review:
Overall it is a pretty good picture, pretty good photo and acting and so on, but it really misses something.

Since finishing the book e few days before I saw the movie I thought it would be a great movie since the entire book is built up pretty much like a movie with it's plot, speed etc. But no..

Big parts of the plot depends on the code-breaking and the mind-puzzles around the brotherhood and DaVinci's artwork, but a lot of it is skipped in the movie -not seldom good for the viewer since the big picture is depending on the small, but smart, details.

Sure, you need to skip a great deal when you convert a book to a film, but here I feel that it goes to far. One needs to get to know the characters better in order to fully understand their roles and meaning, but you don't get any time for that.

And the ending doesn't by far get to you as in the book. Sorry, just a 4.

title: A Hollywood Exercise in Making Money.
review:
A Hollywood exercise in making money and nothing more. That's the first time I've ever come close to walking out of a cinema, and I've sat through some real bombers.

They spend a little money to make a film (well, a 'little' in Hollywood terms), and get it back with profit in the first two weeks of release.

This film did absolutely nothing for the book, except perhaps inspire people to read it again and feel the enjoyment they had when they first picked up a copy.

Talented actors in a mismatch of parts, poor dialogue, poor action, poor interpretation, poor everything.

The only redeemable feature was Ian McKellen who is magnetic (or Magneto, even!) in any role he plays, even if he wasn't quite right for Teabing.

If you loved the book, please just read it again and do not waste your time or money, or you'll regret it.

Fortunately I got free tickets, but I'll never get back the 2.5 hours I wasted.

title: DaVinci Code rates dry and boring in my book!
review:
Hey, I have no problems with the movie either. I wasn't one of those religious people that didn't want it to come out. In fact, i was interested in the movie, and it seemed good. I could not wait to see it. No, i was not expecting it to be a big suspense movie, but i was expecting something...and i didn't seem to find it!

The movie and its explaining of the DaVinci Code is the only interesting part, the rest is dry and boring. It dragged on for too long, and not just the movie in whole. Scenes took forever to complete, it seemed that even when you thought the movie was over, it just continued to drag on. It wasn't interesting, there wasn't any characters that you really could relate to and like that would get you hooked on the movie. Tom Hanks wasn't great. There were only a few Scary Parts. At some scenes the acting was actually bad!

I think if they tried to make it a normal good movie, and add some effects and suspense in, it would of been a favorite. However, they tried to make it this movie-of-the-time, 3 hour, big important movie and it just ended up being rubbish!

I give it a three, could of been better!

title: awful
review: i found that this film was terrible it dumbs down the book way too much, the plot has been changed and the script was atrocious. i was really disappointed. i was a big fan of the book and found that the film was too short to do it justice, it could have been easily another hour with extra time the plot wouldn't have to be cut quite as much.i found that this film was terrible it dumbs down the book way too much, the plot has been changed and the script was atrocious. i was really disappointed. i was a big fan of the book and found that the film was too short to do it justice, it could have been easily another hour with extra time the plot wouldn't have to be cut quite as much.i found that this film was terrible it dumbs down the book way too much, the plot has been changed and the script was atrocious. i was really disappointed. i was a big fan of the book and found that the film was too short to do it justice, it could have been easily another hour with extra time the plot wouldn't have to be cut quite as much.

title: A rather dull and lengthy adaptation
review: The film follows the plot of the novel if anything too closely, and in the process exposes the non-sequiturs and irrelevancies. As a film it has to tackle the problem of how to cover the lengthy explanations of the plot and fails the test. The characters are left to engage in wordy debates which is simply not cinematic. I found myself repeatedly looking at my watch and muttering 'get on with it, do!' Sir Ian McKellen gives good value, and is probably the main reason for sticking with it. The downside of that is that when he is not on screen the pace slackens considerably. About half an hour from the end I thought it had reached its climax and was reaching for my hat and heading for the exit when I realised with dismay it was lumbering off on another twist of the plot. Bonus points though for having the French characters speaking in French.

title: A Major Disappointment
review:
I finished reading the book, ran to my computer, looked up a movie time, and was in the theater 30 minutes after finishing the last page. That's how much I liked the book, and was sure the movie was going to be great, considering the amazing story and impressive cast the director had to work with. I was horribly disappointed, however, with both the acting and the script.

Despite the amazing cast, I found the characters weak. Langdon lacked the intensity, depth, and quirky-handsomeness (where were the tweed jacket and low professorial voice!?) that he had in the book, Sophie's role in discovering and decoding the clues was greatly diminished, and some of Sir Teabing's wittiest lines were removed or replaced. Also, although I love Jean Reno, I did not agree with his casting/performance of "The Bull" (Captain Bezu Fache)--I felt his physical appearance and demeanor were wrong for the part. The only great casting/acting job in the movie is Paul Bettany as Silas.

Additionally, the script veered from the book far more than it needed to, and left a very weak plot that lacked the intensity and cleverness of the book and its characters. The movie rushed through the clues (some of which were completely deleted from the movie) in the first part of the movie, causing the clues to seem all too easy to find and decipher, and then slowed drastically at the end, once all of the action was over. The movie also watered down the more controversial points of the book, which served as its backbone, such as the the histories of the sacred feminine, pagan sex rituals, and Sophie and her grandfather. Most disappointingly, the movie has a completely different ending, for no apparent reason.

I was so frustrated throughout the movie, that had I not been sitting in the far corner of a one-exit theater, I would have left way before it was over.

title: Interesting
review: First off, one must remember that this is FICTION, MADE-UP STUFF, NOT BASED IN FACT!!! Rant over. I think that the best way to describe this movie, and the book for that matter, is for the creation of a new category called SPECTION, short for Speculative Fiction. Hey, we already have Science Fiction, Historical Fiction, Romantic Fiction, etc, etc, etc, so why not SPECTION? I have read the book, and had my own ideas of what each character should be. The casting was almost perfect in every way, although I don't think that Tom Hanks would have been my first choice for the Robert Langdon role. What you take out of this movie has a lot to do with your personality going into it. Are you going to change your mind about Faith, The Church, or History because you saw this movie, I highly doubt it. The book, and this movie caused quite a stir amongst Catholic Church officials, and readers/moviegoers around the country and the world. I, for one, do not see what all the fuss is about. Could it be possible that Jesus Christ was a mortal man and not the Son of God? Sure it is. It is just as likely that He was the Son of God and is/was(?) immortal and all-powerful. No one can ever be sure. You have your beliefs, I have mine. It is impossible for me to understand your beliefs, you to understand mine. I will not attempt to change your beliefs, and I do not want you to try to change mine. Anyway,back to the movie. The sets were spectacular. I do not know if they were filmed at the Louvre, I think that they were, but I now feel like I have been there. The Paris scenes were some of the most breathtaking I have had the pleasure of seeing in a movie in quite some time. The movie was a well made adaptation of the book, true to form in almost every aspect. I highly recommend this movie, not because of the "controversial" content, but because it is an "intelligent" movie, a welcome change from the mindless "popcorn" fare that usually inhabits the theater at this time of year.

title: Great book, so-so movie
review:
I read the book some time ago and couldn't put it down. My son (who just turned 13) read it a month or so ago and felt the same way. The book has a lot of tension and suspense.

My family just got back from the movie. We were actually disappointed in it - it was a little slow. There was too much talking - which works very well in the book but not the movie. The other thing that was very disappointing was the amount of violence in the movie. Silas' discipline is covered well but subtly in the book. However, in the movie, there are graphic scenes of him with his cilice (sp?) and the whip as well. It is totally unnecessary and just makes the movie much more gory than it needs to be.

My recommendation is to skip the movie and read the book. There's a reason it's been on the bestseller list for years.

title: Riveting!
review: I found the movie fascinating and completely riveting from beginning until the end! Everyone was excellent in it! Bravo!!! Tom Hanks was a pleasure as always to watch...My friend said at the end of the movie: "I didn't get it..." so I explained the simple but moving premise of the movie to him. For as long as I can remember, I've always believed that Jesus was nothing more than an extraordinary human being--by no means immortal. We are all of God's children, and he created us men and women, so it's stands to reason that Jesus was being human too and could have had a sexual relationship with Mary Magdalen and produced children with her. I think that the Catholic Church has forgotten what the true meaning of being a Christian is and is purely money driven. And that's all I have to say about that! Go see the movie! You'll love it!!!

title: What The Gnostics Again?
review:
I think most viewers already know much of the unannounced theme behind the movie before they even go see it. Those who had a hand in making this movie no doubt had that in mind with how much money it would earn, simply by knowing many Christians are going to see it too, just to find out what ideas are portrayed in it without having to buy Dan Brown's book.

But the obvious bias it contains is not surprising to anyone who truly knows their religious history about the 2nd century Gnostics who believed Jesus Christ didn't really die on the cross, but that he was just a highly developed spiritual human being like Krishna, Buddah, etc. So the movie must be delegated as a mock false historical triad fiction, based on an equally fictional doctrine going back to 2nd century Gnosticism. Thus anyone taking ideas in this movie as serious factual events are probably living in a fictional fantasy land also.

title: what a thoroughly excellent movie
review:
I've only just been to see this because the book irritated me so I'd blacklisted it. But my son wanted to go, so off I went.

We were both gripped, I kept sneaking looks at my son (12) to see if he'd fallen asleep; there were plenty yawns (we went to a 8.10 showing) but he watched it all and enjoyed it. He especially liked the history bits when they were putting the pieces together. I was impressed.

I was very pleasantly surprised. The acting was great. It was lovely watching a movie where intelligent men are discussing women reverently. I remember reading about the bleak days of the witch-hunts when many women were slaughtered, and the world lost immeasurable knowledge because it was the witches (healers, users of herbs) who were killed and other wise, and therefore threatening women who were butchered. It felt affirming to have that noted.

The Robert Langdon character was very attractive; intelligent, self effacing, strong and gentle. A man who in a crisis says,"I need to get to a library". Excellent.

I enjoyed this enough to get it on DVD when it comes out. do go and see it.

title: Warrants watching twice, if you haven't read the book
review:
I haven't read the Da Vinci Code yet because I had heard that it was poorly written. But I was intrigued by the premise. I was glad that I finally got my butt into the movie theater this weekend to see this movie, because it was an intriguing, thought-provoking flick. (Interestingly, though this movie had been out for a month by the time I saw it, the theater sold out well before showtime, so I'm also glad that I got there early!) The sheer quantity of "information" (I know - historical purists will take issue with this term) presented in this movie, combined with a roller coaster of a plot, led me and my movie-going companion to agree that we'll have to see it again. It's a great date flick, because you'll have plenty to discuss afterward.

I have no idea why the reviews have been so poor; perhaps this is due to the influence of the religious right? Then you have the Dan Brown fans, who on the one hand insist that the movie isn't good because it's NOT true enough to the book, and on the other hand, some saying that it's not worth watching if you've already seen the book because there's nothing NEW in the movie. But if you have an open mind, you might be pleasantly surprised by this ambitious thriller.

title: WoW!
review: This movie has a great plot and story line to keep you guessing! It even tells the secrets throughout the movie and at the end EvErYtHiNg comes together!! Movies that end without "closure" just don't do it for me. I like movies that end when they end, but could still have potential for another. DaVinci Code isn't one of those movies that could have a sequel (i don't think so, anyway...) but it was pretty darn good. Like I said about another movie, I would definitely pay to see it again! This isn't one of those crazy, confusing stories that you have to be a brain surgeon to figure out, but if you pay attention you will get all of it and really enjoy this great movie! You will pretty much be shocked as it comes to a close!

title: Full of Sound and Fury
review:
While the cinematography is quite impressive and the acting of high caliber, the story itself is unremarkable. And in the end no matter how well a film is executed, it needs to resonate with the audience. Partly due to over hyping and partly due to an incoherent plot, the impact of the "The DaVinci Code" falls short. It's simply "National Treasure" on a international scale. Full of sound of fury, signifying nothing.

Perhaps it's inevitable when such a wildly popular novel is converted to celluloid. Popular dramatic novels, by their very nature of appealing to a broad-based audience, have operatic plots -- there are archetypal heroes and villains and a pretense of suspense with a nod to higher themes. The last aspect is the genesis of Dan Brown's appeal. The themes of religion, the origin of God, and the power of the Church are as enduring, universal and grandiose as one can imagine. Brown uses these unflinchingly to grab the Church by the neck with iconoclastic fervor and wring out every last drop of sacrilegious heresy. The absurdity of lines such as"you're the last living descendant of Jesus Christ" are mitigated only by the supposed importance of the statements.

As can be expected, the acting by world renowned cast is solid, albeit somewhat lacking in inspiration. Ian McKellan, Tom Hanks and Jean Reno are all at the top of their craft. And McKellan is one of the few actors who could pull off the convoluted role of Leigh Teabing without allowing it succumbing to farce. Audrey Tautou has solidified her reputation with mass audiences in her first mainstream film after a very promising debut in "Amelie". The scenes with her and Mckellen are the highlights of the film.

The film would have greatly benefited from a shortened run time, a tightened storyline, and the removal of several awkward lines ("Quick, I need to get to a library"). Of course in the end the movie's faults lie with Dan Brown -- and while his writing is imaginative and well researched, it lacks the literary style and character empathy of truly great writers. In the end "Sophie Neveu" and "Robert Langdon" are easily forgettable characters in a film that will be remembered more for the religious controversy than great story telling.

title: Good, but sloppy
review:
Let me say first of all that, having read Dan Brown's 'Angels and Demons' as well as 'The Da Vinci Code' - 'Code' is inferior child's play in comparison. Mystery, story, character development, intrigue, suspense, general strength of the writing - all at the superlative level in 'A&D.' That having been said, I enjoyed DVC the Book.

THAT having been said, I knew ahead of time that I would most likely be disappointed by the film. I had heard mostly negative things about it, and while I wondered how much of the negative press was simply bias of those nutty conservatives against a film that *gasp!* proposes an "unconventional" idea, I also had heard on more than one occasion that the film tears the book apart.

My opinion? Speaking in broad generalities, DVC the Film is a good movie. However, even disregarding the fact that the screenplay really does tear the book apart, the best word with which to describe this enterprise is "sloppy." The quick pace makes the whole affair feel dreadfully rushed; this is going to be a problem when one tries to cram a 500-some-page book into a film less than three hours in length. Still - rushed. And sloppy.

Tom Hanks, while a great actor, is NOT the right performer to portray Robert Langdon.

Paul Bettany, also a good actor, was an outright horrible choice for Silas.

Sir Ian McKellan... While reading DVC the Book, I noticed that even though Brown's description of Leigh Teabing did not even remotely resemble McKellan, the character's mannerisms, in my mind, instantly conjured an image of McKellan as Teabing. If the screenplay left the novel intact, McKellan would have been perfect. As it is, his performance is limited by the parameters of the role and the screenplay. A tragedy. Still, of all the performers involved, McKellan was the best casting choice, second to...

Jean Reno, as Bezu Fache - brilliant.

My only other major gripe - aside from various plot points in the book being altered, as I know is the unfortunate "norm" for Hollywood - is the way the final scene was executed, which was, like the rest of the film, sloppy.

COULD have been much more, IS a vaguely entertaining film.

If you have not read the book and want to see it, be my guest - but please read the book afterwards because this film does no justice to Brown's work or, more importantly, to the theories stated within.

If you have read the book - don't bother seeing it unless doing so involves (a) no exchange of money into the hands of a cashier, and (b) the concession that you have nothing better to do during the time that you would be watching this film.

Real rating: 6.5 / 10

title: Read the book first or you wont be able to follow the movie at all.
review:
I, as many others, read the book and loved it. Dan Browns story is brilliant, choking (in a good way) and also a bit funny.

Now for the movie...To me it was a huge disappointment and I left the theater 1h 40 min into the movie. I really tried to see the whole thing but I just could'nt spend a minute longer watching this junk. So what was so disappointing with the movie? Well first of all there is'nt a scene in the entire movie that is the same as it is in the book, not a single one! The cast is also very disappointing to me. Tom Hanks makes Prof. Langdon seem as interesting as watching a flower grow.

The only character who I'm happy with is Ian McKellens character, Teabing who he plays very well and captures his charm and wit from the book.

Another disappointing, and very very annoying thing is that the scenes are over very quickly and you miss out on the interesting "facts" about, well everything really. An example is when they're all on the plane and try to figure out what the password is to the kryptex, and it is written in a language they've never seen before...In the book you read several pages about it and how the try to figure it out. In the movie Prof. Langdon figures it out in 2 seconds! I mean come on Ron Howard have you even read the book!? Really irritating...It's not believable for a second.

Oh well they made a lot of money.

So I say read the book first because if i had'nt then I would'nt have understood a thing what was going on. Although if you already have then you will end up leaving the theater early like I did.

title: Thoroughly enjoyable, fast paced, witty, true to the book
review:
This is one of those few book-movies that does justice to the book its been based on. The plot follows the book faithfully, without giving undue emphasis on th minor details, but keeping the original book plot chaste, and keeping the plot fast paced.

The movie had its fair share of shockers (Silas pops out of no where, Truck crashes into the Neveus' car, which was done brilliantly) and almost lived up to the book's wit. The book plot was tweaked just a tiny bit to give the viewers a fast paced, action packed, intellectual thriller. But the fast pace may come at the expense of those who haven't read the book, who will find the plot difficult to understand, since it is so fast that it lacks organization to a certain extent. The acting was good too, with Hanks and Tautou filling in their roles pretty well. Although I feel that their faces and looks don't quite match up to those of Langdon and Neveu.

I felt that it was insensible to have a DCPJ inspector confront Langdon during a book signing in front of an audience. I was also disappointed that they did not show Sophie's brother (as her brother).

Overall: Great movie. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

title: Don't get me wrong! I liked the movie, but...
review:
Okay, here's my beef with the book: Dan Brown is not a sophisticated writer. He gives you everything and leaves no clues. Every chapter ends in a bad cliffhanger. He absolutely cannot write romance. But the story? Fantastic. It's a great work of fiction. The only thing wrong with it is the author (which might generally be considered bad, but trust me on this one).

Now, that being said, the movie is fairly good. The direction, the cinematography, the acting... even Tom Hanks pulled off Robert Langdon, which I really did not think he could do well. Paul Bettany was fantastic, as usual. His heartfelt portrayal of Silas made me learn to love the character despite everything, which Dan Brown did not do successfully in the novel. Jean Reno was great as Fache. Ian McKellan made me believe every word he said, even when I knew what was going to happen.

Ron Howard's direction was absolutely marvelous. Everything flowed beautifully. It's definitely worth a viewing just to see how gorgeous it is.

I have problems with the book, but why didn't I give the movie a 10-star rating? Well, you can't really do much with a badly-written novel, can you? Akiva Goldsman certainly couldn't -- the screenplay is awful. Don't go in expecting A Beautiful Mind or LA Confidential. Go in expecting to see exactly what you read: pretty and exciting, but written for the layman.

title: Da Vinci Code makes one think
review: I found the movie to be quite intriguing. I have read the book and thought it was fascinating, and the movie holds true to the book to an extent. The biggest feeling that I got from the movie was the wonder of it all; it makes me think about what might have been and what truly is. I do believe both the book and the movie should make people think about what "truths" have been told to us over the years, and not to take anything at face value. "Don't believe what you hear" would be a very good phrase. I think Dan Brown is a genius for coming up with such a thought-provoking book, and I want to thank Ron Howard and the others for having the guts to put it on the big screen. Kudos to the cast and crew. I would recommend this movie highly, at least for a rental if one is not a big movie theater goer.

title: Filled with disappointment
review:
I recently graduated from College with a BA in History and minors in French and Religion...Somehow I made it four years without actually finishing a book for an assignment and I rarely read for fun. When the movie came out my friends who read the book were so excited...but I couldn't see what all of the hype was about. So after graduation I decided to find out for myself, since the book seemed to be right up my ally, and I actually read it entirely in the course of a single day finding myself enthralled by its mystery, suspense and moderate accuracy for a piece of fiction....I absolutely love it, although not to the point of fanaticism...It brings up some good points, gets people thinking and talking, and although there are some historical errors that made me cringe it wasn't bad.

So naturally the next step was to see the film...and it left me filled with disappointment. I realize that there are many restrictions placed on films; time, money, sets, and the buildings and artwork found in the Da Vinci Code are not easily accessed. So I understand leaving out certain things like flashbacks, conversations and thoughts that are found in the book. However, what I cannot comprehend is why fundamental details of the book were changed for the movie.

To me the characters were underdeveloped, they made them look far less intelligent than they appeared in book, and yet they solved the clues so easily, also in the movie it seemed that Sophie resented code breaking where in the book it appeared to be her passion. The dynamic between characters felt unnatural and what was the need to not just leave out but blatantly change parts of the book for the movie.

Basically I don't like the principle of taking a recent best seller and changing fundamental details like the end,the middle, the beginning and the characters relationships. For me the imagery provided by the book, is so clear in my head that conflicting scenes of the movie made me angry and disappointed. To me the book was far more exciting and I don't even like to read!

title: Interesting, but very predictable
review:
I saw "The Da Vinci Code" last week and just want to say that some things totally blow my mind.

First of all, I'm a catholic... not nerdy one but raised in catholic family and spirit, so this movie revealed some things about Christian teaching or didn't...? So, this movie survived strong impact from Christian communities, but i don't see why? Nobody said in this movie that church is frod, just brought some things that may be true... and if the statements in movie are valid, somebody started with pranks a long time ago and made some false statements about Jesus and whole Christian teaching. I can understand if you are "nerdy" Christian you'll be offended with statements from this movie (famous one is: "Maria was Jesus wife, not mother").

OK, so second thing about movie is his enigmatic part. Like i said, a lot of things (false or true) were put in movie, and they just makes your mind jump between "yes, it makes sense" and "no freakin way". So, i'm not saying statements are true, but they can be, the thing is we'll never know...

And of course, third and last thing is my dissatisfaction with predictability. After 60 minutes, you'll know what will happen next, who will die, who is good guy and who's bad, and the things like that...

But, all in all, very interesting movie, and if you want to learn something more about this phenomenon i suggest reading a book and watching a documentary on this subject.

title: Better than the book in that the dreadful writing style isn't a factor
review: I read the book and thought that the central idea was very clever, but the writing left a whole lot to be desired. To put my reaction into context, I'm not Roman Catholic, or religious in any organized sense. I can see why some practicing Catholics might find this central idea offensive. Considering the movie solely as entertainment, I thought it was a pretty good, if slightly slow and ponderous entertainment. Tom Hanks is an actor I almost always admire; here he seemed to express his seriousness as a character and the gravity of the story by wearing a perpetual frown that wrinkled up his face. No, there's no chemistry between Hanks and the female lead--but under the circumstances, even a suggestion of libido might be inappropriate. Ian McKellan is his usual wonderful self and I didn't think anyone in the cast was less than competent. I figure those people who regard the suggestion that Christ was a man and subject to manly impulses ought to stay away and not expose themselves to this outrage. That's what happened in the case of Mel Gibson's "Passion" film: a lot of people simply avoided it lest their sensibilities be bruised. As for those organizations who have fulminated against the movie and urged that it be embargoed--they've almost certainly done the Box Office a huge favor. Although, what with all the ancillary Da Vinci stuff on the market (the Da Vinci Code DIET??? really!) the Box Office probably needed no outside stimulation. I'd save this one for a weekend when the pickings are otherwise pretty slim.

title: Accurately depicted theory, great story.
review: Accurately depicts one of many a theory in reference to the holy grail, or more specifically the treasures of the Knights of the Poor Temple, or Templars. Great acting, with an interesting learning curve. Also extremely humorous to watch it stir up a hive of bees within certain religious groups. Howard's filming technique is shown well throughout the film. Probably one of his better works. Great cast, convincing storyline and dangerous to the church, this movie provides differing emotional responses from different groups within society. Catholics will generally condemn the movie, perhaps even without seeing it, so don't not see it because one said not too. Ignorance is very powerful. DEFINITELY worth seeing, but do some research on the knights templar before seeing it and the knowledge will make the experience all the more worth while. 10.10.

title: exhilaratingly brainy thriller
review: Not since the advent of Harry Pother has an author so flagrantly delighted in leading readers on breathless chase . This masterpiece has so many twists and all satisfying ,most unexpected..let's just say that if this novel doesn't get your pulse racing you need to check your meds.. this is good fun .Umberto Eco on steroids....Ron Howard is no one short of brilliance in this from Dan Brown adapted novel.. he gave almost every single detail given and indicated by Dan Brown .. I got disappointed not to have been disappointed after the movie..i got tightly seated like doing 90 on the freeway ..it is a blockbuster perfection ..I never ever thought the movie adaptation would be as crucial as the book itself...Dan and Ron .. You guys cemented your unprecedented qualities deep enough.. people who want to find basic Hollywood movie styles and gotcha moments please avoid watching this splendid ..

title: THE DAVINCI CODE : Ron Howard's Numerous Mistakes Make For A Big Disappointment
review:
THE DAVINCI CODE

It took me a while to get out to the theaters to see this one because I wanted to be sure I'd finished reading the book first. From the very first previews for this film, I had faith it was going to be good. I'd yet to even read one page of the best-selling novel and yet Ron Howard's trailers had me enticed from day one. I was able to put aside my disappointment for Ron Howard's past film-work and believe he might have finally created a great film. And after reading the book, there was no doubt in my mind the source material was wonderful. Unfortunately, Ron Howard failed in all the same ways he has in the past... and his adaptation of THE DAVINCI CODE is one big, clunky disappointment.

Granted, to adapt a book with so many complications and so many different characters would have been a challenge for anyone... however, the results could have been much better. The film tells the story of Robert Langdon (played by a miscast Tom Hanks) and Sophie Neveu (played by a miscast Audrey Tatou) as they scramble to unearth the secret of the Holy Grail following the murder of Neveu's grandfather. In the moments before his death, Neveu's grandfather left numerous clues which would lead his granddaughter towards a family secret that would shock the world.

It's impossible to review THE DAVINCI CODE without comparing it to the superior book. Perhaps that's unfair, but if the book was such a daunting thing to be compared to... why did Howard stick so close to it? I felt throughout the entire film that Howard and the production team weren't quite sure what to do with the movie. Should they make a faithful adaptation even though it would be difficult, or should they re-arrange the story a bit to make it more cinematic...? It appears they never made a decision and just straddled that line throughout the entire development process.

Sadly, it appears things were off from the very start. Though Tom Hanks can usually handle any type of role, he is radically out of place in this film. He appears to be too old... and not so much in age, but in body. I never got the sense that finding the Holy Grail filled Langdon/Hanks with a wild curiosity and intense desire like it should have. Instead, Hanks just seemed to be going through the motions. And the same can be said for Tatou's performance as Sophie Neveu. Firstly, she is too young for the role. Secondly, Neveu needed to be the emotional centerpiece for the film when you consider how Howard chose to end things, and yet Tatou's performance didn't have a single extra layer to it. She seemed to be a beautiful shell of a Cryptologist who knows she must figure out the mystery... yet she appears to have no passionate need to know the truth. Without Langdon and Neveu's desperation, none of this mystery is exciting.

The other major casting mistake was Paul Bettany as Silas. While Silas does not necessarily need to look like a monstrosity, he definitely should not be attractive. Yet, nothing is done to downplay Bettany's natural good looks. Sure there are scratches all over his body and he's white as a sheet, but his body is sculpted beautifully and his face normal. And why may I ask did an Albino have blue eyes? All albinos have no pigmentation in their eyes leaving them a red-ish color... so why did Bettany keep blue eyes which only added to the physical attractiveness? Aside from the casting however, Howard's input does nothing to save the film. Instead, Ron Howard uses identical gimmicks as he has in the past (the code breaking in this film is stylized exactly the same as it was in A BEAUTIFUL MIND). In general the film just feels like its spread out too evenly without any significant dips or lulls in the action. In the book, the race between Langdon and the French Police seemed to be an ever shifting game of cat & mouse. In Dan Brown's novel, the police would get closer and closer only to fall back moments later... but in Howard's film, the police seem to be 10 minutes behind our heroes right up until the very end.

Finally, I don't think Ron Howard or Brian Grazer ever sat down at the very beginning of things and firmly decided exactly what perspective they were going to tell this story from. Is he simply telling the story of an interesting mystery? Is he offering an emotional tale of an abandoned child who yearns to know where they came from? Is he telling the story of man's obsession with knowing the truth? I think Howard tried to tell them all... and as a result he has an unfocused film on his hands.

It's hard to pin-point specific things that went wrong with the film... b/c in the end it isn't one specific element that ruined what could have been one of Cinema's most thrilling mysteries ever. It is the entire mixture. The casting is wrong, the direction poorly paced, the story too impersonal, and the mystery too unclear. While THE DAVINCI CODE has a few redeeming factors, such as Ian McKellen's engaging turn as Lee Teabing and some wonderful scenery, it is far too much of a disappointment when you consider the potential. In the end, although it's not the most boring 2 1/2 hours of my life by any means... I could never get past the fact that nothing in it is as good as it could have been. And when the most constant word in your head while watching a movie is "disappointment", then it's not a good sign.

... D ...

title: A solid Science Fiction film with over rated flaws
review:
There are so many knives out for this film. Lots will watch it for the controversy and then bag it for the same reason. This is not a bad film. The plot is significant and interesting. The action is lively. The only area where it falls down is in theology, but then only the marketers and Axe grinders of religion place any claims on this film for THAT.

If the claims of religious historicity were put aside, the leads would be viewed as being good for their roles. The girl is pretty and doesn't need to remove her clothes to prove it. The male lead doesn't use excessive profanity to show emotion. Already supporters of licentiousness have it in for the film on those counts ..

The bad guys are inhumanly weird, which reinforces core values.

The storyline is taken from the book, which I haven't read, but know in minute detail. I'm a committed Christian and am not troubled or enlightened by the story. I can see where history has been inflated and adjusted to suit the story .. and it works. This will disappoint atheists keen to find a new weapon, but it will also distract religious leaders keen to have a opinion on something modern.

I'm a big fan of Mr Howard. This isn't "The Paper" but it is a solid film if you allow yourself to see beyond the hype and suspend your disbelief ;)

title: A thriller with no real thrill
review:
Da Vinci Code:

Bad! From beginning to end this thriller lacked any real thrill. The characters are paper thin leading us to have no real emotional attachment to them, thus not really caring whether they prevail over their adversaries of the cloth or not. The film seems to rest all of its weight on the shoulders of controversy and conspiracy, but neither have the back for it. The theory was definitely intriguing, but not nearly plausible enough to make us believe it for the duration of the film. Certain character relationships weren't clearly defined, they seemed to defy the clutches of the clergy and the French police all too easily; and the self-mutilating, psychopathic, albino 'Angel of Death' wasn't really that scary at all. The ending presented a foreseeable anticlimax to which both actors played with a lack of enthusiasm that was apparent throughout.

Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks), a religious symbology expert, is suspected of the murder of a well know historian murdered in the Louvre. Langdon is innocent but is being set up to take the fall for the murder. A team from the French version of the FBI, led by hard core Captain Bezu Fache (Jean Reno), are sent to arrest him. But With the help of Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tattoo), who's the granddaughter of the Historian, they escape and set out to discover the true identity of her grandfather's murderer. Amidst the hail of bullets, car chases and double crossers, their investigation leads them into a mystery of a code encrypted by Da Vinci which reveals a Secret Society within Catholicism who have held a two thousand year old secret; that if discovered would bring the world's largest religion and all its followers to their knees. To piece together this intricate puzzle they travel throughout France, and with the help of Sir Leigh Teabing, they escape the French police and a Catholic assassin to flee to London where they not only discover the murderer of Sophie's Grandfather, they break the Da Vinci Code itself.

Overall, very disappointing. The only saving grace was Ian McKellen's portrayal of Sir Leigh Teabing, an ageing English cripple, obsessed with Da Vinci's supposed conspiracy and all of its secret societies and who drinks his earl grey with lemon; of course.

Best scene: When Sir Leigh Teabing passionately divulges his knowledge of Da Vinci's hidden code and the Secrete Society who have maintained its mystery.

title: Inconsistent, albeit good, adaptation
review:
After having read the novel twice, I had confidence that a film adaptation could be quite good - the book was suited for it. Unfortunately, this was not the case. The movie was good, yes, but not as fantastic as it could have been. In fact, I would go so far as to say the book was better than the movie - I simply found it more entertaining. Still, this movie is a (fairly) faithful adaptation of the novel, with a few changes that don't really affect the overall story or theme.

Of the changes, the ones I found the most noteworthy were the added character development of Langdon - falling down a well? really? - and the missing puzzle, and of course the end. The end was where the film really dropped the ball - it is far too long, and the revelation could have been done much smoother and more effective. The beginning also could have been compacted - the scenes in the Louvre should have been longer, but the other scenes (Aringarosa & Silas) could have been significantly trimmed. The pace was quite uneven at the start, the cutting back and forth between the separate stories was far too jarring. Even the scene in the bank felt rushed; I couldn't help but feel that these scenes could have been much better realized. The movie didn't really find its groove until they get to Teabing's, where it took off. The scene where they are revealing the true nature of the grail was the best scene of the book, and it's even better in the movie with the accompanying flashbacks and the arguments between Langdon and Teabing (which are not present in the book but are welcome here). After that, the pace really picks up and the movie flies by until the climax - which, unfortunately, is a good 30 minutes before the end of the movie. Talk about a premature ending. I felt the villain reveal was kind of botched, also - it wasn't nearly shocking enough. The scenes at Roslin are needed but were boring, until the final conversation between Langdon and Neveu, where their chemistry finally showed itself. And the final scene was superbly done - much more effective than the novel. A very uneven product results.

The performances were all over the place. Hanks seems to be phoning it in until the scene in Teabing's mansion, where he holds his own against McKellan. I still think he was miscast. Tatou didn't really impress me, she felt kinda flat at times. McKellan was the star of the show, I even felt his performance was Oscar-worthy. It's a mark of his incredible performance that the movie immediately picked up once he entered. Reno was terribly inconsistent - considering the character was written for him, I felt he could have done a much better job. Bettany is sufficiently creepy as Silas - the first scene of him chastising himself went on a bit long, though. And Molina is wasted - I think the entire subplot with him getting money from the Church could have been dropped altogether, actually. No one else makes a decent impression.

Technically, this film is, again, all over the place. The production design was fantastic, but the lighting was off sometimes, and I felt that some of the art & architecture could have been highlighted better. The cinematography was appropriately sweeping at times, and not even noticeable at others. Same with the music - I didn't even notice it until the incredible final scene. The only aspect at which the film really excelled was, surprisingly, the visual effects - the historical flashbacks were very well done, and the visual style they incorporated was very effective. Howard does a decent, if not noteworthy, job directing - pretty much like all his other works. All this makes for an uneven result.

So, overall, this film is probably best described as 'inconsistant'. Story, performances, pace, technicalities - all were all over the place. Considering the book flows very well, this is the fault of the filmmakers. Still, it's a good film, but not the great one I was expecting.

title: Was the hype worth it?
review:
I'm not going to argue that this was a bad movie, I gave it a seven so I definitely feel its a good worthwhile movie to watch... however, I expected more. When I left the theatre I felt let down. This movie was hyped up for I'm guessing a year before it's release, making it something moviegoers were was anxiously anticipating. There has been spin off movies that it has inspired, the list is endless of publicity that it has generated. I sat in the theatre and all I could think of was "wow I think I have seen this before..." anyone remember "National Treasure" with Nicholas Cage? Cage spent the whole movie chasing after a hidden treasure... Well this movie came across as the religious version of that movie. The actors I must say were amazing and the chemistry good among them and the script was well written.

If you liked "National Treasure" then you'll love this movie but don't expect the best movie of your life because that it is not. Indeed a good movie, but again don't believe the hype. Perhaps if I hadn't expected the movie of a lifetime it would have been much better...

title: people have called this movie boring i thought it was thrilling
review: I went to see it with my family and I thought it was smart,entertaining and an overall great film. the acting was really good and so was the directing. then I saw it again with my friends and I knew what was going to happen but I missed things the first time I watched it. I'm looking looking forward the DVD to see the behind the scenes. also the scenery was stunning. I've always wanted to go to Europe and this film makes me want to go even more. the museums were great. I don't know why people have gotten upset over this movie. I'm 15 and I understand a fictional story and that is what the DA vinci code is. it also does not say don't believe in this religion or anything of that sort.tom hanks did a great job.

title: Enjoyable, but not a patch on the book
review:
I had high hopes for this film after enjoying the book. If you have read the book, maybe it's not a good idea to see this movie as ultimately you will leave the cinema disappointed. It is however a well paced, well made movie with some very good points. You can't expect all the aspects of the book to be incorporated into a movie but I felt that the missing parts took away all the point to the story. Tom Hanks was brilliant as always but wasn't streached by the role. The chemistry between the two leads wasn't there at all.

I feel that had I not read the book first I may have enjoyed this film more but the missing aspect of the story, I felt, were the best bits of the book. Maybe this should have been a TV series so that all the aspects of the search could have been included.

It's probably going to be better when I watch it again. I have a feeling it will be one of those films that I will enjoy when it comes out on DVD.

title: Suspenseful and True to the novel
review: As was the case with anticipated films like the Harry Potter series, the books outweigh the film simply because the film makes too many cuts on the plot and character build up. The Da Vinci Code does not suffer from this shortfall, either in book form (which is beyond excellent in my opinion) or as a film, Ron Howard does a fantastic job of creating the right atmosphere that suits the suspenseful plot. To be fair, Dan Browns plot is complicated enough to prevent much cutting, and all for the health of the film too. I was rather expecting to be bored, condsidering I was very familiar with the twists in the plot, but was kept pleasantly rapt by the excellent directing and strength of acting. Tom Hanks is critised, and his performance is nothing on the marvellous Sir Ian McKellen, who steals the screen, but It certainly doesn't detract from the solidarity overall. I was most gratified to find that the final part to the film was in fact clearer than the ending to the novel, which I perceived as a trifle abrupt and ambiguous. Howard clearly had this in mind and does a good job directing it. It was nice to see that the legacy from fantastic book has been continued onto the big screen, I didn't think it a disappointment at all. Well worth viewing IMDBers, if you haven't already!

title: What a let down!
review:
There are those movies that far surpass the novel on which they are based. Think French Leutenant's woman or Bridges of Madison County! And, then there are those that let the viewer down badly. Da Vinci code is the latest to join the latter category. Captain Corelli's Mandolin is another memorable one of this variety. I remember looking forward to both these movies after thoroughly enjoying the books. What prose and imagery that the authors manage to conjure through words.

John Fowles'(author of the French Leutenant's woman) account of the process of initiating and going through the filming is also noteworthy. He makes it a point to articulate that once the director and script-writer has been selected, as per the desire of the author (with a massive wait for getting the chosen pair on board) the author decides to let go of the reins then on.

Or, is it the choice of the leading actors? Meryl Streep (in both movies) and Clint Eastwood in the latter made a significant impact. However, I found it difficult to visualize Tom Hanks or Nicholas Cage in the manner in and orientation in which they are portrayed in the original books.

Lastly, I enjoyed the illustrated version of the Da Vinci Code was far more than the movie. If you have not seen this edition do give the book a browse!

By the way, ever wondered what could have happened with a more cerebral ( as opposed to action) actor like Kevin Spacey (The Usual Suspects or LA Confidential) or Tim Robbins (Shawshank Redemption or Mystic River) in that role of Langdon in Da Vinci Code??

title: Howard VS Brown
review: For many this film has been long awaited, and sadly for many, a disappointing adaptation from Dan Browns novel. This has been the first novel that I have managed to read before being tempted too much by the gossip and triumph of cinema-goers and reviews. As we all know, the world we create in our minds is far superior to world created by someone else, and i believe there is a lack of realism and depth to both the lead roles of Robert Langdon and Sophie Neveu in comparison to the book, subsequently Sir Ian Mckellen and Paul Betteny certainly stole the lime light away from the central characters. What was significantly disappointing from the film was the lack continuity of time surrounding the lead roles. The book began with Langdon being woken from his hotel room in the middle of the night shortly after the discovery of Sauniere's death. This put the reader in a clear position of the situation of its characters, and how the events unfold during the long night to follow. Not only did Ron Howard choose an alternative introduction, in my mind he failed to portray the saga that each character had towards the search for the grail, again with the relationship and depth that the book did. However, it is common to say that the time allowed for the film was not sufficient to fully portray the books depth and structure. I would like to also point out that the alleged teamwork between Langdon and Neveu was also significantly diluted in the film, only allowing room for absurd calculations and almost scripted and formulaic findings. The connections they made towards finding certain answers such as the Zurich account number were consistently weakened as if Howard was pushed for time, in my eyes there are other weaknesses the film brought were Howard added personal 'amusing 'attributes to the dialogue, such as Neveu's reference to the blood line and attempt to walk on water, yet more importantly I found that Neveu's introduction to the reality of her family was far more disappointing than any other part of the film, shadowed with the members of the Priory of Sion, Howard should have taken the opportunity to realise the authenticity and realism behind Browns introduction of truth around Neveu's family tragedy and revealed it far less dramatic and ritualistic. Overall I found the film to represent and portray a fairly good thriller but once reading the book, there are finer qualities that Howard unfortunately failed to represent and yet as with any film everybody interprets differently.

title: A/B+ movie, A+ book
review: Very very very good movie, the beginning is a bit violent for those who have not read the book... but those who have know whats going on. With Ron Howard as the director I expected this movie to be great and stay true to the book and it did. I give it an A/B+ although the book is still better in my opinion. This movie is a tale that takes the audience through Europe on a quest to find the truth. A truth about a secret society that Sophie's (Audrey Tautou)grandfather Jacques Saunière (Jean-Pierre Marielle)belonged to. Sophie finds out things she never knew about her childhood and her family. To help Sophie decipher the clues her grandfather left her after his murder in the Louve, Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) takes Sophie on a whirlwind's of a trip. They work together as a team and finally piece together all the clues.

title: -cHeFz Scoop- " The Da Vinci Code"
review:
___ "The Da Vinci Code"____

St0ry: 6/10

AcTing: 5/10

W0rth Seeing: If There's nothing else showing

HiRe a bAby-sItTer: Na, bring the kids

Dan Browns novel in my opinion was 'awful' and he completely ripped it off another book written a few years previous, but enough on the book. With my opinion of the novel in mind, I wasn't expecting anything great when I went into see 'The Da Vinci Code' and my expectations were lived up to. title: Not all that great
review:
I have to say, I was pretty disappointed with the movie - after all the grand hype, it turned out to be pretty dull. I usually love Tom Hanks, but this time he might as well of not even showed up. His character was lifeless at best. Audry Tautou was also a bad choice of actress for this role. She certainly didn't capture the spirit of the character. It doesn't bode well when you have a film with the two main characters that are boring and devoid of chemistry.

The standouts are Ian McKellen who was great as always and Paul Bettany who was chilling as Silas.

As for the story - I saw the movie before I read the book and found the story to be quite interesting. After reading the book I will say that the movie faithfully follows, with a few exceptions, the book. As for it being fictional - no doubt as most of the references to Da Vinci's paintings, Templer history and the Priory of Sion was lacking in any reality. Interestingly, Dan Brown wants us to think that all the art and architecture was based on fact - this is quite laughable when he mistakenly (most certainly for effect) says the pyramid in front of the Louve has 666 panes of glass when in fact it has 673. I guess the real number just doesn't have that Hollywood appeal! All that aside, the movie had a lot of potential to be good. To bad some bad casting ruined that.

title: Not worth the fuss
review:
I have to admit not being a fan of the book. In fact, I hated it. It can't deny it was entertaining to read, and you could clearly recognize it was made to be a best seller for its fast-paced formula of mystery, action and vague eroticism, but the only I can give to Dan Brown is that he is a genius of publicity  not a good storyteller, not even a good writer. It looked like this guy had just typed symbology and DaVinci in Google and stuffed all the results in the novel. Yet however, it has its fans, and I respect their opinions, but don't ask me to like it. I don't.

The DaVinci Code is a bad book, and though I enjoyed the movie a little more, I can't call it good either. With bad yet commercial source material, my expectations were subzero, and I wasn't surprised or anything. It's simply the novel, with a few tweaks here and there (more on that later because it's one of the few things I loved). The start is okay: it builds up some tension and shows off how good Ron Howard can be as a filmmaker, with these brilliant, story-of-the-character-in-15-seconds style flashbacks, which I found an excellent technique to shove aside all the unnecessary melodrama and annoying angst which riddled the book. The problem, though: after some downright boring bits, you just find yourself wondering when will it recuperate. It doesn't.

This movie takes itself too seriously. It's in serious need of a little sense of humour about itself and so do the two main actors about their characters. But once again, the standard 'you can't make a good movie out of a pile of rubbish' applies; so much cliché, after all, will never possess or deserve a third dimension.

Hanks kept looking confused all the way through, although I can't blame him  it's how I've always imagined Robert Langdon anyway , and Tautou (no matter how much I'm biased in her favour) plays her typical curious, cool & cute, but her character sometimes is just there, with not much to do or say. I guess the novel gave her more protagonism, but can you really call that something good?

Fortunately, the secondary actors are a lot more entertaining to watch. As always, Ian McKellen is brilliant, taking delight in playing flamboyant and eccentric sir Leigh Teabing in a great opportunity to make the audience smile, steal every scene from the boring protagonists and give the plot an okay turn. Jean Reno is always himself, and although I swear I can hear the question of 'what am I doing in this movie', the role of Fache didn't belong to anyone else. Alfred Molina gives an oddly refreshing performance and plays perfectly with that sneaky poker smile, although I just so wish we got to see more of him; and Paul Bettany is without a doubt my favourite: for he's the only character to truly display passion, emotional charge. He makes Silas so expressive and tortured and adds in that soft, sweet, slimy, intentionally unfocused tone which is not based on anything, nor does he owe it to nobody - not even Dan Brown. It's all his.

The movie _did_ accomplish something the novel didn't, for the book was indecisive when it came to who exactly was to be blamed for all the mess. 'Cause you know, the evil character just thought they were saving the Church, and evil albino assassins army aside the Opus Dei is cool. The movie made its message a little less blurry - while for example, the character of Aringarosa did come across as more greedy, twisted and manipulative, the police chief was a member of Opus without being the EBOL and Silas, in reality, was a victim of circumstance  and quite an insane one at that.

It's too bad that it was at least 30 minutes too long, and you couldn't really scratch them off anywhere. Wish the ending had been more agile or entertaining, 'cause after giving a not entirely satisfying cut to the main plot, I just wanted the movie to end.

title: no more Angels and Demons
review:
The Da Vinci Code as a novel is very difficult to move the subject into the movie. As a person who read the book, it is easy to see blank spaces in the subject comparing with the novel. This weakness is not come from the insufficiency of director, but the complexity of the novel.

Both of Audrey Tautou as Sophie and Tom Hanks as Robert have played in standards. This is the movie which subject is superior to the characters. No actor / actress put on an act on top level.

To tell you the truth I felt very sleepy in the movie but not because of unclear vision - I have had an eye-operation recently, the movie was sleepy.

In the novel basic information was given to the readers such as holly grail, Fibonacci numbers, methods in solving secret codes. The books have an advantage in complex subjects and explaining in detail. Without reading novel or learning these topics, The Da Vinci Code was absolutely incomprehensible.

Please no more Dan Brown for the movie, no more Angels and Demons.

title: Loved It
review:
I loved trying to work out the codes. I have even started a website with a fun series of codes to break: thewwwcode.50webs.com Here is what it is about:

To crack the WWW code you will need to follow a series of clues and keywords that will lead you to various places on the web. But be warned - the task is not as easy as it sounds. You may be required to recognise patterns, sequences and common themes among words, letters or numbers.

To crack the code you will need to identify eight words, each word being somehow related to the previous one. You will then need to use these words to figure out the five letter codeword.

The quest begins when the first clue is released on July 23, 2006

title: simply adequate
review: I must admit that I haven't read Dan Brown's book and so I wasn't looking forward to watching this film at the first place. Maybe all the fuss in the media and the excessive publicity that forwarded the opening of this film, worked negatively on me. Or, maybe, I've had enough of Hollywood mainstream, commercial movies. I'm not exactly a fan of Ron Howard's work. He makes decent movies that, unfortunately, fail to touch me. " The Da Vinci Code" wasn't an exception. From what I've read so far, it appears that the film was faithful to the book.That's a good sign for a start but IMO it's not enough. A good story offers a nice background for a movie, but it needs more than that for the story to work on the screen. It's the director's skill that sets the pace and the tone, and makes the story interesting to the viewer.That's what separates a great master like Hitchcock from a league of just adequate directors . All that said, I must admit that I wasn't bored while watching this film.There was enough mystery in the actual story to keep me interested.Interested but not thrilled.I enjoyed the takes in the Louvre's interior and the beautiful landscapes, as a tourist would have done. Not for once, though, did I find myself sitting at the edge of my seat , wondering what will happen next. The actors didn't help either.Maybe they weren't given a chance to do so. Tom Hanks, who managed to break my heart in "Philadelphia", was a pale reflection of himself. Audrey Tautou, the ever engaging Amelie, failed to offer more than a pretty face. The only bright exceptions were the always delightful Ian Mc Kellen along with Paul Bettany. That was not enough though to save this film from being a successful mediocrity.

title: a man is murdered in the Louvre and sets into motion an ingenious code leading to the ultimate truth.
review: before entering the theatre on a day that was not turning out to be too bright, i had already read the Dan Brown book that the movie was based on. i went into the dark theatre before it had started, and by the time the movie was through, i was feeling rather pleased. i was glad that the movie was done by such a well known director, and i was pleased with the outcome of the albino monk, Silas. i will also add the fact that i am Christian, with friends of a variety of different religions, and none of which have been insulted in any way over the movie. it is only FICTION, and i don't understand why people have to boycott it. i must warn thy readers of this: do not see this movie if thou art squeamish. Silas undresses himself and whips his bare back, and it is disturbing.

title: Thought-provoking story that keeps you guessing until the end
review:
Ron Howard seems to have a Midas touch. I have never seen a movie directed by him that I didn't like, and this one is definitely a plus.

I believe that Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou did an excellent job portraying their characters and the relationship between them. I've heard complaints about how there was little chemistry between their characters, but I actually think that's pretty true to life. Tom Hanks was portraying a Harvard college professor, and as a college student, I can tell you that the smartest, the most scholarly, and the most pragmatic college professors like to keep things professional. There's no room in the personality of Tom Hanks' character to start any chemistry. Audrey Tautou was also great as the cryptologist struggling to face her past and uncover her grandfather's darkest secrets. Hers was an unspoken strength that I found refreshing for a female lead. I appreciate the reserved, professional-style relationship between Hanks and Tautou. Just because the two main characters are a male and a female doesn't mean that they automatically have to fall in love and embrace in a passionate kiss in every movie. Their closeness was intangible. It was shown through their gestures and their facial expressions, not their words. It was a silent acknoledgement and appreciation of the other's profession and personality, and I don't even think the dialogue between them was wooden at all. These were two characters who were just thrown into extraordinary circumstances, and I think they handled it pretty well.

Hats also should go off to Paul Bettany (Silas), Jean Reno, and Ian McKellen. Bettany's performance gave me chills throughout the entire movie, but what was even more creepy was at times, I actually found myself pitying his character. Jean Reno's performance was above average as the dignified but vicious police officer pursuing Hanks and Tautou. Like many of the characters, he portrayed his emotions mainly through facial expressions and actions rather than words, and he was excellent at it. You could feel the coldness in his eyes as he watched Tom Hanks in the murder investigation sequence. You could tell he suspected Tom Hanks right from the get go, and he wasn't going to stop until he had both Hanks and Tautou behind bars. Ian McKellen is always wonderful in anything he does, and he provided the perfect witty comic relief for this movie. The argument he has with Hanks while Hanks and Tautou are hiding out in his home was great and true to life. It reminded me of my English professors in my college class during a lecture. I could see any two scholars having the same debate over the historical accuracy of the story of Jesus Christ and Mary Magdelene. Where he falls short is a scene he tries to grab the dial that Hanks tosses up in the air.
