He's supposed to be playing a crippled man, but when he's running to catch the dial before it hits the ground, he barely even uses his crutches. Other than that, his performance was very convincing, but don't get too attached to his character. That's all I'm going to say.

But where this movie shines the most is its cinematography and its plot development. The locations in this film are beautiful, and there is a beautiful scene of Mary Magdelene's coffin in front of a single red rose in a vase with a gleam of sunlight touching the sculpture of her body. It is breathtaking. The plot development is awesome. Just when you think you've figured out a character, something happens or they do something that you never expected. Even when I thought I had figured something out plot-wise, another twist would put me right back to square one. However, when you finally do reach the ending, it all makes sense, and that makes for a great plot. This really is a treasure hunt-style movie.

I must finally acknowledge Hans Zimmer for the amazing original score that shines its best at the very last scene.

Overall, this movie is wonderful. With intelligent characters, beautiful backdrops, an uplifting score, a plot full of twists and turns, and thought-provoking questions on religion, The Da Vinci Code will leave you guessing throughout the film and talking when it's all over.

I give it an A. Great job all around.

title: Glaring illogic and way too many climaxes
review:
Those who watch this after reading the book will think it's just fine, but that's because there's a fair bit of information that is in the book, not in the film, that gives readers an overview that helps to understand the film. Those who haven't read the book will find many of the plot twists confusing, and will have a hard time discerning between the protectors of the Holy Grail, and those out to destroy it. There several plot contrivances that are plainly illogical.

For example, we are supposed to believe that, in the very short time between the initial murder and the arrival of the investigators, the lead investigator was contacted by his bishop and told, falsely, that the murderer had confessed to the bishop and who the murderer was.

BUT...this information had to come from somebody who'd seen the murder scene BEFORE the police did, and then passed this scene info on to the bishop WITH the intent of creating a cover-up, all done because the victim had written the falsely accused killer's name on the floor before he died.

EXCEPT...that what the victim wrote was to contact this person (for help), NOT that this person 'is my killer'!

Come on now! This is almost as illogical as the people in horror films who go ahead and investigate a noise the basement when they know for a fact that a psycho is on the loose in the area. And this is only one of several inconsistencies! Plus there are at least 4 separate climactic moments in the last 30 minutes. If this hadn't come from Ron Howard and the big Hollywood movie machine, it would have been panned terribly rather than getting mostly mediocre reviews on average. However it does have great art direction and cinematography, and very good performances in general.

title: Uneven, see it for good acting and interesting ideas
review: I agree with many of the reviewers here that the movie is uneven. There are excellent performances from Ian McKellen, Audrey Tautou and Paul Bettany, and, in fairness, no weak links whatever on the acting side. Tom Hanks had perhaps the highest hill to climb because the character given to Langdon in the film is a bit nondescript, but he did as well as anyone could have with the material he was given. The writing I thought varied from acceptable to very poor. Hanks/Langdon and McKellen/Teabing were frequently given long explanatory speeches that came close to voice-overs; lectures to the audience about the ideas underlying the plot. Maybe there was no other way to do this but I think with a little more ingenuity it could have emerged more naturally from slightly more convincing screen conversations. In fact the underlying ideas about cynical manipulation by the Roman Catholic Church of its followers to protect its power was the real centre of interest of the film, but probably by now too familiar to most cinema-goers and people who have followed the debate about the book and the film to come as very much of a surprise in this context. The "action" tended to be the familiar Hollywood over-the-top gunfights and car chases and hidden tracker devices that are so much the stock and trade of Bond films, with occasional flashes of something darker and more character-driven when Bettany/Silas was on the screen. As a straight thriller, without the religious/intellectual dimension, I think the film would go almost unnoticed, but the intrigue surrounding the Church and its history, origins and motives will certainly keep you awake if it isn't by now all too familiar.

title: One of the strongest movies in the history
review: This movie has it own theory. You can believe it or you cant. Well i didn't believe this films idea because to me its not true. And trust me if you don't have strong faith in your self don't watch it. It could make you lose your faith in your self completely. There are only some things you can believe in this film. And there are things that are wrong in this film wrong theory's (to me). But look at the bright side the acting is excellent Tom Hanks has showed one of his best acts in his life. And the way they solve the codes are fabulous. If you see the film you will say that this character (Robert) is a guineas. So go and watch this great film. And i don't think your small kids will like it. well i did!!!

title: It was more than i expected it.
review: I have read the book and watched the movie. Before i watched it i had my opinion of Tom Hanks playing Langdon. I questioned as to why Hanks was chosen as i would have picked other actors that would have fit the Langdon character better.I somehow pictured Langdon to be taller. Before watching the movie I thought that the character Silas was done brilliantly and from the trailer, i saw that Paul bettany was the perfect actor to play silas. he was everything i imagined him to be. When i watched the movie, i found that Tom Hanks was good. He played Langdon very well and Paul Bettany was brilliant as Silas. Most of the things i imaged it to be was magically transformed into life like the cryptext. Exactly how i imagined it!Somehow i feel that Alfred Molina was not the right actor for Aringarosa. Aringarosa was suppose to be more down to earth and friendlier. Does it makes sense? Anyway i was quite happy with the movie. There were some parts in the book that wasn't featured in the movie but they captured the gist of it. I like the idea that those who haven't read the book can also understand it. I love the part when Tom hanks was solving the anagrams, that was brilliantly done without having to explain what an anagrams mean. The session with Teabing and when they were explaining the Last supper. That was done really well.I was a bit disappointed when Sophie's character in the movie was not dominantly displayed as compared to the book where she has more say in things. Overall it was a good movie and a great book!

title: Too much like Nancy Drew
review:
I liked the book better than the movie -- I was disappointed with Tom Hanks' performance for the first time. I think it was as much the fault of the director and the script as anything -- his lines were limited, his stricken expression unyielding.

Perhaps the problem lies in the effort to take a convoluted novel and condense it -- something had to go, and it was Langdon's personality and how he processed his dilemmas.

In an effort to keep the sweeping feel as the movie moved from one locale to another -- the Louvre, the Bois de Boulogne, Teabing's country cottage, London -- the movie ends up feeling like a string of ham-fisted clues, all wrapped in a neat little package in a grown-up Nancy Drew mystery. "Oh, look Bess, here's another anagram!"

An example of a movie that does a better job of sweeping to many locations, in my opinion, is the Pelican Brief (based on John Grisham's book) but it had longer to move more gracefully around the continent.

To his credit, I think Ron Howard trimmed some things for good reason -- what seemed somewhat engaging on paper may have come across as goofy and un-credible on the big screen.

title: it was like watching a documentary on the History Channel
review:
I've given this a 4 because I don't want to be entirely evil, but I really just didn't like this movie. I read the book about 3 years ago, and the main points that I remembered from the plot were neglected from the movie (last supper emphasis). I'm a fan of the Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings movies, so I am not just pulling the "book will always be better" mentality. I found many points that could have been better executed as well, in terms of clarifying certain points and making it truer to the book and thus more comprehensible to the viewers.

*spoilers* From the very beginning of the movie when Langdon first set foot in the museum, they made no mention of why Sophie was there- how she was an intellectual. Well in this movie, her "grandfather's" secret code that he left for her was not mentioned and didn't give her any reason to be there or a reason for Langdon to trust her and her opinions.

I also felt that whatever Langdon discovered something or solved a riddle, we were watching him figure it out and not figuring it out with him, very similar to a college lecture or, as stated in my title of this review, a television documentary. Hilighting the letters of the "secret code"? Really Ron Howard? I've suddenly moved from the History Channel to PBS Kids: Let's Read!.

Oh and the ending??? Seriously. Come on now. There was no reason for that. The book is excellent, why not take SOME advice from it? *spoilers over* The flashbacks I found ridiculously corny and just seemed like an easy way out of explaining the plot through other cinematography aspects and an alteration of dialogue.

Which brings me to the dialogue. Dan Brown may write amazing novels, but he ain't no script writer.

The leads I found had no chemistry at all, and while they may have been independently good, that's not what movies are about.

This movie did not hold my attention and I will say that I did find myself nodding off through many parts though, upon questioning friends each time I awoke, I was told I didn't miss much.

Some scenes were much too long. Other scenes that needed to be longer were way too short.

Other people I notice worship this movie, so no offense to you. I just found this film a terrible waste of time and money, and a disappointment after all of the anticipation I felt. I really was watching through rose colored glasses and I still came out with this opinion.

title: Boring, but much better than the book
review:
Grade: C The best way to sum The DaVinci Code up is: boring. The movie plots along with our characters rushing from point to point, much like the book. The only difference is that director Ron Howard and his crew are much better filmmakers than Dan Brown is a writer. Unfortunately, the source material is so bland that the resulting film has a climax that is about as jarring as finding out whether a flipped coin landed heads or tails.

The plot of the movie stays relatively close to the book. Few changes are made, and none of them are significant enough to mention. Robert Langdon is invited to the Louvre by French Police Captain Fache to help solve the murder of the curator. He soon learns that he is the main suspect for the murder. French cryptographer Sophie Neveu rescues him and together they go on a long, long, long journey with many, many, many clues that leads to a discovery that contradicts major Christian beliefs.

As you may have already guessed, the movie was too long. The pacing for the 149 minutes is painfully slow. Even the beginning, which was the only reason I read the book in the first place, turns out to be passive. It's as if Howard wants to skip the initial event and jump right into the mystery. Not a bad idea, but it's not executed well.

Howard does a good job of translating the scholarly historical information (remember, it's fiction, a.k.a. fake, a.k.a. made up) into eye popping visuals. In the same manner Howard showed us the way Nash saw the world in A Beautiful Mind, he shows us how Robert Langdon solves puzzles by just looking at them. Sadly, Langdon isn't Nash. Langdon is a character without flaws, except maybe for sporting the always fashionable mullet. Once one of the great actors of his generation, Tom Hanks has apparently taken to the one-dimensional main characters (remember Viktor Navorski from The Terminal?). There is a ton of talent wasted here from the adorable Audrey Tautou to the always incredible Jean Reno. Why did all these famous and talented actors waste their time on a movie like this?

Luckily, Sir Ian McKellen saves the day as usual. His upbeat and complex portrayal of Sir Leigh Teabing gives the movie the swift kick in the ass it needs before falling flat on its face. Before Teabing, our characters plot along from location to location, clue to clue. A good mystery shows the audience the finish line so the audience can give a damn about what is going on. If it doesn't do that, it gives us characters we should care about along each step of the way. The DaVinci Code does neither. Teabing leads Robert and Sophie on a quest that has an end in sight, even if we don't know exactly what it is. He gives the movie a much needed structure and his short lecture really sets up the mystery (even if it is about half-way into the movie).

Now, what about the big controversy about what the movie is about? Quite frankly if you're somewhat educated and you think that this movie is anything but fiction, you're probably going to die tripping over your own feet sometime very soon. I understand the controversy because the controversial "facts" are presented as just that: facts. I don't want to spoil anything by getting too into the specifics, but it deals with Jesus and whether or not he had a wife. Those who are poorly educated (which is a large part of the worldwide movie going population) can mistake what the movie presents as actual fact. Thus the movie has been banned in countries like India and China and edited beyond recognition in others.

At the end of the day the movie will be successful because the book was successful. Millions of people gobbled it up because it was "entertaining." I ask for a little more from entertainment than a fake history lesson. Heck, it would have helped to at least be a good fake history lesson.

title: Not Original Works
review:
The book, and movie, have used almost a complete reference from this book:

Holy Blood, Holy Grail by Michael Baigent, Richard Leigh, Henry Lincoln http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0440136482 Which was originally published in 1978, and reissued in 1983.

After reading The DaVinci Code, I realized how much the plot line was based upon the research Holy Blood, Holy Grail.

Dan Brown did an amazing job of taking the decades of research in Holy Blood, Holy Grail, and turning it into a 2 day romp around France and England to complete his story.

Dan Brown has written a great thriller with his two main characters Robert Langdon, and Sophie Neveau. However the conspiracy was not originally Dan Brown's idea.

Christians can no more point a finger at "his" outrageous idea, than a historian can praise him for showing the facts. Dan Brown's story could have easily been "National Treasure".

title: Great, great movie.
review:
As a fan of the book, I can happily say I was entirely satisfied with the movie and thoroughly enjoyed it.

I think the negative reviews/press are due to: - the general controversy surrounding the plot. - the expectations of a movie adaptation of a book that was SO popular. - the expectations of a Tom Hanks movie. - critics' somewhat love/hate relationship with Ron Howard movies. - the general idea that a movie can never live up to a book.

This is an excellent movie and a great performance by Hanks. Hanks performance fit as a puzzle-piece to the overall experience rather than taking over the picture.

Overall great, great movie...and I'm honestly surprised with the negative reviews.

title: At least the book was good
review:
I think liked this movie better when it was called "National Treasure".

The film moved along at a nice pace. I wasn't bored. I think my favorite part was the European tour of museums, chapels, and historical sites. The scope and feel of the movie played out on the big screen much as it did in my head when I read the novel. Audrey Tautou is lovely to look at although her character seemed much smarter in the book. Paul Bettany as Silas was disturbing and exciting. Tom Hanks pretty much nailed his part. I don't think the characters of Teabing and Fache could have been better cast, perfection there. The movie strayed from the book too much to explain the story as well as the written version. Please don't hesitate to read the book even if you've already seen the film. You will say "oh yeah!" to yourself severla times. Overall this movie was just like National Treasure.

title: Fantasy . . . Mystery . . . Ennui
review:
Audrey Tatou did not take off her clothes? What is the world coming to? No, seriously, this was a bit of a yawner for me, as I have read the non-canonical materials and simply can't suspend disbelief enough to participate in such an absurd conspiracy theory, all at the hands of the diabolical Roman Catholic Church. Lord help us if we have a generation growing up that knows so little about history as to take this film at all seriously. By way of analogy, it would be as if I made a Superman film and forgot to put in the bit about him having super powers. Yawn.

What I really want to know is: When is this director going to bring "The Satanic Verses" to the screen?

title: Not the worst movie ever made, just seems like it is.
review:
I'm sure "The Da Vinci Code" is not the worst movie ever made, but as you're watching it at times it's difficult to think otherwise. Whether it's the disjointed scenes, clumsy cinematography (a.k.a. flashbacks) or uninspired dialogue, this is a very poorly made film (with a story that is boring and uninteresting).

Tom Hanks is a great actor and gives an admirable performance as symbologist Robert Langdon, but even he cannot rescue this snoozefest. Audrey Tautou is a talented young actress, however, her only purpose on screen (as Sophie Neveu) is to look like a caged and frightened vixen (she succeeds).

It's hard to imagine a book that sold this many copies could become a movie that is so bad, but perhaps DVC can be thought of as a "symbol" for what is wrong with American cinema today. If you must waste 2 hours of your life on this garbage, try to see it for free. I'm glad I did!

title: Secret society tries to protect the astonishing secret and a mysterious bloodline
review:
This is a really good movie of unique dimensions. I would recommend it to anybody that likes adventure and suspense. I will not ruin your entertainment by saying what is going on in the movie. But what disturbs me is the negative attitude of the general public and the negative criticisms towards this movie. This is specially true of the older and middle aged population. REMEMBER THIS IS A FICTION MOVIE OUT OF A Fictitious BOOK. First of all it is not a threat towards Christianity. Second you need to double check your morality if a movie disturbs your foundations of belief.

But if you like action and adventure and a fan of Tom Hanks movies this is a must see.

title: Good Film
review:
I don't know why people hate this film, whether for religious or actually film related reasons, the film is great, not an epic spectacular but still great. It isn't gonna sweep the Oscars or anything.

Da Vinci's main strengths lie in it's supportive roles Audrey Tautou, Ian McKellan and especially Paul Bettany as Silas. Tautou was amazing and very believable as Sophie Neveu, Ian McKellan as per usual was both entertaining and very into his character of Leigh Teabing. But as great as Ian was Paul Bettany was just that little bit better, making Silas (as he is) violent yet very real and human with real feelings and emotions (I felt sorry when he died). All three deserve Oscar Nominations, Oscar wins for Bettany and Tautou.

A lot of people bash Tom Hanks for this, but I think it's only because everyone has their on image of who Robert Langdon was. It isn't the usual stellar Tom Hanks performance, but he is still good.

The cinematography of Da Vinci's flashbacks are also incredible.Oscar Nomination.

There are only three faults:Not enough of Jean Reno. It lacked a spark that I think falls under Ron Howards fault. He's a great director but I think wrong for this movie. Personally I think David Fincher (Fight Club, Se7en, The Game) should've done it, the story is perfect for him and would've been great for his career, he would have made it darker, edgier and more of a thriller.

Overall, great film.

title: Technically perfect, but not very suspenseful.
review:
Ron Howard, is a master film maker. Tom Hanks, Jean Reno, Ian McKlennen, Jurgen Prochnow, Audre Tautou, couldn't have a better, more respected professional cast. The story is great. The editing is some of the best (possibly it's only Oscar nod, it isn't getting any nominations for wardrobe). But, I found myself looking at my watch four times throughout the movie, and the man next to us kept yawning. Was it over hyped? Did we expect too much? Or was it just not suspenseful, which oddly enough draws me again to the conclusion of "no comic element, no suspense." Hitchcock made the opening of wine bottles in "Notorious" suspenseful. This movie failed to draw any feelings of "a-hah" or "whoa", even with the blood and death and flogging and knights of Temple and priority of scion and orgies and car wrecks, etc. Just no ummph.

The conclusion from my wife and I is: It would have been a better movie if Jay and Silent Bob would have done it. "Like, whoa, dude! This DaVinci guy knew a lot of stuff, huh? And that Mary Magdalene babe was there all the time. WOW!"

title: An insult to the intellect and nothing more then a powerpoint slide presentation of the book.
review:
The Da Vinci Code is a missed opportunity, it has a fine cast, a potential good plot, great locations, but it is really not more then a moving powerpoint presentation of the main episodes from the book.

The director, Ron Howard, should be sent to a permanent vacation and should only concern himself with making slide presentations of a book, but never ever be allowed to make a movie again. The guy is an insult to the intellect.

For instance, there is a scene where the main characters are fleeing from France to England. They are waited upon by the police in England and face the problem of escaping from the plane. The plane has landed, Sir Teabing and his driver steps out of the plane, but Langdon, Neveu and Silas are not there. Later, when Sir Teabing drives away, they happened to be hidden in the back of the car. So far so good. However, and this is really insulting of that Ron Howard, then a flashback occurs. In this flashback it is explained how they got away. You see the plane landing, while the plane taxis, the door opens, Langdon and so jump out, run to the car and hide there. A whole stupid and intellect insulting scene during a minute or so. Really, they should fire that Ron Howard!

Other example. The film is shot on location, in the Louvre! An excellent opportunity to provide some nice shots and close ups of some art and the environment. But, nothing of that. Only the absolute bare essentials are brought into picture with respect to the art and the Louvre architecture. But when Langdon arrives at the Swiss bank to obtain the secret box, there is a scene where the access code is tried. This scene is meant to build up tension, intended to be in awe whether the key is correct or not. They punch in the number and a whole freaking minute is wasted with a close up on an ugly green, semi-futuristic display showing the punched in key and displaying a message that it is accepted. A whole minute wasted with an ugly way to build in tension, while all that beautiful art in the Louvre didn't get one minute of extra time.

Good, my conclusion. If you haven't read the book, it is a nice youth thriller. If the reli-conspiracy genre fits you, you might appreciate it even more. However, if you have read the book, you come to the conclusion that it has nothing extra to offer over the book. It follows the story line like a slave, and adds nothing to it, doesn't take advantage of the fact that is a movie, not a powerpoint slide. Furthermore, the atmosphere in the movie doesn't come out, like it does in the book. The movie doesn't give you that reli conspiracy feeling, like it should. Finally, there is no chemistry at all between the two main characters, Sophie and Robert, despite the fact that Tom Hanks is playing Robert Langdon. Clearly you cannot blame Tom Hanks. So please, do not see this movie, and boycott that amateur of a Ron Howard, that isn't able to mix all the fine ingredients in something that tastes good.

title: At times entertaining, at times dumb and boring, a strange movie
review:
I just saw the movie last night, and, as a first impression it wasn't as bad as I thought it would be, based on the critics opinions. Sone parts were actually entertaining (mostly the action parts), and although it got boring and even comically stupid at times, the 2 1/2 hours passed quite fast.

Now the bad parts: The scene that ruined the movie for me early on was the lecture that Hanks had in Paris at the beginning. I don't claim to be very intelligent or educated (I'm just a poor Romanian Engineering student), but even I know that the Svastika is an ancient Indian symbol for the sun, or that the Spanish catholics have a ritual which involves KKK like sheets, and so on.. that scene was so unbelievable because at that kind of lectures, the attendance is usually made up of intelligent people that are interested in that kind of discussion.. well, that wasn't the case in the movie, the audience seemed to be made up of idiots (or Americans) who had no idea of basic European symbols.. I guess the scene was a plot device designed to let everybody know that the Hanks character (don't remember his name, Lon.. something) was a genius, and so on, but for me it was a clear indication that the movie is aimed at the "mentally challenged" (or American) audiences, not at the people who actually know something about European history. And actually it was funny how there was a guy with a fake french accent ready to give the perfect wrong answer, so that Hanks can correct them with an arrogant answer.

One thing that shocked me was the way the movie took myths and pure speculations and presented them as facts. For example, the Merovingian family is presented as part of Jesus' bloodline. As somebody quite familiar with french history, I found that part ludicrous and laughable. And the painting by Da Vinci was presented like it was a firsthand representation of The Last Supper. I found myself wondering if I'm the only one who gets the fact that it was JUST A PAINTING made CENTURIES after the real event took place. How can a sane person base a theory like that on a PAINTING?? Leonardo Da Vinci was indeed a genius, but that doesn't mean he knew what really happened during The Last Supper. He probably did believe that Jesus got married with Maria-Magdalena, but his beliefs are quite irrelevant in a historical context. There were other parts of the movie I found laughable, but I have to see the movie again to make a list..

But the thing I hated most about "The Da Vinci Code" is that the plot was so dumbed-down, that any moron could understand it. I really hate movies like that (unless it has Jessica Alba or some serious T&A), and I couldn't help comparing DVC with another movie I saw recently (Syriana) which, although had some flaws, really made you think, and required at least half-a-brain to understand...

And another thing: I'we been to Paris once, and the biggest impression I had was of cultural diversity: there were like millions of Africans (Blacks and north African Arabs) in Paris, not to mention the many Portuguese, Italians and other Europeans, and scores of Japanese tourists (which were like everywhere). You don't see that in the Da Vinci Code: they're all white stereotypical french. I found that really unrealistic.

title: An admittedly disappointing homage to the great novel...
review: The movie pales in comparison to the very shadow the book casts, maybe not an utter disappointment, but darn close. The book's pacing and the way the story was laid out was spectacular yet the movie couldn't seem to emulate that effect. Not one of Hank's best performances for sure, however, the actor that really stood out was Paul Bettany, who, was stunning as Silas, capturing the essence of the character masterfully. All in all I don't think it was worth the money, I'm sure many would contest that statement, and I myself never thought I'd say that about a film remake of such a good book but I stand by my opinion. With such a high calibre crew I figured they would've been able to pull it off nicely, or maybe my high opinion of the book tainted my review of the film, whatever the case, 5 out of 10 I'd say. Would've given it six had I not almost fallen asleep waiting for it to end due to the lengthly process of tying loose ends about 3/4 of the way through...

title: Harmless (albeit, predictable) popcorn film
review: I was interested in seeing this film based on the controversy and hoopla surrounding the story. I had not read the novel, so I entered the movie with only the basic themes and plot points. What I was not expecting was that the film would give itself away within the first twenty minutes. I mean the whole film. Everything. After that I actually rather enjoyed the film in a kind of ironic way. Ron Howard presents the drama and suspense so seriously and awkwardly that it becomes rather funny at times. (The only suspense the film offered was whether or not it was really an elaborate SNL skit.) You know your film is in trouble when your action hero exclaims urgently, "We have to get to a library, fast!" I wasn't the only one who laughed. I guess the main problem is Ron Howard. He is like the Chistopher Cross of filmmakers. Lots of hits and awards, but in the long run, who will remember him (without laughing or wincing)? He is a utilitarian director who's biggest flaw is that he doesn't seem to understand that it is better to show and not tell. I get it already Ron! I got it a while ago! Tom Hanks is another problem. His acting is wooden, almost imperceptible. (Of course he is the only actor I can think of that has been upstaged by a volley ball). Don't even get me started on the brilliant Ian McKellen who wretchedly embarrasses himself in Da Vinci Code as an excitable Jesus scholar. If you don't believe me, pay close attention to the last twenty minutes where he seems to think that suddenly he needs to project as if he were on stage. The moody and atmospheric cinematography is the only bright spot in the film, and outside of the unintentional humor, the only nice thing I can say. Ultimately, I am not quite sure why everyone is getting all worked up about this film. The conspiracy aspect is interesting and with a better script and director it could have been something of quality. As it is the film is predictable popcorn fare; perhaps a bit better than your average summer mind-drain but all in all..."meh". Not having read the novel I can only speculate on the source material, but I can imagine that Dan Brown spends a lot more time than Ron Howard showing and not telling with his fiction. With all the money he's made from the book, maybe he can finally afford to attend that writing class.

title: Good Movie - Better If You Have Read the Book
review:
It's another fine professional film directing job by Ron Howard - however, because the story is dense with history, exposition and details - the film plays much, much better if you have read the book.

In particular, if you're a fan of the book - you can compare your imagination of who you've casted, how you would've unfolded the script and how you would have directed the story cinematically. The story, plot and action unfolds at breakneck speed as they race to solve the riddle - however, there are parts of the film which bog down for exposition - but for those who've read the book (and who liked the book), the scenes play out much better because we know what's the gist but for those who have not read the book, some pertinent or important info might elude them as some scenes just fire info/details at you.

There seem to be some overly harsh negative reviews of the film, including Tom Hanks & Audrey Tautou performance which I frankly don't understand. Everyone is fine in this film and I wonder if it's just Catholic reviewers (whether they openly come out and disclose that or not) who loath even the mention of the subject matter that they cannot see anything beyond that.

DaVinci Code is not a great movie but it's a nice summer popcorn movie. Tom Hanks, as usual is solid - I was surprised at not only how gorgeous Audrey Tautou was but what a fine acting range she shows in her SECOND LAMNGUAGE - having only seen her in "mousy" roles, she was great. Of course, Ian McKellan really hams it up but that's what his role required and he seems to have great fun (as usual).

Again, don't be scared off by reviewers who might feel it's an affront to their religion. If they really watched the film, they'd see the issues are dealt with in a reasonably and complex manner. Certainly, it's your faith and you can be offended and that's your right - but at least be upfront and tell us that and not couch it by claiming it's the directing or the acting ... because that aspect is all just fine.

title: 50% of the people will agree with this review
review:
I say that because 50% of the people seem to agree with every review on the board. The film is that divisive and so the reviews are necessarily divided as well, along with people's reaction to them. I don't usually read novels but I read this one and I'm kind of sorry I did because it meant I knew everything that was going to happen ahead of time, just as with "King Kong". You wind up dissecting the film rather than experiencing it. If you are one of the few remaining cavemen who haven't read this book, I'd suggest seeing the movie first, then reading the book. It's easier to dissect a book and more fun to experience a movie.

The big problem in both mediums for this material is the tremendous amount of exposition required to have some idea of what is going on. There is conversation after conversation giving a "Cliff's Notes" version of history, at least the history Dan Brown decided to mix in with his dramatic speculations. The film at least cuts down on those to keep the action moving. It might have been a better idea to get all or most of that out of the way with Langdon's opening lecture, rather that jump-cutting to a book signing after his introduction. The filmmakers might have even had him dream about these events before he is awakened by the call from the police.

Ron Howard is a more experienced storyteller than Dan Brown and the movie shows it. It's much more streamlined than the book and handles things like the attitude of Teabing's butler much better. Tom Hanks is adequate as Langdon, (emphasizing his claustrophobia at the beginning is a master-stroke as it seems to confirm Feche's suspicions). Audrey Tautou is OK as Sophie, although the character is not very well defined in either the book or the film. Ian McKellen plays Teabing not merely as the closest thing to a "bad guy" in the story but something of a pathetically obsessed nut, also an improvement from the book.

Although the history in the story ranges from speculative to simply wrong, (the film also cleverly deals with this: Langdon noting that the Priory of Scion is "thought to be a hoax" but isn't), the basic idea of it: that it was intended that we be governed by traits both male and female, that our male dominated churches and governments have produced too much rivalry and violence and that we need more female nurturing, is a good one and well worth thinking about after seeing this film. But I'm still left with the basic question: If your group is opposed to the established church and possesses something that will "destroy" it, (surely an overstatement), why would you keep it a secret for 2000 years? Wouldn't this make more sense if the Church held "the Grail" and the Priory were trying to obtain it?

title: Shattered expectations
review: Dumbed down, softened for the movie-going public, lacked what it ought not, added what it ought not... Like diluted orange-juice, it left me wanting. If you read and enjoyed the book you'll react one of two ways to the movie: You'll either be disappointed as I was, or you may enjoy it (as I know people who did in that category). Having not read the book you will likely enjoy it. Certain comments I have read seem to suggest the movie closely follows the book. This could not be further from the truth. There were some critical differences as have been pointed out in other commentaries (I will not spoil anything here). These differences bothered me to the point of disliking the movie. Make up your own mind as to how severe these divergencies are. I still suggest seeing the movie as it can open your mind up to some very interesting ideas, namely that true history may not be depicted in our flawed accounts of it. The movie does only half the job of the book in conveying Dan Brown's message.

title: It was the ULTIMATE adaptation of a book!!!!
review: WONDERFUL!!! INCREDIBLE!!!!!!!!! I saw it 3 times so far and each time it has affected me more. Read the book twice. The casting was perfect and the script was amazing! The shortcuts they took were excellent; in fact, my nephew, who never read the book, got the movie immediately. Tom Hanks had the right combination of gravity, wit and understatement -his reading of the pivotal lines brought tears to my eyes and the final shot - oh my, how beautiful! What difficult lines they were and how easy to make them maudlin! And Audrey Tautou - she WAS Sophie and such a joy to watch. I'm going to have to start viewing her other movies. The critics are crazy - boring; rushed? I don't think so. Ron Howard and his production staff should be given many Oscars for the way they put this together (one can only IMAGINE how much film was shot and edited to pull this off and how brave they were to tackle it!) but I'm sure that will never happen, as the critics rule everything and fact that the basic premise and subject matter make everyone ballistic will unfortunately override what a terrific movie this is and how much praise it deserves. And hurray to Hans Zimmer for ANOTHER perfect score!And getting back to that subject matter - anything that sparks this much discussion on all sides can only be a GOOD thing! GO SEE IT and then TALK about IT!!!!!

title: Bigotry, hatred and insecurity all in one movie. Never since Birth of a Nation has blind hatred been put on film
review:
This is a movie that has been studied very closely since the time it came out. This movie makes many statements that are absurd and that have been debunked by many who have reviewed the book and the movie. It is simply an attack on the Catholic Church and not a very good one at that. If you hate the Catholic Church, you will love this movie. If you are rational and open minded, you will realize the nonsense that this book and movie actually presents.

I would like to ask Melody a question. If they made a "fictional" movie saying that the Holocaust never happen, if President Nixon was framed or if John F. Kennedy started the Viet Nam war, if he would be so accepting of this movie as "fiction".

Why is it necessary to try to destroy beliefs that people hold dear and sacred. I believe that those who have to attack other's beliefs do it because they are insecure in their own beliefs.

If you enjoy this movie, you should sincerely ask yourself why.

title: Ron Howard didn't quite crack it
review:
Ron Howard's much hyped and rather unnecessarily over-marketed The Da Vinci Code had most critics carping after its Cannes premiere. Who cares? The excitement is at an all time high, there is controversy, the Da Vinci craze is in fever pitch mode, there are huge promotional events, posters are strewn all across the globe, the promos look fantastic- what more could one ask for? Critics? Who cares about them, that sore bunch of losers? The problem here is, they aren't very wrong in their assessment of the film.

Dan Brown's The Da Vinci Code is surely no classic. It is, however- despite the flaws and certain inaccuracies- one helluva entertaining and riveting ride. Sadly, director Ron Howard and screenwriter Akiva Goldsman don't quite manage to crack the code. What they achieve, nevertheless, is nothing short of stupendous- it's an absolute movie-making miracle. For they have actually managed to rob the thrilling novel of almost every bit of thrill, pace and punch it has.

Don't get me wrong. The Da Vinci Code is certainly not a bad film. It is eminently watchable, and I admit it does have some good moments. But when it's an adaptation of a book as explosive as The Da Vinci Code, one expects nothing less than total blockbuster perfection. The film falls way too short of that.

Okay, the good bit first- the monuments and locations look absolutely gorgeous and magnificent on screen, the cinematography is glorious- quite dark and moody, the camera angles are awesome.

The actors are wonderfully cast and play their parts rather well. Though the book likens Langdon's appearance to that of Harrison Ford, I somehow always pictured Tom Hanks in this role. Whether it be Forrest Gump, the AIDS affected lawyer in Philadelphia, or Viktor Navorski in The Terminal- there is this warm, humane quality that Hanks brings to all his characters. Hanks has a purity, an almost childlike innocence that is so vital to Langdon's character. I can't think of an actor who could play Langdon better- his presence illuminates the film.

Audrey Tautou is perfectly cast as Sophie Neveu- she pitches in a good act, complimenting Hanks perfectly with her demure, yet dynamic presence. The other actors' roles are understandably not too fleshed out- with maybe the sole exception of Ian Mckellen who gives a wicked performance as the witty and eccentric Sir Leigh Teabing. However, the other actors- Alfred Molina, Jean Reno, Paul Bettany- are suitably competent in the limited scope that they get.

Now for the quirks- and believe me, they are many. Howard turns Code- which is essentially a fast paced thriller- into profound, serious drama, utterly boring and ultimately pretentious. It's his scholarly, austere, even almost religious approach to the story that pulls it down. This is a film that takes itself a bit too seriously. I mean- all those flashback sequences, the long sepia-toned historical explanations- were they really so necessary? The first one hour is fair enough, moving on pretty smoothly. It's the remainder of the film in which things begin to get really dreary- the excitement and pace is all missing.I can't say if Code begins with a bang, but it does end with a whimper.

Goldsman's script lets the book down terribly- there are hardly any clever, inventive touches- instead, he robs the book of some of its best moments. Much of Teabing's best lines are lost- I especially missed one in which he threatens the police that unless they'd let him go, he'd have his lawyers 'scramble their testicles for breakfast.' Langdon's Mickey Mouse watch is missing- I know it's trivial, but then these are those little touches that make any book or film special. Much of the film is spent in boring conversation and silly, juvenile arguments between Langdon and Teabing. By the time the 'climax' appears, you're too bored to even care. And then Goldsman delivers the worst blow of all- just when you thought that there was some romance brewing between Langdon and Neveu, he has Hanks plant a true-blue Bollywood style fatherly kiss on Tautou's forehead. Ouch, and ugh.

One last grouse- the whole mystique of the Holy Grail lies in its ambiguous form and nature- in the book, we never know how it exactly is, except that it consists of the sarcophagus of Mary Magdalene and some documents. Howard, in the end, actually zooms down into the depths of the earth to show us the remains- as if to tell us- look, it's here! We know, Mr Howard, we know.

The Da Vinci Code, I repeat, is not a bad film at all. Fact is, it could have been explosive on celluloid. After watching Code, the thought that hurts most is that of what it could have been.

title: Why does this movie get such a bad rep?
review:
I saw this movie a couple of days ago, and i must say, i don't see how people don't like this movie. I haven't read the book, so i cant compare... but i thought this was a great movie! It gets you thinking that, just maybe the people who you will always trust to do the right thing (priests.. etc...) maybe are not being totally honest to you. I can see how people who believe deeply in their religion can be offended by this, but common people! Its a movie! Its a theory! Its someones opinion on what could of happened! Tell me this, if i were to say that my opinion is that god doesn't exist, and make a full book about how I'm trying to prove that... would you get just as mad? I mean common guys! Lighten up! Although this is not a role i, nor anyone I've talked to thinks Tom Hanks is suited for, and normally plays, but i think he did quite a good job of it.

10/10!

title: Loved the movie, read the book
review: I was initially afraid after reading some reviews and response at Cannes but I have learned reviews do not usually predict my own reactions to movies. I read the book and I thought Ron Howard did well adapting this to the screen. This sharpened some parts of the book and brought some of the ideas and scenes more into focus. Although the pacing was a little slow at times, after I got into the movie it fit. Overall it worked as a thriller, and it also worked as deeper exploration of the religious ideas. The scenery was gorgeous; I know a few people who've gone on 'Da Vinci' tours and it certainly inspires you to see these locales. The acting was wonderful and the actors were very appropriate for their parts. This is an adult movie, with philosophical and religious themes so maybe that's why it seems to stick out, ; so many movies now have the target of teens and are all animation or slick scifi.

title: Book was great, movie disappointing
review: I thought the movie started out great, but by the end i was disappointed, it missed out a lot of info that was in the book, plus they changed the end, It would have been better if they stuck to the book and just made the movie longer, and the cast, Tom hanks is great but they missed the most simple details, like Silas who is supposed to have red eyes and in the movie had bright blue eyes, and how the circle around Sauniere was supposed to show up under the black light, but it was already there. Hanks and the others found the meanings and worked out the clues to easily. overall the movie was very disappointing after reading the book, which was great.

title: read this comment to its end please.....
review:
Hello there, first of all you sure noticed my location, so you know i am Muslim, but let religion be out of this discussion about a movie i think it is really very well made.

When i heard first about a movie yet to come named "The Da Vinci Code" i didn't know anything about it, then news came flying: first of all the re-teaming of Ron Howard, Akiva Goldsman and Brian Grazer after the great "A Beautiful mind", then they say it is Tom Hanks who will lead the cast, and again names coming and oh my GOD what names!! Ian Mckellen(Gandalf himself!! or shall i say Eric MAGNETO Lensherr), Jean Reno(LEON !???), Alfred Molina(i just love the guy), Paul Bettany(believe me, SILAS was GREEAAAT) and even Audry Tautou(i didn't see Amelie but all that hype for nothing' ??) then when i read all those names i said that's gotta be something.

Then months later i heard about the novel from one of my relatives that had read it and she said it was great but very striking and for sure opposing Christianity as we know it and sure when adapted to the big screen and watched by millions will cause a very huge stir worldwide. So i borrowed it and read in about 16 Hours(on the course of 4 days) and WOW, i loved it very much.

Dan Brown is not Michael Chrichton, i mean he is not writing a Sci-Fi idea which is blended with reality and elements from our life so that we eventually believe it and take it for granted, but he has intrigued me to finish the last half of the book in 7 consecutive hours without stopping to do anything. I mean the rhythm is great and the events take place in just one day and one night and i love this very much, it makes me feel i'm with those guys and i'm actually feeling what they are doing and suffering and dealing with.

I loved the book, it is real and captivating and without entering religious disputes i thought after i read it the movie will be just PERFECT if they didn't mess with anything.

Then it all started, the refusal, the banning and the movie till this very day i write this comment didn't show in Egypt, so i frankly couldn't wait and downloaded it in just two days and just watched it this afternoon and i'll tell you what i think.

I think it is a very perfect movie especially for my taste of movies, the cast is all great-my highlights are especially Ian Mckellen and Paul Bettany-All critics said there is ZERO CHEMISTRY between Tom Hanks and Audry Tautou, I say they work together very fine.

Directing is great and cinematography is great and the Score IS great(Hans Zimmer after all gentlemen!) and the minor changes to the novel are good and they didn't mess with anything according to my own standards..... THIS IS A VERY PERFECT MOVIE.

So what is the problem ?, I'm writing it in these lines: every living Human Being on this very earth has his or her Religious beliefs, when someone in somewhere comes and try to test my faith and belief in my religion i have only 3 limited options: 01.I am not ready enough for discussion and debate because i really didn't read or know about my religion enough to argue.

02.I am totally aware of any aspect of my religion and the base of my belief so i am very ready for any question or discussion or dispute or argument and i will answer because I BELIEVE.

03.Iam not a believer, and any simple question or offense or even a hint to my belief will either confuse me or enrage me WITHOUT THINKING or just make me dump what i believe in and start looking anywhere else for a Religion.

So, why don't we let every man and woman in the world watch this movie and any other religious themed movie and let them decide for themselves and know WHO THEY REALLY ARE? BELIEVERS OR JUST PRETENDERS?.

title: Hardly Worth All The Hype
review: I just returned from seeing this film; I had previously read the book. As I often do, I read IMDb viewpoints afterward. In short, this is a rather tedious film that has taken great liberties with the novel. Were it not for a very sinister Paul Bettany and a consummate pro like Ian McKellen my rating would be lower. However, my biggest complaint is Howard's attempt to have it both ways when it comes to the central issue of whether or not Jesus is(was) mortal or divine. That historical dilemma was addressed, as the film informed, at the Council of Nicea. Howard, unlike those who attended that council, cannot decide which side he is on. Perhaps, he was too worried about selling tickets in the Bible Belt. In summation, a few worthy performances but they are overshadowed by a lack of directorial conviction. My caveat, don't pay full price, go to a matinée.

title: This movie is not so bad !
review:
I really think this movie is not that bad, the acting from the actors was excellent. I also thought it would be better if someone else played Robert Langdon, but Tom Hanks does it not so bad. Tatou, who plays Sophie is very good, as is Ian McKellen. I hadn't read the book, I first played the game of the movie, and it follows the book instead of the movie, it's a really good game.

So when I went to see the movie, I saw it as a Video-Game Movie( :-) ) and if you have that in mind the movie is even better. I really liked how they solved the puzzles in the movie, that was easier in the game, but in the movie they did that really well. And I don't understand why people are so upset by this movie, it was first a book, which also got bad reviews and complaints, but was sold over 30 million copies world wide. But when they make a movie of it, then more people have complaints, why all the fuss ? I know it's not respectful for people who are believers, but who says the movie is based on Facts ? Over 90 percent of the movies are not based on facts. If you don't like it, don't see it, but don't boycott the movie in Countries because most of the people don't like it, there is something called free opinion. But enough about this, back to the movie: The actors were great, The music from Hans Zimmer was excellent (as Ussual ;-) Thnx TriTri). I almost forgot, the two best actors of the movie were : Paul Bettany, I really needed to look twice to see it was him, and Jürgen Prochnow was also very good in this movie.

At the end, this is a very entertaining movie, and i've seen worse movies this year, so this movie isn't in my bottom top 10 for this year. So Watch this movie, you won't regret it !

title: just fine
review: The movie is just fine. It has a well- suited cast and awesome cinematography. Compared to the book though it is rather harmless, as in Tom Hanks' character's reverting back to faith in the second to last scene where the general message is it's important to have faith, no matter what in, be it in Jesus, in a woman, in anything divine or be it Buddhism. That rounds up the story in a nice way and especially in a peaceful way. Maybe that's Sony's compromise to soothe the upset fundamentalist crowds. Therefore the book was way more critical of the whole church/ Catholic apparatus. The movie's good and entertaining and as I said harmless and certainly no one who considers themselves devout has lost his faith over it!!! After all I didn't go hide in a bunker because of Independence Day!!!! To all fundamentalists: shame on you! Why didn't you even blink over movies such as The Hills have Eyes or Hostel, where the premise is just how fun it is to torture/ rape humans!!! Why didn't you go bomb the producers of those evil movies? You are such bigots! That is why I as a Christian have totally lost respect of you bigots and your man- made religion. No devout Catholic has ever gone to protest a porn movie or a brainless Schwarzenegger brutalo movie. THAT is where you should go and protest. The Da Vinci Code- mainly the book- is right, Catholicism is a sect made of men for men and for repressing of anything that these brainless dicks can't deal with: women, homosexuals, abortion, human rights, animal rights, .... you name it.

title: Wanted to read the book, never got to, now I want to even more.
review: This is hands down one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. People complain about it's length, but I must say that this is the fastest two and a half hours I've ever seen in my life. Hanks, Tautou, McKellan, Molina, Bettany, and Reno all turn in outstanding performances that are most definitely going to warrant nods somewhere. Howard's portrayal of each character made me wish that I had read the book, sheerly for the thrill of the ride. I could feel Hanks' fear of enclosed spaces. I felt the pain Tautou felt when telling her past with grandfather. The pain of her memories of the car accident that took her famalies' lives. I followed Langdon as he figured out the riddles, trying to figure them out myself. I guessed while trying to figure out the heir. The teacher's identity was a mystery until he was truly revealed. This movie was nothing short of spectacular, and I urge anyone to see it.

title: An insult to a great novel
review: This was the first time I had been to a movie where I had read the book first. It has proved to me the power of the written word. In fairness, there is no way the director could have fully captured the atmosphere of the book. The book was exceptional because of the detail and dedication to building up key moments in the plot. The movie although not dire, was a disappointment, compounded I am sure by the expectation from having read the novel. Hanks as Langdon was just a ridiculous choice. Having Hanks draws your attention to him rather than his character. His role should have been played by an unknown. The actor playing Sophie was better- more realistically fit the role. The rest of the cast was OK. The director although largely sticking to the plot, did not capture the drama and intensity of the novel. So many key moments were quickly skipped over. Some absolutely bizarre changes to the story were also made. To please fans of the novel, the filmmakers really needed to do a better job with details, and needed to generate the tension and anticipation of the book. Advised my friends to not waste their time with the movie, and instead read the book.

title: Prob. OK if you didn't read the book
review: I finished the Da Vinci Code the day before I headed to theaters. Maybe this is the reason I was able to pick up on so many of the changes they made in the movie. Now I understand why movie adaptations cut certain things, and add others for more drama, suspense, or romance. However the book had all of those and the movie cut a lot of it to add scenes that didn't even come close to matching up. Sophie and Langdon's characters are dumbed down, not really knowing how to figure anything out on their own, relying on Teabing for just about everything. I knew the movie wouldn't be as good as the book, but the entire main story line of the book is changed. Sophie's grandmother and brother weren't supposed to be alive. The entire Priory show up at the end, they never say Sophie's brother is alive....... basically they took the biggest twist of all, that made for a great ending, and omitted it from the movie. I didn't think the acting was that wonderful, and barely noticed the directing. I almost wish they had gone with the R rating so they could show Sauniere's reason for splitting with Sophie and Silas could have been more evil.

title: Film of the year
review: ladies and gentlemen, I am at awe at how great this movie and book are. they did a great job on capturing the books essence. and i just have to say, I totally think that this whole "Jesus was married" "Mary Magdalen was the holy grail" etc. I personally think it's very possibly true. I have studied this theory for years and I have found much scientific evidence to support it. But when I talk to Christians who disagree all they have to say is "Well the bible is all the proof I need" NO THAT DOESN'T COUNT! I have scientific proof to back up this theory you can't just say that and expect me to join your side. GIVE ME ACTUAL SCIENTIFIC PROOF THAT THIS THEORY IS FALSE! then i might actually listen to you.

title: Great movie-true enough to the book
review:
As an avid reader of all things fiction and mystery, I'm no stranger to Dan Brown's works and have found them all to be very exciting, realistic, and have page-turning plots. The DaVinci Code (the 2nd book covering the exploits of Robert Langdon) was by most readers, the worse of the two by a narrow margin. Angels and Demons got better reviews overall. DaVinci Code was chosen for a movie though, because it translated better into movie format, and discussed topics that were both well known (Christ, The Church, Mary Magdalene, etc) as well as inflammatory in nature. Overall, the translation from book to movie was as good as it can be. There are simply too many facts and details presented in literature to cram it into 2.5 hours of acting, no matter how talented a screenwriter is. But DaVinci stays true to the key plot points presented in the book, provides enough key information without losing the thriller/dramatic style to keep the audience interested.

I get really fed up with reviews based on the subject matter of the movie rather than it's artistic merit. All I can say is you knew the storyline before you saw the movie, that's no excuse to bad mouth it later. Whether or not you believe that the Priory of Sion exists or not, the Knights Templar are hiding something that momentous or not, it makes no difference. This is, and has always been, a work of fiction created by one man, and designed to spark intelligent conversation about the life of Christ. Take it as it was meant to be taken, and you will enjoy this movie.

title: great but parts of weirdness
review:
i found the film absolutely brilliant, it was a great film, little different from the book but none the less great. the whole movie kept me at suspense(almost) whilst keeping me thinking, on thing did confuse me a tiny bit, the monk Silas, he tortures himself right because he is the flatulent monk, and he is also religious to extinct, then why is he going around killing people, its going against all the boundaries of what religion stand for, its like telling a 4 year old child to grab a fag and saying light up....

either way it was a brilliant film, worth seeing again, i want to watch it again...

title: So-so...
review: When I began reading the DaVinci Code, I thought to myself, "Hmmm... This could possibly be a great movie!" As I read further into the book, I began to change my mind. There is too much information based on historical speculation contained in the book to accurately translate Dan Brown's writing into a visual medium. I would not say, however, that this is an awful movie. It's just "okay." A good job was done on making visual cues in the book become real on film, such as Landon's deciphering of clues given to him by the murdered professor. But as I stated previously, there is just simply too much information! The movie would have been even more unbearably long than it already was. While the visuals in this movie were excellent, I would have to say the story was far from action-packed. The difference between suspense in print and suspense in the movies is a gap wider than an ocean. What works well in text rarely works well in film! That was definitely the case in this movie. While reading the book, the reader is often caught up in the page-turning suspense... what's coming next, what is the next clue, etc. But in a movie, the action has to be much more tightly laced in order to keep the viewers attention. Such was not the case in the DaVinci Code. Momentary spurts of action are interrupted by lulls which are then interrupted by mediocre action scenes. This movie is not one I would encourage someone to spend 9 bucks on to see in the theatre. Rent it when it comes out - trust me, you can wait.

title: Excellent movie! Just put beliefs aside for the duration, and simply enjoy!
review:
The Da Vinci Code is, in my humble opinion, a very good movie. Admittadly, like all movies, the book is a hundred times better, but it was a good, faithful adaption (unlike The Lost World by Crichton - give me the book any day!).

Many people seem to feel threatened by the film - many Indian countries, and now China, have banned the film. Certainly, the storyline is controversial, and bound to upset people who are staunchly against this kind of idea. However, to quote Dan Brown himself, "It's fictional - it's called a novel"(!). The Da Vinci Code is a fictional book - it is not trying to put forward the idea of Mary Magdalene as true or false, but simply, as other novels, providing an entertaining read - and by the same lines, the film also does not attempt to prove/disprove it, simply trying to entertain us.

Once you have put all previous beliefs aside, and accepted that what you are about to see is fictional entertainment, then the Da Vinci Code is a very good film. Silas and Teabing spring to mind instantly as exceptionally good actors - McKellen provides a very good character, injecting humour as well as seriousness into the film. By the same token, Bettany plays Silas fantastically - his self-flagellation and attacks are often quite unsettling. The music and cinematography used throughout is very good - one thinks especially of the shot where the viewer only realises that the dark figure standing out of focus is Silas once the camera suddenly focuses on him. The film is very true to the novel; while many parts are condensed or left out, and flashbacks added in different places, I (having read (and loved) the novel first) still found the film immensely enjoyable.

10/10

title: Has it's moments, but not totally rewarding
review:
Is there really anyone who has not read The Da Vinci Code? Dan Brown's behemoth best seller was a definite page-turner, and clearly had the makings for a film. So when it was finally announced, there was obvious skepticism over whether it would work as well as the book did. Casting decisions were brought with heavy criticisms, but the hype machine persevered anyway (if anyone had doubts about that, I am certain they did not last). So despite reading the book and not being overly impressed by it (and seeing the film have key moments practically ruined by the trailer), I still decided to give it a shot.

The curator has been murdered in the Louvre, and the French Police decide that Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks), an American symbologist, is the best man to go to in order to find out why. Of course, when Langdon arrives, he finds out that he is totally over his head, and that his symbology skills will become more than handy. What follows is a totally political story, which questions our faith in the knowledge we have, and brings on a whole flurry of new questions for us.

Brown's page-turner was fast-paced, and practically flies right through its four hundred plus pages. But as any film fan should know, a good book does not always make for a good film. Ron Howard's film attempts to fly through its one hundred fifty minute runtime, but hits the roadblock of the immense historical elements of the book, and just slows down entirely about halfway through the film. And as it tries to recover, you realize that it just does not have the same charm as the book did. The book had flashbacks, it had motivations, it had emotions, it had everything you could expect from a good writer. It was practically written like a screenplay. So then, why did Akiva Goldsman find the influence to cut those things out, and allow the film to only make total sense to the book readers (while changing other things around, taking things out and adding in comic relief)? It totally takes away from the overall impact that the book had, and the film suffers as a result. When the interesting parts come, they just do not have the same thrill, or just come off as totally uninteresting.

Howard does make a valiant attempt at staying true to the book though, even with the changes. The editing in of Langdon's puzzle solving work helps the audience better understand his thinking, and the footage used to show off the historical events is pretty well done as well (except for when they try to seamlessly edit it over the modern day, with Hanks and Audrey Tautou walking through it). But while that may work sparingly, the entirety of the soundtrack quite simply, does not. The songs seem out of sync, as if someone edited them into the film at the wrong frames. The volume loudens at the wrong moments, and goes quiet at the even more wrong moments. It seems totally misplaced throughout the film, and lessens the film even more so.

Hanks was the wrong choice from the start, and he shows it with his lackluster performance. It is nowhere near as good as the majority of his work, and he just does not seem to be enjoying himself. Tautou, the female lead, does not fare much better, but at least she puts some work into her performance. Unfortunately, like in the book, these two characters are the most seen, so excellent supporting character work from Jean Reno, Alfred Molina and Paul Bettany falls to the wayside. In fact, Bettany's role as Silas is the most underrated here, because he has nowhere near as much to work with as he would have if his character was adapted a whole lot better. On the other hand, Ian McKellan is fabulous in his role, and shows up anyone he's on-screen with at all times. The passion he has in this role almost makes me want to forgive Howard for even bothering to give Hanks a shot at this.

The film has it's moments, but is ultimately unrewarding to book fans. Some things work, but many do not. The film feels rushed, and feels like it needed much more time to be developed. Brown's book was not disappearing off the best seller list, so why the need to rush out the movie? With time, and a few choice changes, this film could have met the same raving success that the Lord of the Rings and Harry Potter films met. But unfortunately, it falls short of any expectations. Even without reading the book, you may find some enjoyment out of it. Just don't expect it to feel totally complete.

7/10.

title: a handful of sorrows
review: My first sorry is for the mess up that spoilt a good book. Secondly I felt sorry for Paul Bettany -- will there ever be other roles for him after this because he is a reasonable actor. I feel sorry for all the religious freaks who are going to try and start a war over what is a plausible possibility and is but a long shot theory- I mean look how long it took for Newton to come up with his thing. I felt sorry for Leonardo one of the cleverest men ever who has become all tied up in this pipe dream or should I say Pope Dream. My next gripe is the color - everything was so dark and dreary - perhaps black and white would have been better. Ron Howard as you can understand -this is not one of my "happy days"!!

title: pretty good thriller
review:
I had read the book several years back and had forgotten a few things. So this was a pretty good thriller and thought provoking. The mystery does not damage my faith in any way.

The wonderful settings were awesome, and in fact definitely stole some of the scenes.

All of the casting was quite good, except Tom Hanks. I like Hanks a lot in his lighter, comedic roles. He is charming and engaging. He just didn't have the edge needed for this role, and his lines were sometimes wooden. I think someone like Liam Neeson would have played Robert Langdon more effectively. Paul Bettany was fabulous. Audrey is great in everything she does.

title: Much Ado about Nothing: Boring, Silly, and Predictable
review:
I did not read the book, so I expected to have some suspense and excitement in the film. Instead, I found an endless repetition of Keystone Cops police car chases (of course escaping in the nick of time), boring boring lecturing on this that and the other bit of history and background (is this a movie or a lecture?), and downright silly scenes (the Bishop and Silas lying side-by-side like a scene from a grammar school play, or replaying the way they escaped from the private jet, in case we might not have thought that they'd get away). I could hardly keep from laughing at some scenes as I was reminded of the Monty Python skit of "Nobody Expects the Spanish Inquisition". Finally, as far as the great climax to the mystery of the movie, that Sophie was the last descendant of Mary Magdalene was the obvious conclusion about half way through the movie.

As regards the great religious controversy, since it is fiction, the film didn't bother me much except for the scene where Sophie makes fun of Jesus' walking on water, somehow implying that he didn't do it either. The film reiterates that Jesus was divine, having risen from the dead, since they don't seek His grave, which would obviously be of higher importance than Mary Magdalene's grave to believers or detractors.

To sum it up, the film was much ado about nothing (did I mention it was boring?)

title: A waste of Ron Howard talent
review:
This film is, without a doubt, one of the most confusing pieces of garbage it has ever been my dismay to witness.

Because I'm a fan of Tom Hanks, it's not easy for me to say that I just didn't like this film. Through it, there are moments where I thought things like: 'Wait a minute, isn't he supposed to be on their side?' and 'Why is he suddenly pointing a gun at him?'. And the plot line is just ludicrous. So did Jesus engage in sexual activities with Mary Maglidine? However, the film does have a few good bits, such as Hanks's character doing a presentation about symbols. Even though it's crap, I think you should still see it. But don't get me wrong, it does get a bit weird when the bad guy starts whipping himself.

PS: Tom gets a really bad hairstyle.

title: An mildly entertaining (and ordinary) film with high curiosity value !!!!
review:
Well lets be frank I only read the book because of the controversy surrounding it, and only saw the movie because of the curiosity factor and frankly expected no real excitement from this movie.

And I got exactly what I expected.

Even though the book was highly flawed and probably had one of the worst endings in bestseller history it was far superior to the movie (as is the case most of the times).

The main flaws of this movie is the casting of Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon he looked completely out of place in the role (plus I hate to admit it but even I agree with the people when the felt his hairstyle was hideous).

Maybe Reno is not complaining but it saddens me that a actor of his talent is wasted in any movie that has anything to do with France or the french.

Sir Ian was clearly the star of this movie and played the role of the staunch British scholar to the hilt. His one liners also brought the much needed humour into this movie.

However the scene when the three protagonists sit in Sir Ian's mansion and discuss the evidence about the grail which was clearly the most important part of the movie could have been much better. The evidence provided in the book was far more conclusive and here it only looked like a well publicised conspiracy theory which can be summed up in the movies dialogue only (The Eyes See Only What They Want To See). This scene could have also been used to help a lot of the other questions in the movie (such as why did the bank manager attack the duo?).

This movie could have done with at least one more reveal all, or explanatory scene summing up the movies events.

The technically the movie was as good as any but I felt it could have done with some good background score or a theme or something.

The movie offered no excitement a person who has read the book and I'm sure hardly any for one who has not.

Most People who have read the book will not enjoy this movie and those that have not will not understand this movie.

A strictly OK movie which is entertaining and more than anything satisfies your curiosity without leaving you bored (cant say the same about some of the remakes and sequels which have been watched out of curiosity).

Don't expect too much and you wont be disappointed.

title: The Da Vinci Code
review: Almost every review that I've seen of the movie has been a negative one but I thought that the movie was outstanding. I almost didn't go to see the movie because of all the negative reviews but I'm glad that I did. I don't know if critics feel threatened because of the religious aspect of the movie or that the movie follows the book very closely (I don't see what's wrong with that in the first place, most people often complain that the movie is not like the book). Whatever the reason was for the negative reviews I felt like all of the actors did an excellent job and the story was unfolded in the correct "pace", most of the reviews talked about how the timing and pace of the movie were off. I didn't even notice how long the movie was. I also wanted to comment on the religious controversy that the film has sparked. I am a Christian and I went into the theater understanding that the story behind the movie was was just that, a story. I left the theater appreciating how original Dan Brown's story is, not upset. I don't see why people are so narrow minded. Anyway, I felt like the movie was one of the better films that have seen in the last couple of years and look forward to seeing it again.

title: Excellent Adaption of the Book
review:
"The Da Vinci Code" is highly entertaining due to its substance. There have been many negative reviews about its length and tedious pace, but I think that Ron Howard took the right approach when he converted the book to cinema. It's not a Hollywood blockbuster - action-packed, thrilling, or suspenseful as the book ever was. It's smarter than that.

The movie delves deep into a secret that could shake the foundations of the Catholic community, and it emphasizes this aspect of the book more than the pacing. Sure, at times I felt like sleeping, but it was rewarding to see that they really explained the story that has been getting so much controversy lately.

In other words, although the movie was stripped of its excitement, the fundamental part of what made the book intriguing and remarkable remains intact.

The acting won't get any academy awards, but Tom Hanks makes a good Robert Langdon and so does the actress who plays Sophie. Ian McKellen is the perfect Teabing too.

In the end, I wouldn't recommend this movie to anybody who doesn't have the patience to hear about Catholocism (maybe you have to be Catholic to truly appreciate the message?) At any rate, it's that part of the movie - the plot that Dan Brown made so famous - that is the movie's highlight. If you've read the book, I think you'll genuinely enjoy it.

I did. =)

title: Great support acting saves the film-just.
review:
I spent most of this film wondering who would have been better in the role of Robert Langdon other than Tom Hanks. Little doubt the late William Holden for one, amongst many of that era, but in practical terms I kept coming back to Harrison Ford. I thought that Hanks spent his time sleepwalking through the film and there was no chemistry whatsoever between him and his talented leading lady, claimed to be, in a ridiculous ending, the last descendant of Jesus Christ no less. Harrison Ford, along the lines of his excellent interpretation of a very worried husband in the film "Frantic", when his wife was mistakenly kidnapped, ( and also filmed in Paris), would have been far superior to the lacklustre Tom Hanks.

So I say well done to the supporting actors who were basically excellent and literally rescued this film, notably Paul Bettany who was very scary, Sir Ian McKellen of course and the talented Alfred Molina as Bishop Aringarosa. But my personal favourite was Jean Reno as the French Captain whom I thought was first-rate as a somewhat confused but sinister policeman.
