Therefore despite best efforts from all the actors mentioned, in addition to those with small roles who themselves were very effective, when the leading man is wooden, the whole film inevitably suffers.

The story itself is interesting enough and people can decide for themselves if they accept some of the claims made about the Christian faith. As a regular churchgoer I think that the Roman Catholic Church has over-reacted in its condemnation, as anybody with half a brain could see that it was a film based on a theory, nothing more. In any event the Catholic Church could surely see quite clearly that the Ian McKellen character, who believed it all, was eventually portrayed as half-mad and soon for the funny farm. Indeed by the end Sir Ian was playing it a bit like a pantomime, presumably deliberately. The film was so obviously presented as a piece of fiction. interesting but hardly conclusive. People are intelligent enough to work that out for themselves without the Church telling them what to believe. Anyway there were only 7 people for the Catholic Church to worry about in the cinema where I saw the film!!!

I have not followed the career of Tom Hanks so presumably he is a very talented film star. This performance must have been just a one-off or else he would not have gone so far in his career. But I thought he did not come up to expectations here and was barely adequate. As such a potentially very good film was, for me,just satisfactory, thanks to the other performers and some decent location scenes in France. A chance missed I am afraid and I would seriously suggest a remake in about 10 years time.

Michael Dixon,Sunderland, England.

title: For Religious Nutcases Only.
review:
Why is Tom Hanks always playing the good guy? Love to see him in a nasty role for once.

The movie itself has so much religion and philosophy mixed in, it's easy to start losing interest. Unless you are deeply into religion, then it might be okay. Far too much, hushed conversations behind closed doors, robed figures, religious principles and ideology just rolling off the tongue, most of which the average Joe would have no idea about, or be able to visualise. Confusing, boring in places, and too much specialised knowledge needed to understand what on earth this movie is trying to say. Probably will be a hit at the box office, but only because of the names involved, rather than any serious entertainment value, or interest. Divine intervention needed to save this one.

title: Beating around the ol' proverbial bush
review: Well, I finally went and watched this film just to see what all the fuss was about in the media. As a Christian, I figured that this must be some mind-blowing doctrinal thing, but it turned out that it was just something that the Mormon doctrine has been saying for years ... that Christ was married and had offspring. If this movie wins any big awards, it will have to be for the controversy it stirred up, much like "Brokeback Mountain" did last year, and not because of the film's concept. Overall though, I enjoyed the film as it made for a good story. It seemed that it took them forever to just get to the point in some places, but the action scenes were put in at just the right times to keep you interested in the film. I hadn't read the book, but it was pretty easy to figure out that Ian McKellan's character was The Teacher and that Sophie was supposed to be offspring of Jesus and Mary Magdalene. I assumed this halfway through the film, but I sat there for the last hour anyway. Ron Howard pulled off a good show despite what critics with their personal religious agendas may be saying. But I was a little disappointed with Tom Hanks' performance. Tom is such a great actor and one of my all-time favorites. But in this film, he seemed a little wooden in areas. Certainly not "Forrest Gump" or "Saving Private Ryan" material. When he was in the museum, it seemed that, at some points, he was simply reading off of the cue cards with very little emotion. But to take back an earlier point I made, I think that this film is worthy of one Oscar nod, and that would be the nominating of Ian McKellan for Best Supporting Actor. He is always entertaining, and he fit his role in this film very well. He was the bright spot of the film and did not disappoint.

title: Really DID want to like it :-(
review: ...and I was disappointed. Mostly by the dialogue. So many times Howard tried to skip about fifty pages of the book by having Hanks (or sometimes the woman, what's her name?) do a "documentary read" while background scenes played out. And Hanks' voice was just wooden during those times. Oy. I was so bored. I read the book long enough ago that my memory has dimmed, but is everything at night? I was about ready to fall asleep with all the darkness. Tedious and interminable. And I REALLY wanted to like it!! (I was also disappointed that there wasn't a picket line to walk through. Where are the right-wing-nut zealots when you want them?)

title: below average movie
review:
There has been a lot of talk about this movie recently, so I have decided to watch it myself. I must admit that I'm disappointed. I did not read the book, so I don't know if the director was forced to display so many absurd situations by the original story, or it was his own idea.

The story begin when mortally shot man wrote riddles and anagrams on the paintings and floor of the museum. Commissar investigating the case is bringing his main suspect into this site instead of arresting him (and he will delete the main evidence from the floor before). Then the suspect will miraculously escape. Escapes in this movie are really funny. Like when the man with the gun was attacked by pigeon inside the cathedral, or escape in the backseat of the car from the hangar surrounded by police. Story is quite boring and linear. The basic idea of creating the chain of riddles all around the Europe to acquire the password for the casket is unrealistic.

Acting was fairly good. Except for Audrey Tautou, who seemed little affected in some scenes. Surely this was not the best performance of Tom Hanks and Jean Reno, but it was acceptable.

I cannot remember of any music from the movie. I guess there was some, but it was very fading and forgettable. It is a pity, because for mystery movies, the music is quite important to emphasize the atmosphere.

The movie is quite controversial, and I think it is the only reason for its popularity. It is also the only reason to watch this movie. If all religious contents will be erased and replaced by something similar, but not so controversial, this would be below average movie.

title: It's a turkey.
review: Let me get right to the point. This movie is pretentious, poorly acted, and attempts to convey a muddled message on a complicated subject that is meant for serious scholarly consideration and not to be grist for another half-baked Hollywood potboiler. The movie attempts to use a theological controversy as the basis for a convoluted "who-done-it" story and in the process makes assertions that even for a work of fiction demands credible evidence. Now the producers of this movie have the absolute right to make a movie with a theological content, but along with that right comes the responsibility of providing hard evidence to back up the movie's fantastic and completely speculative assertions. Further, the characters in this movie are so utterly superficial, uninspiring, uninteresting and comic-bookish that it seemed that even the actors themselves knew that this movie is one big turkey. Indeed, this could be the worst movie in Tom Hanks's otherwise brilliant career. Indeed, perhaps the main character of the movie should have been Inspector Clouseau.

title: As good as the book
review:
I'm a very big fan of both books and movies, and i have read all of Dan Brown's novels. The movie is a great adaptation of the book, that's exactly how you picture the da vinci code would be. But also as the book, it is not such a great thing, it has some very strong images in it and a great cast starring Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou, Ian McKellen and other great actors, but it offers nothing new. If you've read the book you'll find the movie even more commercial, never in the book Robert Langdon finds out Sophie Neveu is in the line of the blood of Christ, and it never assures that the holy grail is in fact the tomb of Mary Magdalene, but adding those things to the movie is just a way to make the movie more controversial, cause all Ron Howard cares is to make as much money as possible.

I'll say it is a very entertaining movie for those who haven't read the book yet, but if I would have to see a blockbuster popcorn movie (because that's what it is) i'd pick a better one like the amazing X3.

title: A Great Book Ruined-A Great Movie-NOT
review: There is credit here for Mr. Howard's lack of artistic talent in directing what could have been a GREAT movie. Instead, and in my opinion, the movie lacked depth, character building, was miss-cast, left out major components of the book and overall lacked artistic integerity! The reputation of Mr. Howard is clearly tainted by this spoiled attempt to make a 'passable' film rather than a great motion picture. The central characters of Sophie and Langdon totally lacked strong aggressive direction and the writing lost the true feel that the book gave you. The BOOK was a page turner, the movie was a so-so action drama that just did not do the job! I should have waited for the DVD!

title: About as mediocre as they say
review:
I have said it before and I have to say it again: "True-to-the-book-Adaptations" kill potentially good films. Why filmmakers, or film goers for that matter, has not seen the genius of Stanley Kubrick's THE SHINING when it comes to adapting a book, is strange. Why hasn't film yet tried to break free from it's artistically inferior position and stopped slaving behind The Novel. Film is a visual medium. The Novel is, most of the time, not. THE DA VINCI CODE is another example of a bad film that had every potential to be good.

Of course, I couldn't read the book. I found it to be a case of ridiculously poor writing with silly cliffhangers at the end of literary every chapter. I threw it away after four chapters with a feeling of being humiliated as a reader. I had, to say the least, low expectations of the film. Then again, a good opportunity to be open minded.

But the film *was* bad. The main reason is the bad craftsmanship, something that I was truly surprised about. I figured Ron Howard was competent enough to make a Hollywood thriller (RANSOM is underrated) but here we have a Tom Hanks for five minutes, suddenly accused for murder, then an Audrey Tatou hops on the bandwagon - everybody is acting very excited; but the excitement has not been built up, nor has the characters. The result: I don't care about them or their situation. I don't even buy it. And then follows 2.5 hours of not caring or buying, in a plot that constantly is fairly predictable and filled with used tricks. Some defenders have called this a "thinking man's movie". How difficult is it to follow a film that is explanatory beyond the ridiculous; - Unless the letters aren't in it's right place... - An ANAGRAM! - An anagram! Come on...

And then of course, the whole "respect for the book"-idea kills off the film even more. The film is EXTREMELY talky and UNBEARABLY long. That could be good book material. Can we all agree that it is not good film material? Where is the suspense? Where is the excitement? Nowhere of course, since the filmmakers have been too busy reading the book to be thinking of making a good film. This could have been a tight, sweaty two hour cat-and-mouse-film. It could have been anything. It's a filmed book, with the book's "fill the characters up with your imagination"-characters, filler sequences that give coherence to the novel's story (but is dragging the FILM along) and it's "take your time"-ending. This film never ends. It goes on forever, until every drop of the mystery is solved. The mystery that we figured out all about 2 hours ago.

title: Not up to the mark
review:
Arguably the most-awaited film of this year clearly fell short of my expectations. With the book compiled so pain-stakingly in every detail, the movie is clumsy and good only in patches. To top it all, there are some goof-ups too. Although the main essence of the plot has been captured at large, the finer details which make the story so fabulous are missing. I could very well sense that the movie would be a tough one to digest for a person who has never read the best-seller. Lastly, the movie has been condemned for the controversies it has kicked off. In hindsight, there is nothing repulsive shown in this movie and don't know why there is such a fuss.

ACTING : Ian Mckellen, as always, is a class of his own as Sir Leigh Teabing. He pumps in the requisite energy for that role. Tom Hanks, with all due respect, is merely acceptable at best and fails to capture the magnitude of Langdon's character. Audrey Tautou, as Sophie Neveu, is unfortunately pathetic. Her heavy French accent is a pain to the ears and her childish looks somehow fail to mingle with the film's setup - a clear case of character mismatch. Full kudos to Ron Howard for excellent portrayal of the albino- Silas.

Watch the film without keeping high expectations, for u r likely to be disappointed.

title: neither entertaining nor enlightening
review: This movie, intentionally anti-catholic, gets unintentionally to be an Opus Dei propaganda for the unrealistic way it describes that organization. Unaware propaganda aside, the script is clear, everything is spelt twice or even three times, so that the story can be figured out even if you haven't read the book. Should I use a metaphor for describing the film on the whole I would say Ron Howard wasn't able to keep the rhythm high as soon as he pulled the foot off the gas. I mean that most of the flick (actually the entire flick apart from the action scenes) has a enormous problem with its pace and, in spite of the intriguing plot and the good acting, it never succeeds in keeping the audience restless.

title: Like a walk through a museum Davinci Code is nice to look at but long and at times boring!
review: Davinci Code Director Ron Howard has put his sights on another blockbuster, but I think he missed the mark. I read the Davinci Code by Brown and was expecting the cast of characters and this production team to blow me away. Maybe it was the fact that I enjoyed the book so much, or could it have been the anticipation since they've been advertising this flick for a year now. I just felt that the film was cautious, they didn't take any risks. They brought the film to life but didn't go much further than that, and I guess what more do you want? Over all I wasn't impressed with Hanks interpretation of Langdon, I felt that he was too coy, and not rehearsed enough to really be into the mind of langdon, there were too many limpy scenes for him. All the different let downs made this a nice film that was average, but a huge disappointment because it should have set the standard for the summers blockbuster lineup. In the end, much like a trip to the museum the Davinci Code is nice to look at but long and at times boring! I give the Davinci Code 7-10 What it's like- James Bond not shaken or stirred! You will enjoy it if- You have not read the book! I suggest you read the book after you see the film!

title: They had a chance to re-inspire people, but failed utterly
review:
was a well done film with good acting and direction. But if you are expecting to be inspired as you were when reading the book, you will be disappointed.

Like the Harry Potter books, the book 'Da Vinci Code' caught the public's imagination and drew us into a wonderful world of ancient intrigue via the paintings of Da Vinci and the various organizations depicted like the Knights Templar, Opus Dei, etc. as well as opening up for public discourse some questions about the role of the sacred feminine. The hunt took us to exciting places full of rich history and tremendous architecture. It inspired people hugely in many different ways.

The film focused on none of the elements from the book that made it so unique. Rather, it pulled out incidents of violence and highlighted them, beginning with gratuitous scenes of flagellation, taking us far too often into the murky madness of Silas, and bombarding us with a cops and robbers fugitive hunt that offered absolutely nothing new for the viewer.

It was uninspiring. Compared to the book, it was insipid.

Whereas the Harry Potter films succeeded completely in bringing the books alive on the screen so that viewers were transported visually into the same wonderful ambiance created in the books (except for the one stupid bus scene), the movie Da Vinci missed the point entirely.

With Ron Howard as the producer, I don't know how this could have happened. I was gratified when I knew he was going to be in charge of the film. Did none of the people involved with this project have any idea of what they were dealing with? What a disappointment.

If you forget the book and just expect another Hollywood shoot 'em up assembly line hit, then you won't be disappointed.

title: Provoking movie to the Christianity but mind opener
review:
This deeply saddened me and many Christians here in the Philippines when the movie was banned in our country after the first time it was released. It was questioned by our mtrcb (our movie regulatory board) with its content that provokes the mind of the Christians to question their faith after seeing it. With so many religious battle and debate, finally they released the movie with many scenes were already delete, which I believe were very much essential to the movie and understanding of the Christian history I believe that being a Christian needs a person to be deeply rooted to His faith but In my opinion, history is made by man and altered through time so not all things written in the bible were exactly the same as what really happened in the past.

Probably one thing that a person needs put in mind is to have faith in His God and not to question things that are speculative and unanswerable. People are only human to commit mistakes, and Jesus Christ himself was born human, given to us by the God the Father to save us to our sins but it doesn't mean that he is perfect.

title: Watchable
review: The film is like watching one of those text based PC adventure games from the 80's. I can see it now: "You are Robert Langdon accused of murder; the French Police are trying to catch you; you must solve the riddles and find the real culprit, while discovering the real bloodline from Jesus that could shake the whole catholic church before your energy runs out". The protagonist, who is lecturing to students at the start of the film, in an Indiana Jones type manner, is called upon by the French Police to help solve a strange murder. There then follows two and hour hours of puzzle solving and distracting flashbacks. The film, despite it s subject matter, is watchable but suffers from being overly long. In fact, the best use of time, is the telling of silas' past in 30 seconds - just like a Tony Scott TV commerical. The Lead role isn't really demanding for Tom Hanks who puts in a delivery that wouldn't be out of place in the 'Keanu Reeves' school of acting. Audrey Tautou seems miscast in the role. You may as well have put in Rachel Weiz (more fun then!). The only reasons worth seeing the film is for Ian McKellen who really steals the show. Paul Bettany proves he can play a nasty villain, too. There is a twist at the end, if you stay awake that long.

title: "Turgid" comes to mind
review: Slow, boring, incomprehensible, silly in its premise, and no movement at all. By half-way through (about 5 hours), I no longer cared for any single character or plot trait. What a waste of time. Absolutely no character development, an incomprehensible plot, duologue which was stilted and unintelligible to a large part, and filmatography through a mud puddle. What's there to like? Locations in France? I did not at all enjoy the book, finding the ridiculous plot twist at the end of each chapter to be tiring. Naturally, I viewed the movie in a similar vein. But the movie was visually unappealing, slow in every aspect, and made no real sense. Sophie is the only, last, direct descendant of Christ? In 2000 years, the family tree comes down to one person? That can't be. It would have branched hundreds of times. So, the main plot twist is a virtual impossibility.

title: Disappointing to say the least.
review:
I have not read Dan Brown's book on which this movie was based. His book has become a huge bestseller and has created a lot of fuss and interest, almost to the point of hysteria. After seeing this very disappointing movie, I just can't see why.

Ron Howard is an excellent director, but he was totally the wrong choice for this movie. I am thinking what someone like Roman Polanski on song would have done which would have been to create an intriguing atmosphere fulled with suspense, unease, darkness with the necessary compelling complexity. This movie is difficult to follow (perhaps I should read the book but why should I to follow a movie??, boring to the point that I fell asleep watching it, in a few places, extremely badly lit( the whole movie was set in the dark which added absolutely nothing to the story or supposedly what was meant to be a foreboding atmosphere). The performances are totally lacking with everyone seemingly just going through the motions. The conclusion offers nothing startling and I feel right now - so what is all the fuss???As for the direction- it creates a poorly paced, stodgy film lacking in any intrigue and does not make me feel compelled to carry on watching, while now and then nodding off. I actually feel I am being generous giving this one a 4. Ron Howard you have done much better in the past and no doubt will again. Perhaps you were began with a poor script. You always see to work with Akiva Goldsman. Why not someone else for a change? This movie is at the end of the day a wasted opportunity.

title: The Sole Reason To See This Movie...
review: The movie's good overall. Tom Hanks is about average. Ron Howard did a decent job directing. But the one reason I'll recommend this film to absolutely anybody. The one reason I would go see it again. The one reason I will own the DVD when it comes out is this: Sir Ian F'ing McKellen. Ian McKellen is always brilliant. He's a terrific actor, hands down. However, in this movie, with this role, he has elevated himself to a new degree of scrumtralescence. I wish he had just slightly more screen time, but he is a principle character throughout most of the film, and whenever he's on screen, it's an absolute treat. Go see Ian McKellen. Go Now.

title: An overview about what people can do in order to achieve their own interests an beliefs
review: A best seller thriller book, with his own writer as an executive producer,and closely checking the scripts, i suppose. A widely known and Oscar winner director, and at least three actors that are iconic in their home countries. One could imagine one of those films made for history, those which make us go into theaters, at least a couple or three times in order to taste them well and capture all those little issues that made us fall in love with them. Unfortunately a story, which starts with a large background built on controversy, often causes great expectations, not reached in this time. From the technical issues, it's a good work. The sound, the music, the set design were excellent choices and properly developed. A great advertising campaign (of course deserved) for Paris, and it's iconic Louvre. It's a shame that a well-known director, who is recognized for excellent works in actor direction,as those made on A Beautiful Mind, do not exploit also well-recognized acting talents such as Tom Hanks, Jean Reno and even Audrey Tatou. Only remarkable, Sir Ian McKellen, as usual, and Paul Bettany who always achieves his potential in a very, very theatrical but credible way. Also the story is not enough developed, and a book which could became a masterpiece of thrillers, only reaches the level for keeping someone amused for two hours and a half. Very little to talk about after the film. It looks like it was made only for profits and as it has became a big box office hit, i bet they are already planning a film for Angels and Demons. Wish them better luck for the next, not for their pockets as for their artistic conscience

title: fantastic
review: i think the book and the film are fabulous, fascinating and absorbing, a great riveting read i loved it, i can see why its a bestseller i just think Silas was misunderstood ha and didn't deserve to die, don't take the book too seriously because i have a friend who hates it because of what it says about Jesus and what not but don't take it to heart ha, its a great mystery and so shocking ha i preferred the book though because it takes you into much more detail of the mystery and the characters and the background of everything you become close to the characters and its sad to see them go i cried when Silas died bless he was being used and controlled by the bishop who was being used and controlled by the teacher ha he didn't deserve to die he was only doing the dirty work so the bishop didn't get in trouble ha

title: Dull, dull, dull.
review:
For me this film was the equivalent to a visual dose of Vallium, it almost put me to sleep. You know a movie is bad when you keep looking at your watch. Indeed, this is one of those films.

One would think the novel is a perfect candidate for a summer blockbuster with its mix of religious controversy, conspiracy theories and romantic European settings but something got very lost in translation to the big screen. And coming from Ron Howard, of all people, that this film is such a big failure is somewhat puzzling.

I think one of the biggest errors came down to the casting of Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon. He simply is not believable in this role and appears to be merely sleep walking his way through it. His acting seems to set the tone for the entire movie - droll and lifeless. Audrey Tatou's beauty, Ian McKellen's fine acting and Paul Bettany's albino menace are just not enough to overcome this tone that permeates the final product.

Not all is bad. There is some very nice cinematography to be seen; the Louvre, Paris, the cathedrals all look stunning. I also thought the ending scene, Tom Hank's visit to the Louvre was wonderfully done and it really was the only time during the entire move that I actually felt something and was, dare I say it, moved.

One star for the cinematography, and one each for Tatou, McKellen and Bettany.

In the end, nothing I say will change anybody's mind from seeing this film! Having read the book you will feel absolutely compelled to see it (as I was) - just don't set your expectations very high at all. It may also be that those who haven't yet read the book are going to find much more enjoyment in the film, as was the case with my friend. Lucky them.

title: dull at best
review: Having read the book, I had expectations of the movie. But after seeing it, I was utterly disappointed... Solving the puzzles was so lame, based on such unknown logic, that I was surprised; they are drawing conclusions out of nowhere, as if it is expected of the audience to have read the book in advance so that they can fill the gaps in the movie (lots of them, by the way) automatically. Many details in the book are simply omitted, perhaps in light of simplifying the movie for widest audience, but in doing so, the intricacies have also been lost. The role of Robert Langdon could have been cast better. Usually I like Ian McKellen's roles, but here he was also a bit "off center", as if he is pretending to be acting; it looks that the for the most part the script writer did not know what to do and how to capture the audience, to really pull them in, to let them feel the excitement of discovering the solution to the puzzles. Audrey Tautou is a good cast, however her character is also undeveloped. One good thing is the music score. It appropriately accompanies the events, and sounds good, mounting expectation. Hans Zimmer did a good job. The book is a good and gripping fiction novel, but the film is a waste of time and talent.

title: disappointing!
review:
To all the readers of Dan Brown novel, I advise you not to watch this movie... the story seemed to be fast-pace, it would not even enliven you like what you felt in the book We have a better imagination than the makers of the movie Robert Langdon isn't that old in the book! It would've been better if they've chosen some other actor that really fits Langdon's features, and Sophie is not that good enough in acting, which contributed to the movie's unpleasantness; her acting affected of "how" some scenes supposed to be they've had even changed some vistas which frustrate the people's envision...some parts won't even stir up your feelings...

It doesn't worth your time!!! You would rather read the novel over and over again than to watch it! People expected so much of it, anticipated for it to be as great or greater than the book and yet, they just dissatisfied them.

title: Not since The Brothers Grimm have I come this close to falling asleep during a movie.
review:
All of my theological issues aside, The Da Vinci Code was boring and anticlimactic. It was reliant entirely on mediocre music and unoriginal "suspense" filming techniques to maintain interest (which it failed in doing). The movie seemed much longer than its two hours and fifty minutes.

Tom Hanks did poorly in comparison to his other films, and Ron Howard's directing didn't match the standards of his other movies (like A Beautiful Mind and Cinderella Man).

I won't talk about the plot because, really, there wasn't one. It could've been done just as well with a power-point presentation. At least National Treasure was mildly exciting. Not even a crazy monk could save this one.

Absolutely abysmal.

title: He is not god
review:
I loved the book and i loved the movie only who has week faith will get effect, but i believed for long time ago he is a prophet he is not god he is human and i love him and he will save us but still he is not god and not even a son of god. any way its up to us to believe or not but really if we look so deep we can see that the god no need for a son he needed for massangers and prophets to pass the massage to people this what i believe thats all we r all free but am free to till what i believe My friend he is Muslim and he showed me in quran the Muslim book they say the same the god have no son and Jesus he is a prophet like others and he is human come on open your eays find the truth any way one day we all will see the truth

but there is some details in the book didn't appear in movie any why tom hanks was great as usual reno he is cool Ian mckellen he is amazing but the best is Poul Bttany (sellas) .

In the end Ron Howerd Thanks for the vary nice movie .

Dan brown keep rocking.

title: Worth watching for all those, who have read the book, mystery for who have not..positive side: people will be curious to know about it and read a good piece of work!!
review:
The terms, like the secret society, holy grail, Sangreal, Rose Line are easy to comprehend for the people who have gone through the book. At least, one has the satisfaction that, all your life you have underestimated your visualization power!! Because for all that you had imagined while reading the book, are on screen. But what is the explanation for those, who have not read the book? What if there was no literary work? It seems, the film is made for people, who are more than casual audience.

The high points of the movie is its direction, cinematography and use of music.Paul Bettany and Ian Mckellen did complete justice to their respective characters of Silas and Sir Leigh Teabing.Robert Langdon played by Tom Hanks did his bit but more than that, he has something called 'reputation'which played its part. But there is one person in the film who was very consistent and was regularly irregular in giving a different expression. She maintained the same look on her face from beginning to end. Introducing Sophie Neveu who is giving new definitions to consistency. But her dialogue delivery and accent came in as her saving grace.

To bring an element of humour in a mystery is not an easy task, but the film has been able to bring what is called situational humour.

The unfolding of the mysteries came in a flash of second. Agreed, it may strike but the acting on the part of Langdon and Sophie while they were on Louvre was very cold.

There is nothing called 'bad publicity' and the controversy created, has been paid well.

title: An honest review
review:
Dear readers,

I wanted to read this book on it's release date, but as most people expected it got sold out very quickly and I missed my chance. I waited about a week for my book store to get it back in, but sadly no! So I just forgot about it, and I continued to read the bible (my faith) and love the world for what it really is, A Holy Place!

I eventually stumbled across The Da Vinci Code book again, it was really cheap, I thought 'why not?' So I went over to the cash register and bought the book for £2. I read it and put it down all most instantly, I was appalled at what it was suggesting! I made myself think for a long while. I read more extracts from the bible, bits that said 'people may have different thoughts, but you choose what to believe' (words not officially accurate, but gets the point.)

So when I read more of the bible and understood that there are people that do try and unfaith religion, I read it. I in honesty found the book really boring, it was an upset in books, I am a fond reader of books and this was truly an insult to books! I said to myself 'a small work of fictional writing!' Of course I didn't believe what the book tried to put across, it's because your not meant to! It's just an interesting book to read, just read it, so be it really.

Then I heard of a film, and i thought 'great, now all the people who can't be bothered to get of there fat arse and read a book, can see it in screen format!' I was appalled. RON HOWARD! I was shocked that he of all people would make a movie like this! Then he put in a fantastic cast, Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou, Ian Mckellon etc. It was a surprise, did they believe what the book tried to tell us, I don't know. But what I do know is the Catholic church didn't believe it, and neither did I!

Now onto the movie itself. Not bad, not great either, to be honest it's pretty average, it's like one of those book adaptations that are not great, but have something good about them. I am a catholic, so as soon as the film came out, I expected to hate it! But not really hating it, liking some of it. It was an interesting tale.

Jesus getting married to Mary Magdalane, her being in the last supper picture.....That is really a man, look how many men there are now, that resemble women, it was the same then, most men grew long hair. Here are some things raised in the film,

  • Not Holy Grail in the picture of The Last Supper - Mary and Jesus fell in love - Phillip, who was he? An ignored book!Mary's Gospel! - Holy Grail = Woman's womb - Sang real in translation from French to English means Royal Blood - Mary pregnant at the time of Jesus's Crucifixion - The baby was born, it was a girl called Sarah - Greatest cover up in human history - Sophie (Audrey Tautou) Grandfather, is the Grandmaster - Secret to be trusted - The Key Stone - Small facts about the Key Stone Legend hides beneath the Rose Inside a map, leads to Holy Grail Trained by Grandmaster, sang riddle songs No something and never say again


  • Only worthy can unlock the Grail - 2000 years, the church has done loads things in the name of God - Jesus was a normal man - The dark can be exposed - The Prioer was meant to expose the holy grail for the new millennium - Explode the truth - A.P.P.L.E


See these things bring interesting points across, but it's all up to you what you believe really, I don't believe much of this, but it certainly does raise a good few points! Here's a little more:

The holy grail has gone home The holy grail in Ancient Roslin The blade and challis as the Pagins wanted She rests beneath the starry sky's Mary Magdalane is the Holy Grail

This is the final outcome of the film, The film explains history doesn't always explain itself. You believe what you want to believe. But also it raises the point, why cant Jesus have been married and had a child, and be the son of God at the same time.

I honestly cant answer that, but I believe if Jesus really did have a child, it's not a cover up, it's just something that hasn't been explained to its best ability, Jesus was always the son of God.

Amen. P.S: If anyone wants to tell me what they feel about this, please email me, shuichi_shindosan@yahoo.co.uk

Thank you.

title: wonderful book!
review: I have to say that the DaVinci Code is a great book. it is exciting, it has all these twists and turns, and it feels as if you are in a movie theater while reading the book, because it is so thrilling. my over all review is a 9/10 because even thought this book is great, no book is perfect, (harry potter came close). Also, even though i have not watched the movie yet, i know it will be great. (im just waiting for it to come out on a super special special edition on DVD.) thanks for reading. since i seem to need more lines to get this little comment thing published on the internet, i would just like to say that the Eragon series is also very good.

title: Bad adaptation, really bad screen writing
review:
This was by far one of the worst screen writing adaptations I have ever encountered. Akiva Goldsman wrote the screenplay. He can claim fame to other scripts such as A Time to Kill, Batman Forever and The Client (among many more you'd now...and many are adaptations of novels. That would inspire some confidence that he'd do a decent job. Ha! If he didn't have such an impressive resume I'd say never let him write again. Okay that might be a bit harsh. The Da Vinci Code was never a book that could be put on screen successfully in a 2 1/2 time span, but I could have written a better screenplay.

Nothing's ever going to follow a book exactly, but this movie takes way too many liberties.

1) Fache: In the book he's stern, but he comes off as a character that you can still care for. He's strong, a bit ruthless, but has a conscious. When I learned that Jean Reno was playing the part of Fache I was excited. I could see him playing the part beautifully...that is if it had been written well. In the movie his character was portrayed as more of a mean-hearted moron than a smart yet determined man.

And what was the point of making Fache a member of Opus Dei. Seriously there are some things that can't follow the book...this was not one of them. They could have easily written the character of Fache to be portrayed as he was in the novel. This would not have been too difficult a stretch.

2) Sophie: This was by and large one of the most annoying aspects of this movie. They portrayed Sophie as a weak and 'dumb' female. In the novel she's a smart, strong, and quick thinking woman who is Langdon's equal. In the movie they barely give her a brain. All throughout. It's not just here and there a random moment or two...it's the entire movie. Bad bad screen writing.

3) Langdon: Just thinking about his lines make me cringe. I've never had to listen to facts delivers more dryly and uninterestingly (is that a word?) than I did here. Make the male strong the female weak? Is that was they were thinking? Langdon was a flat character. You're suppose to like him but he gives you no reason to feel one way or another about him. He was 'blah'. Uninteresting and a bit pompous at times.

4) Casting: Sorry, but they did an awful job of casting. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou had no chemistry. I actually really like Audrey Tautou. I thought she was (even though they wrote her part awfully) the most believable of characters. She took what she had and made the best of it. Tom Hanks...well to me I felt like he rather be else where the entire time. I felt like he had no interest in the history he was supposedly suppose to know. Worst I felt that he didn't understand what he was spouting off and it came off so stilted.

5) Silas: He wasn't too bad, but he wasn't developed enough. In the movie he came off as evil where in the book there was this constant battle within himself. He wasn't 'good' but he wasn't purely 'evil' either. There was no dimension to Silas in the movie.

6) Bishop Aringarosa: Ugh! He suffered the same fate as Silas. He was portrayed purely as evil. No depth given to him. He was very two dimensional.

7) Sophie's Family: Shot me now. By the time we finally made it to the end I thought not much more can be butchered. I was wrong. Her whole history and family background was totally changed and not for the better.

8) Ritual: They show flashes throughout the movie of a memory of Sophie's. It's from a ritual she witnessed her grandfather partaking in. They should have left it out. They never fully explain it and unless you read the book I bet you were wondering what the hell the ritual was and why it affected Sophie in anyway.

9) Sir Leigh Teabing: Overall he annoyed me the least. Not a great character, but portrayed decently enough.

To sum it up: It all started with the screen writing and went downhill from there. Bad screen writing --> the movie was doomed before it started.

PS: I liked DB's book. Well I liked the story telling. The writing isn't great, but he was able to pull you in to the story and that made up for it.

title: Cheesy and unconvincing
review: This is this year's most anticipated movie, with a lot of controversy surrounding it. So I had to see it. I read the book, and didn't think much of it (Angels and Demons being the better one). The movie is even worse. There were several moments I had the urge to walk away. Because of the cheesiness of the movie. Things like: "The letters are scrambled." "It's an anagram!" Tsssss. And it's such a long movie (2 1/2 hour) that goes on and on and on. Halfway the movie, when Langdon and Neveu are at Teabing's place, the answers to so many questions are given. This is where the ideas are laid out that make or break this story. Teabing (Ian McKellen) keeps talking and talking about how Jesus had kids with Mary Magdalen, and how the Church wants to destroy the royal bloodline of Jesus. I will not repeat that here. It's so unconvincing, that it immediately drowns this movie in its own nonsense. At the end of the film, when Langdon and Neveu say goodbye, there is an over-cheesy dialogue on faith, humanity and godliness. In the end a tribute is paid to Mary of Magdalen, who is the icon of freedom for all oppressed people in the world (especially women). I asked myself how Mary Magdalen could ever be of any meaning to oppressed people, the way it is put in this movie. And even, if you are willing to believe this, how Jesus' descendants could. The acting was pretty poor. Before seeing the movie I already wondered why they had cast Tom Hanks. And after seeing it I wonder even more. In the book the ideas about ancient symbols were more or less interesting (even though it's really 'sensation-science'). But with Hanks uttering them, they are completely unconvincing. Audrey Tautou as Sophie Neveu is a good choice. But whereas her self-chosen naiveté in Amelie, and her blind faith in Un Long Dimanche de Fiancailles, gave her performance strength and depth, in this movie she seems to be clueless about her own identity. The quest for the holy grail is her quest in that she discovers who she is. But it seems that she herself does not really believe the story that she is a descendant of Jesus and Mary. Paul Bettany as Silas the albino monk is utterly annoying. He is self-flagellating throughout the movie, and otherwise too, he is miserable. There is no humanity in his character whatsoever, and it makes him unrealistic. Ian McKellen as Leigh Teabing is alright. This movie is completely humorless. It takes itself too serious. You have to either accept it, or decline. I decline.

title: You've been had!
review: What a load of tripe has been written about the book and now this film. Dan Brown has successfully pulled a fast one and he should be congratulated for that. Ha ha ha! OK, now what did I think of this movie? It was passable but deeply flawed. So, we're supposed to believe that the character Neveu is both 'in on the secret' but completely ignorant of it at the same time? Eh, what? Whose story is this? The code breaker (Langdon)ought to be the minor character but he is made the centre of this piece. As a code breaker he too is a mass of contradictions...he recognises the symbolic meanings of all kinds of things before he spots the significance of his own part in the unfolding story (duh, a bit slow there methinks). Clearly a number of the characters (Silas included) have a set of noxious beliefs that cause them to do dreadful things in the name of their 'duty' to them. Beliefs have to be expressed in words...and words can be manipulated...and facts can be manipulated...and coincidental facts can be conflated...and rhymes can be made...and stories are told...and did you know who Leonardo of Pisa was?

title: Anyone who respects the book... (cont.)
review:
I'm not quite sure what happened but I think I accidentally entered my review without finishing it.

My opinion is that Ron Howard decided to do this for one of two reasons: 1. He knew that it would scrape in an ass-load of cash or 2. He wanted to look cool making a movie that the whole world has been arguing about.

All that aside I think he did a pretty great job. It's a great looking movie with an outstanding cast (except for Mr. Hanks and Ms. Tautou's chemistry which was horrible and poorly written by the screenwriter) and of course you can't put everything in there, because otherwise it wouldn't be marketable to the people who hadn't read the book which is a probably a majority of the people who saw the movie. I also thought it got very boring at times because the only way to present some information was to us duologue which feels too much like a lecture. The reason that it is so interesting to read is because your mind creates your own unique version of what is going on and with this book i don't think it can be conveyed suitably to film. So if you really think the whole concept of church conspiracies is interesting go pick up the book its much more worthwhile. However if you want a nice crash course I suppose I would recommend this movie as most people who did not read the book but saw the movie seemed to enjoy it.

title: The worst movie ever made?
review:
OK, I read the book and though it was excellent read. OK there's been much discussion about the facts and the fiction, the mistakes (which I believe you can count on one hand) etc etc.

Now the film: this was worse than Supernova! One of the worst movies I have ever seen - if you have read the book, when watching you keep wondering "hang on a minute, that's wrong" or "they have missed that bit out" or "that's changed" and so fourth. If you had not read the book my friends said "what the ####, was that about?" Then there's the Albino, ummmm, OK white hair, weird eyes but not 'white' skin. Good albino! A friend of mine is an albino, the 'ghost' wasn't.

My advice is this: if you have read the book miss the movie. Shame on you Ron Howard - I hope this isn't the end of your career, you've made excellent movies in the past and this wan't one of them!

title: Don't go see this movie, pick up the book instead
review:
I reaaally didn't like this movie. I liked the book, read it in 2 days, it was a page-turner. still, the movie sucked big time. i mean, it was watchable for someone who had never heard of the book or the 'controversy' surrounding it, but for me it was just sad, sad, sad.

Here's why: 1. The cast - a big no-no. Tom Hanks was awful, he looked funny, talked funny, his hair was in all the wrong places, i couldn't look at him or listen to him without imagining how it would be to send him back to the terminal as soon as possible. Audrey Tatou was sweet, like candy for the eyes, but she didn't fit in this movie. She looked pretty dumb and not like anything i had imagined while reading the book - i actually cheered for sophie marceau to play her role, but i doubt that hanks could contribute to that chemistry attempt as well. and sadly i disliked jean reno- he was whiny and funny he didn't work at all, and hes one of the coolest actors out there so that was exceptionally sad to see.

2. the book was cut down massively for the running time of the movie. it was altered, made quite simple and generally censored a whole lot.

3. the albino guy sucked. the scenes of self-punishment were gross at times and they showed his face in the first scene of the movie - how unimaginative of the director.

4. the camera did a bad job. editing as well. the shots of the main characters were made so up-close that i felt like i was gonna be consumed by the presence of tom hanks' giant head and his weird up-do. somewhere along the line of these giant heads the beautiful cities of Paris and London got lost - and i regretted not seeing more of them.

5. the story wasn't connected properly. everything went down too fast and it was simplified as if the audience would be too simple-minded to grasp any complicated notions in this film.

There's more, but I'm actually too tired to write more. What I actually did like about this movie was a farely nice ending, technically i mean - the way it was shot and summoned the final idea with the final shots was done right. and also the fact that while talking in between themselves the french actually spoke french! some irritating accent was present in other scenes, but this was a mild condition compared to some other similar Hollywood produced films. so thumbs up for that, if for nothing else.

Cheers, Lana

title: Ugh....
review:
I loved the book but could not get into the movie at all. I was basically bored through out most of it, not to mention that I never wanted Tom Hanks to play Robert Langdon. He just didn't fit the role at all IMHO.

I thought Teabing and Silas were done right. Silas still provoked that bit of sadness from me that I felt for him in the book. I know, crazy murderer LOL but somehow you just have to feel for a guy that is being used for his religious beliefs. He truly believes in what he is doing. Teabing was done well although my picture of him in the book was more of a fat, balding Englishmen.

Anyone who read the book though, had to know that it would be a hard concept to translate into movie form. In fact, I think if you did not read the book, that the movie would lose you in parts. Many people around me in the theater were talking trying to figure stuff out because they were a little lost.

title: An all out attack on Christianity
review:
Although this story is fictional it is still an all out attack on Christianity. I am an eighteen year old who has been blessed with a strong faith and am able to handle the story and treat it as fiction. For those whose faith is shaky, I would not recommend seeing this movie or reading the book.

Imagine if this was not an attack on Christianity but on the Islamic faith and on Mohammed. There would be great uproar and everyone would be opposed to such an idea. Why is it that it is OK to completely bash the foundation of Christianity but it is truly heinous to even question the Islamic faith? This should not be. Christ is true God. I do not consider Mohammed on his level. Mohammed was a demented fool and will be punished justly by God's full omnipotent power on Judgement Day because he started a false religion that has been bringing down others and giving them a free pass to hell.

title: missing something
review: I thought this movie was not extraordinary with one exception. Ian McKellen did a superb job. There was no chemistry with Tom Hanks. I think any talentless actor could pull of the same dull performance as he did. I went with a multicultural group of people and we all had the same opinion that it would have been better with another actor such as Jeremy Irons or even Tom Cruise instead of Tom Hanks. The rest of the cast is good the plot is ever twisting yet I felt the adventure was to dull. I'm not sure if it was because of Hanks or Ron Howard. Ron Howard has proved that he can produce extremely good films yet I don't understand how he could have settled for the averageness of this one. As for the film it is fiction and it is evident that is so. The film is not forcing any beliefs on anyone although people might be encouraged to open their minds when watching this.

title: Purposely Offbase?
review:
Let me start off by saying I am not a fan of the book for many reasons. Theology aside, the research of history, art and architecture was shoddy at best, which would not be so bad if Brown did not claim that so much inside was factual which turned out not to be. Also, Brown stated in a press conference that the DaVinci Code represents history as he has come to understand it, so we cannot continue under the ubiquitous "it's meant to be FICTION, people" guise.

When I first saw the movie, I was sadly disappointed at Ron Howard's spineless approach to the controversy. I mean, if you're going to take on a subject at the height of it's media frenzy, do it all the way, I say. But Howard portrayed Langdon, a Harvard professor who should exude an air of confidence and probably some conceit about his deep knowledge of his life's work, as wishy-washy and more than a little skeptical about the whole idea of secret societies. And the other "expert," Sir Leigh Teabing? A raving lunatic! (Played expertly as always, by Ian McClellan) Foaming at the mouth, practically wetting himself every time he gets the chance to present false testimony.

I must say that Howard's version is good for the church - who in their right mind would put any stock whatsoever in Brown's rantings now? It might as well have been Dan Brown himself driving off in the police cruiser. Which leads me to believe that maybe I was wrong about Ron Howard's intentions for this movie.

Howard said from the beginning that the reason he accepted the project was to film in exotic locations that few have ever been given access to, such as the Louvre. He's never really proclaimed any loyalty to the story, except when he refused to add a disclaimer to the credits. Perhaps that's because he knew it wouldn't need one, being so off-base. Could it be that Howard balanced his remaining Opie-like ethics with that hint of Hollywood selfishness that told him he would never get the chance to see the Mona Lisa alone again? I'll hold on to that glimmer of hope and give the film 2 more stars than I would have without it.

title: Lifeless and pretty Dreadful
review:
Sorry to say that Ron Howard hasn't made a compelling movie here. Its deadly dull with so little energy that the only sound you hear in the audience is people uncomfortably rearranging themselves in the their chair.

It all starts with the script by Goldsman, who knows better. While faithful (i guess) to the "book", it has no flow, or energy, or humor, or excitement, or...well... anything. I had a sinking feeling that Dan Brown cut such a restrictive deal in selling the novel that anyone would have been essentially paralyzed.

Tom Hanks looks avuncular, but doesn't have an opportunity to change the expression on his face for the entire film. He must be embarrassed.

Even Ian McKlellen - who many think bring a hint of life into the movie - is more of a caricature than anything else. Paul Bettany and Audrey Tautou are completely wasted.

Alas...its bad, sadly. Very bad.

title: The book was a 15 out of 10 but the movie was about a 9 out of 10
review: I loved the book it was great. But to try and cram the Dan Brown's novel into 2-1/2 hours was just silly. The overall point was still there. (Even though there was a lot of tip-toeing around Christian beliefs.) But it just seemed that everything was rushed. Locations and events from the book were changed or even completely discarded just to cater to the length of the movie. Don't get me wrong, i liked the movie. But if you haven't read the book yet, i strongly suggest that you do before you see this film. It will help you fill in a lot of holes and not get lost in what seems like a fast forward version of the book.

title: Starts well then makes a dash for the finishing post
review:
"It all depends on what you believe," is Tom Hanks' role's own bottom line in 'The Da Vinci Code'. Ironically, it also seems appropriate to how audiences will respond to this film.

On the positive side, the film follows the book quite faithfully and makes good use of special effects to assist the viewer (whose average reading age will be much lower than readers of the book).

There are some important factual errors and missed opportunities in the book, which the film blindly regurgitates. For example, it makes no sense for a Zurich bank to offer any kind of retail banking facilities outside the jurisdiction of Switzerland - I would have resolved this by switching the château and banking scene order. Also a Geneva (instead of Zurich) bank would fit far better with the key character from that scene.

For me, the greatest missed opportunity in both forms of the story is to miss the inference from the underlying research material that the Catholic church has made the mother of Christ a substitute for Mary Magdalena as part of its campaign against her.

title: unbelievable !
review:
I watched the funniest movie for sometime, DA VINCI CODE. Impressive funny and Mind boggling. A murder happens at the Louvre and it is investigated by a Symbologist who through some anagrams, quotes, etc etc finds out a secret thing which eventually will shake the foundations of Christian Church. It's clearly defined at the start, the movie is a "fiction". The most idiotic of all, is the movie says the person sitting on Jesus's right in Leonardo's LAST SUPPER is Magdalene. Jesus announces to his 12 disciples in Last Supper that one among them will betray him. Exactly 12 people will be sitting along with Jesus there. If it was Magdalene sitting in that painting then who was that disciple, Leonardo ignored. "da Vince" literally means "from Vince". Vince is a place where Leonardo came from.

The title now means FROM VINCI CODE? Dan Brown only knows.

Then the cast. I would have preferred Russell Crowe ahead of Tom Hanks. Hanks and Tautou escape from Police. Everything happens in a night and too fast and nothing believable. They are everywhere. They know everything. They understand everything in a matter of seconds. They go to a place wherever they want. Finally, in Scotland they realize, Tautou is a living descendant of Jesus. Jesus, if sees this movie, will hang himself. Dan Brown became richer writing such stupid fiction. Ron Howard is popular for making it as a movie.I cannot believe the gospels. I cannot believe in the divinity of Jesus. Only Jesus knows what he is all about.

Dan Brown must be mesmerized by the book "HOLY BLOOD AND HOLY GRAIL" Picture is going with the audience but certainly it didn't impress me. Largely because of its cinematic existence. Traitors appear good in the start of a normal cinema. Happens with this as well. Indeed too many traitors. Hollywood should explore new areas and give people wide range of entertainment.

title: Crap compared to the book
review:
The first comment I read on this movie contained a praise for being faithful to the book. I strongly disagree with that as with the movie itself.

What especially struck me as odd was the move from a strong female and supporting male characters in the book to a full blown male hero who solves almost all the puzzles himself. Miss Neveu, albeit being the driving force in the book, the one that only lacks the knowledge of Mr. Langdon but is not without wits herself, is transformed to a side show character that may only lend some hints, have an idea or two, but is mainly drawn into the proceedings instead of leading during the major part of the story. This is particularly interesting in the light of the story itself, that speaks of the suppressed female in Christianity, a story that culminates in revealing ages of denial of femininity.

There are also a lot of detail changes from the book, just take the cross Captain Fache wears: in the book it is a cross made of 13 gems, called the Crux Gemmata, in the movie it is a simple cross made of lines the same size. The same applies to the bank, described as a metal box in the middle of a nightly deserted industry district with the cross of Switzerland overhead, in the movie it is located in a bustling street, has a strange symbol and is not entered in a car. And why on earth did they change the ending? What on earth made the makers do that?

Changing a lot of details and the chronology of events must have been a main issue for the makers of the film, I could go on and on with examples, but there is another thing really creeped me out and that is how flat the characters got. Aringarosa got away worst of them all I think.

As for the movie itself, not comparing it to the book, I still have a thing or two to complain about. The characters appear far too suddenly, there is little introduction. How could the viewer be convinced that some characters are to be taken trustworthy at first? Also, for my taste, there was too much James Bond in it, the narrow escapes seem too far fetched, the superior intellect and wisdom of Langdon seem too exaggerated, but that might still be me remembering the book.

Sorry, as much as I love conspiracy movies, this one just doesn't cut it.

title: A 10 not for the movie but for bringing an idea to far for some ...
review:
A great idea that brings the genius of Leonardo closer to our eyes ... sure its not a great movie ... but it had to be done cos it had a lot of interest around it and lets not forget that what the movie brings are facts not fiction ... we all now it but refuse to believe it ... cold facts .

And for those who choose to believe keep this in mind :

You can have any faith you want ... just don't kill others for not sharing your believes !

I really want to hear your opinions about my comment cos I want to make a statistic about what people think about "The Da Vinci Code"

title: If you liked the movie, you'll love the book!
review:
Ron Howard has indeed given us Dan Brown's book. All the major events are there. Yes, he had to insert some scenes, and change some scenes because movie film doesn't have the ability to put the viewer in the heads of the characters.

If you liked the book, you won't be disappointed in the movie. Visuals are really better for explaining symbols. But some things had to be simplified for film.

No question about it - Dan Brown is a great story teller! Every chapter of the book, and each scene of the movie leaves you hanging. You have to tear yourself away and go on to another part of the story.

Now all I want is an expert I trust to tell me what parts are really true and what parts are fiction... :)

I believe the nerve that this story has touched is that imminent rise to equality of women. That is, women are on the verge of equality and this story screams - "Men have been keeping you down for centuries!"

title: The Davinci Code
review:
THE DAVINCI CODE Written by Akiva Goldsman Directed by Ron Howard

Ordinarily, I would think it grossly unfair to criticize a work directly regarding its translation from book to film. The literary medium offers its readers the opportunity to imagine the events unfolding any way they would like while the cinematic medium does all the imagining for you. In the case of Ron Howard's adaptation of author Dan Brown's international phenomenon, THE DAVINCI CODE, there isn't much imagination happening on the filmmaker's part though. Avoiding comparison here would actually be the great injustice as the immense anticipation that preceded the release of this film was all to do with the ultra- wide popularity of the book. Brown's novel is easily digested. It's lead characters, Robert Langdon and Sophie Neveu, are being chased by numerous parties throughout lavish and romantic European settings. The chase and threat of capture keeps people turning the pages and the international flavor makes people feel as if in the presence of culture. For likely many others, and myself, these were the least intriguing elements of the book. What kept me coming back and barreling through hundreds of pages at a time was the book's unapologetic and relentless blasphemy against the Christian faith. Brown immerses the viewer amidst characters and settings that exist to varying degrees in real life, thus blurring the lines between fiction and non. Somewhere in between the facts and the fabrications, Brown drops his theoretical bomb  that the ever-elusive Holy Grail, the cup of Jesus Christ, is in fact not a cup at all but rather a person, a woman. The woman in question is the infamous Mary Magdalene and the chalice is her womb, the carrier of the bloodline of Jesus Christ. Yes, you heard right, folks! Jesus got it on with the prostitute and she went on to have his child and their descendants are still here on earth today. I am not for attacks on Christians without purpose but this is not an attack so much as an alternate theory to the foundation their shaky religion rests upon.

I can understand why the Vatican is concerned about the impact this film could have. If you forget for a second, it's easy to get sucked into all this lore and accept it as fact or at least as potentially true. That being said, it is borderline insulting of the Vatican to presume the film-going public is not intelligent enough to know the difference between history and plain story. Their concern is not for the entire film-going public though, it is more so for the middle of the road viewer who just passively absorbs images without thinking. When I think of these film-goers, I think of the ideal Ron Howard fan. Howard doesn't make bad movies (OK, HOW THE GRINCH STOLE Christmas was bad) but he also doesn't make spectacular movies (and no, I don't have an example to refute that). THE DAVINCI CODE has all the elements one would expect from a large-scale Howard production, from big names to big locations. But what it attempts to mask with size is not a lack of substance but rather a lack of control over that substance. Howard coaxes performances from the cast that are inconsistent and hollow. As Langdon, Tom Hanks is sensible, curious and introspective. Ian McKellan plays Leigh Teabing, a Holy Grail expert as playful and cheeky. On the other hand, the usually deep Alfred Molina is farcical and Audrey Tautou looks lost and confused as Neveu; at times she barely seems to know where to stand.

One of the book's major criticisms, aside from it relying too heavily on conspiracy theories and barely bothering with style, is that it reads like a high-spirited Hollywood blockbuster. Ironically, Howard's film interpretation plays out nothing like one. It is tiring at times and stale at others. The hackneyed script by frequent Howard collaborator, Akiva Goldsman, cuts out numerous Grail factoids from the book that lend to the theory's credibility but yet still manages to get frequently bogged down in Grail history throughout the film. The result is slowed pacing during scenes that are meant to be suspenseful. Lengthy background explanations take place during car chases and moments when killers are waiting to attack in the next room but the danger never presents itself until the explaining is all done (leading me to wonder if perhaps the attacker took a bathroom break). With the action forced to wait its turn, the viewer feels the flaws and loses their patience. Howard has taken a book that seemed to have been written with a film deal in mind and made a mess of the already carefully laid plans. As cheap as it is to say this, I must. You're better off reading the book.

title: On a back foot before it started
review:
I believe the reason the Da Vinci code has been so poorly received was that because the book was such a massive hit everyone who went to watch it had preconceived ideas about how the story would translate onto the screen. This also relates to Tom Hanks and his portrayal of Langdon. When you read a book you form opinions and mental images about the characters and how they would act should they come to life, Hanks was already on a losing streak before he uttered one word as people knew in their minds if he didn't match the image of Robert Langdon they had, it would be a massive failure.

I'm not saying the film was decent by any means, I was disappointed like most cinema goers but I don't feel the blame should lie on Hanks and Howard as a whole. In my opinion this should have never been made into a film and if you haven't read the book DO NOT go and see this film as you will almost certainly be asking for your money back.

I have also heard they are making Angels and Demons but I hope for all Dan Browns fans sakes this is not the case.

title: What to Expect : good disappointment and lot of sleep
review: The movie drastically fails to keep the attention of the audience.. Too slow... none of the characters really impress.. except for Silas the Monk. The movie is more like a documentary trying to explain about the HolyGrail, and doesn't have the flow required for success. Choosing a sensational theme is not alone enough to make a movie succeed.. The director probably doesn't understand this.... The first 45 minutes of the movie is the worst . The last 15 to 20 minutes seems to be the best of the movie, the last 5 minutes having the climax of a perfect thriller. I was having trouble with sleeping for a few days.. surprise... I slept through many parts of this movie ..I would recommend this movie for ppl who have trouble with sleeping.. :)

title: It was good, but could have been better
review:
I must say that i was a little disappointed with the movie, however i read the book before seeing the movie and its true the book is always better. The one thing that really got me about it was that it was long and about half way through the movie i found myself asking when is this going to be over. Its possible that that was because i already knew the story. Unfortinatly a lot of the symbolism was left out, which was the best part of the book.

However on the other side they did a very good job portraying many aspects that were lacking in the book. However due to time constraints they left out a lot of the really interesting and suspenseful parts of the book.

I must say that it is a GOOD move if you have not read the book, but if you have read the book you will be disappointed.

title: Rosslyn Chapel issue SPOILER
review: First off, I thought the movie, as a hole, was great and I had just finished the book so the book was fresh in my head as I watching the movie. Most of the changes I could under stand due to time constraints but the change they made at the Rosslyn Chapel was awful. I liked the books small little family reunion with grandmother "brother" and Sophie. I'm sure they could have done a grate job with grandma narrating the past and explaining that her and her brother are the only surviving blood line of Christ. I also don't see why they said Jack was not her grandfather, in the book it was clear that he was. Changes like these make a book adaptation go bad.

title: Longer, with suspense is better
review: I'm sure that if I had not read the book first, I would not have understood this movie. The plot was very disjointed and as is, I think it will be hard to follow for those unfortunate ones who have not read the book. The movie was OK...but I don't think its all that Ron Howard lovers hyped it up to be (no offense to Ron, because I do enjoy his work). It was mostly slow, and parts that you were supposed to figure out later on (to add the thrill of suspense) were handed to you in the first five minutes of the movie. The ending was anti -climactic at best, and left out several key elements to wrap up the story. Casting was also a bit odd. I'm sure Tom Hanks does not remind ANYONE of a young Harrison Ford, nor is Silas monstrous with red eyes. In fact, all I can think of is him walking down the road penniless and hungry in A Knights Tale. Jacques Saunière also does not fit his description, as he seemed a bit beefy to be a frail old man. If the story had played out as it did in the book, with all its suspense, I think they could have gotten away with it being over 3 hours long. 2 1/2 hours is not enough time to capture all Dan Brown's magic.

title: Read the book, skip the movie
review: Although the movie as a stand-alone project wasn't horrible, when you've read the book and loved it like I did, the movie is a huge disappointment. The screen play is different from the book on many key points, leading to the whole meaning of the story being distorted beyond any significance, and the tacked on Jesus speech at Roslin church is a huge cop out. Another huge disappointment was the way in which Sophie's character in the movie had all of her moments of brilliance and intelligence removed so that all she was left with was this shell of a character shadowing Tom Hanks around. The distortion of her character and her characters background changed the story from one that empowered woman, and spoke of the sacred feminine, to one in which the the only lead female character was bland and wussy with no real talents. And the changes to Robert Langdon's character took away a lot of his skill and talent, leading one to question why on earth he would have been chosen to help Sophie anyway. In all, this movie takes a fantastic and empowering story and butchers it into a stereotypical Male-as-hero story with totally different religious messages and meanings.

title: Not Happy (Opus) Dei(s) for Cinema
review: No, I'm one of them what hasn't even read the book! However, If this is the best piece of cinematic work these Academy Award winners can produce in the year 2006, then I think it's time for them to consider giving up and getting out of the business. It's all so utterly safe, predictable and dreadfully, dreadfully dull. It has all the charm and intrigue of a third rate 1980's television whodunit film you might (mis)happen upon one Thursday afternoon in late November when there's nothing else on and you just know it's far too cold to go outside to avoid. So, I'll sum up my thoughts for y'all with this conundrum: R I S I B L E - no, it's not as hard as you think!

title: Even more disengaging than the book
review:
Avoid.

Hanks is wasted, Howard seems to fall asleep for the 2nd half, and the plot is even more comedic and low brow on film than it is in print.

I had no trouble accepting the various performances on film as the book had virtually no characterisation at all, but Hanks seems to remain a blank slate throughout the movie, reduced to a mere talking almanac for Tatou's 'please explain it to me again for the simple people in the audience' plot device.

I was totally unmoved by the book, and curiously the movie is even worse. It will be a money maker, but critically it's an absolute yawn-a-thon.

What was the line that made me laugh out loud again?

Quick! We must find a library!

title: The best part...when my friend burped during the movie
review: ...it was long, annoying, pointless and made me wish I was dead. Okay I'm not usually disappointed by any movie but come on 2 and a half hours of nothing...I just didn't get into it my friends and I could barely stay awake. The movie seemed like it would never end. At the very climax of the movie my friend accidentally burped quite loudly and well that was the best part of this ever droning on movie...very disappointed. With the high expectations and the raving of some of my friends who read the book I expected this movie to strongly controversial and very intriguing. After seeing it I feel the Catholic church needn't worry about the effect this movie has on it's parishioners. To me the movie pulled itself under.

title: I'm sorry all you knockers but I enjoyed it!
review:
Sorry to all the people queuing up to knock this movie, but I actually quite liked it. Okay - the hype was unbelievable for this film - it NEVER had a hope in hell of living up to the hype. I think its a very intelligent film, not very easy to watch at times, but all this about being badly paced and not being dramatic et all is a load of toss. HOWEVER... Miss Tatou did absolutely nothing for me - its a shame, but I'm afraid she does rather leave the side down.

In summary.... Good Film, good performances, a bit intense.... but remember it is FICTION! Forget your catholic beliefs etc... and take it for what it is.

I recommend people to make up their own minds, and forget the hype and the Zealots with their pickets....

title: A disappointment...
review:
I thoroughly enjoyed the book. It presented a wealth of historical facts (or fiction depending on your personal beliefs) and allowed my imagination to wander. It sparked discussion and brought new ideas forth. I could easily relate to the characters and was just as interested in them as i was the main story.

The movie however did almost none of the above. The first 5 minutes stuck to the book perfectly. But that was about the only part that did. From there on in locations, times and dialogue was changed around. The dialogue between the characters was dry and lacked any interest. The same can be said of the characters themselves. I was no longer interested in what they were like, and now just wanted to get to the end of the movie. The story itself lacked the intrigue that it had had in the book, and it presented the information like solid facts. This didn't allow me to imagine what COULD happen, what MIGHT have happened. Instead it was clear cut, this is the way it happened.

The final nail in the coffin for this movie was the ending. Unlike at the end of the book where we are left to wonder how Jesus's blood line continues, we are told. And it is not much of a surprise. It was somewhat of a cliché having the grand daughter be the continuation of the blood line. Once again the film leaves no room for imagination.

This movie does have one saving grace. The flashbacks were used very well, particularly in reference to the Conference of Mycenia. Besides that the movie was very uninteresting. I would recommend the book if you like to imagine, and the movie if you want clear cut answers.

title: Seek The money
review:
I am very disappointed for the film i loved the book so i was expecting to love the movie to

BUT it is obvious that the producers want to make the movie as fast as they can. so if someone have not read the book will never understand the movie by its self i went to see the movie with 5 of my friends and only me understand what was happened. I don't know if they cut scenes to lower the movie time.

It was a great idea for a perfect movie but it wasted...

I hope the angel and demons {iluminate} will not have the same ending

PS Angel and demons is on the making i hope langdon is not tom hanks

title: A far fetched confusing movie
