It's the nature of the beast. Characters and plot points are going to be tweaked and changed somewhat. But Goldsman does not give us minor tweaks, he changes the very story itself. Why anyone would feel the need to so drastically change the most basic and important plot elements of one of the most popular stories of all time is beyond comprehension. With the absolutely engrossing story they had to work with from the novel this film should have been something truly special. It is not. Somehow Akiva Goldsman managed to make The Da Vinci Code downright boring. And for anyone who read the novel incredibly frustrating.

There are almost too many ridiculous changes from the novel to mention but the most obvious, and incredibly dumb, change is the fact that the central figure of the story, Harvard professor, symbologist and author Robert Langdon has been turned into a skeptic, someone who does not believe the very story on which the entire novel was based. The first time you hear Tom Hanks as Langdon describe the Holy Grail story as a "myth" you know this film is going to have problems. The only reason Langdon ever became involved in the story in the novel was BECAUSE he knew, certainly believed and even wrote about the Holy Grail story. That is why a dying Jacques Sauniere's last act was to ensure that Langdon would be involved in all the events that would follow. If Langdon did not believe in the Grail he would have never been involved in the story at all.

Turning Langdon into a skeptic makes absolutely no sense but that's only the start. Goldsman has changed the motivations behind many of the characters' actions and in doing so has changed the very essence of the characters themselves, and not for the better. Bishop Aringarosa who in the novel was horrified at the thought of any killing has now become almost downright sinister. Police Captain Bezu Fache certainly had his reasons to be adamant about Langdon's guilt in the novel. Here he has an entirely different reason to be sure of Langdon's guilt. An entirely ridiculous, implausible reason. The character of Jacques Sauniere is someone entirely different from who he was in the novel and the change in his character helps to destroy all the emotion the novel had, which came almost entirely from Sophie Neveu's quest to learn the truth about her family. Suffice to say Akiva Goldsman's truth does not match Dan Brown's. You'll much prefer Dan Brown's.

Somewhere in this film Dan Brown's terrific story is still there. Maybe it's only there as a rough outline for Akiva Goldsman to follow (and ruin) but what's left of that engrossing, fascinating story is pretty much all this film has going for it. The acting by the two leads, Hanks as Langdon and Audrey Tautou as Sophie Neveu, is forced, wooden and completely devoid of any emotion. There is absolutely no spark between the two. Far better and far more convincing performances come from Ian McKellen as Grail scholar Leigh Teabing, Paul Bettany as murderous monk Silas and Jean Reno as Captain Fache. With what's left of Dan Brown's story and some quality performances there are a few good parts here. But it doesn't add up to anything. Nothing worthwhile at least.

Anyone who read the novel could have seen a film adaptation would be quite a challenge. There is a lot of historical information to get across and sure enough the film often gets bogged down explaining the background behind the central theme of the story, the Holy Grail. And the novel took so many sudden and unexpected twists and turns which would certainly be a challenge to portray. But the way many of the plot points are revealed in the film does not even begin to match the stunning revelations of the book. Most notably the novel had one great "A-Ha!" moment where everything gets turned on its head. It should have been the key moment, the most thrilling moment, in the film. It is not, as the big revelation comes across with a whimper not a bang. In another of the most misguided changes characters who were absolutely essential in paying off one of the novel's big themes do not even appear. All the wonderful emotion of the book's conclusion has been lost. Do not be fooled by the obligatory "based on the novel by Dan Brown" credit. This is not Dan Brown's The Da Vinci Code, it is Akiva Goldsman's. And we are all the worse for it.

title: So dark, the bore of The DaVinci Code
review:
I had a hot dog when I went to the theatre. As for the movie, well...uh...the hot dog was good, did I mention that? Great...sausage. I think even the slightly stale bun was better than watching poor Tom Hanks try so darned hard and succeed in being outacted by a tree. OK, so it's not like I had any expectations whatsoever but damn, that was a horrible movie! If it had been 1 1/2 hours, it would have been more tolerable but then, alas, that wouldn't have allowed for the rather silly and asinine "Beautiful Mind"-type "visualizations". The point in which Tom Hanks was solving that Crypto-box thingy and he was visualizing the Newton solution was a complete and rather dull rip-off of those nice scenes in "A Beautiful Mind" where Russell Crowe had his ephiphanies and things. I will say that Paul Bettany and Audrey Tatou (sp?) were OK and Ian McKellen did a fine turn replaying his X-Men character with a less mutanty edge. Granted, I'm not a fan of the book but I will say that despite the rather horrendous writing of Mr. Brown, he kept you turning the pages. The movie made me yawn. And laugh. And wish it was WAY shorter. And poor, poor Tom Hanks. I hated Robert Langton in the books because he was such a pompous twit. No matter how hard Mr. Hanks tried, he didn't exactly become Mr. Langdon for me. He tried to become pompous but his Tom Hanks-iness sort of got in the way and I think he succeeded in being the equivalent of watching Chicken Little try to act like Popeye or something. The result was...wooden, to say the least.

However, I will say, my favourite moment was when the Albino Monk asked "Do you dare mock me?" (or something like that). Oh, how I love when characters talk to me because I can't help but respond! Also, there's this rather darling scene between Jean Reno's character and that other boring french policeman when Bezu or whatever the heck his weird French name is admits to being Opus Dei. If you replace the word "killing" with the word "writing", you have my whole philosophy on the works of Dan Brown! Hurrah for Hollywood!!

title: Pretty close to the book. Unfortunately, the book already had its flaws.
review:
I like Dan Brown's novels. His choice of words is weak, his research is poor, his plots are painfully similar. But they are entertaining as hell and you can't lay his books down until you finished them. You like his characters - protagonists and antagonists alike. And while the central idea behind each book is nonsense, it makes for a hell of a great read.

I like the Da Vinci Code. Jesus marrying Maria Magdalena and getting kids is bull, of course. Besides, it has been done to death. And it's been done better. But the book wraps this tired (and cheesy) theory in a captivating thriller. While the theological conspiracy theory doesn't work, the thriller leaves you on the edge of your seat. What more do you expect from a movie?

The casting was inspired. Hanks as Langdon is the only weak point. The books describe Langdon as Harrison-Fordish, I would have picked Gary Sinise. Hanks comes off as too tired and too boring. Audrey Tautou however is beautiful and fits the character perfectly. Ian McKellen steals every scene he's in, and his almost childish excitement is infecting. Jean Reno is the only one who could have played the role of Bezu Fache. I missed the part (that is in the book) which set up Fache as a red herring, but the film is long enough as it is. Great performances from Alfred Molina, Paul Bettany and JÃ¼rgen Prochnow as well.

All in all, a very faithful adaptation of a pretty entertaining book. I'm looking forward to adaptations of Angels and Demons, Deception Point and Digital Fortress (and Brown's upcoming Langdon book about the Freemasons and Washington, DC). But I'm really starting to wish that Brown and the filmmakers do better research next time. The whole DaVinci code theory that ties the plot together is the weakest part of the book (and the movie) and the Opus Dei? Don't get me started.

title: The real sin of DVC!
review: Ron Howard is possibly the worst director working in cinema today. I rather liked the book, The Da Vinci Code, and thought the plot was pretty much fool-proof. I figured even a hack like Howard couldn't mess up this story too much. Wow! The car chase sequence in Paris? What's with an orchestral score over that scene? Are we expected to RELAX into the chase? How much tension can a director suck OUT of a sequence? The one good sequence of the film - between Sir Ian and (wannabe Sir) Tom - is driven by Sir Ian being the only person on the set who actually seems to understand the words being used. Hanks, to give him credit, does actually try and raise to the occasion. This is not the worst thing I've seen Tom do (it's no Forest Gump!). The sin of this film is not the ideas of Brown's novel (or its antecedents), but that there is just no excuse for suck hackneyed film-making. Somebody stop Howard from making another film. Please!!!!

title: wooden ships float, wooden films sink....
review: You would expect so much from a Cast of this quality, however, they just don't deliver. Much of the dialog is uttered with a character which reminds me of opening a bottle of soda only to find out it has lost it's fizz and is flat; you end up disappointed and thirsty. I like Ron Howard and the Cast (and this film was well cast) however, the overall result is disappointing. Tom Hanks is a wonderful actor, but an actor can only do but so much with the dialog handed to them. I didn't notice who wrote the screenplay, but they bear the bulk of the responsibility for this films overall dullness. This film had the promise of being such an exciting couple of hours, but it just didn't deliver. Ron Howard's dedication to following the original story line was admirable, but when this film was in editing, Somebody should have stood up and said " Hey Ron, we need to make a few changes here. " I don't know...wooden is probably how I would best describe it. The book was OK, the movie, just fair, but then again it was....just a movie.

title: Da Vinci didn't convince me!
review:
Okay, I decided to write a review of THE DA VINCI CODE, but I thought, golly gee, wouldn't it be great to do the critique, but do it in calligraphy in invisible ink on rare parchment paper, seal it in a container with a numerical lock so complicated that only a mathematical genius could decipher it and bury it in sacred ground at a location that can only be determined by solving an anagram created from a riddle written as a limerick and scrawled in blood on the back of a rare painting hanging in a museum that is protected by armed guards who will allow you to bypass security, but only if you can prove you belong to a secret society by telling them the password that is the answer to a question posed as a palindrome written in Hebrew and posted at the website dopeyopie.com.

But, then I asked myself, who in their right mind would be stupid enough to go to all that trouble just to learn the secret of what I think of the movie THE DA VINCI CODE -- as brilliant and insightful as my opinion ultimately might be. Of course, my little scavenger hunt is nothing compared to the conspiracies and counter-conspiracies whose gnarly tentacles thrive like kudzu in Ron Howard's movie based on Dan Brown's novel. It involves competing secret societies, both of whom seem obsessed with creating elaborate puzzles and word games designed to keep or uncover sinister schemes that will either save or destroy Christianity as we know it today. But just who in this ridiculously complex game of charades is supposed to be the good guys or the bad guys is open to interpretation. At any rate, there are tax codes that are easier to decipher than the rambling plots that unravel and tangle up again in this bloated narrative.

Tom Hanks, clearly miscast as a Harvard professor, plays a "symbologist" who, for reasons that are never made clear, becomes the unsuspecting contestant who is sucked into the rival convoluted conspiracies that center on the search for the Holy Grail, which we are told is a who and not a what. All this springs from the notion that Jesus Christ did not die a virgin, but married Mary Magdelene and sired a child and that created a lineage that survives today. It is but one of the film's innumerable plot holes that it assumes that after 2000 years and possibly 100 generations, only one possible offspring would exist and not the thousands that are likely. And if you don't figure out just who that one possible offspring is within the first half hour, than you definitely are not heavenly inspired, because that is the least mysterious mystery in the story.

All the densely packaged clues, theories, wild guesses and "evidence" that supposedly reveal that the Christ story is a hoax are tossed at the audience in a fast and furious manner, yet the story still seems to drag on endlessly. And after going the long way around, it is obvious at the end that the revelation of the "truth" is not likely to make one bit of difference: It would take a lot more than this junk theology to cause the devout to doubt or the church to crumble. Seldom will you find a film's ending more deserving of a shrug and an indifferent "So what?" It is, however, obvious why the Catholic church among others are offended by THE DA VINCI CODE because it does suggest that the churches willful have lied about Jesus' divinity as a cruel excuse to brutalize others and commit church-sanctioned murder. And while it is refreshing, in this era when so many movies are constructed like insipid video games, that here is a movie and book that tries to appeal to the thinking man. But strip away the sanctimonious pseudo-religious prattle and it is just another film about nailing the evil corporation (i.e., the Catholic Church, Inc.) that is selling a product deemed to be defective (i.e., religious faith). That aside, THE DA VINCI CODE is little more than ludicrous neo-feminist propaganda: the piety of women versus the chauvinism of men.

Yet, if Jesus did marry, what's the big deal? Becoming a husband and father would only confirm belief in the power of marriage and family and it would not necessarily contradict Jesus' virgin birth, his divinity or the validity of his philosophical teachings. The true mystery is why the churches have so foolishly acted as the PR agent for the film. All the indignant protests and hysterical calls for boycotts have done nothing but create book-buying, ticket-selling publicity that has drawn in millions of gullible consumers who otherwise wouldn't have cared less about this rather silly story.

And in its pursuit if the Holy Grail, DA VINCI's quest is neither as funny as Monty Python's or as exciting as Indiana Jones'. And for that matter it isn't even as amusingly bad as the similarly themed HUDSON HAWK. Despite its arrogant self-importance, the film doesn't even meet minimum standards as decent entertainment; so let's just say that DA VINCI isn't up to code.

title: See it again!
review:
I read the novel a year ago. And then the wait began...

In the 48 hours or so, up 'til seeing it on it's opening weekend Friday night, I, like most people, had heard the negative reviews (Cannes, pans, etc.). And after the 3 hours that I had sat in a Chicago-area movie theatric that night, I somewhat agreed. That first night, "The Da Vinci Code" seemed rather boring, a little hard to follow, and for the most part, unimpressive. Tom Hanks was something of a shadow: there, but not really more than to just follow the real action, which seemed to be occurring in every other storyline except for his. Ron Howard's direction was so-so, I supposed.

Another 48 hours went by, and on Sunday night, unplanned, I went to see it again.

After walking out of the theatric the second time, I was somewhat speechless. I suddenly had plenty of respect for this movie. Things that I didn't notice the first time jumped off the screen at me the second time around. I found Hanks' portrayal dead on to the Robert Langdon I remember reading of. And yes, Langdon pretty much is a shadow on the wall throughout the book. Oh yes--Hanks is the star. But Imagine (pun intended) Hanks in his ten-year old "Big" mindset screaming at you, "But the movie isn't about me!" Speaking of Imagine, Howard, who did a great job with "The Missing" (at least *I* thought), steered this very well considering, well, how many tens of millions of people have already read the book and already directed this movie in *their own heads.* I wonder how many of us were hoping that we'd see a "shared vision" with Ron Howard up there on the big screen.

Howard got the right performances out of a terrific cast. And a name you might not hear mentioned in anyone else's comments is Akiva Goldsman, who is credited with writing the screenplay. Goldsman does a fine job with a fantastic literary work--don't hear that too often.

"The Da Vinci Code" is a very brainy work of fiction. For movies of this nature, see anything by the Coen Brothers. I learn something new about "The Big Lebowski" every time I see it (and I'm on 10 times at least by now). And that was never a book. Hmmm. "The Le Bowski Code." Maybe I'm onto something here, are you listening Harvey and Bob? Anyhow, my advice is to see it twice.

Write me if you do...tell me what you thought on *second* blush.

title: A great film cleverly made to closely reflect the book.
review:
One of the few films that are adapted from books which follows the book's story line very, very closely.

I've heard a lot of people say that this film did not meet their expectations, and that they felt bits were missing. For me the film exceeded my expectations, as I wasn't expecting the film to follow the book closely, and I have read many bad reviews.

Some of the explanations of events are a little sketchy, such as Silas' and Sophie's past. Also quite a bit of the "factual and historical proof" of the theories put forwards in the book have been omitted. I believe this was done very cleverly and deliberately, such that the ideas that Dan Brown included in the book as though they were fact, but actually turned out to be untrue, have been removed.

At first I didn't feel that Tom Hanks was right for the role of Robert Langdon, but I changed my mind almost instantly, he put across an brilliant performance. Paul Bettany's portrayal of Silas was both excellent and harrowing, I felt he almost stole the show.

The films length flew by, keeping me thoroughly entertained and even slightly on edge, despite knowing the plot inside and out.

Definitely one to watch.

title: The grail is what again? and it's . . . where?
review:
This is one of those films that you don't know to ask for your money back until it's mostly over. Only then do you realize the full scope of how brainless it all was, and how you were cheated.

Tom Hanks is interesting in the part, though dull. The casting seems otherwise good. The French do suggest a little unintentional comedy. But maybe that's just a French thing.

There are those I've heard say - gee, it really makes you think. And they'll turn around two minutes later and say - just fiction and whatchya complain-an about, it's just a movie? So, until such folk get their heads in working order, I'll just suggest that the plot is insane. The tomb of Magdelene is supposed to be buried in the little pyramid under the glass pyramid fairly recently built in the courtyard of the Louvre Museum. And the Tom Hanks character doesn't want to upset 'organized religion' by telling anyone, I suppose. So that's why they built that ugly glass pyramid (as bad guy #1 called it). Had to be a reason. Of course, the real whopper is not that there is this line of offspring, which just coincidentally, we'll say, happens to end with a girl - because imagine how the plot would look if it were a guy - from Jesus Christ. It's that Jesus Christ was just a man, just a prophet. There's a number of sects that believe that, like the Freemasons, and the Muslims, and any number of heretics in the Church's past. Jesus was just some good guy - who literally claimed to be God, Himself. So he was just a good guy, who was completely out of his mind. He was great teacher of morality, who fornicated with Magdalene, or then secretly married her to make it all legal. And then there are Catholics, and Protestants and Greek Orthodox who obviously believe otherwise.

As with pretty much the same supposed conspiracy said to be concealed by thousands and thousands over the millenia as proposed by Kazantzakis, also made into a film, and the same as with Lincoln's original Holy Blood myth from which Brown's fiction is wholly lifted, despite what a court may have ruled, what's sort of sad when watching this is not that the film just seems to drag on and on, it's not that the camera occasionally bounces all around, or that it screens like a book when they first elude capture, etc., but that people actually spend their lives coming up with these kind of conspiracy theories. To imagine that this described the early Church, the Apostles and disciples who literally were tortured and martyred, that of course is the classic argument against this, or similar notions.

As for the Priority of Sion stuff, this group of four that is murdered by McKellen who are trying to protect the female descendant, and the supposed 'grail', which in this myth isn't the cup at Valencia Cathedral, but the corpse of St. Mary Magdalene, this 'Priory' was admitted to be a hoax perpetrated in recent decades by a couple of guys, a con-man named, Pierre Plantard, and his buddy, Philippe de Cherisey. As for the Opus Dei involvement in the plot, that may come closest to the truth. The cult is not necessarily orthodox, and has been otherwise seen as heterodox, but it seems even more just to be a group which is very opportunistic, and really just out for itself, and power. It's a shadowy group, no question. It's considered dangerous by many traditional 'religious' Catholics. Whether any Opusites wear monk costumes is another thing, as is whether it's just a group of psychotic assassins, as Brown would have it.

If one wants a real conspiracy, a real threat to Catholicism, it's been in the news and in front of everyone - since at least the mid-1960s. It's the changes made in virtually everything, and blamed on Vatican II by the very 'reformers' themselves. There's a line that one of the bad guys, played by McKellen, says, or keeps saying. People ignore what's right in front of them. But what people see, and don't want to see, is this 'reformist' destruction on the inside (not necessarily including altering the appearance of Da Vinci's Last Supper), and which extends to the Protestant denominations, as well, and all the while the anti-Church conspiratist nuts keep pounding away with Holy Blood myths, and Gnostic gospels. That's the danger. It's 'world church reform'. Watering down. There's your threat, not in the deep desire of Kazantzakis and others that Jesus Christ be some sort of guy who can't keep his pants on. Such notions are so ridiculous, and so trivial in the face of the real threat, and what's really going on. In fact, one wouldn't be surprised with the desire of these newChurchers, who speak like secular feminists in everything, to believe that St. Magdalene wasn't really a Saint, but was rather the Incarnation, herself. Considering how far gone they are, already, that would just be one more against them on the list of offenses to both God, and The Church which He founded. If that's what 'making one think' is what anyone means who says it, hopefully it will.

Now, if Ron Howard ever made a film about the life of a Catholic Saint, that might be a sure sign that one could use ice skates in hell. But he'd probably go Oliver Stone one better and have the Saint dream of 'sexing' Jesus while discovering that The Church has been concealing the 'truth' that Pius X was a ten year old girl, name John - Joan. abbr. in Latin - who had good make-up people to make her appear old. Dakota Fanning as the Pope. Teen Pope. Coming soon. After all - it's just a movie!

title: entertaining but whats with the hype?
review: OK so i haven't read the book so i went in not knowing what to expect but i thought it was a major disappointment! don't get me wrong it was a good movie, however there was soo much hype leading up to it i expected a lot more. tom hanks gave an amazing performance as always which i expected, and the other actors did very good also, but i was just wanting more. while i was watching the movie it was good but i left wondering why i liked it when i was watching it. i would go see it just because its a huge summer blockbuster but don't expect to be blown away. also it is really really long (try around 3 hours) and you seem to just get the run around in the middle. i remember thinking OK are we done with all the weird clues yet? because some of them you think you are done with and then show up again (this may be just part of the story). when you go see it expect an exciting summer movie not the best movie ever made!

title: not bad at all
review:
it's amazing to me how religious people are so easily offended by a story that questions their own religion. do you think the book burning in italy would have happened if the story revolved around judaism or hinduism or Islam? no, but they would have done it somewhere else.

this is a truly intriguing mystery, well acted, well directed and fresh. i enjoyed it immensely. without spoiling anything for those who have yet to see it, i will only say that every performance was rock solid (despite the occasional bit of bad dialogue, which is to be expected in almost all films).

if people who are offended by this material would just watch it and say to themselves, "it's just fiction", and just think of it as a murder mystery, they might actually enjoy it.

title: Book is better.. as always..
review:
If you haven't read the book, go watch the movie. If you have read the book, go watch the movie anyway.

The movie itself is good, but maybe because I've read the book (and thus know who the real bad guys are..) I couldn't enjoy it as much as someone who spent 2 hours thinking "who the hell is the bad guy really?". But then, the action is good.. surprises.. codes (in real pictures.. i love the part when Teabing explains about the Last Supper painting, you don't get that many pictures from a book).

BUT, books will always be better than movies. As I expected, lots of details got omitted. Even though they did use flashbacks to explain history or past events, even though Tom Hanks talks 70% of the time.. there just ain't enough time to tell them all. As a book reader, though, I get to know *more* than other non-book readers do ;).

So, watch the movie, then read the book. Or, just do one of them, Co once you know who the bad guy is then.. well.. you know.

title: Too different from the book.
review:
I love movies. I especially love when great movies come from great books. The DaVinci Code happens to be my favorite book. I've been looking forward to the movie version since I first read the novel two years ago, since the book always seemed like an excellent screenplay. I went into the movie theater opening weekend with high expectations and excitement, and left confused and disappointed. I do not want to give any spoilers away, but from the very beginning of the movie, details were already changed. Now, I knew they had to change some things, but these changes were ridiculous! Not only were details cut from the movie, but things that NEVER happened in the book were in the movie. What purpose is that?? Also, I believe that as a result of the amount of controversy that surrounded the novel when it first came out, the creators of the movie decided to minimize the controversial elements. This did not help the movie. In one chapter of The DaVinci Code, Teabing and Langdon are explaining the secret of the Holy Grail to Neveu, both agreeing and on the same side. In the movie, Langdon is arguing Teabing, trying to dissuade Neveu from believing everything Teabing was saying about Mary Magdalene. The movie was lacking in suspense. Also, Langdon's character is too religious in the movie. In the book, his religion does not make up a large part of his life, whereas in the movie, it seems somewhat more important to him. What's most upsetting, however, is the missing "what if?" factor. Yes, the novel is fictional. Yet, after reading the book, you can't help thinking, "What if Dan Brown's right about something? What if maybe .... really happened?" The movie didn't have that at all.

On the other hand, if you have not yet read the book, I would recommend seeing the movie first. The DaVinci Code has excellent actors and a superb director. All and all, it is a good movie with a good plot. However, since The DaVinci Code is my favorite novel, I'm going to be too nit picky and dislike the movie, purely because it is too different from the book.

title: Sublime imagery buoys up difficulties of The DaVinci Code
review: After all the blustering and whining commentary on what is termed "wooden" about Ron Howard's handsome take on Dan Brown's hugely popular novel evaporates, perhaps someone will notice the graceful and occasionally sublime imagery employed to buoy up a difficult topic. We are taken into Langdon's vivid imagination via CGI and beautifully compelled to embrace obscure concepts. Having read Brown's book and it's source, "Holy Blood, Holy Grail", and a good deal on the Templars, and European history and art in general, I'm pretty delighted to be part of a culture that allows a writer or filmmaker to have this kind of adventure with what we consider to be the foundation belief system of Western Civilization. (And, anyway, who can complain about looking at Audrey Tautou, ever?) The real issue at question is not art, it's math: if Mary Magdalene's issue had procreated by even the minimal factor of two per generation, Christ's descendants would have outnumbered the current population of the planet by the year 825a.d.! Brown's payoff, that Sophie is Christ's sole living descendant, can only work if each successive offspring exercised extreme discipline and produced only one child per life. It's a dicey proposition that I'm not sure is adequately addressed in either book or film.

title: Gross mis-justice
review:
Little more than half the content of the book is portrayed in the movie. They seem to have just picked out the pieces that they liked best while also inventing others eg. her super-magic Jesus power to heal robert's claustrophobia. Teabing has become nothing more than a comic element with the audience laughing at most of his dialogue.

The worst thing has to be the scenes with Rossyln Chapel. The interior may be the church in question but the exterior sure ain't. For one it's a semi-ruin in the process of restoration (doesn't actually have a roof at present) and secondly does not sit atop a hill in a near jungle-like forest, it's about half way down the valley with views of the surrounding villages easily seen. How do I know this? I live in one of those villages, I've been to services at the chapel and it looks sfa like that. At the cinema in near-by Edinburgh where i went to see it the audience could be audibly heard to gasp when the scene appeared on screen with people even proclaiming "Where's that?". Such a fuss has been made over the use of the chapel in filming that i find it insulting that a CGI landscape has been used.

Apart from that, it's an OK film. Better if you haven't read the book I suppose. Bit of a non-brainer but easy to eat popcorn to.

title: I'm sure to stay longing for your next film, Ron.
review: However I love director Ron Howard, my favorite one, I don't like to mark him better than he had done. I wonder if it was related to something about the locating, nope it wasn't; it was a result to face to challenge such a bigger project or something like that. You had been enthusiastic a bit, or rather to say, you had been discouraged maybe. You had not kept a balance. You lost so-called "Tension and Relief." The original book is quite great and the script has been done so-so, however, Mr. Director, may I ask that it made me think "you had been disturbed by somebody?" I didn't see your skills somehow. The heroin, after all, was the unsuccessful. I have expected her very much. But it is the result, which is regrettable. Has she something wrong in her privacy? Or has you some by yourself, Ron? When I was asked who can make that best-seller, "The Da Vinci Code" into film, I thought you'd be the best. Eventually we had needed an Orson Welles for this sort. I guess a Hitchcock would be available anyway. It is what the book wants, isn't it. On just running around, you could not convey that noble story to the audience, We have very few scenes which they halt; it is the point of the failure, Ron. I should say one thing more that someone would remake this book in the feature. Begins in Paris; in the Leuvre; pictures of Leonaldo; and Jesus Christ had been in love..., with these marvelous stuff, you have finished them with just running wild. Oh, Christ might cry, Ron.

title: A fantastic film!
review: If your a lover of the book or not this film is fantastic. I went to see it with my friends not having read the book but really enjoyed it. So I am now wanting to read this book. The scenery was great, when they were going through Paris it really pulled me into it. This thriller really gets your heart rising and your on the edge of your seat waiting to see what happens next, with car chases and bloody violence at some parts it keeps you gripped.The acting was excellent as well, Tom Hanks the leading role really shone in this movie as he excelled at the role of a clever professor. Audery Tautou a women I happened seen acting before was amazing at her role and her and Tom Hanks's on screen chemistry also made the film enjoyable to watch. I enjoyed watching Ian Mckellen, as I think he is a great actor to begin with. Also he shows off his talent as the role of Lee Teabing. The only character I didn't enjoy watching was Stalis played by Paul Bettany, not because he is a bad actor, in fact he's an excellent actor, the reason was I was scared of him. His character was really creepy! Overall I really enjoyed this film and would recommend it, as it also had me questioning what would happen if Dan Brown was on to something and it was true. Would it show that women were equal to men, or that Jesus was a normal man? Many other questions I could ask. I hope you enjoy this film as much as I have and i definitely want to see it again.

title: Not That Bad.........Forget the critics
review: This movie was honestly not that bad. OTWN is either not intelligent or needs to see some more movies before he writes another review. Number One the the movie was cast perfectly except for Tom Hanks, but thats okay because he doesn't hurt the movie, he certainly doesn't help it, but with the other characters he really doesn't need to. Yes the character of Robert Langdon is important but there are far more interesting characters in the book and they were cast to perfection. OTWN talks of the plot as if it were bad, maybe he should try reading the book or reading anything for that matter other than a critics point of view. The plot is great. Where this movie slacks is with simple corniness. Yes it's a Ron Howard film. Yes its bound to have some corniness. I think many of us expected this for those of us who didn't we should try other Ron Howard films (ie. Ransom). So with that being said Howard doesn't steer very far off of the plot of the book, some stuff was discarded but this was definitely expected. Even now everyone I've talked to seems to have enjoyed this film. I understand its easy to criticize a movie when Peter Travers bashed it in Rolling Stone and you think that you're in the majority. But please don't compare this to National Treasure, this was far more interesting than trying to steal the Declaration and then hike to the core of the earth. Disregard the critics this one time and check this film out if you like Dan Brown's novel or you simply like science fiction stories

title: The code is broken. Into pieces. Then stamped on.
review: akiva goldsman should hang his head in shame, after writing one poor screenplay. TOM HANKS'S performance was mediocre, but I don't actually blame him for that. Who I blame is GOLDSMAN for writing such a rubbish adaptation of what was one of the best books that I have ever read. AUDREY TAUTOU's performance, was I think better than TOM HANKS'S, but only just. the only reason why I didn't give this film a 1 start was because of JEAN RENO who plays CAPTAIN FACHE, He was brilliant, and stole the show from the rest of the cast. which includes PAUL BETTANY as SILAS, and ALFRED MOLINA ( DOCTOR OCTOPUS, SPIDER-MAN 2) who's performance's I thought were okay. The direction by RON " HAPPY DAYS" HOWARD was bog standard, he has done better and should have done better here. Heres some advice, DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY and DON'T THROW AWAY THE TIME THIS FILM TAKES UP FROM YOUR LIFE.

title: disappointed
review: I would just like to express my disappointment for this movie. I am an enormous fan of this book, encouraging people to read it and enjoy it as much as I did. Last Friday night, with my tickets in hand I sat in the line for the theatre for 1 1/2 hrs so that i could get the best possible seat, only to find that my favorite book had been butchered. The ending was completely wrong (like all those documents that had been protected for hundreds of years would just be kept behind a rope that says private), and numerous important parts of the book were excluded (the first cryptex etc). Furthermore, the made everything seem to easy for it to be found, or deciphered, or broken. That was part of the essence of the book that they had to work hard to crack the codes and really think and use their brains. and the fact that teabing and langdon were fighting in the grail explanation scene (which was actually quite magnificently done) NEVER REALLY HAPPENED, it made langdon look like he was too religious to ever think that this could ever be plausible. I thought Paul Bettany did an amazing job of Silas, he really became his character, as did Audrey Toutou, however Tom hanks performance was to say the least disappointing. I did not believe him as his character.

title: This movie show why the Book Is so good
review:
When i watch it .. I already read the review in here that say that the movie is bad .... that the idea is not crazy.. I believe the plot of the movie is not bad at all .... My first impression is that the movie is not as bad as the review but Yes... few facts are 1. the movie is not as good as the book 2. if you haven't read the book it is hard to watch it.. 3. its not thrilling enough for a Great Movie

but overall i think it bring the book to live .... they follow the story.. the anti-climatic way of dan brown is also still there... ( like in all of his book)...

this movie is for the ppl who read the book and also not judge the movie as DOOMSDAY movie... ENJOY it .. it has great idea.. for ppl who has open mind.

title: Little mystery in this mystery - what a relief
review: Is it sensible to make mystery (sacrament) into a theme of a mystery (detective story)? I doubt. The genres are too different. Take this fragment from the introductory chapter of the book: "The click of an empty chamber echoed through the corridor. The curator's eyes flew open. The man glanced down at his weapon, looking almost amused. He reached for a second clip, but then seemed to reconsider, smirking calmly at Sauniere's gut. 'My work here is done.'" This is how these nasty guys always act - the more so if they are albinos. They just cannot help it. In the next few pages you get a tall blue-eyed hero and a charming heroine, and there you go. But at a certain moment a character starts to lecture on some funny, pop-art sort of religion theory; and the more he dwells on it, the more suspicious you are that the author, unbelievable as it is, believes every word of it. You need not to know about what is said of Jesus in the Dead Sea Scrolls (nothing), about the "marginal" vote of 2 to 300 something at the Council of Nicaea, or about the Priory of Sion hoax. From the very wording of Teabing's exposition it is clear that nothing of substance is revealed to his eager listeners. Right, it is just a fiction. But the driving impression that the author is dead serious about it is, uh, painful. Perhaps one should take comfort in the line by D. B. himself: "'Pain is good, monsieur,' the man said." In the movie, the SF (Sacred Feminine) promotional sequence feels much less annoying. Who cares about a slide show when there is a fine car race before it and a villain jumping from behind the door after it? The action is perpetual, although it proceeds at a rather mild pace. This is understandable. It is not appropriate for a man of letters, like the main character, to jump from one sky-draper to another attached to a rope like Tom Cruise in MI3; neither one would show good manners if setting off a couple of rockets at a nice old château near Paris. The meek behavior of the characters during the action takes, however, does not imply that one can truly sympathize with them. They are, after all, but comic book characters. All in all, when factorizing out the pretentious "revelation" scenes, the movie is not that bad. A piece of respectable craftsmanship, I would say. The mechanical development of the plot may seem a bit awkward, but the emperor of the Andersen fairy tale, too, preferred the artificial nightingale to the real one. Perhaps a distant echo of beauty can be heard even in the sounds produced by a mechanical gadget. Producing Fibonacci numbers is mechanical as well but, as Robert Langdon himself mentions in the book, if you wait long enough (in actual fact, infinitely long) you will end up with the Golden Section.

title: Nice
review:
A murder happens in the Louvre, Paris. The police is called to the scene and quickly after that a Professor in ancient symbols is called to the scene as well. What follows is the hunt for the killer and the chase after a lot of mystery, straight into Christian history.

I guess most of us know the story by now. It's been hyped to high heavens from the moment it was known that a film would be made from the book. So I won't go into the story any deeper here.

That said... I haven't read the book yet. I did thoroughly enjoy the film - it shows many analogies to films like National Treasure in that it follows a trail of frail clues through history. It's also a fairly well designed slow thriller, that sadly is just a little too predictable towards a couple of the final "secreties". No bad though, it still managed to kept me bound to it for its full length, and since that length is 149 minutes that is pretty good.

Scenery is cool. All around. Settings are done wild, and the acting of Paul Bettany jumps out. His character is played out insanely well.

In the end, I can say I thoroughly enjoyed this film. With some luck I'll get the book tomorrow, and then I'll see if that is better, like most reviewers who did read the book seem to be agreeing about.

8 out of 10 dark secrets.

title: Dan Icd Voice
review: I never read the book,but came to the film via the BBC "Chronicle" programmes 35 years ago and "The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail" Which Dan Brown did acknowledge by even giving one of his characters Sir Leigh Teabing an anagram for one of the authors of The Holy Blood!! I thoroughly enjoyed the film.What the critics got wrong is that the story is the most important element,the characters take second place.Why does there have to be a romance ? It may be interesting for people who see the film to read the "Holy Blood" and find out who the real Sauniere was,and how an impoverished priest from Rennes Le Château a small village in the foothills of the Pyrenees became a mega wealthy philanthropist for his local community for what he discovered in his church. The Da Vinci Code,great entertainment and mind provoking.

title: Almost a wonderful movie.
review: It should have been a great piece of movie making--all the fine actors and the best writers and director, etc. It is still pretty good as a movie but the saddest words are, "It might have been (great)". It seemed that many of the books most enjoyable lines, such as Remy's were left out. Also, Remo was 55 (not the young actor playing him) and "The Teacher" was "portly"...so it goes. I reread the book, again...what a read. My thanks to author Dan Brown. I don't know what happened to my favorite director, Ron Howard? I suppose he tried to please all the viewing public. If one sits on a fence, one can get a sore crotch and all that. Several friends saw it "cold" without reading the book and really enjoyed it..so perhaps it fit together better than at first viewing. I hope to see it again at Ron Howard's suggestion in an interview and hope that helps it.

title: Wonderful
review:
I thought this was a wonderful movie.

I'm not surprised by the number of bad reviews this movie has received, given it's controversial subject matter. While this movie is a work of fiction, it contains some very accurate information from Symbiology, and even paired with the several controversial theories that have been discussed for ten years if not more, I didn't see anything which I found outrageously offensive toward religious faith.

This is, after all, a work of fiction, and religious groups like Opus Dei need not worry that viewers of the movie will assume the group in the movie and book is exactly like the group in real life. Fictionalizations are part of literature and Hollywood, and 'secret societies,' and any exclusive group should expect to be misrepresented from time to time.

Then again, I may be biased, having read the book and having been exposed to the theories and speculations introduced in the book in Philosophy classes before that.

The Davinci Code is an interesting work of fiction, and a very entertaining one at that.

Casting was very well done, and even the changes made from the book to the screenplay were well thought-out.

Obviously Teabing wasn't quite as over-weight, or red-headed as in the book, but Ian McKellen was still perfect casting. As were Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou... And most everyone else appearing in the movie.

In closing, if you don't take fiction as an exposition of fact, you will enjoy this movie. But if you're looking for an explanation of accurate theories and conjecture about the life of Christ and the foundations each different church, you may want to hit up your local Public Library and do some research. If nothing else, you'll have some interesting reading for a while.

title: Great, if predictable and confusing
review: I didn't read the book, so I don't know if this follows the same line. I did start to read it but couldn't keep on going once I realized that it was just a scavenger hunt for clues. Towards the end, there was no other possible outcome than Ms. Tautou being the descendant of J.C. But the ending was very climactic. And the very very end didn't make any sense because it was using the I.M. Pei pyramid, which was a hell of a lot later than the clues were done. And what was the grandfather doing humping that girl with all the masks looking on? And the church, all its money, and it can only come up with Silas to do the dirty work of protecting the secret? Why didn't the girl get a book deal at the end? The clever historical scenes, especially the people at the time of Newton's death, were truly magical cinematic elements. I was born on Christmas Day. Why not make a movie about me?

title: Could have been much better.
review: After reading the book "The Da Vinci Code", which author Dan Brown made into a fantastic suspense thriller, I expected the same thing from the likes of master director Ron Howard. Alas, I was disappointed. Not that this is a bad movie, but unlike the book, this version seems disjointed, and not that Tom Hanks or the other actors did a bad job, but they've seen better days. It seemed to me that the script was rushed, which isn't surprising considering they had to condense a long book down into 2 hours - but because of that, the movie suffers, with more explanations necessary. That said, one interesting method Howard employed was to see Langdon's as he "sees" (aka highlights) the numbers and letters (a method Howard used with Russell Crowe's character in "A Beautiful Mind"). However, another method Howard employed, that of flashback, was too in your face, as if the audience needed to see what was being explained. Oh well, a 7 out of 10.

title: Che Valiers de Sangreal
review: I am now convinced that Hans Zimmer has taken over from John Williams as the most interesting composer of film music at this time. His score for "The Da Vinci Code" which at first hearing sounded so very subdued becomes more and more interesting with each repeated listening. I believe the movie has the same quality. It bears re-watching. I think critics are jumping too early on the "let's pan it" band wagon. It's almost impossible to take one's eyes off Audrey Tautou, or off Tom Hanks for that matter. In fact the film is impeccably cast down to the smallest role. It's hard to imagine a better adaptation of a book, and I can't imagine who could have done it better. Would that "Memoirs of a Geisha" had been handed into the skilled hands of Ron Howard and Hans Zimmer. It's hard to remember the last time I left the theatre genuinely thinking and feeling something as I did after seeing "The Da Vinci Code".

title: Well done from the perspective of a non-reader of the book
review:
First and foremost, I have to say I did not read the book prior to seeing the movie. I have started it today, but only read the prologue, thus, I saw the movie with nothing to compare it to. As with any movie, I found a variety of pros and cons, but by no means were there more cons and pros. I overall would say the movie was extremely enjoyable, and had it not been for the lack of sleep I had obtained over the past three days, might have enjoyed it more.

Lengh of the movie?: This is questionable. The movie obviously needed the time to make sure it got enough of the valid points in. However, unlike King Kong, the time didn't seem wasted or useless. I enjoyed the progression of the story, though I am sure it could have progressed at a slightly faster speed, thus keeping a little more interest early on.

Acting: The acting, I found, to be very well done. My favorite character by all means was Silas. However, from my understanding, he was bigger in the book. IF this is the case, I would have definitely liked to see more of him. Perfectly cast. By no means was Hanks bad, that isn't what I"m saying. But he did leave something to be desired in the chemistry he had on screen. Ian, of course, was great, no question there.

Cinematography: Loved it, there isn't much I can really go into without wanting to give away info, haha, but it really was very well done. Definitely caught my attention, and kept me involved in the movie.

Overall, I could go on, but I would prefer to read the book to do a full review of the movie. From the point of a movie goer, it made sense, it told the story appropriately and kept me interested.

Good job Ron Howard

title: The critics
review: I cannot believe the bad reviews this movie has gotten, the stir it has caused! it's been years since i saw some real controversy over something that is a fictional story! I've read the book and after i saw the movie i was personally amazed at how accurate it was to the narrative of it! even if some of the lines comes out cheesy at times,this for the purist is a point of honor! the fans of the book (like myself) won't be disappointed with this adaptation, it have a great cast of name actors, it has a great pacing and it's a very enjoyable movie! Look for it not as a masterpiece of cinema, but as something that is entertaining, and the experience will be good! the critics don't know jack about what they are talking!

title: Mediocre
review: Well, the first 20 minutes was rushed.. Langdon(tom hanks) was solving puzzles and codes to fast, and if you did not read the book, it might have made it very confusing.. The Actress who played the role of Sophie Nueve was miscast and portrayed the character poorly. Besides these two things the movie was great. Ian Mckellen played his part great, and if you get past the first 20-30 minutes, the movie becomes more understandable and fun.. i would recommend this movie, but you should read it first in order not to get lost with the small details that might not be noticed in the first part of the movie. .... off topic, iam now writing to burn space and to actually write enough to get this review submitted.

title: Cannot Compare to the Novel
review:
Most of the reviews I have read of this film, due to its subject material, are biased, either completely towards it, or completely against it, simply based on its accusations against Christianity. Almost none of them, however, have even mentioned anything about whether it was a faithful adaptation of the novel or not. Therefore, I believe that it is my duty to inform fans of the novel that this film will most likely disappointment you. I personally found the novel to be a great read and it was easily one of the most interesting books I've read in ages. I account this primarily to the fact that I took it merely as a piece of fiction, although the arguments it made intrigued me. The novel was a great page-turning thriller that ended every chapter with the reader wanting more, however the novel, although extremely thrilling, is not the type that is easily adaptable to film. This is due to the facts that it is neither emotionally nor psychologically deep nor does it contain very much action. I therefore did not expect much of the film, but even my low expectations weren't met by this unfaithful adaptation. My primary concerns are that a significant deal was changed for the worse. It is important that film versions of books do not copy their source material exactly and that they inject something new, however this film did little new and instead removed a few important parts of the novel. Anyway, in conclusion I was disappointed by this film because it barely maintains the suspense and thrill of the novel and does not remain, in my eyes, very faithful to it. However, if I were to solely grade it based on my expectations I would have given it a 5, but due to the fact that I'm trying to be impartial here and that if I hadn't read the novel I might have enjoyed it somewhat, I shall give it a 6 for now.

P.S. Please take this film for what it is; FICTION!!!

title: Exactly what I expected
review:
There was only a few spots in the movie that did not coincide with how it happened in the book. The few spots have nothing to do with the formation of the plot, but that is beside the point. The first one at the very beginning of the movie. Langdon is at a book signing when the police tell him about Sauniere. Almost every Dan Brown book starts out with a phone call in the middle of the night. Not a big deal and nothing to do with the plot, but it really bugged me. The second one was that they used some kid's cell phone to connect to the library when they really did go to a library and used a big database to search words like grail, blood, etc. Again, not important but wrong.

The thing that I missed the most in the movie was the information. The best parts of the book for me is when they are sitting around exchanging information. There is a scene in the book when they are at Teabing's house that consists just of them sitting around staring at each other and trying to think of different possibilities of a code for the cryptex. I missed moments like that. I also would have liked more explanation of Silas's background. I understood the flashbacks because I had read the book, but I'm not quite sure that someone who didn't read the book was going to fully understand Silas's past. They also left out things like the camera in Sauniere's office that the "Teacher" and Remy had been watching him on for months, maybe years.

Tom Hanks was terrible as Langdon. I missed the flashbacks to Langdon teaching the symbols of the sacred feminine to his class. I missed Langdon's personality. I missed the way he was able to crack a joke even though he was in an extremely dangerous situation. I also think that Sophie needed to be played as a brave and smart girl and I think the actress played her a lot dumber than she actually was. Every line she said was a question. In the book Sophie was a brilliant and cunning young woman. There was also a lot of romantic chemistry between Langdon and Sophie that I think could have been played up more. Silas was perfect. Teabing was more than amazing. Collet and Fache weren't the best, but I enjoyed them.

Overall it was an OK movie but the book is ten times better. I do suggest that you all go see it though.

title: Great movie for thinking adults
review:
I thought the DaVinci Code was an excellent movie for thinking adults. I had read the book, but did not remember many of the details. The settings were incredible and the plot made perfect sense to me. I don't understand the reviews that have ranged from negative to lukewarm. This isn't a typical action movie, but it did have me shouting out and gripping my companion at a number of places. For a progressive religious person who thinks a great deal about the history of Christianity and isn't afraid of looking at it with all of its warts, this is a great choice for viewing. Tom Hanks and Ian McClellan were excellent as was the ingénue from Amalie. The length of the movie was not noticed by me or my companion. We thought the time just flew and were totally engrossed in the plot. We both said, "Great movie. What were those reviewers thinking?" when the film ended. I was very glad we decided to see the movie for ourselves rather than paying attention to the several reviews we'd read.

Kate Goodspeed, Denver, Colorado

title: OK, sorta "Indiana Jones"/"The Game" mixture. But shoddy history.
review: Cast, director, genre, and polish save the film from absolutely awful. It's still worth seeing if you want a mediocre mix of Indiana Jones type stuff with "the game." The theory behind it is primarily bunk, with major historical errors re council of Nicea, some unnecessary overly general slugging of Christianity's view of women, and some great embellishments re Opus Dei and other groups and past events. Good choices for cast. Of course, the main reason this film will do well is because of the cast. The other booster group will be pretty much anybody who wants a movie to slave any pre-existing prejudices they have concerning organized religion, people of faith, or the church in general. Go see the film, but if you're interested in it for the theory, make sure you read some reputable academic history on this stuff first.

title: Fine adaptation
review:
I asked several people sitting nearby, at least 7 out of 10 have read the book. There are differences, at some points they simplified the story (e.g. # cryptexes), however I think the movie is true to the spirit of the original story.

I was glad to see the segment when Teabing and Langdon argue/explain the grail history in Teabing's house. It was made clear that there is controversy on important points of the grail history; this was probably ignored by those who gave the 1-3 marks to the movie out of (misplaced) "religious loyalty". (I guess the mere fact that there are / can be alternate theories or people considering them irks these reviewers.) It is worth looking at the median score for this movie: 8. I wish IMDb would show both the median and the average on the main page as well. A significantly (>1 diff) lower average than the median may indicate that some zealot's are voting the movie down.

Some parts may be difficult to understand without reading the book, for example Teabing's background was not presented fully.

Note that when reading, the reader adds a lot through their imagination. You cannot make a movie matching everyone's idea. For example my girlfriend pictured a more bulky guy for Silas, and so on.

I liked that they did not make out an obvious romance between the main heroes. There were some hints for attraction letting the viewer interpolate to his/her wish. I also liked the ending a lot, finishing with focusing the intellectual aspect (search for truth/solution/resolve whatever) and not the action, hence putting the two in excellent balance.

Some will say the movie is slow. My theory is that many moviegoers today use their imagination less and less. Using the brain is work you know. They just want all their senses overwhelmed with effects, speed, action, emotion etc. without any effort on their own. A friend of mine sometimes mentions that a movie is good/interesting but a little slow. That immediately makes me consider it!

title: Great casting but the book was better
review: These are entirely personal opinions from someone whose faith is not hampered by fiction. In my opinion this is not Dan Brown's best book and carries pride of place based on skillful manipulation of contentious material. I love a good stir, so I was really looking forward to this film. I was impressed with how much from the book they managed to pack in, I was very impressed with the casting, Reno and Tautou carried the French angle superbly, Bettany and McKellan both turned in sterling performances. At this point though it all falls apart, having been so faithful to the book, and cramming so much in I found myself squirming in the seat waiting for the end. Hanks' (or maybe his lines) did not match my expectations of an American Professor. The book for me was a real page turner, I was wholly enthralled by the pace and the ideas that circulated around the text. The film though stuttered in several places leaving me hanging and disinterested. Such a shame, it promised so much but in the end delivered a middle of the road product. The star of the film, well that has to be the glass pyramid!

title: Greeeeaaaaat movie!!
review: Fanatastic film! I always have lots lots of question regarding the Christian faith. I don't know, until now it seems hard to understand it with my logic. I think that is why people try to make theories by themselves to make it logic. But i never knew this one, especially about the code beneath Leonardo's's work on the last supper. Wow, for me this theory is a new one...that is why this film it is so intriguing for me, it catches my mind in how this film sets up another new theories about the origin of the Christian faith  again to make it logic! I never understand until now why a man could be perceive as a God and put that as the main dogma in the faith. Isn't it simple to believe a man as a mortal rather than an immortal. I cannot imagine a God being born as a human, nursed and taken care by human, educated by human then grew up to be God the Almightywell this film really workshell he grew up to be a real man, wise, handsome and in need of love from a woman.

title: The Davinci Code
review: the Da Vinci is a good movie in my opinion because the most difficult thing to do is to make a movie out of a book. And director Ron Howard has done that very well. The cast in the movie are all perfect and especially Silas (Paul Bettany). He is also my favorite in the movie so... The music by Hans Zimmer, is (as always) gorgeous. But I'm not giving it more than 8 because the trailers and commercials have made everyone think that there is a message hidden in the Mona Lisa by Leonardo Da Vinci. When actually Mona Lisa has almost nothing to do with the movie. And the end was kind of disappointing. I mean, how can you know what would happen if the heir of Jesus Christ realized who she was? But it was a wonderful treasure quest and a good bunch of special effects.

title: Disappointing
review:
Hmmmm - is there anyone else out there who read the book (in my case probably about 5 times), thought it was pretty damn good (not exactly Shakespeare in terms of the skill of the author) but a decent story nonetheless and yet was completely disappointed with the film?! I'm not going to go into storyline details but some of my feelings are listed below. 1. What was the point of Audrey Tautou's character? Yes, she looked very pretty but she had absolutely nothing to do! In the book, as the cryptologist, she solved, or at least had a very big part in solving, the riddles, puzzles and clues. On top of this, Sophie was feisty, in control and had a very major role. In the film, she simpered and pouted. Not a great performance. 2. I went to see this with a friend who had also read the book and we both agreed that if we hadn't have done, we wouldn't really have known what was going on. Before anyone jumps down my throat, I know it isn't possible to put absolutely everything from the book into the film, but I feel too much of what was important/interesting/relevant in the book was left out. 3. Why was Jean Reno's character such a thug? In the book he came across as tenacious, determined and rather bullish, but he also came across as a decent police officer and human being. In the film, he was simply portrayed as a bully.

However, there were parts of this film that were very well done. I think Paul Bettany did a really good job as Silas; although I usually avoid Tom Hanks films like the plague, I actually didn't mind him in this; the support cast generally were very good (Collet and Vernet) and the pace of the film was good. Special praise must be given to Ian McKellen who was simply phenomenal as Leigh Teabing. Without his explanation as to the Grail legend halfway through the film, I honestly believe the whole thing would have collapsed.

My advice? Wastes a couple of hours but wait for it to come out on DVD

title: This was crap!
review:
National Treasure on steroids. I couldn't believe my eyes. Don't get me wrong the story was okay but it needed serious improvement and I think I've lost a little respect for Tom Hanks. His performance was so stale. Bettany was amazing but you never sympathize with his character. I've always liked Ron Howard movies but this one lacks his usual spark and charm.

I liked it better than the book but I'm probably the only person on he planet who hated the book. There were some serious plot holes in the book and the movie didn't even attempt to fill in those blanks. What the hell? I repeat, what the hell?!

title: The Greatest Cover-up on movie history
review:
*SPOILER*SPOILER*SPOILERS* As all who read the book I saw the movie with great expectations, although mixed with the anticipation of Hollywood part on hmm lets say lower the quality of the storyline. But knowing the cast especially to m\hanks and his Oscars , and the director Ron Howard a man who directed v.good movies like beautiful mind , and Cinderella man ,and his partner (seems to be ) writer Akiva Goldsman ,I expected to be happy with the finale scene But apparently I wasn't very. Away from all the religious debates going on, away from all the hustles. Let be honest Mr. Howard and Mr. Akiva , made so many mistakes on this moving it turned at some points to become disappointing , i.e. (in my opinion ) un necessary change of places ) why did they picked up Langdon while signing the book which was actually his hotel room ( it could've been done to fit the movie and still be faithful to the book ) the ride to the museum why not showing few little seconds of the scenery while Langdon thinks things over ,small dialogues and comments made by Langdon to several characters and if you read the book you'll see that in the movie the characters were actually doing nothing why not the small talk and I mean like the comment about the symbol the detective was wearing when he met Langdon at the Louvre it would've took 30 seconds just to do this conversation But I think the film crew was busy making a movie we didn't watch, or maybe enjoying the journey to Europe The book was a great mystery from start to end, always talking about riddles and clues and symbols and anagrams. But not yet revealing anything that would harm the ending surprises and the momentum build up But hmm at the movie they decided to let Mr. Langdon just literally say it on so many occasions Like just after 30 mins or so into the movie when he tills Sophie that her grand father was preparing her with all the puzzles and games hmmm (very insightful and intelligent), they actually almost destroyed all elements of surprise

then again when they arrive at the chapel and ( oh crap ) they easily magically find the place where the grail was ( where was that on the book ) as naïve as movies can get Langdon looks at the newspaper and discovers that hmm her grand father wasn't really her grand father ( hmmm yeah ) WHY ) what benefit the movie gained by twisting the story at this point ( hmm absolutely none ) then a disaster < Langdon again with a drawing on the wall finds out and till Sophie that she's Jesus descendant ( on another word grand daughter ) again whyyyyyyyyy even if the book hinted it , it wasn't ever meant to be literally announced ( I find it very dumb ) when I 1st read the book I knew that what ever was Dan browns believe or findings , the book wasn't about then , even though he hinted some of it , but the book was pure thriller and a great fiction Oh will I need not to go any further I hate to say this ( as a great fan of the book ) but Dan browns da'vinci code was an amazing journey adventure and its no where to be found on Ron Howard's movie

I believe 6 is fair enough rating for it

title: The Code is revealed
review: This movie was held high in my expectations... Why you may ask???? Well I was told to read the book before I saw the movie... and well I did big mistake. The book is awesome but...I wish I could say the same for the Movie. As you can tell by my rating I was not very pleased. There were many parts in the movie that did not happen in the book and the parts that happened in the book that was in the movie was all wrong. The Main characters are Langdon, Sophie, Fenche, Teabing, Salias,and Bishop Aragosa. These people are all in search to find the GRAIL and the Prioty of Sion. Salias and the Bisop claim to be doing the work of God when they are actually doing the work of an old man. Who in turn wants to find the GRAIL and let the whole world know what it is. Well if you are reading this you are more than likely wondering why do you have this as a spoiler.... really I don't know maybe because more people will read it or is it that less people will read it? Well I recommend that you read the book and for this one time SKIP THE BLASTED MOVIE!!!

title: Why all the controversy?
review:
The Da Vinci Code/2006/***

Main Stars: Tom Hanks Ian McKellen Paul Bettany Audrey Tautou Jean Reno Alfred Molina

Every single person in the United States knows that this film has caused more controversy than any film in decades and decades. I don't listen to one word those people say. They might as well shut it because no one is listening to them and if anyone is listening to the people who waste their breath they're in the crowds shouting like lunatics like all the others. I think the unnecessary ranting and raving should stop because now it's just getting ridiculous. "IT'S BLASPHEMY! DON'T BELIEVE ONE WORD OF IT! DON'T SEE IT OR YOU'LL GO STRAIGHT TO HELL IN BURN IN ITS FIRING, EVIL DEPTHS!" the overly-melodramatic people roar. I will have to say for the sixth trillionth time, it's FICTION! Do NOT blame Dan Brown or Ron Howard, one of THE BEST directors of all time besides Spielberg and don't blame the actors either or the screenwriter, Akiva Goldsman who does wonderful scriptwriting for several Howard films. I also have discussed the film with three of my teachers and they all believe it is FICTION and should really be left alone and not be insulted the way it is. No, when I talked to the teachers, they said they hadn't seen it yet but they are planning on it. So even the TRUE CATHOLIC SCHOOL teachers aren't making as big a deal about it as much as these extremely annoying protesters that are really starting to get on my last nerves. But yet I tell a few students that I had seen the film and they gasp and say it is against our religion. Is it? Yes. Is it FICTION? YES! It shouldn't be offending the Catholic Church or our Lord. You know why? Because it wasn't us that thought of the theory. It was Da Vinci who thought that Jesus married Mary Magdalene and had a child and that the famous painting The Last Supper proved it. All the movie is is a fiction. A fiction with fictional characters and crisis

THE FILM: The film was far-fetched and entertaining at the same time as was the great National Treasure which I thought was much better than what the critics thought. It contained a murder mystery and also contained a few secrets which I obviously will not reveal The murder mystery was an old man that supposedly had to tell an albino (Paul Bettany) this information that is later explained in the film. The albino is part of the religious membership Opus Dei which is another religious group besides others that are mentioned in the film. Opus Dei also includes French actor Jean Reno playing the captain named Captain Fache. It also includes a bishop named Bishop Aringarosa (Alfred Molina) who also seems to be part of the Opus Dei scheme. Opus Dei seems to be portrayed as the criminal group here or at least in my eyes it is because it tries to seize the Priory of Sion's secret which is a secret religious organization. Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) is the one to solve the murder mystery. The ones that find the body pick Langdon because they think he is an expert on examining religious symbols. He is a quite impressive symbologist! His photographic memory also comes in handy during the investigation. Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou) is the woman who is gifted with wonderful experience in cryptology and who also is the woman who joins forces with Langdon with this murder mystery. The symbols and codes they find and try to find lead up to the Priory of Sion and what it is. And unless Langdon and Neveu can decipher puzzle in time everything will be pretty much be lost. And that's not good. So it kept you going with intense, preposterous scenes and even some humor from which you wouldn't expect it from, Ian McKellen as Sir Leigh Teabing. He was a very interesting character that seemed very wise and yet it was a surprising end that involved him but obviously it is not fair to tell unless you've already read the book. The reason why I'm not making this movie review as long as some of the others I write is because most of the film is secret so if I say too much you have just been told a secret from the film and you will blame me for spoiling the film for you. My lips and words are shut about the film's story now. The movie was not excellent but it was not stupid either as some of the anti-'Da Vinci' think. I thought it was good and Ron Howard, as I said in my Cinderella Man review, is becoming better and better and will soon be the Steven Spielberg of film. Movie directed by Ron Howard.

title: The movie was exceptionally cast.....except for the director.
review:
Having read the book twice, once around when it came out, and then again when i bought the paperback, i thoroughly enjoyed the book. I loved the characters, the plot, the time line it followed, everything. The movie, I can't really say the same. I thought it was a decent adaptation, though there were a few glaring omissions that would have made it much better, and a couple characters who's parts were drastically reduced who were larger characters in the book. Though the characters in the movie i found were cast very well. Though i would have liked to see someone else as Langdon, i thought Tom Hanks did quite well, as he always does. Audrey Tatou(sorry if i butchered her name)I found did very well as Sophie, and never have seeing her act before, i thought she did very well. Paul Bettany was impeccable as the misled Silas. I thought Aringarosa could have had a larger part, and how they twisted his storyline i did not like, though Alfred Molina did well with what he had. And what can i say about Ian McKellan that hasn't been said before, this man can do no wrong. He always takes what he is given and makes it his own. His scenes were the funniest, and truly got the character.

The only part cast that i had qualms with was the director, Ron Howard. Why would they give this highly controversial(whether you believe it or not)story to him. This man makes family movies. He washes down what he can to make it less a controversy so that it panders to everyone. I felt that just about anyone, including Lucas could have given this story a better treatment. My choice would have been Scorcese(again, sorry for butchering the name)to direct given his record for making "His" movie, not the "Studio" movie. Even Roman Polanski could have done well, and would have had no problem directing in France, though England would have been problematic.

All in all, the movie was decent for an adaptation, i wouldn't recommend it for a night movie, don't waste the 10 to 12 dollars, see the matinée.

title: Boy is this movie dumb
review:
Putting aside any religious reference and only looking at the movie, nothing had anything to do with anything. Langdon is supposedly an expert on religious symbols, but that hardly comes into play. He spends most of the movie following other character's leads and looking sedated. I like Tom Hanks but what was he doing? Didn't seem like he was acting as much as simply being on camera.

We've got a psychopathic masochistic killer albino monk. That's three adjectives too many for one character. It doesn't give him depth; it gives him too many scenes without plot relevance. There are flashes of flashbacks for him and for others that only serve to show parts of the characters the rest of the story couldn't figure out how to get across.

They're chased on suspicion of murder without evidence. They have intimate knowledge of every obscure religious reference they happen to need. Despite making it incredibly easy to find or entrap them, they always get away. There are clues that could mean anything but always happen to mean exactly what they think it does, except when they guess wrong the first time and realize it later. It's just dumb storytelling. They also never eat or change their clothes or use the bathroom, but one can't fault the movie too much for that. A lot of movies are the same way.

Then there's the supposed religious aspect to the story. That made less sense than anything else. How anyone would find this blasphemous instead of ludicrous is beyond me. The controversy seems to be about the idea Christ was not what the church claimed. I think they would find it much more offensive that the church, as depicted in the movie, has spent centuries killing anyone who tries to disprove that divinity. Because what sense would that make?
