The church doesn't want anyone to know their belief is a lie? Why? So they'll keep donating to the church? And if you don't we'll kill you? That's the stupidest thing I've heard this week!

I could understand a religious organization's objection to any attempt to sway the beliefs of its followers. However, if the attempt is to show proof, of which said organization is aware, that those beliefs are false...I don't get it. We know we're wrong but we'll kill anyone who tries to prove it? That doesn't make any sense. If there was actually proof they were wrong, they'd find another way to claim they were right, and deny the credibility of the evidence. They wouldn't spend two millennia killing everyone who came in contact with the proof.

And as for the proof, within the logic of the movie, there really isn't any. There's a lot of information and conjecture and assumption, but no proof. Even if they prove the one thing they're trying to, that still doesn't discount the initial religious claims. It just tells a different story.

I can't be more specific without giving things away, but there's no point. A lot of little moments in the trailer tell you all sorts of things you're not supposed to have figured out. And whenever someone or something turned out not to be what they or it appeared, it was fairly obvious, but it still didn't matter because even though I knew who was supposed to be good or bad, I couldn't tell why. I had no idea why anyone was doing anything they did or had others do for them. Totally unmotivated. Some things are explained in a throw-away manner, but that's simplistic motivation, not explanatory. "I did this because of this." It's a reason but it's not defined.

A stupid movie with nothing of interest or any moment of solid entertainment. One guy in the theater snored through most of Ian McKellen's big scene with The Last Supper, which was actually pretty dull and wholly uninformative, not to mention meaningless. No I wasn't the guy snoring. I do snore occasionally, but I don't sleep through movies.

DaVinci hardly has anything to do with this movie. It's called his code but there was almost nothing shown of his works that came from him with the purpose of mystery or hidden truth. Slightly more was done by someone else in reference to his work, but only as a point of reference. I can say that, without giving anything away, somebody leaves something for someone else behind one of his paintings, and writes in blood on the floor and the window in front of the Mona Lisa. Just a location. DaVinci himself did almost nothing to contribute to the mystery. It has nothing to do with him. If you want a fun movie about the intricate mystery of DaVinci's work and inventions, go rent Hudson Hawk. It's a lot more entertaining. It's even more realistic, and if you've seen Hudson Hawk...it ain't realistic. But it is funny.

The only truly enjoyable part of the movie was that Audrey Tautou always looked cute. I don't mean to sound like a dumb guy in saying that, but seriously...I didn't like the photography, the music annoyed me, none of the actors looked all that thrilled to be there...even she didn't seem interested in the story. But she still looked cute. For whatever that's worth.

The financial success of the movie, however ridiculous that is, probably means we'll see another Dan Brown adaptation within a couple years. Having read a pair of his paperbacks before DaVinci first hit the shelves, I can honestly say I am not looking forward the promotion of another crapfest.

title: Too long for too little
review:
In the few days before seeing the Da Vinci Code, I had heard nothing but bad things about it. Critics found it a bore, a jumbled mess, and too slow for a film such as this. Going in I expected the critics to be wrong, like they usually are to my judgment. Well, they were a little right.

Halfway through the movie i began saying, wow, when will this end? Ironically enough i was basically praying for it to end, it just moved so slow. I'm sure Ron Howard had a reason for this, but I don't know what it was. the film could have easily been 30-45 minutes shorter and it would have only helped. However, even with its slow pace there's really nothing it could use to cut.

Along with the length i noticed all the supposedly big twists were either easy to predict or not as big as they wanted. One of them i was even sure they had figured out, because they'd said it earlier in the movie, i was certain. Then they revealed it at the end, and i was surprised only because they were just BARELY revealing it.

It wasn't necessarily a bad movie. Being a catholic, i wasn't offended (though i was shaking my head almost laughing at some parts). And the acting was top notch, just what you'd expect in a film by Ron Howard. If you can finish the movie without giving up on it because it seemed so slow, it was still a good movie. nothing great, but oh well.

title: Didn't live up the book
review:
Personally, I am a gigantic fan of Dan Brown, I mean sure, he writes like an 11th grader, sure, his dialogue isn't exactly airtight, but he comes up with some of the most INCREDIBLE plots! I read the book in under 10 hours, and I was simply amazed. I remember after I read it I said "This would make a great movie!".

Ron Howard's directing was no doubt worse than Dan Brown's writing, but it wasn't unbearable, it could've been a lot better. The acting from Ian Mckellen was superb, same goes with Tom Hanks. But the plot in the movie was not informative enough, and too much was left out. If they had spent a little more time and decided what needed to be kept, and what left out, it wouldn't have been blasted by the critics.

6/10 Clayton

title: A Mutilation of a Perfectly Good Read
review: I found the DaVinci Code to be one of the most entertaining reads of my life, and it was all destroyed during the blasé and extremely drawn out plot of DaVinci Code the movie. Nothing seemed realistic, nor did anything seem to be fancifully false--it was stuck somewhere in a boring in-between. The jokes that were cracked were ridiculously cliché and a lot of the Langdon/Neveu characters are not explained. Not only was it not entertaining, the plot line seemed overly dramatized and nothing seemed genuine. I would not recommend the movie and would prefer that excited movie-goers would read the book instead. The hype of this summer blockbuster is not actually worth your time.

title: a good film, not as good if you have read the novel
review:
For the record I did read the book before viewing the movie but I will try to abstain from making this review an essay comparing the movie to the book.

First the acting, overall the actors did a fine job, however there was some room for improvement. I did particularly like the part of Ian McKellan as Sir Leigh Teabing. I thought that Audrey Tautou could have brought more the character of Sophie Neveu, there seemed to be an overall lack of chemistry between the characters of Sophie and Robert. When I first heard that Tom Hanks was picked for the lead role of Robert Langdon I was surprised, but after viewing the film I have changed my thinking, his character was very well played. Jean Reno was perfectly casted as Bezu Fache and Paul Bettany could not have been a better choice for Silas.

I did have a few issues with the screenplay, especially the fact that the movie reveals secrets far before it needs too, particularly when revealing one of the main villains. The film at points used flashbacks to explain historical data and personal backgrounds, but at a point they sometimes revealed information that would have been better if just spoken in dialog.

The film visually was very well done particularly the scenes that take place in the Louve and in the home of Ian McKellan's character Leigh Teabing. For instance visual elements were added when in the book it was simply spoken by the characters.

Now for the book-to-movie comparisons. As with any film based off a book cuts had to be made from the story to fit it all on screen, however with this film the screenwriters added elements to the story that were in no way alluded to in the original novel. I will not give too much detail on these changes but let me just comment that some of them were made in what appeared to be an attempt to cause more controversy particularly with the role of the catholic church. The film changed several major plot points that Dan Brown originally wrote, I believe some of those changes took away from the story.

Overall the film on its own does very well, had I not read the book before seeing the movie I would have thought that this makes a good mystery story, and I most likely would have been more interested in reading the original novel. However, those who have read the book upon seeing the movie might have several questions about the plot changes.

title: Just not good enough
review:
I've never been compelled to comment on anything, ever, but what is wrong with the Davinci Code that made come here and do this, i don't know. I read the book, and enjoyed every second of it. I was seeing pictures of what was happening in my head, it was great. . . But the movie just spoilt it. It was such a huge disappointment. There was not enough happening, the book seemed to hold your hand and drag you through the quest... the movie felt like it needed a push here and a shove there and it wasn't as breathtaking as the book, nor was it faithful to it. The only thing that i enjoyed was the brilliant visual explanations of gadgets and flashbacks.

I've seen tom hanks do better, i've seen Sir Ian do better too, Audrey Tautou did well, she seemed to be as shocked as i was by the whole thing. Paul Bettany, did a FANTASTIC job! The script writers decided to slash out bits that kind of killed the movie for me. But they added things like the close up of "THE LAST SUPPER" where Mary Magdelene is moved away from Peter and seems to be resting her head on Jesus' shoulder! That was amazing stuff! If someone asked me, should i go and see this film, i would ask them if they had read the book? If you've read the book, the film is a disappointment, and if u haven't read the book then u just might be compelled to comment on my comments!

title: Well shot, terrible performances
review:
Should you go see it? Yes.

Is it interesting to watch? Mostly.

Is it the best movie of the year? God no.

I enjoyed the book for the most part, except when Dan Brown insisted on going into minute detail on the symbology of the Sacred Feminine, and then repeated it over and over.

The movie on the other hand borders on boring about two thirds through and is far too long. Harrison Ford could have played the part of Robert Langdon but could have been even more wooden than Tom Hanks (at least Tom Hanks remembers to smile now and again).

Audrey Tautou was terrible, not sure if Sophie Marceau or Virginie Ledoyen would have pulled it off either...

I give it 5 or 6 out of ten for entertainment.

Just keep your expectations low and you may enjoy the ride.

title: Can you say Anti climactic?
review:
After reading the book(which I couldn't seem to put down), I was very excited to hear they were making the film. Especially, when I saw that Ron Howard would be directing the flick. Add in the stellar cast that had signed on to do the project, and it has to be a great movie right? Wrong.

The "Da Vinci Code" is pretty good, and worth the ticket price, IF(and I stress) you have read the book. However, if you haven't there's just too much historical and theoretical information being spewed to fully absorb in that short of time. At least that's how my wife and friends(whom I saw it with) felt.

Tom Hanks and Audrey Tattou displayed good chemistry, except for the last scene they are in. The acting of Hanks, Reno and McKellan was on par, but the stand out was Paul Bettany, his performance was stellar as Silas! Tattou's acting was a little weak, though.

Overall, Howard was faithful to the book, but for me it just didn't work like I had hoped. Granted, I'd had high expectations, but the film just didn't deliver.

title: So dark the con of DAN
review: Viewers...The movie came to me as a expected disappointment..like every other movie adapted from a book ( except godfather :) )If you notice closely..this is a book that has DETAILS..every page is filled with turn..twists ..and excitement..thus making it a extremely poor choice for a movie..as the movie has to cramp a full length novel into a 1.5hr movie...the main essence ..the suspense and all the excitement is lost in the movie...Tom hanks might flinch every time he sees his performance..the first of a Tom Hanks disappointment for me..The main part of the story..the decoding of the series of codes is what is exciting..which I guess Ron Howard has conveniently forgotten in his movie...my serious suggestion..if you have read the book..don't view this money making Dan/ Ron scam...you have been warned...if u haven't read the book and are looking for a complete no brainer..u are most welcome to watch the biggest cover-up in human history...BINGO

title: The Book is Better!
review: I read the book first in hopes that the movie would do it justice. My fault for being an optimist. It didn't. For the most part, the movie is similar to the book. However, there is one important part that is different, but I won't say what. I was disappointed with that. Not only that, but I thought the movie jumped around too much and left out important details that the book included. If I had not read the book first, I'm sure I would have loved the movie, but I didn't. I enjoyed the book much more and don't think the movie was very well done. Also, I thought that Tom Hanks' character in the movie took a back seat to Audrey Tatou's. I felt that he should have been the leading role. I just wish the movie had been more like the book.

title: The critics are proved wrong - once again
review:
The critics prove themselves wrong again. If opening collections of any movie are a barometers of its quality, than the box-office collections of Da Vinci code speak for themselves. The second best opening next only to Star Wars.

I haven't read the book, nor I am familiar with the European history, so I do not know as to how much justice, the scriptwriter has done to the original story, but as a thriller, Da Vinci Code is successful in making you glued to your seat for two and half hours.

The strength of the movie lies in its script. The direction and photography are excellent. The sights of London and Paris are a visual treat for somebody who has not visited those places. The movie moves at a satisfactory pace - not to slow to test your patience, nor too fast to leave you baffled.

The only minor disappointment is in form of Tom Hanks, as his character does not demand any extraordinary acting abilities. Having said that, it does not mean that even Adam Sandler or Ban Affleck would have been able to play the character of Robert Langden, but maybe it is the script and the story, that puts restriction on the character of Tom Hanks.

On the whole, the movie was fully worth my $8.95 and two and half hours of my Sunday evening. I would not mind watching the movie again.

title: Most Breathtaking Film Ever
review: I've never left a film so utterly amazed, overwhelmed, and alive. No film has ever touched every part of me the way The Da Vinci Code has. From beginning to end Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou create a riveting, hold onto your seat suspenseful environment. The consistencies in this film are absolutely amazing. Each minute detail was paid attention to in the most extraordinary way. At no time during this film was I bored or restless. It's impossible to take your eyes away for even a moment. Director Ron Howard and screenplay writer Akiva Goldsman have produced a masterpiece. I truly believe that Da Vinci himself would have judged this film likewise. It was a beautiful tribute to a genius artist and to mankind's quest for truth. I am not surprised that certain groups and individuals feel threatened by this film and its revelations. There is nothing more threatening to lies that the TRUTH! AN ABSOLUTE MUST SEE!

title: All the visuals, not much of the substance from the book
review: I have no idea why Hollywood is so afraid to write a straight adaptation from book to film (it works for Harry Potter), but they seem to feel the need to change a bunch of things that made the book great. In this case, the Da Vinci Code was a wonderfully written book (setting aside religious arguments for others to fight). But Ron Howard removed scenes that would have made the movie better, added scenes that either didn't make sense or slowed the movie down (the most egregious toward the end of the movie) and all in all made an exciting book boring. This is of no fault to the visuals, which were stunning to say the least, and were really the only thing that lived up to the book. But the screenplay was bad, the editing a bit abrupt and the cast's performance, with some exception to Ian McKellen, were as flat as flat can be. I just felt that a movie based on a book this well written, with this much hype, with a cast this great, with a director this acclaimed and especially with a budget this huge should have been far far better than it was.

title: Absolutely loved the book, however did not care for the movie
review: It is difficult to translate a book into a movie. It is even more difficult to adopt a very popular novel that almost everyone heard about or read. High public expectations do not simplify that process either. For me personally, the book was a clear winner, a page turner, a great adventure. Movie, in turn, was a dull, slow going, yawn-generating compressed adaptation. Honestly, I did not care for it at all. Having such important issues at stake as religion and the genesis of Christianity (never mind imaginary), a director could have made a very powerful story of the Da Vinci Code. Instead, Ron Howard created a very toned-down, more restrained, politically correct movie where the dynamics of the book are really not felt at all. Despite its 2 and a half hour runtime, it felt like events were rushed one on top of the other, the story was not developed, things were barely explained. I think that overall this movie was a very poor representation of the book.

title: See the film before reading the book!
review: I succumbed a month ago to buy the Da Vinci Code book and I was pleasantly surprised to find a cleverly thought out book merging fact with fiction to produce a damn good story. However, the film was sadly lacking for me as it skipped over some of the more interesting parts of the book. Obviously a film can never fully recreate every thought mentioned in the book, but there were obvious omissions which could have easily been included. (I am awaiting the DVD Director's cut edition to see if they made the cutting room floor!) The supporting cast were superb, and not something that I had obviously noticed in other films - maybe because Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou were a little disjointed together I noticed it more. Jean Reno as the 'Bull' Fache was particularly good. Without reading the book first, however, I think that viewers would have really enjoyed it as a light thriller with excellent locations and wonderful trick photography - Newton's funeral cortège for one was brilliant and brought me out in goosebumps. My husband is now reading the book AFTER seeing the film and he is now agreeing, although he did enjoy the film more than me! A few moments when I jumped or cringed kept me on my toes though, so overall not bad but could do better.

title: An entertaining book with few redeeming values loses them entirely in the movie
review:
When watching this movie the first thing I noticed was the almost total change in the character of Robert Langdon. His character was watered down simply to put a skeptic about the "true" grail in the movie. It renders any legitimate connection to Sophie ridiculous and creates the effect of no chemistry between the two leads (which may or may not be true). Particularly horrendous was the changing of the bishop's part to 'evil bishop plotting to destroy the grail and kill all those involved.' This is extremely unfaithful to the story and creates a very watered down version of the book which is made more "safe" for Christian audiences. It is appalling how changes like this were probably necessary because Americans cannot be free thinkers and instead must ban "heredical" thought.

If you enjoyed the book I would recommend going to see the movie. However, don't be surprised by the changing of the story to be more wholesome.

title: The Book and The Movie
review: Well, overall I was kind of disappointed. For any one out there I suggest going to see the movie before you read the book. This is just to the fact that the movie left out or didn't fully explain some of the things that went on in the book. If you haven't read the book I will recommend going to see this movie. IF you have already read the book don't waste your 8 dollars on a movie to go see it because your not missing out on anything. The acting in the movie was good. I mean you can't expect anything less from Tom Hanks. Another negative in the movie is all the French subtitles you have to read. In the book there are only bits and pieces of French. But in the movie you have to actually read a whole conversation in French and then it switchs back to talking in English, which I felt was very distracting. But to sum things up like I said, if you haven't read the book go ahead and see it because you will be amazed at the facts that occur. IF you have already read the book. Don't go waste your time.

title: Maybe a coconut would have helped........
review:
It took a while but after the initial absolute unbelief that Tom Hanks was to play Langdon, in what had become for me an exciting movie prospect, had subsided and I'd cleared my mind of any negative thoughts.

Benefit of doubt had been given! I now reflect on the wealth of talent in the industry, new and old. Why Tom? enters the mind once again..

With potentially better works that can be converted to the big screen, Dan Brown should take this abortion too heed before enlisting the likes of Ron Howard for future projects.

I for one look forward to Dan's next book and have no qualms if it or any previous stay within the dust jacket..

(Apologies to the supporting cast, of which most were perfect for their roles) (Apologies for my grammar too)

title: Don't believe the hype
review: Having just given my vote I am genuinely saddened to see that most people are giving this dreary money making exercise 10 out of 10. It must be fans of MacGyver, desperate to see more of the same since Richard Dean Anderson moved on to Stargate-SG1. I went to see this film with low expectations, but even these were not met by this-made-for-TV adaptation. The production as a whole seemed rather pedestrian, both writing and acting were, for the most part, poor. The cinematography wasn't the greatest, there was never a sense of foreboding no matter how many dimly lit churches the characters entered. As for the plot, which apparently makes up for everything else, I lost track of the number of anagrams,cyphers and other examples of word play and it soon became tedious. They may keep you interested when you're reading the book, but they fail to do so on screen, especially when Langdon seems to solve them so quickly only to move onto the next. I'd agree that a cryptic crossword is an engaging, thought provoking source of entertainment. But you can't seriously watch someone else solving one (being fed the answers) and say it's thought provoking. Nor is it thrilling or exciting "I need to get to a library fast". Especially when the "crossword" has been set by Dan Brown (the non-thinkers Umberto Eco). Being an atheist myself this kind of conspiracy theory should pander to my lack of belief in the divinity of Christ and the power of the Catholic Church. But it's all based on factoids and the writer's own machinations. The way Teabing glosses over the fact that the Priory of Sion was the brain child of Pierre Plantard (a hoaxer who believed he was a direct descendant of the Merovignian Kings) with "That's what THEY want you to believe" is a perfect example. I fail to see how it can be so readily accepted as the truth behind a religious conspiracy. After all "History is the search for fact NOT truth".

title: real disappointment
review: It is really quite bad. I was disappointed by Tom Hanks' and Audrey Tatou's acting, I had impression they didn't read the book, and they know nothing about their characters. Hanks was pretty unbelievable as a scientist, and I would suggest physically stronger actress for playing Sophie as Audrey is. Even it can't jeopardize the success of Dan Brown's book it can certainly blame the actors and film-makers who participated in this "fast food" movie. Thanks God for Ian McKellen. His performance is always a pleasure. I think the film was made in rush. The film-makers wanted to earn money from it as soon as possible as it is a secure blockbuster. What a pity.

title: packed it all in
review: I was surprised at how many elements of the book they packed into the movie. I wish there could have been more cohesive scene shots of the major architectural locations it was hard to tell if they were real or a set. In the Louvre they could have done some extra shots of the treasuries hidden inside. I had to laugh at the Itty Bitty cars they drive in Paris.I wasn't sure Tom Hanks could pull of the role but he did it justice. The character of Sophie Nevu was caught splendidly, although her memories of her grandfathers ceremony should have been longer. All the other characters except Aringosa were fabulous. This a great STORY and it deserves time on the big screen.

title: Beautiful Story, but false nonetheless (possible spoiler?)
review: Magnificent story and kudos to Dan Brown for his ability to arrange these happenings in a way to incite massive debate, but unfortunately, this is proved wrong, probably numerously. The Film/Novel insists the audience to rely on the ideal it is attempting to destroy or more kindly "reshape", which is Faith. If you don't want to believe it's falsities, please indulge yourselves by watching the Da Vinci Code episode of "Digging for the Truth" on the history channel. If the Marovingians were descended from Christ, they'd have Middle eastern markers in their blood, which they didn't, after it was tested in a Belgian lab.

title: The Da Vinci Catastrophe.
review:
Films rarely fit the viewers' expectations of the books, and then there are films like The Da Vinci Code. Dan Brown's novel should never have been made into a film. First of all, in the novel, the story paces itself well, keeps up the suspense for the reader, and explains its theories in detail and clearly. When converted into a film, the story dilutes itself and the pacing falls short of anything remotely exciting or suspenseful due to the interlacing explanations. Secondly, Brown's novel is plot-driven, not character-driven, so when transferred on to the big screen, Tom Hanks and Company have little to do but recount theories, stories, and throw out clues for the viewers. While the film does stick to the novel (for the most part), it cuts out quite a bit of details that may confuse someone who has never read the book before (I went with someone who hadn't). The script should have included more suspenseful and thrilling scenes, but it ends up taking itself way too seriously and kills any potential thrills. For example, even the potentially awesome scene of Sophie driving backwards through the streets of Paris was ridiculously botched by shaky camera work and lack of focus.

As for the actors' performances... The people who really walked away winning from this film were definitely Paul Bettany and Sir Ian McKellan. Bettany is absolutely brilliant in his supporting role as the albino Silas. His performance really outshines everyone else in the film, including the King of Kings in Hollywood - Tom Hanks. McKellan was blessed with the few funnier lines in the script, which is mostly why his character really shines through. However, much credit must be given to his impeccable timing in dialogue. Tom Hanks, though a brilliant actor, falls short of anything incredible in this film. He goes through the entire film (the whole whopping 2.5 hrs) with a constipated look on his face and very little creativity. However, I think that is largely due to the fact that Brown's novel lacked greatly in character development to begin with, so it's not really Hanks' fault. Audrey Tautou -- looking absolutely sexy in this film -- has her moments of high-level performances (i.e. the scene where she confronts Silas in Teabing's jet), but overall, like Hanks, has little room for character development. Fortunately, being the eye-candy of the film, she generally alleviated much of the intense and overly serious atmosphere. Tautou and Hanks did all they could with what they had, so I don't blame them for their lackluster performances. After all, both are obviously highly qualified actors. The end product of the Hanks-Tautou partnership becomes two people running around on screen recounting the legend of the Holy Grail and shooting at or being shot by people. Even more unfortunate is the fact that they have zero chemistry.

Finally, I also want to make a note that the last 10 minutes of the film was completely unnecessary and over-the-top C-O-R-N-Y. Overall, I was quite disappointed and bored with this film. The pacing was horrible, the acting was stiff, and basically, it was a poorly-presented story. However, I will admit that Ron Howard did all he could with it because frankly, I don't think this novel should have been adapted into a film in the first place.

title: The wrong man for the job
review: It's obvious after seeing The Da Vinci Code that Ron Howard was the wrong man for the job. He just doesn't have a feel for the material. This is obvious from his casting choices. Tom Hanks is all wrong for Robert Langdon, never really understanding the character he is playing, the same for Audrey Tautou. The sense of urgency that made the book such a page turner is totally absent. That said, there are some good things, most especially Paul Bettany who captures the savagery, blind devotion and anguish of Silas, and Ian McKellan as Leigh Teabing who chews up the scenery as only a great English thespian can. And despite the two and a half hour running time, I was never truly bored, but I must admit I do love a good conspiracy theory so all the details didn't bore me. Still I do think there may have been a more imaginative way of conveying the information to a visual medium. Think of what someone like Spielberg could have done with this material. Maybe in 15 or 20 years a remake will be produced by a director who better understands the material. It's been known to happen (think "Lord of the Rings" 1978). Until then, and as someone once said, the book remains after all.

title: A Visual Cliff's Notes
review:
I took the time to read a sampling of other reviews here, spanning the entire range, before writing mine. While none of them changed my opinion, many reinforced what I had already guessed I would find, which was: (a) Most (not all) of those who pan the movie had not read the book. I can understand this. My wife (read it 3 times so far) and I (read it once) agreed that if you had not read the book you might have a difficult time following or even wanting to follow the movie.

(b) Many of the bad reviews mention long periods of exposition. However, this is not only necessary in order to competently bring the book's plot to screen, but it is also faithful to the book, which contains much lengthy exposition.

(c) Many of the bad reviews - those from people who did read the book - complain about so much being left out or abridged in the movie. People, there is simply no way to cram a complete novel into a 2.5 hour movie. Deal with it.

(d) Other reviews, both good and bad, focus on the controversy or the plausibility of the plot, and certainly the media have gone bonkers over the religious implications and have gone to great lengths to dig up various spokespeople who are more than willing to froth at the mouth in front of a camera over this sacrilege or that blasphemy. Can we all please remember that the book is a work of fiction, does not pretend to be anything other than a work of fiction and, as a work of fiction, is an enjoyable and provocative romp? In case you're wondering, my own perspective here is that of a former clergy member (as is my wife). Ease up, folks.

As to our actual review, we both thought the movie was extremely well done, tremendously faithful to the novel, and we had a difficult time imagining that it could have been done any better while remaining true to its source. Given the time constraints of a movie, pretty much everything you could have expected to be there was there. We could think of three instances where there were noticeable plot alterations and in each instance the alteration served the purpose of condensing plot elements in order to suit the movie time frame. In our view, this is perfectly acceptable.

In our opinion (seemingly supported by many of the reviews here) you won't really appreciate this movie unless you've read the book first. You also won't particularly enjoy it (or the book, for that matter) if you insist that all plot elements must be plausible. My title for this review may seem like a bit of a dig, but it really isn't. About halfway through the movie, my wife remarked that she was a bit perturbed by the fact that, while so much of what she was seeing was what she had imagined in her mind's eye as she read the book, many of the characters had different faces than what she had envisioned. We both quickly realized that this was actually a tremendous compliment to the filmmakers, and was how we both perceived the movie. It was as if Mr. Howard et al had shared our personal visions, from actions to ambiance, and had succeeded in bringing this to the screen. Small quibble, then, that some of the faces didn't quite match our own imaginations.

If you've read the book and can be realistic in your expectations of how a novel can be translated to screen, we highly recommend this film. If you haven't read the book, we highly recommend you do so before you see the film. If you insist on taking any of it seriously, you might as well take a pass on both - and try lightening up a bit.

title: Actually, I missed the knights who say....ni.
review:
Whoo-boy, this is the blockbuster that never should have been.... a 'blockbuster'.

It should have been promoted as 'just another film BEFORE blockbuster season'. By that, no one would have had any BIG expectations.

I didn't read the book. And from the crowd I went with that HAD read the book, they were happier that I didn't and just watched this film as a movie. They said a lot was missing and misdirected. Sadly, I sat through the film watching so-so action, wooden acting and plots that went no where with an International cast of first class actors. Those who are harping on Tom Hanks and Audrey Tatou really shouldn't. I think they did the best with what they had to work with. This disappointment is clearly on the director, Ron Howard and the approved screenplay.

For example, during the alleged "action" scenes, I never saw such choreographed product placement. I swear, I was thinking: "I should buy a BMW. They look great!" and "I'd like to come out of a Rolls Royce like that at my wedding." The story? I didn't care.

The code? Big Whoop. If you can't figure it out in 20 minutes or less at the beginning of the picture, I feel sorry for you. I did 'nod' off at a few points, but lucky for me, got jolted awake by the audience laughing.

Tom, Audrey, Jean, Albert, Jurgen and Sir Ian did what they could with what they had. Sadly, I didn't get any build up of suspense, intrigue, international espionage and the questionable dealings of the "church". I got a tad bit of this -- and a tad bit of that but I felt like I was eating fast food....Satisfying for a moment but not very filling and the calories complied on me later are sinful for taking such an indulgence.

And yes, like many other comments I read, I sat there thinking, "Who could have done a better job directing this?" John Woo? David Lynch? No, my choice was definitely Darren Afonsky -- but any of those named above would have had you on the edge of your seat with their interpretation and view of the book. I found this two and a half hours of a film that just doesn't live up to all the hype.

It's not fair to call this a "stinker"..but it isn't a blockbuster of entertainment either. But....just to stay awake...I did have a gas humming tunes from "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" in my theater chair - clearly a better film on just a part of this issue.

title: Confusing and badly directed
review:
I did not read the book, so I am not one of those people who compare movies to books. I knew nothing about the book, characters, or story. So I am judging this movie solely on what's on the screen. I found the whole movie difficult to follow and extremely confusing. I lost track of the characters and did not believe the story logic. This is one of Ron Howard's worst directed film. He cut scenes everywhere. If two people were talking, he would cut between them. If someone picked up a glass of water---bamm! closeup of hand picking up water then cut to a closeup of person drinking water.

Subtitles were overdone. Sometimes there would be something on the screen we were supposed to pay close attention to, but unfortunately was distracted from because we were supposed to read the subtitles! The actress who played the lead french girl was annoying beyond belief. Her whiny french accent became unbearable.

I know this film was fiction, and I am sure most people know that. But I can understand why (and I am not a religious person) the church does not like this film. It unfairly puts the church down with theories that some people might think are based on real theories. I gave this movie a 3 rating but in my heart I would like to give it a 0.

title: What's the big deal?
review: What's the big deal? I mean why is almost everyone against seeing this movie? ITS FAKE! you're not going to hell if you see it, people are so ignorant these days and they need to be slapped! I just see it as just another mystery/thriller type movie. It reminds me how the REALLY Christian people made such a big deal out of Harry Potter saying it was evil and all that other crap. I wish people would just grow up and instead of saying it's evil and whatnot to just go and see it! I thought it was a good movie,I think it was very suspenseful. I will most likely be buying it when it comes out on DVD, besides I think everyone should go see this movie, unless they don't like these types of movies.

title: heartfelt rendition of novel
review:
good read, great movie experience. only mismatch, i think, was when the bishop fell shot- his suitcase was closed; and then in the next scene, the bonds are loosed, and the briefcase sprung.

audrey tautou was scintillating. i fantasized that tom's character would be the next male in line. the moment tom and audrey realize- is fabulous movie making- my hair stood up and i was breathless- even though i had read the book- seeing it was incredible.

the moment her grandmother introduces herself brought an interesting question to me- would i have allowed my grandchild to be taken from me- i think not. ever. that's biologic imperative to protect your seed, your self expression of god's gift, in a new time. i am my grandfather now, the time is now, and always will be. i think your child is the most precious thing on earth.

i gave it a nine, which is rare for me to give to an American movie.

title: Negative reviews have more to do with fear of religious right
review: Negative reviews of this film have more to do with critics fear of the religious right than any minor flaws this movie has. Is 'Da Vinci Code' a great film? Probably not, but it's a darn good film and Ron Howard stays very close to the source materials in the major points and while it relies on a great deal of actual history for elements of its back story it never claims to be anything more than a work of fiction. All performances are solid, the pacing allows for character and story development and the action pieces are exciting with out stretching believability too far. If Catholics and other Christians could accept 'The Passion' as authentic despite its reliance on works outside the Gospels and its overwhelming antisemitism then they have nothing to complain about in a movie that never attacks Jesus. As far as Albino's complaints, they do get used a lot as villains in cinema and 'Powder' hardly makes up for a stereotype based only on their skin.

title: Film-Making at it's Most Average
review:
Having read the book and being enthralled by the debatable topic it questioned (a hypothesis like that of the bible itself), I entered this film with a somewhat open mind and wondering how the movie would amuse in parts that it does not rely on the gimmick of "the holy grail".

I was disappointed. Howard is remarkably faithful to the book but does no more, and as the book can not be regarded as a particularly "good" book  a somewhat poorly written adventure essentially, the movie itself is exactly that  a slow, visually bland adventure. More effect should have been taken to make the film ACTUALLY interesting instead of a visual form of the novel.

That's not to say the film is bad, it just lacks imagination. Everything in this film is just plain average, the acting specifically where Hanks attempts a lackluster performance that comes off as forced and Tautou who seems more concerned at speaking in English than actually acting.

No doubt this film will be a box office success with the 60 million fans that have read the book, and some would find that great to great out this "truth". But it is important to remember that this theory like the nature of history is open to fallibility, especially considering the source "The Holy Blood and The Holy Grail" which make a number of ridiculous inferences. It like the bible, evolution and gravity can prove to be very different.

title: Does not stay true to the book
review: I have to admit that I am the type of person that tries to find the best in every movie I watch. Did I enjoy the movie?? Yes, I did; but only due to the anticipation I had had to endure for the past few months. Did I read the book..yes...and recently too. Perhaps this is why I was able to see all the differences in the movie. Now I fully understand the reason for hurrying the story along for the sake of film length. However why were things changed?? The ending of the movie was completely different than the book. All of a sudden he is not Sophie's grandfather??? And where did these Opus Dei come from??? Also why is Sophie's brother not even mentioned. Either way; if you haven't read the book...or at least not recently perhaps you can look over these inaccuracies...I can't.

title: If you like monologues and unnatural character interactions, look no further!
review:
I really enjoyed the original Dan Brown book, however it was hard to be anything but disappointed with the movie. Much of the mystique that engrossed millions of readers was destroyed by wooden acting and superficial treatment of key story elements. I found the first half of the movie to be particularly galling - the protagonists' interactions were simply not believable.

Worse, a huge amount of the back story was told through boring monologues. I'm not sure that there was much of an alternative, but half hour conversations alternating with ten minute action sequences does not make a great movie in my opinion.

This movie showed several glimpses of greatness, particularly in the cinematography department, but unnatural character dialogue and reactions ruined it for me.

title: whats wrong with making up a story
review: In Dan Browns book it says in the front cover fictional, he researched and created a story with accusations. He isn't saying its true or false hes a writer, he makes things up. So what if there are a lot of coincidences, if it was true, he would claim the facts to be true.In Dan Browns book it says in the front cover fictional, he researched and created a story with accusations. He isn't saying its true or false hes a writer, he makes things up. So what if there are a lot of coincidences, if it was true, he would claim the facts to be true.In Dan Browns book it says in the front cover fictional, he researched and created a story with accusations. He isn't saying its true or false hes a writer, he makes things up. So what if there are a lot of coincidences, if it was true, he would claim the facts to be true.

title: Does not stand alone from book
review:
Having been amongst the many who had read and loved The Da Vinci Code, I wasn't sure what to expect from the movie. I had heard the stories about people walking out but I wanted to see for myself if it was really that awful. The answer is, in short, it is not that bad. If you expect it to live up to the hype and the precedent set by the book, you will be disappointed. If you go in with minimal expectations expecting a typical Hollywood thriller, you will probably enjoy yourself. Readers of the book will really notice how much is missed out in the film. This may be simply due to the restrictions of the medium, as the pages of explanation of different symbols, ideas and theories are probably not easily adapted to the screen. This makes the storyline lack depth and appear superficial. The movie does not stand alone well and will be enjoyed the most by those who have knowledge of the background detail supplied by the book. Cinematically, it is enjoyable as the shots are beautiful but there is a lot of superimposing of images that are supposed to represent Langdon's thought processes as he solves puzzles which just get annoying and serve only to demonstrate the very large budget the film obviously had.

Tom Hanks does better than expected, but he lacks the intelligent charisma required by the character of Langdon. Audrey Tautou is sweet and charming as Sophie, but there is no chemistry between her and Hanks' Langdon and their relationship seems more father-daughter than anything else. The strongest performances are by Jean Reno as Captain Fache and Paul Bettany as Silas.

title: The fun must be in the fact gathering.....and Paul Bettany
review:
If you are already familiar with art history or apothrycal mythology; skip this movie. If you don't know what "apothrycal" means in terms of Catholicism, then the movie is for you. (I don't mean this in an insulting manner either.) There is a lot of explaining things, and not much really happening. For the amateur art historian, it's like watching a training video at a job you've been familiar with years and therefore drags.

*******Minimal spoiler alert******

The acting is awful. I was giddy with excitement at with Tautou being cast, but she brings the film down more than anyone. Ian McKellen brings some life into film, but the real scene stealer was Paul Bettany as the murderous, misguided, monk. I wanted to see lots more of him and in comparison to the scenes with Hanks and "Amelie" Tautou, I wanted to cheer when he was on screen.I also wanted to walk out when it was apparent that his role in the story was over, since he was the only person of interest. *****Okay again!*****

Conclusion; avoid if you know the info. But if you are not into history and such, it might be an enjoyable ride.

title: What a read! Now, what a movie!!!
review: The DaVinci Code is a fabulous, thrilling movie! Ron Howard has brought to life on the screen one of the most mesmerizing and fascinating fictional works of all time. Howard, keeping the film true to the novel, knew that would be critical to its success among its millions of devoted fans. For those who did not read the book, the occasional flashback was expertly used to tie events together. That Howard could capture all of the intricate aspects and idiosyncrasies of the novel in two and a half hours without sacrificing the integrity of the storyline is spectacular in itself. Nothing, not one iota of Dan Brown's masterpiece was lost. Howard's reward...the DVC's $225 million opening weekend. The moviegoers' reward...experiencing a "virtual reality" of this awesome read in which the main characters were expertly cast, delivering noteworthy performances. Those who read the book and loved it inherently knew that the agenda-driven naysayers and movie critics had it all wrong. And that didn't take a miracle.

title: Sophie is a character too!
review:
I watched DaVinci earlier today, and omg what a big waste of money IMO. It was laughable, and that's with pity. The facts that led to the whole theory that Jesus had a bloodline were basically forgotten, they weren't laid out like the book did. I tried to block all knowledge I had from the book, but it was hard to follow what was going on without going back to it. I had to constantly explain to my friend why things were (she was my test subject) happening.

And for chrissake there was even no mention of the golden ratio (being the math geek that I am), nada!! 1.1618....the only math mention was the Fibonacci sequence, which wasn't even explained!! Now how many people know exactly what the Fibonacci sequence is, and its relation to Phi? Plus points though to the casting of the guy who played Silas, Paul Bettany. Although his hair isn't really white, it looked good on him. Also plus points for choosing Audrey Tautou for Sophie.

Speaking of Sophie, apparently all she was was a doll. Of course we all know that she's the last descendant, but that doesn't mean you leave all the figuring out to Robert. What's the freaking point that she's a cryptologist? And not once did she mention grand-pére, which she does a lot of times in the book. Not that it matters, I just think they totally changed her character.

Finally, Robert Langdon, played by no longer suave Tom Hanks. Nicely acted yeah, but there's something missing. There's no charisma to his character, he's boring, he's not the Robert Langdon who was introduced to me in the book, he's not convincing me that what he's saying is true. Oh and he has "near-photographic memory," which was shown by floating images that sparkle and shine....oooohhh....the letters in the anagrams are shining and floating. I wish I could do that for sudoku.

title: Good but not brilliant
review:
This is one of those films where you need to read the book first or at least have a passing knowledge of the Holy Grail, Knights, the Catholic Church and Opus Dei! Poor Silas is not an ordinary hit-man! He is God's hit-man.

Oh! by the way. You need to read the Bible as well before you are qualified to watch this movie! Might help to know a little bit about London and Paris both of which are not in America. What I mean is the customs are very different on this side of the Big Pond! Once you understand the above go and watch the movie on the big screen. I found it entertaining but not brilliant. Audrey Tautou was good and Tom Hanks was acceptable. There was no 'Love Interest' as such but the relationship between Langdon and Sophie is more of a father-daughter relationship. Remember that the poor girl never really knew her father.

title: It was okay, but it had some serious holes in it
review:
My biggest problem with the film was the plot holes, most of which were motivational.

While the curator was running around thinking of complex codes, writing arcane rhymes (in a foreign language no less), stripping his clothes off, smearing himself with little-known religious symbols in his own blood and visiting the Mona Lisa and the Madonna of the Rocks for one last look and to drip some sanguine clues.... Wouldn't he have had the time to get himself some first aid, and maybe live? It was a rather herculean task for a dying man.

Teabing naturally as an expert and the mastermind of the entire plot would have wanted Langdon to come to him. But Teabing never really laid a fail-safe trail straight to him. Sophie and Langdon never would have found him if Langdon hadn't thought to call in an expert.

Fache was the most inept cop since Inspector Clouzeau. He had multiple opportunities to capture Langdon and Sophie, and let them slip through his fingers by falling for ruses anyone with a brain would have figured out.

Remy, the manservant, was not to be trusted from the beginning, and the direction made it obvious. But why go through all the rigamarole of him staying in the car to guard Silas when they were in cahoots with Teabing?

Aringarosa's character was completely inconsistent.

What was Vernet's motivation for stopping the truck? It would have made more sense for him to simply deliver them to Teabing.

All in all, it was well acted and the dialogue was good. Overall, I enjoyed it. But the writers kind of expected a huge suspension of disbelief concerning character motivation that I just couldn't swallow.

title: justice wasn't served.
review:
i loved the book, i read it three times, each time as gripped as the last. the movie wasn't, by any means, good. it lacked everything that made the book so special. it just felt like the story was just banged out, leaving intricate details to the side, details that made the book so great.

the casting of Tom Hanks as Prof Robert Langdon, was, i thought, a mistake. a much better choice would have been Kevin Spacey. Tatou as Sophie was great, Sir Ian McKellin or course was fantastic.

there wasn't anything memorable about this film. nothing stands out. the story as we all know is a great one, but the movie let me down. maybe its because the emotions and feelings one experiences whilst reading such a book cant be portrayed on film because on film its presented to you, whereas a book leaves the pictures and perceptions up to you.

one particular theme that was omitted was the relationship Sophie had with her grandfather. this is a major theme in the book. one that is reiterated hugely throughout the story. but the love that is presented to us in the book is totally over looked in the movie, i felt that the film relied on the sensationalism of the storyline too much, which in turn completely over shadowed hugely important aspects of the novel. one such aspect is the absence of the second cryptex, the second cryptex was to represent a secret held with in a chalice (womb). the password to that cryptex was "sofia" which again pushes the theme of love between grandfather and grand daughter.

another is the ritual of female worship in the basement of Jacques Sauniere, this is a pivotal point in the book that backs up the powerful theme of the divine feminimity and it is totally rushed in the movie. the detail of it in the book really hit home the importance of the sacred female

all in all i was pretty let down by it, and so to save myself from any further disappointment I am going to disassociate the book from the movie.

go to see it, and you can judge

title: Still don't know what to think
review:
Like the majority of the world, I read the book, and loved it. The beauty of the book was contained in the shock of discovering things as Langdon did. Heading into the movie, I knew all of these things and knew all the secrets of The Da Vinci code. For example, I knew Teabing was the teacher and I knew that Sophie was the blood line of Christ and all that. It's impossible for me to review a suspense story such as this because the shocking revelations that occurred in the book simply weren't shocking in the film.

That being said, I also don't think some things were presented to be as shocking as they were in the book. Especially the opening sequence in the Louvre. When Langdon cracks the codes in the beginning of the book, it is one of the most exciting points of the story. However the movie takes a while to get into its stride, a Ron Howard trait. Once it gets going, it is a decent film, nothing remarkable, but not terrible.

The casting was okay. Jean Reno, Paul Bettany, Ian McKellan, and Audrey Tattou are great in their roles. And Tom Hanks is great too, I mean he's Tom Hanks, he's never bad. I just didn't like the choice of him for Langdon when I heard it, and Hanks simply isn't what I feel that most people had in mind when they pictured the professor in their head. This is obviously opinion, but with such a STORY-based film, it seems to help when there are no huge name actors involved (Star Wars is prime example) and having perhaps the biggest actor in Hollywood in this film brings the viewer away from the story somewhat.

And finally, it is sadly a Ron Howard film. He's not really great at suspense. Good director, works well with high priced actors and big budgets, I guess that's why he was chosen, but I would have liked to see a director with a talent for suspense and darkness take this on, it would have made it much more enjoyable.

title: No That Bad
review:
Just returned from the cinema and I have to say that this film is certainly undeserving of the hammering it has received from the critics. It's no masterpiece but it is an entertaining film. If you've read the book you'll find the step by step explanations in the film annoying but if you haven't, like my wife, they are a very useful guide to the theories underpinning it.

Stand out stars are Paul Bettany as Silas and Jean Reno as the French police officer. Not sure that Tom Hanks was the best choice for Rober Langdon and his hairstyle is very dodgy - that DOES deserve the criticism!

title: A very good summer blockbuster...nothing more, nothing less
review:
did have high expectations when this project was first announced. But the final trailer plus the TV spots plus the reviews kind of lowered my expectations. But, to my surprise, the film met the high expectations I initially had.

The film starts out kind of slow, but its interesting. The score and the puzzles in the beginning keep you on the edge of your seat. Plus, there are some great action-chase scenes that make your heart skip a beat.

The film though really starts to become something amazing when Ian McKellen arrives. The way he explains history is very entertaining and it makes the mind ponder about the whole thing(even though you know in the back of your mind that it is all fiction). The puzzles get more and more interesting and even if you have read the book, you're still confused a bit about what is going on.

However, the film starts to take a turn for the worse once Ian McKellen character goes away, as it did in the book. The rest of the film is OK and just finishes everything up. It kind of makes people a bit bored.

That said, the film overall was great. WHile it may seem odd that a drama could be a summer blockbuster, the film has the qualities. Big star, big name, good acting overall(Ian was the only one who did a great job, everyone else was good) and a film that is just very entertaining, nothing more. While it does intrguie the mind, the fact that you know it is fiction sort of takes away this element after the film is over. Its just a film that keeps you very entertained for 2 and a half hours, which is what a summer blockbuster should do. Def. catch this in theaters as the theater sound is very key for this, as the score is amazing.

8/10

title: A ho-hum effort from an incredible team
review:
When you begin with Ron Howard and Tom Hanks, throw in a pretty girl and some incredibly talented "character" actors like Ian McKellan and Jean Reno, you probably would expect a grade A movie. The best I can give it is a seven, and it probably deserves that much. Hooray to Howard for not including much sex (one brief scene flashes on the screen in black and white) in a movie that has Tom Hanks pretty much mopes his way through a maze of religious demagoguery that combines reasonable historic truth with unreasonable religious fiction.

Having been one of the few who never read the book I might not catch everything, but the movie simply takes too long to get where its going, and even then the muddled ending left me questioning if it was an introduction for a sequel or actually had a meaning?

title: re: Robert Langdon's role
review:
i don't want to give much away since the movie just came out this weekend and i know there are a lot of people who haven't read the book, but last night i got into a debate with my husband as to when robert langdon was chosen for his role.

i don't know if this will make sense to anyone, but he's saying that he was "predestined" for his role since the time he'd fallen in the well. as though falling in the well actually had anything to do with why he was chose.... because he prayed. i think that's bull and that he was chosen by the grand master for his skill and knowledge and nothing more.

it's just one of those annoying arguments that i know i could have squashed if i had read the book. anyone have any idea what i mean? thanks! :)

title: ****Absolutely Boring****..
review: I can not understand why America is thinks Tom Hanks is so great an actor..he is not and this movie proves it...some scenes and script from him, I felt I was looking at a High School play. He is no where near the statue of a Jimmie Stewart as Hollywood likens him too. Ian McKellan, Jean Reno and Paul Betthany carried the movie with their acting skills..at one point I wanted yell out "just go and find the darn grail" and quit taking us around and around...Opy sorry you missed this mark with this one...but it will sell because of all the hype!!!! I wouldn't recommend it to any one, wait for video or a free cinema ticket! p.s. Tom Hanks is a phony...when he did the movie "Philadelphia" and he was interviewed on how ground breaking the movie was being the first one about aids...and they interviewed Denzel Washington...Tom said I don't care what effect it has on the world, I just want your $8.50..but Denzel said he hoped the eyes of the world would be opened to aids affecting all walks of life...now you go figure!

title: Typical Ron Howard flick, yet totally watchable
review:
Let me preface this by saying I have not read the book - I have far too much real literature to read first.

Overall, the movie was worth the $6 admission price. Granted, it was a typical Ron Howard film (everything works out in the end), but overall not too shabby. It looked nice at times, but there were instances when I asked myself "what is that shot doing in there?" There were times when I snickered at the delivery of lines, but nothing like the reports from Cannes. The actors did an adequate job. Ian McKellan was absolutely wonderful as always, and his scenes were by far the best of the whole film.

However, it did feel like the whole thing was a bit thrown together. It's hard to put my finger on it, but the narrative flow of the film, the fact that it often felt very linear despite the many 'plot twists,' and the fact that it never really had the mystery of a thriller, left me wondering "what is all the fuss about?" This could be a screenplay problem, or a directing problem - I suspect it's a combination of both.

Go see it if you're at all curious about this movie - it was worth the 2.5 hours and the price. The PG-13 rating might bring a lot of teenagers to the theater (as happened to me), but you'll probably get over it.

title: Amazing movie, stop crying over the religion part of it, it was fine
review:
I took a date to this movie and the both of us read this book, we both enjoyed it and thought the movie would be good. and in fact it was. it follows the book very well, almost exactly until the ending which is a slight change which is a little cheesy. Still i knew that the critics would say this movie was not any good, rip on the author of the book, just because it explores a different thought to religion. which is stated that it is fiction, but now they all hate the movie saying its slow, i mean the movie has action in pretty much every scene.

Go see the movie with an open mind. who cares if it thinks different than we were taught for centuries.

Thanks and i Hope this helps

title: there is a murder in the Louvre & victim's death message points to Robert Langdon
review: this is an excellent movie, as much as it could have been. the movie follows the plot closely, it does miss out on some nifty details such as how are they breaking the crypts and so on, but overall a solid effort. they do show as much as possible in 2 and a half hour, the book is long and each detail is important, hence the movie well, cannot do complete justice to it. this might be more evident for people who haven't read the book at all or are not interested in crypts and to some extent mythology. another important thing? if you don't like discussions of history and especially Christian history, don't bother to go. you wont understand or like the movie. the acting by Tom Hanks is superb and even the actress playing Sophie Neveue is great.

title: overall summary of The Da Vinci Code
review: I believe that the critics are underestimating the movie. Of course this movie is very controversial and rises many questions. But religion is always controversial. The movie talks about the hidden truth of Christianity and what the real significance of the shadyness of the catholic church. The story is historical fiction with some truth to it. Robert Langdon is a symbologist hired by the french police to decipher some symbols found on the dead body of curator of the Louvre. He meets Sophie and they begin on an epic journey to discover the secret of Christianity through piecing together clues from Da Vinci's paintings. This sends off on an chase and hunt throughout Europe to discover the truth hidden from the world for over 2000 years. But however they are being tracked by a mysterious cloaked man named Silas who tries to prevent them from discovering it. None of these characters are real. This does not that the Da Vinci Code is totally false. There is a Priory of Sion organization that existed thousands of years ago. There could be a possibility that this movie could have some truth to it. Overall i give this movie a 7 because i love religious movies and i like Ron Howard and Tom Hanks so i think that they did a good job on this movie. I do think that Tom Hanks should at least have trimmed his hair a bit. But besides that i think that the movie was brilliant and a beautiful masterpiece.

title: One of the year's best
review:
I read the book about 6 months ago because of all the hype. It was a very good book. It was suspenseful, fast-paced, and interesting. I had high hopes about the movie. I was pleased. It was exactly as I hoped it would be. The acting was decent, especially from Ian McCellean. Tom Hanks was all right, but he just seemed off, but everyone else was good in their roles.

After I walked out of the theater, I saw 3 protesters next to the red light. I mean, come on people. Don't you have anything better to do? Can't anyone understand that it is Fiction? It is a novel, which if you check the dictionary, it says work of fiction. Now, can't anyone just watch it? Come on, it's just a movie.

title: Slap in the Face to DaVinci Code Fans
review: This movie is disappointing. I am a huge fan of the book and was so excited to see this movie. I understand that they couldn't fit all of it in there but why did they change what they could fit in there. The first half was okay, but the second half ( which was the best part of the book) was changed and was almost a completely different story. The Suspense of the book was left out of the movie. The revealing of the Teacher was completely not as anticipated in the movie. I feel embarrassed for the people who have not read the book and saw the movie because I feel like they are like " this is what we have missed out on" The people who have not read the book are robbed out of hearing this great story. I feel like I have been slapped in the face. Why Dan Brown would let them get away with this, I don't know but I am very disappointed that he let this happen. I am also disappointed in Ron Howard, whom I was a big fan of before this. This is a very disappointing movie to the fans of the book!!!!

title: It's been done...
review: It was a decent flick, but... what can I say, it's been done before. Anyone see National Treasure? Mix that with religion and you get this movie... the "ease" at which he figured out puzzles reminded me of Bruce Willis in The Fifth Element. Who would have guessed that "Magneto" (Ian McKellen) would have been the bad guy in all this? OK, maybe you wouldn't see that coming, but when it happens, there's no surprise. The plot was pretty good and not overly predictable. I also expect people to destroy the glass pyramid thingy (Pyramide du Louvre) in the end to look for Jesus' wife, people are crazy and often can't tell fact from fiction, movie from reality. There are some things that would make the open-minded think, "yes, this could be possible". I'm sure it will offend some people, and those kinds of people should stay home in their closets. Like I said, it's a decent flick, go see it.

title: Sad, sad, sad
review:
I'm only giving this movie a 4/10 just because of Silas' character which seems to be the only one composed with any possible professionalism. Other than that Tom Hanks could have played the worst role in his career. Sir Gandalf Teabing (aka Ian McKellen) too plays a predictable and shallow character... closer to Mr. Chips but only for the teaching-side. Needless to mention Sophie Marceu or the lost-in-the-mess character of Jean Reno. All in all there is one thing only worst than the movie: the book (so poorly written the author should thank to the Chatolic church for the marketing).

Alfred Hitchcock would have laughed for hours... just to end up crying if he'd watched this one.

Sorry Ron... try harder next time.

title: Don't take any notice of the bad reviews
review:
I saw the film on the 20th May in a packed Leicester Square Odeon in the UK, the day after it's release. I enjoyed the book very much and was looking forward to the film, although I wasn't expecting it to be excellent as films never usually do books justice, and following the bad reviews I was a bit apprehensive.

But I found that the film was far better than I was expecting it to be, a was very pleased with what I saw, the tension was still there and the film was very well presented.

I took along my wife who has not read the book, and wasn't expecting it to be any good following the press reports, but she said that she also thoroughly enjoyed the film and was easily able to follow the story, (despite the press stating it was difficult to follow if you had not read the book.) If you have not read the book just make sure that you pay attention to the dialogue, if your mind wanders for a minute or two you may miss something important (which I suspect was the problem the critics made, ie, did not pay attention therefore lost the plot).

Definitely worth a second viewing, and will add to my DVD collection when it is released on DVD.

title: Good Movie
review: I don't see why this movie is getting such bad reviews. I did not find it to be boring and slow paced. Everyone should have known it wasn't going to be as good as the book. I took it for what is what, a theological treasure hunt. All the actors were solid in their roles. I don"t know what people expected Tom Hanks to do playing a symbolics teacher from Harvard. Thought he did a very good job. Movie deviated somewhat from the book but overall it followed it fine. Movie could not live up to the hype of the book, but what movie ever does that's based off a book.Movie is getting unfair bashing and should be seen by all cuz it will definitely make you think about the catholic church.

title: Vinci not as bad as critics suggest
review:
I have just returned from the local (packed) cinema after watching this movie - released this weekend. I hadn't expected much as the press had been full of downers, but I thought that I had enjoyed the novel so much that I had to give the film-makers a chance.

The list of talented actors that appear, even in some of the minor roles, is very impressive. Not one lets us down. The two primary leads do well, although I had the feeling that Hanks wasn't comfortable, and the chemistry between he and Tautou didn't come off in my opinion. But, as I said, each played their parts well.

Those that have read the book, I would say that you will enjoy the film, but do keep in mind that such a long novel cannot carry the whole story to the silver screen. Those that haven't read the book, and I think there's about 2 people on Easter Island and 1 in Nepal that haven't, you need a brief outline of the jist of the story before you go.

Conclusion, not as bad as the critics say it is, and worth the cost of admission.

title: A good Watch.
review: We came to a general consensus that we all enjoyed the movie pretty well. My wife especially seemed to enjoy it. We both enjoyed it for the same reasons I enjoyed the Angels and Demons book. It does a good job of undermining the Catholic power base and contrary to what anyone will tell you it is actually pretty factual. The events described were far closer to the truth than anything the church would have one believe. For me the movie, like the Angel and Demons book, was puerile in its overuse of meaningless symbology, stuff I outgrew when I was 13 or 14. Arcane , bizarre combinations of numbers and obscure references that some poor soul scribbles in blood as he is dying - give me a break please. I only add this as my contribution to what I didn't enjoy about the movie and why I rate it lower than an 8 or a 9. Why would ANY person write anything backwards in mirror writing - just to make it harder to read ?. Like I say - things I did when I was first in grammar school and got a kick out of it. I thought Tom Hanks and Amelie Tatou did a very credible job contrary to what some critics said. Tom Hanks made a much better scholarly University expert type than they seemed to be looking for. I heard one review on the radio where they said something to the effect of he couldn't pull of the polished smooth character he was supposed to be. I read the book. He wasn't purported to be that at all. Tom Hanks was excellent in his role and Audrey is , as usual , divine. A good watch.

title: Great Movie
review: I don't get all of the criticism of the movie. Maybe it's because I have not read the book. The movie was over 2 hours long and I enjoyed every minute of it. I am usually a very critical movie goer and I really believe that this movie is being unfairly attacked. Everyone in my theater seemed to like the movie. They all applauded at the end. See it for yourself and decide don't listen to the critics. One critic claimed that Tom Hanks gave a mechanical performance. Tom Hanks, the Oscar winner? How was Tom Hanks suppose to act? He is playing the role of a professor of symbology. I would think that a professor in that field would be a little mechanical. He surely wouldn't be a James Bond type.

title: The Da Vinci Code was great!! *spoilers*
review: *SPOILERS* I thought it was great stayed very true to the book, and it even had some funny stuff to it to which was enjoyable (like Sophie trying to walk on water at the end) I also lost my breathe when they put the epilogue to the book in the movie as well, when Tom Hanks was praying on top of the inverted pyramid, I was worried they wouldn't put it in but I was so happy when they did, and also I enjoyed the police following the bar of soap! I thought that was great too, and I think Ian McKellan did a fantastic job as Teabing. I think they did great though with all the casting the guy who played Andre Vernet was good too.

title: good movie, bad ending
review: Generally the movie was good but there where a few flaws. The worst thing about the movie was the ending they search the world for the holy grail to find it was the girl he was travelling with. this was predictable but that was not the end, Robert Langdon(Hanks)cuts himself shaving, looks at the drain then reads the book. He leaves the place where he is staying and walks down the street,kneels down and thats the end. what was the point in that there was nothing really special, in my opinion it ruined the film. The best part of the film was the part when they where getting chase by police in Paris. It was very exciting and thrilling.

title: It is what it is: a fictional thriller
review:
For starters, let me say that while I did not read the novel I can imagine the validity of "the book was better" type arguments; the same could be argued for the Lord of the Rings trilogy.

That being said, I enjoyed this movie. It was a good thriller with an interesting plot, good acting, and decent writing (though it would be unfair to blame the script writers when I understand that Brown did not provide masterful prose in the first place). In short, I was entirely entertained and left the theater satisfied. It is unfortunate that this film receives such an undue amount of scrutiny due to its controversial subject matter; essentially, there are milions who would not give any film with this subject a good rating no matter how good it was.

title: I wonder if there could be more boring 3 hours
review:
You can read a book, watch a football match, learn two dozens of words in foreign language, walk the dog, meet a friend. You can even just stay in bed and stare at the wall. Each of this would be much more useful then watching The Da Vinci Code. This movie is ridiculous and boring at the same time, so that you're getting nervous choosing between laugh and yawning while watching it.

Mr Brown realized that his theory lacks of logic, facts, proofs, evidences and, the most important, originality. Actually, his book is a total fiction of quite a mediocre person who expected that his readers never attended history classes or have no idea of who Da Vinci was. Or never have been to Paris. (Actually, I don't know, what audience he expected to impress?) So he spent dozens of pages trying to explain what makes Sophie Christ's descendant and The Da Vinci Code - an interesting book.

The creators of the movie lack of screen time, so the whole picture consists of huge gaps and of situation that have no any sense or explanation. I wonder, why didn't they put a based-on-a-true-story stuff at the very beginning. That would allow them to avoid those funny attempts to gather Da Vinci, Christ, Maria Magdalena, emperor Constantin, Isaac Newton, Opus Dei, st Grail and etc. together.

Instead of making a Harry Potter-style story, in which fiction is on the surface and is a part of the game, they made it seriously, as if they would be writing a new Byble. I wonder if they have ever read a single history study? I don't count mr Brown's books! And what specially makes me wonder is the reaction of the church. The only goal that they reached is that they really helped the producers to spend less money on the promotion.

I wish they'd protest against war or gather money for starving children in Africa with the same strength. That would really helped to make the church's image more convincing and closer to what is written in the Byble.

title: Great if you have an open mind, are not Christian, and do not love the book to the T.
review:
I think a lot of people are not giving this movie enough credit.
