Yes, if you're a Christian you will probably dislike the movie just because it goes against everything you've ever been told about Christianity and obviously no one wants to be told their religion is a lie. And yes, if you love the book you obviously will not like the changes to the movie. But other than that if you just see the movie for what it is, a movie, you should really enjoy this take on religion and women.

The movie tells the story of a different side of religion and how it was planned and defined by not a few people who wrote the bible, but by leaders of all the religions around at the time of its conception to establish Christianity to the world.

Definitely worth seeing, Christian or not.

title: Feeble, Formulaic and Dull
review: I suppose you would call this a 'worthy and honest' adaptation of the book ... but unfortunately the quality of the novel really needs a bit more effort to make it good entertainment let alone a good film. Whereas Crichtons novels read like film scripts and need little tinkering with, this is a ripping yarn within a flawed book that needs a lot of 'oomph' to make it work. Bettany and Reno are good, Hanks and Tatou are wooden, McKellen overacts like a demented victorian shakespearian thespian ... and most of the supporting cast is sub-wooden - nay ... concrete... to say the least. There is no characterisation that engenders any empathy .. except Bettany's ... whose side story would have made a better film in itself alone ... and the final denouement is flat and mawkish in the extreme. It was along 150 minutes ... which is bizarre as the books pages fly. Just how they managed to de-excite this film beats me with all the money and alleged talent at their disposal. OK it's a mildly entertaining evening out .... but it looked pretty thin stuff even compared to Woody Allens slight tale 'Match Point' which I saw in the same cinema the night before (with 6 people instead of a full house) ... which left me with a much more lasting impression and more food for thought. Shame. It could have been so much better.

title: Excellent movie; very close to the book
review:
I thought this movie was super! It did a very good job of following the book's story line -- just a couple of small deviations.

The only potential issues are where the movie had to "speed up" in order to finish in time. These are spots the book readers will notice that the movie lacks some detail.

As an action / adventure movie, it did a good job living up to expectations. I'm not quite sure why anyone would rate this movie on the lower scale expect, perhaps, just to "knock it down" because of its approach on Christianity.

We need to look at this as a movie. It's entertainment. Enjoy it!

title: Good Adaptation out of the book
review: As I liked the book so much, I was afraid of getting deception with the movie. Fortunately that wasn't the case - I liked it very much! Even though I liked the book the most (mainly because it exploits the subject much better and explains everything in detail to the reader), the film is very good - it's a very good adaptation most of the time. Due to obvious time-limitations, some parts were ripped off. Most of them weren't really necessary, but there are two or three that shouldn't have been suppressed - reason why my vote isn't higher. In my opinion the end is even better in the movie. The cast offered us some very good performances (specially Tom Hanks).

title: And I thought the book was disappointing!
review:
And I thought the book was disappointing! Well I've now got a newfound appreciation for it despite its horrific writing style--all it took was seeing the movie!

Let me preface the remainder of this review by noting that I do not abide by Catholicism and was not offended by the story's subject matter--if anything, I was disappointed that the "secret" was essentially a puff of hot air and, in the real world, would never muster enough attention to threaten the Catholic church.

For the "biggest movie of the summer" this has got to be one of the worst. I read the book about three days before the film's release and, admittedly, was quite disappointed with it. The film however, makes the book look like a Pulitzer Prize winner.

Tom Hanks was an awful choice. His makeup was in poor taste and his wardrobe lacked the intellectual feel Langdon *should* give off. His on-screen chemistry with Audrey Tautou just wasn't there. Most of their scenes--and hence the bulk of the film--felt awkwardly acted. The production value also seemed oddly low for a book boasting over 40 million copies sold; It's as if the producers felt the second-rate book deserved a second-rate screen adaptation or they had simply spent their budget hiring Ron Howard and Tom Hanks.

Let's face it: Screen writers add and remove elements when adapting a screenplay from a novel. In this case it is painfully obvious that their choices were not entirely prudent. The most obvious case was the initial scene in the Louvre which was insultingly short and suspense-free. The scene at Rosslyn was equally strange and poorly acted/directed--the dialogue was embarrassingly awkward.

Wait for the DVD and avoid the long lines and protesters who are unable to distinguish between entertainment and a threat to reality!

title: Enjoyable and thought provoking, but could have been better !
review:
I have just seen the film. I did not read the book.

  • First and foremost I have to say this: I am a scientist and I also believe in God (who created everything, including life, and the process of evolution, and we all are, in a sense, indirectly His sons and His daughters) but I am not a Christian (I do not believe God is man, and man is God, and I do not believe in universal salvation, only individual) and I am not dogmatic. Therefore I cannot be offended. I am open to anything. With respect to what Jesus Christ is or was: I am convinced the great Jewish man Jesus of Nazareth really existed, and I accept many possible versions regarding his life.


  • With respect to the film: The film is watchable, and even enjoyable, though the plot is not always easy to follow. It is, unfortunately, not a great adventure, thriller, conspiracy, historical, philosophical, or detective film. The main flaw is the story, the sequence of events, the connections between various scenes. As a result, what is hard to believe is not Akiva Goldsman's and Dan Brown's thesis regarding Jesus and Christianity in general (I am willing to believe it), but their own story, i.e. the film itself. The acting also seems a little bit forced. Good performance, but I have seen them doing better in much more memorable films: Hanks ("Philadelphia", 1993), Tautou ("Le fabuleux destin d'Amélie Poulain", 2001), McKellen ("Richard III", 1995), Reno ("Leon", 1994). Prochnow ("Das Boot", 1981).


  • Watch and enjoy the film  great places in France and England to see in real life (faith was always at the origin of memorable art: painting, architecture), however, if, like me, you are not dogmatic and, at the same time wish to watch a much better film, watch "The "Last Temptation of Christ" (1988) with Willem Dafoe, Harvey Keitel, Barbara Hershey, directed by Martin Scorsese, written by Paul Schrader, music by Peter Gabriel, and based on the very good book by Nikos Kazantzakis, who also wrote Alexis Zorba, upon which the film "Zorba The Greek" (1964) with Anthony Quinn was made.

title: the book is better
review: yes we all know the controversy about this movie being made but the book was a best selling novel, it had to be made into a movie. the book is better but I'm not taking anything away from the film because the film is good but i preferred the book and the film was too long too. i went to see it with someone who had never read the book and he loved it and it convinced him that maybe there is a conspiracy going on, for me I'm in between did Jesus have an affair with a prostitute, possibly!go and see it no matter what your religious beliefs are, the facts are there leonardo da vinci has the facts in pictures,the acting is brilliant especially tom hanks, ian mckellen is brilliant as usual and jean reno who i respect a lot had a good performance

title: Above average, but lacks the depth of the novel
review:
No need to go on about the story line, as everyone probably knows it by heart now.

Now, these comments come from someone who has read the book, and found it better.

I just thought the film was pretty good, but focused on other things than I did when reading the book - way too many violins at the end if you get my point - and that Silas as a character has been hollowed out and made to be nothing more than a maniacal murderer. I understand it is difficult to elaborate on a character in a film where the storyline is already pretty complicated, but where as you may have had some sympathy for his actions as a result of the past, when reading the book, you would have none from seeing the film.

I didn't have very high expectations on Hanks as he was never one I'd have picked for the part and I wasn't positively surprised either. McKellen on the other hand was as good as ever, no surprises there. Although I pictured Reno as Fache when reading the book, I found he was given little to work with and I have seen him do better in other films, Leon is still a firm favorite there.

All in all, I'd recommend people to read the book and wait for the film to come on DVD unless you're a total film freak.....

title: awesome movie
review: for all those other da vinci code buffs out there, the movie pretty much remains true 2 the book, although there are some minor changes to some of the scenes, although they are not significant changes and do not ruin the plot line in anyway shape or form.... for all the others, due to the pace of the movie, it is best if you do read the book beforehand, otherwise you can get a little lost in some parts. all in all a great movie, with some brilliant acting by all cast members and great direction from Ron Howard. a movie well worth seeing... well worth the wait... can't wait to see the prequel, angels and demons, if and when they decide to make it!

title: Just not that good...
review: So I saw the Howard/Hanks collabo having already read the book and feeling that it was a very entertaining piece of fiction. With that understanding, I entered the movie hoping that the filmmakers could credit the human race with enough intelligence to realize that since this is a MOVIE, its value is ENTERTAINMENT (for the most part). Unfortunately, we have not earned that credit, so instead the movie is dumbed down to the lowest common denominator and so wrapped up in presenting the movie without upsetting anyone that the opportunity awarded to a controversial film to open lines of communication is completely overlooked in light of the low quality of the film itself. I am very curious as to what happened to the Oscar-winning Hanks as well. I'm still not sure if the role was just not right for him, or if he just realized half-way through filming that he didn't want to be there anymore. Audrey Tautou didn't do a bad job, but the Sophie character is written so weak, I felt sorry for her the entire time. In replacing Dan Brown's strong female counterpoint with the weak woman so dependent on Langdon, I find a certain sad irony. The ideas presented by the Da Vinci Code are revolutionary partly because they back-up the idea that women are strong, powerful beings forced into a role of subservience by the men who lead the Church. It must really stink for a woman today to be feeling those same outdated pressures in Hollywood. As for the rest of the film, the cinematography was OK, Ian McKellan was a riot (just because he could be, was the only real spark in film), and the two and a half hour running time was uncalled for, especially with this dragging storyline. SO DISAPPOINTING.

title: Constroversory aside... it's a very entertaining movie
review:
I will get this out of the way first. I read the book "The Da Vinci Code" when it was first released some years ago & I thought it was very entertaining. First let me say that I'm not religious & I saw this movie with four devout Christians & one other non-religious person. Out of all of them, I was the only one that had read the book. Upon the movie's completion, we all talked about the movie and everyone liked it, the Christians didn't believe it & that's it. There was no yelling at each other... no screaming... no claim's of 'heresey, etc. We all were able to discuss the movie as a form of ENTERTAINMENT not religious fact. Upon leaving the theater, we were approached by a Christian group asking us, if we had seen the Da Vinci Code, we answered yes & immediately they gave us a pamphlet written by a Pastor about the Da Vinci Code. This movie, will not cause Christian's to loose their faith. I encourage anyone who see's the movie, reads the book or even hears anything about the storyline to do your on research. There is a plethora of books on the subject coming out every few weeks. Now onto my review...

I thought Ron Howard did a fantastic job with directing, some of the cinematography is just beautiful, particularly the scenes inside the Louvre. He kept the movie flowing at a good pace, since if he followed the book, page for page, we would have had to watch a mini-series. Tom Hank's was convincing as 'Robert Langdon', a cryptologist from Harvard who is wanted for murder he didn't commit. Audrey Tautou was also fantastic as Sophie Neveu, a French CSI'Esq member. But the real scene stealer was without a doubt Sir Ian McKellen as Sir Leigh Teabing, an eccentric billionaire Grail fanatic. He played the part perfectly, adding a charm to the film, it would have lacked without him. Paul Bettany & Jean Reno were also convincing in their roles.

Overall, I gave the movie a 7/10, there are a few things they have added, such as dialog (Langdon saying, "I need a library. Fast!) was a little 'overdone.' See the movie, ignore the protester's & just got to be entertained not to be taught a theology lesson.

title: so dark the con of trailers...
review:
I didn't read the book and maybe thats why i found myself lost with all the bible talk (or maybe i should have read the bible?). but anyways, it was confusing none the less.

the main story was not hard to follow, it was how the movie gave no time to absorb the details of the information being discovered. i felt the movie really ask a lot for people to believe everything the movie was saying about the Da Vinci paintings. i don't recall if the movie actually tells us why da vinci had a relation to the bible, maybe i need to see it again (maybe this is the con of man, or Hollywood).

For all the hype this movie got it was very disappointing. the most disappointing part was when the movie suddenly turned into "National Treasure". after that i lost all taste for it.

i really feel though i need to go see a different movie before the weekend is over just so i don't feel i wasted my free time.

i recommend that you wait for the cheap theater or borrow the DVD from someone (cause you know everyone's gonna buy it).

title: An apropos equivalent of the (im)famous(?) novel
review: While the movie does an excellent job of portraying the book, it also speaks to the ambiguity and uncertainty most people have about the book. The concepts of the mind seeing what it wants to and believing in something without proof are prevalent in the movie. Of course, being the movie adaptation, some things have to be changed. Character motivations have changed from the book, but the story remains essentially the same. There is more argument between Langdon and Teabing, which speaks to the ambiguity mentioned earlier. All things considered, it's a beautifully done movie. It won't get any Oscar nods, but that's not the reason movies are made.

title: Sounds strange... and wrong...
review:
Let's start saying I'm a catholic, but I read the book and found it well written and very enjoyable, that means no religious prejudice is forcing this comment into an hypercritic direction.

It is a quite obvious comment that "the movie is less valuable then the book", but in this specific situation it is the only thing you can say when getting out from theater. You get an unpleasant impression that nearly everything is wrong or, at least, is non at the book level, starting from the cast (consider Tom Hanks is normally good and I personally like him, but he is wrong choice for Langdon and he also gives an under his level performance) and going on with some dialogues (you will find quotes from the book that are not really needed and then some needed quote that is missing).

In the end, I must say it is not a completely bad movie and a couple of my friends found it pretty good, but it gets bad if you think what kind of raw materials and worldwide expectations they had in hand to forge it. I give them all a 6 just because I'm sure the book was great (as a novel, not as an historical text) but I also have to admit that it was not simple for sure to be translated on the big screen, especially if your audience, having read the book, is already aware of all the main revelations in the plot.

title: Not as good as the novel...
review:
...but few movies are. Too much was changed from the book to the movie, including a critical scene with DaVinci's masterpiece "Madonna on the Rocks," the importance of the Golden Ratio to the artist (as in "Vitruvian Man"), and a scene with the cryptic (it had two layers of codes in the book, only one in the movie).

It was cool to see DaVinci's paintings, particularly "The Last Supper," used in the context of the book. I had a hard time picturing the details of the painting, specifically the posing of Mary Magdalene and Jesus.

I thought all along that Tom Hanks (one of my favorite actors) was a bit miscast as Langdon, but he was credible. Audrey Tautou is understatedly beautiful and sophisticated as Princess Sophie. Jean Reno played Capt. Fache as if the role was written for him. Ian "Gandolf" McKellan was perfect as the obsessive Grail historian Leigh Teabing. And Paul Bettany was spooky as the Opus Dei assassin Silas.

Bottom line, "The DaVinci Code" didn't live up to the hype, but was nowhere near as bad as the critics say. 7 out of 10.

and now, a rant: The worst part of The DaVinci Code had nothing to do with either the book or the movie. We had to sit through 18 minutes of commercials (yes, commercials!) before the previews. Now I don't know about you the reader, but I go to the movies to escape the commercials. People in the theater were actually booing and yelling. I don't drop $9.50 on a movie so I can watch commercials that I can see at home. In my theater in North Jersey, the commercials were for Cablevision and its subsidiaries I/O digital cable and Optimum Online, none of which are even available in my area.

title: Almost a masterpiece...
review: The casting was inspired, the script grew almost organically from the original novel by Dan Brown, the acting was everything that a fan of the story could ask for, showing yet again what a talented and passionate movie-maker Ron Howard is. His movies always tell a story about something, teaching and informing his audience about the human condition. "The Da Vinci Code" has proved that there are huge numbers of people who appreciate and are entertained by a mystery, and who are seekers of knowledge about themselves and others. From now on there will be another great divider of the people - The Pro Da Vinci Coders and the others!(Poor things!)I don't think anyone could have brought this novel to life as a movie better than Ron Howard's cast and crew have done.

title: This is not your typical Hollywood movie; fanatics in audience.
review: The Da Vinci Code is a great movie and very close to the book. Acting is absolutely amazing  I believed every scene. Applause at the end of the movie was unexpected since several viewers were trying to deliberately ruin the movie by making snoring noises and loudly telling to each other how boring this movie is. So you can safely assume that you will see some fanatics that will try to spoil your movie experience. If you are not familiar with at least some of the historical facts discussed in the movie you will have a hard time following the logic of it. This is not your typical Hollywood movie and it is better then the book in many aspects. Book was trying to capture the audience by clever tricks and movie was trying to show unusual insight on human history.

title: Quite a good movie but a little disappointing...................
review:
I have recently seen it on Friday and my overall comment is that the movie is actually quite good but there are some points that I want clear out.

First of all,in the book Sophie is the one who suppose to decode the password, the code, etc. Howvever in the movie, it is Rober who has done the job of Sophie. Therefore this made the role of Sophie meaningless. Also Robert is just a symbologist. How can he know so much things about cryptography? Secondly, when Teabing killed his servant, at the same time, he is revealed as the "teacher". May be because I have read the book before, this scene can not give me a stunning feeling. I think this scene can be supplemented with more music in order to more fully demonstrate the "stunning" or "shocked" feeling.

Overall this is quite a good movie for it is not easy to refer back to the history without much talking. Ron cleverly used some colourlful and beautiful visual effect to demonstrate it in order to avoid boredom.

title: I didn't read the book but I loved the film
review:
I loved it. It was a very good thriller and detective. It isn't boring like some people said. If you don't pay attention for a small moment you can't follow it anymore. Especially if you didn't read the book, like me, if you read it you can follow it easily I think. I didn't read the book but I loved the film.

Robert Langdon he has to solve a murder. He is a suspect because the man who is killed wrote a lot of things with his blood before he died 1 was "P.S. contact Robert Langdon". The granddaughter of the man who was killed helps Robert Langdon solve the murder. They find lots of things that leads them to something else...Not only the murderer...

title: Fact or Fiction?
review:
The book of The Da Vinci Code has been out for a couple of years, and people have had plenty of time to check out the so-called "facts" presented in the book.

The main lie in Da Vinci Code is that Jesus was secretly married to Mary Magdalene. Is that fact or fabrication? Let's check out an eyewitness' account and think about it. According to Apostle John, who was the eyewitness of the crucifixion, Jesus made arrangements for Mary, his mother, while hanging on the cross. Mary Magdalene was standing right next to her. Yet, Jesus made no arrangement for her. If Jesus were secretly married to Mary Magdalene, wouldn't he at least have said something to her before he died? But John recorded nothing that Jesus said to her or about her.

Dan Brown based his assumed marriage on an account in one of the Gnostic Gospels, written hundreds of years after the death of Christ, using someone else's name (Thomas, Judas, Philip, etc.) who clearly did not write it years after their death. The account said Jesus kissed Mary Magdalene  (then the page was torn, and the account was incomplete). But Dan Brown's highly imaginative and heavily polluted mind jumped to the conclusion that Jesus must have kissed her on her lips, which led to the conclusion of this assumed marriage. How do we know Jesus did not kiss her on her forehead or on her cheek? I for one would rather believe the person who lived with Jesus for years, and not give any credit to an account written under a pseudo-name by someone who lived hundreds of years afterward.

So this lie alone by Dan Brown, deliberately and purposely presented, would disqualify this book, or the movie for that matter, as a historically accurate account. In fact, judging from the motive of writing this book, I would not hesitate to say that Dan wrote it to satisfy his anti-Christian bias; and so did Hollywood in producing this movie out of the same bias. If this book were written about Mohammed or about Islam out of even less amount of bias, Dan Brown will certainly be living in hiding now, like the author of The Satanic Verses' author Salman Rushdie still does today. But has Dan Brown ever thought about his own eternity? Though Dan Brown is making $millions now, can he take one cent with him when he dies?

title: Controversial because...
review: The strongest statement made by "The Da Vinci Code" is one of irony. The fear this movie has generated among Christians does not stem directly from the possibility of Mary Magdalene being Jesus' wife and having children by her. No, the most damaging idea the Da Vinci Code conveys to Christianity is the possibility that Jesus was not divine. The DVC posits that Jesus was just a man and it was the church, as a powerful institution, that perpetuated the legend of his divinity. Over time and through tradition, like so many other legends, Jesus' divinity became accepted as fact. The DVC makes viewers think about which possibility is more plausible; was Jesus a normal human being or was he God. Which seems more likely to you? Devout Christians don't want people to think about this because it strikes at the pillar of their beliefs. The sweet irony is that "The Da Vinci Code" presents the question of Jesus' divinity as fiction and Christianity presents it as fact! It may be that the movie is fact (concerning Jesus' divinity) and the religion is fiction. That's the blasphemy. It's nicely demonstrated by Sophie, at the movie's end.

title: Good vehicle for Audrey Tautou
review: I loved so this movie.And mainly because i didn't heard to the critics that All,included Church,did to the newest Ron Howard's masterpiece.I really enjoyed this movie,even because when i red Dan Brown's book,i said to myself,"What a fantastic book!The upcoming film should be just better"!I don't know if what the film and the book say it's all true,i think that it's just FICTION..however,coming back to the film,is so good,well shooted,doesn't annoyes never,and all the main actors are fantastic,beginning from Tom Hanks,that always sounds a bravo actor,to Audrey Tautou,that will break in USA as a French actress has never made before.Last but not least Jean REno,incredible as bezu Fache,a quick overrated Paul Bettany as Silas,and Alfred "Ock" Molina and Sir Ian Mc Kellen.

title: This is the most distorted version of a movie ever
review: Up to the point on the airplane with the British dude..everything seemed alright after that...i don't know . Seem like everything was choppy and the end was there... Like 2 and half hours or more wasted. I think this movie lacked a lot. If I didn't read the book I would say i would be lost. READ the book it would help over all the movie has pretty cool scenery and nice angle shots. Some flash backs or what nots. But it was cool. I liked it. but was a little disappointed in it over all. I hope that there is another version which is better. Opie you suck. I bet the fonz could do better. LOL So Please do not think about watching this movie, nor read this book unless you are really interested in the conspiracy. Just joking, just needed to fill up space so this comment can go through. Read it , Watch it, and then Compare it. Book 10 , movie 4, time wasted watching this...priceless. actually 12 dollars..Hope you all enjoy seeing this, comment and share your opinions.

title: It was aright
review: The movie was alright. As a MOVIE, its actually pretty good. There are a few things that were weird... like the secret messages that were "left" by DiVinci, I don't think he wrote in perfect English, but thats just me. Anyway, the movie was worth the 15 bucks I paid to see it. The one other problem that I had with the movie is that it could have ended roughly about 4 times, and around the last 10 minutes of the movie drag on FOREVER! A lot of critics are saying also that Tom Hanks did not do a very good job in the movie. I would have to totally disagree with this, compared to his last couple of movies... like The Lady Killers..?? He delivered his lines well and did a good job. Everything was good with Hanks, up until he monologued in the end, it was a bit corny, but I can deal with one bit of corn in a 2.5 hour movie. Definitely go see it for yourself and don't take my comments or anyone comments as your final judgement. Its one of those you'll like it or not movies.

title: Worth seeing but somewhat over-hyped
review:
Tom Hanks and a pretty French girl in high heels on a quest for the Holy Grail in the churches and museums of France and England.

Interesting and worth seeing, but not as good as Raiders of the Lost Ark, the first Star Wars, or the first Ghostbusters, and hence somewhat over-hyped. I agree with the SF critics that while the characters are in constant danger, people keep getting shot, and a centuries-old mystery is about to be revealed, it's not all that thrilling. Maybe Ron Howard's directing is too conservative, or the book is a glorified Agatha Christie novel.

For those who haven't read it (myself included) "The Da Vinci Code" is a Grail-Quest novel, set in France, featuring a renegade Catholic sect (with some Opus Dei members) who want to wipe out all traces of the Grail, versus another ancient secret society (The Priory of Zion) who are sworn to preserve it. The quest involves a series of clues, like an Easter Egg hunt. There are many mysteries and reversals as characters are revealed to be part of one group or the other, and engaging in gangland style warfare.

Despite the religious furor, few would (I hope) mistake this for serious history. The list of what-ifs goes on and on, the plot is driven more by hunches and coincidence than evidence, and the underlying premise of a secret that will shake the foundations of Catholicism might have been electrifying 50+ years ago, but is ho-hum today, at least in the West.

(In particular, since Christianity didn't exist in France in 43 AD, any descendants of Jesus would have lived in total obscurity for centuries. Also during the Middle Ages every monarch in Europe tried to claim descent from the Caesars, Jesus, King Solomon, or whomever, to bolster their claims to the throne. So there would have been ample motive and opportunity to fabricate such a romantic legend in Merovingian France, including perhaps still-existing secret societies.)

This movie needed a director who realized he could not coast on the bestselling book. Just narrating the story isn't enough. Why is the Grail such a big secret? How will the Church 's foundations be shaken? What was the real richness of the message or meaning that was handed down through the centuries? If the film had done a better job of laying some groundwork, the plot action could have been more compelling.

Even just some eerier music, more portentous scenes and lighting, or a few miracles could have made a huge difference in setting things more on edge. Plus the idea that this is a "millennial revelation" of an ancient secret (with current news value) is not leveraged at all. "The Bridges of Madison County" did a much better job of faking authenticity for emotional impact.

Many in the audience, and anyone who's seen or read "Possession," will guess the secret at least 40 minutes before the end, so how suspenseful can that be? Author Dan Brown did a nice job of borrowing themes from "The Celestine Prophesy" (ancient religious quest with violence) and "Possession" (self discovery via historical research) and weaving them with some old French legends. But that's it -- it's a decent novel, not a major cultural event.

Rated PG-13. No sex, not even a kiss, but brutal killings, some nudity, and disturbing images.

title: hmmmmmm....
review: One would think that with names like Ron Howard, Tom Hanks, Alfred Molina, and Ian McKellen attached, and the best-selling novel as the basis, this movie would blow audiences away. It seems, however, that none of these names cared that the screenplay was dreadful, just that they would be backing a summer blockbuster called the Da Vinci Code. I cannot say that this movie was totally bad. In my opinion, had there been no book and this movie had been made the way it was, it would have been quite the spectacle. However, almost every person who saw the movie the first day had read the book and was comparing the movie to the book. If you see this movie and expect it to be in the same league as the book you will be seriously disappointed. Now, I must admit it has been a while since I read the book, but it seemed that a lot of information was taken out and/or changed. Also, many of the twists and turns that made the novel great were quickly thrown in and poorly explained. I must admit that I think Tom Hanks is a great actor but he seemed very dry in this role. I never thought he was right for this part. Audrey Tautou is a fantastically charming actress and I felt her part was done pretty well, but she had no chemistry with Hanks. Jean Reno, in my opinion, nailed the role of Bezu Fache, he was perfect. McKellen was good, but he didn't have the look of Teabing. Aringarosa was played somewhat well by Molina, but it was Paul Bettany as Silas that really seemed perfect. He was eerie to say the least. All in all this movie, compared to the novel, was a bust, which is sad to say because Dan Brown himself backed the movie. And with the star power behind it, this could have and should have been a site to see. It fell short. I must say that the last 2-3 minutes of the movie did give me goosebumps, as it was well shot and the music was perfect. But again, do not go to see this movie with expectations that it will do the book justice.

title: Disappointingly Mediocre
review:
I'm no die hard religious guy and I'm not saying that its bad because of its controversy, but I had high hopes for this movie and was disappointed. The casting was good, but Howard did a terrible job in this flick. Some of it seemed kind of lame, and i feel he left out some important details from the book. The characters are developed poorly, which doesn't surprise me because he blows through the first 150 or so pages in around 5 minutes, which is to say disappointing because i thought that the beginning was was the best, as well as the most important part of the whole story. In certain parts I felt it it was almost necessary to have read the novel to understand what was going on. Ialso didn't like how he made some parts word for word from the book,yet added in things and left others out. As it says in other reviews there is absolutely no chemistry between the main characters. Events in the movie sometimes seemed out of place, leaving you wondering, and then finally their answered an hour later.Some of you may disagree with on this, but I thought that the movie was almost a slap to the face of the book. The book talks about how the major religions down play the importance of women, compared to the pagan religions which worshiped them (to which no no real explanation was given except machismo). In the novel Sophie is quick witted, as a cryptologist, and langdon even says that he was intimidated by he r intelligence, while in the movie langdon some how knew everything it seemed, figuring out things that took him in the book, he knew seemingly instantly case and point: the vitrouvius man or the anagram,o Draconian Devil!O Lame Saint! This had the potential to be a great film, the novel was excellent, but it was just made poorly.

P.S. If your whole views on religious foundation can be shaken by a movie be it this or maybe the passion, your are obviously stupid and more impressionable than a 3 year old. Also Robert Redford should have played Langdon

title: An interesting idea gone Hollywood
review:
Having never read the book, I went into the Da Vinci Code with no expectations other than those I usually have going into a Ron Howard production.

The beginning sequence dove right into the story and Paul Bettany's performance as Silas begins in spectacular fashion. Unfortunately, and it seems to last throughout the entire film, Hanks' acting skills seem to have been buried along with the secret of a holy bloodline and never makes an appearance in this film. Ian McKellan proved himself once again a great actor as Sir Leigh Teabing, and Jean Reno was a natural choice for Captain Fache.

The story itself was utterly predictable if not entertaining. Hanks and Tautou's lines were classic Hollywood thriller (boring and cheesy), and that was not helped by the fact that they looked uncomfortable along-side each other for the entire two hours.

Thankfully for us, the viewers, Bettany and McKellan save the piece from itself.

title: Great potential, great director, bad casting
review:
I read the DaVinci Code before i even knew it was going to be a movie so i have just been counting the days until it came out. Well, i went to see it last night and while the movie remained rather loyal to the book the casting did not. Tom Hanks should not have been Robert Langdon. I had hoped that it was merely disappointment for me not seeing him as Robert before, but watching the movie confirms it. His look and everything just doesn't fit to me. While Audrey Tatou sort of warmed up to me as Sophie, she still seemed to hold some sort of stiffness about her. Now, most likely the cause of my dislike in the portrayal of the characters has to do with some of the horrible lines that were used in the movie.

And i mean horrible. In the attempt to include information, especially in the Louvre, it came across really fake and very out of character for them to be in a life-threatening crisis and take the time to explain the meaning of artwork. Now while this is very well crafted in the book adding intellectual rigor with a stunning plot it is merely used as part of Dan Brown's descriptive style. That is why i've come to the conclusion that it is impossible to successfully adapt any of Dan Brown's books into movies. They truly contain too much information. While it fits in a book as description and thoughts that run through Langdon's mind, it comes out awkward with Langdon giving Sophie Art 101 while they are hurrying to figure out her grandfather's riddles.

It literally would make me cringe at some of the lines with how robotic they were. As well such things like Sauniere not being Sophie's grandfather when he was; at least i always thought he was when reading the book. And of course such little details like Sophie having brown hair and not red (since that was a pretty important detail in the book), Silas having blue eyes and not pink, the grandmother having short and not long hair bothered me for they were clearly described in the book. And as much as i think of Ian McKellan, Leigh Teabing was described entirely different in the book. He was supposed to be portly with curly hair.

Now, don't get me wrong, Ian McKellan did a wonderful job and definitely pulled off Teabing, but i feel that you cannot capture the book if the characters do not fit correctly. So that definitely bothered me as i watched it. The best was Paul Bettany as Silas, perfect for the part. Besides being a wonderful actor he truly fits the role with the look and everything, minus the pink eyes which as i've said before, bothered me. As well Fache and Aringarosa were perfect in the casting.

So over all, it is a really good movie if you have not read the book, but if you have then i would suggest to not see the movie, because more likely it will annoy you than entertain you. I can be pretty picky on adaptations of books, so it's not so much a bad movie as just disappointing. It's still pretty good though.

title: Depends on whether you've read the book or not
review:
First I'd like to say that I am perplexed from people who rated this movie with 10 out of 10. Even though I try to be non-judgmental with regard's to people's taste, this movie is definitely not perfect and certainly does not rank with The Godfather and the like. But who am I to say so anyways, right?

The movie review now. If you have read the book, an excellent read (but with no literary value, mind you), then you will be happy to know that it is a pretty good adaptation that stays close to the text without major diversions. Some added dialogues between Hanks and Tautou though attempt at making the movie more "religiously-politically correct" and that annoyed me. A book is a book and if it offends you, don't see the movie. The extra dialogue and cross questioning in some scenes, aiming at easing the burden on the Catholic church, was too much and irrelevant. Everything else aside, book fans will like it. Yet, the movie does not move as fast as the book and the reason is that the explanatory dialogue (explaining splendidly the theories presented in the book, particularly to those who haven't read it) overwhelms the action and pace. If one judges the movie on its own merit, book aside, will be left with the impression that there is no chemistry between the protagonists even though the casting is pretty good. It is a decent movie, provocative in its own way, with good photography but does not add up to the pre-release hype. Had the book not been famous beforehand, I don't think the movie would ever be made. Overall, a decent movie and that's just about it.

title: tom hanks was a wrong choice
review:
It could have been a masterpiece! Ron Howard is one of my favorite directors. But he was disappointing this time. Turning a book like Da Vinci Code into a movie is not an easy task, but people like Ron Howard are not supposed to fail! There is too much information and a movie cannot be too long. There is also a certain pace people expect from thrillers.

But adapting a book doesn't mean you have to start and end the way the book does!! I would have given audience a quick 5 minute curtain raiser on the subject without killing the suspense, before plunging into the main story-line...this also could have helped Hans Zimmer who just couldn't liven it up in the first half an hour (not sure if Horner would have succeeded either, the way Howard chose to shoot it)...the movie never really picks up..McKellen rescues the movie now and then. Tom Hanks looks half dead! if it can be of any consolation to 'the church', the movie is not going to be remembered as a masterpiece.

title: Too Subtle for Critics? Too Balanced for Zealots?
review:
This is not Howard's best work, but I would recommend seeing this film for several reasons. The first is that even more so than the book, the film tries hard to walk the fence between decrying religious faith and exonerating Jesus' divinity, and is less about persuasive refutation and more about questioning basic assumptions of history. The second is that all of the actors do a wonderful job navigating the more obtuse aspects of their roles. This is where I think the critics misunderstood: these performances are not wooden or "sleep walking," they aim for subtle, and often hit the mark. If anything, the editing is a bit heavy-handed, putting exclamation points on the end of already compelling statements (i.e. Yes, this person really DID choke! And they really ARE dead! Look how DEAD they are!). Because of this contrast, the more nuanced acting is often lost (or perhaps better understood by European audiences?).

Lastly, there is real magic in many of the sequences, and it continually probes our understanding of history, religion and very personal spiritual faith. Probes  and excites controversy  but as the verbal sparring between the "historical authorities" in the film so often reveals, the story doesn't slam the door shut on any one particular worldviewor on any possibility. Personally, I found the film inspiring, exciting (despite the fact that I had read the book and new the outcome), and much more enjoyable than I had anticipated.

title: Saw it the second time and guess what.....
review:
Okay, this is my story. My girl and I read the book and I promised her to go to Da Vinci with her. we would go on a Saturday. But on the Thursday when it came out, my roommate had two tickets... I'm a movie fanatic so I thought, first see it on Thursday and keep my mouth shut about it.

spoilers:

THURSDAY: My god what a drag. It took so long. I loved the Louvre scenes, loved the Teabing mansion scenes but after that, the story was ripped apart. Some lines were B-level and my biggest problem was that when Langdon had to solve a code, I couldn't follow it. There was too much info and the hints flew by to quickly. When Langdon cracked the APPLE-code, I just couldn't figure out how the hell he found that out. And after that when Teabing was taken by the cops (which was more hideous to see than looking at Tom Cruises big smile), I lost the plot, I couldn't care anymore.

5/10

I thought please NO, not again on Saturday, KILL ME.

Saturday: Sat there acting surprised next to my girl, who was so eager to see it. But than it happened! Knowing the plot, knowing the riddle answers,, seeing the hints as they occurred on screen immediately as they were spoken out loud, the movie gets to you. You hear every single bit of information. You hear the complete 'history' lesson. And it was then, after seeing five hours of Hangs and the beautiful Tattou, that I got goosebumps when Ron Howard showed Mary M to the audience.

So here's the advice to you all, When the first time you saw it, the movie seemed lame and too far stretched out, see it again, sure, there are some crappy scenes (IM YOUR GRANDMOTHER), but they HAD to be put in there. But when you follow the story word to word, you solve all the mysteries that puzzled you the first time you saw it...

9/10

ENJOY GUYS

title: Pretty true to book, and well done I think
review:
Really like a 7.7, but that's not an option. I will try to keep this short and to the point. All in all I liked the movie quite a bit. Viewing it as a movie on its own merits it was a good thriller. Definitely had an heir of mystery. The acting from Tom Hanks was good, he had a sort of fatherly tone at points, making him a believable professor. Ian Mckellan did a wonderful job and perhaps did the best acting in the film. Audrey Tautou I felt also had a good performance, but not great, she however seemed fitting to the character, and I am glad to see her break her way into more mainstream films. Many worried this movie would stir up controversy, but I do not feel it took a biased approach to the religious themes presented, and probably was more PC the than book itself.

Looking at it as a book turned movie I think it was very well adapted. There are few parts that differ, which at the risk of spoiling anything for non-readers I will not mention suffice it to say it is pretty true to the book, and the parts that were changed I was able to understand the reason for the change. The movie kept a lot of the informative sections without making them bland, through discussion we get somewhat of a history lesson, I'm sure some people would fine it bland, but I am patient and like the background, it adds a great depth to the story.

Good movie, not great, for those who read the book its a quick fix, for those who hate reading but wonder what the fuss is about, go see it.

title: really good, if you haven't read the book
review:
I know a 9 is pretty high but I LOVED LOVED LOVED this film. I have never read the book which seems to have been why I have this opinion. Because I was able to go into it without any preconceived notions I could enjoy it for what it was, a great FILM. Obviously people who have read the book have their own ideas and it is extremely difficult to turn a best-selling book into a fabulous movie that will please everyone.

I thought the casting was done very well and Paul Bettany as Silas was great. I don't think there has been any other 'creepy' character that has truly creeped me out like he did. Audrey Tatou is probably one of the best actresses to break onto the Englishfilm scene of late and pairing her with Tom Hanks was a smart move.

As far as the controversy surrounding the film, the book was a work of fiction and the film is as well. It's a great drama that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

title: This was great entertainment. AAA
review:
Those who can't create criticize!!

I have read the book and though that experience surpassed my movie experience i thought the movie was great.

The movie left out a few minor details but with the time constraints it followed the book very nicely and did not feel slow or rushed.

I see a few comments about weak character development... No kidding. With a story like this there doesn't need to be nor is there the time for it.

Lets not forget that that is what this is, a great story. There is so much controversy surrounding this that everyone is quick to look for the bad, but this movie was a great experience and i would pay to see it again.

The acting was excellent. When I first heard the cast i admit I was a bit skeptical, but now I couldn't see anyone else pulling it off that well.

Big ups to Bettany (Silas), that dude is flat out amazing, as was Mc Kellan (Teabing).

The only disappointment was that they didn't end up together at the end.

Bottom line..... Howard delivered.

title: Read the book first
review: The book is exciting and interesting, the movie doesn't give you enough background information to get into the story (because of time constraints), and therefore doesn't grab the audience as the book does. I recommend reading the book and then seeing the film. If you see the film first you will probably think it's slightly boring and ask yourself: why do I care, or what's this? Without the book or a deep knowledge about this kind of history, you won't know or get any of the good stuff in the story. The film follows the storyline of the book rather faithfully with a few scenes cut/altered. However those scenes were needed to bring thrills to the story and make you sit at the edge of your seat, which you don't watching the movie. Still the film was entertaining. But read the book first, you won't be sorry.

title: OK but not great
review: I have to say that my expectation was running high for this film although I felt that it had much more potential than what it achieved. For a director of Ron Howard's calibre I was expecting this to be the best movie of year but I'm afraid to say that it just isn't. As is the case with many films, it is well below par with the book, but it is quite entertaining and will keep you gripped throughout. When reading the book I felt that the character of Robert Langdon would not be played by someone like Tom Hanks. Although I enjoy most movies Tom Hanks stars in, I couldn't really place him in the shoes of Robert Langdon, I thought that someone such as Clive Owen would better suit the role. The one person, however, I instantly knew should play the part he did was Sir Ian Mckellen as Sir Leigh Teabing. Ian McKellen fits the role so well and I have to say he gave a wonderful performance. The book for me was very enjoyable, it is a world-wide best-seller and naturally the film had great expectations. However, whoever made this movie, the critics wouldn't be happy, the book just had so much success that no one could ever do it justice, that is why the critics have given it such poor reviews. Overall, this is quite an enjoyable and entertaining film which has much more potential than shown, it is hardly the best movie of the year, but it is worth watching and although not completely true to the book, a pretty good movie.

title: Fact nor fiction (A Must See)
review:
I saw the Da Vinci Code with my husband (who hadn't read the book) on opening day. We both loved it! I think it's a great movie. Although it's not fiction (neither is it non-fiction). It presents ideas that have been of interest to scholars for ages and portrays them in a thriller that can be enjoyed by people of all ages and interests.

The hopes of Dan Brown and Ron Howard are probably that it would at least start a dialogue as to what really is the truth? What happened? And I think it has easily managed to do that.

I'm not a religious person but I think that people who truly believe in Jesus (as oppose to just the "organization" of the church) would definitely be pulled to see this. Because ultimately they would be more open to the finding the "truth."

It's definitely "a must see" for anyone.

title: The Da Vinci Code
review: I thought The Da Vinci Code was good, not great. The left some things out put new things in...but I guess I shouldn't be too shocked about that. One thing I really loved was seeing the Lourve, Paris, Teabing's Villa...it was everything I had imagined it to be. I thought everyone's performance was right on...but the Robert Langdon is much more exciting than the Robert Langdon on screen. It moved pretty fast, I think the movie was about 2 1/2 hours long but it went by so quickly...none of the scenes dragged on at all. The flashbacks are also enjoyable. Ian McKellen's performance as Teabing was great as well as Paul Bettany's. Overall I thought it was good film.

title: The Critics are Wrong this Time
review:
Critics have flamed this film and I have to say I think they were wrong and overly biased. This is not the first time this year where professional reviews were just plain off base. Come on, who really thought MI III deserved a 70% on the tomato meter. MI III had to be one of the worst movies ever, and I love action movies and have seen tons of them. I'm usually pretty dead on with critics of my assessment of a film.

Reading all of the reviews on Rotten Tomatoes, I just don't buy that the story was flat. Let's face it, the book, although a page turner, was not an action packed thriller. It was more of a slow evolving mystery-thriller. Hello, that's why a 2 ½ hour movie was necessary. Although I do agree that Tom Hanks was wrong for the role and that Ron Howard is a sucky director anyway, this movie did NOT deserve an 18 on the tomato meter.

I saw the movie in Lake Mary, Fla and the audience clapped when it was over. I thought the film did what the book didand that is appeal to the average American audience. I read one review on IMDb that pointed out the lack of European flair, but this movie was made for Americans, by Americans. Who is more American than Opie? So why the crummy reviews? I think critics and movie snobs alike, all got on the band wagon to pick apart one of the most anticipated movies of our generation. Let me say here, that I don't believe this movie deserved a 90%, or even an 80% for that matter. But an 18??? Who are we kidding. The movie was very respectable. It had good pacing and took time to elaborate the details, albeit multiple times, but it was very necessary to get the whole point across.

Everyone that I have spoken too really liked the movie and seemed to get a lot out of it. It may not be a work of cinematic genius on par with the likes of the top movies of last season, but certainly did the book justice.

title: Well-made film, some flaws but overall works
review:
Unlike many others, I say this movie is excellent. It is hard for others, but I watched this movie discarding the religious controversies the move ignites. The acting is well done in most areas of the film. Tom Hanks is an amazing actor, and while this was not his best performance. it certainly was good.

The plot is a good one, and for the most part stays true to the book. There a few minor changes of situations and words, but the book is there. However, the movie is LONG. The mystery that is to be solved, though intriguing and exciting, gets a little boring. It was fun to find out what this message meant and where this riddle leads, but it goes on for too long. But Howard wanted to keep to the book, and cutting too much out of the movie may have ruined it.

Overall The Da Vincie Code was an exciting and enjoyable film experience, and without some of these minor flaws, it would be a perfect film.

title: film better than book
review:
Ron Howard has delivered a film that surpasses the original novel in ease of comprehension, although the premise that Tom Hanks' character needs to explain the concepts to Tatou's character at each juncture (obviously to clue in the audience) is too much talk yet too little illumination. The story line is interesting, obviously believable (hence all the outcry opposed) and has generated more religious or theological discussion within my circle of family and friends than we have experienced in generations. Any film that can do that is worth seeing. The film and book are fiction but expose many truths, fears and fantasies that have gripped civilized man from the beginning of Christianity. It strives to note the past human foibles and judgments which have left some of our basic truths open to various questioning or repositioning. No one should be offended, shocked or upset by this film, which only tries to tell a "what if" chapter of Christianity, NOT TO DENY the one the world has accepted for 2000 years. It takes nothing away from Christ or His followers.

I enjoyed the film much more than the novel's wooden style. (Nonetheless, I feel a stronger lead than Hanks was warranted. It was as though he was marching while everyone else was dancing.)

title: This is an excellent MOVIE (keyword: movie).
review:
I can see only one reason why anyone would vote below, say, a 7 for this movie: if it made them question their faith and they resent such a thing happening. Of course, if a movie can make you question your faith, then it wasn't very strong to begin with.

The movie itself is very well made. Direction, acting, cinematography, art direction/set decoration, action, pacing, etc. I did not feel there were any plot holes; it is a complete movie. I felt that it was gripping, exciting, suspenseful, intelligent, and even had a bit of humor thrown in at the right moments (so you could shift in your seat, relax again, and move on). People at my screening all laughed out loud at funny moments, but were otherwise quiet and seemingly enthralled throughout the rest of the film. I even heard several gasps here and there. A few people clapped at the end. My wife said the look on my face was perfect for someone who hadn't read the book (she has read it). She gives the movie a 9 as well, and a 7 when comparing it TO the book (which she said was a 10).

Yes, the movie is a statement, but it isn't trying to convert everyone. It's just giving you another theory about what may have happened. In all honesty though, I do find it a very convincing theory/story.

I believe everyone SHOULD see this movie, if for no other reason than to defy the governments and churches that are trying desperately to continue controlling the masses. Why would they care so much about a movie unless it scared them? It doesn't take much to realize that powerful people fear losing their power. I think this movie at least gives us pause to think about the things we've been told to just blindly accept for all these years.

Myself? I'm not religious at all. I found that the movie simply confirmed the things I already wondered about and/or doubted about Christianity anyway.

title: Not as bad as critics say
review:
I won't get into the details of the movies, as most of you by now, know what the story is about.

I've read the book and I was excited to see this movie, but then I became disheartened after reading all the horrible reviews for the movie. However I went into the movie and was quite pleased with it. I'm not sure what the critics were complaining about, but I was entertained by the movie. I'm not sure if a lot of people are just expressing their displeasure with the subject matter instead of the movie itself.

Furthermore, one important thing I must point out is the balance it brings to both sides of the religious argument. There are statements made by Tom Hanks that bring balance to the religious argument that is going on about this book. Ron Howard didn't need to put that into the movie, but is a great touch and people who have some against this movie just because of their religious views, should see this movie for themselves.

title: Why was the end changed?
review:
I've read the book, a really great one, and since then I had been waiting anxiously to watch the movie. I bought the tickets two weeks in advance and on 19th May there I was.

The beginning of the movie was good. I really thought it would be the best film ever, but when it ended, I just couldn't understand: Why were there so many changes? Why wasn't Saunire Sophie's real grandfather? Why didn't she have a brother? And the most important: Why didn't she kiss Robert Langdon? I was completely disappointed with this lack of romance. I see no reason for that, even though I know the importance of a script adaptation and the intention of keeping the attention on the mystery about the holy grail and the religious history.

title: Great Interpretation of a Great Book!
review: Spoilers (If you have not read the book or already seen the movie, do NOT read this)! Its rare that a movie follows the premise of a book, verbatim! For those of you who read the novel, you are in for a treat. True, the movie is not the book, word by word, scene by scene; if it had been, the movie would have been a lot longer than 2 1/2 hours. I think it was very well done, overall. At first, I was disappointed that they had chosen Tom Hanks for the lead as Robert Langdon, I felt it was too old and it was Hollywood's attempt to distort the actual book but he did an excellent job in playing the character. In the interest of time, there were a lot of things that was in the book, not in the movie. I still say, Ron Howard, Well Done!

title: Universal Story, American Writer, International Cast
review:
It took more than one year after I read The Da Vinci Code, the most popular and controversial novels of our time and just 2nd best sold after The Bible, more than one year until the adaptation was finally released.

The movie has an international cast headed by two time Academy Award winner Tom Hanks supported by Sir Ian McKellen, Alfred Molina and Jean Reno, every one of them a mega star. Audrey Tautou brings freshness to it in a "jolie" kind of way and Paul Bettany and Jurgen Prochnow are also not to be missed. Ron Howard is a great filmmaker, following Brown's formula (exotic setting, astonishing disclosures, a frenetic search for the truth and also the chase to cover it all). With the help of his crew he elevates it into a greater entertainment full of style and an aura of mystery that is undeniable.

I had VERY high expectations when I went to watch the movie. I already had my own image of the whole story and the characters and was mostly wondering how Tom Hanks / Robert Langdon will fit into it. He did! Maybe the fact that I am an European helped me enjoy this movie from a different perspective as well. Langdon (Hanks) is a Harvard Professor who brings the young American spirit into this who's who mystery network of french police-mens, Italian Clerc and English noblemen. He is trapped and drawn into solving a mystery as old as the world.

I think that beyond the story of the novel Hanks and the entire European part of the crew managed in a brilliant way to reveal this inter-cultural mixture. Wonderful! Another nice surprise was that, except for a few details left out, the movie follows the book religiously. The novel is quite dense and i suppose the director had only this much time on his hands. Tom Hanks, Audrey Tautou and Jean Reno do a good job of not overplaying their roles, and Sir Ian McKellen (you might have seen him in The Lord of the Rings, X-Men and quite a few TV productions of Shakespeare's) overplays his in just the right way. Young Paul Bettany portrays a convincing Silas. Jurgen Prochnow, a leading man and strong character of the German stage and screen does a wonderful job during his short part as Andre Vernet. Sauniere himself is portrayed by one of the key stones of French cinematography, Jean-Pierre Marielle.

It has also been wonderful to me to so see the Louvre again - even if the Grand Gallery was build out of scratch in the studio. The paintings, the spectacular wooden floors - everything, even the window sole are part of the studio decor, but build identical to the real thing to millimeter. Bottom line, this is a movie not to be missed.

If you liked the book, like a good riddle, are a history lover or an art lover or you just want to enjoy a good cast, go and see it. In the theaters. Now.

title: Nice action movie
review:
I saw it last night with my 15 year old son. We both enjoyed it as an action movie. I don't think it will threaten anyone's view of religion. It was vintage Ron Howard. If you liked Apollo 13, you will love DVC.

My son read the book and enjoyed it. He thought the movie followed the book well. I thought it was less detailed and less historical with much more action in the "24" sense of action -- they were always running someplace.

One issue not well covered in the movie was the riches supposedly found by the Templars in Jerusalem. When the Romans destroyed the Temple in 70 AD, they took most of the treasure back to Italy and used it to finance the construction of the Colosseum. Is it so far fetched that some of that fabulous treasure was hidden from the Romans but found by the Templars and removed to finance the construction of Feudal Europe?

title: Pretty good, but could have been better
review: I thought the movie was pretty entertaining as a piece of fiction. Sure it had its flaws, but on the whole it could have been a lot worse. The major flaw, i found, was that it lacked any real build-up to climactic events. It seemed as though Ron Howard made the film under the supposition that everyone has read the book (which wouldn't be all that inaccurate). Therefore he didn't give the turning points the proper feeling of anticipation and build as the book did. I never felt as though the characters were ever making any revelations with the story. It was delivered all-in-all rather blandish. The music didn't help with this either. I felt the music to be rather boring. The most notable example would be the car chase scene where Sophie and Robert escape in Smart Car. Where was the exciting music? It was cut together in an exciting way with fast pace cuts, but the music was lagging. It seemed as though Howard was treating this film as a drama/thriller rather than the fast paced high intensity popcorn entertainment piece the book offered. The result- a fairly light entertainment film that could have been a lot more entertaining!!! But worth seeing non-the-less.

title: can't say
review: i have to say, the da vinci code is a perfect book to be transformed into film. i'm just rather confused by the csi -like moments here and there. well, whatever the public says, i liked it. if for nothing else, for the unusual camera angles.without them a few scenes would've been rather dull, i might say. and also, it's a conspiracy.against church.you gotta love that. overall,even the fact that i had read the book before didn't bother me as it so many times does in these kinds of filmisations ( anyone remember harry potter III?) it was a straight-from-the-book movie, but there'd also been added just the right amount of "can only be done on film" material, for example sophie's "walk on water"- try out.overall, both the book and the movie were good,but since i don't know any of the places mentioned in the book (and i doubt many do)so it was good to see them for real, not just think; oh,there's a room with a rose, and that's it. there's a certain point where even imagination can't help you.

title: Well adapted from the book
review: I know this is probably going to turn some thumbs down here, but what i can say is this is a 2.5hrs movie taken from a 500+ pages book that's gonna take you at least 2 days to finish reading it if you read it non stop. Ron Howard did well to consolidate all the information from the book and turn it into a movie which could truly captured the audience imagination. Both for readers and non readers. Tom Hanks Acting was mediocre if you compare it to all the previous films he has acted in, but readers should know it's a helluva task to fit in a role of a very complex character, Robert Langdon, as he was portrayed in the book. Audray was okay as Sophie, she seems more of a strong willed type of lady in the book as compared to the movie. Ian Mckeller played Leigh Teabing excellently and so did Paul Bettany as Silas. I would like to invite everyone to go watch this movie before making any comments and also not believing people whom are giving prejudgment and criticism of this film without even watching it. Keep an open mind, erase the thought of any written history and watch this movie adapted from a fine piece of fiction(as claimed by the majority) Think, if The Da Vinci Code is a fiction written by man Isn't there a chance that the bible is a great piece of fiction written by men also? FACT OR FICTION? Do you have to always believe what others says? YOU BE YOUR OWN JUDGE!

title: To heck with the critics
review:
This movie is a must see! The movie, for the most part, stayed true to the book. The beginning didn't start out with Langdon getting woken up in his hotel room. A little extra was added to the ending (I won't say what!). And some of the intellectual thought was removed, but only to keep the movie flowing. For those that had said the critics were right, must have not watched the same movie I watched. Those who haven't read the book will enjoy the movie just as much as those who have. I know, because my girlfriend didn't read the book. I give this movie a 9/10 (only cause they changed the story a bit!) Overall, great story, great acting, great special effects. I wasn't watching the movie thinking, "this is Tom Hanks." I was thinking, "Wow.. that's Robert Langdon!". My biggest complaint is the audience. I found it very frustrating that some teenage girl behind me felt the need to giggle when any of the controversial material was discussed.

Don't listen to the bad reviews... Go see the movie!

title: I enjoyed it!
review:
It was with great anticipation that I went to see The Da Vinci Code at the premiere last night. The many bad reviews had lowered my expectations somewhat, but I was still looking forward to seeing the film very much.

The opening is really intense, which is extremely important in this kind of film. Pretty soon we get to see Silas punishing himself with the cilice belt and the whip. This scene is extremely powerful and I noticed that some people had a hard time watching it.

Having re-read the book recently I found that although the script follows the book very closely on a general level, very many little things are actually different. Most of these things I think was cleverly done to make the book work on screen. Overall I really enjoyed the film. It is well acted, visually perfect and has a beautiful score. And I always like a great conspiracy theory. There are some problems with the movie, though.

One problem with the film is naturally all the information that has to be conveyed to the audience somehow. Of course all the dialogue slows the film down a bit, but I did not miss the hysterical tempo that could have been if the script had been cut shorter. Actually I think I would have preferred an even longer film if that would have meant more insights into why some people suddenly turned out to be "on the wrong side". These twists and turns are explained in the book, but come more or less as surprises in the film. If I had not known the story I might eventually have expected Sophie to suddenly point a gun at Robert, telling him that she had hired her boyfriend Silas to kill her grandfather and that Robert was the next in line! (Or maybe not, but I hope you get what I mean.) Another thing that I found less convincing is that Robert and Sophie at times do not seem to be in a great hurry, which is a mystery to me.

The puzzle solving is also a bit of a problem. It seems a little too easy and there is really no time for the audience to try to figure it out for themselves. I do, however, not see how this could have been done in any other way in this format.

At the end of the film the tempo slows down pretty dramatically, but this is necessary in order to follow the book's storyline. Having read the book I had no problem with this tempo change and I must say that the very last scenes, accompanied by Hans Zimmer's amazing original score, are just as intense as the beginning of the film.

The best thing about this film is definitely Sir Ian McKellan's interpretation of Teabing. He is extremely funny without ever being silly. I was also impressed with Paul Bettany as Silas, although I did find him "just looking crazy" in a few scenes. I am glad his role was not reduced to just looking crazy and brainwashed all the time, though, and I would have loved to see more of him.

The rest of the cast did a fine job, too. I do not understand, at all, the bad press that Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou have received. I found them totally convincing, but of course their parts are not as spectacular as that of Silas or Teabing.

Some critics have called this film boring. I do not agree at all. It is exciting and very often funny. Some scenes in The Da Vinci Code have been accused of being unintentionally funny, but I was very pleased that the audience last night never laughed at anything that was not supposed to be funny. The applause after the screening was not a thunderous one, but it was pretty widespread and I never hesitated to join in. Although it could have been better, I was not disappointed.

title: Disappointing- A Missed Opportunity
review:
The problem was always going to be how to get the ideas in the book across to a cinema audience , Howard manages a workman like job of this, but I felt viewers who may not be familiar with the story may have been confused by some of the "leaps" made in the explanations.Saying that it is very faithful to the book but Sadly Howard fails to capture the energy and tension of the novel and some of this has to be down to his choice of Hanks as Robert Langdon. Fine actor that Hanks is he just doesn't cut the mustard in this role, The Langdon character in the book comes across as slightly more dashing charismatic and occasionally Heroic , Hanks I'm afraid came across as a bit of a plumb !. Audrey Tautou is excellent and was everything I imagined the character of Sophie to be , Mckellen again does a superb job ,and Paul Bettany tremendous. The Loctaions were superb and Howard uses some techniques he first employed in "A Beautiful Mind" .

Its amazing how this film just does not capture the spirit and breakneck pace of the novel , which heaped revelation upon revelation on the reader and rather like "24" left you wanting more after each chapter.

Alas Howard and Hanks really were a bad choice for this film and some the dialog feels rather clumsy. If You haven't seen this or read the Book my advice would be read the book . If you see this you'll wonder what all the fuss is about.

title: Expecting more than I got...
review: I was looking forward to the Da Vinci Code, having enjoyed the book for what it was... a good movie script!!! I was really pleased when I heard that Ron Howard was directing some of Hollywood and Europe's finest talents. Imagine my surprise when I found myself getting a little bored during the movie. It had all of the elements, intrigue, chase scenes, mystery but no real sense of tension. The pacing seemed really slow and I have been wracking my brain to see where it all went so wrong.. I have come to the conclusion that there was so much story to tell that the characters spent most of the time explaining the background to the tale. The film I was hoping for would have been an intelligent version of "National Treasure" which although very slight was paced just about right. I think that I may have enjoyed the Film more if I hadn't read the book.

title: Brilliant Movie
review:
Quick summary: I felt the movie was simply awesome.. it was worth the wait.

To back up a bit - I read the book a couple of years ago and felt it was a fairly interesting read.. I was more impressed by the way the book was written then by the actual content i.e. the holy grail, Christ's bloodline etc (though I must admit that I was very tempted to visit the Louvre, Rosalyn chapel etc while I was in Paris and Edinburgh for other reasons). After the book, I did catch up on a few follow ups on Discovery or the History Channel related to the DaVinci code but my interest really perked up when I saw Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou on the cover of a French magazine in Paris. I simply love Hanks and was just waiting for the movie to be released.

I saw the movie last night with my wife (who was not as thrilled about the movie) and here's my thoughts:- The casting is simply superb (except for Reno.. though he does a good job of the character cant Hollywood find anyone else to play a French cop?!!). Hanks and Tautou do a fine job and I felt the on screen chemistry was just perfect. The subtle smiles, the tension.. leaves the viewer guessing on whats going to happen next towards the end of the movie. The supporting characters are very well chosen and acted out. I also liked the direction and the overall pace and flow of the movie. I don't remember the book in much detail and thus did not compare if the movie was as good as the book.

title: Is this even the same story?
review:
I read the book a week before the movie and, despite serious objections to the falsely claimed "facts" given by Dan Brown, I was drawn in by the engaging cat-and-mouse/treasure hunt story and wanted to see how this story can be adapted to the big screen. Despite the film's keeping to the basic storyline (search for the holy grail and its true meaning while evading multiple opposing forces) I left with the overwhelming sensation of "what the heck did I just see?" Granted, one can never transfer all the minute details, exposition, dialog, or action that the book contains into a 2 hour film; however, there is a fine line between editing out certain parts and adding new parts that have absolutely no relevance or relationship to the original story. In the film version of "The DaVinci Code", director Ron Howard not only crosses this line but leaps over it with reckless abandon. The pacing was all wrong, far too fast to develop any sense of tension (except the scenes where Silas physically attacks his adversaries). Character interaction in some cases were so different from the book that you are looking at a completely different person (see spoilers below). The ending was for the most part completely different (again see spoilers below). But despite all these changes, the overall film (standing on its own) was a serious let down in the entertainment factor. Bad pacing (as stated before), motivation of major characters changed unreasonably or were never explained, dialog seemed forced by some of the characters (Sofie and Langdon), and the ending just reeked of cheese.

6 out of 10. Definitely no where near the quality of film that Howard or Hanks usually produce.

********************************** SPOILERS **********************************
