This is mostly for those who have read the book. As I watched the film I couldn't help but cringe or scream (internally, wouldn't actually do it in the theater) "HOWARD YOU *******" based on these blatant changes:

1) Silas's eyes are blue in the film, not red as the book states.

2) "The Sacred Feminine" theory that is so blatant in the book is not as aggressively "preached" in the film. A change that I actually found relieving.

3) Bishop Aringarosa, to put it bluntly, is not the same person. The book portrays him as a righteous priest duped by to find the Holy Grail in hopes of saving Opus Dei from being excommunicated and is horrified at what was done in the name of God. The movie, however, portrays him as a zealous member of a inner circle within the Vatican (no where mentioned in the book) who will do anything to destroy the Holy Grail including lying and murdering.

4)Fache's motivation for thinking Langdon is guilty is different. It starts off like the book, Sauniere left Langdon's name at the crime scene thus, in Fache's mind, Langdon is identified as the killer; however, later in the film we are told that Fache is after Langdon cause Aringarosa lied (as later revealed) that Langdon told the bishop he committed the murders in confession.

5) Fache and Aringarosa's relationship. The movie portrays Aringarosa as a manipulator like "The Teacher" and pulls the strings of Fache's sense of faith and duty by framing Langdon. When the truth is revealed in the end, Aringarosa is unrepentant and still hell bent on his mission. The book is nothing like this. Why Howard decided to make a blatant change to the story is beyond me.

6) Only one cryptex, the smaller one with the Issac Newton riddle, is kept in the film. Any reference to the larger (heavier) cryptex and the "Sofie" riddle are completely gone.

7) Langdon is approached by Collet at the lecture and not at his hotel room. Minor point, I know.

8) Langdon and Sophie's trip to the Swiss Bank is on foot instead of by Taxi (they even added a scene of Sophie paying a guy to not take drugs).

9) Rosalyn Church is completely different than described in the book. Don't know if the movie shows the actual church or not. Furthermore, Langdon and Sophie actually go beneath the church and find Priory documents and evidence at the sarcophagus was present. No such event was in the book.

10) Major changes concerning Sophie's family: Sauniere was not her grandfather but acted as one after Sophie's family died to protect her; Sophie and her brother were in the car wreck and only she survived; as stated before, her brother is really dead; it was her parents that took her to Rosalyn church not her grandfather; she was scolded (rather harshly) by Sauniere because she was trying to find out what happened to her family (not because she snuck into his room and found the key).

11) Langdon figures out the rose line riddle all on his own with absolutely no help from Sophie's grandmother.

12) Sophie confronts Silas in the airplane. This scene didn't make any sense. Not the way Sophie acted, but how Silas talked to her which I felt was totally out of character.

title: Entertaining but disappointing at the same time...
review:
It's hard to say for certain if this movie lived up to the hype. It provides a good two plus hours of entertainment, but doesn't leave much of a lasting impression and you probably won't want to see it again.

In my places the movie plays it too safe, it's almost as if Ron Howard is terrified of doing anything that might offend the Catholic Church. As a result, the film does not push the envelope as much as the book does.

Tom Hanks does a decent job as Robert Langdon although he seems to be without emotion for much of the performance. There also seems to be a lack of chemistry between his character and that of Audrey Tatou.

The best performances in the film come not from Hanks but from the supporting cast. Ian Mckellen, Jean Reno, Paul Bettany and to a lesser extent Alfred Molina account for most of the films more dramatic moments.

Yes there are many changes from the book, but the central plot twist revealed at the end is the same in both. In the movie though, savvy viewers will probably figure it out about an hour before it is revealed as it seems to be pretty well telegraphed through most of the films second half.

The film also seems to suffer from lack of comedy relief. There are perhaps two chuckles in the whole film. Granted, this is a serious subject, but even a serious film needs a bit of humor.

Is it worth the price of admission? Probably. Is it one of the best films ever made? Definitely not.

title: the movie was great
review:
OK first off i don't see why "67rocks" from sydney Australia is saying the movie wasn't good... there is no way anyone can make a movie that is as good as the book the da vinci code. they cant get every single detail into the movie. as i watched i noticed they left out some parts, but they gave you all of the main ideas and explained them very well. i agree with wrong actor... tom hanks should not have taken this role, he is a good actor but not serious enough to play robert langdon.

having read the book i knew what was coming and i knew what was going on. if you have not read the book i suggest reading it before watching the movie or you will be asking everyone what is going on... i heard "what is this" at least 1,000 times while sitting in the theatre last night.

i had such a pre-conception to what robert langdon was supposed to look like, so i couldn't really settle with tom hanks. overall i enjoyed the movie, it didn't blow me away, but i enjoyed it... my expectations were too high i guess, but it was a good movie.

title: Slammed for being "clean" www.messiahtruth.org
review: This is a decent good film completely without disrespect for the "Xtians".....there is no sexual content none save a brief kiss on the hand ...and not a bit of cursing...the Euro-trash are so immune to smut and vulgarities the can not even hope to enjoy something without titillation ....it really speaks well of Christy's being so very very afraid of a few "what if's" questions.....WWW.MESSIAHTRUTH.ORG HAS EVEN MOR GREAT QUESTIONS precious churches have given Ron Howard More publicity than he could have ever bought....where were all the cry of boycott when it was a book....How can xtianty ever be respected if they are so afraid of there own too real shadows.

title: I Found it Engrossing and Moving
review:
I tried to avoid the reviews and hoopla surrounding this movie. I found Dan Brown's book to be plodding, and, in the end, it lost me, even though I have read a fair amount of recent scholarship about the role of Mary Magdelene and the Gnostic gospels, in general. There is no new information in the book, and even Brown's conjectures are not his.

But the history nerd in me enjoyed the movie, and the best part for me is Audrey Tautou's performance as she gradually awakens to her real origins, and what her life from the end of this movie, on, may be like.

In the sold out theater I was in, there was what seemed like respectful silence at the end of the movie. . .no applause, which sometimes happens on the opening weekend of a movie, but my sense was that the audience was moved, and it also seemed like about half the people got their cellphones out and were calling people about the film.

If you are literary at all, you will like this flick better than the book, I think.

title: Entertainment vs. Accuracy
review:
I think that a lot of people that give this film a low vote is because of its improbability. If you are looking for a historically accurate film, don't get your hopes up going to this movie. However, it is entertaining. I think that the most important outcome of this movie is that people actually ask questions about religion and not just accept what the Church tells the world to believe...

Also, I think that Audrey redeems herself from a slew of average movies since AmÃ©lie. I think that some viewers might miss a few elements of the movie because there is quite a bit of French dialogue. Most of it is translated but there are several times that someone says something that isn't put in subtitles. There isn't anything crucial, but it does add to the movie.

title: Heard the critics and wondered
review:
After reading and hearing the critics of the Da Vinci Code I wondered whether it was worth going to see it, but in the end I'm glad I did.

OK its not a perfect film but its very watchable, even if its for Tom Hanks hair style. The film has good pace and the acting is OK, Jean Reno is as normal very good as the Police Captain.

So the only thing go and see the film with an open mind you may surprise yourself and enjoy the film.

Although the external shots in London were of Westminster Abbey the internal shots were from Lincoln Cathedral, I was very surprised when visiting the cathedral that this was so. The cathedral had some photo's on display of them filming inside the cathedral. so if anyone gets a chance its worth a visit.

title: ***I loved the film I enjoyed it I would see it again.***
review:
Well I have just come in from seeing the fi-lum and I thought it was very good. I enjoyed it! I enjoyed it so much I have now seen it three times, I will be buying the DVD.

Just to think Tom Hanks stood in my foot steps when in Scotland. No shots of Edinburgh. Still Roslyn seven miles south of Edinburgh Scotland looks great inside and out.

I like the book also. So its not Charles Dickens so the fi-lum is not Gone With the Wind. Its a good thriller like the Thirty Nine Steps man gets murdered: man goes on the run; man seeks answers, mystery solved.

Puzzles to be solved, now the holy of holies what on earth was the Maltese Falcon all about and does it matter? Its a good film too. Like the Da Vinci Code.

Nothing wrong with the fi-lum but as always the book is always better, but at 603 pages its shortened for the cinema. I'll give it seven and a half out of ten Its no more far fetched than Mission Impossible. Well more believable actually. Any changes from the novel are for the better in my opinion.

I simply can't see what the critics have a problem with, hell its just a movie people like the Thirty Nine Steps. What the critics loved was BRICK which was lousy. God now that was a waste of money. Seems to me if the critics love it; I will hate it; if they don't like it I will love it, and most of the paying cinema going public would agree with me. Rather than the snobs who don't even pay for the price of admission.

Yes I recommend the Da Vinci Code to everyone who likes a good thriller. Its faction {part fiction part fact} like any Fredrick Forsyth novel. Dan Brown only took some true facts some true history and wrote a fictional story a thriller which makes a very good film. D.Brown did not write the historical facts! Facts are facts history happened or it did not, he only took the historical facts with some myths and added a fictional story. No one attacks Christian beliefs. Who cares if Opus Dei does not have monks? Who cares if the pyramid has 666 panes of glass or 669 its fiction. The Vatican is not attacked. Robert Langdon does say the Priory of Sion was a hoax. "That's what they want you to believe". If people can't follow the unfolding story its because they have the attention span of a goldfish.

Its not in my opinion if you have faith but do you have faith in what old men wrote hundreds of years after Christs death?. This is not a theology documentary but a fictional story and a damn fine story at that. See the movie and enjoy the story its very very good. Only the MTV 30 second attention span generation would have a problem and those who can't read subtitles. French people speak french to each other and not English. _____________________________

title: U don't have to believe
review: well the movie was great! i mean a lot of people think it isn't only because it says something u might believe in but come on if movies can't influence u that much.Even in the movie, Robert Langdon says "It all depends in what you believe." This movies isn't suppose to bring so much contravery as it has and neither should the book. Dan Brown and the director of this movie were simply making a great mystery story and I have to say that if this movie and this book wouldn't have left you thinking it wouldn't of been good. If u strongly believe in what you worship then there is no need to believe in what this movies contains. After all, Dan Brown has a pretty good imagination and has to have a great mentality to put all this together. To show that, the director made an awesome movie packed with action, mystery, and betrayal. The movie was great and i would pay again to watch it in theaters!

title: Think "American Treasure" for grown-ups
review:
For all the hype surrounding it, "The Da Vinci Code" is somewhat of a letdown. At about 2.5 hours it was all I could do to not wake up my girlfriend and make an early exit from the theatre.

I'd never read the book so I didn't walk into the theatre with any expectations in that regard. However, I was somewhat disappointed that with such a smart cast and crew, the viewer has to suspend his disbelief for most, if not all, of the movie. Hanks solves the puzzles and codes a little TOO easily, and too much happens in such a short period of time. The smartest of men have worked their entire lives to do a fraction of what Langdon and Co. did in a few days.

There was no character development, save a few grainy childhood flashbacks, and the characters were rather unsympathetic. The dialogue seemed forced at times. Much of the movie I wondered if in real life Langdon would've stopped and said, "Woah woah woah... slow down here! Why am I involved in all this mess and what the hell is going on?" But he never did... despite the fact people around him were losing their lives, Hanks's character just went with the current, going where ever it took him.

I know this isn't a big deal but it bothers me... We never see a break in any of the action... we never see Langdon or Sophie or Teabigs or whatever his name is stopping for a bite to eat or a few hours to sleep or for a quick shower. Yet Langdon and Co. are going at it full-throttle; Langdon with a cleanly-shaven face and Sophie with her unblemished hair and makeup. I know, I know.. it's a ticky-tack thing to bemoan, but honestly I felt I could identify with these characters a little bit more if we saw them doing some of the routine simple things we all do in our every lives.

Overall, the movie wasn't THAT bad; I (and many like me) was let down because of the hype. Think "American Treasure" with a more sobering undertone. Everything happens too fast and everything works a little too perfectly for viewers to get seriously involved in what's going on on screen. It's apparent the world of Dan Brown's Da Vinci Code depends on a lot of brains and a hell of a lot more luck for everything to come together for our characters at the right time.

title: Maybe Ron Howard shoot of stayed by acting.
review:
I don't know why there are so many bad commentaries. Here in Belgium I was one of the first to see the movie on the 17 of may. Maybe Ron Howard shoot of stayed by acting. I know it could better the movie but it isn't that bad. Tom Hanks (as Robert Langdon), Audrey Tautou (as Sophie Neveu), Ian McKellen (Sir Leigh Teabing) and Jean Reno (as Captain Fache) are all great actors. The fact that miss Tautou speaks English with a very bad French accent makes it great. The story is in France, Langdon is a American and don't speaks French so the French speaks English to Langdon, so of course there is a French accent in there English that makes is so great.

Il loved the book and the movie. There are some things that aren't completely the same as in the book, but the story is the same.

I really recommend this movie. If you don't like the book maybe you can enjoy the film. I liked it. I could be better if there was another director. For example Chris Columbus (the first two Harry potter's are still the best till now) or Steven Spielberg one of the best directors. But the choice was Howard, not a bad choice but I think because it is Ron Howard that the reviews are so bad, the story is great. The book is a bestseller in the world.

title: A Good Film
review:
As it is a film quite based on the novel, I should say it is worth seeing to the readers. It's just like a festival coming in China this weekend. We were talking about going to the cinema in companies this Friday after school. And most of my classmates are quite expected.

Meanwhile, the box office of the cinemas are just quite busy.

The movie itself is excellent in the visual and the atmosphere.

I love the constructions in the film and I was really attracted by the plot.

Although it omitted some of the details, it is still a very theatricality and imaginative film.

title: Definitely see it to make up your own mind....
review:
I thought this film was visually fantastic and I'm not sure what critics hate about it....? I have Catholic friends who won't see it out of principle, but I think you have to see this one to make up your mind.

I didn't read the book so maybe it helps to go in with an open mind... but I thought it was refreshing, pacey and well-directed. Audrey is gorgeous and drives the film beautifully. Tom Hanks is very good through-out. I think it is interesting that in a largely-secular world, this film seems to be incurring a back-lash. It has a nice message about feminine strength and spirituality. I really enjoyed it and hope it does better at the box office than it did in critical circles. Go and see it with an open mind!

title: Everyone's a critic...a fine film that hits the mark
review:
Adapting a successful novel is a difficult task that greater directors than Ron Howard have failed. The screenplay for "The Davinci Code," is a high achievement. Little is kept out of the film and that which is changed ensures the books themes and pacing are true. The use of flashbacks to give some of the novel's depth to certain situations (especially including Sophie's upbringing) were perfectly placed and well paced). Howard's use of visual effects to help the reader through a scene--first used in "A Beautiful Mind,"--were valuable to the pacing of the film.

The casting is also spot on. Tom Hanks is being unnecessarily trashed for his portrayal of what is, by my account, one of the most poorly developed characters from a best-selling novel in decades. And I read a lot of novels. Dan Brown uses Langdon in "Code" for the second time, and thus, dispenses with some element of character development. Upon reading the novel I believed Langdon to be a very dull, essentially empty character. I thought only Tom Hanks or Kevin Spacey could fill the role of a peaceful academic caught up in an out of control situation without resorting to stuffed shirt foolishness. (Russel Crowe as Langdon would have been idiocy...I would NOT have seen that film.) Hanks appears to do an apt job of stuffing Langdon's turtleneck and getting out of the way of the story...which is this film's real selling point. Audrey Tautou made herself future millions, Jean Reno is great as Fache, Molina is very strong as the bishop, Bettany is adequate as Silas, and McKellan is a scene stealer as Teabing.

I've wasted a lot of units of $9.50 at films in my life, this was not one of those films.

title: The Da Vinci Code
review:
The Da Vinci Code movie is amazing, the movie starts out all dedicated to the famous Dan brown novel. But as you go in, you are soon to realize that they change tinny bit's of it so it fits the movie time perfectly. For all the people that have read the Da Vinci Code and loved it, well you better go watch the movie, it is a fast paced movie, thats keeps you wondering the whole time, and shocks you in the end. Its film locations are gorgeous, and its story line is amazing, and for all the fellow catholics like me that are, i mean, were offended by the book and the movie. Don't worry, they do not make it such a big deal, the movie is half and half. They don't totally offend the catholic church but at the same time get there story line across without offending anyone. An for all those people who thought that if they change what happens from the book in the movie they will ruin it, well, they change certain parts, but they keep the important ones, and if they change an important one, they change it so you still understand. Buuutttttttt. The movie wouldn't have been the movie without the actors, i give them a round of applause, they made the movie. An in my opinion Audrie Tatou, (Sophie Neveu) was the best actor. This movie is amazing and everyone should go watch it. I am saying that this movie is going to win an Oscar!!!!!

Agostino Leone

P.S. Everyone, don't listen to the critics, they don't know what they are taking about, it was a great performance, Bravo, Tom Hanks, Audrie Tatou, Ian Mckellan, Jean-Pierre Marielle, Jean Reno, Paul Betanny and Alfred Molina,

BRAVO

title: I liked it
review:
I enjoyed the movie.

Of course, the book is better, but most books don't translate 100% to the screen.

My big problem with the movie, and hence my 7 instead of 10, was all the flashback scenes with the crusades and young Sophie. Flashback scenes work well in novels, but don't always don't translate well in movies. This was no exception. The flashback scenes drew my attention away.

Another issue was some of the scenes were so bright that they actually hurt my eyes.

But all in all, I was pleased with the movie. It could have been a lot worse, and it could have been a bit better.

title: Great Movie - A Must See
review:
For reader's of Dan Brown's The DaVinci Code, they will find that the Ron Howard has done a good job of ensuring that he has kept with the Plot.

Acting in the movie is great, and directing is fabulous. I was engaged throughout the whole movie. I am usually very picky with movie endings but was very satisfied with the movies ending, leaving me wanting to watch more.

I can't wait to watch the movie again. You MUST Watch the movie carefully DO NOT think you can walk into the movie and lose track - if you do you might not enjoy the movie, as many on this site have. Lastly, watch the movie with an open mind! Ajay

title: public are loving it,it was awesome
review: I went to see this movie last night and was blown away,yes some critics have had a pop but it wont matter all shows last night were sold out and we had to Que for ages,no bad review will stop people going and listening to people saying how great it was at the end was pleasing knowing this will be a massive hit as it is such a fascinating subject. The book was fantastic and Ron Howard has done a great job of it on film,i found it fascinating.The acting is top class Tom Hanks excels as Robert langdon and sir ian is as watchable as ever.The camera work throughout was superb and the choice of music spot on.This was a brilliantly made thriller that had me sat on the edge of my seat and was so interesting as I'm open minded on such a worldwide subject with various opinions,it really makes you think.10 out of 10

title: What have they done?!
review:
I DEMAND A REMAKE !!!! I loved the book, but what a rubbish tribute(the movie) was to such a magnificent work of art (the book)!!! Disappointed beyond disappointed. This movie should have met the likes of King Kong, Titanic, Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, but quite simply didn't reach anywhere above the Princess Diaries 2(a much better movie may i add). It was as sour as a sequel and as deprived of detail as my printing paper. Maybe a bit far-fetched but... lets hope in a few years from now we will see a properly done remake that isn;t going to tip us to the edge of utter boredom. Tom Hanks was just wrong for the part,he was much to old and passionless, like ''oops i found a keystone to the holy grail(giggle giggle)'' and their lines were stunningly dead. It was like they were forced to do the movie and desperately didn't want anything to do with it. Fache and Silas were the only two characters that struck me as good. In the remake I would love to see Silas played by the same guy! Fache, loved him too, room for improvement in this movie, but the actor is a saint among actors.

Overall... if I was a director I wouldn't have had the guts to release that!

title: Magnificent, but you have to sort out Fiction from Fact on your own!
review: Well first I must admit that I'm one of the 21 people on this planet that didn't read the book, but I found the movie magnificent! Great ways of filming and acting, good script and a very exiting storyline! But I'm kinda familiar with history, so I new when I was watching the movie I noticed that some things, in the movie were presented as facts, where actually incorrect or made up! So you have to keep in mind when you're watching the Da Vinci Code that it's a mix of more fiction than facts! When you don't think about this, and you are not making any judgement towards any religion on this earth based on the storyline of this movie, it's absolutely wonderful and very exiting! I can see why there is al this media-fuzz about this movie, because fiction is presented as facts in the movie. Though, it's interesting that it maybe possible that indeed there is a small possebilty that Christ was married and evenso maybe had a child...so that sheds a interesting light on this movie. But always remember, read wikipedia afterwards you've seen the Da Vinci Code, because there you can read the Facts and not the Fiction in the movie!

title: The Divinci Cult
review:
When the Tom Hanks character confesses that he once said a prayer to Jesus when he was a boy, a prayer similar to a boys desire for Santa Claus to bring him a puppy dog for Christmas, it was a moment that revealed what lied in the heart of the main character, nothing at all. Like any good fairy tale, there is a little bit of truth and a whole lot of make believe in order for a tale to be enchanting.

The Davinci Code is a very good bit of Hollywood movie making. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou are world class actors. Ron Howard made a very entertaining murder mystery movie. There was a good balance of tension rapped around the urgent need of the heroes to uncover a mystery.

The films shortcoming has to do with its biblical inaccuracies. Like the biblical inaccuracies redefined as doctrine within the Catholic Church, I'm afraid most fans of the book and now the movie will be seduced by this new cult that has been unleashed onto a naive populous.

title: design of the Louvre
review: i might sound a bi thick here, i haven't read the book although i don't quick rad u on the story before i saw the movie, ..... DA vinci left clues on the back of the rose on that box telling them were M.M was buried or rested, under stars ETC, ...in Roslyn castle thats were she would have been or was, .. but at the end he follows the "rose- line " and ends up on the glass roof of Louvre which also has all the clues in its location the chalets and the starry nights, .... who designed that modern addtion to the Louvre as they must be aware of M.M place of rest was it sophies grandfather?. is that why he was at the Louvre in first place as the grandmaster of P/S to watch over DA Vince's work?

title: The Da Vinci Code
review: The Da Vinci Code is a great and very fast-paced movie. One bad thing about the movie is that there are some subtitles, but there isn't too much and they aren't all that bad. There is some nudity in this movie but it is just back end and it is very brief, it also plays a significant role in the movie. I really liked the character of Leigh Teabing. I believe Ian McKellan did an excellent job portraying Teabing. If you like movies with codes and "riddles" (for lack of a better word) then you will definitely like The Da Vinci Code. Tom Hanks plays Robert Langdon and he does an amazing job. When I first saw the cast list I didn't think Hanks would make a good Langdon but he did and I was very surprised. Overall The Da Vinci Code is a very great movie and worth the money for sure.

title: Best compliment
review:
The best compliment I can give 'The Da Vinci Code' is this: When I left the cinema last night, _everybody_ was quite when leaving the theater. I think that says enough! Back at the car I still had the creeps from the ending scene.

Lightning, sound, it all came together with my imagination while reading the book. Also most of the characters. However, the most important person (Prof Langdon) didn't fit my expectation. And the chemistry between Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou isn't the one you would expect when you have read the book.

Nevertheless, the critics in the national (Dutch) papers were not to be called very good. But as a reader of the book, I think the movie kept the speed fascinating. Not to quick and not to slow, well done Mr Howard! And like many other 'critics' at IMDb keep saying: take it as a nice fiction story, forget your theology background and just enjoy...

title: absolutely disappointed
review: I was really looking forward to watch this film and of course in the end I felt disappointed like anyone else, I guess, who read the book before watching the movie. Although the cast was perfect (Ian Mckellen was the very appropriate person acting Teabing and Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou were very convincing too), it remained unused and marginalized by the lack of suspense. Also, interesting scenes of the book have been ignored while others have been changed dramatically in order to limit the duration of the film but that affected the transmission of the deepest ideas expressed in the book. To sum up the most interesting and thrilling book of the last 20 years turned into an ordinary adventure for pop corns. Against to all of these, I find it a good motive for the 1% of the world who did not read the book to start reading it.

title: A very interesting movie
review: 'The Da Vinci code' is not only a very well made film plenty of action and excellent performances, but also an interesting story which could be true or not depending on people. The film is quite similar to the book and although it is totally impossible to describe the whole book on a 2 and a half hour film, the movie is very close to the book. I like both, the book and the film. I do not understand why the critics have been so critic with it because 'The Da Vinci code' is full of action and very well made, other thing is that perhaps they do not like the story, but this is another question. What I do not understand either is the attitude of some powerful groups of the Catholic church, as a Catholic I dot not feel ofended by the film because it is just fiction, nothing else. There is no reason for attacking neither the book nor the film, if the Opus Dei attacks it is because this is a powerful, conservative and dangerous sect inside the Catholic church. But apart from what the Opus Dei say we live in a free society where there is freedom of expression and they should keep in mind that our society is secular and everybody has the right to think by themselves. I feel totally ofended by the declarations of the Opus, which are absolutely closed to the fundamentalist Muslims. In conclusion, I totally recommend this film to all those people who have enjoyed the book.

title: Good entertainment - don't expect much else
review:
The Da Vinci code (the book) is a clever story. The film makes excellent work of a clever story in a well-directed way. It cuts out the unnecessary sub-plots and complications (e.g. instead of solving a puzzle-within-a-puzzle, they just solve a puzzle), and adds to a somewhat drab book a certain elegance, grandeur and ethos. For worried book-fans, don't worry - it follows the book pretty faithfully, with obvious licenses necessary for a film.

The soundtrack is fantastic and atmospheric - although not so much so that it becomes over-the-top. The director must be commended for pulling off the story without taking it all far too seriously. Epic is not overdone and is sparse, mystery is not blown out of proportion but is gripping. It is very delicately handled by Ron Howard in light of the obvious success of the book: a very good adaptation; in my mind better than the book.

The film introduces (or emphasises) certain motifs and themes not as strong in the book, for instance putting more of an influence of the visual motif of a rose. This adds a certain style and director's license to the film which makes it more than just a book-to-film transcription.

Despite certain poor performances (odd extras, and Sophie Neveu), Hanks and McKellen, plus particularly Bettany, pull off their characters very well indeed. Silas (Bettany) is done extremely well.

Overall I feel this film was an enrichment to a good story, certainly worthy as a counterpart, if not as a replacement altogether. Grand and visually rich, it was certainly worth watching - but maybe only once.

title: Da Vinci Code is not as bad as you may hear
review:
I saw the movie tonight, and having read the book for the first time only two weeks ago, I feel the movie stood up well. There were a few plot line changes, but that is to be expected when developing a movie from a book. In all actuality, I liked the changes. As a Catholic, I was not in the least bit offended by the movie or the book, but especially the movie. Always keep in mind, IT IS A WORK OF FICTION. I feel that the book and movie can be used to strengthen or even encourage one's faith in what they choose to believe. It raises points that if researched, may actually bring you to deeper understanding of your faith. I hope that the movie will cause people to look into these issues for themselves. Don't take the movie as history. Too many people do that

Tom Hanks didn't give the performance of his life, but I felt he was pretty much the way I imagined Robert Langdon as I read the book. Sophie's character in the movie wasn't as strong as in the book, but I think that is due to time constraints. Some things had to be glossed over or skipped to keep the movie down to 2 1/2 hours.

Any way, the movie is worth a look, don't get too caught up in what the critics are saying, and remember it is a work of fiction.

title: Not the Movie of the Year
review:
The Da Vinci Code book was the continuity of the trend started with angels and demons. Same plot.. same character.. same situations.. same twist.. but hey .. its a bestseller.. and it must be for a reason.

But moving to the movie, if you are expecting to see the book translated word by word to the screen I strongly recommend you NOT to watch it!.. I can't say it's a piece of nothing.. it has a lot of scenes in which.. if you haven't read the book .. you'll get completely lost. I lot from the book is skip or changed but .. as it says in the credits.. "BASED ON THE NOVEL" not "EXACTLY LIKE IT"..

This isn't THE movie of year.. or of the month.. or of the week. I mean, I know it will sell a lot, but its not a great movie.. Some people have said to me that the movie was slow.. and i say it was going on a little fast. for not-readers comprehension..it misses order and a lot of explanations. My apologies to Howards.. but this wasn't your best work. In other part, congrats to Hanks cause he did a good R. Langdong.. not what i would wanted ..but good anyways..

For my conclusion, the Da Vinci Code, its just that movie that you have to see.. only because it will be the most commented thing the next day. But i think the essence or the power and force of book and its ideas were lost in transition! Thank u!

title: Just great..
review: With a book loaded with details, which covers a journey that almost can't be caught on film, why worry about the length of the film and the depth of details inside the movie? It's a wonderful journey, especially by the great acting of Audrey Tatou. Must see, even if you didn't read the book..The riddles, the suspense. Everything makes this movie one you have to watch. The chase in Paris with the Smart is crazy, but very nicely done. By all means, you couldn't expect anything more in the translation from the book to the cinema. Of course some people won't like the movie, especially because of the statements made. But when you look through those statements, it's a very nice movie, and the look of Paris and London makes up for some losses (like not filming in the Westminster).

title: Highly Disappointed
review: I was highly disappointed with the DaVinci Code movie. After finishing the book I was anticipating a great movie, but it didn't deliver. I thought there were way too many plot deviations from the story line in the book. I understand that some of the plot had to be changed to speed the story along, but most of what was changed was either unnecessary or way off the original plot line. It didn't go as deep into the breaking of the code as the book did. It also seemed to me that Robert Langdon didn't know much. The book made him seem highly intelligent and in the movie he seems to be learning just as much as Sophie about the grail. The end took a VERY different turn and overall I was just annoyed with the changes. I am recommending to my friends to skip the movie and read the book instead.

title: Da Vinci code, Not so bad after all
review:
Some people thought this movie was bad, but please notice it is a film version of the best selling book. I've to give in, that there some mistakes and some important things missed , but they had to summarize a whole book. There are so much complainers but all of them compare the movie with the book. You have to watch this movie as a movie, just like you watch the harry potter movies as a movie.

The Da Vinci code has some beautiful special effects, it's a bit in the style of a beautiful mind (also from director Ron Howard). The Da Vinci Code isn't so bad as many people say that it is. But thats my opinion.

Don't listen what others say, if you want to watch it, WATCH IT. If you don't, DON'T.

Vincent

title: Well done Ron Howard!
review: I have the misfortune of not reading the book. I understand a lot of people that have first read this story will be upset. I have already read reviews of people that are upset. It seems the only REAL complaint is that the book is much better. As a person that has not had the privilege, I enjoyed the movie. It was never dull, and it was never insulting. The characters were well played, and the story was non offensive. It could have criticized the church but didn't. It was an incredibly interesting movie and I highly recommend it to all. The only complaint I have is that I had to sit in an uncomfortable movie theater seat for two and a half hours. Go see this movie. My advice to those who have read the book is to separate the two in your head. It would be an insult for a movie to replace a novel. Movies of books have and will always be highlights, or they will be just one short interpretation of the story itself. This is a great interpretation.

title: Expect a provocative and intelligent thriller!
review:
A man runs through the Louvre museum in Paris, France past paintings as a dark figure pursues him. He falls while attempting to remove a large painting only to meet his death at gunpoint by a robed, albino assailant. Forced to reveal a secret before his demise, with his body later pentangled in the pose of Leonardo Da Vinci's Vitruvian Man, this smart and intriguing film begins. Did the dying man, with his last ounce of energy, draw a pentangle on himself in his own blood and finally die in this Vitruvian pose (notable for Da Vinci's attempt to correlate the material with the spiritual aspects of human existence) in order to leave a material clue or evidence that leads to a spiritual revelation? After viewing the film, I think yes.

This movie was not what I thought it would be. It was more. Although fiction, it weaved a tale of theatrical suspense, drama, and excitement driven by an intelligent theme without delving into gratuitous violence or substitution of literary substance with the distraction of superficial action meant as filler. This is what I really enjoyed, thickening plot, interesting characters, dueling motives, the unexpected, and of course literary drama based on historical perspective. Scholarly Robert Langdon (actor Tom Hanks) and Paris police cryptologist Sophie Neveu (actress Audrey Tautou) initially form an uneasy team based on mutual motives to discover the identity of her grandfather's murderer, which later builds into a close and mutually inter-dependent alliance. The benefit of this alliance, each with their own open-minded contributions, is that their individual strengths support the other's weaknesses as they unlock the multi-faceted code.

The film's premise is that Mary Magdalene was not only the apostle believed to be John to Jesus' right in Da Vinci's painting of the Last Supper, but also was his wife who, after the crucifixion, bore Jesus a daughter named Sarah. Artful and intelligent, coded elements are designed to connect finally ending with the answer regarding the holy bloodline of Jesus. This cannot be revealed to the general public, as it would likely bring into question the credibility and legitimacy of Christianity based on the divinity of Christ. So there exists a rogue Christian sect that must ensure its secrecy and preserve the continuity of the belief that Jesus was divine and not just a man; for the revelation of even the possibility that Jesus sired a child would have indicated that he was indeed just a man and not divine (in the face of the immaculate conception), directly challenging the concept of the trinity. Additionally, does the aspect of apostolic gender jealousy enter into the equation? Suffice to say that there is plenty of evidence that Jesus could have sired a child.

Ron Howard did a fine job directing the audience to rely on examination of evidence in front of them. This combined with the fast pace forced the two main characters, and by extension the audience, to think on their toes and not just blindly and dogmatically follow what has been told what to believe. Look what the church had been doing for decades regarding pedophilia, which was protected by the clergy only to repeat itself. Its results are ethical, moral and financial bankruptcy.

One thing that I learned from established artist friends is that one never leaves the center of a painting empty (the masters would never do this). This artistic no-no came into distinct focus while reviewing Da Vinci's Last Supper. Da Vinci was a brilliant man and for him to inadvertently leave the center of an important painting empty I believe is unlikely. The patrons who commissioned it were furious at his four-year delay (1495 - 1498) but he refused to go faster. The empty space is there for a reason. Da Vinci was known at the time to dislike the direction of the Roman Catholic Church and was also known to be heretical. With obvious motive, and the fact that his main focus was his love for science and anatomy (artistry a bit of a sideline), since he only made 27 paintings (most incomplete) to approach these select few paintings with the embodiment of cryptic symbolism is not a surprising activity.

An interesting character development scene is when Sophie exhibits a proclivity for coolness under fire during the Parisian street escape lending credibility to the secret she and the audience were later to discover. This demonstration of a natural affinity for confidence and leadership in taking matters into her own protective hands while under physical danger underlined the feminine aspect early in the movie. This personal tendency would later inherently support the film's central revelation. Film notables include the saying "The mind sees what it wants to see," laughter by the women in the audience when Sophie tapped her sole on a pond, and the final scene leaving the distinct possibility of a sequel open.

Again, like the furor over the Last Temptation of Christ, The Passion of the Christ, faith was not shaken or stirred. I was excited at the thought of watching the film knowing it would be controversial & provocative. My personal faith remains well intact as I continue to respect the authority of God while questioning the intentions of people and their misinterpretations of the Bible for personal gain. The Bible does not state Jesus married; however it does not state that he didn't either. But if you ask me, in a world so corrupt, insolent, unforgiving, arrogantly contemptuous, meaninglessly violent, sometimes seemingly headed towards some no good place, it would be a nice thought that the sacred bloodline perpetuated over millennia for salvation in our time. So my questions are these: What if the Sangre Real bloodline still endured today? Could it have survived to contemporary times in secrecy? And if it did, would that be a silent test for us as individuals and the public at large? Finally, what if this blood is within you? What would you do?

title: Few changes from the novel!
review: The book was written like a movie. Short chapters, quick action, suspense, etc. So the movie adapted well. In the movie Langdon is summoned differently, they change some of the character's relations slightly, but nothing you'd notice to be important. The flash back footage of Paris, Israel, London was great. They really took advantage of illustrating history visually. Audrey Tautou who plays Sophie Neveu is a 10. Movie was cool! It wasn't insulting to catholocism at all. The "teacher" who is the villain, is the one making the church and Opus Die look bad. Everybody else is cool about religion. People need to get a hobby. Stop crying every time a movie or show or book comes out that people say mocks your religion. People like that never even see the movies or read the books anyway. They're just bored with life.

title: NOT as good as the book... NOT by a long-shot
review:
I had VERY high hopes for the movie... While it was decent, I think I might be a little bit generous in giving it a 7 out of 10 stars. Primarly because I _really_ liked the book, and am thinking that perhaps, because I read the book, it somewhat jilted a perhaps really great movie.

I can understand they can't portray everything the book has (due to time limitations) -- no problem. But to, instead of just cutting things out, change the story, doesn't seem good.

If you have to see the movie in the theater (and can't wait to rent it), I might recommend waiting until it starts playing in the second-run theaters. If you can't wait that long, at least see it during the matinÃ©e showing so you're not paying an arm and a leg.

title: "it doesn't matter what you do or hear, it is what you believe"
review:
This movie was all great from any perspective you may see it. Whether it didn't follow the book thoroughly or some facts or scenes were missing. The fact stays that this movie turnout to one of the most calculating and thrilling movie about what we believe.

People or critics argue that they didn't follow the book or it should have been more descriptive as like the book did.people,It doesn't mean that everything you've read in the book will come out in the movie itself.What's the cause of having Ron Howard on the director's seat?I was also quite disappointed too that some of the scenes in the book weren't shown in the movie, but you've got to hand it to Ron Howard for giving a very unique and brilliant persona or aura of the movie.

For the people who have read the book and watch the movie,it creates a friction and a opposite force which results to a disappointing and confused shock.but for people who haven't read it,gives that person a positive outcome wherein he does not find emptiness or shall we say missing something in the movie.

The cast was great and was perfect for there roles.I don't only want to credit Tom Hanks and Ian McKellen but the WHOLE cast.Everyone was fit and right for their roles.

to sum it up,this movie is great even though somethings were left out. The movie as i said was unique compared to the book and everyone who made the movie should pat their shoulder for a job well done.Finally,to all the haters and people who think this movie is of blasphemy, read my title.

title: Da Vinci Code Delivers
review:
I've read the book three times, and knew the movie wouldn't be as good as the book. Still, the major plot points are treated well for those few who don't know the story or the reason for the controversy. At times, the film does seem rushed, but at 2 hours and 26 minutes, extending the film any longer may have had the opposite effect, ie: the film seemed too long.

The movie plays out like the book, so expect a lot of flashback sequences, not just for the characters, but historical flashbacks that help to push the movie forward.

I wouldn't look for any academy awards out of this film, but it certainly does entertain, and for fans of the book, it is a real treat to see the story presented in a movie format. But for the casual moviegoer, I think they may struggle to keep up and follow the story cause there are elements left out from the book that could help explain certain scenes and motivations more. All in all, a good film. Could it have been made better? Sure. But it could have also been much worse.

title: Very Good Movie
review:
I just saw the "Da Vinci Code" and I was so pleased that the "critics" got it wrong. I loved the movie and it was as faithful to the book as it could be. Ron Howard did a very good job as well as the cast but the real winner was the the message the film sent. I noticed the audience seemed riveted to the screen. I'd give them a lot more credit for intelligence than those critics seemed to think. The Rosslyn Chapel sequence was beautiful.

Sometimes movies and fiction open doors to ideas that help us understand our world so much better. This is one of those movies and one of those times.

title: When it finally ended, I recall smiling and giving the arm rest of my seat a good thump as I, myself, had triumphantly solved the whole thing.
review:
Having never read the book on which this film is based, I can safely say I hold no bias in either direction one might steer when gauging it's value. I watched this movie with an open mind and simply sought to be entertained. And I must say, despite a few odd things I noticed during my viewing tonight, I was thoroughly entertained throughout.

Firstly, let me say that the music here did not stick out for me until the end, as which point it was the driving force behind all you could see. The main theme to this film is beautiful. You'll find yourself humming it as you leave the theatre, I do not doubt. Onto the characters...

Tom Hanks did not strike me as the man who was born to play this role. He is, of course, a professional through and through and I got the feeling that he did the best he could. His character, however, did not seem suited to him. Mr. Hanks just does not strike me a deep thinker, not on this magnitude, although he does pull off a very casual method to it all as I imagine a genius would adapt. There are scenes where Mr. Hanks is in deep or frenzied thought, trying to sort through a puzzle of some sort in order to progress to the next step, and I can quite honestly believe that he is sorting it all out at the pace that is suggested. I credit the use of computer graphics for this more than his acting (the use of CGI was very well done here and showed us exactly what was on his mind and how he went about solving it). He doesn't give too much away by thinking aloud, nor are we expected to come up with it all ourselves. We're shown his thought pattern so he doesn't have to tell us and, so long as you are not an idiot, you can easily see where he is going and in most cases arrive at the same conclusion as he.

Audrey Tautou's character did little for me. Serving as the character who asks all the questions that we, the audience, would like answered, she can certainly communicate a sense of motivation. Her character seems surprisingly simple until the last legs of the movie, where more focus is mercifully placed on her and we can truly begin to appreciate her. One funny little thing bothered me though, and that is her character's apparent superhuman driving ability. How she got as good as she did is never shared, nor does it seem we're expected to wonder about.

Paul Bettany did a fantastic job here. As a fanatically faithful servant of God, one willing to go so far as murder to uphold ancient tradition, he brilliantly conveys a man lost in his faith. A troubled character to be sure. I found myself pitying him not long after his introduction. A maimed and tortured soul to be sure.

Ian MaKellen steals the show the moment you hear him. The man is quite brilliant, and having him play a brilliant man was a logical and wise choice. Combine his earthly wisdom with some great lines (he made me laugh more than once) and you have a truly great character to watch and grow attached to.

The pacing of this film was spot on. I never felt rushed nor did I ever feel I was being dragged down. I received all the information I needed to appreciate the plight of the characters and I felt quite satisfied when a pivotal moment or clue is passed. I watched this film alongside my two cousins (who both enjoyed the movie as much as I) and was surprised to learn the movie is as long as it is. When it finally ended, I recall smiling and giving the arm rest of my seat a good thump as I, myself, had triumphantly solved the whole thing.. I loved the ending to this film, especially the music.

I need to get that soundtrack!

title: You won't be disappointed
review:
I find it disappointing that most of the negative reviews of this movie is based on the controversy centred around Jesus rather than on the actual storyline and quality of the movie. I have read Da Vinci code a year ago and at that point in time this book has not left much impression on me as much as what it has on others. I personally enjoyed Angels and Demons more than the Da Vinci Code and always thought that it will make a better thriller movie than the Da Vinci Code. So, I went into the cinema with very little expectation out from this movie.

Surprisingly, after watching the movie, it has rekindled my interest in re-reading the Da Vinci Code. I like the flow and the pace of the movie and it was very comfortable sitting through the two and a half hour movie. I think people has been too harsh on this movie. I am not going to argue about what are facts and fictions here. There is not a single moment of boredom and from the point of entertainment, it has certainly done its job. As a consumer, I could not ask for more. So, well done Ron Howard, Tom Hanks and the rest!

title: An echo of the novel...slightly different, and not heard as well.
review:
Every now and then a best seller rises up to international fame, a film hitches the ride and punishes audiences with missing scenes, bad direction, story change and everything else that made the novel so special. This is not the entire case for Ron Howards 'The Da Vinci Code'. Normally i think it would be wrong to compare a film to its novel, however there is no secret to its popularity and it wouldn't be wrong to assume most of the viewers of the film would be the readers of the novel or Tom Hanks and/or Amilie fans.

The film in comparison to the book is not far off, only the occasional additional lines, that i will not give away, seem to be strategically placed to calm the Christians who were outraged by the novel. The character of Robert Langdon seems to be dumbed down and given a spiritual side, this i could imagine would outrage the most devout believers of the novels claims. However, i still think even though the film was not completely faithful (95% faithful) to the novel, it was still a good little puppy; following the main issues of the book. The film did create the atmosphere i remember reading about, i found myself sitting in the theatre and thinking 'this is how i imagined it' but then again i have seen postcards of France.

The performances of the actors were mediocre. Tom Hanks was lacking dimensions of a character known so well to so many, personally when reading the novel i pictured Harrison Ford in the pre-adventure university lecturing acts of the Indiana Jones movies. Audrey Tautou wasn't as great as i imagined her to be, my advise would be not to expect too much from her. Ian McKellen (Sir Leigh Teabing) was fantastic, i imagined his character to be stocky from the novel, but i forgot all that at once when seeing the charming old bugger.

The film loses a sense of revelation, which the readers of the novel apparently obtain. My guess it was done to calm outraged Christians, but it is my guess again why they would be watching the film. However with or without revelations, the film was entertaining and worth the watch. Bonza!

title: This film delivers what it promises.
review: After both reading the book and seeing the film, I was surprised that the film was much better. The film tightened up the story greatly which was good because the book got long winded in some places. The pacing of the film keep you involved so the 2 plus hours flew by. The acting was well done with much of the dialog in French as it should be. (I hate to see French actors having to speak English especially when the film takes place in France). Despite how you feel about the theology of Dan Brown the author, the story is engaging and very entertaining. I don't believe that the film is going to undermine anyone's faith and I resent people saying that I or anyone else should't see it. I especially agree with the film's director Ron Howard that we need more films like this to get people talking and asking questions about the history and foundation of the Christian faith so that those who profess to be Christians know why it is that they believe what they believe. Should get best picture of the year.

title: View on movie largely depends on if you read the book....
review:
If you read the book, you'll likely be disappointed in the movie. Not necessarily think it was awful, just another one of those "the book is TEN TIMES better than the movie" type of deal.

If you didn't read the book you don't deserve to see the movie. Do yourself a favor and read the book. Rent the movie after.

I'm not a huge book person.... at all. And lots of times I actually enjoy the movie more than the book... i'm a bit of a movie fanatic. But this is one case where I can honestly say the book is much better than the movie. While I enjoyed the movie, the two types of media give the story an ENTIRELY different feel. The book is more mystery like and non-stop suspense. The clues unravel piece by piece yet you have no idea what to expect and each page is like a riddle. The movie, on the other hand, may have a mystery/suspense overtone, but it's not as adrenaline based and the information and clues revealed along the way are not as exciting to discover.

title: It's a fictional novel... fictional movie... why all the hostility towards it?
review:
I read the book when it first came out and could not believe how it captivated me. I am a Christian and understand how religious people could be offended, but in the book, Dan Brown states the facts of the novel on the front page.

Now to the movie...

The novel was adapted seamlessly to a movie, probably because of the very descriptive way Brown writes his novel. I felt like I was literally watching the book. I think those that have not read The Da Vinci Code will also enjoy this movie. Ron Howard did a great job of providing a lot of info from the novel to convey the whole story. Bottom line, this movie will top the box office for a while and will probably grab some awards, too. Not seeing this movie because of strong religious beliefs is ignorant. You can't criticize it until you see it.

title: Not great... not bad... It's just entertainment.
review:
This is the typical case that the Trailer is better than the movie itself. But, after all, I really liked this movie. I'm from Chile, and in here the premiere was before that in USA. That's great. Yeah! Well, I found it a good movie, basically because I go to the theater to have a great time, and forget all the problems. It's very faithful to the book, but the beginning was really fast. Like light-speed. The scenes in the Louvre were to shorts. That's was disappointing. But from the moment they visit the house of Sir Teabing, the movie is better. The best of the movie were sir Ian McKellen and a amazing Paul Bettany, both were the best characters from the movie. And of course, the good cinematography and the locations. What a good end. Not as well that the book, but good after all. If you like the book, you will love it. It's just entertainment, of the good one. Do you want something else? In that case, what a hell do you want????????? The critics a really wrong... Give it a chance to this movie.

7/10

title: The Bad Reviews it got -- are all a crock of sh*t...
review:
If you've read the book, you'll love the movie. It plays to the book about 90%.

I've heard a lot of horrible reviews from pre-screenings...critics were harsh on this one, saying that Tom Hanks was boring in his role. ... but, like I said before, if you read the book, you can appreciate the fact that he played the character pretty much to a 'T'.

I saw the movie tonight, somehow got in even though all the screenings prior to mine were sold out.

I heard comments from the audience throughout the movie, people who obviously have not read the book... They were a bit confused. There is so much going on that unless you get the detail as it is in the book about everything, you're confused. There is a point in a movie where it all finally starts to make sense to the viewer.

Like most GREAT books, it's hard to fit everything into a movie of 2.5hours. I think Ron Howard did a great job.

Unlike Memoirs of a Geisha, The Da Vince Code movie... was like reading the book all over again. Props to Howard.

For those of you who have not read the book, I recommend purchasing the audio version, especially if you have a long commute to work. This is what I did, and thank goodness, because I never would have been able to pronounce everyone's name just by reading them. Also, the audio version has voice overs so it's like listening to multiple actors ... watching TV with your eyes closed...

title: The Code
review: I enjoyed the movie very much. For those who are fans of the book, the movie does stick quite closely to the novel. Even though the critics panned the movie, I enjoyed and so has everyone else that I know that saw the movie. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tatou do amazing performances, not a big shocker to those who know their work. You forget the time (even though the movie is not that long) because of how quickly and smoothly the movie goes. It is best for those who watch the movie read the book first, for there are some parts that are unexplained. Yet, for those who have seen this movie already, I wonder does anyone know what the code that flashed in the middle left of the screen was? Those who saw the movie do not know what it means, so if someone could please explain that would be wonderful.

title: All of you will go to hell that see this movie!!!!
review:
Well, you will not, just spend the 8 t 14 bucks to be part of the hype, and see a OK movie... People; If Rome and the Church can get though Galileo, Charles Darwin and Herbert Spencer; they will get pass Tom Hanks... Is it just media? Discuss? I have to make more then ten lines to post this I have to make more then ten lines to post this

I have to make more then ten lines to post this I have to make more then ten lines to post thisI have to make more then ten lines to post thisI have to make more then ten lines to post thisI have to make more then ten lines to post thisI have to make more then ten lines to post this Herbert Spencer (27 April 1820  8 December 1903) was an English philosopher and prominent liberal political theorist. Although today he is chiefly remembered as the father of Social Darwinism, a school of thought that applied the evolutionist theory of survival of the fittest (a phrase coined by Spencer) to human societies, he also contributed to a wide range of subjects, including ethics, metaphysics, religion, politics, rhetoric, biology and psychology. He was a close contemporary of many famous philosophers and scientists of his period such as John Stuart Mill, Thomas Huxley and Charles Darwin and was renowned for the long-reaching, accessible, and profoundly sensible qualities of his work. Although he has often been criticized as a perfect example of scientism, he was at the time considered by many to be one of the most brilliant men of his generation.

title: Good movie, although it is rather long
review: I watched this movie without any expectations, good or bad, and came out thinking it was a good movie. The movie keeps you interested by feeding you bits and pieces of the story at a time. Hanks does a good job, as usual, but Paul Betany stole the show in my opinion. He portrays his character with such raw emotion, viewers can't help but feel sympathy for Silas, "the ghost". The filming was also done very well, the viewing into the past was magnificently done. My one complaint with this movie is that the ending ran a little long, causing most of us to grow fidgety and wonder where Ron Howard is leading us, only to discover that it was just a long ending. Overall, I would have to say that this movie was a success, despite what critics may say.

title: All star cast and director giving an all star film.
review: Having read the book and hearing negative comments I was skeptical. I was surprised, I thought Audrey Tautou nailed her role perfectly. I also thought Tom Hanks was OK, not that he was bad he is still Forrest Gump to me. Simply put Ron Howard put to film what I envisioned when reading the book. I think that this would be hard for any director to make in that it was such a hit as book that everyone knows the story ahead of time how can you have suspense knowing what the next scene will bring. It's like watching Titanic you know the boat sinks there is no getting around that but you can still enjoy the movie. I can't wait for Angels & Demons to hit the big screen and the Solomon Key to get published. I may be biased because I am a big fan of Dan Brown's. This is a film that you will either love it or hate it I for one loved it.

title: Congrats to Ron Howard
review: Although reviews for this Ron Howard film have been mixed (and thats putting it mildly), I thoroughly enjoyed it. It is slow moving at points but it is necessary to explain the story. I found Tom Hanks to play a pretty solid character in Robert Langdon. Almost precisely as I had imagined in reading Dan Brown's best seller. The use of flashbacks can become annoying, but I found the visuals in them and throughout the entire film incredible. Once again Ian McKellen is outstanding and possibly saves this film from critical destruction. I would definitely not let negative reviews deter you from seeing this because the visuals, locations and story are amazing.

title: Very good job but not as good as the book
review: I personally liked the movie. The truth is that Tom Hanks doesn't feed in really well to the character of Robert Langdon we are all used to. Anyway Ian Mckellen as well as Audrey Tautou made a great job. Jean Renois perfect for the part of Bezu Fache. The script is very attached to the book except for the ending which is quite different. But for all the people who haven't read the book I suggest you watch it. It's a great movie. And it is also a great story. And for the people that did read it. Also watch it 'cause I think it's just about the best anyone can do which such a great book. And by the way Audrey Tautou looks fantastic!!!

title: Another Well Made Film by Ron Howard
review:
I went to see the film on the first day when it was released for the public. Having read a few negative reviews in the media, I was rather apprehensive about this film by Ron Howard. I recently purchased the illustrated edition of the Da Vinci Code, but decided to read it after watching the film, as I did not want to know how the story begins, progress and ends. Here I was inside the theater with no anticipation or expectation. The author, Dan Brown never claimed his book was based on facts, and consequently he called it a fiction.

The result was fantastic. I enjoyed every second of it's 149 minutes. It was Indiana Jones all over again, except the Da Vinci Code was a bit more intellectually written, a step higher than the average "Boys Adventure" story. During the hunting for the Holy Grail, the characters study several paintings by Leonardo Da Vinci, and found a clue in his Last Supper. Whether the person standing right side of Christ was Mary Magdalin or John the Apostle maybe debatable. But for the sake of the film, it had to be Mary Magdalin to whom Christ was married and bore a child. Apparently this information was considered taboo in the religious world, and certain factions within the religion tried to conceal that side from the public at any cost- including murders.

AS the story progress, there were a couple of times, the dialog seemed to be a bit lengthy when explaining some of the controversial theories. This is to be expected in a film like this, as it is going to be screened worldwide where there are millions of non Christians gather into their theaters to enjoy.

Tom Hanks has done justice to his character as Professor Robert Langdon. Ian Mckellan is brilliant as Lee Teibing who outshines all others. Audrey TauTou's Sophie is commendable. French actor Jean Reno- I haven't seen him since his appearance in Mission Impossible- is built for this role. Paul Bettany's Silas too was well done. The sound effects combined with the Dolby Digital was fabulous. All in all, Ron Howard made another good film to entertain the hungry audiences worldwide.

title: I liked it- really
review:
I went into the movie with the knowledge that Cannes audiences laughed at it instead of with it, and was pretty worried. However, I was really wasn't disappointed with it, even at its lowest points.

Those lowest points come near the end when the story begins to drag into multiple endings that aren't necessarily boring but more anticlimactic. The involving action and plot twists leading up to the end should signal a more dramatic finish. The real finish works, but it seems like it could have played out in a more entertaining fashion.

However, the high points of the movie outweigh the occasional dull moment. The actors, for example, are quite good. I especially enjoyed Paul Bettany and Ian McKellan, but then again, they're always good. I've loved Paul Bettany since A Beautiful Mind, and it's encouraging to see that he's still finding good roles. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou have surprisingly little to do besides look scared/pensive/incredulous, but they do well with what they have. Regarding Alfred Molina, I wish we could've seen more of him- but not in the way we see more of Bettany. You'll see what I mean if you go to the movie.

And as for the controversy surrounding the movie- well, I was going to say that you should disregard it, but you really shouldn't. No one should change their faith over a movie or a book, and I don't think this sort of popcorn fare will. The debate has been over-hyped for a year or so since Dan Brown's book came under scrutiny by the press. All I can say is that the controversial ideas mentioned in this movie are just that- ideas, not proved or dismissed. If it means that much to you, don't see it. If you think you can get past it, then by all means, see it. It's fun and definitely worth it.

title: a darn good mystery -a darn good movie
review: I never read the book so I had the awesome privilege of not having any clue what to expect from the film. To me the worst thing any movie goer could gripe about is: "...it ain't as good as the book.." you know -the typical complaint against any movie made from a best selling novel. Otherwise,I have no idea why the critics hated this movie!! Probably to be different from the hype (a last ditch effort of balding flabby gutted non film makers trying to be off beat and radical) Admittedly this film has little action so if you need CGI and explosions in your ADD existence then it's true, this film is not for you. However, if you enjoy watching a mystery unravel before you this movie is about excellent. The pacing is faster than an early 1970's film but slower than say LAST BOY SCOUT. But I never found myself fidgeting in my seat or turning my cel phone back on. The characters are well developed and done so quickly enough so as not to keep you wondering why they are the way they are. Also the acting is very convincing. The film is written well enough to add a chuckle here and there without making a farce of the atmosphere. Also the writer doesn't make the main character a super genius amongst a band of idiots. Personally, I feel, being the film is set mainly in France had Ron Howard added subtitles, cut scenes without thought and paced it even slower he'd have ensured the critics of today to taught it as inspired and a masterpiece. Seriously, the only problem I had with the movie at all was that I guessed the mystery half way through the film. Yet despite that I thought it was great and I would gladly sit through it again. Please don't let this fall by the way of THE ALAMO or TROY it is definitely worth the watch.

title: For the readers and non-readers of the Book
review:
If you have read the book then the movie might not be your favorite. The movie lacks the focus of code breaking and turns into an Indiana Jones treasure hunt of the 21st century with very little detailed history of femininity. Some scenes are changed, skipped, and some dialogs are rewritten which makes it sound cheesy, rather sophisticated.

For the one's who haven't read the book, well they might like it. Overall, it is a good movie refreshing our minds about history, religion, and femininity. So, for the readers go and find out if the movie lived up to your expectation and the non-readers go and find out what everyone is so excited about?

title: Engaging, Excellent, and True to the book
review: After reading reviews, I went to see the movie with a salt shaker... and came out wondering how the reviewers could be so blind. Ron Howard did a careful weaving of reality, recall, imagination and history which made it engaging and very satisfying. Having read the book, as well as Angels and Demons prior to seeing the movie, I was prepared to be disappointed in the adaptation to film. Instead, I was pleased at how well the important details of the epic were presented, and how well the boring details were reflected quickly. Impressive cinematography, as well as spot on casting for the rolls of Sophie and Silas. The only disappointment was the casting of the roll of Langdon (Tom Hanks), when the roll called for an older, more handsome man.

title: Better the second time.
review:
Saw this movie again yesterday and decided to simply sit and enjoy the movie without the critiquing and comparing it to the book. It was more powerful to me after the second screening and my emotions were more moved this time as well. All I can say is that Dan Brown is the literary version of the Wachowski brothers. His story hits me like the Matrix did.

Below is my review from the first time I saw the movie.

This movie is a niche movie. It is a GREAT movie for those who 1) have read the book and 2) are big fans of the codex nature of the book or 3) a big fan of the opinions found in the book. . If you have not read the book the movie will be a confusing 2 ½ hours of your life.seriously. You'll have to read the book just to make sense of the movie. The movie does not do well independent of reading the book. If you have read the book and what you enjoyed most was the fast pace action of the book the movie will bore you. BUT if you enjoyed the many religious explanations or following the clues to solving the code then this movie is for you. It's an intellectual movie. It's a movie that ponders and explores alternative Christianity. This is a movie that lays out in front of you all these alternative ideas of Jesus with references you may or may not agree with. It will make you think. Yet, it does have some action in the movie.

Acting: Mostly very good. Silas was too monstrous for me. He walked with a limp like some hideous monster. The way he acted reminded me of Frankenstein. I always seemed to expect him to say teacher "teachhhhhhhherrrrrrrr". My take on Silas from the book was a smart street wise man who found the church in Opus Dei. The movie version of Silas didn't fit. Tom Hanks was good and he got better as the movie moved along.

If you understand French that will help you 100% to enjoy this movie better. This movie had subtitles because when the scenes were in France the French characters spoke French. And that was the case for the first hour of the movie. It's authentic but if you can't understand French those subtitles were a bit cumbersome. This movie should be a hit in France.

The movie deviated from the book in a few areas and that made the movie a little more enjoyable because it made the movie less predictable. If you read the book then what happens at Roslin chapel in the movie is not in the book. What happened at Newton's tomb is not how it happened in the book either. Also how Langdon determines who is A. Pope in the book is NOT how it is done in the movie. So this movie took some liberties.

Scenes: Wonderful. The scenes are the reason I'll see this movie twice. It takes you inside all those fascinating places found in the book. You see Newton's tomb which is amazing. You visit the Templar church, Roslin chapel, and the Louvre. The scene of the sex rite was tastefully done but if you didn't read the book the movie does not explain what it was. Overall it's a great movie for the intellectual Da Vinci Code fan.

title: Entertaining to non-reader
review:
From early reviews I was anticipating a movie that would be boring, but found myself thoroughly entertained. The faster pace of the movie kept it from being boring and I enjoyed the story line and fairly easy to follow story, if some of it was predictable to me.

But then - I haven't read the book. My 13 year old daughter (an advanced English student and avid reader) had and updated me on all the differences in the movie, but felt the movie was worth seeing even though she has read it. Don't expect an epic film, or even worry if the leads are supposed to be romantically linked in their on-screen chemistry and you should be entertained - worth the price of an evening out.

title: Good Movie, not as good as it could be.
review:
I like Tom Hanks, as well as Ron Howard, so I am mildly disappointed in the movie. It was a bit too frenetic in the beginning and a bit too slow in the middle. It ended nicely though.

Well filmed and fairly well acted, I was a bit put off by the aforementioned slow pace in the middle of the movie. It was slow to get the people who have not read the book caught up, but for a thriller, it had too much dialogue.

Some scenes were beautiful, but the night scenes at the beginning were too dark. Don't the French know about electricity yet? I have no spoilers in this review, but I do recommend it to those who read the book. If you have not read the book, get someone to tell you the basic storyline. It will allow you to keep up.
