I probably will not see it again until its release on DVD.

title: Catholic Church has made a big deal about it
review:
This movie is excellent, really good job. Photography, very good. Good action.

The performance of Tom Hanks, Jean Reno and Ian McKellen excellent, very convincing.

I do not understand why the Church has made such a big deal about this movie. Thousands of histories has been made about this topic and the church did not say anything about it.

There must be a reason why they pay so much attention to something that can be considered as social fiction and has not any proves to demonstrate that the Church is wrong.

Perhaps they have stocks in Hollywood and by forbidding something they make people wanting to go to see what is all the fuzz about.

Or, the main reason is that people will lose their faith or believe less in Jesus or God. If that happens so is because the church has done a terrible job along history in teaching faith and morale, when they have encouraged the killing thousands of people just because they think different. Why are they so afraid of, anyway?

title: So, God was NOT my copilot?
review:
Despite reports of bad reviews, I didn't find this one nearly as hard to take as I expected. That's not to say it is any Hitchcockian masterpiece, either, although it has a Hitchcock feel to it in places.

It is a slick, well directed, well produced Hollywood thriller/potboiler that, after an excruciatingly long opening sequence in the Louvre, is off and running, running so fast at times that it is hard to keep up with.

Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou star as two people on a quest to find the Holy Grail (so to speak) and Ian McKellen, Alfred Molina and Jean Reno, among others, play the bad guys dedicated to keeping them from their goal.

While the acting is uniformly solid, and the direction crisp, the film takes a good deal of suspension of disbelief for it to work, not in accepting the premise, but in making peace with the rich collection of murderous bad guys menacing the hero and heroine. Of particular note is Paul Bettany as an albino monk turned hit man who, when he is not trying to murder people, engages in naked self flagellation, apparently to atone for sins past, present, and presumably future. He was probably not intended to exactly provide comic relief for this story, but he is always just one step away from pure parody. In fact, in some ways he would have fit in better in a Mel Brooks movie and you can almost count on his being roasted on Saturday Night Live.

I have never been much of a Tom Hanks fan and he did little in this film to up my opinion of his work. Although saddled with an under written part, he failed to do much with what he was given and I never had any real reason to become emotionally involved with him. Over the years, many actors, from Jimmy Stewart to Gregory Peck to Joseph Cotton have played Americans caught up in intrigue in a foreign land and made us feel much more for them. Hanks went nowhere in my view. Audrey Tautou, not my favorite French actress by a long way, was also a little wooden.

Finally, there is the controversial content of this film, which does deserve being addressed. You would have to have just emerged from a time capsule if you didn't already know the "secret" before you watched this movie. So this was a film about process --how the mystery unfolds and how the protagonists go about solving it. And the only part of that mystery we didn't know in advance was the role Audrey Tautou played in it and I guessed her hidden significance almost immediately.

Which leads us to the theology. There was little in this particular theory of Christianity that I had not heard before, even though I have not read the book.

Yet I can understand how Christians would be offended by this one, since the basic premise implies Jesus was NOT god after all. But why his "marrying" or even just having dated Mary Magdalene would prove he was not god is never really explained. If you believe in the concept of god, then god could probably marry anyone he wanted. He could probably set the rules, too. ( "No, I am not helping with the dishes or taking out the garbage and if I want to go out one night a week with my buddies...." Well, you get it.) Also of concern to me is the number of murders churchmen are seemingly willing to commit here and who is behind them. The film seems to say they are the work of a "rogue" group of clerics within the church. Oh, yeah, we've heard about those Black Ops groups before. And I assume their role is to give the Vatican plausible deniability

Lastly, and this is the part that bothers me the most,is the sort of feel good ending dreamed up here, an ending that takes great pains not to come down on either side of the theological argument. Was Christ god or not? Tom Hanks' character tells us it doesn't matter, because he was a great profit no matter what. Hello? Try telling a couple of billion Christians it doesn't matter. Hell, tell Pat Robertson, Jerry Farwell, Doctor James Dobson and the rest of the Looney tunes who populate the airwaves that Christ was actually NOT god after all. Oops, our bad, they will say. All you guys we condemned to hell. You can come back up now.

Overall this one makes for some good moments, but it is not a movie you want to examine too closely, when unfortunately, its premise requires, no virtually commands close scrutiny.

A marginal thumbs up, but more for the direction than any other element.

title: I suppose I set my expectations too high.
review:
I only finished reading The Da Vinci Code in April, and was really pumped for the movie. The trailers were thrilling, and Tom Hanks and Ian McKellen sounded perfect as Langdon and Teabing. Unfortunately, I never liked the choice of actress for Sophie Neveu, because she wasn't even remotely how I pictured her. I suppose I was sort of determined not to like Audrey Tautou during the movie, but she did a good job despite my judgment that she wouldn't.

I guess I just thought the movie would be better. A lot of important details in the book were changed, like the fact that Jacques Saunière was not Sophie's grandfather at all, but only assigned to protect her. A large amount of excellent bits from the novel were cut out, including the intense code breaking of the first cryptex on the plane, which hinted at Sophie's bloodline.

Of course, there is only so much you can take from the novel to put into the movie. Almost 500 pages of reading are hard to fit into a two and a half hour film. Will I buy it when it comes out on DVD? Most likely. It was enjoyable, and I always tend to be analytical of books turned to movies when I see them first (which is why I hated the third Harry Potter movie for some time).

title: Almost entirely faithful to book, but the only change ruined it.
review:
This movie was one of the most faithful to a book I've ever seen. From the beginning it followed the book to a tee and I knew exactly what was coming next. For the first 2 hours I was impressed with seeing what I had pictured as I read the book on the screen before me.

**SPOILER ALERT** However when the movie finally departs from the book is when they portray that Aringarosa and condoned the killing that the teacher was doing, not that he was trying to stop it when he found out about it. No mention is ever mentioned that he wanted the Grail to force the Catholic Church to keep Opus Dei as a member. They portray it as if they were doing it in conjuction with the church to destroy the bloodline. That's okay I can live with that.

The other change though I could not and totally changed my opinion of the film. The ending with the revelation of Sofie's grandmother and brother are totally changed. In the film Jaques Suniere was not really her grandfather, and her brother is dead. When her grandmother is revealed, there's no emotion. She never thought her grandmother was dead in the film, she was never told that she was in the car. She never knew her.

That took away the whole powerful ending of the book, along with the scene I had looked forward to of the brother noticing the box.

Overall I gave it a 6 out of 10, during the first 2 hours I thought it would be the masterpiece I'd hoped for, unfortunately in the end they ruined it for me. Perhaps if I had not read the book I would not have minded this ending.

title: Intellectual and Thoughtful Movie With Minor Technical Flaws
review:
The Da Vinci Code. Lately I've been hearing those four words a lot lately, both good and mostly bad. But i know that sometimes critics may be biased, so i went against the grain and I have to say, maybe critics aren't that right nowadays. This movie was extremely idyllic and thought-provoking and was no where near as disappointing many critics have touted it to be. Although the movie did have some flaws, very minor although:

Pros: -Acting was on-key and consistent, unlike the reviews. Tom Hanks, although not shedding his charm at all, still maintains to be interesting. Audrey Tautou has her moments as well. But the show-stealer is none other than Magneto himself-Ian McKellen, the most vocal about the project since the controversy. He is humorous, dramatic, condescending and fragile all in the same line and delivers with such a exciting intensity, it brings you into the movie. Paul Bettany also steals the show as the Opus Dei monk Silas, bringing a dark and eery feel to the movie.

-The cinematography. Howard knew how to film the movie in all of it's European splendor. From the Louvre in Paris to the Rosalyn Chapel, he focuses on mostly every detail in the room or city.

-The explanation. I personally decided to research Opus Dei and Priory of Sion before the movie and I can honestly say I could've not researched at all and still recognize most of the movie.

-The final shot. This is a spoiler: Seeing Hanks as Langdon stand over the glass pyramids, where the movie started, as the last shot was brilliant and unexpected.

Cons: -The editing. You'd ever think that something irrelevant is coming your way after 3 seconds of watching something else? Think about that while watching the movie.

-The claustrophobia side story. Kind of unnecessary if you ask me. Didn't need to be in there.

That's personally what I think about the movie. And go in with an open mind if watching. As Langdon says "It is what you believe." I believe this movie is something critics are panning to kill the controversy, even so this movie is way better than they said.

Breakdown: Acting-18/20 Directing-17/20 Cinematography-20/20 Screenplay-14/20 Music-20/20 Final Score: 89/100- B+

title: Great Movie
review: Overall I give it one and a half stars out of two, it would have had the full stars if the cast was more unknown. Nothing against Tom Hanks but i think they should have used an actor less known to the audience he was the only person i recognized and it wasn't his type of movie.But everything else was absolutely amazing, it pretty much kept up to the book right to the point it changed in a couple spots and it added some humor in spots but overall it was amazing. I dunno what version of this movie the critics at the Cannes Film Festival saw but it must have been totally different because their critiques were off. But if i do say so myself this is a movie you should definitely go see it would help if you read the book before you see the movie but its not 100% necessary!!

title: A refreshing good movie
review:
I saw the movie this afternoon and was pleasantly surprised on how good it was. I had listened to poor reviews over the last few days and must say that all the reports were way off.

Having not read the book, I had not expectations of the film - so perhaps that played a part on my opinion.

The film has numerous locations, some of which the lighting is very poor - supposedly to preserve the works of art in the background. The story line was very good and flowed very well. The 2 1/2 hours went by rather quickly and and only a few minutes of dull moments.

Sections of the plot were predictable, but what movie isn't anymore. Sit back enjoy the movie for the story it presents - well worth your time and your money.

title: No Umph
review: It is unfair to expect the movie to come close to the book. In fact if you haven't read the book, you will enjoy the movie more. The flashbacks are done well and the casting is good, however I felt Tom Hanks should have been a bit more excitable rather than so straight. There is simply no sense of urgency in the movie which the book had. The music did little to help the movie along. Sir Ian McKellen steals the show and gives the whole movie a more intellectual flavour. I was hoping for Sophie Marceau to play Sophie, there would have been a bit more life there. I avoided reading the Harry Potter books and so enjoyed the movies without asking the question "Why did they leave this or that out?"

title: A Film That Makes You Wonder
review:
Dan Brown has always written engrossing books and The Da Vinci Code is a prime example.

The film is no exception. Tom Hanks gives as always a good performance as Robert Langdon, with the supporting cast of Audrey Tautuo, Sir Ian McKellan and Jean Reno(brilliantly cast as CAptain Fache).

The story, and it is a story (Fiction) with some factual references, is about the Holy Grail and it's keepers (Priory of Sion). That if revealed would shatter the Christian faith. NOTE: I am catholic and take this as a work of fiction, nothing else.

The film centres around the French(some subtitles) and English with Robert Langdon the prime suspect in 4 murders.

Having read the book prior to the preceding Court Case last year (2005). I was hoping to see how DVC converted onto screen.

There is a lot of back story to Langdon(See Angels And Demons) that is explained in the film and a lot of back story that is left out of the film. It is not integral to the film but they moved around the important parts to fit the movie.

This movie is long, over 2 hours and does sometimes move rather slow. It does make up for parts with some action and answers to clues come a bit too easily.

You think near the end that that is all for the film. The film does have a twist in the tail, even though this review contains some spoilers, I will not reveal the end (People who have read the book will know what I am talking about, but will surprise even them).

title: not great, but worth the admission
review: I read the book a few months ago and noticed that the three Dan Brown novels I've read follow a pretty similar formula; Similar story + Similar Characters + meticulous detail = a decently interesting yet trite kind of novel. Brown's attention to detail is probably what made this novel-to-film adaptation receive less "stars" than expected. There were few significant differences between the novel and movie that stood out. Yet when you consider amount of info written in the novel about the artwork, the buildings, the Roman Catholic Church, the opus dei, the priory of sion, and Da Vinci, one should expect that some of the information has to be cut. Otherwise you'd end up watching one of those "Da Vinci Code themed" documentaries that have been trying to cash in on the hype. I liked that the actors were true to their characters in the novel. Tom Hanks and Audrey Tautou were fine choices to personify the main characters, and Jean Reno is perfect for Fache as was the choice of Ian McKellen as Teabing. The acting was convincing, and the movie was filmed nicely. I didn't like how Ron Howard chose to shoot some of the history in the book (both the factual, and character back stories). Sometimes it felt like you had taken a mind altering substance that put you back in the time when these things happened. Characters would remain but the background would fade into the same place in a different time, and it felt more like a hallucination than a good transition. Additionally Tom Hanks would occasionally think a puzzle through and some CGI effect would float in front of him as if he were on a peyote trip Though the differences between novel and film are tolerable, they are not necessarily justified. While, I guess, the changes worked somewhat well with the movie, had the screenplay remained closer to the novel it probably would have worked better. In sum, yes the book was better than the movie, what was cut will bother Brown fans, what's different will bother people who love and read the book. Yet for those who haven't read it, the movie will probably convince you to pick up a copy of the novel and figure out what everyone is so bugged about. It was a pretty good attempt and worth watching.

title: Excellent...If you didn't read the book...
review: Even though I read the book, I rather enjoyed most of it. Maybe that's because I'm a history major in college and this stuff seems cool to me. In the movie Tom Hanks sort of matched my perception of Dr. Robert Langdon in the book. However, a few of my friends disagreed. Ian McKellen plays a magnificent role and steals every scene he is in. Jean Reno also matched the exact description and played the role of Captain Fache to a "T". The movie was slow at some parts and seemed like an adult version of hunting on a wild goose chase. I would recommend seeing this movie if you read or didn't read the book. I gave the movie a rating 8/10 because it entertained me while I was there, but I would not buy the movie when it comes out on DVD.

title: great movie.....Amazing
review: this is great i think its everything you would expect nothing more and nothing less. i have also read the book and found that to be great interest also. the effects of the movie really are amazing it was great to see a movie like this.......there hasn't been a movie this good for many years and Ron Howard does a terrific job with this film. the cast in this movie was great i also think it was a strong point in this film. The scenery, most of it the real-life venues of the book, was spectacular and enchanting. After reading the Da Vinci Code and now seeing the movie, I am more determined than ever to visit the Louvre and to learn how to speak French! The paintings in the films backdrop, though we only get quick glimpses of them, add a rich and ancient dimension to the aesthetic experience.

title: A Secret Code with a Punch.
review: "The Da Vinci Code" is an excellent film with a really suspenseful punch. Tom Hands plays the lead role of Robert Langdon, a professorial role for him in this adaptation of Dan Brown's extremely successful novel. Audrey Tautou plays Sophie Neveu the fictional descendant of the Messiah. She has a charming screen presence and gives a very convincing performance. I found the part of Sir Leigh Teabing to be a most eloquent portrayal by Ian McKellen. He gives an electrifying performance that truly ignites the story. The photography is perfect under the direction of Ron Howard. His incorporation of the scenes and architectural sites in France and England are brilliant and cleverly woven into the theme. This cinema has the intrigue and energy of a James Bond thriller coupled with educational spots that titillate the imagination. Dan Brown's book has been given good justice by the director. It is more than worthwhile and meets all the expectations of the several months of hype that we have heard.

title: Okay But If U Read The Book Read This
review: OK i read the book and loved it i spent all night and day reading it and watched those breaking he DA Vinci code DVD's it was good.when i heard they where making a movie i was excited because i wanted to see how Hollywood would make it.as i was watching the movie it followed the book at first. but as i got more in the movie i saw it was leaving out some of the good parts such as the monitor room Sir Leigh Teabing had in the barn and th whole fact that Captain Fache was a member of Opus Dei and was helping Bishop Aringarosa kinda made frown.Also the acting by Sir Leigh Teabing towards the end was horrible,But over all it was still a good movie because the book was great but if u read the book u should still see it just done have your expectations to high

title: Well done
review:
If you are one of those people who never watch an adapted film because you think it will never be better than the novel it is based on, think twice. OK, again, the novel is better, but at least this time the result is good, and it is worth watching. First, it is good to see Tom Hanks in action, second, the director Ron Howard, did a good job.

The first minutes are incredibly fast, and it may confuse people who haven't read the book. The ones who know the novel, people like me for example, may have to think of the the original text sometimes, but it does not damage the movie as a whole.

As someone who has read the novel and seen the film, as well as a Christ believer and highly interested in history, I say we have to be always ready to learn and know fact that may (or may not) take us to the truth, no matter if sometimes we have to redo our own faith.

title: DaVinci Code a Magificat
review:
I found DaVinci Code to be a beautiful film, thoroughly thought provoking, with much factual material embedded in the fiction, sort of like a Richard Armour version of U.S. history. At the Clark Theater it would be paired with Dogma, another film about Jesus' family in current times and also about the Roman Catholic Church. One should also read Dostoyevsky's chapter "The Inquisitor" in his Brothers Karamazov. Then of course there are all the slanders against priests and their problems with sexual molestations. Incredible, of course.

The DaVinci Code, in a word, is provocative, wonderfully, deliciously so, much as The Last Temptation of Christ was a few years back, or as The Passion more recently provoked, except on its head. Roger Ebert says enough about the films good points as a "film" per se: good acting, good direction, great music, delightful setting, suspenseful enough plotting. It did follow the novel closely, thank you.

One theme worth noting is that of the feminist issue. There was an Emperor Constantine and a Council of Nicaea, and the place of women have had their "inferior" place in church history since and before it.

The film has exposition, yes, and complication, complication, complication, and its denouement is not altogether satisfactory, yes, but if the film has predictable elements, it is very satisfying altogether very much and deserves better than its negative clamorers.

title: Well presented!!!
review:
Bearing in mind that the film had to live up to extremely high expectations, the final result was surprisingly good, understandably the pressures from the worlds media make this a hard film to get right, but in this case all expectations have been exceeded!

The film is long, yet bearable each key fact is explored to the correct degree consequently the film flows extremely well! Having read the book, the imagery I had in my head was very closely depicted within the film.

All in all, a very enjoyable film, well made with a good representation of the book.

title: Not boring if you understand or have read the book
review:
It is frustrating for me to read reviews that comment on how boring the movie was. I can imagine for those that have not read the book it would be quite boring, but for those of us that have, the outcome should have been expected. The screenplay is adapted from Dan Browns novel as we all know, which follows an historical theory to the bloodline of Christ. No one that is familiar with the novel should have expected this film to be an intense action packed thriller. The plot of the film was exactly that of the novel, we can't blame the writers of the film for a poor plot...that is something you'd have to take up with Dan Brown. The movie is a history lesson (theoretically) not an action movie, its purpose is not to watch the police chase the suspects but to follow the pieces of the puzzle and uncover the mystery as the characters do. This movie and novel force people to think outside of their original paradigm regarding the Christian faith; that is, to possibly consider another aspect to truth about Christ.

Overall i think this movie was worth the $10, but only if you are a fan of the book. Of course i do enjoy the book adaptation better, it seems to leave a little more to the imagination, whereas the movie sets our thoughts in stone. But as you watch, don't blame the actors, directors, or writers for a boring movie. It was more closely drawn from the book than any movie I've ever seen (granted a few scenes due to time constraints). Ultimately they should have made Dan Browns "Angels and Deamons" into a movie before "Da Vinci Code". I believe it was the better of the two novels and it is also the first time the reader is introduced to Robert Langdon; which would have gave the viewers a better understanding of his character. Tom Hanks played him well, but this was not his best role. Again don't expect a thrilling police chase full of explosions, chase scenes, and fighting. This is no love story nor an action adventure, and the movie producers have nothing to do with the intensity of the plot, they made it exactly as it was meant to be portrayed.

title: A Brilliant Film!
review: As a result of reading some reviews from the critics, I almost did not see the movie because the reviews were so bad. However, after the movie was over my sister, mother, and I all turned to each other and said, "That was great!" I do not understand the harsh criticism of the film, because THE Film IS NOT THE BOOK. Perhaps from all of the buzz surrounding the movie, people have built up such a high expectation of the film. I am at a loss as to why everyone is coming away so disappointed. All the scenes are beautifully shot and I thought the performances were spectacular. There were many moments of tension. The intensity was so great that I jumped in my seat a couple of times. Like the book, the film generates discussion. This is an intelligent film, and it is very refreshing to see a movie that makes you think.

title: A very nicely done movie!
review:
The movie was great, very nicely done - and having read the book - i can appreciate the work the director has done here. many people (so called critics) try to point out holes in the script or other things - but lets face the fact - the task to create a movie out of that huge book was no easy task. Overall experience it and relive the feel - its greatly done.

I think both actors are great, i don't know why people are gossiping about Hank's hair and the chemistry with the lead lady, all were fine.

what would you rather want a US actress giving a fake french accent? Ian Mckellen does a great job - Audrey too had the class to represent royalty. i cant say how a person who hasn't read the book or doesn't know about these strong theories would react to the movie. might be too much for them to learn. but overall its great entertainment! and Hollywood should do more original stuff than make stupid movies like MI 3. they actually called the organization IMF - impossible mission force, how dumb is that? The Davinci code had a lot of ground to cover - in compressing the book. some small parts had obviously to be left out. and as always a book is more descriptive than a movie.

but the point is - its great entertainment - a very well done job. at least people will pay more attention to art, davinci and all the good stuff. rather than focusing on the usual oil-war-terror nonentertaining crap.

title: Recommend you read the book first....
review:
.... as it's not as good as the book but I wouldn't say that it was a major disappointment. The build-up was good, but it seemed to linger too long in France. It was a little slow to start, but once it got started, it moved along pretty well. It was well cast, though I did find it difficult when I first heard about Tom Hanks in the role, preferring someone a little more like Harrison Ford in Indiana Jones, though when he is being a professor rather than an archaeologist. But he surprised me and was actually rather good. Same with Audrey Tautou, and most of the central characters were well cast.

There were some odd moments though, like when the Bishop visits the Vatican Council and plays pool with what I can only presume is the Pope and then has a supremely modern mobile phone. Or Silas's phone and car, when he lives in a cell in order to bring himself closer to God. Little things which don't make sense. If the geography of London is not known, then it is easy to believe that Remi manages to drive all the way to Tower Bridge and then back across the river to Docklands (some 6 miles from Temple) in the same time that Langdon and Neveu take to get to Westminster on a bus only half a mile from where they started off. Plus, there's several libraries closer to Temple than Chelsea, it being on the other side of Central London, including the library originally in the book, and only a five minute walk away.

The scenes in the Louvre and Paris were fabulous though, and made me really want to revisit Paris. Several little things were left out of the book though, which was slightly disappointing, though, all in all, it made for a thoroughly entertaining film although I recommend that you read the book first!!!

title: what is everyone talking about??
review: this movie is awesome!!! if you loved the book, take some friends to see this. i am never listening to critics again. overall, it was one of the best adaptations of a book i've seen. some stuff was left out, but it flowed well. the acting was surprisingly good, especially considering all the horrible press, and the script was fine. exiting the theater, all i could hear were people trying to figure out where all the negative stuff about the movie came from. the only thing i can think to complain about is that some of the settings weren't identical to the image i had in my mind, but some of them actually helped me enjoy the book more, looking back on it. overall, it's a great movie and I'm shocked and a bit disturbed by all the bad things being said about it. and obviously, if you find the book offensive, going to see this is probably a bad idea unless you're open minded.

title: Those Critics and their silly reviews
review:
Wow, after reading only 1 review that was almost positive, from someone who had an early screening, well midnight one, i thought, What am i putting myself up for? The answer was 2 and a half hours of film, yes kinda long considering there was no f-words of explosions, they go down well in a coherent plot in my opinion, look at Pulp Fiction and Die Hard 2! But for a slow film this was well made, a breathtaking, not thriller in particular, drama about a silly little treasure hunt, like a mature National Treasure, which i love.

The fact that all the 'twists' are obvious without reading anything says a lot, but still, the score makes the film really work, a great use of choir esquire music really adds to the revelation scenes, and makes the car chase a little different.

Even if u don't care about the film, u see Paul Bettany whip himself, smug git, and we can all marvel and the fluffiness of Tom Hank's do.

Ron Howard, you have done it again!

title: Extremely Great!
review: I've just seen The Da Vinci Code and I have to tell you that it raised high above my expectations. I never thought that the film was going to be near as great as the movie, but it really was. Anyhow, the music is a bit disturbing and feels a bit too much Hollywood sometimes, but otherwise it's one of the greatest movies ever. Only ones who criticize is people who haven't read/understood the book or people in Opus Dei or other religious movements. Tom Hanks as professor Langdon is also great. Some of my friends thought he was boring and to be honest, he is at a few moments, but he is in the book as well and since it's the book that came before the movie, the movie has to follow the book. And it sure has. I believe that it's sad though that they met such a resistance from the church. I mean, they weren't allowed into Westminster Abbey, they didn't even got an explanation. In Moldavia, the press had wrote a report on the film before it had even been showned to the world, telling everyone about how it would split the country and so on and so on. Judging by the fear of the churches all around the globe and their influence on the criticism of this movie it's obvious that they're in possession of too much power, which is really sad since it's a great film!

title: the greatest secret of our time
review: The book was great. It's even one of my favourites. My hopes where quite high when I went to see it. I mean I liked the movie very much, but there was still something missing. I expected a little more of it. Ron Howard is a great director. So I knew that it can't be a total disaster movie. The movie started off really quickly and evolved pretty fast. I doubted if Tom Hanks could handle the role of Robert Langdon. I thought they were so much different, but when I saw the movie I knew I was wrong. Hanks did a great job and looked more handsome than he's ever looked. One of his best roles lies within Langdon. Audrey Tautou was brilliant. I've never seen her in a bad movie. I think that her person helped to put out the best of Sophie Neveu. And I think that Leigh Teabing's character (played by magnificent Ian McKellen) was really the first one who brought in some relaxiation. In the meaning of jokes. First the movie seemed to be a bit of tense, no real laughs, but Teabing and he's three questions seemed to be the ones that people really laughed about. Good Brithish humour never dies apparently. And I also must mention that Paul Bettany really was Silas. Although I would've made him maybe ever more pale. I don't even need to mention how good Jean Reno was. However I would've liked to see more of the Remy character. He was not given so much role here. Somewhere in the middle of the movie I started to mix the book and the movie. And things got a bit different, but I didn't let myself disturbed from it. I understand that it's a difficult job to transform such a complexed and informative book into a movie and certainly you can't put everything in it and you usually have to change something. The one thing that bothered me a bit was the ending part. If the beginning was fast, then the end was a bit too slow and it got a bit boring even. And again,everything wasn't quite like in the book. And they didn't do IT:( And what I really have to say is that they visually did a wonderful job with the secret of "The Last Supper". Technology is a good thing! I certainly hope that there will be more close to the book scenes in the DVD near future. It's not necessary to read a book before watching the movie, but if you have read it, the more exciting things you know. And don't let yourselves disturbed for goodness sake - it's just a fiction! A brilliant fiction!

title: Its fiction!! Get over yourselves!
review:
I would first like to say how amazed I was to see how many people are taking this film so seriously. Its a story designed to entertain people! Dan Brown wrote The Da Vinci Code based on one of Catholicisms conspiracy theories, and that's all it is, not what is seen as truth.

Now that's out of the way I loved this film. Of course, I have to say what has become a clichÃ© when a film is adapted from a book... the book is better, so if you liked this film (or didn't like it) and haven't read the book yet, I suggest you do.

The film is very entertaining with a brilliant cast. The only person I have to say I was disappointed with is Sir Ian McKellen, who was definitely "chewing the furniture" in this one as the eccentric Sir Leigh Teabing. He took it a tad too far! The star of the film is most definitely Paul Bettany who is simply terrifying as the albino monk, Silas. Its nice to see him in a film that isn't a chick-flick or a romantic comedy! As always, Jean Reno is very good, but unfortunately we didn't see enough of him.

If you like a good thriller, and don't like films that instantly spell everything out for you, go and see this film. Its definitely worth the price of a ticket and you're bound to find some part of it entertaining. But if you don't like these kind of films, or your moral values are likely to be offended by the content matter (and we all know what that is. Its had enough attention from the press world wide for goodness sake!) then don't go and see it. Its as simple as that!!

title: Good "thinkingman's" movie.
review:
A really good intelligent mystery movie. Almost as good as the book, a very good adaptation.

I think once all the hype and hysteria have calmed down, people will see it for what it is, a well-crafted film derived from a well written book.

I put in the same league as JFK, or the Omen (not fiction, not fact but ... faction.) Based on historical fact, but also on one author's imagination, as in "what if?"

The movie did make one think ( as did the book) but it didn't make me abandon my beliefs or see Opus Dei as a dark cult, the Catholic church as a evil or change my belief s concerning the divinity of Christ.

The only people who's beliefs could possibly be shaken by this movie are the gullible .. the few misguided who think movies are real.

But as a good popcorn movie its tops!

title: Too long, too plot heavy, but interesting none the less
review: Having read the book I wondered what plot lines would be abandoned. I was surprised to find the book's plots were more or less intact. A good point and a bad point. Good in that a complex interesting book found its way to the screen more or less intact, bad in that the film turned out overlong and rather too talk laden (plot lines were talked of rather than shown). The actors stuck to the task well enough but were so busy explaining things that they hardly emerged as people. On the whole baddies did better than goodies. I have rated the film 7 rather than the 6 or 5 it may have deserved, probably as a reaction to the ungenerous reviews of the professional critics which nearly prevented me from seeing an interesting effort of filming a complex book with some good action sequences, nice plot twists, some splendid photography and a bit too much gore for my taste.

title: As Jesus himself said, "Who do you say I am?"
review: Quite simply Dan Brown is a Gnostic. He has his reasons to attack the Catholic Church for it's 1500+years of pushing the Gnostic faith towards irrelevancy. However Dan is guilty of horrid prose, tepid dialogue and playing free and easy with facts. And He's retread a formula (a mysterious man assassinates an elderly leading authority in a field whose female progeny teams up with Robert Langdon to set about to discover a conspiracy through esoteric clues...) that he has made millions off of - which is a literary sin but not heresy. And he ends every single chapter with a mini-cliffhanger fooling people into thinking the book is a real page turner. I was rather exhausted with his books. Onto the movie. Ron Howard did an excellent job with integrating history (the crusades, nicean council, knights templar) into the flow of the movie. And they gave a more fair and balanced approach to the material with Langdon being rather skeptical at the beginning. The big explanatory scene with Ian McKellan is the best in film since Donald Sutherland's Mr. X in JFK-a movie the DaVinci Code should truly be most compared with. Some people will find the movie slow going-even boring. Not enough chase and CGI special effects. But at least it does involve thinking-unless the viewer either buys all of Dan's half-baked theories or prejudges against the hidden story. I for one found this movie to be far more thought provoking about the nature of Jesus than Passion of The Christ. But it's still no Last Temptation Of Christ.

title: interesting story well presented
review:
I saw the movie today and I liked it very much. I had read the novel before. So I concentrated on the question how the director of the movie presented this quite difficult and complex story. The journalists who saw the movie at the festival in Cannes severely critized it, but I think Howard did a very good job. I cannot understand why so many critics said that the protagonists spend too much time with talking which would make the movie boring. If you compare the plot of the movie with the book, you will see that the long explanations (e.g. about the conflict between paganism and Christianity or the hidden codes in da Vincis "Last Supper") have been shortened to the most important facts which you need to understand the story. The cracking of the mysterious "cryptex" is much easier in the movie than in the novel. Some dialogues and explanations appear at different positions. So the movie constantly switched between talk and action and so becomes lively and interesting. The director changes or even adds some scenes. Langdon and Neveu don't go the library in London, but use a mobile phone with internet access. At Rosslyn Chapel Sophie learns the truth about her family from Langdon, not from her grandmother. The scene with the blood dripping into the basin pointing Robert to the "rose line" in Paris isn't in the novel. Howard also added the fact that Bezu Fache is a member of Opus Dei. But all these changes and additions don't reduce the quality of the story. The only minor point of critic I would like to mention is the scene in Westminster Abbey. The producers were not allowed to stage the movie in the original church and so they had to build a copy of Newton's tomb. This work was not done very well. You can easily recognize that the big orb on the tomb is made of styrofoam.

So you should not discuss whether the catholic church or Dan Brown has the correct theory about Jesus, but enjoy the novel and the movie. Both are excellent!

title: DaVinci Code revitalized interest in religious history
review:
I read the DaVinci Code over a year ago. Reading the book did prepare me a bit for the references to secret societies but the complexities of the various histories were hard to retain in memory, so the movie seemed fresh in that regard. I was more intrigued by the history of the use of symbols than the religious controversies.

The cinematography by Salvatore Totino is excellent. I love his use of colors, the blues, grays and shades of light. Totino's camera-work is an actor in this movie, too. The dialogue/ screenplay is crisp, respectful and occasionally amusing. Howard's direction is tasteful and excellent. The story jumped with energy and suspense.

I may never get to Paris or see the Louvre, so I found the movie's various settings intriguing.

Great acting by Hanks, Tautou, McKellen, Reno, Molina and others. I take exception to the previous reviewer, George Floyd's comments on Hanks' performance. I felt Hanks captured the sense of an academic caught unprepared in the middle of a violent power struggle. While I enjoyed Tautou's performance, her character was confusing to me. One minute she seemed in control then she slipped into confusion, and her input as a cryptographer was minimal.

It is a thought-provoking story that if treated respectfully by those who disagree with it's premise could be a vehicle to revitalize interest in religious history. While I was raised Methodist, I became a Unitarian Universalist at 18. So, questioning history and seeking facts appeals to me because, as a UU, I am an active participant in my own spirituality. Do I think the theories presented are true? I am not a historian but I feel there are some small truths buried in the complex theories of conspiracies. One fact and it is a fact, millions of women were killed during various witch hunts over the centuries and it saddens me that we, as humans, can be so cruel, for if Jesus stood for one thing, he stood for compassion and love of his fellow human beings.

title: Excellent Movie
review:
I had read reviews for the Da Vinci Code before I went to see it today, the result of the first viewing at Cannes and the one in my local newspaper. I was surprised that the audience at Cannes laughed at the most intense parts, but went anyway. I read the book about two months ago, well after it became popular. I really enjoyed the novel and was quite excited to see the movie. It is an action packed book, which I believed would translate well onto film.

The movie was excellent. There were some points that were a bit awkward, but that can happen in all movies. They changed the story somewhat, but it did not change the theme of the movie. In response to the controversy surrounding the book, I feel the director, Ron Howard, and the writing was well done enough not to throw the ideas of Jesus having children right in your face. It focused more on how Jesus was still great, and does it really matter that he was a father? I am not really religious, but I saw the book and movie as FICTION. Why cant people just go out and enjoy the adventure of it?

title: The Da Vinci backlash
review:
Well for the past 6 months we've trudged through the court case, the controversy the endless documentaries spouting theories surrounding what is deemed as the most controversial thing...ever. And then came the film...

First off, I did read the Da Vinci before the film came out and enjoyed every minute. It was a guiltless, fun, enjoyable and thrilling read and when the film was advertised I was quite excited. But as with many of these hyped-up blockbusters it's bound to suffer backlash and in this case I wasn't overtly surprised that virtually every critic under the Sun took every opportunity to nit-pick on the tiny details and then say it's one of the worst films ever.

Before I continue, I would just like to take the opportunity to say that I enjoyed the film. Although many accuse Hanks' performance as "woody" at best, he was playing to the best of his ability to the lines Goldsman provided. It wasn't the most polished script but I thought the film was wonderfully edited, acted to the extent it could and shot in brilliant locales. I especially thought the transition between modern London to Newton's London particularly inspired.

This is slightly ironic considering the film itself was about, I reckon, 80% faithful to the book and the book was hailed as an intelligent, fast paced thriller -a real page turner! These critics really can't make their minds up can they. But then again we mustn't forget there is a distinct difference between book and film and although the book was good the film did lack the pace that was expected.

Still though, it was a good film although not the most technically precise however with all this hype we must sit through the Da Vinci backlash and hope that soon, in the not too distant future, we all having something else to talk about because all this controversy is getting slightly tiresome.

title: Outstanding, riveting from beginning to end.
review: What an excellent film, having read the book I was really looking forward to seeing the film and the more the so called experts slammed it the more I was looking forward to seeing it. For we all know that when the majority of film critics pan a film then "normal" people like you and I will enjoy it. I was not wrong, it kept it's grip on me from the beginning to the end and I do mean the very end. OK the film style was a bit dark at the beginning and I do mean " not enough light" not dark as in plot but that is the only real fault I can see and that is nit-picking. The story was great the explanation was very good and very thought provoking. When the film finished there was total silence in the cinema, it was the silence of people thinking of the film and it's contents and satisfaction at having seen an outstanding film. In my opinion the critics have slammed the film, not because it is a bad film but because they think they should and were to scared of being seen to agree with the film's contents. They should mark it on it's premise and it being a work of fiction and not it's so called attack on Christianity. My advice is go seen this film, enjoy it for what it is and make your own mind up.

title: Fine Adaptation of Dan Brown's Intellectual Thriller
review:
There must be a vast clerical conspiracy to use film critics to convince the movie-going public that "The Da Vinci Code" is a dull, inept, and plodding film, because Ron Howard's adaptation of the best-selling Dan Brown novel is anything but. Although the movie is far from a masterpiece, it does engage the thinking viewer and holds attention for its two-and-a-half hour running time. Like the film version of "Gone with the Wind," Akiva Goldsman's script feels like the entire book has been covered, even though logic tells you that much has been omitted from the long, detailed work. Unfortunately, the script apparently has been softened by political correctness throughout, and several instances of "but that's only a theory" pass between characters that must have forgotten that few Biblical events have ever been proved with incontrovertible historic evidence. However, unlike Oliver Stone's "JFK," "The Da Vinci Code" does not blur the line between history and fiction and, thereby, confuse less-informed viewers. Anyone with the intellectual curiosity to pursue the subject will be more confused by a reading of "Holy Blood, Holy Grail," the book that inspired the novel, than by a viewing of this relatively safe film.

For avid readers of the Brown novel, Paul Bettany perfectly embodies Silas, the albino monk. Bettany captures what could have been a cardboard villain and imbues him with the glow of a true zealot whose trust has been used for evil. Ian McKellen shares top acting honors with Bettany, and, with devilish charm, he effectively carries the heavy burden of expounding the theories and history that surround the Holy Grail. Grainy footage is often used to add visuals to McKellen's historic details about the Knights Templar and to some of the characters' relevant memories. Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon is effective, if not dynamic. His oft-criticized long hair works in the context of the film, and the English of his partner in the search for the Grail, Audrey Tautou, is easily understood. Her accent is nowhere near as thick as critics have declared. Readers of the novel will enjoy the scenes that were shot on location in London's Temple Church, the Louvre Museum, the Rosslyn Chapel, and other sites that are now famous from the book. However, somewhat disappointing is the elimination of any mention of the 19th-century priest in Southern France who gained great power and wealth from something that he found while renovating his old church.

While "The Da Vinci Code" does move slowly, the script has much information to impart, and the film could be termed an intellectual thriller, because the excitement is found more in the pursuit of clues, ideas, and truths than in chases. However, while Hanks and Tautoo have several tense moments, and Bettany provides a few bloody scenes, the movie is not for the action crowd. Unlike "The Last Temptation of Christ," the film is not for religious people who want to explore spiritual issues. Instead, Howard has crafted an intelligent thriller for inquiring minds who are not afraid to ask questions. As a fan of Brown's book, I was not disappointed in this wide-screen illustration of the novel, which may send me back for a second reading. The extent of the conspiracy to degrade the film has even extended to revisionist carping about the quality of the novel, which was generally received as an exciting read. Could countless millions of readers have been wrong? Hardly, and countless millions of viewers of the film will likely enjoy Ron Howard's fine adaptation and later relish some lively conversation.

title: Excellent - no spoilers
review:
I saw the movie this morning's first showing. Like many others I also read the book first and I truly enjoyed this movie immensely. I felt Ron Howard and the cast did a tremendous job with very difficult material. I felt Ian McKellen did an especially good job, but the whole cast was right on target. I was so glad Hanks didn't play it over the top which would have been easily done in most other actors' hands.

I also thought the ending was very satisfying. I don't want to say too much about the movie since it did just come out and don't want to spoil it for others, but just to say that it was excellent and if you have an open mind you'll get delightfully wrapped up in this treasure.

title: Da Vinci Code met all my expectations
review:
Others have said that folks who have not read the book may not "get it". I reply to that by saying that if 40 mil have read the book...then 40 mil will easily, "get it". I consider it a well done flick.

If you base (the book's) success on sales, then the movie should surpass that handily. One of my jobs, before retiring was screening carry-on luggage at an airport. "The Da Vinci Code" seemed to be everywhere. Now, even the main-stream-media appears to be catering to main-stream-Religion and are attempting to "poo-poo" the movie. That places a "red" flag in front of the bull.

I read the book two years ago and frankly, could not wait to see it made into a movie. My patience was rewarded. I don't know if I'll see it again at the theater, but, it's on my list to purchase when it hits DVD.

title: Director Liberties Adds Drama
review:
Slight variations from the book, but when you watch the movie, some of the differences make sense. The guard is not pointing a gun at Sophie Neveu, but she and Langdon escape without confronting him. History depicted in the book is shown in purple as flashbacks, in scenes reminiscent of Braveheart and Gladiator. The hint of graphic imagery in the book, ie. tightening the cilice belt around thigh, is made more intense in the close ups. Langdon is shown to possess a photographic memory, which proves to be beneficial later in the movie. The ghostly animations in London, and cross sectional views of Westminster Abbey set apart filmmaker from the novelist. Time factor is another issue addressed by Mr. Howard. Instead of wasting time (as noted by Langdon in the movie), they borrow cell phone and search the web, finding name of Alexander Pope. The Neveu lineage and family is brought into question at the Rosslyn Chapel, and largest tangent from the novel. Sophie is an only child, and not related to the young male tour guide at the chapel, though a crowd of strangers are brought into the chapel to show Sophie people willing to sacrifice themselves to save her lineage. At the end of the novel, Langdon is depicted as standing below the ancient Rose Line in prayer to Mary Magdaleine. The movie end seems more accurate for someone visiting the Louvre after hours. Langdon is outside, standing over one of the Arago Medallions, pondering the puzzle "She rests at last beneath the starry skies". This final departure from novel is followed by the camera work spiraling down the pyramids, to what is depicted as a secret chamber beneath the Louvre, and the sarcophagus of Mary Magadeine.

The movie never slows, providing a definite conclusion, though finding the tomb of Sir Isaac Newton should have been more complex than clues found through a cell phone.

title: It is a good movie and is underrated by critics.
review: This film is underrated by critics because of how a lot of people do not like Dan Brown because of his theory of the holy grail. What they do not do is concentrate on the acting and how it is Filmed. I enjoyed this movie because of how it was Filmed the exiting plot even though it was a bit offencive to some people. I also thought it had a strong cast including two time academy award winner Tom Hanks who also starred in Philapelphia, Forest Gump and Saving Private Ryan and starring Sir Ian Mckellen who starred in The Lord of the Rings Trilogy and the X-men movies. So over all I thought it was a good movie with a strong cast good filming. I think it was better than the book.

title: A great movie to see
review: This movie stood up and overcame the criticism. Many critics believe that Robert Langdon's (Tom Hanks) part felt flat in this movie. It was supposed to be a more serious role than we are used to with an incredible actor such as Tom Hanks. The acting gave off the impression of a very serious professor. That's is who Langdon was meant to be. Ian Mckllelan is the actor who brings the livelihood to the set. The same was in the book. The ability for a director to condense a 500 page book into 149 minutes is rare. Ron Howard did an exceptional job including all the major details. This movie was meant to be dark, serious, and overall thought provoking. And that is just what it did. Tom Hanks' performance as the professor brought the mood to the theater that this movie will get your mind actually thinking, a feat few movies have accomplished. Paul Bettany as Silas was thoroughly convincing. True to the book, it brings out the sense of deceit and confusion. Where does the fact begin and fiction end? I give this move 10 stars. A phenomenal cast along with great directing, make this movie a privilege to see. And, come on! Who doesn't love the dreads that Hanks is working? Huh?

title: a summer blockbuster suspense movie that makes you think
review:
The Da Vinci Code - Ron Howard's adaptation of the infamous novel in which Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) and Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou, a favorite of mine) unmask a mystery involving Mary Magdalene's place in the Catholic Church, and the finding of the Holy Grail. I've been told by nit-picks that I don't include enough plot details. You want a total synopsis, see the movie.

Anywho, Lot of big names in this one, and not coincidently, a lot of good performances. Hanks does well as Langdon, and Tautou even better as Neveu. Ian McKellen has great fun with his screen time and is quite good at clearing through lengthy exposition (There's quite a bit in this movie, but it's all done quite well). There's suspense and intrigue, and no one is quite who they say they are. It kept me on my toes for the movie's two and a half hour run. Jean Reno and Alfred Molina have slightly less time on screen and bring strong support to the table. Paul Bettany is quite shocking and scary in his role as Silas.

The film is about 98% fiction, but personally I've always wondered why we've promoted Jesus into a deity. "Does mortality take away the splendor of his deeds?" is one of the themes the film goes into, and it really makes you think.

I have not read the book, but I am told that this was pretty much the same experience. If you liked the book, you'll like the movie. If you haven't read the book, give this film a run. It's a summer blockbuster suspense movie that makes you think. I couldn't have asked for more. This film gets an A-

title: Better than the book
review:
The film starts when Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) is lecturing somewhere in Paris at the exact same time as Jacques Souniere (Jean-Pierre Marielle) is followed and murdered by an Opus Dei monk in the Louvre. At his book signing Langdon is approached by a French policeman, who wants him to look at a photo of the crime scene. Langdon is taken to the Louvre to see the crime scene itself. And this is where the charming police cryptologist Sophie Neveu (Audrey Tautou) appears on the scene and warns Langdon that police captain Fache (Jean Reno) suspects him of murdering Jacques Souniere. Langdon and Neveu try to figure out the clues Souniere left for them which leads them on a quest for an important secret kept by a secret society.

Now, I know that almost everyone has read the novel by Mr. Brown, and there's not much I can do to ruin the story for most people. However, I'd like to stop my summary right here and now, otherwise it may ruin what you will see when/if you go and watch the film.

The press crucified this film, saying it wasn't worth watching, and they did the same for the book. I'd beg to differ though, I truly enjoyed this film, even if it was a tad long. At least while watching it one is not distracted by Mr. Brown's mediocre writing style (and I have to admit the man is a master story teller even if his writing leaves a lot to be desired). There is just one thing wrong with it, and that is Tom Hanks. I do appreciate Mr. Hank's performances in other films have been absolutely wonderful, this part just didn't seem right for him right from the start. I personally pictured George Clooney as Robert Langdon from the minute I read the first chapter.

Hanks certainly tries to fill Robert Langdon's shoes and on occasion he manages to do so for a split second, however his lack of facial expressions (he has two or three in this film  mostly involving a lot of frowning) just didn't do it for me. The lovely Miss Tautou however, is everything and more than I had imagined for the part of 'Princesse Sophie'. I only felt sorry for her since she had to run in those high heeled shoes throughout the film  but well that's Parisian women for you dressed to the nines for every single occasion even if it's going to the supermarket.

When I heard that Paul Bettany had been cast for the part of the Opus Dei monk Silas, I wasn't too sure whether he could pull it off. I had no idea who would be the ideal Silas. Paul Bettany was after all an excellent choice. The emphasis in Silas' performance lies in his deep rooted faith, and his wish to protect the bishop he works for and idolises. Though he is the bad guy in the film, you can't help but feel sorry for him as he is in fact a tragic hero.

Another actor I'd like to compliment on his part in the film is Ian McKellen who plays Sir Leigh Teabing, an eccentric historian and old friend of Robert Langdon. When Langdon and Neveu seek his help, he insists on helping them to sort out the clues that will lead to unraveling the mystery he has searched for for so long. McKellen's performance is outstanding.

What you need to take into account before you go see this film is the following: The parts that are set in France are mainly spoken in French, the bishops and Silas mainly speak Italian or Latin (not quite sure) so you will have to read a lot of subtitles.... However it does give the film an authentic feel.

The premise of the film is slightly different than the storyline in the book. This does not make the story worse... in fact some of the changes actually give the film more strength.

Did I mention I enjoyed the film?

title: It is less blasphemous than Opus Dei wants us to believe
review: Strange that so many gave the movie a rating of 1. I voted 10 although the movie is not perfect, of course, but still very well made. I think those who voted 1 may not have seen it at all and don't want other people to see it either (typically members of Opus Dei who have not even read the book because they are not allowed to). They say is blasphemous but what they are really worried about is the way this prelature is pictured by Dan Brown. They were quite lucky that the chapter 100 of the book does not really appear for full in the film. This is maybe due to the need to compress everything into 150 minutes, but it could also be the result of pressure from Opus Dei!! This chapter could become a reality before Opus Dei imagines. I am a practicing catholic and of course we know that the stuff about Jesus and Mary Magdalene is probably not quite true. Anyway, I do not think it is blasphemous at all. In conclusion I enjoyed the 150 minutes of intense suspense, beautiful scenery and good acting. Go and watch it and judge for yourself!

title: Da Vinci Da-licious
review: I have been disappointed with the many reviews I have read over the past 48 hours concerning The Da Vinci Code. Many reviewers and critics have predetermined their mark out of ten before they have even seen the film itself! While the film is I felt too long at 150 minutes (10 minutes + could have been shaved off the running time), it is however a solid piece of work. Critics have complained that there is too much talking and analysing in the film, yet they complain also when films focus too much on action, at the expense of plot. You learn little in the film about the characters themselves (especially Robert Langdon) but it is somewhat irrelevant. The film is about the story NOT the characters, the plot is what drives the film. It is worth noting that I have not read the best selling Dan Brown novel, and therefore entered into watching the film with no preconceptions. If you want to see an intelligent blockbuster that doesn't patronise its audience then this is for you.

title: This was amazing!.......a must see classic
review: Having read the book, being very excited about the prospect of the movie my other half booked the very first time we could see, 19.05.06 00:01! The film really lived up to expectations and more, the film was just as I'd imagined it would be when I was reading the book, an excellent adaptation. DO NOT listen to the self righteous critics who are all saying its rubbish as it is not, and even if you have not read the book, like my other half, you can still understand it, I was preparing myself to answer a few questions after in case he didn't, but he did. The cast was an excellent choice and there were some amazing additions to the movie to help explain some of the history. Go see it..now!

title: time to speak
review:
OK. It's time to say something. Having read the book and seen the film it is startlingly obvious that Dan Brown is not the most talented of writers but he hit on a great story and the movie is a fair reflection of that. So to the critics, 60 million book sales can't be wrong and any Ron Howard and A list cast movie will hardly flop, particularly with all the free publicity kindly provided by world-wide church folk. I enjoyed them both.

I'm a Christian and I follow my faith and I have to say it takes a lot more than an average novelist and a good movie to sway me away from that. Especially when it is a work of fiction and has never been claimed to be any more than that by ANYONE. Just correct references to art, architecture, documents and secret rituals. But not the story.

Did the religious world go crazy when in Raiders of the lost Ark, Indy went in search of a TRUE religious relic the Ark of the Covenant, the treasure hunt which followed and the murder of the nasty Nazis at the end. The same holds for Indiana Jones and the last Crusade - the search for the Holy Grail no less - followed by treasure hunt and 800 year old templar nights protecting it - sounds kinda familiar huh? Joseph and his amazing technicoloured dream coat - based on a religious truth and turned into a musical - do i really think it happened that way - no, its a fictitious musical obviously still running in theatreland across the globe without religious protests to help market it. The Omen series was actually based on the BIBLE and other easily accessible religious documents and had more of a basis for being fact than most but no, its a made up story, a good yarn - we didn't need to be told then and we don't now. Devil's advocate, where Al baby screams that God is an absentee landlord etc etc - did I shake with religious fury, no no no - its made up you see.

I could go on as could you - the point is very clear. Come on church people, have a little faith in your world-wide flock - we know its just a story and it seems to be you who needs convincing otherwise. You have done far more to raise doubt over the truth we know and believe than Dan Brown ever could have. Have faith.

title: Why do some people hate this film?
review:
Why do some people hate this film? especially those who haven't seen it? Apparently it promotes Ideas that are 'rubbish' or 'nonsense'. Apparently it will cause the destruction of Christianity. You would have to be a pretty bad Christian if this is true.

People are not scared that the existence of God or Jesus is challenged by this film, just the way they believe in God or Jesus. Why is it so bad that Jesus may have had a wife or even children?. In what way does it make him less divine?

Ah there is the key question: 'In what way does it make him less divine?' Some people say this film is Blasphemous:

blasphemous - grossly irreverent toward what is held to be sacred

So what exactly is being held sacred? Jesus' Devinity? The belief he had no heirs? The belief that he had no wife? All of these are irrelevant to believing in God and in Jesus, Jesus still died to save the souls of sinners.

He is still believed to be the son of God. These are the core beliefs christians should concentrate on, these are the things that made him important in history.

Blind faith is not strong faith, its faith for the weak of mind, for those who have no imagination, for those who need to be told what to believe.

If this film causes you to question your beliefs, then your beliefs were not strong in the first place.

If you truly believe in Jesus and God, then this film should be no more than an entertaining yarn that holds an exciting suggestion.

Barthez

title: Wow!
review:
Fascinating mix of commonly accepted history, controversial history and fiction makes for an excellent story and fairly decent film. Ignore the reviews, ignore all the hype and go check this movie out.

Once you're done enjoying the film take the time to research which parts of the film were history, what might or might not be true and what is straight up fiction.

It's all very interesting and deals with material that has played a significant role in how Western civilization has developed over the past 1700 years.

That's all I have to say, however I'm required to submit 10 lines. :)

title: Endurable
review:
I sat though the film today.

The Davinci Code was endurable, but it failed on its promise. Like "the Shining" some films can never match the written word. This effort may be lacking in that same regard.

I certainly wouldn't, for even an instant, depreciate the abilities and talent of the actors. They were great. Their craft as presented was exemplary - the problem was,the film is a well done effort that will appeal to some, be boring to many, and repulsive to those of the religious bent.

My score, 6.5 out of 10 stars.

title: EXCELLENT then Good...
review:
It was a great film with a lot of potential but it just didn't deliver as expected. If you have read the book then you will appreciate the fantastic visual representations that you can associate with. This film is very fact based and close to the book but is COMPLETE FICTION and those who think otherwise deserve the confusion.

Nice film and very enjoyable. Good have done more but not the epic that was promised.

If you haven't read the book you will find it hard to get your head round this film and sometimes it is difficult to follow but it's a great film with lots of potential but just poorly written.

title: One of the Year's Best Films...
review: OK, I'm tired of hearing that this film was bad. I mean, remember, most of the reviews came from over there from the Cannes Film Festival. Most reviewers here found it entertaining, as did I was well. I thought Tom Hanks was the perfect choice for Robert Langdon, bringing him to life in a different, yet recognizable, sense than what we read in the book. The screenplay was very close to the book, which is what you find rare in Hollywood these days. Ron Howard did a wonderful job of directing this big, anticipated adaptation and I found myself more into it than most people. Now, I went to a midnight screening and, unlike the Cannes, the people applauded. I did as well. I would definitely go see this film and I wish people would stop complaining about the film's length. You wanted a true adaptation of the novel and now you've got it. So, yeah, I highly recommend this movie for serious film-goers. As for you negative types, go see "See No Evil". But do see "Over the Hedge". That film is almost as good as "The Da Vinci Code".

title: Genius!
review: First off, to all those there who have called the film boring or lacklustre. Were you expecting to see an all action movie, have you even read the book? This was never going to be a terminator, last action hero, or an Indiana Jones. NEVER! The book is a dark thriller based on the beliefs and foundations of the Roman Catholic Church. How many movies that are entitled thrillers do you know that could be called all action? Not many i am guessing. The Da Vinci Code on the big screen is monumental! It takes all the super aspects of the book - the twists, the darkness, the riddles and mysteries, and the murders - and portrays them almost exactly the way in which you imagine them as you read. There is a serious underlying tension in the film that keeps focus and concentration at their highest levels, because you realise that once you switch off, you may miss something, and due to the complexity of the plot, if you miss something, you will be confused for the rest of the time. Dark, gripping, tense, complex - not really a Friday night popcorn film, but a film that makes you think, REALLY makes you think! Superb for what it is.

title: Brown must have been quietly disappointed!
review:
I take my words back regarding my anticipation of wanting to see this movie. Just saw it today and there was a huge number of changes from the book. Can't say I wanna complain about the changes made but it's more of the continuity of the storyline.

For those who read the book, you might feel like the story was a bit "rushed" that Ron Howard and Akiva Goldsman tried to make a movie that practically stuffed the whole of the Dan Brown's book into a 2½ hour movie.

There were some parts that I felt that the film was a bit too draggy. But not as draggy or dry as the book. At least once you've done reading the "drier" part of the book, you'll be indulging in a refreshing treat of maybe a hint of clues to make you think. But the film version didn't really do that.

Plus, there are too many flashbacks into history. TRUE, while these flashbacks are critical in telling the story but they were rather too messed up.

***** SPOILERS STARTS HERE*****

Among the changes made were: 1 - Langdon was summoned at a book signing instead of from his hotel as written in the book; 2 - There was only one clue from the cryptex when there were in fact two as from the book; that is the first answer to the cryptex (SOFIA) was deleted; 3 - The identity of the "TEACHER" was revealed too soon.; Another point to take note was that Teabing's manservant, Remy, suddenly died without giving the audience any clue what he died from.

4 - The HIEROS GAMUS ritual was (I believe) almost deleted due to its sexual nature.

5 - As compared to the book, Sophie was reunited only with her grandmother but her brother was nowhere around; the young church caretaker might as well be her brother but even that info was not revealed.

***** SPOILERS ENDS HERE*****

I'm not suggesting that you totally ignore this film completely. By all means, go see it since it's a "much anticipated movie" of the year. This is only my personal opinion. Who knows maybe you might like it even more.
